Title: Genetics and Regulatory Impact of Alternative Polyadenylation in Human B-Lymphoblastoid Cells

    A recent study investigated the role of RNA 3′-end processing in regulating gene expression in human B-lymphoblastoid cells. The researchers conducted a genomic survey of transcript ends in lymphoblastoid cells from genetically distinct human individuals and found that transcript end positions did not occur randomly in untranslated regions. Instead, they preferentially flanked the locations of 3′ regulatory elements, including miRNA sites. The usage of these transcript length forms and motifs varied across human individuals, and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and other 3′ motifs were significant predictors of expression levels of the genes in which they lay.

    Independent single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyadenylation variants on steady-state expression of their respective genes, and validated the regulatory function of 3′ cis-regulatory sequence elements that mediated expression of these distinct RNA length forms. Focusing on the immune regulator IRF5, the researchers established the effect of natural variation in RNA 3′-end processing on regulatory response to antigen stimulation.

    The study highlights the importance of two mechanisms at play in the genetics of 3′-end variation: the usage of distinct 3′-end processing signals and the effects of 3′ sequence elements that determine transcript fate. The findings suggest that integrating observed 3′-end positions with inferred 3′ regulatory motifs will be a critical tool in interpreting human genome variation. The study also speculates that many genetic variants with biologically relevant effects mediated by RNA 3′-end processing remain to be discovered in the human population.
A live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) vaccine, SIVΔnef, has been shown to be highly effective in inducing protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. However, the mechanisms underlying its protective efficacy are not well understood. To investigate this, researchers used deep sequencing technology and comprehensive CD8 T cell epitope mapping to study the CD8 T cell response in SIVΔnef-vaccinated animals. The study found that the initial CD8 T cell response in the acute phase of SIVΔnef infection targets more variable epitopes, followed by widespread sequence evolution and viral escape. As a result, the CD8 T cell repertoire expands to target highly conserved epitopes, defined as anentropic specificity, and generates de novo responses to escaped epitope variants during the vaccination period. These findings correlate SIVΔnef-induced protection with expanded anentropic specificity and increased response depth. The study also demonstrated that epitope escape leads to the generation of de novo CD8 T cell responses against novel epitopes and escape variants during chronic infection, and that these responses are maintained as central memory CD8 T cells, contributing to the increased cumulative breadth of the CD8 T cell response. The results suggest that SIVΔnef is a proof-of-concept vaccine that highlights the importance of anentropic specificity and repertoire depth in successful vaccine design. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying the protective efficacy of SIVΔnef and has implications for the development of effective HIV/SIV vaccines.
Interleukin-1 receptor (IL-1R) signaling plays a crucial role in coordinating the neutrophil response to Candida albicans infections in the oral mucosa. Using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC), researchers found that IL-1R signaling is essential for fungal control at the onset of infection. The study demonstrated that IL-1R regulates the recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and the mobilization of newly generated neutrophils from the bone marrow. IL-1R-deficient mice displayed impaired chemokine production at the site of infection and defective secretion of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in the circulation in response to C. albicans. The study identified endothelial cells as the primary source of G-CSF during OPC, which responded to IL-1α released from keratinocytes in the infected tissue. The IL-1-dependent crosstalk between keratinocytes and endothelial cells was confirmed in vitro using a novel murine tongue-derived keratinocyte cell line and an established endothelial cell line. These findings establish a new link between IL-1 and granulopoiesis in the context of fungal infection. The study highlights the importance of IL-1R signaling in coordinating the neutrophil response in the oral mucosa, which is critical for preventing fungal growth and dissemination, and thus protects the host from disease.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals in 48 endemic countries through annual mass drug administration (MDA) of anti-filarial drugs. This effort resulted in significant economic benefits, with an estimated US$21.8 billion in direct economic benefits gained over the lifetime of 31.4 million individuals treated during the first 8 years of the GPELF. Of this total, US$2.3 billion is attributed to the protection of nearly 3 million newborns and other individuals from acquiring lymphatic filariasis as a result of being born into areas freed of LF transmission. Additionally, over 28 million individuals already infected with LF benefited from GPELF's halting the progression of their disease, resulting in an associated lifetime economic benefit of approximately US$19.5 billion. Furthermore, decreased patient services associated with reduced LF morbidity saved the health systems of endemic countries approximately US$2.2 billion. The economic rate of return of the GPELF is extremely high, with favorable program implementation costs largely due to sustained commitments of donated drugs from the pharmaceutical industry. The study highlights the significant economic benefits of MDA for LF, making it an excellent investment in global health.
A novel model of neuronopathic Gaucher disease (GD) has been established in medaka (Oryzias latipes) using a glucocerebrosidase (GBA) nonsense mutant (GBA-/-). This model displays pathological phenotypes similar to human neuronopathic GD, including infiltration of Gaucher cell-like cells into the brain, progressive neuronal loss, and microgliosis. Detailed pathological analysis revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. Notably, disruption of α-syn did not improve the life span, formation of axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in GBA-/- medaka. This study provides insights into the pathological mechanisms of α-syn accumulation caused by GCase deficiency and the minimal contribution of α-syn to the pathogenesis of neuronopathic GD. Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disease, caused by homozygous mutations in the GBA gene, leading to decreased enzymatic activity of glucocerebrosidase (GCase) and accumulation of its substrates. Mutations in GBA have also been linked to an increased risk of sporadic Parkinson's disease (PD), which is characterized by the accumulation of α-syn in Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites. The GBA-/- medaka model provides a valuable tool for investigating the relationship between GCase deficiency and α-syn accumulation, and may aid in the development of novel therapies for neuronopathic GD and PD.
Listeria monocytogenes, a facultative intracellular pathogen, induces a robust cell-mediated immune response to sub-lethal infection. The bacterium's ability to escape from the phagosome and enter the host cell cytosol is crucial for the induction of long-lived CD8 T cell–mediated protective immunity. However, research has shown that the impaired T cell response to L. monocytogenes confined within a phagosome is not solely due to inefficient antigen presentation, but rather the direct suppression of the adaptive response. This suppression not only limits the adaptive response to vacuole-confined L. monocytogenes but also negates the response to bacteria within the cytosol. Co-infection with phagosome-confined and cytosolic L. monocytogenes prevents the generation of acquired immunity and limits the expansion of antigen-specific T cells relative to the cytosolic L. monocytogenes strain alone. The presence of L. monocytogenes within a phagosome suppresses the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and leads to the rapid MyD88-dependent production of IL-10. Blockade of the IL-10 receptor or the absence of MyD88 during primary infection restores protective immunity. These findings demonstrate that the presence of microbes within a phagosome can directly impact the innate and adaptive immune response by antagonizing the signaling pathways necessary for inflammation and the generation of protective CD8 T cells.
Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is the most common subtype of glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness worldwide. Genome-wide association studies have previously identified a significant association between POAG and the SIX6 locus (rs10483727, odds ratio (OR) = 1.32, p = 3.87×10−11). The SIX6 gene plays a role in ocular development and has been associated with the morphology of the optic nerve. To further investigate the relationship between SIX6 and POAG, the authors sequenced the SIX6 coding and regulatory regions in 262 POAG cases and 256 controls. Six nonsynonymous coding variants were identified, including five rare and one common variant, Asn141His (rs33912345), which was significantly associated with POAG (OR = 1.27, p = 4.2×10−10) in the NEIGHBOR/GLAUGEN datasets. The variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish) complementation assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye size and optic nerve structure. The results showed that five variants, primarily found in POAG cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth variant, found only in controls, was benign. One variant in the SIX6 enhancer increased expression of SIX6 and disrupted its regulation. Furthermore, the authors identified a clinical feature in POAG patients that appears to be dependent on SIX6 genotype: patients homozygous for the SIX6 risk allele (His141) have a statistically thinner retinal nerve fiber layer than patients homozygous for the SIX6 non-risk allele (Asn141). The results suggest that SIX6 risk variants disrupt the development of the neural retina, leading to a reduced number of retinal ganglion cells, thereby increasing the risk of glaucoma-associated vision loss.
In the human intestinal pathogen Clostridium difficile, a genetic switch known as the flagellar switch controls the production of flagella and glucosylating toxins. The flagellar switch is a 154 bp invertible sequence located upstream of the flgB operon and is flanked by 21 bp inverted repeats. When the flagellar switch is in the ON orientation, bacteria express flagellum and toxin genes, produce flagella, and secrete the toxins. In contrast, when the switch is in the OFF orientation, bacteria are attenuated for flagellar and toxin gene expression, are aflagellate, and show decreased toxin secretion. The orientation of the flagellar switch is reversible during growth in vitro. Gene regulation via the flagellar switch occurs post-transcription initiation and requires a C. difficile-specific regulatory factor to destabilize or degrade the early flagellar gene mRNA when the flagellar switch is in the OFF orientation. The tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at the cwpV switch, is also responsible for inversion at the flagellar switch in both directions. The flagellar switch affects transcription of the toxin genes by way of σD, impacting the production of the glucosylating toxins and the cytotoxicity of C. difficile. Flagellar phase ON bacteria and recV mutants with the flagellar switch locked in the ON orientation display peritrichous flagella, engage in swimming motility, and produce the glucosylating toxins. In contrast, flagellar phase OFF bacteria and recV mutants with the flagellar switch locked in the OFF orientation are attenuated for transcription of flagellar genes and toxin production. The flagellar switch orientation controls toxin production in addition to flagellum biosynthesis and swimming motility, indicating that these major virulence factors are coordinately phase variable in C. difficile.
The study investigated the spore differentiation pathway in Clostridium difficile, an intestinal pathogen that relies on endospore formation for its infectious cycle. The researchers examined the function and regulation of the sporulation sigma factors (σF, σE, σG, and σK) in C. difficile, which are essential for controlling gene expression during endospore development. The results showed that while the main periods of activity of the sigma factors are conserved, there are significant deviations from the paradigm established in the model organism Bacillus subtilis. Specifically, the activity of σE is partially independent of σF, σG activity is not dependent on σE, and σK activity does not require σG. Furthermore, σK is not strictly required for heat-resistant spore formation. The study also found that the temporal segregation between the activities of the early and late sigma factors is reduced in C. difficile compared to B. subtilis. The results suggest that the top level of the endosporulation network is conserved in evolution, with the sigma factors acting as key regulators of the pathway. However, the study also highlights differences in the function and period of activity of the sporulation sigma factors in C. difficile compared to other Clostridial species, which may be related to the coordination of solventogenesis, toxin production, or other functions with sporulation.
The article presents a compact framework for modeling the dose response of allosteric multisite phosphorylation proteins using a single auxiliary variable. This reduction is shown to closely replicate the steady-state behavior of detailed multisite systems, such as the Monod-Wyman-Changeux allosteric model or rule-based models. The framework is useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems in practical applications, where several multisite proteins may interact simultaneously. Optimal ultrasensitivity is obtained when the activation of an allosteric protein by its individual sites is concerted and redundant. The framework is applied to a newly discovered checkpoint signaling pathway in budding yeast, which has been proposed to measure cell growth by monitoring signals generated at sites of plasma membrane growth. The known components of this pathway can form a robust hysteretic switch, incorporating a signal proportional to bud growth or size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-none response triggered only when the signal reaches a threshold indicating sufficient growth has occurred. The framework can also be extended to other types of multisite modification, such as ligand binding, multisite transcription factor regulation, and multisite methylation or acetylation.
The LsrR Quorum Sensing “Switch” Is Revealed by a Bottom-Up Approach
    The autoinducer-2 ( AI-2 ) quorum sensing system of E. coli was studied using a combination of experimental work and mathematical models to decipher network connectivity and signal transduction. The system was separated into sub-networks to examine negative and positive feedback mechanisms. A new unreported negative feedback interaction was hypothesized and tested via a simple mathematical model, revealing the importance of the LsrR regulator and its determinant role in the E. coli QS “switch”. The LsrR-mediated genetic “switch” of E. coli QS circuitry was found to be buried but still effective in the native system. The AI-2 uptake mechanism was taken apart and analyzed in isolation, leading to the speculation of new regulatory interactions within the network. A bottom-up approach was employed to analyze the natural biological network, isolating important regulatory elements and constructing a hypothetical model to predict the existence of new regulatory mechanisms. This approach allowed for the simulation of both the intact network and its sub-systems using the new proposed network architecture. The results provide a mechanistic understanding of the interplay among regulatory sub-structures and their contributions to the overall native functioning network. The study sheds light on other regulatory pathways within the metabolic networks of bacterial cells and may be used to guide phenotypes in new ways as the quorum sensing switches become incorporated into various biotechnological applications.
This study investigated the effect of schistosomiasis and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) on the prevalence and incidence of Plasmodium falciparum infection in school-age children living in rural areas of Gabon. The study found that schistosomiasis tends to increase the risk of Plasmodium infection, but a combined effect with Trichuris trichiura or hookworm infection significantly increases the risk. The incidence of malaria over time was higher in the Schistosoma-infected group compared to the non-infected group, with a significant delay of time-to-first-malaria event only in children aged 6-10 years old infected with Schistosoma haematobium. The results suggest that STH enhance the risk for P. falciparum infection in schistosomiasis-positive children, and that schistosomiasis enhances susceptibility to developing malaria in young children but not in older children. The study highlights the need to account for STH and schistosomiasis co-infections when designing malaria control programs in areas of co-endemicity. The findings support the consideration of STH and schistosomiasis control as an additional tool for malaria control. The study's longitudinal design allowed for a more precise examination of the interactions between schistosomiasis and malaria, providing evidence for the cumulative impact of these co-infections on malaria outcome in school-age children.
IRF-5-Mediated Inflammation Limits CD8+ T Cell Expansion by Inducing HIF-1α and Impairing Dendritic Cell Functions during Leishmania Infection

    IRF-5-dependent inflammation induced by Leishmania donovani infection inhibits CD8+ T cell expansion and the development of short-lived effector cells (SLECs) by inducing HIF-1α in dendritic cells and altering DC functions. IRF-5 is involved in the transcriptional activation of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-12, TNF, IL-23, and IL-6. IRF-5 is essential for the development of protective Th1 responses, and its ablation leads to a higher frequency of SLECs, enhanced CD8+ T cell expansion, and increased IL-12 expression by splenic DCs. Mice with targeted depletion of HIF-1α in CD11c+ cells had a significantly lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting that HIF-1α induction in DCs represents an immune-evasive mechanism adopted by Leishmania parasites to establish persistent infections. HIF-1α upregulation in DCs resulted in decreased IL-12 and increased IL-10 expression. Ablation of HIF-1α in CD11c+ cells led to a higher frequency of SLECs, enhanced CD8+ T cell expansion, and significantly reduced parasite burden. These findings indicate that IRF-5-mediated inflammation induced by Leishmania at early stages of infection plays a detrimental role in the development of protective CD8+ T cell responses.
A systematic review of 14 studies on American visceral leishmaniasis (VL) conducted in Latin America was conducted to identify prognostic factors associated with adverse outcomes and death. The review found that jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age less than 5 years, age greater than 40-50 years, severe neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections were the strongest predictors of unfavorable outcomes. Edema and low hemoglobin concentration were also associated with poor outcomes. The review highlights the need for the development of externally validated prognostic models to aid in the identification and management of patients at higher risk of adverse outcomes. The lack of reduction in fatality rates of VL in Brazil is attributed to limitations in therapy, delay in diagnosis, and inadequate management of high-risk patients. The review suggests that undernutrition is not a risk factor for severity or mortality in VL, but rather a consequence of the wasting syndrome associated with the disease. The findings of this review provide valuable information for clinical practice and highlight the need for further research to develop effective prognostic models. The review emphasizes the importance of prioritizing the development of externally validated prognostic models to improve patient outcomes in VL.
The study investigated the antimony susceptibility of Leishmania isolates collected over a 30-year period in Algeria. The researchers analyzed 106 isolates from humans, dogs, rodents, and phlebotomines collected between 1976 and 2013 in 14 localities where leishmaniasis is endemic, as well as 18 isolates from dogs in France. The 50% inhibitory concentrations ( IC50 ) of potassium antimony tartrate ( Sb ( III ) ) and sodium stibogluconate ( Sb ( V ) ) were determined in promastigotes and intramacrophage amastigotes, respectively. The epidemiological cutoff ( ECOFF ) values were established to differentiate between Leishmania species causing cutaneous or visceral leishmaniasis that were susceptible ( S+ ) or insusceptible ( S- ) to the trivalent form of antimony. The results showed a trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) isolates during the 30-year period. In contrast, an increase in the frequency of S- phenotypes in cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) isolates was observed during the same period. The emergence of S- phenotypes correlated with the inclusion of L. killicki ( syn: L. tropica ) isolates that cause cutaneous leishmaniasis and have emerged in Algeria during the last decade. The study highlights the need for an effective methodology to determine the antimony susceptibility status of Leishmania isolates to detect the emergence of and prevent the dissemination of drug-resistant strains. The results provide insight into the spatiotemporal dynamics of Leishmania antimony susceptibility in Algeria.
The study investigated the link between acute infectious gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn’s disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition. Researchers developed two novel models to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacter rodentium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIEC), a bacterial pathobiont linked to CD. The results showed that disease activity in the post-infectious period after gastroenteritis is driven by the tissue-associated expansion of the resident AIEC pathobiont, leading to an increase in immunopathology, barrier defects, and delays in mucosal restitution following pathogen clearance. The study found that AIEC-colonized mice that developed infectious gastroenteritis had a worsened outcome compared to AIEC-naive animals exposed to the same infection stimuli. The tissue-associated expansion of AIEC required resistance to host defense peptides and a fulminant inflammatory response to the enteric pathogen. The study suggests that individuals colonized by AIEC at the time of acute infectious gastroenteritis may be at greater risk for CD onset. Importantly, the data identify AIEC as a tractable disease modifier, which could be exploited in the development of therapeutic interventions following infectious gastroenteritis in at-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis consists of two gametic cells, the egg cell and the central cell, surrounded by five accessory cells. The mechanisms governing the formation of accessory versus gametic cell fate are unknown. A screen for regulators of egg cell fate identified the lachesis ( lis ) mutant, which forms supernumerary egg cells. In lis mutants, accessory cells differentiate gametic cell fate, indicating that LIS is involved in a mechanism that prevents accessory cells from adopting gametic cell fate. LIS is homologous to the yeast splicing factor PRP4, suggesting that components of the splice apparatus participate in cell fate decisions. The temporal and spatial pattern of LIS expression suggests that this mechanism is generated in gametic cells. The lis-1 mutant phenotype reveals two levels of cell fate regulation, one between gametic and accessory cells, and one between egg and central cell. The late initiation of cell-specific marker genes indicates that in Arabidopsis distinct cell fates are only manifested after cellularization. In lis-1 mutant gametophytes, accessory cells become gradually recruited as gametic cells, and several morphological features that distinguish lis-1/LIS plants from wild type become more pronounced over time. The lis-1 mutation was mapped to the At2g41500 locus, which encodes a protein with seven WD40 repeats. These findings suggest that all cells in the female gametophyte are competent to differentiate gametic cell fate and that LIS is involved in a mechanism that represses gametic cell fate in accessory cells.
In a rural highland Ethiopian community endemic for podoconiosis, a Neglected Tropical Disease (NTD) triggered by exposure to irritant soils, a qualitative study was conducted to explore the barriers related to the use of footwear. The study used the PRECEDE-PROCEED model to assess social, behavioral, environmental, educational, and ecological needs influencing whether and when children wear shoes. A total of 242 respondents participated in focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and extended case studies. The results showed that shoe-wearing norms are changing, with going barefoot increasingly seen as "shameful." However, many practical and social barriers prevented the desire to wear shoes from being translated into practice. Limited financial resources meant that people were unable to purchase more than one pair of shoes, ensuring their longevity, or afford shoes of the preferred quality. As a result, shoes were typically preserved for special occasions and might not be provided for children until they reached a certain age. The study identified several barriers to shoe wearing that are amenable to intervention, including financial constraints, poor suitability of shoes for daily activities, and low risk perception. These barriers are likely to be relevant to a range of NTDs. The findings suggest that targeting individuals' beliefs and attitudes about shoe wearing, as well as their perceived capabilities to prevent NTDs, is crucial for effective prevention through shoe distribution programs.
The pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us9 protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of dissociated sympathetic neurons. Us9 null mutants are defective in anterograde transmission of infection in vivo. To understand how Us9 promotes axonal sorting of viral proteins, researchers investigated the association of Us9 with lipid rafts. Lipid rafts are microdomains on the surface of infected cells that are involved in protein sorting and trafficking. The study found that Us9 is associated with lipid rafts and that this association is critical for Us9-mediated sorting of viral structural proteins. In non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a rat pheochromocytoma cell line that acquires characteristics of sympathetic neurons, Us9 is highly enriched in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Reducing the affinity of Us9 for lipid rafts inhibited anterograde transmission of infection from sympathetic neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. These findings suggest that association of Us9 with lipid rafts is key for efficient targeting of structural proteins to axons and directional spread of PRV from pre-synaptic to post-synaptic neurons and cells of the mammalian nervous system. The study demonstrates that Us9 is essential for the axonal sorting of viral capsids and glycoproteins, and that lipid rafts play a critical role in this process.
Genetically identical cells of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae exhibit phenotypic variation in growth rate and stress tolerance under constant and benign conditions, a phenomenon known as nongenetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity has important clinical implications, as it is observed in tumors and microbial infections. The study investigated the molecular mechanism underlying this heterogeneity and found that it is controlled by the cyclic AMP ( cAMP )-regulated transcription factors Msn2 and Msn4, acting through the conserved Ras/cAMP/protein kinase A ( PKA ) pathway. The study used genetic and chemical perturbations, combined with high-throughput single-cell assays of yeast growth and gene expression, to show that lower levels of cAMP correspond to slower growth and increased susceptibility to acute heat stress. The paralogs Msn2 and Msn4 were found to differ in their roles in nongenetic heterogeneity, with Msn2 being required for heterogeneity in expression of Tsl1, a subunit of trehalose synthase that contributes to acute-stress tolerance. Perturbations that increase intracellular cAMP levels reduced the slower-growing subpopulation and increased susceptibility to acute heat stress, while PKA inhibition slowed growth and decreased susceptibility to acute heat stress. The study suggests that the Ras/cAMP/PKA pathway, acting through Msn2 and Msn4, underlies nongenetic heterogeneity in yeast-cell growth and stress tolerance, and provides a possible means of defeating bet-hedging pathogens or tumor cells by making them more uniformly susceptible to treatment.
During the 2013-2014 outbreak of Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) in the Caribbean, a team of researchers conducted a whole-genome sequencing analysis to understand the genetic diversity of the virus in infected individuals. The study focused on samples from Guadeloupe and Martinique, two islands at the epicenter of the epidemic. Using deep-sequencing technologies and bioinformatics pipelines, the researchers identified changes in the consensus sequence and a diverse range of minority variants present in the population. Notably, they found that the overall diversity of the virus was significantly reduced after a single passage in cell lines. Furthermore, the team constructed an infectious clone from the outbreak and discovered a novel 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure, not previously found in nature, which led to increased replication in insect cells. This new UTR structure was unique among circulating CHIKV strains worldwide. The study also performed an intrahost quasispecies analysis, revealing novel variants present in infected individuals. The findings suggest that CHIKV has rapidly evolved in a short period of time since entering the naïve population in the Americas. The results highlight the importance of continued viral diversity surveillance over time to understand the evolutionary potential of CHIKV. The study provides an in-depth look at the minority variants present during the ongoing CHIKV epidemic, identifying novel variants and structural elements that can inform future research on the pathogenesis, adaptation, and evolution of CHIKV in the Americas.
The study identifies UBTOR, a previously unannotated gene, as a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling. UBTOR depletion in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells promotes neurite outgrowth and activates mTOR signaling, leading to increased cell growth. Conversely, UBTOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. Mechanistic studies reveal that UBTOR stabilizes DEPTOR, a component of the mTOR complex, to inhibit mTOR signaling. In zebrafish models, disruption of the ubtor gene upregulates mTOR signaling and promotes HRAS(G12V)-mediated tumor formation. Furthermore, UBTOR depletion promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in a xenograft mouse model. These findings demonstrate that UBTOR regulates cell growth and neoplasia via mTOR signaling. The study also shows that UBTOR interacts with DEPTOR and mTOR complexes, and that NGF treatment upregulates UBTOR expression, which may help to keep mTOR signaling activity in check. The results suggest that UBTOR plays a role in regulating cellular growth and neoplasia, and that its dysregulation may contribute to cancer development. Overall, the study highlights the importance of UBTOR in mTOR signaling and its potential as a therapeutic target for cancer treatment.
The study presents a comprehensive protein complex map of Trypanosoma brucei, a protozoan parasite responsible for human African trypanosomiasis. Using in-depth biochemical fractionation and a rigorous methodology, the researchers identified 128 high-confidence complexes encompassing 716 protein groups, including 635 previously uncharacterized proteins. These complexes correlate with known pathways and proteins co-expressed across the T. brucei life cycle, providing potential functions for a large number of uncharacterized proteins. The study also validated the functions of several novel proteins associated with the RNA-editing machinery, including a candidate involved in mitochondrial post-transcriptional regulation of T. brucei. The protein complex map is the largest proteomics-based interaction map of trypanosomatid parasites to date and serves as a reliable resource for further characterization of trypanosomatid proteins. The results provide an unprecedented view of the protein complex map of T. brucei and offer a useful resource for formulating new biological hypotheses and experimental leads. The study's findings are available at www. TrypsNetDB. org. The researchers used two complementary biochemical fractionation approaches to systematically study protein complexes in T. brucei, leading to the assignment of many previously uncharacterized proteins to complexes. The predicted essential complexes recapitulated previous findings for T. brucei, including the cytoplasmic ribosomal complex, proteasome, and T-complex, which are essential in all life stages of the parasite.
Lymph nodes (LNs) are a common site of extrapulmonary Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection, yet the dynamics of Mtb infection in LNs and its impact on LN structure and function are not well understood. This study investigated Mtb infection in thoracic LNs of cynomolgus and rhesus macaques using PET CT scans, bacterial burden, and immune function analysis. The results showed that LNs in Mtb-infected macaques exhibited increased metabolic activity early during infection, and at necropsy, almost all FDG-avid LNs contained viable Mtb or persistent Mtb DNA. The study found that Mtb grows to the same level in LNs of both macaque species, but cynomolgus macaque LNs were better able to control the infection compared to rhesus macaque LNs. In contrast to lung granulomas, LNs were found to be poor at killing Mtb, even with drug treatment. Granulomas that form in LNs disrupt LN structure, pushing out T cells and B cells, introducing large numbers of macrophages that can serve as niches for Mtb, and destroying normal vasculature. The data suggest that LNs are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation during infection but also serve as important sites for the persistence of significant numbers of Mtb bacilli. The study highlights the dynamic process of mycobacterial involvement in thoracic LNs and the need for further investigation into the role of LNs in Mtb infection.
A large collection of 47 nematode-infecting microsporidia has been isolated and cultured from wild nematodes, including Caenorhabditis elegans and other related species. The most common microsporidia infecting C. elegans in the wild is Nematocida parisii, which was previously identified as the first natural intracellular pathogen of C. elegans. In addition to N. parisii, six new species in the Nematocida genus have been described, as well as two new subclades, Enteropsectra and Pancytospora, which are genetically distinct from Nematocida and belong to the main clade of microsporidia that includes human pathogens. These microsporidia are horizontally transmitted and primarily infect intestinal cells, except for Pancytospora epiphaga, which replicates in the epidermis of its Caenorhabditis host. At the subcellular level, spores of Enteropsectra exhibit a characteristic apical distribution and exit via budding off the plasma membrane, whereas spores of Nematocida exit via exocytosis. The host specificity of these microsporidia varies, with some species infecting multiple nematode species while others exhibit narrow host specificity. Furthermore, the microsporidian N. ausubeli fails to induce the transcription of genes in C. elegans that are induced by other Nematocida species, suggesting it has evolved mechanisms to prevent host response. This collection of microsporidia provides a rich resource for investigating host-parasite coevolution in tractable nematode hosts and highlights the diversity and ubiquity of microsporidian infections in nematodes.
Chemokine receptors, a subclass of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), play crucial roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis and HIV infection. Recent studies have shown that homo- and heterodimers or higher-order oligomers of chemokine receptors modulate receptor function. However, structural information about homo- and heterodimers formed by chemokine receptors and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. This study used molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the spontaneous homo- and heterodimerization of chemokine receptors CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2. The results reveal that the closely related CC chemokine receptors CCR5 and CCR2 share common features with regard to dimerization and interactions with cholesterol that differ from CXCR4. Cholesterol was found to modulate the CC homodimer interfaces in a subtype-specific manner. Chemokine receptor heterodimers display distinct dimerization patterns for CXCR4/CCR5 and CXCR4/CCR2. Furthermore, associations between CXCR4 and CCR5 reveal an increased cholesterol-sensitivity compared to CXCR4/CCR2 heterodimerization patterns. The study provides a comprehensive structural overview of the complex interaction network between chemokine receptors and indicates how heterodimerization and interaction with the membrane environment diversifies the function of closely related GPCRs. The findings suggest that cholesterol can increase the dynamic range and versatility of associations of closely related transmembrane receptors.
Systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, has been traditionally characterized by symptoms such as prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting. However, a sub-clinical form of the disease has been identified, presenting with one or two of these symptoms missing, and other findings such as lymphadenopathy and anemia. A third, unsuspected form of the disease, referred to as "atypical" systemic leishmaniasis, has been discovered. This form presents with symptoms masquerading as a condition of non-functional immune system, leading to recurrent secondary infections and a variety of clinical signs and symptoms. The atypical form was identified in 19.4% of 160 patients with suspected immune deficiency, who underwent specialized laboratory tests, including microscopic examinations and cultures of biopsies. These patients had close to normal laboratory profiles, but exhibited dysfunctional macrophages laden with Leishmania parasites. The findings suggest that systemic leishmaniasis has a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously suspected and is more common than diagnosed to date. The disease is not limited to the pediatric age group, as adults were also affected. The authors recommend considering atypical systemic leishmaniasis in patients with unexplained depressed immunity and no obvious immunologic defect. The discovery of this new form of the disease highlights the need for a more comprehensive approach to diagnosing and treating systemic leishmaniasis.
Genome-Wide Analysis of Human Disease Alleles Reveals That Their Locations Are Correlated in Paralogous Proteins
    A genome-wide analysis of human disease alleles was conducted to investigate the potential of variants occurring at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins as a means of identifying polymorphisms with likely phenotypic consequences. A collection of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and HGMD was assembled and used to identify and characterize pairs of sequence variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins. The results demonstrate that the locations of variants are correlated in paralogous proteins, and if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. This suggests that information about variant-pairs can be used to identify potentially disease-causing variants, extend existing procedures for polymorphism prioritization, and provide a suite of candidates for further diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. The study also found that sequence variants co-occur at aligned amino acid pairs more frequently than expected by chance, indicating that similar functional constraints on paralogous protein sequences result in coordinated distributions of both disease and non-disease-causing variants along their lengths. These findings provide a novel resource for functional genomics and suggest that paralogous human genes can be used to identify new disease gene candidates and uncharacterized variants within them likely to have phenotypic consequences.
The study analyzed the transcriptomes of 44 Plasmodium falciparum isolates that caused severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papuan patients using RNA sequencing (RNAseq). The results showed that parasites causing severe malaria had altered gene expression profiles compared to those causing uncomplicated malaria. Specifically, severe malaria parasites had decreased glycolysis without activation of compensatory pathways, altered chromatin structure, and reduced surface expression of PfEMP1, a major target of protective immunity. Additionally, multiple chaperone proteins were down-regulated in severe malaria parasites. The study also identified novel associations between disease severity and PfEMP1 transcripts, domains, and smaller sequence segments, and confirmed previously reported associations between expressed PfEMP1 sequences and severe disease. Notably, the severe malaria parasites had down-regulated genes involved in PfEMP1 surface expression, which may explain why immunity to severe malaria is acquired more rapidly than immunity to uncomplicated malaria. The findings suggest that parasites adapt to or are selected by the host environment in severe malaria, and may inform efforts to identify vaccine targets for severe malaria. Overall, the study provides new insights into the Plasmodium falciparum transcriptome in severe malaria and highlights the complex interactions between the parasite and the host environment.
Title: AAV-Delivered Antibody Mediates Significant Protective Effects against SIVmac239 Challenge in the Absence of Neutralizing Activity

    AAV vectors were used to deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) in IgG1 form to rhesus monkeys, achieving persisting levels of delivered mAb as high as 270 μg/ml. However, host antibody responses to the delivered antibody were observed in 9 of the 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration of delivered antibody that could be achieved. Despite the absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the challenge virus, the six monkeys in the AAV-5L7 IgG1 mAb group showed clear protective effects following repeated, marginal dose, intravenous challenge with the difficult-to-neutralize SIVmac239. These effects included lowering of viral load at peak height, lowering of viral load at set point, and delay in the time to peak viral load from the time of infectious virus exposure. All of these effects were statistically significant. Notably, the monkey with the highest level of delivered 5L7 mAb completely resisted six successive SIVmac239 i.v. challenges, including a final challenge with a dose of 10 i.v. infectious units. These results demonstrate the continued promise of this approach for the prevention of HIV-1 infection in people. However, the problem of anti-antibody responses will need to be understood and overcome for the promise of this approach to be effectively realized.
The article presents a numerical investigation of conformational relaxation properties in two motor proteins, myosin V and kinesin KIF1A, using the coarse-grained elastic network approximation. The study challenges the assumption of linear response of protein molecules to thermal noise or structural perturbations, which is commonly used in protein dynamics studies. The authors found that the linearity assumption is deficient for ligand-induced conformational motions and can be violated for characteristic thermal fluctuations. Specifically, the normal mode description fails to accurately describe functional mechanochemical motions in KIF1A, a monomeric motor protein from the kinesin superfamily. While slow conformational relaxation motions in myosin V can still be qualitatively characterized in terms of normal modes, the normal mode description breaks down completely for KIF1A. However, the study reveals that ordered and robust mechanochemical motions are characteristic for both protein motors, even though they cannot be described in terms of linear response. The results indicate that important assumptions of the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered, as neither a single normal mode nor a superposition of such modes yields an approximation of strongly nonlinear dynamics. The study provides new insights into the conformational relaxation processes associated with ligand binding and hydrolysis in motor proteins, highlighting the need for a more nuanced understanding of protein dynamics.
This study investigated the molecular mechanisms and functional relevance of crosstalk between different clathrin-independent endocytic pathways. The researchers found that specific caveolar proteins, including Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, act as negative regulators of the clathrin-independent carriers/GPI-AP enriched early endosomal compartment (CLIC/GEEC) endocytic pathway. Cavin-1 and Cavin-3 inhibited the CLIC/GEEC pathway in a process independent of caveola formation. Caveolin-1 (CAV1) and CAV3 also inhibited the CLIC/GEEC pathway upon over-expression. The expression of caveolar proteins led to a reduction in the formation of early CLIC/GEEC carriers, as detected by quantitative electron microscopy analysis. Furthermore, the CLIC/GEEC pathway was upregulated in cells lacking CAV1/Cavin-1 or with reduced expression of Cavin-1 and Cavin-3. The inhibition by caveolins could be mimicked by the isolated caveolin scaffolding domain and was associated with perturbed diffusion of lipid microdomain components, as revealed by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) studies. In the absence of cavins, CAV1 was itself endocytosed preferentially through the CLIC/GEEC pathway, but the pathway lost polarization and sorting attributes with consequences for membrane dynamics and endocytic polarization in migrating cells and adult muscle tissue. Noncaveolar Cavin-1 was found to act as a modulator for the activity of the key regulator of the CLIC/GEEC pathway, Cdc42. The study provides new insights into the regulation of noncaveolar clathrin-independent endocytosis by specific caveolar proteins, illustrating multiple levels of crosstalk between these pathways.
The Aspartate-Less Receiver (ALR) domains are a subclass of atypical Receiver (REC) domains that lack the conserved aspartate (Asp) residue typically phosphorylated by sensory histidine kinases in two-component signaling systems. A comprehensive analysis of deposited REC domains revealed that ALRs are surprisingly common, comprising approximately 4% of all REC domains, or about 2 per completed genome in bacteria. These domains are enriched when attached to rare effector outputs and have reorganized their active pockets to take on a constitutive regulatory role or accommodate input signals other than Asp phosphorylation. The ALR archetype, RitR from Streptococcus pneumoniae, has been structurally, biochemically, and genetically characterized, showing that ALRs largely retain the canonical post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimeric interface. The conserved phospho-Asp site in ALRs is often substituted with residues such as Ser, Thr, Tyr, Arg, and Cys, which can be phosphorylated by bacterial Ser-Thr kinases, Tyr kinases, or arginine-specific kinases. These substitutions suggest that ALRs have diversified to accommodate various signaling inputs, including binding small molecules and Ser-Thr phosphorylation through bacterial eukaryotic-like Ser-Thr kinases and their cognate PP2C phosphatases. The identification of ALRs as an atypical REC subclass provides insights into shared mechanisms of activation between ALR and REC domains and highlights the complexity and diversity of two-component signaling systems in bacteria, Archaea, and plants.
Oncolytic herpes simplex viruses (oHSVs) have shown efficacy in clinical trials and practice, but most are attenuated or over-attenuated due to deletions or mutations in genes that counteract the host response. To address this limitation, a new generation of oHSVs has been developed that carry no deletions or mutations and gain cancer-specificity through specific retargeting to tumor cell receptors, such as HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2). These fully-virulent oHSVs replicate efficiently in tumor cells while sparing other cells in the tumor. This study reports on the first efficacy study of a HER2-retargeted, fully-virulent oHSV armed with IL-12 (R-115) in immunocompetent mice. The results show that both the unarmed R-LM113 and the IL-12-armed R-115 inhibited the growth of the primary HER2-Lewis lung carcinoma-1 (HER2-LLC1) tumor, with R-115 being more efficacious. Notably, mice that survived the primary treated tumor were protected from the growth of contralateral untreated tumors, indicating an abscopal immunotherapeutic effect. Analysis of the local response revealed that R-115 unleashed the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, inducing immunomodulatory cytokines, including IFNγ and T-bet, which promoted Th1 polarization. The study highlights the potential of fully-virulent, retargeted oHSVs as a novel approach to cancer therapy, eliciting local immunity and vaccine therapy towards distant tumors.
A recent study investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. The study compared the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by adenovirus 5 (Ad5) and canarypox viral vector (ALVAC) to HIV. The results showed that Ad5-specific CD4 T cells were readily susceptible to HIV, whereas ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells were substantially less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV in vitro. The lower HIV susceptibility of ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells was associated with reduced surface expression of HIV entry co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on these cells. Phenotypic analyses revealed that ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells displayed a strong Th1 phenotype, producing higher levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 (MIP-β) but little IL-17. The study also found that ALVAC and Ad5 vectors induced distinct profiles of vector-specific CD8 vs. CD4 T-cell proliferative responses in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC). Depletion of ALVAC-induced CD8 T cells in PBMC led to a modest increase in HIV infection of vector-specific CD4 T cells, suggesting a role of ALVAC-specific CD8 T cells in protecting ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells from HIV. These findings highlight the importance of evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination and suggest that the choice of vaccine vector may impact the susceptibility of CD4 T cells to HIV infection.
The article presents a theoretical population genetic analysis of X inactivation evolution in therian mammals. X inactivation is the process by which females transcriptionally silence one of their two X chromosomes in each somatic cell. The study examines how conditions of dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection influence the evolution of X inactivation strategies, which can range from strict paternally inherited X inactivation ( PXI ) to unbiased random X inactivation ( RXI ). The results indicate that a single interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential selection can select for a broad range of X inactivation strategies, including unequal rates of inactivation between maternally and paternally inherited X chromosomes. RXI is favored over PXI when alleles deleterious to female fitness are sufficiently recessive, and the criteria for RXI evolution are more restrictive when fitness variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolutionary transitions from PXI to RXI generally increase mean relative female fitness at the expense of decreased male fitness. The study also predicts that species-specific properties of mutation and genetic variation can affect patterns of selection for different X inactivation strategies, and that sex-differential selection can influence the relative transmission probabilities of female-deleterious alleles between maternally and paternally derived X chromosomes. The results provide a theoretical framework for predicting and interpreting the evolution of chromosome-wide expression of X-linked genes.
The study investigated the antiviral potential of human zinc-finger antiviral protein (ZAP) against three flaviviruses: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV). The results showed that overexpression of ZAP inhibited JEV infection, while depletion of endogenous ZAP enhanced JEV replication. In contrast, DENV and ZIKV were not affected by ZAP overexpression. ZAP hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3'-5' RNA exosome-mediated degradation. The zinc-finger motifs of ZAP were essential for RNA targeting and anti-JEV activity. JEV 3'-UTR, particularly in the region with dumbbell structures and high content of CG dinucleotide, was mapped to bind ZAP and confer sensitivity to ZAP. The study identified JEV as the first ZAP-sensitive flavivirus and suggested that ZAP may act as an intrinsic antiviral factor through specific RNA binding to fight against JEV infection. The data also indicated that 3'-5' RNA degradation by the exosome complex is involved in the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against JEV infection. Furthermore, the study found that ZAP overexpression boosted innate immune responses during JEV infection, as measured by increased mRNA levels of type I IFN and proinflammatory cytokines.
The study investigated the pathogenesis of Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) infection in C57BL/6 mice using wild-type strain ZH501 and attenuated vaccine strain MP-12. The results showed that mice infected with live-attenuated MP-12 survived productive viral infection with minimal clinical disease and cytokine response. In contrast, ZH501 infection was lethal, causing lymphopenia, platelet depletion, and a strong systemic cytokine response, which correlated with high virus titers and significant tissue pathology. The study found that RVFV is hepatotropic, with significant clinical and histological data supporting liver involvement. However, a pro-inflammatory response in the liver was not apparent, instead, a chemokine response indicating infiltration of immunoreactive cells, such as neutrophils, was observed. In the brains of ZH501-infected mice, a significant chemokine and pro-inflammatory cytokine response was evident, but with little pathology indicating meningoencephalitis. The data suggest that RVFV pathogenesis in mice is associated with liver function loss due to liver necrosis and hepatitis, while the long-term course of disease for those that survive the initial hepatitis is neurologic in nature. The study highlights the differences in host response to infection with wild-type and attenuated RVFV strains, providing insights into the mechanisms of RVFV pathogenesis. The findings have implications for the development of effective vaccines and treatments for RVFV infection.
Chemotherapy-induced C-C motif chemokine ligand 20 (CCL20) promotes chemoresistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) by enhancing the self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) and increasing the expression of ATP-binding cassette subfamily B member 1 (ABCB1), leading to the extracellular efflux of taxane. CCL20 activates the p65 nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) pathway through protein kinase Cζ (PKCζ) or p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) activity, which in turn promotes the expression of ABCB1 and CCL20, creating a positive feedback loop that enhances chemoresistance. This feedback loop is mediated by the activation of p65 NF-κB, which regulates the transcription of both ABCB1 and CCL20. As a result, CCL20 promotes the proliferation, invasion, and anchorage-independent growth of TNBC cells and enhances their resistance to taxane. Furthermore, CCL20 also exhibits strengthening in resistance to taxane, demonstrating its pivotal role in the regulation of breast cancer malignancy. The study suggests that CCL20 can be a novel predictive marker for taxane response, and the blockade of CCL20 or its downstream pathway may reverse taxane resistance in breast cancer patients. The combination of taxane treatment and the adjuvant pharmacological inhibition of ABCB1 may greatly improve the chemotherapeutic efficacy in breast cancer, including TNBC.
Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that can infect virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. The parasite’s ability to infect and manipulate its host is dependent on its ability to transport proteins called GRAs across the parasitophorous vacuole membrane ( PVM ) into the host cell. GRAs have diverse roles in Toxoplasma’s intracellular lifecycle, including co-opting host cell functions and proteins. However, the translocation process and its machinery are not well understood. A previous study identified a protein called TgMYR1 as essential for GRA transport into the host cell. To identify additional proteins necessary for effector transport, researchers screened Toxoplasma mutants defective in c-Myc up-regulation for their ability to export GRA16 and GRA24 to the host cell nucleus. The study found that novel proteins MYR2 and MYR3 play a crucial role in translocation of a subset of GRAs into the host cell. MYR2 and MYR3 are secreted into the PV space and co-localize with PV membranes and MYR1. The proteins are membrane-associated and MYR3 stably associates with MYR1, whose N- and C-terminal fragments are disulfide-linked. The study also found that fusing intrinsically disordered effectors to a structured DHFR domain blocks the transport of other effectors, consistent with a translocon-based model of effector transport. Overall, these results reveal a novel complex at the PVM that is essential for effector translocation into the host cell.
The E2 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) and bovine papillomavirus (BPV-1) binds to the origin recognition complex 2 (ORC2), a component of the pre-replication complex (pre-RC). However, ORC2 is not detected at the viral origin of replication. Depletion of ORC2 enhances viral replication in a transient replication model and in keratinocytes stably maintaining viral episomes, but has no effect on copy number in a cell line with integrated HPV genomes. In contrast, over-expression of HPV E2 decreases ORC2 occupation at two known mammalian origins of replication, suggesting that E2 restricts pre-ORC assembly that could otherwise compete for host replication complexes necessary for viral genome amplification. These findings imply that the ORC2 complex with E2 restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase of the viral replication program and that elevated levels of E2 that occur during the differentiation-dependent amplification stage subvert ORC loading and hence DNA synthesis at cellular origins. ORC2 co-immunoprecipitates with BPV-1 and HPV-31 E2, and its depletion increases viral copy number in transient replication assays and in keratinocytes that maintain episomal HPV-16 genomes. Repeated chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays failed to detect endogenous ORC2 near the HPV-16 or HPV-31 long control region (LCR), while ORC2 was detectable near the mammalian origin of replication present within the GM-CSF gene.
This study investigated the presence of Brucella DNA in bovine milk in the urban and peri-urban area of Dushanbe, Tajikistan. A total of 564 cow milk samples were collected from 326 herds in 21 villages, and DNA was detected in 10.3% of the samples using IS711-based real-time PCR. Brucella DNA was found in the milk of all seropositive cows, but also in 8.3% of seronegative cows. Sequence analysis of the rpoB gene suggested that one cow was infected with B. abortus and another cow was most likely infected with B. melitensis. The study highlights the need for implementing complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false serological negative individuals in Brucella surveillance, control, and eradication programs. The results also suggest that vaccination of cattle with S19, in addition to vaccination of small ruminants with Rev 1, might be necessary to control Brucella infections in the livestock population. However, further research is required to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the Brucella spp. circulating among the livestock in this region. The study's findings are concerning, given that consumption of unpasteurized dairy products is common in the region.
The study investigated the role of histone H3 lysine 27 methylation (H3K27me3) and H3 lysine 9 methylation (H3K9me3) in maintaining genome stability in the pathogenic fungus Zymoseptoria tritici. Z. tritici has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable during meiosis and mitosis, transcriptionally repressed, and enriched with heterochromatic histone methylation marks, including H3K9me3 and H3K27me3. The researchers deleted the genes encoding the methyltransferases responsible for H3K9me3 and H3K27me3, kmt1 and kmt6, respectively, and generated a double mutant. They used whole-genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure, and differences in gene expression between mutant and wild-type strains. The results showed that loss of H3K9me3 led to dramatic chromatin reorganization, with H3K27me3 being relocalized to regions enriched with H3K9me3 in wild-type strains. Many genome rearrangements and formation of new chromosomes were found in the absence of H3K9me3, accompanied by activation of transposable elements. In contrast, loss of H3K27me3 increased the stability of accessory chromosomes under normal growth conditions in vitro, without large-scale changes in gene activity. The study concludes that H3K9me3 is essential for maintaining genome stability by preventing H3K27me3 in regions considered constitutive heterochromatin. The findings suggest that H3K27me3 reduces the overall stability of accessory chromosomes, generating a "metastable" state for these quasi-essential regions of the genome.
Title: Evaluation of Cost-Effective Strategies for Rabies Post-Exposure Vaccination in Low-Income Countries

Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is crucial in preventing rabies, a fatal disease. However, life-saving vaccines and biologicals are often inaccessible and unaffordable, particularly for the poorest populations who bear the largest burden of rabies. To address this issue, researchers analyzed different PEP vaccination regimens and evaluated their relative costs and benefits. The study found that PEP vaccination is an extremely cost-effective intervention, with a cost ranging from $200 to less than $60 per death averted. Switching from intramuscular (IM) to intradermal (ID) administration of PEP was shown to result in significant savings in vaccine volume and costs, which could mitigate vaccine shortages and reduce costs for healthcare providers. The study also identified financing mechanisms that could make PEP more affordable and accessible, including subsidies for those in need and support for rabies control and prevention programs. The results suggest that a universal switch to ID delivery would improve the affordability and accessibility of PEP for bite victims, leading to a likely reduction in human rabies deaths and cost savings for healthcare providers. The study demonstrates that ID delivery of PEP is considerably more cost-effective than IM delivery in terms of averting rabies cases and saving lives.
Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, exploits host lipid droplets (LD) as a source of lipids for its intracellular development. The parasite replicates within a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. The study found that Toxoplasma replication is reduced in host cells depleted of LD or impaired in triacylglycerol (TAG) lipolysis or fatty acid catabolism. In infected cells, the number of host LD and the expression of host LD-associated genes increase until the onset of parasite replication. Toxoplasma accesses lipids stored in host LD and incorporates them into its own membranes and LD. Exogenous addition of oleic acid stimulates LD biogenesis in the host cell, resulting in the overaccumulation of neutral lipids in very large LD inside the parasite. Toxoplasma intercepts and internalizes host LD within the PV, some of which remain associated with Rab7 and become wrapped by an intravacuolar network of membranes (IVN). Mutant parasites impaired in IVN formation display diminished capacity for lipid uptake from host LD. Additionally, parasites lacking an IVN-localized phospholipase A2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from host LD in the PV. Gavage of parasites with lipids reveals the presence of endocytic-like structures containing lipidic material originating from the PV lumen. These findings highlight the reliance of Toxoplasma on host LD for its intracellular development and its capability to scavenge neutral lipids from host LD.
Biomedical researchers have identified chalcones as potential inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cathepsin L, a key enzyme involved in the parasite's life cycle. Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke that causes fasciolosis, a widespread disease in cattle and sheep, and is increasingly recognized as an emerging zoonotic disease in humans. Current chemotherapy relies on triclabendazole, but resistance to this drug has been reported in several countries, highlighting the need for new control measures. A library of 40 flavonoid derivatives was screened for inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cysteine proteases (FhCL3 and FhCL1), and chalcones with phenyl and naphthyl groups emerged as effective inhibitors. One compound, C34, was found to bind tightly to juvenile-specific FhCL3 with an IC50 of 5.6 μM. C34 was shown to be a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with the Cys-His catalytic dyad and key S2 and S3 pocket residues, determinants of the substrate specificity of this family of cysteine proteases. In vitro studies demonstrated that C34 reduces the ability of the parasite to migrate through the gut wall and induces a loss of motility phenotype, leading to parasite death within a week. Notably, C34 is not cytotoxic to bovine cells. This study identifies chalcones as novel inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cathepsins and opens new avenues for the development of novel agents to control fluke infection and potentially other helminthic diseases.
The visual system transmits information about fast and slow changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways, with bipolar cells (BCs) playing a crucial role in transmitting these signals to the inner retina. Using in vivo imaging, researchers investigated how BCs transmit signals to the inner retina and found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filters. Individual cells transmit through multiple terminals varying in size, with smaller terminals generating faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher initial gain, followed by more profound adaptation. Smaller terminals transmitted higher stimulus frequencies more effectively. Modeling global calcium dynamics triggering vesicle release indicated that variations in the volume of presynaptic compartments directly contribute to differences in response dynamics. Voltage-dependent calcium channels in the synaptic terminal of BCs are responsible for the first major non-linear transformation of the visual signal as it is transmitted through the retina. The output from the synapse is impacted by variations in filtering of the presynaptic calcium signal, with smaller terminals responding to a step of light with higher relative release rates. The synaptic terminal of BCs exhibits strong rectification, with an increase in stimulus variance causing an increase in the mean rate of vesicle release even when the mean luminance is held constant. A model predicted that the rate of vesicle release would depress more profoundly in smaller terminals.
A novel probabilistic method for detecting synapses from multiplex fluorescence microscopy (muxFM) image data has been developed and tested using conjugate array tomography (cAT) datasets that provide voxel-conjugate fluorescence microscopy and electron microscopy (EM) images of the same individual synapses. The method uses a probabilistic model-based synapse detector that accepts molecular-morphological synapse models as user queries and delivers a volumetric map of the probability that each voxel represents part of a synapse. The algorithm was evaluated by comparing its performance to EM gold standard annotated data and by examining its ability to reproduce known features of cortical synapse distributions. The results show that the algorithm detects synapses from muxFM data alone as successfully as human annotators seeing only the muxFM data, and accurately reproduces known architectural features of cortical synapse distributions. This approach opens the door to data-driven discovery of new synapse types and their density. The probabilistic synapse detector may also be useful for analysis of standard confocal and super-resolution FM images, where EM cross-validation is not practical. The method addresses the challenges of detecting synapses in immunofluorescence images and has potential applications in large-scale synapse detection and single-synapse molecular profiling of diverse synapse populations. The algorithm may also be useful for analyzing volume images large enough to contain complete neural arbors, allowing discernment of the relationships between detected synapses and their presynaptic and postsynaptic parent neurons.
Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in various cellular processes, including nucleic acid metabolism, gene expression, signal transduction, and immune and nervous system functions. Impairment of zinc homeostasis can lead to various human pathologies. Mammalian zinc transport is mediated by two transporter families, ZnT and ZIP, with ZnT2 being responsible for vesicular zinc accumulation and secretion into breast milk during lactation. However, the detailed mechanism of action of ZnT2 is currently unknown. This study aimed to elucidate the mechanism of action of ZnT2 and investigate its coupling to the proton gradient in acidic vesicles. Using computational modeling and experimental approaches, including functional zinc transport assays, the authors demonstrated that ZnT2 is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter. Bafilomycin A1, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar-type proton ATPase, abolished ZnT2-dependent zinc transport into intracellular vesicles. Additionally, the authors showed that ZnT2 overexpression in intracellular vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc resulted in vesicular pH alkalization, which was reversed in the presence of TPEN, a specific zinc chelator. Computational energy calculations suggested that ZnT2 functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry of 2H+/Zn2+ ions. Therefore, ZnT2 is a proton motive force-driven, electroneutral vesicular zinc exchanger that concentrates zinc in acidic vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to the cytoplasm. This study provides new insights into the mechanism of action of ZnT2 and its role in zinc homeostasis.
This study identifies 14-3-3 proteins as novel interaction partners of Exonuclease 1 (Exo1) in both yeast and mammalian cells. Exo1 is responsible for processing stalled replication forks in checkpoint-defective yeast cells. The research reveals that 14-3-3 proteins regulate the phosphorylation status of Exo1 and other unknown targets, promoting fork progression, stability, and restart in response to DNA replication stress. In yeast 14-3-3 deficient cells, Exo1-dependent single-stranded DNA gaps accumulate at stalled forks, leading to persistent checkpoint activation and exacerbated recovery defects. Furthermore, the study shows that 14-3-3 proteins facilitate fork progression under limiting nucleotide concentrations using DNA bi-dimensional electrophoresis. The findings suggest that 14-3-3 proteins act as central integrators of signals that regulate fork stability and processing. The study proposes that 14-3-3 proteins modulate Exo1 phosphorylation and activity to prevent unscheduled Exo1 activity behind stalled replication forks in a checkpoint-proficient background. The research also implies that 14-3-3 proteins may regulate additional targets during replication stress, possibly through modulation of their phosphorylation. Overall, the study provides new insights into the role of 14-3-3 proteins in maintaining genome stability during DNA replication stress.
Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) play a complex role in human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infection and pathogenesis. In humanized mice, HIV-1 infection leads to persistent infection and immunopathogenesis, characterized by type I interferon (IFN-I) induction, immune activation, and depletion of human leukocytes, including CD4 T cells. To investigate the role of pDC in HIV-1 infection, a monoclonal antibody was developed to specifically deplete pDC in humanized mice. Depletion of pDC prior to HIV-1 infection abolished the induction of IFN-I and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) during acute HIV-1 infection, resulting in increased HIV-1 replication. However, pDC depletion also reduced cell death induced by the highly pathogenic HIV-1 isolate. During chronic HIV-1 infection, pDC depletion reduced IFN-I and ISG induction, associated with elevated HIV-1 replication. Notably, HIV-1-induced depletion of human immune cells, including T cells, was reduced in pDC-depleted mice, despite increased viral replication. These findings suggest that pDC play opposing roles in suppressing HIV-1 replication and promoting HIV-1-induced immunopathogenesis. The results also indicate that pDC depletion and IFN-I blockade may provide novel strategies for treating HIV-1 immune non-responsive patients with persistent immune activation despite effective antiretrovirus treatment.
Sulforaphane (SFN), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, has been shown to inhibit HIV infection in primary macrophages through the activation of nuclear erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2). Nrf2 is a transcription regulator that controls the expression of anti-oxidant genes. SFN mobilizes Nrf2 to reprogram cellular gene expression, leading to a block in HIV infection after reverse transcription but before the formation of 2-LTR circles. This restriction is mediated by Nrf2, as siRNA-mediated depletion of Nrf2 increased HIV infectivity in primary macrophages and reduced the anti-viral effects of SFN treatment. The study found that macrophages express sufficient Nrf2 to maintain a partial restriction on HIV infection even in the absence of SFN. In contrast, SFN did not inhibit HIV infection in primary T cells or in other cell lines tested. The results suggest that SFN's anti-viral activity is not due to direct modification of the virus or a cellular component required for infection, but rather through the activation of Nrf2. This study highlights a novel way to trigger Nrf2-mediated inhibition of HIV infection, which could have implications for the development of new anti-viral therapies. The findings also contrast with previous studies showing that Nrf2 activation is beneficial for other viruses, such as Marburg virus, Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus, and Dengue virus.
Geohelminth infections are common among pregnant women in rural western Kenya, with 76. 2% of 390 participants infected with at least one geohelminth species. The most prevalent species were Ascaris lumbricoides ( 52. 3% ), hookworm ( 39. 5% ), and Trichuris trichiura ( 29. 0% ). Infection with at least one geohelminth species was associated with the use of an unprotected water source ( adjusted odds ratio [ AOR ] 1. 8, 95% confidence interval [ CI ] 1. 1–3. 0 ) and the lack of treatment of drinking water ( AOR 1. 8, 95% CI 1. 1–3. 1 ). However, geohelminth infections were not associated with clinical symptoms or low body mass index. Hookworm infection was associated with a lower mid-upper arm circumference ( adjusted mean decrease 0. 7 cm, 95% CI 0. 3–1. 2 cm ). Hookworm infections with an egg count ≥1000/gram feces ( 11 women ) were associated with lower hemoglobin ( adjusted mean decrease 1. 5 g/dl, 95% CI 0. 3–2. 7 ). Among gravidae 2 and 3, women with A. lumbricoides were less likely to have malaria parasitemia ( OR 0. 4, 95% CI 0. 2–0. 8 ) compared to women without A. lumbricoides.
The study investigated the anti-inflammatory effects of mycolactone, a macrolide produced by Mycobacterium ulcerans, on the nervous system. Mycolactone has previously been shown to have cytotoxic, analgesic, and immunomodulatory properties, which are attributed to its ability to block the Sec61-dependent production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells. This study aimed to determine whether mycolactone affects the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, which are involved in pain perception, transmission, and maintenance. The researchers found that mycolactone suppressed the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by these cell types without affecting their viability. Notably, mycolactone prevented the pro-inflammatory polarization of cortical microglia, which are critical contributors to neuroinflammation. In a rat model of neuropathic pain induced by chronic constriction of the sciatic nerve, mycolactone injected into the spinal canal decreased the local production of inflammatory cytokines without inducing detectable cytotoxicity. The study provides evidence that mycolactone suppresses the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, suggesting that its analgesic properties may be partially explained by its anti-inflammatory effects.
