These findings have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for chronic pain management.
The study investigated the association between candidate gene polymorphisms and clinical phenotypes of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in populations from HAT active foci in Guinea. A total of 425 individuals, including 232 HAT cases, 79 subjects with long-lasting positive and specific serology but negative parasitology, and 114 endemic controls, were genotyped for 28 SNPs in eight genes. The results showed that IL6 rs1818879 allele A was associated with a lower risk of progressing from latent infection to active disease (p = 0.0001, OR = 0.39, CI95 = [0.24-0.63], BONF = 0.0034). In contrast, MIF rs36086171 allele G and MIF rs12483859 C allele were associated with an increased risk of latent infections (p = 0.0239, OR = 1.65, CI95 = [1.07-2.53], BONF = 0.6697 and p = 0.0077, OR = 1.86, CI95 = [1.18-2.95], BONF = 0.2157, respectively). The study also confirmed earlier observations that APOL1 G2 allele (DEL) was associated with a higher risk (p = 0.0011, OR = 2.70, CI95 = [1.49-4.91], BONF = 0.0301) and APOL1 G1 polymorphism was associated with a lower risk (p = 0.0005, OR = 0.45, CI95 = [0.29-0.70], BONF = 0.0129) of developing HAT. No associations were found with other candidate genes. These findings suggest that host genes are involved in modulating Trypanosoma brucei gambiense infection outcome in infected individuals from Guinea.
The genetic structure and diversity of 38 South Asian Indians from Singapore were investigated through deep whole-genome sequencing as part of the Singapore Sequencing Indian Project (SSIP). The samples exhibited greater intra-population genetic diversity and a higher heterozygous-to-homozygous genotype ratio compared to other Asian populations. The genetic makeup of the SSIP samples was found to be closely related to South Indians when compared to a panel of well-defined Asian Indians. However, eight samples were assigned to mitochondrial haplogroups predominantly present in Europeans and showed higher European admixture than the remaining samples. An analysis of the relative relatedness between SSIP samples and archaic hominins (Denisovan, Neanderthal) revealed higher ancient admixture in East Asian populations than in SSIP. The SSIP samples clustered distinctly from Europeans in the global population structure analysis with autosomal SNPs. The data resource for these samples is publicly available and is expected to serve as a valuable complement to the South Asian samples in Phase 3 of the 1,000 Genomes Project. The study provides insights into the genetic structure and diversity of Asian Indians in Singapore and contributes to the understanding of the complex genomic diversity present in the Indian subcontinent.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, exhibits intrinsic resistance to aminoglycosides and macrolides due to the expression of the AmrAB-OprA efflux pump. However, a rare subset of clinical isolates from Thailand, including strains 708a, 2188a, and 3799a, exhibit aminoglycoside susceptibility. Quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction ( qRT-PCR ) revealed the absence of amrB transcripts in 708a and reduced levels in 2188a and 3799a. Serial passage of 2188a and 3799a on increasing gentamicin concentrations yielded mutants that became resistant to other aminoglycosides and macrolides, whereas mutants could not be obtained with 708a. Transcript analysis showed that the resistance of the 2188a and 3799a mutants was due to upregulation of amrAB-oprA expression. The amrAB-oprA operon was found to be missing in 708a due to a large deletion of more than 70 kb of genetic material. This deletion also removed gene clusters for malleobactin and cobalamin synthesis, as well as the anaerobic arginine deiminase pathway, putative type 1 fimbriae, and secreted chitinase. Despite missing several putative virulence genes, 708a was found to be fully virulent in a murine melioidosis model. The study suggests that strain 708a may be a suitable candidate for genetic manipulation experiments using Select Agent compliant antibiotics.
During the early differentiation of naive CD4 T helper (Th) cells into Th1 versus Th2 states, researchers observed that transcription factors Tbet and Gata3 are co-expressed in individual cells at high levels, contrary to the expected mutually exclusive expression of antagonistic transcription factors. This co-expression is distinct from basal-level co-expression during lineage priming and is not positively correlated with cytokine expression in individual cells. However, the expression of cytokines in the entire cell population is still in concert with the expression level of the transcription factor. The study suggests that transcription factors may be responsible for de-condensing the cytokine locus during early activation of CD4 T cells. Upon inhibition of cytokine signaling, the classic mutual exclusion of antagonistic transcription factors is observed, revealing a weak intracellular network otherwise overruled by strong extracellular cytokine signals. The results indicate that CD4 T cells acquire a mixed Th1/Th2 state during the early differentiation process, instructed by extracellular cytokines. This interplay between extracellular and intracellular signaling components may be a common strategy for mammalian cells to buffer against noisy cytokine expression. The study provides insights into the interplay between extracellular cytokines and intracellular transcription factors on the fate specification of single cells during early CD4 T helper cell differentiation.
In Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans), the protein PAQR-2 plays a crucial role in adapting to low temperatures by regulating fatty acid desaturation. PAQR-2 is homologous to the insulin-sensitizing adiponectin receptors in mammals and is essential for growth at 15°C, a temperature that is usually acceptable for this organism. By screening for novel paqr-2 suppressors, researchers identified mutations in genes involved in phosphatidylcholine synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. These findings suggest that PAQR-2, phosphatidylcholines, and Δ9-desaturases form a cold adaptation pathway that regulates the increase in unsaturated fatty acids necessary to maintain membrane fluidity at low temperatures. Genetic evidence supports this model, as paqr-2 suppressors normalize the levels of saturated fatty acids, and low concentrations of detergents that increase membrane fluidity can rescue the paqr-2 mutant. Furthermore, PAQR-2 is shown to be a transmembrane protein essential for the regulation of Δ9 desaturases during cold adaptation via the modulation of phosphatidylcholine levels. This regulatory axis controls the increase in unsaturated fatty acids during cold adaptation, which is essential for the organism's survival. The findings of this study provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying cold adaptation in C. elegans and highlight the importance of PAQR-2 in regulating fatty acid metabolism.
The structure of herpes simplex type-1 (HSV-1) virions has been studied using electron cryo-tomography, revealing a previously unsuspected feature at the portal vertex. This feature extends across the tegument layer, forming a connection between the capsid and the viral membrane. The location of this assembly suggests it plays a role in genome release into the nucleus and is important for virion architecture. The discovery of this feature is supported by evolutionary and structural links between HSV-1 and tailed bacteriophages, which share a common origin with herpesviruses. Tailed bacteriophages have a well-characterized genome packaging and release machinery, which includes a portal and a complex apparatus (the tail) located at the portal vertex. The HSV-1 portal occupies a similar position and has a similar subunit organization as that of tailed bacteriophages, suggesting that equivalent machinery might be present in herpesvirus particles. The tegument layer of HSV-1 virions is a proteinaceous layer that surrounds the capsid and is bounded by a glycoprotein-containing lipid envelope. The infectious HSV-1 particle varies in size, but the capsid has a constant diameter of 1250 Å. The capsid is composed of pentons, hexons, and triplexes, which are the main structural features of the icosahedral capsid. The discovery of the tail-like assembly at the portal vertex of HSV-1 virions provides new insights into the structure and function of herpesviruses, which cause a range of diseases from cold sores and chicken pox to congenital defects, blindness, and cancer.
This study investigated the effects of Schistosoma mansoni soluble egg antigen (SEA) and recombinant Omega-1 (rω-1) on HIV-1 infection in vitro. The results show that SEA can modulate CD4+ T-lymphocyte responses and HIV-1 infection. Specifically, SEA was found to block DC-SIGN-mediated HIV-1 trans-infection by binding to kappa-5, a component of SEA. Additionally, DCs exposed to SEA while maturing under Th2-promoting conditions induced T-cell populations that were less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection, but not X4 infection. This effect was not observed when DCs were exposed to SEA under Th1 or Th1/Th2 (Tmix) promoting conditions. Furthermore, T-cells induced by SEA-exposed DCs demonstrated a reduced capacity to produce IFN-γ and MIP-1β. The study also found that rω-1, a plant recombinant protein with similar functions to natural ω-1, induced T-cell populations that were less sensitive to HIV-1 R5 infection, associated with reduced IFN-γ and MIP-1β expression, and reduced CCR5 expression. These findings suggest that SEA and rω-1 can modulate HIV-1 infectivity and may influence disease course in co-infected individuals. The study provides evidence that helminthic infections, such as Schistosoma mansoni, may have a beneficial effect on HIV-1 infection, and highlights the potential for deciphering mechanisms to modulate immune responses beneficial for limiting viral transmission or reducing viral loads.
The article presents a dynamic model that explains the phenomenon of neural-activity-induced shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECS) between neurons and surrounding astrocytes in grey and white matter. The model accounts for experimental data from wild-type and gene knockout individuals and identifies key mechanisms contributing to ECS shrinkage. These mechanisms include neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride through passive channels, action of the Na/K/ATPase pump, and osmotically driven transport of water through the astrocyte membrane. The model suggests that the actions of the Na+/K+/Cl− (NKCC1) and Na+/HCO3− (NBC) cotransporters are critical determinants for achieving observed quantitative levels of ECS shrinkage. The authors propose that measuring ECS shrinkage, membrane potential, and ECS and astrocyte ion concentrations in wild-type and knockout individuals, as well as obtaining data on neuronal water, sodium, and chloride uptake during activation, is essential for further understanding this phenomenon. The model framework is considered sufficiently detailed and constrained to guide future experiments and pave the way for more comprehensive astroglia–neuron interaction models for normal and pathophysiological situations.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, the expression of transposons and repetitive DNA elements is suppressed by the siRNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing pathway. This pathway involves RNA Polymerase V ( Pol V ) producing long non-coding RNAs ( lncRNAs ) that guide ARGONAUTE4 ( AGO4 ) to chromatin and attract enzymes that establish repressive chromatin modifications. However, the mechanism by which chromatin modifying enzymes are recruited to chromatin is unknown. This study investigated the role of SPT5L/KTF1, a silencing factor and homolog of SPT5 elongation factors, in the siRNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing pathway. Using chromatin immunoprecipitation ( ChIP ), the study found that SPT5L/KTF1 binds chromatin at loci subject to transcriptional silencing downstream of Pol V but independently of 24-nt siRNA. Additionally, SPT5L/KTF1 and AGO4 are recruited to chromatin in parallel and independently of each other. The study also showed that binding of both AGO4 and SPT5L/KTF1 is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications of several loci. The results suggest that the coordinate binding of SPT5L and AGO4 creates a platform for the direct or indirect recruitment of chromatin modifying enzymes. This study provides new insights into the mechanism of siRNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing and the role of SPT5L/KTF1 in this process.
This study investigated the role of the alternative sigma factor RpoS in the transmission of Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease, from ticks to mammals. The authors found that RpoS-dependent gene expression is essential for the transmission of spirochetes by feeding nymphs, as RpoS-deficient organisms are confined to the midgut lumen and form an unusual morphotype, referred to as round bodies, during the later stages of the blood meal. Round body formation is rapidly reversible and appears to be attributable, in part, to reduced levels of Coenzyme A disulfide reductase, which provides NAD+ for glycolysis. The authors also demonstrated that RpoS is induced during the nymphal blood meal but is not expressed by spirochetes within replete larvae or unfed nymphs, indicating a bipartite regulation of RpoS during the tick phase of the enzootic cycle. Furthermore, the study revealed a previously unsuspected role for RpoSBb in the physiological adaptations required for tick-to-mammal transmission and the existence of a default survival mode, round body formation, triggered when spirochetes are unable to produce sufficient energy for dissemination within the nymph. These findings highlight the importance of RpoS-dependent gene expression in the transmission of B. burgdorferi and provide new insights into the tick-phase of the enzootic cycle.
In Arabidopsis, gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) play crucial roles in regulating stamen development. GA promotes stamen filament elongation, pollen maturation, and anther dehiscence by triggering the degradation of DELLA proteins. However, the relationship between GA and JA in controlling stamen development is not well understood. This study reveals that GA acts through JA to control the expression of MYB21, MYB24, and MYB57, which are GA-dependent stamen-enriched genes. The loss-of-function of two DELLAs, RGA and RGL2, restores the expression of these MYB genes and promotes stamen filament growth in GA-deficient plants. The myb21-t1 myb24-t1 myb57-t1 triple mutant exhibits a short stamen phenotype leading to male sterility. Genetic and molecular studies demonstrate that GA suppresses DELLAs to mobilize the expression of the key JA biosynthesis gene DAD1, resulting in increased JA content in young flower buds. Furthermore, exogenous application of GA to GA-deficient plants induces the expression of MYB21, MYB24, and MYB57 and restores normal floral development. These findings establish a hierarchical relationship between GA and JA, where modulation of the JA pathway by GA is a prerequisite for GA to regulate normal stamen development in Arabidopsis. The study also suggests that other GA-regulated JA-independent factors are necessary for normal stamen filament development.
This study investigated the role of hypoxia-inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) in modulating lifespan extension by dietary restriction (DR) in Caenorhabditis elegans. Previous research has shown that the target of rapamycin (TOR) pathway is essential for longevity phenotypes resulting from DR, but it is unclear whether additional targets of this pathway also modulate lifespan. HIF-1 is a transcription factor complex that plays key roles in oxygen homeostasis, tumor formation, glucose metabolism, cell survival, and inflammatory response. The study found that HIF-1 deficiency results in extended lifespan, which overlaps with that by inhibition of the RSKS-1/S6 kinase, a key component of the TOR pathway. HIF-1 modulates longevity in a nutrient-dependent manner, and its loss-of-function mutant extends lifespan under rich nutrient conditions but fails to show lifespan extension under DR. Conversely, a mutation in egl-9, which increases HIF-1 activity, diminishes the lifespan extension under DR. The study also found that increased lifespan by HIF-1 or DR is dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulator inositol-requiring protein-1 (IRE-1) and is associated with lower levels of ER stress. The results demonstrate a tissue-specific role for HIF-1 in the lifespan extension by DR involving the IRE-1 ER stress pathway. The study suggests that HIF-1 acts downstream of the nutrient-responsive TOR-S6K pathway to determine lifespan in C. elegans.
The study investigated the changes in chromatin organization and transcription factor binding in human epidermal keratinocytes as they transition between different functional states, including differentiation and migration. The results show that when keratinocytes differentiate or migrate, they form unique complements of typical enhancers and super-enhancers that are specific to each state. These super-enhancers are linked to gene expression that confers functions associated with the respective cell state and are enriched for skin disease sequence variants. The transcription factor GRHL3, which promotes both differentiation and migration, binds preferentially to super-enhancers in differentiating keratinocytes and to promoters in migrating keratinocytes, where it represses the expression of migration inhibitors in collaboration with the transcriptional repressor REST. GRHL3 is also located within super-enhancers that regulate key epidermal differentiation transcription factor genes, and it represses the formation of progenitor and non-keratinocyte super-enhancers in differentiating keratinocytes. The study highlights the reciprocal regulatory relationship between GRHL3 and chromatin domains, including super-enhancers, and suggests that GRHL3 regulates divergent gene expression programs in differentiating and migrating keratinocytes by switching locations of chromatin binding in the context of enhancer landscapes that are distinct for each state. These findings provide mechanistic insight into how a single transcription factor can control distinct gene expression programs under different physiological states within the same cell type.
This study investigates the coevolutionary dynamics between endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) and exogenous retroviruses in sheep. Endogenous retroviruses are remnants of ancient retroviral infections that have integrated into the host genome and are transmitted vertically from generation to generation. Some ERVs have been found to interfere with the replication of related exogenous retroviruses, suggesting that they may be used by the host as restriction factors to block pathogenic retroviral infections. The study focuses on the evolutionary history and molecular virology of 27 enJSRV proviruses in sheep, which have been integrating into the host genome for the last 5-7 million years. Two enJSRV proviruses, enJS56A1 and enJSRV-20, acquired a defective Gag polyprotein resulting in a transdominant phenotype that blocks late replication steps of related exogenous retroviruses. These transdominant proviruses became fixed in the host genome before or around sheep domestication ( ∼ 9, 000 years ago ). Interestingly, a provirus escaping the transdominant enJSRVs has emerged very recently, most likely within the last 200 years. The study suggests that endogenization and selection of ERVs acting as restriction factors is a mechanism used by the host to fight retroviral infections. The findings indicate that the evolutionary antagonism between endogenous and exogenous retroviruses in sheep is a continuous process that has not reached equilibrium.
The diagnosis of schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma species, relies heavily on microscopic detection of eggs in stool or urine samples and serological assays. However, the sensitivity of standard microscopic procedures is limited, making molecular detection methods more appealing. This study aimed to evaluate the performance of two real-time PCR assays targeting Schistosoma mansoni (Sm) and Schistosoma haematobium (Sh) in excreta, biopsies, and sera for diagnosing active infections and monitoring treatment efficacy. A total of 412 samples from patients with suspected schistosomiasis were analyzed using PCR and compared to microscopic examination and serological assays, including enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), indirect haemagglutination (HA), and Western Blot (WB) assay. The results showed that PCR significantly increased the sensitivity of diagnosis, from 4% to 10.5% and from 33.7% to 48.8%, for Sh in urine and Sm in stools, respectively. The overall sensitivity of PCR on serum samples was 72.7% and reached 94.1% in patients with positive excreta (microscopy). The specificity of serum PCR was 98.9%. After treatment, serum PCR positivity rates slowly declined from 93.8% at day 30 to 8.3% at day 360, whereas antibody detection remained positive after 1 year. The study suggests that Schistosoma PCRs outperform standard microscopy on stools and urine and could be part of reference methods combined with WB-based serology. Serum PCRs provide species information to guide further clinical exploration when serological assays are positive and microscopy is negative.
This study demonstrates the feasibility of using machine learning (ML) to estimate conformational energies of large, structurally complex molecules, such as the natural product Archazolid A. Archazolid A is a potent inhibitor of vacuolar-type ATPase produced by the myxobacterium Archangium gephyra. The researchers employed Gaussian process regression, a Bayesian non-parametric ML method, to model the relationship between molecular structure and quantum mechanical (QM) properties. They used a simple molecular representation based on nuclear charges and inter-atomic distances to encode the conformations of Archazolid A. The ML model was trained on a dataset of relaxed conformations and their corresponding energies calculated at the density functional theory (DFT) level of theory. The results show that the ML model can accurately predict energies of new conformations with a mean absolute error of less than 1 kcal/mol. The study also demonstrates that the predictive variance of the ML model can be used to assess whether a conformation is in the interpolation region, allowing for a controlled trade-off between prediction accuracy and computational speed-up. This approach has the potential to enable significant speed-ups in simulations of larger molecular structures, which is particularly relevant for pharmaceutically relevant compounds. The study contributes to the development of innovative ML algorithms that are tightly integrated with molecular dynamics techniques, providing access to long-term simulations of challenging chemical and biomolecular systems.
A new approach for monitoring ebolavirus in wild great apes has been developed through the non-invasive detection of antibodies against Ebola virus (EBOV) in fecal samples. This method allows for the identification of gorillas with antibodies to EBOV, with an overall prevalence rate of 10% on average, indicating that EBOV exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. Furthermore, evidence of antibodies was found in gorillas previously thought to be unexposed to EBOV, suggesting that they may have been protected from exposure by topological barriers of transmission. The new approach enables early detection of increased incidence of exposure, identification of immunologically naïve at-risk populations as potential targets for vaccination, and tracking of vaccine efficacy if such intervention is deemed appropriate. Additionally, this method may prove valuable in the development and employment of prospective epidemiological ebolavirus studies in wild great ape populations. The study represents the first time ebolavirus antibodies have been detected in wild great ape fecal samples, carrying important implications for the future management and survival of these primates. This breakthrough has significant implications for the development of intervention strategies to protect apes against future Ebola virus disease (EVD) infections, including vaccination, as ebolavirus vaccines have been shown to protect laboratory monkeys from disease.
A novel type III effector protein, XopL, from the plant pathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria, has been identified to possess E3 ubiquitin ligase activity in vitro and in planta. This activity is associated with the C-terminal region of XopL, which specifically interacts with plant E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and mediates the formation of predominantly K11-linked polyubiquitin chains. The crystal structure of the XopL C-terminal domain revealed a novel fold, termed XL-box, which is not present in any previously characterized E3 ligase. Mutation of amino acids in the central cavity of the XL-box disrupts E3 ligase activity and prevents XopL-induced plant cell death. The N-terminal region of XopL contains a leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain, which may serve as a protein-protein interaction module for ubiquitination target recognition. The E3 ligase activity of XopL is required to provoke plant cell death, while suppression of PAMP responses solely depends on the N-terminal LRR domain. The unique structural fold of the E3 ubiquitin ligase domain within XopL highlights the variation in bacterial pathogen effectors mimicking this eukaryote-specific activity. This study demonstrates that pathogenic bacteria have employed different solutions to fulfill the otherwise typical eukaryote-specific function of E3 ubiquitin ligases during co-evolution with their hosts.
This study investigated the interaction between circulating T follicular helper cells (cTfh) and B cells in individuals with early acute HIV infection and the impact of early antiretroviral treatment (ART) on T and B cell function. The research used the RV254 cohort of HIV-infected individuals in stages 1/2 and 3 of acute infection. The results showed that cTfh cell function was impaired in individuals treated in stage 3 compared to those in stage 1/2. Cocultures of cTfh and B cells demonstrated lower B cell survival and IgG secretion in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with increased inflammation and elevated plasma viral load. Elevated viral load was found to correlate with decreased cTfh-mediated B cell IgG production, suggesting a role for increased viremia in cTfh impairment and dysfunctional humoral response. Phenotypic perturbations were also observed in the mature B cell compartment, with a decrease in resting memory B cells in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2. The study suggests that early ART for acutely HIV-infected individuals could prevent immune dysregulation while preserving cTfh function and B cell memory. The findings indicate that cTfh-mediated B cell responses are significantly altered in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with increased inflammation and a reduction in memory B cells.
A miniaturized screen of a Schistosoma mansoni serotonergic G protein-coupled receptor (Sm. 5HTR) has been conducted to identify novel classes of parasite-selective inhibitors. The study aimed to address the need for next-generation anthelmintics to combat schistosomiasis, a tropical disease affecting over 200 million people worldwide. Current therapy relies on a single drug, praziquantel, which has several suboptimal features. The researchers pharmacologically profiled Sm. 5HTR, a downstream modulator of PZQ efficacy, using a miniaturized screening assay compatible with high-content screening. This approach employed a split luciferase-based biosensor sensitive to cellular cAMP levels, resolving the proximal kinetics of GPCR modulation in intact cells. The data revealed a divergent pharmacological signature between Sm. 5HTR and its closest human GPCR homolog, Hs. 5HTR7, supporting the feasibility of optimizing parasitic-selective pharmacophores. New ligands and chemical series with potency and selectivity for Sm. 5HTR over Hs. 5HTR7 were identified in vitro and validated for in vivo efficacy against schistosomules and adult worms. Sm. 5HTR also exhibited an unusual antagonist-evoked inactivation mechanism, a phenomenon also observed at Hs. 5HTR7, enhancing its appeal as a target for anthelmintic ligand design. The study demonstrates the feasibility of profiling flatworm GPCRs in a high-throughput screening format and highlights the promise of Sm. 5HTR as a chemotherapeutically vulnerable node for the development of next-generation anthelmintics.
During embryonic development, the formation of germ layers is crucial for the establishment of the metazoan body plan. The ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm layers must be separated to prevent intermixing, yet the ectoderm-mesoderm boundary also serves as a substratum for mesoderm migration. A new study reveals that localized detachment resulting from contact-induced signals at the boundary is essential for ectoderm-mesoderm segregation. EphrinB/EphB signaling plays a key role in this process, with multiple ephrinB ligands and EphB receptors expressed on each side of the boundary. Forward signaling across the boundary in both directions is necessary for tissue separation, involving partially redundant ligands and receptors and activation of Rac and RhoA. This mechanism differs from a simple differential adhesion process of germ layer formation. Instead, it involves localized responses to signals exchanged at the tissue boundary and an attachment/detachment cycle that allows for cell migration across a cellular substratum. The study suggests that the ephrinB/EphB mechanism of tissue separation may be conserved in other organisms, such as zebrafish and Drosophila, where a cleft-like ectoderm-mesoderm boundary is also observed. The findings have implications for our understanding of germ layer formation and tissue separation during embryonic development.
The study presents a novel approach to classifying children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) using multivariate data analysis of markers of oxidative stress and DNA methylation. Blood samples from 83 participants with ASD and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers were analyzed for metabolite concentrations of the folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transulfuration pathways. Fisher Discriminant Analysis enabled the correct classification of 96.1% of neurotypical participants and 97.6% of the ASD cohort. Furthermore, kernel partial least squares was used to predict adaptive behavior, as measured by the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Composite score, with an R2 of 0.45 after cross-validation. This level of accuracy exceeds previous approaches in the field, suggesting that the metabolites under consideration are strongly correlated with an ASD diagnosis and that the statistical analysis used here offers potential for extracting important information from complex biochemical data sets. The study also highlights the importance of incorporating biochemical data into ASD diagnosis to enable earlier and more accurate diagnoses. The multivariate statistical analysis presented in this study provides unprecedented quantitative classification results for separating participants into ASD and neurotypical cohorts based solely on biochemical data.
The article presents a Bayesian geostatistical analysis of leishmaniasis incidence in Brazil over a 10-year period (2001-2010). Leishmaniasis is a significant public health concern in Brazil, with an estimated 350 million people at risk and approximately 2 million cases annually. The study employed Bayesian geostatistical negative binomial models to analyze reported incidence data of cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis, with a focus on spatial and temporal patterns. The models were fitted using integrated nested Laplace approximations for fast approximate Bayesian inference. Bayesian variable selection was used to identify the most important climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic predictors of both types of leishmaniasis. The results showed that precipitation and socioeconomic proxies were significant risk factors for both cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis. The predicted number of cases in 2010 was 30,189 (standard deviation: 7,676) for cutaneous leishmaniasis and 4,889 (standard deviation: 288) for visceral leishmaniasis. Spatially explicit, high-resolution incidence maps identified priority areas for leishmaniasis control efforts, with the highest numbers of infected people predicted in the states of Minas Gerais and Pará for visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis, respectively. The study provides a deeper understanding of the determinants of leishmaniasis in Brazil and highlights the need for targeted control efforts to reduce disease incidence.
In a large cohort study conducted in southern Vietnam, researchers compared the clinical features of dengue in 647 adults and 881 children with confirmed dengue infection. The study found that while the overall clinical picture was similar in both age groups, there were distinct differences in the pattern of complications. Children experienced more frequent and severe signs of vascular leakage and shock, whereas adults were more likely to exhibit bleeding manifestations and organ involvement. Additionally, adults had significantly lower platelet counts than children, with thrombocytopenia being more severe in adults. The study also found that secondary infection, but not serotype, was independently associated with greater thrombocytopenia. Notably, the effect of age on platelet count persisted even after recovery, indicating that healthy adults have intrinsically lower platelet counts compared to children. These findings highlight the importance of considering age-related physiological differences in the management and treatment of dengue infection. The study's results have implications for the development of guidelines for the use of blood products, such as platelet transfusions, which are becoming increasingly common in dengue-endemic countries despite a lack of evidence supporting their routine use. Overall, the study provides valuable insights into the clinical features of dengue in adults and children, which can inform research on disease pathogenesis and improve patient care.
Sooty mangabeys (SM) are natural hosts of the Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIVsmm), which replicates robustly without causing disease. In contrast to HIV infection in humans and SIV infection in macaques, SIVsmm infection in SM is non-pathogenic. A novel CCR5 mutation, a two-base pair deletion (Δ2), was identified in SM, resulting in a truncated molecule that is not expressed on the cell surface and does not support SIV entry in vitro. This mutation was present at a 26% frequency in a large SM colony, along with a 3% frequency of a CCR5Δ24 deletion allele that also abrogates surface expression. The mutant allele was also found in wild SM in West Africa. CD8+ and CD4+ T cells displayed a gradient of CCR5 expression across genotype groups, which was highly significant for CD8+ cells. Notably, the prevalence of natural SIVsmm infection was not significantly different in animals lacking functional CCR5 compared to heterozygous and homozygous wild-type animals. SIVsmm primary isolates infected both homozygous mutant and wild-type PBMC in a CCR5-independent manner in vitro, and Envs from both CCR5-null and wild-type infected animals used CXCR6, GPR15, and GPR1 in addition to CCR5 in transfected cells. These findings suggest that SIVsmm relies on CCR5-independent entry pathways in SM, which may enable the virus to replicate efficiently without causing disease in the face of restricted CCR5 expression.
The co-existence of transcriptional activator and transcriptional repressor MEF2 complexes influences tumor aggressiveness in leiomyosarcomas (LMS). MEF2 transcription factors (TFs) can support both pro-oncogenic and tumor suppressive activities depending on their interaction with co-activators or co-repressors. These interactions regulate histone modifications associated with gene activation or repression, such as H3K4 methylation and H3K27 acetylation. Class IIa histone deacetylases (HDACs) play a critical role in generating a MEF2 repressive environment. In LMS, high levels of MEF2, HDAC4, and HDAC9 inversely correlate with overall survival. The knockout of HDAC9 suppresses the transformed phenotype of LMS cells by restoring the transcriptional proficiency of some MEF2-target loci. HDAC9 also coordinates the demethylation of H3K4me3 at the promoters of MEF2-target genes. Notably, class IIa HDACs do not bind all the regulatory elements bound by MEF2, allowing for the coexistence of actively transcribed and strongly repressed MEF2-target genes. These repressed genes are poised in terms of chromatin signature. The study identifies class IIa HDACs, particularly HDAC9, as potential druggable targets for therapeutic intervention in LMS. The findings suggest that LMS can be clustered into two groups based on MEF2 dysfunction, with one group exhibiting low proliferation and low MEF2 levels, and the other group showing high MEF2 and class IIa HDAC levels, which is associated with poor patient survival.
Hydrophobins are a group of proteins produced by filamentous fungi that play a crucial role in their interaction with the environment and have potential applications in nanotechnology. This study used a combination of protein docking, molecular dynamics simulation, and electron cryo-microscopy to investigate the surface structure of films composed of two class II hydrophobins, HFBI and HFBII, produced by Trichoderma reesei. The results suggest a unit cell composed of six proteins with P6 symmetry, but experimental data show P3 symmetry with a unit cell size of 56 Å. Computational simulations indicate the possibility of an alternate ordering with a three-protein unit cell with P3 symmetry and a smaller unit cell size. A Monte Carlo simulation of a spin model representing the hydrophobin film suggests that this alternate metastable structure may play a role in increasing the rate of surface coverage by hydrophobin films. The study provides a detailed atomic resolution picture of the assembled structure of hydrophobin films at the air-water interface. The unique macroscopic properties of hydrophobin films arise from cooperative effects in the stabilization of the film resulting from interactions between interlocking proteins in the structured surface network. The findings have implications for both biological and nanotechnological applications of hydrophobins.
The study reports the functional characterization of threonyl tRNA synthetase (LdThrRS) from Leishmania donovani, a protozoan parasite responsible for visceral leishmaniasis. Recombinant LdThrRS was expressed in E. coli and purified, and its kinetic parameters were determined. Immunofluorescence analysis revealed that LdThrRS is localized to both the cytosol and mitochondria. Heterozygous mutants of LdThrRS were generated in Leishmania promastigotes, which showed a restrictive growth phenotype and attenuated infectivity. These mutants were also more susceptible to inhibition by the known ThrRS inhibitor, borrelidin. An in silico-generated structural model of LdThrRS was compared to human ThrRS, showing considerable similarity. Borrelidin displayed a strong affinity for LdThrRS (KD: 0.04 μM) and inhibited the aminoacylation activity of recombinant LdThrRS (IC50: 0.06 μM). Furthermore, borrelidin inhibited the promastigotes stage of parasites (IC50: 21 μM). The study demonstrates that LdThrRS is essential for L. donovani survival and is a potential target for drug discovery efforts. The results suggest that LdThrRS could be targeted by small drug-like molecules with strong affinity, making it a promising new class of targets in antileishmanial drug discovery.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA is recognized as non-self by the innate immune receptor RIG-I through the presence of a 5′-triphosphate (5′-ppp) on the viral RNA in association with a 3′ poly-U/UC tract. A detailed structure-function analysis of RIG-I and poly-U/UC RNA interactions revealed that the 34 nucleotide poly-uridine "core" of this sequence tract is essential for RIG-I activation. Interspersed ribocytosine nucleotides between poly-U sequences in the RNA are also required to achieve optimal RIG-I signal induction. 5′-ppp poly-U/UC RNA variants that stimulated strong RIG-I activation efficiently bound purified RIG-I protein in vitro, and RNA interaction with both the repressor domain and helicase domain of RIG-I was required to activate signaling. The poly-U/UC U-core sequence conferred non-self recognition of the RNA and innate immune signaling by RIG-I when appended to 5′-ppp RNA that lacks PAMP activity. HCV poly-U/UC RNA variants that strongly activated RIG-I signaling triggered potent anti-HCV responses in vitro and hepatic innate immune responses in vivo using a mouse model of PAMP signaling. These studies define a multi-motif PAMP signature of non-self recognition by RIG-I that incorporates a 5′-ppp with poly-uridine sequence composition and length. This HCV PAMP motif drives potent RIG-I signaling to induce the innate immune response to infection.
This study investigated the role of eosinophils and interleukin-4 (IL-4) in promoting the growth of Trichinella spiralis larvae in skeletal muscle. Eosinophils were found to be necessary for normal larval growth, and IL-4 competent eosinophils were sufficient to support growth in the absence of adaptive immunity. Gene expression in infected muscle tissue indicated a regenerative response and a shift in energy source. Eosinophils suppressed local inflammation and influenced nutrient homeostasis in muscle. Redistribution of glucose transporter 4 ( GLUT4 ) and phosphorylation of Akt were observed in nurse cells, consistent with enhanced glucose uptake and glycogen storage by larvae. The data suggest that eosinophils promote larval growth through an IL-4 dependent mechanism that limits interferon-driven responses that alter nutrient metabolism in infected muscle. This interaction between parasite and host facilitates worm growth by co-opting an innate host cell response. Further experimentation is needed to establish the direct mechanism by which eosinophil-derived IL-4 enhances glucose uptake in host cells. The study also found that the effect of eosinophils on larval growth depends on their IL-4 competence and is independent of ILC2. Transfer of IL-4-/- eosinophils failed to improve larval growth in PHIL/Rag1-/- mice, supporting the role of IL-4 in eosinophil-mediated larval growth.
Genome-wide replication timing studies have suggested that mammalian chromosomes consist of large domains of coordinated origin firing separated by originless transition regions. However, a quantitative genome-wide analysis of DNA replication kinetics in HeLa cells contradicts this view. DNA combing in HeLa cells sorted into four temporal compartments of S phase shows that replication origins are spaced at 40 kb intervals and fire as small clusters whose synchrony increases during S phase. Replication fork velocity remains constant and narrowly distributed through S phase, with a mean of 0. 7 kb/min and a maximum of 2. 0 kb/min. Multi-scale analysis of a genome-wide replication timing profile reveals a broad distribution of replication timing gradients with no regions larger than 100 kb replicating at less than 2 kb/min. This suggests that HeLa cells lack large regions of unidirectional fork progression. Instead, temporal transition regions are replicated by sequential activation of origins at a rate that increases during S phase. Replication timing gradients are set by the delay and spacing between successive origin firings rather than by the velocity of single forks. Activation of internal origins in a specific temporal transition region is directly demonstrated by DNA combing of the IGH locus in HeLa cells. These findings are corroborated by analysis of published origin maps in HeLa cells and replication timing and DNA combing data in several other cell types, with the exception of embryonic stem cells where regions of unidirectional fork progression seem more abundant.
The article explores the concept of slowness as an objective for spike-timing–dependent plasticity (STDP) in the nervous system. The authors propose that the ability to recognize objects despite changes in contextual variables, such as perspective or lighting conditions, can be attributed to the fact that object identities typically vary more slowly in time than contextual variables or noise. They investigate how this "temporal stability" or "slowness" approach can be implemented within the limits of biologically realistic spike-based learning rules. The authors first demonstrate that slow feature analysis (SFA), an algorithm based on slowness, can be implemented in linear continuous model neurons using a modified Hebbian learning rule. This approach provides a link to the trace rule, another implementation of slowness learning. They then show analytically that for linear Poisson neurons, slowness learning can be implemented by STDP with a specific learning window. The authors derive STDP learning windows that implement SFA and the "trace rule" and find that the resulting learning windows are compatible with physiological data in terms of shape and timescale. Their analysis suggests that the learning window can be split into two functionally different components that are sensitive to reversible and irreversible aspects of the input statistics. The theory indicates that irreversible input statistics may generate oscillatory weight dynamics, offering a novel interpretation for the functional role of STDP in physiological neurons.
In a study on non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), researchers have identified a previously unrecognized phenomenon called cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT), where cancer cells induce co-resistant phenotypes in neighboring cells when exposed to cancer therapy. The study used a CRISPR/Cas9 toolkit to engineer phenotypically diverse NSCLC cells with mutations in Dicer1, a type III cytoplasmic endoribonuclease involved in small non-coding RNA genesis. The researchers monitored the growth dynamics of mutant and/or wild-type cells individually or in co-culture using a substrate-free NanoCulture system under unstimulated or drug pressure conditions. Mathematical modeling and flow cytometry were used to characterize the growth patterns of mono- and co-cultures, revealing that the combination of wild-type and mutant cells in co-cultures allowed for beneficial growth in previously drug-sensitive cells despite drug pressure. This growth was attributed to a cooperative game theoretic change in the fitness values of the cells. The study also used an ex vivo human tumor model to determine that cellular and morphologic heterogeneity correlates with prognostic failure of multiple clinically-approved and off-label drugs in individual NSCLC patient samples. These findings suggest that profiling for druggable targets alone may be insufficient to assign effective therapy, and that non-genetic cooperation among tumor cells plays a significant role in drug resistance. The study highlights the importance of understanding how phenotypically distinct cells within the same tumor interact to promote resistance to therapy.
A cross-sectional seroprevalence study was conducted in Mbeya Region, Southwestern Tanzania, to estimate the seroprevalence of IgG antibodies against Spotted Fever Group (SFG) rickettsiae and assess socioeconomic and environmental risk factors. A total of 1,228 participants above the age of 5 years were randomly selected from nine communities, stratified by age, altitude of residence, and ownership of domestic mammals. The seroprevalence of SFG rickettsiae was found to be 67.9%, ranging from 42.8% to 91.4% among the nine sites. Multivariable analysis revealed associations between SFG-seropositivity and age, warmer temperatures, male gender, and low population density. At higher elevations, higher cattle density was associated with higher seroprevalence. The study suggests that SFG rickettsial infection is common in the more rural population of Mbeya Region, and its spread may be limited by temperature and higher elevation. The findings are compatible with previous descriptions and add information on risk factors for SFG rickettsioses in southwestern Tanzania. The study highlights the need for further research to examine the contribution of SFG to febrile illnesses and to determine the causative pathogens in a prospective study. The results also suggest that SFG rickettsiae may contribute to the disease burden in the population, particularly in rural areas.
This study investigates the role of oleate, a monounsaturated fatty acid, in the innate immune response of Caenorhabditis elegans, a nematode worm commonly used as a model organism in biomedical research. The researchers conducted an RNA interference (RNAi) screen to identify regulators of innate immune defense genes and found that two stearoyl-coenzyme A desaturases, which synthesize oleate, are essential for the pathogen-mediated induction of immune defense genes. The study shows that C. elegans deficient in oleate production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse human pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterococcus faecalis, and Serratia marcescens. However, the addition of exogenous oleate rescues this susceptibility, indicating that oleate is necessary for innate immune activation and pathogen defense. The researchers also found that oleate is not sufficient to drive protective immune activation on its own, suggesting that it acts in conjunction with other factors to promote immune responses. Furthermore, the study demonstrates that oleate and polyunsaturated fatty acids, such as γ-linolenic acid and stearidonic acid, affect immune effector expression and pathogen resistance through distinct mechanisms. Overall, the findings of this study highlight the importance of oleate in the innate immune response of C. elegans and suggest an ancient link between nutrient stores, metabolism, and host susceptibility to bacterial infection.
Scientists have identified a novel compound, PC1, that selectively inhibits the growth of certain bacterial species, including nosocomial pathogens, by targeting guanine riboswitches. Guanine riboswitches regulate the expression of genes involved in purine metabolism, which is essential for bacterial survival. PC1, a pyrimidine compound, binds to guanine riboswitches and causes transcription attenuation of the downstream open reading frame, leading to bactericidal activity. This activity is only observed in bacteria that use guanine riboswitches to control the expression of the guaA gene, which codes for a GMP synthetase. Notably, PC1 exhibits bactericidal activity even when bacteria are grown in a rich medium, suggesting that it targets a specific metabolic pathway. In a mouse model, administration of PC1 was shown to reduce Staphylococcus aureus infection in mammary glands. The study demonstrates the potential of using existing structural knowledge to design novel antibiotics that target guanine riboswitches. This approach may provide a new strategy for developing powerful and selective antimicrobial compounds, particularly against community-acquired bacterial infections. The findings also highlight the importance of guanine riboswitches in bacterial metabolism and their potential as targets for antibiotic development.
The study investigated how gaze influences the construction of mental space during navigation in primates by examining navigation behavior, visual exploration, and hippocampal activity in macaque monkeys searching a virtual reality maze for a reward. The results show that hippocampal cells sensitive to place also responded to variables such as head direction, point of gaze, or task context. Many cells fired at the sight (and in anticipation) of a single landmark in a viewpoint- or task-dependent manner, simultaneously encoding the animal’s logical situation within a set of actions leading to the goal. Overall, hippocampal activity was best fit by a fine-grained state space comprising current position, view, and action contexts. The findings indicate that counterparts of rodent place cells in primates embody multidimensional, task-situated knowledge pertaining to the target of gaze, supporting self-awareness in the construction of space. This conjunctive type of coding appears ubiquitous across mammals, consistent with the encoding of task-related demands by hippocampal neurons in rodents. The study provides a comprehensive analysis of the variables controlling the activity of hippocampal cells, bridging the gap between studies in rodents and primates, including humans, collected in real and virtual environments. The results suggest that the counterpart of place cells in primates is expressed as activity related to point of gaze in conjunction with other variables essential to navigation, such as position and identity of visual elements at key instants of trajectory planning.
The article presents a spatial analysis of gene expression patterns at the mid-hindbrain boundary (MHB) in vertebrate development. The MHB is characterized by a well-defined pattern of locally restricted gene expression domains, which is established and maintained by a regulatory network between several transcription and secreted factors. A Boolean analysis of the spatial gene expression patterns at the murine MHB reveals key regulatory interactions in this network. The analysis predicts a maintaining, rather than inducing, effect of Fgf8 on Wnt1 expression, which is experimentally validated using mouse anterior neural plate/tube explant cultures. The results show that Fgf8 maintains, but does not induce, ectopic Wnt1 expression in these explants. This finding, combined with previously validated interactions, allows for the construction of a regulatory network between key transcription and secreted factors at the MHB. Analyses of Boolean, differential equation, and reaction-diffusion models of this network confirm that it is able to explain the stable maintenance of the MHB as well as time-courses of expression patterns under wild-type and various knock-out conditions. The study demonstrates that spatial expression patterns can be used to gain information about the structure of regulatory networks, and that the spatial gene expression patterns around the MHB help to understand the maintenance of this boundary on a systems level.
Theileria annulata, an apicomplexan parasite, transforms infected host cells, inducing uncontrolled proliferation and clonal expansion of the parasitized cell population. The parasite develops into a schizont, which remains tethered to host cell microtubules (MTs) and engages with the cell's astral and central spindle MTs during mitosis and cytokinesis to secure its distribution between the two daughter cells. The molecular mechanism by which the schizont recruits and stabilizes host cell MTs is not known. The plus ends of growing MTs, which are dynamic and constantly switching between phases of growth and shrinkage, are thought to provide the first point of contact with the parasite. The end-binding protein 1 (EB1), a central component of the MT plus end protein interaction network, is a key regulator of host cell MT dynamics. The schizont recruits EB1 through its surface protein p104, which contains a consensus SxIP motif that binds to EB1. This interaction is cell cycle regulated and is the first description of a pathogen-encoded protein interacting with EB1 via a bona-fide SxIP motif. The findings provide new insight into the mode of interaction between Theileria and the host cell cytoskeleton. The schizont's association with host cell MTs during mitosis and cytokinesis is crucial for its persistence in the transformed host cell, and the interaction with EB1 is essential for the distribution of the schizont between the two daughter cells during cytokinesis.
In budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, broken replication forks result in DNA breaks that are normally repaired via homologous recombination or break-induced replication ( BIR ). Research has shown that mild insufficiency in the replicative ligase Cdc9 leads to a population of cells with persistent DNA damage, constitutive activation of the DNA damage checkpoint, and longer telomeres. This telomere lengthening requires functional telomerase, the core DNA damage signaling cascade Mec1-Rad9-Rad53, and the components of the BIR repair pathway – Rad51, Rad52, Pol32, and Pif1. The Mec1-Rad53 induced phosphorylation of Pif1, previously found necessary for inhibition of telomerase at double strand breaks, is also important for the role of Pif1 in BIR and telomere elongation in cdc9-1 cells. Two other mutants with impaired DNA replication, cdc44-5 and rrm3Δ, exhibit a similar long telomere phenotype dependent on the Pif1 phosphorylation locus. The study proposes a model in which the passage of BIR forks through telomeres promotes telomerase activity and leads to telomere lengthening. The DNA damage-induced phosphorylation of Pif1 promotes telomere-stabilizing telomere extension while repressing deleterious de novo telomere addition events at DNA breaks. This mechanism may explain previous reports of constitutive activation of Rad53 and longer telomeres in rrm3 mutants and cdc44-5 cells.
A novel diagnostic tool for onchocerciasis, an infection caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus, has been developed using a luciferase immunoprecipitation system ( LIPS ). This system utilizes four recombinantly produced Onchocerca volvulus antigens : Ov-FAR-1, Ov-API-1, Ov-MSA-1, and Ov-CPI-1. The LIPS assay was tested on a large cohort of sera from uninfected controls and patients with proven parasitic infections, including Onchocerca volvulus, Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, Strongyloides stercoralis, and other potentially cross-reactive infections. The results showed that antibody responses to the four different Onchocerca volvulus antigens allowed for unequivocal differentiation between Onchocerca volvulus-infected and uninfected control sera with 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity. The use of a mixture of the four antigens simultaneously in the standard format or a quick 15-minute format ( QLIPS ) showed 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity in distinguishing Onchocerca volvulus-infected sera from uninfected control sera. The QLIPS format had the best performance with 100% sensitivity and specificity values of 76%, 84%, and 93% for distinguishing Onchocerca volvulus from Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Strongyloides stercoralis-infected sera, respectively. The multi-antigen LIPS assay can be used as a rapid, high-throughput, and specific tool for diagnosing individual Onchocerca volvulus infections and for early detection of recrudescent infections in areas under control and for mapping new areas of transmission of Onchocerca volvulus infection.
A 54-month iron-folic acid and de-worming program was implemented in a rural population of women in northern Vietnam to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing anemia, iron deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and soil-transmitted helminth infections. The program involved weekly iron-folic acid supplementation and regular de-worming. A prospective cohort design was used to assess the impact of the program on mean hemoglobin levels and the prevalence of anemia, iron deficiency, and soil-transmitted helminth infection. The study enrolled 389 women aged 16-45 years prior to the intervention. After 54 months, 76% of participants were taking the iron-folic acid supplement and 95% had taken the most recent deworming treatment. The mean hemoglobin level increased from 122 g/L to 131 g/L, and anemia prevalence decreased from 38% to 18%. Iron deficiency fell from 23% to 8%, and iron deficiency anemia was reduced to 4%. The prevalence of hookworm infection decreased from 76% to 11%, and the level of moderate or heavy infestation of any soil-transmitted helminth was reduced to less than 1%. The results indicate that population-based interventions can efficiently and effectively reduce anemia and practically eliminate iron deficiency anemia and moderate to heavy soil-transmitted helminth infections, maintaining them below the level of public health concern.
The Epstein-Barr Virus Glycoprotein gp150 Forms an Immune-Evasive Glycan Shield at the Surface of Infected Cells
    The Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) exploits immune evasion strategies to persist and produce virus in the face of primed immunity. A novel, broadly acting immunoevasin, gp150, is expressed during the late phase of viral replication and inhibits antigen presentation by HLA class I, HLA class II, and the non-classical, lipid-presenting CD1d molecules. The mechanism of gp150-mediated T-cell escape does not depend on degradation of the antigen-presenting molecules nor does it require gp150’s cytoplasmic tail. Instead, gp150 creates a shield that impedes surface presentation of antigen through its abundant glycosylation. This is an unprecedented immune evasion mechanism for herpesviruses. B cells infected with a gp150-null mutant EBV displayed rescued levels of surface antigen presentation by HLA class I, HLA class II, and CD1d, supporting an important role for iNKT cells next to classical T cells in fighting EBV infection. EBV gp150 prolongs the timespan for producing viral offspring at the most vulnerable stage of the viral life cycle. This mechanism is novel in herpesvirus biology and further supports the notion that herpesviruses use diverse ways to achieve escape not only from T cells, but also from iNKT cell immunity. EBV gp150 is encoded by the BDLF3 gene, which is unique to EBV and the closely related Rhesus lymphocryptovirus (LCV). The study provides evidence that gp150 shields the recognition of surface molecules in a glycan-dependent manner, representing a novel immune evasion mechanism in herpesviruses.
The translocated actin recruiting phosphoprotein (Tarp) is a conserved protein among all pathogenic chlamydial species, including Chlamydia trachomatis, Chlamydia caviae, and Chlamydia muridarum. A peptide antiserum specific to the Tarp actin binding domain was generated and shown to inhibit actin polymerization in vitro and Chlamydia trachomatis entry in vivo, indicating an essential role for Tarp in chlamydial pathogenesis. Sequence analysis of Tarp orthologs from multiple chlamydial species and Chlamydia trachomatis serovars revealed multiple putative actin binding sites. In vitro polymerization assays demonstrated that Chlamydial Tarps harbored variable numbers of actin binding sites and promoted actin nucleation. These findings indicate that Tarp-mediated actin binding and nucleation is a conserved feature among diverse chlamydial species and plays a critical role in bacterial invasion of host cells. The Tarp actin binding domain is present in all examined strains and is essential for Chlamydia trachomatis invasion. The mechanism of Tarp actin nucleation appears to be distinct from known eukaryotic actin nucleators. Furthermore, a peptide antiserum targeting the actin binding domain prevented Tarp-mediated actin nucleation and reduced host cell susceptibility to chlamydial infection when delivered into host cells. These results suggest that the actin nucleating activity of Tarp is required for Chlamydia trachomatis invasion.
A novel procedure, the formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation-digestion (FEA-SD) technique, has been developed for the precise quantification of Schistosoma japonicum eggs in bovine feces. This technique is essential for determining the prevalence and intensity of S. japonicum in mammalian hosts, which is crucial for calculating transmission rates and assessing environmental contamination. The FEA-SD method involves filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion, and centrifugation steps prior to microscopy, allowing for improved visualization of S. japonicum eggs. This technique is particularly useful for identifying and quantifying S. japonicum eggs in fecal samples from naturally infected Chinese water buffaloes and carabao (water buffalo) in the Philippines. The FEA-SD method removes nearly 70% of debris from the fecal samples, rendering the remaining debris translucent and facilitating accurate microscopic visualization of S. japonicum eggs. This technique has been shown to be as efficient as real-time PCR (qPCR) for determining schistosome prevalence in bovines but is less costly to implement. The FEA-SD method has the potential to be a valuable surveillance tool for animal reservoirs of S. japonicum, particularly in areas with low to high infection intensity or where schistosomiasis japonica is suspected to be eliminated following control efforts.
Mutations in the genes encoding cartilage-associated protein (CRTAP) and prolyl 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1) are the first identified causes of recessive Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI). These proteins, along with cyclophilin B, form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a single proline residue on the α1(I) chain and has cis/trans isomerase activity essential for proper collagen folding. Recent data suggest that prolyl 3-hydroxylation of Pro986 is not required for the structural stability of collagen, but its absence may disrupt protein-protein interactions integral for proper collagen folding and lead to collagen over-modification. A novel mouse model, Lepre1H662A/H662A, was generated with a knock-in mutation in the catalytic domain of P3H1, inactivating its 3-hydroxylase activity and causing loss of 3-Hyp at Pro986 in the collagen α1(I) chain of bone and a reduction to 9% 3-Hyp at Pro986 in the α1(II) chain of cartilage. The mice showed decreased trabecular bone mass but no significant over-modification at other collagen residues. This new model recapitulates elements of the bone phenotype of OI but not the cartilage and growth phenotypes caused by loss of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex. The results suggest differential tissue consequences due to selective inactivation of P3H1 hydroxylase activity versus complete ablation of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex. The findings highlight the importance of this complex in collagen modification and maintenance of bone mass.
The P-element, a selfish genetic element, has invaded Drosophila simulans, a species closely related to Drosophila melanogaster. This invasion is associated with a hybrid dysgenesis-like phenotype, characterized by abnormal phenotypes such as sterility, in the offspring of crosses between D. simulans strains. A survey of 181 strains revealed that approximately 20% of strains induce hybrid dysgenesis. Genomic and transcriptomic data indicate that the P-element is responsible for this dysgenesis-inducing phenotype. The invasion of the P-element in D. simulans occurred rapidly and nearly simultaneously across three continents, with strains containing the P-element being rare in 2006 and common by 2014. Strains collected from the latter phase of the invasion have adapted to suppress the worst effects of the P-element, as evidenced by their resistance to the hybrid dysgenesis phenotype. In comparison to D. melanogaster, the spread of the P-element in D. simulans is surprisingly fast. Both D. simulans and D. melanogaster have evolved to suppress the dysgenesis phenotype by the end of the invasion, suggesting strong selection to ameliorate the P-element's effects. The study highlights the evolutionary challenge posed by selfish elements and the rapid adaptation of species to mitigate their impact.
The use of rhodamine B to mark the body and seminal fluid of male Aedes aegypti for mark-release-recapture experiments and estimating the efficacy of sterile male releases has been investigated. Rhodamine B, a thiol-reactive fluorescent dye, was administered via sugar-feeding to males at concentrations of 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.8% (w/v) in 50% honey solutions during free flight. The results showed that all concentrations produced >95% transfer to females and successful body marking after 4 days of feeding, with 0.4 and 0.8% solutions producing the longest-lasting body marking. Importantly, rhodamine B marking had no effect on male mating competitiveness and proof-of-principle field releases demonstrated successful transfer of marked seminal fluid to females under field conditions and recapture of marked males. These results suggest that rhodamine B is a potentially useful evaluation method for male-based Sterile Insect Technique (SIT) and Incompatible Insect Technique (IIT) control strategies. Additionally, rhodamine B marking is a viable body marking technique for male-based mark-release-recapture experiments without the negative side-effects of traditional marking methods. Compared to other methods, such as PCR and stable isotope semen labeling, rhodamine B marking is less expensive and less time-consuming.
Bacterial superantigens, a diverse family of toxins, induce an inflammatory cytokine storm that can lead to lethal shock by binding to the T cell receptor and major histocompatibility class II molecule on antigen-presenting cells. However, a new study reveals that superantigens must also bind directly to the CD28 homodimer interface on T cells to elicit toxicity. CD28 is a costimulatory molecule that plays a crucial role in the immune response, and its interaction with superantigens is essential for the induction of Th1 cytokine genes that mediate lethal shock. The study shows that blocking access of superantigens to CD28 is sufficient to block lethal toxic shock, and that peptide mimetics of the CD28 dimer interface can inhibit the induction of Th1 cytokines and protect mice from lethal superantigen exposure. Furthermore, the study identifies a conserved β-strand/hinge/α-helix domain in superantigens that is essential for binding to CD28. Structural analysis reveals that CD28 can be accommodated as a third receptor in the quaternary complex formed by the superantigen, T cell receptor, and major histocompatibility class II molecule. The findings of this study highlight the critical role of CD28 as a receptor for superantigen toxins and broaden the scope of pathogen recognition mechanisms.
The Wnt/Tcf1 pathway plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle and proliferation of mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs). Unlike its mitogenic effect in somatic cells, the Wnt/β-catenin pathway triggers an anti-proliferative effect in mESCs through the activation of the Ink4/Arf tumor suppressor locus. The Wnt-effector Tcf1 is recruited to the promoter of cell cycle repressor genes, such as p15Ink4b, p16Ink4a, and p19Arf, which mediate the Wnt-dependent anti-proliferative effect in mESCs. This effect is dependent on β-catenin and Tcf1, but not Tcf3, indicating specialized and non-overlapping functions of Tcf/Lef factors in mESCs. Activation of the Wnt pathway results in the downregulation of some cell differentiation genes, while the expression of pluripotency genes remains unperturbed. Tcf1 recruitment is enriched at the promoters of cell cycle genes, including the Ink4/Arf locus. Furthermore, GSK3 inhibition or β-catenin stabilization transcriptionally regulates the expression of the Ink4 and Arf family members in a Tcf3-independent manner. The Wnt/β-catenin pathway induces an increased expression of negative regulators of the cell cycle, such as the tumour suppressors Cdkn2a and Cdkn2b. These findings demonstrate that the Wnt/Tcf1 pathway restricts embryonic stem cell cycle through the activation of the Ink4/Arf locus.
This study investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) in the immune response to dengue virus (DENV) infection. pDCs are innate immune cells that produce interferon-alpha (IFN-α) and express membrane TRAIL (mTRAIL) in response to viral exposure. The study found that pDCs from mild dengue patients exhibited higher frequencies of mTRAIL expression compared to severe cases or healthy controls. Plasma levels of IFN-α and soluble TRAIL were also increased in mild dengue patients, positively correlating with pDC activation. In vitro experiments showed that exposure to DENV-2 induced mTRAIL expression on pDCs and relocalized TRAIL from the intracellular compartment to the plasma membrane. Chloroquine treatment inhibited DENV-2-induced mTRAIL relocalization and IFN-α production by pDCs, suggesting that endocytosis is involved in DENV-2 activation of pDCs. Coculture of pDCs with DENV-2-infected monocytes revealed a decrease in antigen detection, which was also observed after exogenous IFN-α treatment. The study suggests that pDCs play an antiviral role in DENV-2 infection and that TRAIL-expressing pDCs may contribute to the outcome of the disease. The results indicate that pDC activation is associated with mild dengue fever and that IFN-α and TRAIL levels are positively correlated with pDC activation.
Differences in Reactivation of Tuberculosis Induced from Anti-TNF Treatments Are Based on Bioavailability in Granulomatous Tissue
    A computational study investigated the role of tumor necrosis factor (TNF) in host defense against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) in both active and latent phases of infection. TNF-neutralizing drugs used to treat inflammatory disorders have been linked to an increased risk of tuberculosis (TB) in animal studies. The study extended previous mathematical models to examine the roles and production of soluble (sTNF) and transmembrane TNF (tmTNF) in TB control and pathology. Virtual clinical trials (VCTs) were simulated to analyze the effects of two commonly used anti-TNF therapies: anti-TNF antibody and TNF receptor fusion. The results showed that bioavailability of TNF following anti-TNF therapy is the primary factor causing reactivation of latent infection, and that sTNF, even at low levels, is essential for controlling infection. The study suggests that a TNF-modulating agent could be developed to balance the reduction of inflammation with the need to maintain resistance to infection. Alternatively, the dose and timing of anti-TNF therapy could be modified to minimize the risk of TB reactivation. The findings also indicate that anti-TNF therapy will likely lead to numerous incidents of primary TB if used in areas where exposure to Mtb is likely. The study provides insights into the mechanisms of action of anti-TNF treatments and the role of TNF in TB control and pathology.
This study investigated inter-population differences in retrogene loss and expression in humans using data from the 1000 Genomes Project and RNA-Seq data from the Geuvadis Consortium. The researchers developed a new approach to detect novel retrocopies absent from the reference human genome and experimentally confirmed the existence of 193 retroduplication variations ( RDVs ), the majority of which resulted from retrocopy deletion. Most of these RDVs had not been previously reported. The study found that the frequency of retrocopy absence was low for the majority of retrogenes, with only a few showing absence in more than 50% of individuals. In contrast, new retropositions were expected to have absence close to 100% of alleles in at least some populations. The researchers also examined retrocopy expression levels and found 9 retrogenes that underwent statistically significant differential expression between populations. Furthermore, they experimentally confirmed the expression of 11 ancestral retrogenes that underwent deletion in certain individuals. The expression, conservation, and low rate of deletion of these retrocopies may suggest some functionality. The study highlights the potential of retrocopy polymorphisms as markers for human population history and ongoing evolutionary processes, and provides new insights into the functional implications of retrocopy variation.
This study investigated the relationship between the location of Taenia solium cysticerci in the brain and the inflammatory response to praziquantel treatment in pigs with neurocysticercosis (NCC). The researchers analyzed 196 histological specimens from 11 pigs naturally infected with T. solium cysticerci, comparing the inflammatory responses to cysticerci located in the brain parenchyma, meninges, or both tissues. The results showed that cysticerci in the parenchyma provoked a significantly greater level of pericystic inflammation after treatment compared to those in the meninges or corticomeningeal locations. The inflammatory score (ISC) of meningeal cysticerci was not significantly affected by treatment, while the increase in ISC score in corticomeningeal cysticerci was correlated to the extent of the cysticercus adjacent to the brain parenchyma. Disruption of the blood-brain barrier was associated with treatment only in parenchymal tissue. The inflammatory response to cysticerci located in the meninges was significantly decreased compared to parenchymal cysticerci. These findings suggest that the location of T. solium cysticerci in the brain influences the inflammatory response to praziquantel treatment, which may explain why subarachnoid NCC is generally refractory to treatment compared to parenchymal NCC. The study highlights the importance of considering the location of cysticerci in the brain when developing treatment strategies for NCC.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in 30 communities in two districts of Ghana where mass drug administration (MDA) of azithromycin for trachoma control had previously been implemented. The study aimed to investigate the presence of yaws, a treponemal infection caused by Treponema pallidum ssp. pertenue, in these communities. Children aged 5-17 years with ulcerative lesions compatible with yaws were enrolled, and samples were collected for treponemal serology and lesion PCR. A total of 90 children with 98 lesions were enrolled, and syphilis serology was negative in all of them. PCR for T. pallidum ssp. pertenue was negative in all children, but Haemophilus ducreyi DNA was detected in 9 lesions. The study found no evidence of ongoing transmission of yaws in these communities, which had previously been treated for trachoma. The results suggest that H. ducreyi may be associated with a proportion of skin lesions, but the majority of lesions remain unexplained. The study highlights the need for integration of diagnostic testing into both pre- and post-MDA surveillance systems to better inform yaws control programs. The findings have implications for the World Health Organization's (WHO) yaws eradication campaign, which relies on mass distribution of azithromycin.
Despite the effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in treating HIV infection, the persistence of the virus in the body remains a significant challenge. T cell homeostasis is a major driver of HIV persistence, and cytokines involved in regulating memory T cell homeostasis trigger the Jak-STAT pathway. Two FDA-approved Jak inhibitors, tofacitinib and ruxolitinib, were evaluated for their ability to block the seeding and maintenance of the HIV reservoir in vitro.
