The results showed that PrPSc from each strain had a distinct pattern of cell specificity, with strain 22L mainly associated with astroglia, strain ME7 mainly associated with neurons and neuropil, and strain RML showing a mixed pattern depending on the brain region.

The study also examined the expression of 90 genes involved in neuroinflammation in the thalamus of infected mice at preclinical times. Surprisingly, despite the differences in PrPSc accumulation, the pattern of upregulated genes was similar for all three strains, and the small differences observed correlated with variations in the early disease tempo. Gene upregulation was associated with activation of both astroglia and microglia detected in early disease prior to vacuolar pathology or clinical signs. The profile of upregulated genes in scrapie differed markedly from that seen in two acute viral CNS diseases, LaCrosse virus and BE polytropic Friend retrovirus, which had reactive gliosis at levels similar to the prion-infected mice.
The 3D organization of chromosomes plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression and cell function. To understand the mechanistic principles behind chromosome folding, researchers have developed polymer models and simulation methods to investigate the multi-spatio-temporal scales of chromosomes. However, chromosomes are long and densely packed, making it challenging to develop adequate models and simulation methods. To address this issue, the authors proposed a generic strategy to develop efficient coarse-grained models for self-avoiding polymers on a lattice. The model accurately accounts for the polymer entanglement length and volumic density, capturing the steady-state structural and dynamical properties of the system. This approach offers a strong power-law gain in numerical efficiency and allows for the study of long chromosomes during an extended time period with good statistics. The authors applied this strategy to investigate the 3D organization of chromosome 3R (20 Mbp) in drosophila during one cell cycle (20 hours). The results show that a combination of the coarse-graining strategy with a one-parameter block copolymer model integrating epigenomic-driven interactions quantitatively reproduces experimental data at the chromosome-scale and predicts that chromatin motion is very dynamic during the cell cycle. The study demonstrates the utility of the coarse-graining approach to study chromatin organization in drosophila and highlights the importance of accounting for the time evolution of chromosome organization in quantitative models.
The article presents an integrative modeling approach to understand the mechanisms underlying cell type specificity of expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs). eQTLs are genetic variants that influence the quantity and spatiotemporal distribution of gene transcription. The authors analyzed eQTL data from eleven studies on seven cell types and integrated it with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from the ENCODE project. They found that eQTL SNPs overlap with hundreds of cell type-specific CRE classes, including enhancer, promoter, and repressive chromatin marks, regions of open chromatin, and DNA binding proteins. These associations provide insight into the molecular mechanisms generating cell type specificity of eQTLs and the mode of regulation of corresponding eQTLs. Using a random forest classifier with cell-specific CRE-SNP overlap as features, the authors demonstrated the feasibility of predicting the cell type specificity of eQTLs. Furthermore, they showed that CREs from a trait-associated cell type can be used to annotate GWAS associations in the absence of eQTL data for that cell type. This approach has the potential to improve our understanding of the mechanistic basis of human complex phenotypic variation. The study highlights the importance of integrating eQTL data with CRE data to understand the cell type specificity of eQTLs and to predict the function of GWAS SNPs with phenotypes relevant to cell types lacking eQTL data.
The development of a stable Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cell line that limits N-linked glycosylation to mannose-5 (Man5) or earlier intermediates has been achieved using the CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing system. This cell line, referred to as MGAT1− CHO, contains a mutation that inactivates the gene encoding Mannosyl (Alpha-1,3-)-Glycoprotein Beta-1,2-N-Acetylglucosaminyltransferase (MGAT1), a key enzyme in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. As a result, monomeric gp120s produced in the MGAT1− CHO cell line exhibit improved binding to prototypic glycan-dependent broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bN-mAbs) directed to the V1/V2 domain and the V3 stem, while preserving the structure of glycan-independent epitopes. The MGAT1− CHO cell line maintains a normal doubling time and ability to grow at high cell densities, making it a suitable substrate for the biopharmaceutical production of HIV-1 vaccine immunogens. The development of this cell line addresses the challenge of producing vaccine immunogens that display early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway, which are critical for binding to glycan-dependent bN-mAbs. This achievement has significant implications for the design and manufacture of HIV vaccines, particularly those targeting glycan-dependent epitopes.
The structure of trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase (T6PP) from Brugia malayi, a parasitic nematode responsible for lymphatic filariasis, has been determined using X-ray crystallography. T6PP is essential for nematode survival due to the toxic effects of trehalose 6-phosphate accumulation. The protein structure consists of a stabilizing N-terminal MIT-like domain and a catalytic C-terminal C2B-type HAD phosphatase fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses identified five residues crucial for binding and catalysis. A proposed model of the T6PP-trehalose 6-phosphate complex suggests a substrate-binding mode driven by shape complementarity and van der Waals interactions. This is in contrast to the homolog sucrose-6-phosphate phosphatase, which relies on extensive hydrogen-bond interactions. The results indicate that high-affinity inhibitors will be bi-dentate, utilizing substrate-like binding to the phosphoryl-binding pocket and non-native binding to the trehalose pocket. The conservation of key residues in T6PP enzymes from parasitic nematodes and pathogenic bacteria suggests a common strategy for inhibitor design, potentially leading to the development of broad-range anthelmintic and antibacterial therapeutics. A model of the T6PP-trehalose 6-phosphate complex was constructed using molecular dynamics simulations, providing a platform for inhibitor design.
A novel computational framework has been developed to simulate vascular blood flow and interstitial fluid transport in whole, heterogeneous tumours. This framework incorporates realistic tumour vasculature and spatially heterogeneous blood vessel lumen and interstitial permeabilities to generate accurate predictions of tumour fluid dynamics. The model couples Poiseuille and Darcy descriptions of vascular and interstitial flow, respectively, and enables highly-controlled experiments to be performed to investigate how tumour vascular heterogeneity contributes to tumour fluid transport. The framework was applied to an orthotopic murine glioma and a human colorectal carcinoma, and sensitivity analysis was performed to gain an understanding of the key biological mechanisms that determine tumour fluid transport. The results showed that incorporating realistic tumour vasculature is crucial for accurately predicting spatial flow heterogeneities induced by blood vessels. Furthermore, the study found that reducing tumour interstitial fluid pressure is not necessary to increase tumour interstitial perfusion, and that developing an interstitial fluid pressure gradient across the tumour is the key response. Vascular normalization was also found to alter interstitial hydraulic conductivity within tumours, suggesting that normalizing the interstitial microenvironment may provide a more effective means to increase interstitial perfusion within tumours.
HIV-1 can spread through both cell-free and cell-cell transmission modes, but the relative importance of cell-cell transmission in natural infection and its vulnerability to inhibition by neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors is not well understood. To address this knowledge gap, researchers used tailored experimental strategies to investigate the activity of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) and entry inhibitors during cell-cell transmission. The study found that the activity of these inhibitors varies depending on their mode of action. Specifically, gp41-directed agents remained active, while CD4 binding site (CD4bs)-directed inhibitors, including the potent neutralizing mAb VRC01, lost potency during cell-cell transmission. This suggests that CD4bs mAbs preferentially block free virus transmission, allowing HIV to spread through cell-cell contacts. The findings provide a plausible explanation for how HIV maintains infectivity and rapidly escapes potent and broadly active CD4bs-directed antibody responses in vivo. The study highlights the need to consider the efficacy of entry inhibitors and neutralizing antibodies in blocking cell-cell transmission, which is a critical aspect of HIV infection in vivo. The results have implications for the design of neutralizing antibody-based HIV vaccines and entry inhibitors, as it remains uncertain whether both cell-free and cell-cell spread of HIV must be blocked with equal efficacy or if only the dominant transmission mode needs to be targeted.
The article proposes a feedback model of attention that explains the diverse effects of attention on neural firing rates and receptive field structure in the visual system. The model suggests that attentional modulation targets higher levels of the visual system, such as V4 or MT, rather than input areas like V1. The proposed mechanism requires the existence of modulatory feedback connections between areas and short-range lateral inhibition within each area. Feedback connections redistribute the top-down modulation to lower areas, altering the inputs of other higher-area cells, including those that did not receive the initial modulation. This produces firing rate modulations and receptive field shifts. Simultaneously, short-range lateral inhibition between neighboring cells produces competitive effects that are automatically scaled to receptive field size in any given area. The model reproduces the observed attentional effects on response rates and receptive field structure without modifying model parameters. It also makes the novel prediction that attentional effects on response curves should shift from response gain to contrast gain as the spatial focus of attention drifts away from the studied cell. The model suggests that the observed effects of attention arise spontaneously from the interaction of feedback connections between higher and lower areas with short-range divisive mutual inhibition between neighboring cells within each area. The source of attentional modulation in the model is a plain response modulation of the top layer, which models the intermediate layers of the visual cortex.
The Drosophila posterior signalling centre (PSC) plays a crucial role in controlling hemocyte homeostasis in the larval hematopoietic organ, the lymph gland. The PSC acts in a non-cell-autonomous manner to maintain janus tyrosine kinase/signal transducers and activators of transcription (JAK/STAT) signalling in hematopoietic progenitors, preserving their multipotent character necessary for differentiation into lamellocytes, a specific immune cell type required to fight wasp parasitism. A short type I cytokine-related receptor, CG14225/Latran, has been identified as essential for switching off JAK/STAT signalling in prohemocytes, allowing for massive differentiation of lamellocytes upon wasp parasitization. Latran forms heteromers with Domeless, the Drosophila type I cytokine signalling receptor, and antagonizes Domeless activity in a dose-dependent manner. In response to wasp parasitism, there is a strong decrease in cytokine mRNA levels in the lymph gland, followed by an increase in the Latran/Domeless ratio. This sequence of events leads to the complete inhibition of residual JAK/STAT signalling by Latran. The specific function of Drosophila Latran is the first in vivo example of a role for a non-signalling receptor in controlling a dedicated immune response, raising the question of whether short, non-signalling receptors also control specific aspects of vertebrate cellular immunity. JAK/STAT activity has been associated with several human diseases, including leukaemia, and knock-out studies in mice point to a central role of this pathway in hematopoiesis and regulation of immune functions.
This study investigated the recombination patterns of two begomoviruses, Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV) and Tomato leaf curl Comoros virus (ToLCV), during a 120-day experimental infection of tomato plants. The results show that the recombination patterns between these viruses can be highly complex, with some recombinant genomes containing up to 58 detectable recombination breakpoints. The study found that local degrees of sequence similarity, but not genomic secondary structure, strongly influence the location of recombination breakpoints. Additionally, natural selection plays a significant role in shaping the overall patterns of recombination, favoring the preservation of co-evolved protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions. The study also found that selection against recombinants with disrupted intra-genomic interactions, such as those required for proper protein and nucleic acid folding, is strong. Furthermore, the study demonstrates that the imprint of selection favoring the preservation of co-evolved longer-range protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions can be used to identify the exact sequence tracts involved in these interactions. The findings of this study provide new insights into the mechanisms of recombination in begomoviruses and highlight the importance of selection in shaping the evolution of these viruses. The study's results also have implications for understanding the emergence of begomoviral crop pathogens, which have been attributed to natural inter-species recombination.
This study investigates the relationship between nucleosome footprints and sequence evolution in eukaryotes and archaea. Nucleosomes, the basic repeat units of eukaryotic chromatin, have been suggested to influence the evolution of eukaryotic genomes by altering the propensity of DNA to mutate and by selection acting to maintain or exclude nucleosomes in particular locations. Contrary to the popular idea that nucleosomes are unique to eukaryotes, histone proteins have also been discovered in some archaeal genomes. Despite fundamental differences between eukaryotic and archaeal nucleosomes, the association between nucleosome footprints and sequence evolution is strikingly conserved between humans and the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii. The study examines whether selection or mutation can explain concordant substitution patterns in the two kingdoms and finds that neither the mutation nor the selection model are sufficient to explain the observed association. Instead, the study demonstrates that nucleosome-associated substitution patterns are more consistent with a third model where sequence divergence results in frequent repositioning of nucleosomes during evolution. The study shows that nucleosome repositioning is both necessary and largely sufficient to explain the association between current nucleosome positions and biased substitution patterns. This finding highlights the importance of considering the direction of causality between genetic and epigenetic change.
The conformational diversity of a protein’s native state plays a crucial role in modulating its function. The selection paradigm suggests that different ligands shift the conformational equilibrium by binding to the protein’s highest-affinity conformers. A novel procedure has been developed to identify key positions that sustain conformational diversity associated with ligand binding. This method involves normal mode analysis of a coarse-grained protein model to explore conformational features. The procedure was applied to a refined dataset of 188 paired protein structures in their bound and unbound forms. The results show a negative correlation between the effects of mutations on normal mode subspaces associated with ligand binding and position-specific evolutionary conservations obtained from multiple sequence-structure alignments. Positions whose mutations alter these subspaces the most are defined as key positions, which are dynamically important residues that mediate the ligand-binding conformational change. These positions are found to be evolutionary conserved and are mostly buried aliphatic residues localized in regular structural regions of the protein, such as β-sheets and α-helix. The findings suggest that these key positions are essential for the evolutionary conservation of protein conformational diversity required for ligand binding. The results provide new insights into the relationship between protein structure, dynamics, and function, and highlight the importance of conformational diversity in protein-ligand interactions.
The study investigated the role of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate aldolase (FBA) in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) by engineering an Mtb strain with regulated FBA levels. Depletion of FBA resulted in clearance of Mtb in both acute and chronic phases of infection in vivo and loss of viability in vitro when cultured on single carbon sources. However, the essentiality of FBA could be overcome when cultured on mixtures of glycolytic and gluconeogenic carbon sources, enabling the generation of an fba knockout (Δfba) strain. In vitro studies of Δfba revealed that lack of FBA could only be compensated for by a specific balance of glucose and butyrate, where growth and metabolism of butyrate were dependent on Mtb's ability to co-catabolize glucose. These findings suggest that FBA is a potential drug target in both replicating and persistent Mtb. The study expands our understanding of the multiplicity of in vitro conditions that define the essentiality of Mtb's FBA in vivo. The results have implications for the development of new chemotherapies for tuberculosis, as Mtb mutants lacking metabolic enzymes are among the most attenuated in the mouse model of tuberculosis.
The study investigated the role of the mitochondrial 2-Cys peroxiredoxin (mTXNPx) in Leishmania infantum, a parasite that causes leishmaniasis. Leishmania lacks catalase and selenium-glutathione peroxidases, and mTXNPx is one of the enzymes responsible for peroxide removal in this organism. The researchers generated mTXNPx null mutants (mtxnpx−) and found that they were unable to thrive in a murine model of infection. However, the avirulent phenotype of mtxnpx− was not due to the lack of peroxidase activity of mTXNPx, as these mutants behaved like controls when exposed to oxidants added exogenously or generated by macrophages during phagocytosis ex vivo. Furthermore, mtxnpx− were also avirulent when inoculated into murine hosts unable to mount an effective oxidative phagocyte response. To definitively conclude that the peroxidase activity of mTXNPx is not required for parasite survival in mice, a peroxidase-inactive version of this protein was used to rescue the non-infective phenotype of mtxnpx−. The results suggest that mTXNPx has a novel function as a molecular chaperone, which may explain the impaired infectivity of the null mutants. This premise is based on the observation that the enzyme is able to suppress the thermal aggregation of citrate synthase in vitro. The findings change the paradigm that regards all trypanosomatid 2-Cys peroxiredoxins as peroxide-eliminating devices and demonstrate that these enzymes can be determinant for pathogenicity independently of their peroxidase activity.
The study aimed to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of the Histoplasma urine antigen (HUAg) test, specifically the IMMY ALPHA Histoplasma EIA, for progressive disseminated histoplasmosis (PDH) in HIV-infected patients. A multicenter, prospective diagnostic test study was conducted in two secondary and eight tertiary-care facilities in Mexico, including 288 HIV patients with suspected PDH. The reference standard for diagnosis was Histoplasma capsulatum growth on blood, bone marrow, and tissue cultures or compatible histopathologic examination. The results showed that 29.5% of patients had PDH, with a sensitivity of 67.1% and specificity of 97.5% for the HUAg test. The positive likelihood ratio was 27.2. In 10.5% of PDH-proven patients, a co-existing opportunistic infection was diagnosed, mostly disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection. The study found a high specificity but low sensitivity of the IMMY-HUAg test, suggesting that while it may be useful for starting early antifungal treatment, a culture-based approach is necessary due to frequent co-infections. The results are consistent with previous studies, which have reported varying sensitivities and specificities for different HUAg tests. The study highlights the importance of considering co-infections when diagnosing PDH in HIV-infected patients and the need for a culture-based approach to confirm diagnosis.
Title: Metagenomic Analysis of Human Diarrhea: Viral Detection and Discovery
    Summary: 
    Diarrhea is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide, with approximately 1. 8 million deaths annually. However, in up to 40% of cases, no etiologic agent can be identified. Metagenomic sequencing offers a systematic and unbiased approach to characterizing microbial populations, including viruses, in stool during episodes of acute diarrhea. This study employed a “micro-mass sequencing” strategy to analyze eukaryotic viral communities in diarrhea specimens from 12 children. The approach involved minimal starting sample quantity ( <100 mg stool ), minimal sample purification, and limited sequencing ( 384 reads per sample ). The results revealed known enteric viruses as well as multiple sequences from putatively novel viruses with limited sequence similarity to viruses in GenBank. This study demonstrates the potential of micro-mass sequencing to define the diversity of viral communities found in fecal samples from diarrhea patients. The findings provide a foundation for future studies to assess whether novel or unexpected viruses detected play a causal role in human diarrhea. This research expands on previous metagenomic studies of human stool, which have been limited to analysis of a few specimens from healthy patients. The results of this study will serve as a springboard for further investigations into the roles of diverse viruses in the gastrointestinal tract.
Zika and dengue outbreaks in the Dominican Republic were compared using national surveillance data from 2015 to 2016. The study found that dengue cases were predominantly reported in individuals under 20 years old, with 75% of cases occurring in this age group. In contrast, Zika infections were more evenly distributed among the population. Dengue attack rates were higher in males (25.9 per 10,000 population) compared to females (21.5 per 10,000 population), while Zika infections were more common in females (7.64 per 10,000 population) compared to males (2.72 per 10,000 population). The reproductive number (R0) calculations also showed a significantly higher metric among females for Zika (1.84) compared to males (1.72). Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) attack rates were slightly higher in males (0.62 per 10,000 population) compared to females (0.57 per 10,000 population). The study found little evidence that existing dengue immunity affected Zika attack rates at the population level. However, sex-specific over-reporting may have confounded R0 and incident risk calculations. The findings suggest that community awareness campaigns may have influenced increased reporting among women of reproductive age, although biological susceptibility cannot be ruled out. Therefore, media campaigns and screening are recommended for women of reproductive age during Zika outbreaks. Future research should focus on clinical Zika outcomes among dengue seropositive individuals.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, poly ( ADP-ribose ) polymerase 2 ( PARP2 ) is the predominant enzyme responsible for poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation in response to DNA damage and immune responses. Unlike in animals, where poly ( ADP-ribose ) polymerase 1 ( PARP1 ) accounts for more than 90% of overall cellular PARP activity, PARP2 makes the greatest contribution to PARP activity and organismal viability in Arabidopsis in response to genotoxic stresses caused by bleomycin, mitomycin C or gamma-radiation. Plant PARP2 proteins carry SAP DNA binding motifs rather than the zinc finger domains common in plant and animal PARP1 proteins. PARP2 also makes stronger contributions than PARP1 to plant immune responses, including restriction of pathogenic Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato growth and reduction of infection-associated DNA double-strand break abundance. In contrast, poly ( ADP-ribose ) glycohydrolase 1 ( PARG1 ) is the major contributor to poly ( ADP-ribose ) removal from acceptor proteins in Arabidopsis. The activity or abundance of PARP2 is influenced by PARP1 and PARG1, which physically interact with each other and with PARG2. These findings suggest that core aspects of plant poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation are mediated by substantially different enzymes than in animals, indicating the likelihood of substantial differences in regulation. The results also indicate that PARP1 and PARP2 both contribute to poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation, but that PARP2 is the primary Arabidopsis enzyme responsible for poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation activity in response to DNA damage.
In C. elegans, the Pam/Highwire/RPM-1 ( PHR ) proteins regulate synapse formation and axon termination. The PHR protein RPM-1 acts as a ubiquitin ligase to inhibit the DLK-1 and MLK-1 MAP kinase pathways. A new MAP kinase pathway has been identified that suppresses synapse formation defects in rpm-1 mutants, but not axon termination defects, in mechanosensory neurons. This pathway includes MIG-15 ( MAP4K ), NSY-1 ( MAP3K ), JKK-1 ( MAP2K ), and JNK-1 ( MAPK ). The MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway functions cell autonomously in mechanosensory neurons and localizes to presynaptic terminals, suggesting a role in synapse development. Transgenic overexpression of kinases in the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway impairs synapse formation in wild-type animals. Loss of MIG-15/JNK-1 signaling suppresses defects in habituation to repeated mechanical stimuli in rpm-1 mutants, a behavioral deficit likely resulting from impaired glutamatergic synapse formation. These findings indicate that the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway restricts both glutamatergic synapse formation and short-term learning. The MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway functions as a parallel opposing pathway to RPM-1, suggesting a complex regulation of synapse formation and learning in C. elegans.
The study investigated the evolutionary change within a bipotential switch that controls the sperm/oocyte decision in hermaphroditic nematodes. A bipotential switch is a transcription factor that can activate or repress the same target gene in response to changing signals from upstream genes. The study confirmed that the sex-determination protein TRA-1 is bipotential by identifying a co-factor, TRR-1, which is required for spermatogenesis in Caenorhabditis briggsae. TRR-1 works as part of the Tip60 Histone Acetyl Transferase complex to promote the expression of Cbr-fog-3, a gene needed for spermatogenesis. Epistasis tests revealed that TRR-1 works through TRA-1 to activate Cbr-fog-3 and control the sperm/oocyte decision. The study also showed that TRR-1 regulates the development of the male tail and that Cbr-tra-2 and Cbr-trr-1 double mutants resemble Cbr-tra-1 null mutants, indicating that the two regulatory branches control all TRA-1 activity. Furthermore, the study found that the relationship between the two branches of the switch has shifted rapidly during evolution, with C. briggsae trr-1 null mutants preventing hermaphrodite spermatogenesis, while C. elegans fem null mutants prevent spermatogenesis. However, synthetic interactions confirmed that both halves of the switch exist in each species, suggesting that the same phenotype can be produced by alternative, complementary mechanisms.
The article introduces two new measures of integrated information, ΦE and ΦAR, which can be applied to time-series data to quantify the extent to which a system generates more information than the sum of its parts as it transitions between states. These measures overcome the limitations of ΦDM, a previous measure of integrated information that is defined only for discrete Markov systems, which are rare in biology. ΦE and ΦAR are designed to be easy to apply in practice and can be used to examine information integration in real and model systems. The authors use simulations to demonstrate the in-practice applicability of the new measures and explore their properties. The results provide new opportunities for examining the relationship between integrated information, consciousness, and other neurocognitive processes. However, the findings also pose challenges for theories that ascribe physical meaning to the measured quantities, such as the integrated information theory of consciousness (IITC). The IITC posits that consciousness is equivalent to integrated information and has the status of a fundamental property of the universe. The new measures of integrated information, ΦE and ΦAR, can be used to test hypotheses and specify synthetic models aimed at examining the role of integrated information in neurocognitive processes. Future work will involve empirically examining integrated information in neuroimaging and other biological datasets, investigating how integrated information is modulated by input and output relations, and determining the theoretical implications of the new measures.
A Bayesian geostatistical analysis was conducted to investigate the spatial distribution of Rhodesian human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in two recently affected districts of Uganda. The study aimed to provide a more robust evidence base for targeting control measures by accounting for spatial autocorrelation, incorporating uncertainty in input data and model parameters, and undertaking predictive mapping for risk of high HAT prevalence in the future. A generalized linear geostatistical model was used in a Bayesian framework to analyze the relationship between HAT prevalence and several social, environmental, and climatic variables. The results strongly supported the theory that Rhodesian HAT was imported to the study area via the movement of untreated, infected livestock from endemic areas. The analysis also confirmed the confounding effect of healthcare accessibility on the spatial distribution of HAT and the linkages between the disease's distribution and minimum land surface temperature. Predictive mapping indicated an increased risk of high HAT prevalence in areas surrounding livestock markets, highlighting the importance of livestock trading for continued disease spread. The study demonstrated the utility of Bayesian geostatistical modeling for predicting HAT prevalence based on external covariates and provided strengthened evidence of the role of livestock trade in the continued spread of Rhodesian HAT within Uganda. The results emphasize the need for adherence to government policy to treat livestock at the point of sale to prevent the spread of sleeping sickness in Uganda.
The feasibility of equilibria in large ecosystems has been a long-standing assumption in the complexity-stability debate. However, this assumption has not been rigorously tested. The authors of this study provide analytical results and simulations that show that equilibrium feasibility vanishes in species-rich systems. This challenges the conventional wisdom that complexity leads to stability in ecosystems. The authors extend their analysis to different interaction structures and intensities, finding that feasibility and stability are warranted in systems with weak interactions, regardless of species richness. This suggests that the interplay between interaction strength and network architecture is crucial for understanding ecosystem dynamics. The study highlights the importance of considering the feasibility of equilibria in ecological systems, particularly in species-rich communities where interactions should be moderate to ensure stability. The authors also demonstrate that network architecture plays a non-trivial role in determining equilibrium abundances, contradicting previous suggestions that topology has a minor role in system stability. Furthermore, the study shows that the probability of observing a feasible equilibrium decreases exponentially as the size of the network grows. Overall, the findings of this study underscore the need for a more nuanced understanding of ecosystem dynamics, one that takes into account the complex interplay between interaction strength, network architecture, and species richness.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in Western Kenya to investigate the sero-epidemiology of Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, in humans and cattle. Serum samples from 2049 humans and 955 cattle in 416 homesteads were analyzed for C. burnetii antibodies. The overall sero-prevalence of C. burnetii was 2.5% in humans and 10.5% in cattle. However, no correlation was found between cattle and human seroprevalence within households or when accounting for spatial proximity between households. Multilevel regression analysis revealed that cattle obtained from markets and those residing in areas with lower precipitation levels had the highest sero-prevalence. In humans, the youngest age group had the highest odds of seropositivity, and variations were observed between ethnic groups. Frequent livestock contact, specifically grazing and dealing with abortion material, was also a risk factor for human exposure. The study suggests that environmental factors may play a role in cattle exposure patterns, but human exposure patterns are likely driven more strongly by livestock contacts. The findings highlight the importance of livestock contact in the transmission of C. burnetii and indicate that livestock markets may be a suitable target for interventions. The study provides evidence of the endemicity of C. burnetii in Western Kenya, although the prevalence is relatively low.
The genome sequences of Schistosoma mansoni, a blood fluke that causes schistosomiasis, have been analyzed to identify potential targets for novel anti-schistosomal interventions. Bioinformatics analysis revealed 33 putative DEAD-box RNA helicases in the S. mansoni genome, including three vasa-like genes, Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3, which are members of the Vasa/PL10 DEAD-box subfamily. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed the vasa-like nature of these genes. Quantitative real-time PCR showed that Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3 are expressed in various developmental stages of S. mansoni, including sporocysts, adult females, eggs, and miracidia, with high expression in the undeveloped egg. Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) analysis revealed that Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3 are transcribed in the posterior ovary, where oocytes mature. The expression of these vasa-like genes in germ cell-rich tissues and organs of the adult female schistosome suggests that they may serve as informative landmarks for germ line transgenesis of schistosomes. This approach could aid in the development of novel anti-schistosomal interventions. The identification of vasa-like genes in S. mansoni highlights the potential of DEAD-box RNA helicases as targets for intervention in schistosomes. Germ cell-specific expression of these genes may provide a valuable tool for monitoring the introduction of transgenes into the schistosome germ line.
The Hippo signaling pathway plays a crucial role in organ development and tissue homeostasis, but its function in heart valve formation and maintenance was previously unknown. This study investigated the role of VGLL4, a transcriptional co-repressor in the Hippo pathway, in heart valve development and homeostasis. The results show that VGLL4 is mainly expressed in valve interstitial cells at the post-EMT stage and is maintained until the adult stage. Tissue-specific knockout of VGLL4 in different cell lineages revealed that only loss of VGLL4 in endothelial cells led to valve malformation with expanded expression of YAP targets. Furthermore, semi-knockout of YAP in VGLL4-ablated hearts significantly constrained hyperproliferation of arterial valve interstitial cells. These findings suggest that VGLL4 is essential for heart valve development and that manipulation of Hippo components may be a potential therapy for preventing the progression of congenital valve disease. The study also found that loss of VGLL4 in endothelial cells resulted in abnormal arterial valve morphology and cardiac hypertrophy in aged mice, while semi-knockout of YAP rescued heart malformation induced by VGLL4 deletion. The results identify a previously unknown function of VGLL4 in valve remodeling and homeostasis, and suggest that mutations in VGLL4 may underlie human congenital heart valve dysplasia.
Recent studies have reported the presence of soft selective sweeps in humans, Drosophila, and HIV, suggesting that positive selection acts on standing genetic variation and multiple beneficial mutations. However, other researchers have questioned the validity of these findings, arguing that soft sweeps are likely to be rare. To reconcile these opposing results, three recent studies were evaluated using population genetic theory and extensive simulation. The analysis revealed that all three examples are prone to extremely high false-positive rates, incorrectly identifying soft sweeps under both hard sweep and neutral models. Furthermore, well-fit demographic histories combined with rare hard sweeps provide a more parsimonious explanation for the observed patterns of genomic variation. The authors argue that the lack of sufficient model testing and statistical performance analyses underlying these claims of recurrent soft sweeps has led to inaccurate views of the evolutionary processes governing these organisms. The generalization of these results has resulted in misleading answers to decades-old questions in population genetics, with some suggesting a dominant role for positive selection in shaping patterns of genomic variation. The authors conclude that pervasive soft sweeps are a highly unlikely explanation for the observed patterns in humans, Drosophila, and HIV, given the highly non-equilibrium history of these organisms and the model specifics outlined by Jensen.
Female Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, the primary vector for dengue fever, exhibit inhibited host-seeking behavior for three days following a blood meal due to a hemolymph-borne humoral factor. Head Peptide-I, a candidate peptide mediating this suppression, shows sequence similarity to short Neuropeptide-F peptides (sNPFs) that signal through Neuropeptide Y (NPY)-Like Receptors (NPYLRs). The authors identified eight NPYLRs in the Ae. aegypti genome and screened them in a cell-based calcium imaging assay for sensitivity to a panel of peptides. Four NPYLRs responded to one or more peptide ligands, with NPYLR1 being the only receptor sensitive to Head Peptide-I and sNPFs. Injection of synthetic Head Peptide-I and sNPF-3 inhibited host-seeking behavior in non-blood-fed female mosquitoes. To investigate the role of NPYLR1 in host-seeking inhibition, the authors generated npylr1 null mutant strains using zinc-finger nucleases. However, npylr1 mutants displayed normal behavior, suggesting that NPYLR1 alone is not required for host-seeking inhibition. The study deorphanized four Ae. aegypti NPYLRs and identified NPYLR1 as a candidate sNPF receptor sensitive to Head Peptide-I, but other receptors, additional peptides, or both may regulate this behavior. The findings propose two models for the regulation of host-seeking behavior in Ae. aegypti.
This study aimed to identify areas with suitable conditions for schistosomiasis transmission in Akure North Local Government Area (LGA) of Ondo State, Nigeria, using satellite-derived environmental data and spatial analysis. The research employed multicriteria evaluation (MCE) and Saaty’s analytical hierarchy process (AHP) to determine the weight or importance of individual schistosomiasis risk factors, including temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, slope, and land use/land cover. These factors were reclassified and overlaid to identify areas vulnerable to schistosomiasis. The weighted overlay analysis was conducted after assigning weights to each factor based on the AHP. The prevalence of urinary schistosomiasis in the study area was also determined through parasitological analysis of urine samples collected through random sampling. The results showed that 82% of the area falls under the high and very high risk category, with one community (Oba Ile) having the lowest risk and the risk increasing in the four remaining communities (Iju, Igoba, Ita Ogbolu, and Ogbese). The predictions made by the model correlated strongly with observations from the field study, with high risk zones corresponding to known endemic communities. The study demonstrated that environmental factors can be used to identify and predict schistosomiasis transmission and effective monitoring of disease risk in newly established rural and agricultural communities. The findings suggest that satellite-derived environmental data can be used to determine schistosomiasis risk levels in an area using relevant techniques.
Pneumococcal meningitis, a bacterial infection of the brain caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, results in significant morbidity and mortality. The cholesterol-dependent cytolysin pneumolysin ( PLY ) is a key factor in determining the neuropathogenic potential of pneumococci. This study investigated the role of PLY in synaptic damage during pneumococcal meningitis. Post-mortem brain samples from individuals with pneumococcal meningitis showed selective synaptic loss in the superficial layers of the frontal neocortex. A similar effect was observed in mice with pneumococcal meningitis only when the bacteria expressed PLY. Exposure of acute mouse brain slices to non-lytic concentrations of PLY caused permanent dendritic swelling, dendritic spine elimination, and synaptic loss. The NMDA glutamate receptor antagonists MK801 and D-AP5 reduced this pathology. PLY increased glutamate levels within the mouse brain slices, and in mouse astrocytes, PLY initiated the release of glutamate in a calcium-dependent manner. The study proposes that PLY plays a significant role in pneumococcal meningitis by initiating glutamate release from astrocytes, leading to subsequent glutamate-dependent synaptic damage. This is the first demonstration of synaptic pathology in pneumococcal meningitis and highlights the potential of PLY to dysregulate glutamate control in the brain, inducing excitotoxic damage. The findings suggest that PLY is a critical factor in the pathogenesis of pneumococcal meningitis and may contribute to the long-term cognitive decline observed in survivors of the disease.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are DNA viruses associated with major human cancers, and understanding their infectious life cycle is crucial for developing new prevention methods, such as vaccines and microbicides. Research has shown that the HPV infectious life cycle is closely linked to the differentiation state of the stratified epithelium it infects, with progeny virus produced in the terminally differentiating suprabasal compartment. However, it has been unclear why HPVs must first establish infection within the basal layer of stratified epithelium. Using chemical biology approaches, scientists have revealed that cell cycle progression through mitosis is critical for HPV infection. Specifically, they found that the recipient cell must enter the M phase (mitosis) for HPV infection to take place. Inhibitors of the G1, S, G2, and early M phases of the cell cycle efficiently prevented infection, while late M phase inhibitors had no effect. These findings suggest that host cells need to pass through early prophase for successful onset of transcription of the HPV encapsidated genes. This discovery provides one reason why HPVs initially establish infections in the basal compartment of stratified epithelia, where cells are progressing through the cell cycle. These results have important implications for HPV control, as they define a major condition for cell susceptibility to HPV infection. Further research is needed to confirm the physiologic relevance of these findings in primary keratinocytes and in vivo models.
The study identified microRNA-like RNAs (milRNAs) in the thermal dimorphic fungus Penicillium marneffei, which causes systemic mycosis in China and Southeast Asia. The researchers used high-throughput sequencing technology to analyze small RNAs in both mycelial and yeast phases of the fungus. The results revealed 24 potential milRNA candidates, with 17 in the mycelial phase and 7 in the yeast phase. Two genes, dcl-1 and dcl-2, encoding putative Dicer-like proteins, and the gene qde-2, encoding Argonaute-like protein, were identified in P. marneffei. Phylogenetic analysis showed that dcl-2 was more closely related to homologues in other thermal dimorphic pathogenic fungi than to Penicillium chrysogenum and Aspergillus spp. Northern blot analysis confirmed the expression of two milRNAs, PM-milR-M1 and PM-milR-M2, only in the mycelial phase. The biogenesis of both milRNAs was dependent on dcl-2, but not dcl-1 or qde-2. The mRNA expression levels of three predicted targets of PM-milR-M1 were upregulated in a knockdown strain, supporting the regulatory function of milRNAs. These findings provide the first evidence for differential expression of milRNAs in different growth phases of thermal dimorphic fungi and shed light on the evolution of fungal proteins involved in milRNA biogenesis and the possible role of post-transcriptional control in governing thermal dimorphism.
Zika virus (ZIKV) emerged in French Polynesia in 2013 and spread throughout the Pacific region between 2013 and 2017. Two potential Aedes mosquito species, Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis, may have contributed to the transmission of ZIKV. This study aimed to evaluate and compare the vector competence of wild Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis populations from different Pacific islands for a ZIKV strain that circulated in the region during the 2013-2017 outbreak. Field-collected Ae. aegypti (three populations) and Ae. polynesiensis (two populations) from the Pacific region were orally exposed to a ZIKV strain isolated in the region in 2014. The results showed that ZIKV infection rates were heterogeneous between Ae. aegypti populations, but dissemination rates were moderate and more homogeneous between these populations. For Ae. polynesiensis, infection rates were less heterogeneous between the two populations tested. The transmission rate and efficiency results revealed a low vector competence for ZIKV of the different Aedes vector populations under study. The study found that Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis from the Pacific region had a low ability to transmit ZIKV. The results suggest that other factors, such as vector density, mosquito lifespan, or a large immunologically naive fraction of the population, may have contributed to the rapid spread of ZIKV in the Pacific region during the 2013-2017 outbreak.
The long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) Xist is a master regulator of X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells. To study the structure of Xist in cells, the authors developed Targeted Structure-Seq, a new approach that combines chemical probing of RNA structure in cells with target-specific massively parallel sequencing. This method allows for high coverage of the target RNA with relatively few sequencing reads, providing a targeted and scalable approach to analyze RNA conformation in cells. The authors used Targeted Structure-Seq to probe the full-length Xist lncRNA and developed new models for functional elements within Xist, including the repeat A element in the 5’-end of Xist. The analysis also identified new structural elements in Xist that are evolutionarily conserved, including a new element proximal to the C repeats that is important for Xist function. The repeat A region of Xist is a functional element important for gene repression. The authors validated the utility of Targeted Structure-Seq to study lncRNA conformation in mammalian cells and expect that this approach will be particularly useful for advancing our mechanistic understanding of lncRNAs. The data generated by Targeted Structure-Seq can be used to develop a conformational model of full-length Xist, providing insight into RNA function, molecular evolution, and modularity.
A new statistical framework has been developed to evaluate the predictive power of genetic variants for complex diseases. The framework connects various predictive indices and allows for the estimation of metrics such as the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve ( AUC ), the mean risk difference between cases and non-cases, and the proportion of cases explained by a specific percentile of the population at the highest risk. The framework also enables the construction of graphs to visualize the performance of risk models, including the ROC curve, the density of risks, and the predictiveness curve. The results from simulations match well with theoretical estimates, and the methodology has been applied to nine complex diseases to evaluate the predictive power of genetic tests based on known susceptibility variants. The study highlights the importance of complementing AUC with other measures to assess the performance of genetic risk prediction models, as a high level of statistical significance does not necessarily equate to good predictive power. The framework provides a more comprehensive assessment of prediction model performance by incorporating additional indices and graphs, such as the net reclassification improvement ( NRI ), the integrated discrimination improvement ( IDI ), and risk distribution plots. This approach is particularly useful when established risk thresholds exist, as a large part of the ROC curve may be derived from cutoff points not of clinical interest.
A new rapid diagnostic test (RDT) for Trypanosoma brucei gambiense human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) was evaluated and compared to the Card Agglutination Test for Trypanosomiasis (CATT) and another RDT. The new RDT, SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0, uses recombinant antigens and was tested on 57,632 individuals in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The results showed that SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 had the highest sensitivity at 71.2%, followed by CATT at 62.5% and SD BIOLINE HAT at 59.0%. CATT had the highest specificity at 99.2%, while SD BIOLINE HAT and SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 had specificities of 98.9% and 98.1%, respectively. The sensitivity of the tests was lower than previously reported due to the identification of cases from partially overlapping sub-populations. All three tests were more sensitive in passive screening than in active screening. Combining two or three tests increased sensitivity, with a combination of SD BIOLINE HAT and SD BIOLINE HAT 2.0 reaching 98.4% in passive and 83.0% in active screening. The recombinant antigen-based RDT was more sensitive than SD BIOLINE HAT but less specific than CATT. The study suggests that using two or more tests can enhance the sensitivity of diagnostic algorithms, but may also decrease specificity.
In the municipality of Comapa, Department of Jutiapa, Guatemala, a region with persistent Triatoma dimidiata infestation, a decade of vector control activities has shown mixed results. Despite multiple rounds of indoor residual insecticide spraying (IRS), the infestation index decreased significantly from 39% in 2001-2002 to 27% in 2011. However, household construction materials alone predicted less than 10% of infested houses. Chagas disease seroprevalence in school-aged children declined by 10-fold, from 10% in 1999 to 1% in 2015. In contrast, seroprevalence in women of childbearing age remains above 10%. After a decade of vector control activities, there is evidence of reduced transmission, but the continued risk for vector-borne and congenital transmission poses a threat to the 2022 Chagas disease elimination goal. Systematic integrated vector control and improved Chagas disease screening and treatment programs for congenital and vector-borne disease are needed to reach the elimination goal in regions with persistent vector infestation. The study highlights the need for sustained efforts to control Chagas disease in areas with persistent infestation, such as Comapa, where ecological, biological, and social risk factors contribute to the persistence of T. dimidiata infestation.
The bacterium Citrobacter rodentium is a natural mouse pathogen that causes attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions and shares a common virulence strategy with the human pathogens enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and enterohaemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). The genome of C. rodentium strain ICC168 was previously sequenced and found to display characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen, including a large number of pseudogenes and IS elements. This study further investigates the genomic flux in C. rodentium, focusing on the impact of mobile genetic elements on its genome evolution. The results show that the genome of C. rodentium is unstable due to repeat-mediated, large-scale genome recombination and the active transposition of mobile genetic elements, such as prophages. An additional strain, EX-33, was sequenced to confirm that the reference strain ICC168 is representative of the species and that many inactivating mutations are common to both isolates and likely occurred early in the pathogen's evolution. The study draws parallels with the evolution of other bacterial pathogens and suggests that C. rodentium may have emerged alongside the development of inbred mice as a model for human disease. The findings indicate that C. rodentium is a recently evolved pathogen that is still adapting to its new lifestyle, with many of its virulence functions located on horizontally acquired mobile genetic elements.
The article presents a computational framework for analyzing stochasticity in gene expression by inferring biochemical rate constants that govern chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation. The authors propose a method to estimate these rate constants from protein expression distributions without making any limiting assumptions. They derive analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution and show that these four moments completely capture the shape of protein distributions. An efficient algorithm is developed to infer gene expression rate constants from the moments of protein distributions. The method is applied to a particular steady-state protein distribution, and the results show that most protein distributions are consistent with a large number of different biochemical rate constant sets. However, the solution space of rate constants almost always informs on underlying mechanisms, allowing for the distinction between regimes where transcriptional bursting occurs and regimes reflecting constitutive transcript production. The framework is shown to be a powerful tool for deducing the contributions of particular molecular mechanisms to specific patterns of gene expression. The method agrees with the current standard approach and identifies rate constants not previously obtainable in the restrictive regime where the standard method operates. In 91% of tested cases, the method obtains estimates of individual biochemical rate constants or meaningful ratios of rate constants, and in some cases, it identifies all underlying rate constants.
A novel vaccination strategy using bovine herpesvirus 4 ( BoHV-4 ) vectors expressing different monkeypox virus ( MPXV ) glycoproteins has been investigated for its efficacy in protecting against lethal MPXV challenge in STAT1 knockout mice. Three recombinant BoHV-4 vectors, each expressing A29L, M1R, and B6R glycoproteins, were constructed and demonstrated to be safe and capable of expressing their transgenes following intraperitoneal administration. A small challenge study showed that BoHV-4-A-EF1α-M1RgD106ΔTK alone or in combination with the other two vectors was able to protect 100% and 80% of STAT1(-/-) mice against mortality and morbidity, respectively. This study demonstrates the potential of BoHV-4-based vectors as a vaccine platform for MPXV. The results are significant given the lack of FDA-approved therapies against MPXV and the limitations of current vaccines due to safety concerns. The use of BoHV-4 vectors may provide a safer and more effective alternative for protecting against MPXV, particularly in populations where smallpox vaccination is contraindicated. The study's findings have implications for the development of a vaccine against MPXV, which is an emerging orthopoxvirus zoonosis in Africa and has the potential to be used as a bioterror agent.
The ApaH-like phosphatase TbALPH1 has been identified as the major mRNA decapping enzyme in trypanosomes. Unlike other eukaryotes, trypanosomes lack homologues to the subunits of the decapping complex. Instead, TbALPH1 acts downstream of deadenylation and upstream of mRNA degradation, consistent with a function in mRNA decapping. RNAi depletion of TbALPH1 is lethal and causes a massive increase in total mRNAs that are deadenylated but have not yet started 5’-3’ decay. In vitro experiments show that recombinant TbALPH1 protein sensitises the capped trypanosome spliced leader RNA to yeast Xrn1, but only if an RNA 5’ polyphosphatase is included. This indicates that the decapping mechanism of TbALPH1 differs from the decapping mechanism of Dcp2 by leaving more than one phosphate group at the mRNA’s 5’ end. The substrates of eukaryotic ApaH-like phosphatases are unknown, but the substrate of the related bacterial enzyme ApaH, diadenosine tetraphosphate, is highly reminiscent of a eukaryotic mRNA cap. TbALPH1 localises to P-bodies and its depletion causes the accumulation of deadenylated mRNA molecules that have not yet started degradation. Its exclusive co-localisation with the 5’-3’ exoribonuclease XRNA suggests that both enzymes are members of the same pathway. The data provide strong in vivo evidence for TbALPH1 being the trypanosome decapping enzyme. ApaH-like phosphatases are present in all branches of the eukaryotic kingdom, and this is the first reported function of a eukaryotic ApaH-like phosphatase.
The inactivation of the Arx gene in pancreatic α-cells has been shown to trigger their neogenesis and conversion into functional β-like cells. Using conditional loss-of-function and lineage tracing approaches, researchers demonstrated that the selective inhibition of Arx in α-cells is sufficient to promote the conversion of adult α-cells into β-like cells at any age. This conversion induces the continuous mobilization of duct-lining precursor cells to adopt an endocrine cell fate, with the glucagon+ cells generated being subsequently converted into β-like cells upon Arx inhibition. The study found that Pax4 is dispensable for these regeneration processes, indicating that Arx represents the main trigger of α-cell-mediated β-like cell neogenesis. Importantly, the loss of Arx in α-cells is sufficient to regenerate a functional β-cell mass and thereby reverse diabetes following toxin-induced β-cell depletion. The findings suggest that strategies aiming at inhibiting the expression of Arx, or its molecular targets/co-factors, may pave new avenues for the treatment of diabetes. The study provides evidence that the sole loss of the Arx gene in α-cells is sufficient to initiate a continuous cycle of glucagon+ cell neo-formation and their conversion into β-like cells, leading to the regeneration of a functional β-like cell mass.
Eukaryotic cells employ a battery of regulatory mechanisms to prevent re-initiation of DNA replication at each of the thousands of origins in their genome. These mechanisms reduce the activity of replication initiation proteins to minimize the probability of re-initiation from multiple origins. However, recent studies have revealed that origins re-initiate with diverse efficiencies when these mechanisms are disabled, suggesting an additional layer of replication control that can differentially regulate re-initiation at distinct origins. Novel genetic elements, termed re-initiation promoters (RIPs), have been identified that are necessary for preferential re-initiation of specific origins and sufficient to confer preferential re-initiation on heterologous origins when the control of re-initiation is partially deregulated. The RIP elements map to ∼60 bp AT-rich sequences that act in a distance- and sequence-dependent manner. These elements do not enhance the S phase timing or efficiency of adjacent origins and thus specifically act as re-initiation promoters. During the induction of re-replication, Mcm2-7 reassociates with both origins that preferentially re-initiate and origins that do not, suggesting that the RIP elements can overcome a block to re-initiation imposed after Mcm2-7 associates with origins. This local level of control creates a complex genomic landscape of re-replication potential that is revealed when global mechanisms preventing re-replication are compromised. These findings provide the first insight into how diversity can be introduced in the regulation of eukaryotic replication origins.
Invasive amebiasis (IA) caused by Entamoeba histolytica is a significant public health concern, particularly among men who have sex with men (MSM) and those co-infected with HIV-1. A retrospective analysis of 170 HIV-1-infected patients with IA in Japan revealed that the clinical presentation of IA was similar to that in non-HIV-1-infected individuals, with high fever, leukocytosis, and high C-reactive protein (CRP) levels associated with extraluminal amebic diseases. Two patients died from amebic colitis, while three died from unrelated causes. Treatment with metronidazole or tinidazole was effective in 165 cases, with no significant difference in recurrence rates between patients who received luminal treatment and those who did not. However, recurrence was more frequent in patients who were HCV-antibody positive or acquired syphilis during follow-up. Genotyping of E. histolytica was performed in 14 patients, but no correlation was found between genotype and clinical features. The study suggests that luminal treatment following metronidazole or tinidazole treatment does not reduce recurrence of amebiasis in high-risk populations, likely due to re-infection. The findings support the use of metronidazole or tinidazole as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated amebiasis in HIV-1-infected individuals, and highlight the need for educational approaches to prevent new amebic infections in high-risk groups.
A study was conducted in the Mandoul focus of Chad to assess the impact of adding tsetse control to medical activities on the transmission of Gambian sleeping sickness, also known as Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT). The disease is caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense and is transmitted by riverine species of tsetse flies. The study aimed to determine whether the addition of vector control to case detection and treatment could further reduce transmission and consequently decrease the annual incidence of HAT in the area. A census of the human population was conducted, and a pre-intervention survey of tsetse distribution and abundance was implemented. Tiny targets, which attract and kill tsetse, were deployed in the riverine habitats of tsetse in 2014, 2015, and 2016. The impact on tsetse and HAT incidence was assessed through nine tsetse monitoring surveys and four medical surveys of the human population in 2014 and 2015. Mathematical modeling was used to assess the relative impact of tsetse control on incidence compared to active and passive screening. The results showed that 70.4% of the reduction in reported cases between 2013 and 2015 can be attributed to vector control, and 62.8% of the reduction in new infections can be attributed to tsetse control. The study suggests that the combination of tsetse control and medical detection and treatment has played a major role in reducing HAT incidence in 2014 and 2015. Model predictions anticipate that elimination as a public health problem could be achieved by 2018 in this focus if vector control and screening continue at the present level.
A retrospective study of 1245 cases of imported strongyloidiasis in Spain from 2009 to 2017 was conducted to describe the epidemiological, clinical, and microbiological characteristics of patients with the infection. The majority of cases (66.9%) were immigrants, with South America being the most frequent area of origin. Eosinophilia was present in 82.2% of cases, and detection of larvae in stool samples was observed in 21.9% of patients. Serological tests were used to diagnose the remaining cases. Treatment with ivermectin, compared to albendazole, was found to be the most strongly associated factor with achieving a cure, with an odds ratio of 2.34. The study suggests that screening for Strongyloides stercoralis infection should be mandatory in patients coming from or traveling to endemic areas, particularly those with immunosuppressant conditions, due to the long latency of the infection and the risk of developing a severe presentation. The results of this study contradict those of a previous observational study in Buenos Aires, Argentina, which found that ivermectin treatment was not effective in all patients. The study highlights the need for a combination of diagnostic strategies, including classical parasitological methods, serology, and PCR, to accurately diagnose strongyloidiasis.
Vaccination is a crucial method for protecting against infectious diseases, and determining the optimal inoculum dose is a critical component of vaccine design. The inoculum dose refers to the amount of antigen or live attenuated pathogen used in a vaccine formulation. While higher inoculum doses can stimulate a stronger immune response, they may also cause more severe side effects and limit population coverage in the event of vaccine shortages. To address this challenge, researchers have developed a mathematical modeling framework that combines experimental data to determine the impact of inoculum dose on host immunity and morbidity. This framework was applied to data from influenza A virus ( IAV ) infection of mice and human parainfluenza virus ( HPIV ) infection of cotton rats at various inoculum doses. The results showed that the impact of inoculum dose on immune protection and morbidity can depend on the specific pathogen, and that protection and morbidity do not necessarily increase monotonically with increasing inoculum dose. The framework can be used to predict the optimal inoculum dose for a given vaccine and setting, taking into account required levels of protection and acceptable levels of morbidity. This approach can help in the rational design of vaccines and determination of the optimal amount of inoculum. The study demonstrates the potential of combining mathematical models with experimental data to inform vaccine design and improve public health outcomes.
The study investigated the spatial fluctuations in expression of the heterocyst differentiation regulatory gene hetR in Anabaena filaments under nitrogen-replete and nitrogen-deprived conditions. A chromosomally-encoded translational hetR-gfp fusion was used to measure hetR expression levels at the individual cell level in wild-type and mutant filaments. Statistical analysis revealed that hetR expression fluctuations in nearby cells are coupled, with a characteristic spatial range of approximately two to three cells. This coupling is primarily due to intercellular molecular transfer rather than cell division. The study found that under nitrogen-rich conditions, basal, steady-state expression of the HetR inhibitor PatS, cell-cell communication influenced by the septal protein SepJ, and positive HetR auto-regulation are essential determinants of fluctuations in hetR expression and its distribution along filaments. A comparison of hetR-gfp expression under nitrogen-rich and nitrogen-poor conditions highlighted the differences between the HetR inhibitors PatS and HetN, as well as the differences in specificity between the septal proteins SepJ and FraC/FraD. The results demonstrate that proteins involved in activation, inhibition, and cell-cell communication combine to control the coupled fluctuations of gene expression that give rise to a one-dimensional developmental pattern in Anabaena. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying heterocyst differentiation and the development of multicellular patterns in cyanobacteria.
This study investigated the differential replication efficiencies of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) genotype I (GI) and genotype III (GIII) in avian cultured cells and young domestic ducklings. A serological survey in JEV-non-vaccinated pigs in China revealed a genotype shift from GIII to GI, with an average ratio of GI/GIII infection of 1.87. To understand the reasons behind this shift, the replication kinetics of seven recently-isolated JEV isolates, including three GI strains and four GIII strains, were compared in mosquito C6/36 cells, chicken fibroblast cells (DF-1), and porcine iliac artery endothelial cells (PIEC). The results showed that GI strains replicated more efficiently than GIII strains in DF-1 and PIEC cells, with titers reaching 22.9-225.3 fold higher than those of GIII strains. In vivo, young domestic ducklings inoculated with GI strains developed higher viremia titers and displayed a longer viremic duration than those inoculated with GIII strains. These findings suggest that GI viruses have an enhanced replication efficiency in birds, which may contribute to their increased transmission efficiency in the birds-mosquitoes-birds enzootic transmission cycle. The 36 amino acid differences between GI and GIII viruses may be responsible for the enhanced replication efficiency of GI viruses in birds. These results provide insight into the reasons behind the JEV genotype shift from GIII to GI in China.
The Candida albicans biofilm transcription factor (TF) network is composed of six genes (Bcr1, Brg1, Efg1, Ndt80, Rob1, and Tec1) that regulate biofilm formation. A systematic genetic interaction approach was used to analyze the network by generating all possible double heterozygous mutants of the network genes and quantitatively analyzing the genetic interactions between them. The results showed that the network is highly susceptible to genetic perturbation, with all six network heterozygous mutants exhibiting alterations in biofilm formation (haploinsufficiency). Furthermore, many double heterozygous mutants showed phenotypes as severe as homozygous deletions, indicating that the network is highly interdependent. The analysis revealed that the network has properties of a "small-world" network, which is highly efficient but not robust. The study also found that Tec1 is a network component whose expression is highly sensitive to small perturbations in the function of other network TFs, and that Rob1 expression is dependent on both auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other network TFs. Additionally, the heterozygous Ndt80 deletion mutant was found to be hyperfilamentous under both biofilm and hyphae-inducing conditions in a Tec1-dependent manner. Overall, the genetic interaction analysis of this network has provided new insights into the functions of individual TFs and the role of the overall network topology in its function. The study suggests that the structure and function of the biofilm TF network contributes to the ability of small perturbations to be communicated through the network to regulate the expression of a functionally important member of the network.
Leishmania infantum asparagine synthetase A (LiAS-A) is an enzyme responsible for converting aspartate into asparagine in an ATP-dependent manner, using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source. Previous studies suggested that LiAS-A is essential for Leishmania donovani survival, making it a potential drug target. However, this study aimed to investigate the role of LiAS-A in Leishmania infantum. The results show that LiAS-A can use both ammonia and glutamine as nitrogen donors, similar to Trypanosoma spp. and L. donovani. Targeted gene replacement was used to generate LiAS-A null mutants in L. infantum, which did not display significant growth or infectivity defects under normal in vitro and in vivo conditions. However, a severe impairment of in vitro growth was observed when null mutants were cultured in asparagine-limiting conditions. These findings indicate that LiAS-A is not essential for parasite survival, growth, or infectivity in normal conditions. Therefore, LiAS-A is not considered a suitable drug target against L. infantum parasites. The study also highlights the differences in asparagine metabolism between Leishmania and Trypanosoma species, suggesting that asparagine homeostasis is differently regulated among trypanosomatids.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to investigate the association between human toxocariasis and epilepsy. The review included 11 case-control studies from 13 countries worldwide, involving a total of 4740 subjects ( 2159 people with epilepsy and 2581 people without epilepsy ). The pooled odds ratio ( OR ) for the association between epilepsy and Toxocara spp. seropositivity was 1. 69 ( 95% CI 1. 42–2. 01 ). A positive association was consistently reported in the restricted analysis, including studies that used Western Blot as a confirmatory or diagnostic test, younger populations, and population-based studies. Meta-regression showed no statistically significant association between covariates and outcome. The results provide epidemiological evidence of a positive association between Toxocara seropositivity and epilepsy. New studies supported this association, particularly population-based studies. The findings suggest that health strategies to reduce the impact of Toxocara spp. are strongly advised. Further research is needed to understand the physiopathological mechanisms of toxocara-associated epileptogenesis. The association between toxocariasis and epilepsy is still debated, but the updated meta-analysis provides a more accurate estimate of the relationship between the two conditions. Toxocariasis is a common helminthiasis infection worldwide and is potentially preventable, making it an important public health concern.
The article describes a novel ATM-mediated DNA damage response pathway involving microRNA-335 (miR-335) that modulates the repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). Irradiation (IR)-induced DSBs activate ATM, which leads to the downregulation of miR-335, a microRNA that targets CtIP, a protein involved in homologous recombination repair (HRR). CREB, a transcription factor, is responsible for miR-335 expression and its binding to the promoter region is reduced after IR, consistent with previous studies showing that IR-activated ATM phosphorylates CREB, reducing its transcription activity. Overexpression of miR-335 in HeLa cells results in reduced CtIP levels, post-IR colony survival, and BRCA1 foci formation. In patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines with decreased post-IR colony survival, miR-335 expression is elevated, CtIP levels are reduced, and BRCA1 foci formation is decreased. Treatment with miRNA antisense oligonucleotides (AMO-miR-335) partially rescues colony survival, BRCA1 foci formation, and CtIP levels. These findings suggest that an ATM-dependent CREB-miR-335-CtIP axis influences the selection of HRR for repair of certain DSB lesions. The study proposes a working model in which the downregulation of miR-335 by ATM-CREB increases CtIP protein expression after IR-induced damage, enhancing the DNA damage response (DDR). The miR-335-CtIP axis impacts BRCA1 foci formation, cell cycle checkpoint regulation, DNA repair, and cell survival.
The study investigated the role of mentalizing, or attributing mental states to others, in learning during social interactions. Participants played repeated games against artificial mentalizing agents that differed in their sophistication, and were led to believe they were either playing against another person or engaging in a casino-style game. Results showed that participants won against the sophisticated mentalizing agents in the social framing, but lost in the non-social framing. Furthermore, participants' choice sequences were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing Bayesian learning models only in the social framing. These findings demonstrate the added value of mentalizing in learning during repeated social interactions and suggest that deciphering intentional behavior relies on a priori attributing mental states to others. The study supports the "social Bayesian brain" hypothesis, which proposes that the brain assumes others are Bayesian learners and updates recursive beliefs based on repeated observation of others' behavior. The results indicate that social framing induces mentalizing and recursive inference, and that domain-general learning heuristics are vulnerable to artificial mentalizing agents in non-social contexts. The study provides the first demonstration of the importance of mentalizing in learning during social interactions.
Title: FastGGM: An Efficient Algorithm for the Inference of Gaussian Graphical Model in Biological Networks

A novel algorithm, FastGGM, has been developed for the statistical inference of Gaussian Graphical Model (GGM) in biological networks. GGM is a probability model that characterizes the conditional dependence structure of a set of random variables by a graph, and has wide applications in the analysis of biological networks. However, existing approaches are either not statistically rigorous or are inefficient for high-dimensional data. FastGGM is an efficient algorithm that implements the estimation of GGM and obtains p-value and confidence interval for each edge in the graph, based on a recent proposal by Ren et al. (2015). Simulation studies demonstrate that FastGGM is faster by several orders of magnitude than the current implemented algorithm for Ren et al. without losing any accuracy.

FastGGM has been applied to two real data sets: transcriptomic data from a study of childhood asthma and proteomic data from a study of Alzheimer’s disease. The resulting networks reveal interesting interactions and the differential networks between cases and controls show functional relevance to the diseases. The algorithm has been implemented in an R package named “FastGGM” and is available for download.
