FastGGM provides an opportunity for researchers to study large-scale networks, such as gene/protein networks, using GGM in practice. It is an exact implementation of the asymptotically normal and efficient estimation established by Ren et al. (2015), and hence is statistically sound. FastGGM can make it feasible to infer biological networks under the framework of GGM at a whole-genome scale.
The striatal medium spiny neuron (MSN) network plays a crucial role in the learning and execution of movement sequences, with its population firing rates varying coherently on slow behaviorally relevant timescales. A model of a local MSN network has been shown to exhibit such activity, but only at realistic connectivities and inhibitory post-synaptic potentials (IPSPs). This study investigates how MSN network-generated population activity interacts with temporally varying cortical driving activity, as would occur in a behavioral task. The results show that at unrealistically high connectivity, a stable winners-take-all type regime is found, where network activity separates into fixed stimulus-dependent regularly firing and quiescent components. In contrast, at lower connectivity, a more dynamically active regime occurs, where all cells constantly switch between activity and quiescence. Only in the transition regime between these two do weak changes in cortical driving interact with many population components, resulting in reproducible activation of sequential cell assemblies for hundreds of milliseconds after stimulus onset. This activity is maximized at striatally realistic connectivities and IPSP sizes. The study suggests that the local MSN network has optimal characteristics, neither too stable nor too unstable, but rather optimized to generate stimulus-dependent activity patterns for long periods after variations in cortical excitation. The findings are supported by dynamical systems theory and have implications for understanding how the striatum processes sensory stimuli and behavioral task events.
The study investigated the relationship between polarized exocytosis and endocytosis in yeast cells. Polarized exocytosis transports membrane components to specific locations on the cell cortex, while endocytosis retrieves these components before they can diffuse away. The study found that the yeast Rab GTPase Sec4p couples polarized exocytosis with cortical actin polymerization, which induces endocytosis. After polarized exocytosis, Sec4p binds Las17/Bee1p ( yeast Wiskott—Aldrich Syndrome protein [WASp] ) in a complex with Sla1p and Sla2p during actin patch assembly. Mutations that inactivate Sec4p or its guanine nucleotide exchange factor ( GEF ) Sec2p inhibit actin patch formation, whereas the activating sec4-Q79L mutation accelerates patch assembly. In vitro assays of Arp2/3-dependent actin polymerization established that GTPγS-Sec4p overrides Sla1p inhibition of Las17p-dependent actin nucleation. The results support a model in which Sec4p relocates along the plasma membrane from polarized sites of exocytic vesicle fusion to nascent sites of endocytosis, promoting actin polymerization and triggering compensatory endocytosis to control surface expansion and refine cell polarization. The study also found that Sec4p physically interacts with Las17p and Sla1p, and induces Arp2/3-dependent actin polymerization in vitro. These findings suggest that Sec4p plays a specific role in actin patch assembly and endocytic internalization.
Acetaminophen (APAP)-induced liver injury in mice is a widely used model for drug-induced liver injury in humans. The prevailing mechanistic explanation for this injury, known as the NAPQI zonation hypothesis, suggests that the formation of the reactive metabolite NAPQI within hepatocytes increases from the periportal space to the central vein (CV) of the liver lobule, leading to early perivenous necrosis. However, this hypothesis has not been directly challenged in mice due to the difficulty in controlling influential variables and obtaining sequential intracellular measurements at different lobular locations within the same mouse.

To address this limitation, virtual hepatocytes were used to simulate the behavior of liver cells in response to APAP exposure. These virtual cells were configured to exhibit location-dependent behaviors based on independently configured periportal-to-CV gradients. The results of these virtual experiments showed that zonation of NAPQI formation alone is insufficient to explain early perivenous necrosis. To develop a more comprehensive explanation, two additional features were incorporated into the model: a glutathione depletion threshold that decreases in the CV direction, and the ability to repair mitochondrial damage that also decreases in the CV direction. The inclusion of both features enabled the model to successfully replicate the observed phenomenon of early perivenous necrosis. This merged mechanism provides a multilevel, multiscale causal explanation of key temporal features of APAP hepatotoxicity in mice and offers a plausible explanation for the variation in necrosis scores among genetically diverse mouse strains.
This study aimed to improve the early diagnosis of Trypanosoma cruzi infection in congenitally infected children. The diagnosis of infants born to T. cruzi-infected mothers currently relies on the detection of parasites by INP micromethod or the persistence of T. cruzi-specific antibody titers at 10-12 months of age. The study quantified parasitemia levels in 51 congenitally infected children using PCR and grouped them according to the results of one-year follow-up diagnosis. The results showed that neonates diagnosed by INP micromethod within the first month after delivery had a median parasitemia of 1,700 parasites/mL. Infants diagnosed at six months of age had a median parasitemia of 20-500 parasites/mL, while those diagnosed by serology at around 1 year old had a median parasitemia of 5-20 parasites/mL. T. cruzi parasites were isolated from 19 congenitally infected children, with 18 genotyped as DTU TcV (former lineage TcIId) and one as TcI. The study found that some children (22 out of 51) had parasitemia levels below the detection limit of the INP micromethod. The results suggest that more sensitive parasitological methods are needed to ensure early T. cruzi congenital diagnosis and prompt trypanocidal treatment. The study highlights the importance of developing more sensitive diagnostic methods to improve the early detection of T. cruzi infection in congenitally infected children.
A biophysical model of Escherichia coli (E. coli) has been developed to predict growth rate and cellular composition from a coarse-grained representation of its genome. The model assumes that E. coli is in a state of balanced exponential steady-state growth in a temporally and spatially constant environment rich in resources. The model was applied to past measurements of growth rate and rRNA-to-protein ratio in seven E. coli strains with rRNA operon copy numbers ranging from one to seven. The results showed that growth rate decreased for strains with fewer than six copies. The model was able to reproduce these measurements and suggested that the volume fraction of macromolecules inside E. coli is not fixed when the rRNA operon copy number is varied. Furthermore, the model predicted that increasing the copy number beyond seven would result in a densely packed cytoplasm with ribosomes and proteins, leading to weakened binding affinities and no substantial increase in growth rate. This prediction is consistent with other experiments. The model also suggests that changing the rRNA operon copy number of wild-type E. coli cells growing in a constant rich environment does not substantially increase their growth rate. Additional observations regarding strains with altered rRNA operon copy numbers, such as nucleoid compaction and the rRNA operon feedback response, are qualitatively consistent with the model.
The Arabidopsis MYB protein RSM1 interacts with the transcription factors HY5/HYH to modulate seed germination and seedling development in response to abscisic acid ( ABA ) and salinity. RSM1 is a member of the MYB-related subfamily and has been implicated in plant development, stress responses, and hormone signaling. Down-regulation or up-regulation of RSM1 expression alters the sensitivity of seed germination and cotyledon greening to ABA, NaCl, and mannitol in Arabidopsis. The expression of RSM1 is dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl. Genetic analyses reveal that RSM1 mediates multiple functions of HY5 in responses of seed germination, post-germination development to ABA and abiotic stresses, and seedling tolerance to salinity. Pull-down and BiFC assays show that RSM1 interacts with HY5/HYH in vitro and in vivo. RSM1 and HY5/HYH may function as a regulatory module in responses to ABA and abiotic stresses. RSM1 binds to the promoter of ABA INSENSITIVE 5 ( ABI5 ), thereby regulating its expression, while RSM1 interaction also stimulates HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. The results suggest that HY5/HYH and RSM1 may converge on the ABI5 promoter and independently or dependently regulate ABI5 expression and ABI5-downstream ABA and abiotic stress-responsive genes.
Mitochondrial complex I, the largest and most complicated proton pump of the respiratory chain, links electron transfer from NADH to ubiquinone to the pumping of four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. Recent X-ray structural analysis of prokaryotic and eukaryotic complex I revealed that redox reactions occur in the hydrophilic peripheral arm of the L-shaped molecule, far from the membrane domain. This implies that proton pumping within the membrane arm is driven indirectly via long-range conformational coupling. However, the molecular mechanism and the number, identity, and localization of the pump-sites remain unclear. To address this, researchers deleted the gene for a small accessory subunit of Yarrowia complex I, resulting in a stable subcomplex ( nb8mΔ ) that lacks the distal part of the membrane domain. Analysis of the subunit composition of holo and subcomplex revealed that two subunits ( ND4 and ND5 ) with homology to bacterial Mrp-type Na+/H+ antiporters were missing in nb8mΔ. Notably, nb8mΔ still pumps protons at half the stoichiometry of the complete enzyme. These findings suggest that the membrane arm of complex I harbors two functionally distinct pump modules connected in series by a long helical transmission element. This discovery provides new insights into the molecular mechanism of proton pumping in complex I and has implications for understanding the role of complex I in bioenergetic diseases.
This study investigated the effect of febrile temperatures on the binding affinity of antibodies to malarial and dengue antigens in vitro. The researchers used Isothermal Titration Calorimetry ( ITC ) and Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay ( ELISA ) to measure the affinity of antibody-antigen complexes at 37°C, 40°C, and 42°C. The results showed a significant increase in affinity at 40°C compared to 37°C or 42°C for both malarial and dengue antigens. Thermal equilibration of the protein partners prior to measurements further increased their binding affinity. The study suggests that febrile temperatures may play a positive role in modulating immune responses to infection by enhancing the binding affinity of antibodies to antigens. The findings also highlight the importance of thermal priming in enhancing protein-protein affinity, particularly for samples with limited availability. Thermal equilibration of protein partners prior to in vitro assays may improve binding affinities and inform on the optimal temperature conditions for testing. The study provides new insights into the role of fever in regulating immune responses and has implications for the development of diagnostic and therapeutic strategies for infectious diseases caused by malarial and dengue viruses.
Actomyosin-based cortical flow is a fundamental process in cellular morphogenesis, generated by cross-linked networks of actin filaments and myosin motors. To maintain continuous flow, local remodeling through crosslink unbinding and/or filament disassembly is necessary. However, how local remodeling tunes stress production and dissipation, and how this affects long-range flow, remains poorly understood. A computational model was developed to study a cross-linked network with active motors based on minimal requirements for production and dissipation of contractile stress. The model included asymmetric filament compliance, spatial heterogeneity of motor activity, reversible cross-links, and filament turnover. The analysis showed that filament turnover is required to maintain active stress against external resistance and steady-state flow in response to external stress. Steady-state stress increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τm, then decreases with lifetime above τm. Effective viscosity increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τc, and then becomes independent of filament lifetime and sharply dependent on crosslink dynamics. These dependencies define multiple regimes of steady-state flow. When filament lifetimes are shorter than both τc and τm, the dependencies of effective viscosity and steady-state stress on filament turnover cancel each other, resulting in flow speed being insensitive to filament turnover. This framework provides a basis for understanding how animal cells tune cortical flow through local control of network remodeling.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, a quantitative trait locus ( QTL ) analysis was performed to identify genetic loci that overcome the inhibition of seedling growth on high sugar media. A glucose and fructose-sensing QTL, GSQ11, was mapped through selective genotyping and confirmed in near-isogenic lines in both Col and C24 backgrounds. Allelism tests and transgenic complementation showed that GSQ11 lies within the ANAC060 gene. The Col ANAC060 allele confers sugar insensitivity and is dominant over the sugar-sensitive C24 allele. A single-nucleotide polymorphism ( SNP ) in Col ANAC060 affects the splicing patterns of ANAC060, resulting in a truncated protein lacking the transmembrane domain ( TMD ) that is present in the C24 ANAC060 protein. The absence of the TMD results in the nuclear localization of ANAC060. Glucose induces GSQ11/ANAC060 expression in a process that requires abscisic acid ( ABA ) signaling. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-qPCR and transient expression analysis showed that ABI4 directly binds to the GSQ11/ANAC060 promoter to activate transcription. The truncated Col ANAC060 protein attenuates ABA induction and ABA signaling, resulting in sugar insensitivity. This negative feedback from nuclear ANAC060 on ABA signaling renders seedlings insensitive to high sugar concentrations. The Col ANAC060 allele reduces ABA sensitivity and Glc-induced ABA accumulation, and ABI4 expression is also reduced in Col ANAC060 lines.
The Diguanylate Cyclase HsbD Intersects with the HptB Regulatory Cascade to Control Pseudomonas aeruginosa Biofilm and Motility
    The molecular basis of second messenger signaling relies on proteins that synthesize, degrade, or bind cyclic di-GMP (c-di-GMP) to produce coherent functional outputs. In Pseudomonas aeruginosa, c-di-GMP regulates various behaviors, including the transition from planktonic cells to biofilm communities. However, the multiplicity of c-di-GMP control modules and regulated cellular functions raises the question of signaling specificity. This study demonstrates how c-di-GMP signaling gains output specificity in P. aeruginosa through the intersection of the c-di-GMP synthase gene hsbD with the HptB regulatory cascade. The HptB pathway controls biofilm formation and motility by involving both HsbD and the anti-anti-sigma factor HsbA. The rewiring of c-di-GMP signaling into the HptB cascade relies on the original interaction between HsbD and HsbA and the control of HsbD dynamic localization at the cell poles. HsbD and SadC, another c-di-GMP synthase, intersect within the same global regulatory network (Gac/Rsm) in a hierarchical order, contributing to the high c-di-GMP regime necessary for P. aeruginosa biofilm formation. The study suggests that HsbD and SadC act at distinct positions in the c-di-GMP network that controls P. aeruginosa behavior, with HsbD controlling biofilm formation and motility, and SadC regulating biofilm formation and swarming motility.
The study investigated the learning and generalization of visuomotor mappings based on contextual information. Participants performed a rapid target-pointing task while visual feedback was manipulated to require different visuomotor mappings depending on the target shape. The target shapes were morphed between spiky and circular shapes, and participants learned to associate each shape with a specific visuomotor mapping. After training, participants were tested on novel target shapes that had not been learned previously. The results showed that participants applied the mapping corresponding to the trained shape that was most similar to the current one, consistent with a Bayesian learning model. This model predicts that learning should slow down with increased numbers of training pairs, which was confirmed by the results. The study found a good correspondence between the Bayesian learning model and the empirical results, suggesting that this model may be a possible mechanism for simultaneously learning multiple visuomotor mappings. The study also found that participants could extract the linear relationship between target shape and visuomotor mapping and generalize accordingly, but this was not the primary mechanism of learning. The results indicate that learning the associations between shape cues and visuomotor mappings requires explicit awareness of the cues’ role, and that the Bayesian learning model provides a more accurate prediction of generalization.
The inferior olivary nucleus provides the cerebellum with one of its two main inputs, the climbing fibers, which are believed to be involved in timing of motor commands and motor learning. Climbing fiber activation leads to large all-or-none action potentials in cerebellar Purkinje cells, silencing them for a brief period. Research has shown that climbing fibers can transmit a short burst of spikes as a result of an olivary cell somatic spike, potentially increasing the information transferred to the cerebellum. A three-compartmental model of an inferior olivary cell was used to investigate the factors determining the size of the climbing fiber burst. The results suggest that the phase-dependency of the burst size is present but limited, and that charge flow between the soma and dendrite is a major determinant of the climbing fiber burst. Furthermore, the study found that phenomena such as cell ensemble synchrony can have a significant effect on the climbing fiber burst size through dendrodendritic gap-junctional coupling between olivary cells. The model predicts that there may be a phase-dependency of climbing fiber burst size, but only in a limited range of sub-threshold oscillation (STO) amplitudes and in coupled cell ensembles of sufficient size. The study highlights the importance of understanding the electrophysiological properties of the inferior olivary nucleus to better comprehend the information it can and cannot transfer to the cerebellum.
A computational model of human liver iron metabolism has been developed to provide a quantitative understanding of the complex biochemical network involved in iron sensing and regulation. The model includes the core regulatory components of iron metabolism and was constructed based on known mechanisms of regulation and kinetic properties obtained from several publications. The model was validated by comparing its results with previously published physiological data and was able to reproduce multiple experimental findings. A time course simulation following an oral dose of iron was compared to a clinical time course study and the simulation recreated the dynamics and time scale of the system's response to iron challenge. A disease state simulation of haemochromatosis was also created by altering a single reaction parameter that mimics a human haemochromatosis gene (HFE) mutation, providing a quantitative understanding of the liver iron overload that arises in this disease. The model supports and supplements understanding of the role of the liver as an iron sensor and provides a framework for further modelling, including simulations to identify valuable drug targets and design of experiments to improve further knowledge of this system. The model is the most detailed quantitative mechanistic model of cellular iron metabolism to date, allowing for a comprehensive description of its regulation. It can be used to elucidate the link from genotype to phenotype, as demonstrated here with hereditary haemochromatosis. This computational modelling effort constitutes a clinical translational approach, enabling data from multiple sources to improve our understanding of human iron metabolism.
The nuclear pore complex (NPC) plays a crucial role in regulating molecular traffic across the nuclear envelope by selectively controlling the transport of molecules between the nucleus and cytoplasm. Despite its importance, the transport mechanism of the NPC remains poorly understood. To address this knowledge gap, researchers have developed a coarse-grained model of the NPC structure that mimics nucleocytoplasmic transport. This model takes into account the polymeric nature of FG-repeats grafted on the elastic structure of the NPC and the hydrophobic interactions between karyopherins (kaps) and FG-repeats. Using Brownian dynamics simulations, the model predicts that the first-passage time of a 15 nm cargo-complex through the NPC is approximately 2.6 ± 0.13 ms, with an inverse Gaussian distribution. The simulations also reveal that the cargo-complex is primarily attached to the channel wall, interacting with the FG-layer as it passes through the central channel. Furthermore, the model shows that the kap-FG hydrophobic interaction is highly dynamic and fast, ensuring efficient translocation through the NPC. Additionally, the study found that almost all eight hydrophobic binding spots on kap-β are occupied simultaneously during transport. The results also suggest that cytoplasmic filaments play a crucial role in the selectivity barrier of the NPC, as NPCs lacking these filaments exhibit high permeability to inert cargos.
Determining the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for nonhuman primate (NHP) models is crucial for testing interventions against human pathogens such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. A limiting dose of the infectious agent, where only a fraction of animals become infected, is often used in these models. However, finding the correct dose is challenging, as using too-high or too-low a dose can lead to false negative results and excessive animal use. To address this issue, a new protocol has been developed to determine the dose of pathogen that infects 50% of the time (AID50). This protocol minimizes the number of animals and resources required while providing an estimate of the AID50 within 1.5-fold of the true value. The method involves iterative exposures of cohorts of animals to a dilution of the pathogen stock, adjusting the dose between each round to achieve 50% infection. The protocol is generalizable to any pathogen and animal model, but is most critical for NHP models due to ethical considerations. On average, the protocol requires 15 animals, 3 phase 1 rounds, and results in an estimate of the AID50 within 40% of the true value. By following this protocol, investigators can efficiently determine the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for NHP models, reducing animal use and resource waste.
The study reports a new form of adaptation in a first-order auditory interneuron (AN2) of crickets, characterized by a time constant of 1.5 seconds for adaptation and recovery. This adaptation shifts the stimulus-response curves toward higher stimulus intensities, resulting in reduced spike responses to low-intensity sounds. The researchers investigated whether this adaptation leads to an improvement in signal representation by comparing the experimental results with two competing hypotheses: infomax and selective coding. Infomax predicts that information conveyed about the entire signal range should be maximized, while selective coding predicts that "foreground" signals should be enhanced while "background" signals should be selectively suppressed. The study used Bayesian data analysis to quantify the shifts of the measured response curves and found that adaptation actually reduces the amount of encoded information when considering the whole range of input signals. The response curve changes were also not consistent with the selective coding hypothesis, as the amount of information conveyed about the loudest part of the signal did not increase as predicted but remained nearly constant. Instead, less information was transmitted about signals with lower intensity. The study suggests that adaptation in the AN2 neuron does not follow the infomax principle, which predicts that adaptation should maximize the information conveyed about the entire signal range.
The study investigated the role of polybasic domains in the prion protein ( PrP ) in the context of prion propagation. Prions are infectious proteins that cause neurodegenerative diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Previous research suggested that polybasic domains of the cellular prion protein ( PrPC ) bind to the disease-associated conformer PrPSc, facilitating prion propagation. To examine this further, the study used prion proteins lacking one or both polybasic domains expressed from Chinese hamster ovary ( CHO ) cells as substrates in serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification ( sPMCA ) reactions. The results showed that PrPSc molecules lacking the central polybasic domain ( ΔC ) could bind to and induce conversion of all polybasic domain mutant substrates into PrPSc molecules. However, these ΔC-PrPSc prions displayed diminished or absent biological infectivity relative to wild-type PrPSc, despite their ability to seed sPMCA reactions of normal mouse brain homogenate. This suggests that the propagation of PrPSc molecules may not depend on a single stereotypic mechanism, and that normal PrPC/PrPSc interaction through polybasic domains may be required to generate prion infectivity. The study provides the first example of dissociation between normal brain homogenate sPMCA seeding ability and biological prion infectivity, and highlights the importance of polybasic domains in prion propagation.
A novel inverse reinforcement-learning (IRL) framework was developed to identify animal behavioral strategies from behavioral time-series data. The framework was applied to C. elegans thermotactic behavior, where worms were cultivated at a constant temperature with or without food and then placed on a thermal gradient. The results showed that fed worms used both the absolute temperature and its temporal derivative to control their behavior, involving two strategies: directed migration (DM) and isothermal migration (IM). DM allowed worms to efficiently reach specific temperatures, explaining their thermotactic behavior when fed, while IM involved moving along a constant temperature, reflecting isothermal tracking. In contrast, starved worms escaped the cultivation temperature using only the absolute temperature, but not its temporal derivative. The neural basis underlying these strategies was investigated by applying the IRL method to thermosensory neuron-deficient worms. The IRL-based approach was found to be useful in identifying animal strategies from behavioral time-series data and could be applied to a wide range of behavioral studies, including decision-making in other organisms. Cross-validation confirmed that the prediction ability for a future state transition was significantly higher in the 2-D than in the 1-D behavioral strategy, indicating that fed worms utilized sensory information of both the absolute temperature and its temporal derivative for their behavioral strategy. The value function represented the benefit of each state, and by applying the IRL framework to time-series behavioral data, the value functions underlying thermotactic strategies were identified.
The draft genome sequence of Chrysochromulina tobin, a haptophyte belonging to the order Prymnesiales, has been reported. The nuclear genome of C. tobin is small (59 Mb), compact, and encodes approximately 16,777 genes, with 40% of the genome dedicated to protein-coding regions. Genes involved in fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism exhibit distinct expression patterns over a 24-hour light/dark cycle. The C. tobin genome harbors a unique hybrid polyketide synthase/non-ribosomal peptide synthase gene complex and encodes potential anti-microbial peptides and proteins involved in multidrug and toxic compound extrusion. Additionally, a new haptophyte xanthorhodopsin and two "red" RuBisCO activases were identified, which are shared across multiple algal lineages. The C. tobin genome provides new insights into the evolutionary history, ecology, and economic importance of haptophytes. Haptophytes play a crucial role in aquatic ecosystems, contributing to carbon sequestration, serving as a food source for various organisms, and forming harmful blooms. The availability of the C. tobin genome sequence will enhance our understanding of haptophyte biology and facilitate the development of commercial applications, such as aquaculture feed stocks, nutraceuticals, plastics, and biofuel production. Furthermore, genomic knowledge of haptophytes will support efforts to understand the fundamental metabolic processes associated with harmful algal bloom events.
Breast cancers that are triple-negative for the clinical markers ESR1, PGR, and HER2 typically belong to the Basal-like molecular subtype. Research has shown that defective Rb, p53, and Brca1 pathways are each associated with triple-negative and Basal-like subtypes. Mouse genetic studies have demonstrated that the combined inactivation of Rb and p53 pathways is sufficient to suppress the physiological cell death of mammary involution. Furthermore, concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, metastatic adenocarcinomas. These tumors are poorly differentiated and exhibit histologic features common among human Brca1-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplasia, and necrosis. Gene expression analyses reveal that the tumors share attributes of both Basal-like and Claudin-low signatures, two molecular subtypes encompassed by the broader, triple-negative class defined by clinical markers. The results suggest that concomitant inactivation of all three tumor suppressor pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, malignant carcinomas. Mouse models that mimic the complexity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) will be invaluable tools for defining the diverse cellular biology and behavior of these tumors and for rigorously triaging new drug candidates.
Aedes aegypti (L.) is the primary vector of dengue, the most important arboviral infection globally. Accurate predictions of vector populations are required to assess control methods and develop effective population reduction strategies. A study conducted in rural Kamphaeng Phet, Thailand, from 2004 to 2007, estimated model parameters using 84,840 samples of water-holding containers. Regression modeling was used to assess the effect of larval development site density, access to piped water, and seasonal variation on container productivity. The results showed that the number of suitable larval development sites and their density in the environment were the primary determinants of the distribution and abundance of Ae. aegypti pupae. The productivity of most container types increased significantly as habitat density increased. A two-part modeling structure, called a hurdle model, was employed to account for the large number of zeroes and overdispersion present in pupal population counts. The study found that an ecological approach, accounting for development site density, is appropriate for predicting Ae. aegypti population levels and developing efficient vector control programs. The findings suggest that incorporating development site density into vector control efforts, along with research on the ecology within larval development sites, will lead to a more cohesive understanding of Ae. aegypti population dynamics and contribute to the design of increasingly effective vector interventions.
The conserved Target of Rapamycin complex 2 (TORC2) plays a crucial role in coordinating larval development and adult behaviors in response to environmental cues and feeding state in Caenorhabditis elegans. TORC2 acts in the intestine to regulate neuronal expression of the daf-7 TGF-β and daf-28 insulin-like peptide genes, which reflect bacterial-diet dependent feeding status and provide a mechanism for integration of food signals with external cues in the regulation of neuroendocrine gene expression. During development, pheromone, bacterial food, and temperature regulate expression of daf-7 and daf-28 in sensory neurons to promote a binary decision between reproductive growth and entry into the alternate dauer larval stage. In the adult, TORC2 similarly acts in the intestine to modulate food-regulated foraging behaviors via a PDF-2/PDFR-1 neuropeptide signaling-dependent pathway. Genetic variation affects food-dependent larval and adult phenotypes, and quantitative trait loci (QTL) associated with these traits have been identified. The results suggest that TORC2 acts as a hub for communication of feeding state information from the gut to the brain, thereby contributing to modulation of neuronal function by internal state. Furthermore, intestinal TORC2 activity is required for food-dependent modulation of dauer entry and exploratory behavior in C. elegans, and the essential TORC2 component rict-1/Rictor acts in the intestine to promote neuronal expression of daf-7 and daf-28.
Systematic Identification of cis-Regulatory Sequences Active in Mouse and Human Embryonic Stem Cells
    A novel computational algorithm, CompMoby, was developed to identify short DNA motifs that regulate gene expression in pluripotent cells. The algorithm combines comparative genomics and DNA sequence segmentation to predict motifs in the upstream regions of coregulated genes. CompMoby was used to identify motifs that are statistically overrepresented in genes upregulated in mouse embryonic stem ( ES ) cells and primordial germ cells, and highly conserved across multiple mammalian species. These motifs were shown to be preferentially active in undifferentiated mouse ES and embryonic germ cells in a sequence-specific manner, and can act as enhancers in the context of an endogenous promoter. Importantly, the activity of the motifs is conserved in human ES cells. The transcription factor NF-Y was identified as a regulator of gene expression in ES cells that is required for their proliferation. NF-Y specifically binds to one of the motifs and is differentially expressed during ES cell differentiation. The study provides novel insights into the transcriptional regulatory networks of pluripotent cells and suggests that this systematic approach can be broadly applied to understanding transcriptional networks in mammalian species. The findings have implications for efforts aimed at directing differentiation of ES cells or reprogramming somatic cells.
The structure of the vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) N0-P complex has been characterized using a soluble, heterodimeric complex between a variant of VSV N lacking its 21 N-terminal residues (NΔ21) and a peptide of 60 amino acids (P60) encompassing the molecular recognition element (MoRE) of P that binds RNA-free N (N0). The complex crystallized in a decameric circular form and was solved at 3.0 Å resolution. The structure reveals how the MoRE folds upon binding to N and competes with RNA binding and N polymerization. Small-angle X-ray scattering experiments and NMR spectroscopy on the soluble complex confirm the binding of the MoRE and indicate that its flanking regions remain flexible in the complex. The structure of this complex also suggests a mechanism for the initiation of viral RNA synthesis. NMR spectroscopy confirms that the MoRE of P binds to N in the NΔ21-P60 complex in solution as in the crystal structure and shows that the regions of P flanking this MoRE remain flexible in the complex. The results suggest mechanisms for the encapsidation of newly synthesized RNA and for the initiation of RNA synthesis by the viral polymerase. The reconstituted NΔ21-P60 complex is a suitable model for the viral N0-P complex, and the crystal structure and NMR spectroscopy experiments show that the MoRE of P, which adopts a stable conformation upon binding to N, includes residues 6 to 35 and corresponds closely to the fragment that was previously identified as essential and sufficient for maintaining N in a soluble form.
The study investigates the role of gap junctions (GJs) in the fly visual system, specifically in the vertical system (VS) network, which plays a key role in visual processing. Gap junctions are electrical synapses that allow direct communication between neurons. The VS network primarily connects via axonal gap junctions, making it an ideal system to explore the functional role of GJs in sensory information processing. An information-theoretical analysis of a realistic VS network model shows that the presence of axonal gap junctions enables the VS system to efficiently encode the axis of rotation (θ) of the fly’s ego motion within 10 ms following visual input onset. This encoding efficiency is near-optimal, matching the physical limits of performance determined by the statistical structure of the visual input. The VS network is connected to downstream pathways via a subset of triplets of VS cells, and the presence of axonal gap junctions enhances the efficiency of this subpopulation in encoding θ, making it superior to the whole VS network. This efficient encoding is necessary for the fly’s visually guided behavior, such as banked turns in evasive maneuvers. The study suggests that gap junctions only impact the system’s readout while maintaining the dendritic input intact, indicating that the computational principles implemented by neural circuitries may be richer than previously appreciated. The findings provide new insights into how specific network connectivity leads to efficient encoding of sensory stimuli and may encourage exploration of GJs as a common mechanism for improving information transmission in other neuronal systems.
Enterovirus 71 (EV71) is a major causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease in children, and has been associated with various neurological diseases, including fatal cases in large outbreaks in the Asia-Pacific region. Recent studies have identified human P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1) as a cellular receptor for EV71 entry and replication in leukocytes. PSGL-1 is a sialomucin expressed on the surface of leukocytes, which serves as a high-affinity counterreceptor for selectins and mediates leukocyte rolling on the endothelium. The interaction between PSGL-1 and P-selectin requires sulfation of at least one of three clustered tyrosines and an adjacent O-glycan expressing sialyl Lewis x in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1. To elucidate the molecular basis of the PSGL-1-EV71 interaction, a series of PSGL-1 mutants were generated and expressed in 293T cells. Flow cytometry assays revealed that O-glycosylation on T57, critical for PSGL-1-selectin interaction, is not necessary for PSGL-1 binding to EV71. In contrast, site-directed mutagenesis at one or more potential tyrosine sulfation sites in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 significantly impaired PSGL-1 binding to EV71. Furthermore, an inhibitor of sulfation, sodium chlorate, blocked the PSGL-1-EV71 interaction and inhibited PSGL-1-mediated viral replication of EV71 in Jurkat T cells in a dose-dependent manner. These results suggest that tyrosine sulfation, but not O-glycosylation, in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 is critical for EV71 binding and replication.
The study investigated the therapeutic efficacy of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) inhibitors in controlling Leishmaniasis, a serious global health problem. Mice infected with Leishmania major were treated with rapamycin, GSK-2126458, and KU-0063794, and their footpad swelling and parasite burden were assessed. The results showed that treatment with a clinically relevant dose of rapamycin or GSK-2126458, but not KU-0063794, significantly reduced footpad swelling and parasite load in the draining lymph node. The employed dose of rapamycin did not kill the promastigotes in vitro. Furthermore, the IL-4 production capacity of splenocytes from infected mice treated with rapamycin was significantly reduced, and the IFN-γ:IL-4 production ratio was elevated, indicating a T helper-type 1 (Th1)-skewed cytokine profile. The expression level of CD69, an early activation marker, on splenic and lymph node CD4+ and CD8+ T cells was also enhanced in rapamycin-treated mice. These findings suggest that select mTOR inhibitors, such as rapamycin and GSK-2126458, may be used in therapeutic settings for the management of leishmaniasis due to their immunomodulatory properties. The study proposes that the adjuvanticity of mTOR inhibitors may also be considered in vaccination strategies against Leishmania species.
The interdependence between the DNA uptake sequence (DUS) and its cognate ComP receptor during natural transformation in Neisseria species has been functionally analyzed. Natural transformation is a biological process by which competent bacteria take up free DNA, incorporate it into their genomes, and become genetically altered. To prevent deleterious transformation by foreign DNA, some competent species preferentially take up their own DNA containing specific DUS watermarks. Recent findings identified ComP as the DUS receptor in Neisseria species, enabling a detailed analysis of the DUS-ComP interdependence. Experiments were conducted to investigate the impact of ComP on transformation in the presence and absence of DUS, the importance of DUS and its bases for transformation and recognition by ComP, and the ability of naturally occurring DUS variants in human Neisseria commensals to transform Neisseria meningitidis. The results showed that ComP is essential for transformation in the presence and absence of DUS, and that inner bases of DUS are critical for recognition by ComP and transformation. Furthermore, naturally occurring DUS variants in human Neisseria commensals were found to be impaired for transformation of N. meningitidis, and a ComP homolog from a commensal species was shown to specifically bind its cognate DUS variant and mediate DUS-enhanced transformation in a comP mutant of N. meningitidis. These findings provide new insights into the molecular events involved in the earliest step of natural transformation and reveal a mechanism for modulating horizontal gene transfer between competent species sharing the same niche.
In fission yeast, cytokinesis requires the coordinated closure of a contractile actomyosin ring (CAR) and the synthesis of a cell wall structure known as the division septum. A genetic study in fission yeast reveals that cooperation between the paxillin homolog Pxl1 and the glucan synthase Bgs1 is essential for CAR stability and septum formation. Pxl1 is required for ring integrity, while Bgs1 is responsible for linear β(1,3) glucan synthesis and primary septum formation. The study shows that Pxl1 and Bgs1 work together to anchor the CAR to the plasma membrane before septation onset and facilitate cleavage furrow formation. Depletion of Bgs1 in cells lacking Pxl1 results in failure of ring contraction and lateral cell wall overgrowth towards the cell lumen without septum formation. The study also finds that Pxl1 concentration at the CAR increases during cytokinesis, which depends on the SH3 domain of the F-BAR protein Cdc15. The absence of Pxl1 is lethal when Cdc15 function is affected, generating a large sliding of the CAR with deposition of septum wall material along the cell cortex. The findings indicate that CAR anchorage to the plasma membrane through Cdc15 and Pxl1, and concomitant Bgs1 activity, are necessary for CAR maintenance and septum formation in fission yeast. The study suggests that Pxl1 and Cdc15 cooperate with Bgs1 to confer stability to the CAR and form the septum during cytokinesis.
A recent outbreak of glanders, a highly infectious zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia mallei, occurred in Bahrain. To investigate the outbreak dynamics and epidemiology of the disease, researchers applied high-resolution genotyping and comparative whole genome sequencing to B. mallei isolates from infected horses and a camel. The results showed that the samples from the outbreak in Bahrain separated into two distinct clusters, suggesting a complex epidemiological background and evidence for the involvement of multiple B. mallei strains. The samples from Bahrain were more closely related to B. mallei isolated from horses in the United Arab Emirates in 2004 than other B. mallei, indicating repeated importation to the region from similar geographic sources. High-resolution genotyping and comparative whole genome analysis revealed the same phylogenetic patterns among the samples. The close relationship of the Dubai/UAE B. mallei populations to each other may be indicative of a similar geographic origin that has yet to be identified for the infecting strains. The recent emergence of glanders in combination with worldwide horse trading poses a new risk for human infections. The study suggests that at least two different B. mallei populations were involved in the outbreak, with strains from 2010 and 2011 found in both clusters, indicating an outbreak that persisted across both years and was caused by two independent but temporally simultaneous introductions.
A cross-sectional observational study was conducted to investigate the clinical and parasitological features of patients with American cutaneous leishmaniasis (ACL) who did not respond to treatment with meglumine antimoniate (Glucantime). The study recruited 43 patients from three Colombian Army National reference centers for complicated ACL. The majority of patients (95.4%) were infected with Leishmania braziliensis, and 35% of the isolated parasites showed a significant decrease in in vitro Glucantime susceptibility after previous administration of the medication. The study found a negative correlation between lesion size and in vitro infectivity of the parasite, as well as a negative correlation between lesion size and parasite resistance to Glucantime. Leishmania braziliensis was the main parasite species associated with treatment failure or relapse. The study suggests that the indication of a second round of treatment with pentavalent antimonial derivatives in cases of therapeutic failure of ACL produced by L. braziliensis is debatable. The study's findings highlight the need for further research on the mechanisms of resistance to Glucantime and the development of new treatment strategies for ACL. The study's results also emphasize the importance of species confirmation in the diagnosis and treatment of ACL, as L. braziliensis is more prone to treatment failure than other Leishmania species.
In Escherichia coli, the biosynthetic pathways of siderophores ( enterobactin, salmochelins, and yersiniabactin ) and the genotoxin colibactin require a 4′-phosphopantetheinyl transferase ( PPTase ). Two PPTases, EntD and ClbA, have been identified, with EntD being part of the core genome and ClbA encoded on the pks pathogenicity island. The pks island is associated with the high pathogenicity island ( HPI ) in highly virulent E. coli strains. This study investigated the interplay between siderophore and colibactin biosynthetic pathways through potential functional interchangeability between EntD and ClbA. The results show that ClbA can contribute to siderophore synthesis and that inactivation of both EntD and ClbA abolishes the virulence of extra-intestinal pathogenic E. coli ( ExPEC ) in a mouse sepsis model. The presence of either functional EntD or ClbA is required for ExPEC survival in vivo. This study demonstrates a connection between multiple phosphopantetheinyl-requiring pathways leading to the biosynthesis of functionally distinct secondary metabolites in E. coli. The data suggest that the association of the pks island with HPI has been selected in highly virulent E. coli because ClbA is a promiscuous PPTase that can contribute to the synthesis of both the genotoxin and siderophores. The findings highlight the complex regulatory interaction of various virulence features with different functions and identify key points of these networks as potential targets for anti-virulence therapy strategies.
The article presents a probabilistic model of multiple sequence alignment that accounts for insertion and deletion events in addition to substitutions, given a phylogenetic tree and an evolutionary model. The model is based on a continuous Markov process and assumes that insertion and deletion events occur one residue at a time. The authors extend the program dnaml in phylip to incorporate this model, resulting in a new program called dnamlε. The extended program is shown to improve accuracy relative to the usual approach of ignoring gaps, while retaining the computational efficiency of the Felsenstein peeling algorithm. The authors assess the performance of dnamlε using standard benchmarking methods on simulated data and a new "concordance test" benchmark on real ribosomal RNA alignments. The results demonstrate that dnamlε outperforms the usual approach in terms of accuracy. The article also discusses the limitations of current phylogenetic models, which only account for residue substitution events, and highlights the importance of integrating evolutionary modeling into probabilistic models used for other sequence analysis problems, such as HMMs and SCFGs. The Felsenstein peeling algorithm, which is the basis of maximum likelihood methods in many phylogenetic inference tools, is also discussed as a key component of the new model.
This study investigated the mechanism by which immunity to Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is initiated in human skin. HSV initially infects the mucosal epidermis before entering nerve endings. In mice, epidermal Langerhans cells (LCs) are the first dendritic cells (DCs) to encounter HSV, but it is CD103+ dermal DCs that carry viral antigen to lymph nodes for antigen presentation. This study compared HSV-1 infected human foreskin explants with biopsies of initial human genital herpes lesions to show that LCs are initially infected and then emigrate into the dermis. LCs bearing markers of maturation and apoptosis formed large cell clusters with BDCA3+ dermal DCs and DC-SIGN+ DCs/macrophages. HSV-expressing LC fragments were observed inside the dermal DCs/macrophages, and the BDCA3+ dermal DCs had up-regulated a damaged cell uptake receptor CLEC9A. Correspondingly, LCs isolated from human skin and infected with HSV-1 in vitro also underwent apoptosis and were taken up by similarly isolated BDCA3+ dermal DCs and DC-SIGN+ cells. These findings suggest that a viral antigen relay takes place where HSV-infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken up by dermal DCs for subsequent antigen presentation. This provides a rationale for targeting these cells with mucosal or intradermal HSV immunization. The study demonstrates that LCs take up HSV, become infected, and pass live virus or antigen onto dermal DCs through cell clusters in the dermis. BDCA3+ or DC-SIGN+ dermal DCs taking up HSV antigen via LCs may be able to present HSV antigen to T cells in the lymph nodes and the dermis itself after CD4 and CD8 T cell infiltration.
This study investigated the biogenesis and remodeling of Leishmania parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in primary mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages infected with either Leishmania major or L. amazonensis amastigotes. Using multidimensional imaging of live cells and the lysosomotropic fluorescent probe Lysotracker, the researchers characterized three dynamic features of Leishmania amastigote-hosting PVs. These features include the entry of Lysotracker transients within tight-fitting, fission-prone L. major amastigote-housing PVs, the decrease in the number of macrophage acidic vesicles during L. major PV fission or L. amazonensis PV enlargement, and the L. amazonensis PV remodeling after homotypic fusion. The study also examined the biogenesis of large or tight-fitting, membrane-bound Leishmania PVs in live infected macrophages and found that the fission of Leishmania tight-fitting PVs is a two-step process involving the replication of amastigotes in a single PV prior to separation into two distinct PVs. The process is accompanied by the depletion of macrophage small acidic compartments. Additionally, the study found that approximately 50 acidic vesicles in macrophages infected with L. major or L. amazonensis are consumed in the course of intracellular infection, representing a hypothetical volume contribution of 30 µm3 to Leishmania PVs.
The study investigated the role of chromatin structure in regulating homology-directed repair, specifically gene conversion, in the chicken B cell line DT40. Immunoglobulin genes in DT40 undergo regulated sequence diversification by gene conversion templated by pseudogene donors. The researchers found that the immunoglobulin Vλ pseudogene array is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. To directly demonstrate the importance of chromatin structure for gene conversion, they used a regulatable experimental system in which the heterochromatin protein HP1 was tethered to polymerized lactose operators integrated within the pseudo-Vλ donor array. Tethered HP1 diminished histone acetylation within the pseudo-Vλ array and altered the outcome of Vλ diversification, resulting in nontemplated mutations rather than templated mutations. These results suggest that chromatin structure regulates homologous-directed repair. The study also found that histone modifications may contribute to maintaining genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences. The findings have practical ramifications for developing strategies that harness a cell's capacity for homology-dependent repair to promote gene therapy. The results suggest that permissive structure at the donor will be an important design parameter in developing donor genes for therapeutic applications. The study provides new insights into the role of chromatin structure in regulating gene conversion and homologous recombination in vertebrate cells.
The cerebellum plays a crucial role in adjusting motor behavior to meet the demands of a given situation. It is generally believed that cerebellum-based motor learning is guided by the difference between desired and actual behavior, or error information. This error information is thought to induce lasting changes in parallel fiber synapses on Purkinje cells, which in turn mediate behavioral adjustments. Olivary climbing fibers, which connect with Purkinje cells, are assumed to convey information on instant errors necessary for synaptic modification, but not to contribute to error memory. However, recent studies have challenged this concept, including a previous study on short-term saccadic adaptation that observed patterns of complex spikes ( CS ) at odds with the assumptions of the mossy axon interneuron ( MAI ) theory. To further investigate the role of climbing fibers in cerebellum-based motor learning, the authors employed a random error saccadic adaptation paradigm, which avoids the gradual buildup of strong behavioral changes and the accompanying diminution of the error. The results show that complex spikes exhibit a clear signature of the error at the time of its occurrence and a reverberation of this signature much later, before a new manifestation of the behavior, suitable to improve it. These findings suggest that climbing fibers may play a more significant role in cerebellum-based motor learning than previously thought, and that they may contribute to error memory.
In a study using a yeast model of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), researchers found that overexpression of the Sis1 chaperone reduced the effects of TDP-43 on toxicity and proteolysis. TDP-43 is a protein frequently associated with ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases, and its aggregation is thought to contribute to disease pathology. The study showed that overexpressed TDP-43 altered cell shape and reduced ubiquitin-dependent proteolysis of a reporter construct in yeast. However, overexpression of Sis1, a heat shock protein 40 (Hsp40) chaperone, mitigated these effects. The study also found that Sis1 did not physically associate with TDP-43, suggesting an indirect mechanism of action. Furthermore, overexpression of the mammalian Sis1 homologue, DNAJB1, reduced TDP-43-mediated toxicity in primary rodent cortical neurons. These findings suggest that Sis1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS and related conditions characterized by cytoplasmic mislocalization and aggregation of DNA/RNA binding proteins such as TDP-43. The study highlights the potential of Sis1 and its homologues as therapeutic targets for the treatment of ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases.
The study aimed to investigate the parasite load and molecular diversity of Trypanosoma cruzi in patients with chronic Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. A total of 65 patients were recruited, with 35 (53.8%) presenting positive amplification by real-time qPCR. The parasite load was quantified, with a median of 2.54 parasite equivalents/mL, ranging from 0.12 to 153.66 parasite equivalents/mL. Notably, the parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old, with a median of 20.05 parasite equivalents/mL. Using guanidine-EDTA blood samples spiked with reference T. cruzi strains, it was possible to genotype the parasite up to 0.5 parasite equivalents/mL with high specificity. The T. cruzi discrete typing units (DTUs) were identified in 28 patients (80%), with TcVI, TcII, and mixed infection TcVI+TcII being the most prevalent. Two patients were infected by TcV, and one patient was coinfected by TcIII+TcVI. The parasite load was higher in patients infected by TcII compared to those infected by TcVI. However, patients infected by TcII had a lower frequency of chronic chagasic cardiomyopathy (CCC) compared to those infected by TcVI or TcV. The study contributes to the epidemiological knowledge of T. cruzi DTUs in Brazil and highlights the importance of patient age and infection by TcII in determining higher parasitemia levels.
Between 2009 and 2011, enhanced bat rabies surveillance was conducted in Guatemala as part of a larger pathogen detection program. A total of 672 bats from 31 species were sampled and tested for rabies virus (RABV). The overall prevalence of RABV detection among all collected bats was low, at 0.3%. However, viral antigens were detected and infectious virus was isolated from the brains of two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus). RABV was also isolated from oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats, and viral RNA was detected in all tissues examined by hemi-nested RT-PCR, except for the liver of one bat. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein gene showed that the two viruses were 100% identical, while sequencing of the glycoprotein gene revealed one non-synonymous substitution. The two vampire bat RABV isolates were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in the eastern states of Mexico and El Salvador. Additionally, 7% of sera collected from 398 bats demonstrated RABV neutralizing antibody. The proportion of seropositive bats varied significantly across trophic guilds, suggesting complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RABV perpetuation. This study provides the first report and isolation of RABV from bats in Guatemala, highlighting the need for novel strategies to prevent and control bat-associated zoonoses in tropical regions.
The study investigated the role of A-type lamins in herpesviral DNA targeting and heterochromatin modulation during lytic infection. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) DNA initiates replication in replication compartments near the inner edge of the nucleus, where histones are excluded. The study used wild-type and A-type lamin-deficient (Lmna−/−) murine embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) to examine the role of nuclear lamins in HSV replication. In Lmna−/− cells, viral replication compartments were reduced in size and failed to target to the nuclear periphery, as observed in wild-type cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies showed that HSV DNA was associated with increased heterochromatin in Lmna−/− MEFs. These results suggest that A-type lamins play a functional role in viral gene expression, DNA replication, and growth, with the greatest effect on viral replication at low multiplicity of infection. The study found that lamin A/C is required for targeting of the viral genome and the reduction of heterochromatin on viral promoters during lytic infection. The nuclear lamina serves as a molecular scaffold for DNA genomes and the protein complexes that regulate both euchromatin and heterochromatin histone modifications. The study provides evidence that lamin-dependent targeting of the HSV genome to the nuclear periphery is associated with a reduction of heterochromatin on viral lytic genes. Further studies are needed to determine the precise mechanism by which the nuclear lamins are exploited by HSV to keep its genome transcriptionally active during productive infection.
Mitochondria originated from proteobacterial endosymbionts and their transition to organelles was linked to the establishment of protein import pathways. The translocase of the outer membrane (TOM) complex is common to all forms of mitochondria, but an unexpected diversity of subunits between eukaryotic lineages has been predicted. This study analyzed the TOM complex in hydrogenosomes, a metabolically specialized anaerobic form of mitochondria found in Trichomonas vaginalis. The results show that the highly divergent β-barrel T. vaginalis TOM (TvTom) 40-2 forms a translocation channel to conduct hydrogenosomal protein import. TvTom40-2 is present in high molecular weight complexes, which contain four tail-anchored (TA) proteins. Two of these proteins, Tom36 and Tom46, have heat shock protein (Hsp) 20 and tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) domains and can bind hydrogenosomal preproteins, likely functioning as receptors. A third subunit, Tom22-like protein, has a short cis domain and a conserved Tom22 transmembrane segment but lacks a trans domain. The fourth protein, hydrogenosomal outer membrane protein 19 (Homp19), has no known homology. Electron microscopy revealed that TvTOM forms three pores and has an unconventional skull-like shape. The study suggests that the triplet-pore TOM complex, composed of three conserved subunits, was present in the last common eukaryotic ancestor (LECA), while receptors responsible for substrate binding evolved independently in different eukaryotic lineages.
A comparative eQTL analysis of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells was conducted to investigate the pathogenic implications of autoimmune mechanisms. The study revealed cell type-specific regulation of transcript levels of genes associated with several autoimmune diseases, including a trans-acting regulatory locus at chr12q13. 2 containing the rs1131017 SNP in the RPS26 gene. A common missense variant in IL27 was identified as a significant trans-eQTL for IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells. This variant is associated with type 1 diabetes and results in decreased functional activity of the protein and reduced expression levels of downstream IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells. The study suggests that the rs181206[G] variant of the IL27 gene confers protection against type 1 diabetes through the inhibited expression of IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells. In contrast, IL-27 may promote autoimmunity toward pancreatic islets via the upregulation of the STAT1 pathway. The results indicate that eQTL mapping in purified T cells provides novel functional insights into polymorphisms and pathways associated with autoimmune diseases. The study highlights the importance of cell type-specific regulation of gene expression in understanding the genetic regulation of the immune system and its cellular phenotypes. Genome-wide association studies have identified thousands of single nucleotide polymorphisms associated with various immune-related diseases, and this study contributes to the understanding of the underlying mechanisms.
A qualitative study was conducted in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) to investigate community perspectives on the treatment of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT), also known as sleeping sickness. The study involved semi-structured interviews and focus group discussions with current and former HAT patients, healthcare providers, and program managers of the national HAT control program in the Bandundu and Kasaï Oriental provinces. The results showed that community members and healthcare providers adhere to strict prohibitions after HAT treatment, including avoiding work, sexual intercourse, hot food, and walking in the sun for six months. These prohibitions are believed to prevent serious complications, but are not evidence-based and were originally intended to mitigate the adverse effects of the melarsoprol regimen, which is no longer used due to its high failure and adverse event rates. The prohibitions have become taboos that deter people from participating in HAT screening campaigns, fearing they will have to observe these restrictions if diagnosed. The study highlights the need for better understanding and addressing these socio-cultural and economic barriers to enhance the effectiveness of HAT control efforts in the DRC. The findings suggest that providing correct health information and engaging in a dialogue with the community is essential to keep abreast of unintended transformations of meaning and to improve HAT control strategies coordinated by the Programme National de lute contre la Trypanosomiase Humaine Africaine (PNLTHA).
Between 2009 and 2011, Médecins Sans Frontières diagnosed and treated patients with visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) in Tabarak Allah Hospital, eastern Gedaref State, Sudan. To estimate the VL incidence in surrounding villages, an exhaustive door-to-door survey was conducted in 45 villages of Al-Gureisha locality between May and June 2011. A total of 17, 702 households were interviewed, representing a population of 94, 369 inhabitants. The crude mortality rate over the mean recall period of 409 days was 0. 13/10'000 people per day, with VL being a possible or probable cause for 19% of all deaths. The VL-specific mortality rate was estimated at 0. 9/1000 per year. The overall incidence of VL over the past year was 7. 0/1000 persons per year, or 7. 9/1000 per year when deaths possibly or probably due to VL were included. The survey found that 12. 5% ( 11, 943/95, 609 ) of the population reported a past VL treatment episode. Visceral leishmaniasis represents a significant health burden in eastern Gedaref State. Active VL case detection had a low yield in this setting with adequate access to care, suggesting that it may not be the priority intervention to enhance control in similar contexts.
The study investigated the relationship between gyrase supercoiling and transcription elongation in bacterial chromosomes. Gyrase catalyzes negative supercoiling of DNA, which helps condense bacterial chromosomes into a compact structure. The supercoil density (σ) of prokaryotic DNA occurs in two forms: diffusible supercoil density (σD) and constrained supercoil density (σC). The study found that Escherichia coli chromosomes have a 15% higher level of σ compared to Salmonella enterica. Using a 9 kb "supercoil sensor" inserted at ten positions around the genome, the study monitored supercoil density and transcription elongation rates in wild-type and mutant strains of Salmonella. The results showed that RNA transcription causes (−) supercoiling to increase upstream and decrease downstream of highly expressed genes. Topoisomerase I (Topo I) relaxed excess upstream supercoiling, while gyrase replenished downstream supercoil losses to maintain an equilibrium state. Mutations in the gyrase gene (gyrB) caused significant supercoil losses, which were influenced by transcription. Addition of rifampicin (Rif) caused supercoil density to rebound throughout the chromosome. The study found a link between RNA polymerase elongation speed and gyrase turnover, suggesting that bacteria with fast growth rates may generate higher supercoil densities than slow-growing species. The results indicate that the mean supercoil density of Salmonella DNA is determined by a mechanism that links the catalytic efficiency of gyrase to the elongation rate of transcription.
Leishmania amazonensis, a protozoan parasite responsible for cutaneous leishmaniasis in the New World, replicates within parasitophorous vacuoles ( PVs ) that share characteristics with late endosomes/lysosomes. Research has shown that L. amazonensis PVs expand significantly during infections, but the impact of PV size on parasite intracellular survival was unknown. This study investigated the role of LYST/Beige, a gene previously linked to lysosome size regulation, in controlling PV expansion and parasite growth. The results indicate that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate LYST/Beige transcription, which restricts PV expansion and inhibits parasite growth. Mutations in LYST/Beige caused further PV expansion and enhanced L. amazonensis replication, while overexpression of LYST/Beige led to small PVs that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment with vacuolin-1 reversed the phenotype of LYST/Beige overexpressing cells, expanding PVs and promoting parasite growth. In contrast, E-64d reduced PV size in LYST-Beige mutant cells and inhibited L. amazonensis replication. The study suggests that enlarged PVs protect parasites from oxidative damage, as inhibition of nitric oxide synthase had no effect on L. amazonensis viability within large PVs, but enhanced their growth within LYST/Beige-induced small PVs. The findings provide evidence that LYST/Beige upregulation functions as a host innate response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV volume and inhibiting intracellular survival.
Zebrafish with a mutation in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 (MCT8) gene, which is associated with Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome (AHDS), a rare X-linked psychomotor retardation disorder, were generated using a zinc-finger nuclease (ZFN)-mediated targeted gene editing system. The MCT8 knockout zebrafish (mct8−/−) exhibited neurological and behavioral deficiencies, including reduced locomotor activity, altered response to external light and dark transitions, and increased sleep time. These deficiencies were associated with altered expression of myelin-related genes and neuron-specific deficiencies in circuit formation. Time-lapse imaging of single-axon arbors and synapses in live mct8−/− larvae revealed a reduction in filopodia dynamics and axon branching in sensory neurons and decreased synaptic density in motor neurons. The administration of thyroid hormone (TH) analogs, which can enter cells in the absence of MCT8, restored the myelin and axon outgrowth deficiencies in mct8−/− larvae. These findings suggest that MCT8 regulates neural circuit assembly, mediating sensory and motor control of behavioral performance. The mct8−/− zebrafish model provides a stable and transparent vertebrate model for studying AHDS, allowing for whole-brain analysis in live animals during all developmental stages. The study proposes that early administration of TH analogs may specifically reduce neurological damage in AHDS patients.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) gH/gL forms a stable complex with the viral fusion protein gB in virions. This complex is present in the absence of other viral proteins and can include up to 16-50% of the total gH/gL in HCMV virus particles. The interaction between gH/gL and gB is not dependent on the fusion competence of gB, as gB mutants that are unable to mediate cell-cell fusion can still interact with gH/gL. These findings have significant implications for models of herpesvirus entry, which suggest that gH/gL interacts with gB to mediate membrane fusion. Previous studies have proposed that gH/gL is activated by receptor binding and then binds to gB, triggering gB for fusion. However, this study provides direct evidence for the interaction between gH/gL and gB in wild-type glycoproteins in virus-infected cells and in virus particles. The presence of gB-gH/gL complexes in extracellular virions suggests that these complexes form before gB is activated for fusion and entry. These findings support the proposal that gH/gL interacts with gB and have implications for our understanding of the entry mechanisms of HCMV and other herpesviruses.
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sequence variants segregate in a mutation and tissue-specific manner, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. A study has identified Gimap3, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, as a critical regulator of mtDNA segregation in leukocytes. The researchers used a heteroplasmic mouse model to demonstrate that Gimap3 influences the rate of mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues. The study found that Gimap3 is essential for T cell development and survival, suggesting that leukocyte survival may be a key factor in the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and in modulating human mitochondrial diseases. The researchers also showed that mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues is a complex genetic trait that is regulated with age but is independent of mtDNA copy number. Further analysis revealed that Gimap3 regulates mtDNA segregation through a cell-specific context or pathway, rather than through a direct physical interaction with mtDNA. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms of mtDNA segregation and highlights the importance of Gimap3 in regulating this process in hematopoietic tissues. The findings have implications for understanding the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and their role in human mitochondrial diseases.
The incubation period of Buruli ulcer (BU), a geographically-restricted infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been estimated in Victoria, Australia. A retrospective review of 443 cases of BU notified between 2013 and 2016 identified 20 new cases among short-term visitors to endemic regions. The mean incubation period for these cases was 143 days (4.8 months), which is similar to a previous estimate of 135 days (4.5 months) from an earlier study. The incubation period was defined as the time between exposure to an endemic region and symptom onset. The study found no association between incubation period and age, sex, location of exposure, duration of exposure to an endemic region, or location of BU lesion. The results confirm the mean incubation period of BU in Victoria to be between 4 and 5 months. This knowledge can guide clinicians and suggests that the mode of transmission of BU is similar in different geographic regions in Victoria. The study's findings are consistent with a previous estimate from an earlier group of patients who acquired their infections in a different geographic location, suggesting that the mode of disease transmission is similar in different Victorian endemic regions.
The study investigated the role of a Toxoplasma gondii protein, named TgNCR1, which is related to the human Niemann-Pick, type C1 (NPC1) protein. TgNCR1 contains a sterol-sensing domain (SSD) and shares significant identity with human NPC1, including residues implicated in human NPC disease. The protein localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the plasma membrane of Toxoplasma, rather than endo-lysosomes like its human counterpart. When expressed in mammalian NPC1 mutant cells and targeted to endo-lysosomes, TgNCR1 restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from these organelles, indicating a conserved activity with human NPC1. To understand the role of TgNCR1 in Toxoplasma, the researchers generated a parasite cell line lacking NPC1, which was viable but exhibited perturbations in lipid content, including an overaccumulation of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyelins, and ceramides. The mutant parasites also showed increased storage lipid bodies and membranous tubules derived from their parasitophorous vacuoles. Notably, ΔNCR1 parasites were more virulent in mice than the parental strain and could generate multiple daughters per single mother cell at high frequencies, allowing for fast replication in vitro. These findings suggest that TgNCR1 plays a role in lipid homeostasis in Toxoplasma, controlling the intracellular levels of several lipids and regulating lipid storage, membrane biosynthesis, and parasite division.
Ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome (OAS), also known as Waardenburg Anophthalmia syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the combination of eye malformations, most commonly bilateral anophthalmia, with post-axial oligosyndactyly. Homozygosity mapping and targeted mutation analysis identified mutations in the SMOC1 gene in eight unrelated families, including four nonsense, two frameshift, and two missense mutations. The missense mutations are located in the second Thyroglobulin Type-1 (Tg1) domain of the protein. The orthologous gene in mice, Smoc1, shows site- and stage-specific expression during eye, limb, craniofacial, and somite development. A targeted pre-conditional gene-trap mutation of Smoc1 resulted in highly penetrant hindlimb post-axial oligosyndactyly and eye malformations, including coloboma and cleft palate, in homozygous mutant animals. These findings suggest that partial loss of Smoc-1 results in a convincing phenocopy of the human disease. The SMOC-1 protein is a mammalian paralog of Drosophila Pentagone, an inhibitor of decapentaplegic, and functions as a Bone Morphogenic Protein (BMP) antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagonism during mammalian development provides a plausible explanation for both the limb and eye phenotype in humans and mice. These findings support the loss of SMOC-1 function as the major cause of OAS and highlight the conserved non-redundant function of this protein during ocular and limb development.
The study investigated the role of the tripartite motif protein TRIM22 in inhibiting HIV particle production in human cells treated with Type 1 interferons. The researchers used transcriptional profiling to identify TRIM22 as one of the most strongly up-regulated genes in response to interferon treatment.
