Differences between Trypanosoma brucei gambiense Groups 1 and 2 in Their Resistance to Killing by Trypanolytic Factor 1
    Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, a subspecies of the parasite responsible for African sleeping sickness, exhibits two distinct groups with varying levels of resistance to human serum. Group 1 T. b. gambiense has an invariant phenotype and is resistant to trypanosome lytic factor 1 (TLF-1), while group 2 T. b. gambiense shows variable resistance. Previous studies suggested that group 1 T. b. gambiense is resistant to TLF-1 due to reduced expression of the haptoglobin-hemoglobin receptor (HpHbR) gene, which mediates TLF-1 uptake. However, this study found that isogenic resistant and sensitive group 2 T. b. gambiense lines express the HpHbR gene at similar levels and internalize fluorescently labeled TLF-1 in a similar fashion to T. b. brucei. Both resistant and sensitive group 2 T. b. gambiense, as well as group 1 T. b. gambiense, internalize recombinant APOL1, but only sensitive group 2 parasites are lysed. The results indicate that group 2 T. b. gambiense is innately resistant to APOL1, which could be based on the same mechanism as group 1 T. b. gambiense. However, group 2 T. b. gambiense variably displays this phenotype, and expression does not appear to correlate with a change in expression site or expression of HpHbR. Therefore, there are differences in the mechanism of human serum resistance between T. b. gambiense groups 1 and 2.
DNA methylation of the HIV-1 5′ long terminal repeat (LTR) has been investigated as a potential mechanism of transcriptional suppression to evade host immune responses and antiretroviral drugs. However, the role of DNA methylation in HIV-1 latency has remained unclear. This study demonstrates that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR is an additional epigenetic restriction mechanism that controls resistance of latent HIV-1 to reactivation signals and determines the stability of HIV-1 latency. In an in vitro model of reactivable latency and in a latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected patients, CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR was found to be a late event during establishment of HIV-1 latency and is not required for initial provirus silencing. The latent reservoir of some aviremic patients contained high proportions of non-methylated 5′ LTR, while the latency controlled solely by transcriptional interference and chromatin-dependent mechanisms was found to be leaky and easily reactivable. In contrast, the latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected individuals without detectable plasma viremia showed HIV-1 promoters and enhancers to be hypermethylated and resistant to reactivation. However, even dense methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR did not confer complete resistance to reactivation with certain histone deacetylase inhibitors, protein kinase C agonists, and their combinations with 5-aza-2deoxycytidine. The study proposes a two-step model of epigenetic control of HIV-1 latency, suggesting that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR is an important epigenetic mechanism that maintains HIV-1 latency by preventing reactivation.
The study presents a comprehensive catalog of genomic variations in Drosophila melanogaster, including single-nucleotide, multi-nucleotide, and structural variants, in 39 inbred lines from the Drosophila Genetic Reference Panel. Using an integrative, local assembly-based approach, the researchers identified over 3.6 million distinct variants, with more than 800,000 unique insertions, deletions, and complex variants. The study reveals a high density of molecular polymorphisms in Drosophila, with a SNP every 43 bp and an indel or complex variant every 144 bp, contributing a genetic marker every 33 bp on average. Deletions and complex variants affect 4.2% of the reference euchromatic genome, while insertions add 2.1 Mb.

The researchers also investigated the impact of these variants on gene expression, mapping cis-expression quantitative trait loci (cis-eQTLs) for over 2,000 genes. Indels comprise around 10% of all cis-eQTLs and show larger effects than SNP cis-eQTLs. The study found that most cis-eQTLs are sex-specific, revealing a partial decoupling of the genomic architecture between the sexes. Additionally, the researchers performed RNA-seq-based allelic expression imbalance analyses in the offspring of crosses between sequenced lines, validating the majority of strong cis-eQTLs in heterozygous individuals. These findings provide insights into the complexity and evolution of the cis-regulatory architecture of gene expression in Drosophila and highlight the importance of genetic factors in mediating sex-biased gene expression.
This study investigated the impact of amplitude cancellation on the correlation between the neural drive to muscle and the rectified electromyography (EMG) signal. Amplitude cancellation occurs when motor unit action potentials overlap, resulting in a loss of EMG amplitude. The researchers used analytical derivations and a computational model to examine the effect of amplitude cancellation on the correlation between the neural drive and the rectified EMG signal. The results showed that an ideal rectified EMG signal without amplitude cancellation (EMGnc) is a superior estimator of the neural drive to muscle compared to the actual rectified EMG signal. However, the correlation between the rectified EMG and the neural drive decreased linearly with increasing amplitude cancellation. The simulations also demonstrated that a stronger neural drive resulted in a stronger correlation between the rectified EMG and the neural drive, and that amplitude cancellation distorted this correlation mainly for low-frequency components of the neural drive. The study found that amplitude cancellation impairs the ability of the rectified EMG signal to reflect the neural drive to muscle, except in conditions with low contraction levels and/or highly variable common synaptic input. The results suggest that valid use of the rectified EMG as an estimator of the neural drive requires low contraction levels and/or strong common synaptic input to the motor neurons. The study highlights the importance of considering amplitude cancellation when using the rectified EMG signal to infer sources of synaptic input to motor neurons.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, aluminium (Al) stress inhibits root growth, and auxin plays a crucial role in this process. However, the molecular mechanism controlling auxin-mediated root growth inhibition in response to Al stress is not fully understood. This study reveals that YUCCA (YUC), a flavin monooxygenase-like protein, regulates local auxin biosynthesis in the root apex transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Al stress upregulates YUC3, YUC5, YUC7, YUC8, and YUC9 in the root-apex TZ, leading to auxin accumulation and root growth inhibition. The Al-dependent changes in YUC regulation and root growth inhibition are dependent on ethylene signalling. Increasing or disrupting ethylene signalling enhances or reduces upregulation of YUCs in the root-apex TZ, respectively. Ethylene also enhances root growth inhibition under Al stress, which is alleviated in yuc mutants or by co-treatment with yucasin, an inhibitor of YUC activity. Furthermore, ethylene-insensitive 3 (EIN3) is involved in the direct regulation of YUC9 transcription, and PHYTOCHROME INTERACTING FACTOR4 (PIF4) functions as a transcriptional activator for YUC5, YUC8, and YUC9. PIF4 promotes Al-inhibited primary root growth by regulating local expression of YUCs and auxin signalling in the root-apex TZ. The Al-induced expression of PIF4 in the root TZ acts downstream of ethylene signalling. These findings highlight a regulatory cascade for YUCs-regulated local auxin biosynthesis in the root-apex TZ mediating root growth inhibition in response to Al stress.
This study investigated the interaction between simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIV ) peptides and natural killer ( NK ) cells in rhesus macaques. The researchers found that certain SIV peptides bound to the major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class I molecule Mamu-A1*002 can suppress the cytolytic activity of NK cells expressing the killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptor ( KIR ) Mamu-KIR3DL05. Twenty-eight out of 75 SIV peptides bound by Mamu-A1*002 inhibited the killing activity of Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells, including three immunodominant CD8+ T cell epitopes. Substitutions at the C-terminal positions of these peptides changed their inhibitory effects to disinhibitory effects, and vice versa, without altering their binding to Mamu-A1*002. The functional effects of these peptide variants on NK cell responses corresponded to their effects on Mamu-A1*002 tetramer binding to Mamu-KIR3DL05. In assays with mixtures of inhibitory and disinhibitory peptides, low concentrations of inhibitory peptides dominated to suppress NK cell responses. Consistent with the inhibition of Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells by viral epitopes presented by Mamu-A1*002, SIV replication was significantly higher in Mamu-A1*002+ CD4+ lymphocytes co-cultured with Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells than with Mamu-KIR3DL05- NK cells. These results demonstrate that viral peptides can modulate NK cell responses by modulating MHC class I interactions with inhibitory KIRs, providing a mechanism by which immunodeficiency viruses may evade NK cell responses.
Bacterial pathogens, such as nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae ( NTHI ), must adapt to dynamic microenvironmental stressors to survive and establish chronic infection. A study investigated the microevolution of NTHI in response to transient heme-iron restriction and its impact on intracellular bacterial community ( IBC ) development and persistence. The researchers hypothesized that strains adapted to nutrient limitation are more adept at colonization and evasion of host immune responses, leading to persistence. To test this hypothesis, they created a mutant strain of NTHI with a mutation in the icc gene, which results in decreased 3', 5'-cyclic adenosine monophosphate phosphodiesterase activity. In a preclinical model of NTHI-induced otitis media ( OM ), the icc mutant strain formed significantly more IBCs than the parental strain early during experimental OM. In contrast, the parental strain formed few IBCs at early stages of OM, but a significant increase was observed at later stages that coincided with the absence of recoverable effusion, suggesting the presence of a mucosal reservoir following resolution of clinical disease. The study provides the first insight into NTHI microevolution during nutritional limitation and demonstrates the formation of IBCs in a preclinical model of chronic OM. These findings suggest that adaptation to nutrient limitation can enhance the ability of NTHI to form IBCs and persist in the host.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, modulates host iron homeostasis to facilitate iron availability and intracellular survival. Infection of primary macrophages with B. pseudomallei resulted in downregulation of ferroportin, leading to increased iron availability within macrophages. Exogenous modification of iron export function by hepcidin or iron supplementation by ferric ammonium citrate stimulated B. pseudomallei growth, whereas the iron chelator deferoxamine reduced bacterial survival. Iron-loaded macrophages exhibited a lower expression of NADPH oxidase, iNOS, lipocalin 2, cytokines, and activation of caspase-1. Infection of mice with B. pseudomallei caused a diminished hepatic ferroportin expression, higher iron retention in the liver, and lower iron levels in the serum (hypoferremia). In vivo administration of ferric ammonium citrate tended to promote bacterial growth and inflammatory response, whereas limitation of iron availability significantly ameliorated bacterial clearance, attenuated serum cytokine levels, and improved survival of infected mice. The study suggests that modulation of the cellular iron balance is a strategy of B. pseudomallei to improve iron acquisition and restrict antibacterial immune effector mechanisms, promoting its intracellular growth. Furthermore, changes in host iron homeostasis can influence susceptibility to melioidosis, and iron chelating drugs may be an additional therapeutic option.
A novel technique termed “functional mode analysis” (FMA) has been proposed to identify collective motions in proteins that are directly related to a specific protein function. FMA is based on an ensemble of structures and an arbitrary “functional quantity” that quantifies the functional state of the protein. The technique detects the collective motion that is maximally correlated to the functional quantity, which can be a geometric, electrostatic, or chemical observable. Two correlation measures are applied: the Pearson correlation coefficient, which measures linear correlation, and the mutual information, which can assess any kind of interdependence. The maximally correlated motion is used to derive a model for the functional state in terms of a single collective coordinate. FMA is complementary to established methods such as principal component analysis (PCA) and normal mode analysis (NMA), which elucidate large-scale and low-frequency modes, respectively, but do not necessarily yield collective motions directly related to protein function. FMA is expected to elucidate relations between collective motions and protein function for proteins that accomplish their biological function by structural transitions such as hinge motions, domain rotations, or side chain reorientations. The technique is illustrated using a number of biomolecules, including a polyalanine-helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein.
This study investigated the order of intron removal from nuclear transcripts of Euglena gracilis, a eukaryotic organism that harbors atypical, nonconventional introns not found in other eukaryotes. Nonconventional introns lack conserved borders and sequence complementary to U1 snRNA, forming a stable secondary structure that does not resemble self-splicing or tRNA introns. In Euglena gracilis, nonconventional introns frequently insert at new positions, while conventional introns are either found at conserved positions or lost. The study examined the relative order of intron excision from transcripts of the tubA and gapC genes, which contain both nonconventional and spliceosomal introns. Using PacBio Next Generation Sequencing, the analysis revealed that nonconventional introns are removed rapidly but later than spliceosomal introns. Furthermore, the accumulation of transcripts with conventional introns removed and nonconventional introns present suggests a time gap between the two types of splicing. This study provides new insights into the splicing process in Euglena gracilis and highlights the unique characteristics of nonconventional introns in eukaryotic organisms. The findings have implications for understanding the evolution and function of introns in eukaryotic genomes. The study also underscores the need for further research on the whole-genome survey of nonconventional introns in Euglena gracilis and other eukaryotic organisms.
The Impact of Juvenile Coxsackievirus Infection on Cardiac Progenitor Cells and Postnatal Heart Development
    A mouse model of juvenile coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) infection was established to investigate the effects of mild infection on cardiac progenitor cells (CPCs) and postnatal heart development. Mice infected with a subclinical dose of CVB3 at three days old showed no immediate symptoms, but when subjected to cardiac stress in adulthood, they developed cardiac hypertrophy and dilation, indicative of progression to heart failure. Evaluation of the vasculature in the hearts of adult mice revealed a compensatory increase in CD31+ blood vessel formation, which was suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. Furthermore, CVB3 efficiently infected juvenile c-kit+ cells, and cardiac progenitor cell numbers were reduced in the hearts of juvenile-infected adult mice. These results suggest that the exhausted cardiac progenitor cell pool following juvenile CVB3 infection may impair the heart's ability to increase capillary density to adapt to increased load. The study provides evidence that a self-limited juvenile CVB3 infection may have lasting effects on the ability of adult mice to undergo compensatory vascular remodeling under cardiac stress. The findings also indicate that CVB3 preferentially targets CPCs in the juvenile heart, leading to a sustained reduction in the CPC pool into adulthood.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, regulates IL-1β and IL-18 production through NOD-like receptors NLRP3 and NLRC4, leading to pyroptosis. However, the downstream signaling pathways of these receptors and other cell death mechanisms induced during B. pseudomallei infection are not well understood. This study investigated the role of caspase-1-dependent and -independent cell death pathways in macrophages infected with B. pseudomallei. The results show that caspase-1 processing and pyroptosis are exclusively dependent on NLRC4, but not NLRP3, in the early phase of macrophage infection. At later time points, caspase-1 activation and cell death are NLRC4-independent. An activation pathway involving caspases-9, -7, and PARP downstream of NLRC4 and caspase-1 was identified in the early phase of infection. Caspase-1/11-deficient infected macrophages exhibited a strong induction of apoptosis, which is dependent on activation of apoptotic initiator and effector caspases. The early activation pathway of caspase-1 in macrophages was reduced or abolished after infection with a B. pseudomallei flagellin FliC or a T3SS3 BsaU mutant. The T3SS3 inner rod protein BsaK mutant failed to activate caspase-1, resulting in higher intracellular counts, reduced cell death, and IL-1β secretion during early but not late macrophage infection. Intranasal infection of BALB/c mice with the BsaK mutant displayed decreased mortality, lower bacterial loads in organs, and reduced levels of IL-1β, myeloperoxidase, and neutrophils in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. The results indicate a major role for a functional T3SS3 in early NLRC4-mediated caspase-1 activation and pyroptosis and a contribution of late caspase-1-dependent and -independent cell death mechanisms in the pathogenesis of B. pseudomallei infection.
The Arabidopsis KINβγ subunit of the SnRK1 complex plays a crucial role in regulating pollen hydration on the stigma by mediating the level of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in pollen. KINβγ is a plant-specific subunit of the SNF1-related protein kinase 1 complex, which is involved in the regulation of plant development. In Arabidopsis, KINβγ was found to be localized in the cytoplasm and nucleus of vegetative cells in pollen grains. Mutations in the KINβγ gene resulted in defective pollen germination on the stigma, although pollen germinated normally in vitro. Further analysis revealed that the hydration of mutant pollen on the stigma was compromised, and adding water to the stigma promoted germination of the mutant pollen in vivo. The structure and number of mitochondria and peroxisomes in mutant pollen were significantly reduced compared to wild-type pollen. Moreover, the mutant pollen exhibited reduced levels of ROS. The addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensated for the reduced water absorption of the mutant pollen, and reducing ROS levels in pollen by overexpressing Arabidopsis CATALASE 3 resulted in compromised hydration of pollen on the stigma. These findings indicate that Arabidopsis KINβγ is essential for regulating ROS levels by mediating the biogenesis of mitochondria and peroxisomes in pollen, which is necessary for pollen-stigma interactions during pollination.
The essential function of RNase III in Bacillus subtilis is to protect the organism from the expression of toxin genes borne by two prophages, Skin and SPβ, through the degradation of double-stranded RNA. Unlike in other bacteria, the RNase III gene is essential for the survival of B. subtilis, as its absence leads to the expression of toxin-encoding mRNAs txpA and yonT, resulting in cell death. These toxin-encoding mRNAs are sensitive to RNase III and are cleaved by the enzyme in the presence of their antisense RNA, RatA. The mechanism of RNase III-mediated decay of the txpA mRNA has been explored in vivo and in vitro. The essential role of RNase III in B. subtilis is distinct from its function in rRNA metabolism and maturation, as other enzymes, such as RNase J1, Mini-III, and RNase M5, can efficiently process rRNA precursors in the absence of RNase III. Furthermore, RNase III does not significantly contribute to the stability of many known antisense RNAs in B. subtilis. This study highlights the unique role of RNase III in B. subtilis as a defense mechanism against viral infection, which is distinct from its functions in other organisms, including eukaryotes, where RNase III domains are involved in RNA interference and microRNA generation.
The filarial nematode Brugia malayi, the causative agent of Lymphatic Filariasis, has been found to release extracellular vesicles (EVs) across all stages of its life cycle, including microfilariae, L3, L4, adult male, and female worms. These EVs are internalized by murine macrophages through phagocytosis, suggesting a conserved mechanism for effector molecule trafficking. Proteomic profiling of adult male and female EVs revealed quantitative and qualitative differences in the adult EV proteome, indicating sexual dimorphic characteristics in immunomodulatory cargo. Ivermectin was found to rapidly inhibit EV release by all Brugia life stages, and this effect was also observed in the related filarial nematode Dirofilaria immitis, but not in an ivermectin-unresponsive field isolate of that parasite. The morphology of the parasite-derived vesicles was examined using negative stain electron microscopy, revealing round single vesicles with a "cup-shaped" or "donut" morphology consistent with exosome-like vesicles. The study suggests that Brugia malayi uses EVs to release effector molecules that facilitate the establishment or maintenance of parasitemia, and that ivermectin may exert its anti-filarial effects by inhibiting EV release. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms by which filarial nematodes modulate host biology and highlight the potential for EVs as a target for anti-filarial drug development.
A cross-sectional survey was conducted in ten rural villages of the Western Province of the Solomon Islands to determine the prevalence of scabies and impetigo. The study enrolled 1908 participants, who were interviewed and examined by a pediatric registrar. The total unweighted prevalence of scabies was 19.2% (95% CI 17.5-21.0), with the highest prevalence found in infants < 1 year of age (34.1%) and children aged 1-4 years (25.7%). Scabies affected two or more body regions in 80.9% of participants, and 4.4% of cases were classified as severe. The total unweighted prevalence of active impetigo was 32.7% (95% CI 30.6-34.8), with the highest prevalence found in children aged 1-4 years (42.6%). Scabies infestation was associated with active impetigo infection (AOR 2.0, 95% CI 1.6-2.6), with 41.1% of active impetigo cases also having scabies. The study found that scabies and impetigo are common in the rural Western Province of the Solomon Islands, with scabies infestation being a significant risk factor for the development of active impetigo. These conditions place a great burden on the communities, with clinical management of individual cases consuming a significant proportion of limited health resources. The study highlights the need for community control strategies for scabies to reduce the burden of both conditions and their downstream complications.
A recent study investigated the relationship between T cells and cellular proliferation in the adult hippocampus of mice. The research revealed a significant correlation between the proportions of CD8+ and CD4+ T lymphocyte subsets and cellular proliferation in the hippocampus. This correlation was found to be driven by shared genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2Ea locus, which had a dominant influence on T cell subsets but no impact on neurogenesis. The study used a large stock of outbred mice to analyze the relationship between T cells and cellular proliferation in the hippocampus. The results showed that higher levels of hippocampal proliferation were associated with a higher proportion of CD8+ T cells and lower proportions of CD4+ T cells, resulting in a lower CD4+/CD8+ ratio. This correlation accounted for about 6% of the phenotypic variance. The study also found that the relationship between T cells and cellular proliferation in the hippocampus was not an artefact of transgenic or knockout mice, but rather arose from natural genetic variation. Analysis of knockouts and repopulation of TCRα-deficient mice by subsets of T cells confirmed the influence of T cells on adult neurogenesis, indicating that CD4+ T cells or subpopulations thereof mediate the effect. These findings suggest a broader role for T cell function on adult neurogenesis than previously suspected.
The study investigated the prophylactic efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine, TcVac2, against Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, in a murine model. TcVac2 was constituted of antigens identified by computational analysis of the T. cruzi sequence database and cytokine expression plasmids. C57BL/6 mice were immunized with antigen-encoding plasmids plus cytokine adjuvants, followed by recombinant proteins, and then challenged with T. cruzi trypomastigotes. The results showed that TcVac2 induced a strong antigen-specific antibody response and a moderate level of lymphocyte proliferation in mice. Upon challenge infection, TcVac2-vaccinated mice expanded the IgG2b/IgG1 antibodies and elicited a substantial CD8+ T cell response associated with type 1 cytokines (IFN-γ and TNF-α) that resulted in control of acute parasite burden. During the chronic phase, the antibody response persisted, and splenic activation of CD8+ T cells and IFN-γ/TNF-α cytokines subsided, while IL-4/IL-10 cytokines became dominant in vaccinated mice. Histological analysis revealed undetectable tissue parasitism, inflammation, and fibrosis in the heart and skeletal muscle of TcVac2-vaccinated chronic mice. In contrast, mice injected with vector or cytokines only responded to T. cruzi with a mixed (type 1/type 2) antibody, T cell, and cytokine response, and exhibited persistent parasite burden and immunopathology in the myocardium. TcVac2-induced activation of type 1 antibody and lymphocyte responses provided resistance to acute T. cruzi infection and prevented the evolution of chronic immunopathology associated with parasite persistence in chagasic hearts.
Title: From Disease Association to Risk Assessment: An Optimistic View from Genome-Wide Association Studies on Type 1 Diabetes

Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been successful in identifying disease susceptibility loci for common and complex diseases, including type 1 diabetes (T1D). However, a remaining challenge is to quantify individual disease risk based on genotype data to facilitate personalized prevention and treatment. Previous studies have failed to achieve satisfactory performance due to the limited number of confirmed susceptibility loci used. This study proposes that sophisticated machine-learning approaches with a large ensemble of markers can improve disease risk assessment. The authors applied a Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm to a GWAS dataset generated on the Affymetrix genotyping platform for T1D and optimized a risk assessment model with hundreds of markers. The model was then tested on two independent datasets, one genotyped on the Illumina platform and the other on the Affymetrix platform, resulting in an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of approximately 0.84 in both datasets. In contrast, poor performance was achieved when limited to dozens of known susceptibility loci in the SVM model or logistic regression model. The study suggests that improved disease risk assessment can be achieved by using algorithms that take into account interactions between a large ensemble of markers. The results indicate that genotype-based disease risk assessment may be feasible for diseases where a notable proportion of the risk has already been captured by SNP arrays.
During a secondary viral infection, memory CD8+ T cells rapidly infiltrate non-lymphoid tissues, such as the skin, to provide protective immunity in an antigen-specific manner. However, the fate of these memory CD8+ T cells after entering non-lymphoid tissues is not well understood. This study investigated the role of central memory (TCM) CD8+ T cells in providing protective immunity against Vaccinia virus (VacV) infection in the skin. The results show that TCM CD8+ T cells traffic into the skin independently of CD62L-mediated lymph node re-activation and provide robust protective immunity against VacV infection. In contrast to effector memory (TEM) CD8+ T cells, TCM CD8+ T cells differentiated into functional CD69+/CD103- tissue residents following viral clearance, which was dependent on local recognition of antigen in the skin microenvironment. Additionally, memory CD8+ T cells expressed granzyme B after trafficking into the skin and utilized cytolysis to provide protective immunity against VacV infection. These findings demonstrate that TCM CD8+ T cells become cytolytic following rapid infiltration of the skin to protect against viral infection and subsequently differentiate into functional CD69+ tissue-residents. Overall, this study provides new insights into the protective mechanisms used by circulating memory CD8+ T cells during a secondary viral infection in peripheral tissues.
The study investigated the role of Myosin VI in the localization of axonal proteins in neurons. Myosin VI is a minus-end-directed motor protein that plays a crucial role in the enrichment of proteins on the surface of axons. The researchers engineered a non-neuronal protein, CD8, to interact with Myosin VI and found that it became highly concentrated at the axonal surface in dissociated rat cortical neurons. Conversely, disruption of Myosin VI function or expression led to aberrant dendritic localization of axonal proteins. The study suggests that Myosin VI mediates the enrichment of proteins on the axonal surface at least in part by stimulating dendrite-specific endocytosis, a mechanism that has been shown to underlie the localization of many axonal proteins. Furthermore, a version of Channelrhodopsin 2 engineered to bind to Myosin VI was concentrated at the surface of the axon of cortical neurons in mice in vivo, indicating its potential as a tool for probing circuit structure and function. The results indicate that myosins contribute to the enrichment of both axonal and dendritic proteins at the plasma membranes of the appropriate polar compartments, playing a role in specifying the polarized structure of neurons necessary for proper electrical signaling.
In the freshwater branchiopod crustacean Daphnia magna, a Doublesex ( Dsx ) gene plays a crucial role in controlling sexual dimorphism during environmental sex determination ( ESD ). Two Dsx genes, DapmaDsx1 and DapmaDsx2, were identified in D. magna, with DapmaDsx1 being responsible for male trait development when expressed during ESD. The domain organization of DapmaDsx1 is similar to that of Dsx from insects, which are thought to be the sister group of branchiopod crustaceans. However, the molecular basis for sexually dimorphic expression of DapmaDsx1 differs from that of insects, with DapmaDsx1 exhibiting sexually dimorphic differences in transcript abundance rather than sex-specific pre–mRNA splicing. During embryogenesis, DapmaDsx1 expression is increased only in males and its transcripts are primarily detected in male-specific structures. Knock-down of DapmaDsx1 in male embryos resulted in the production of female traits, including ovarian maturation, while ectopic expression of DapmaDsx1 in female embryos resulted in the development of male-like phenotypes. These results establish DapmaDsx1 as a key regulator of the male phenotype in D. magna. The findings reveal how ESD is implemented by selective expression of a fundamental genetic component that is functionally conserved in animals using genetic sex determination ( GSD ), suggesting an ancient link between GSD and ESD.
A trivalent HSV-2 subunit antigen vaccine was evaluated for its immunogenicity and efficacy in preventing genital herpes in rhesus macaques and guinea pigs. The vaccine contains glycoproteins C, D, and E ( gC2, gD2, gE2 ) to block virus entry by gD2 and immune evasion by gC2 and gE2. In rhesus macaques, the trivalent vaccine induced plasma and mucosa neutralizing antibodies, antibodies that block gC2 and gE2 immune evasion activities, and stimulated CD4 T cell responses. After intravaginal challenge, a self-limited vaginal infection of brief duration was detected in naïve macaques, but not in trivalent immunized animals. In guinea pigs, the trivalent and trivalent + gD2 groups were 97% and 99% efficacious, respectively, in preventing genital lesions and outperformed gD2 alone. The trivalent group had genital lesions on < 1% days and shedding of replication competent virus on 0. 2% days. Vaginal swabs were evaluated daily for HSV-2 DNA and replication competent virus between five and seven weeks after challenge. HSV-2 DNA shedding was reduced in all groups compared with mock, and shedding of replication competent virus occurred on fewer days in the trivalent than gD2 immunized animals. The trivalent + gD2 group had no shedding of replication competent virus. These results suggest that the trivalent vaccine has outstanding potential for prevention of genital herpes in humans.
Title: Perm-seq: Mapping Protein-DNA Interactions in Segmental Duplication and Highly Repetitive Regions of Genomes with Prior-Enhanced Read Mapping

Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) is a high-throughput assay for profiling transcription factor binding and histone modifications. However, segmental duplications and highly repetitive regions of genomes pose a challenge for mapping protein-DNA interactions due to short reads mapping to multiple locations in reference genomes. Standard analytical methods discard multi-mapping reads, leading to large false positive and negative rates. To address this issue, a prior-enhanced read allocation method, Perm-seq, was developed to allocate multi-mapping reads in highly repetitive regions with high accuracy. Perm-seq utilizes DNase-seq and histone ChIP-seq data and read counts of local neighbourhoods of mapping locations to discriminate between multiple alignment positions of the same read. The method was comprehensively evaluated and found to significantly improve multi-read allocation accuracy over approaches that do not utilize additional data types. Perm-seq was applied to 64 ENCODE ChIP-seq datasets from GM12878 and K562 cells, identifying many novel protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplication regions. The analysis revealed that protein-DNA interaction sites in repetitive regions share overall sequence characteristics with those in non-repetitive regions, despite being evolutionarily less conserved. The Perm-seq framework is highly versatile and enables incorporation of multiple sources of data, including histone ChIP-seq, for read allocation.
A nested case-control study was conducted in Tanzania to investigate the effects of schistosomiasis on susceptibility to HIV-1 infection and HIV-1 viral load at HIV-1 seroconversion. The study population consisted of adults from seven villages who were tested for HIV in 2007, 2010, and 2013. Approximately 40% of the population had Schistosoma mansoni infection, and 2% had S. haematobium infection. The study found that women with schistosome infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition compared to those without ( adjusted OR = 2. 8 [1. 2–6. 6], p = 0. 019 ). In contrast, schistosome-infected men did not have an increased odds of HIV-1 acquisition ( adjusted OR = 0. 7 [0. 3–1. 8], p = 0. 42 ). The study also found that HIV-1 RNA levels in the post-seroconversion blood spots of HIV-1 seroconverters with schistosomiasis were significantly higher than in those without schistosomiasis ( 4. 4 [3. 9–4. 6] log10 copies/mL versus 3. 7 [3. 2–4. 3], p = 0. 017 ). The results suggest that pre-existing schistosome infection increases the odds of HIV-1 acquisition in women and raises HIV-1 viral load at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion. This is the first study to demonstrate the effect of schistosome infection on HIV-1 susceptibility and viral control, and to differentiate effects by gender.
The study investigated the copy number and sequence variation of ribosomal DNA (rDNA) in human and mouse genomes, particularly in cancer states. Using computational and droplet digital PCR approaches, the researchers found that rDNA copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Contrary to expectations, human cancer genomes showed a loss of rDNA copies, accompanied by global copy number co-variation. This loss was also observed in hematopoietic cancer stem cells from a Pten-/- mouse model for leukemia, despite increased proliferation, rRNA production, and protein synthesis. Furthermore, the study found that cancer genomes with lower rDNA copies had mutational evidence of mTOR hyperactivity. The PTEN phosphatase, a tumor suppressor critical for genome stability and a negative regulator of the mTOR kinase pathway, was found to be associated with the loss of rDNA copies. The results suggest that rDNA copy number may be a useful indicator of whether a cancer will be sensitive to DNA-damaging treatments. The study also found that short-term treatment with an mTOR inhibitor did not alter the rDNA copy number in hematopoietic cancer stem cells, indicating that the loss of rDNA copies is not an immediate event upon loss of PTEN. The findings are consistent with previous studies in budding yeast, which showed that loss of rDNA copies is associated with sensitivity to DNA damage.
The article presents a novel approach to understanding the spatiotemporal dynamics of bacterial growth, death, and spread within mammalian hosts during an infection. By using tagged Salmonella enterica populations (wild-type isogenic tagged strains) in wild-type and gene-targeted mice, researchers were able to map the population dynamics of bacteria during an infection. This approach allowed for the estimation of bacterial death rates based on the disappearance of strains over time. The study revealed that shortly after infection, concomitant death and rapid bacterial replication lead to the establishment of independent bacterial subpopulations in different organs, controlled by host antimicrobial mechanisms. Later, decreased microbial mortality leads to an exponential increase in the number of bacteria that spread locally, with subsequent mixing of bacteria between organs via bacteraemia and further stochastic selection. The study provides an unprecedented outlook on the pathogenesis of S. enterica infections, illustrating the complex spatial and stochastic effects that drive an infectious disease. This approach has the potential to transform our understanding of within-host dynamics of pathogen interactions with host cells, providing the information needed to build mechanistic mathematical models, generate new research hypotheses, and make quantitative predictions. The application of this novel method in diverse host-pathogen combinations will facilitate a comprehensive view of the spatial and stochastic nature of within-host dynamics.
Existing models of 3D motion perception are insufficient to solve the inverse problem of binocular 3D motion. The inverse problem refers to the process of determining the 3D motion of an object from 2D retinal images. Current approaches such as interocular velocity difference, changing disparity over time, and joint encoding of motion and disparity do not provide a general solution to this problem. The authors suggest that local velocity constraints in combination with binocular disparity and other depth cues offer a more flexible framework for solving the inverse problem. In the context of the aperture problem, the authors derive predictions from two plausible default strategies: the vector normal prefers slow motion in 3D and the cyclopean average is based on slow motion in 2D. Predicting perceived motion directions for ambiguous line motion allows for the distinction between these strategies of 3D motion processing. Theoretical results indicate that velocity constraints and disparity from feature tracking are necessary to solve the inverse problem of 3D motion perception. The authors propose that motion and disparity input are processed in parallel and integrated late in the visual processing hierarchy. Late integration of motion and disparity constraints in combination with other cues can solve the inverse problem of local 3D motion and allows the visual system to remain flexible when binding and segmenting local inputs from different processing stages into a global 3D motion percept.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes the anionic, O-acetylated exopolysaccharide alginate to form a protective biofilm matrix during chronic infection in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients. Four proteins, AlgIJF and AlgX, have been implicated in the O-acetylation of alginate. To elucidate the biological function of AlgJ, its structure was determined to 1.83 Å resolution. AlgJ is a SGNH hydrolase-like protein, structurally similar to the N-terminal domain of AlgX, but with a distinct electrostatic surface potential. A conserved catalytic triad composed of D190, H192, and S288 was identified, and AlgJ exhibited acetylesterase activity in vitro. Residues in the AlgJ signature motifs formed an extensive network of interactions critical for O-acetylation of alginate in vivo. In contrast to AlgX, AlgJ showed weak or no detectable binding to polymannuronic acid. AlgX, however, bound polymannuronic acid specifically in a length-dependent manner and utilized the surrogate acetyl-donor 4-nitrophenyl acetate to catalyze the O-acetylation of polymannuronic acid. The results suggest that AlgJ and AlgX have separate and distinct roles in O-acetylation, with AlgX acting as the terminal acetyltransferase. This refined model for alginate acetylation provides a rationale for the variability in the number of proteins required for polysaccharide O-acetylation.
Candida albicans, a common cause of human fungal infections, diminishes its detection by innate immune cells through masking of β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan in the inner cell wall with an outer layer of heavily glycosylated mannoproteins ( mannan ). However, mutations or drugs that disrupt the cell wall can lead to exposure of β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan ( unmasking ) and enhanced detection by innate immune cells through receptors like Dectin-1. A previous study showed that the phospholipid phosphatidylserine ( PS ) synthase enzyme ( Cho1 ) plays a role in β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan masking. The homozygous PS synthase knockout mutant, cho1Δ/Δ, exhibits increased exposure of β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan. The Cek1 and Mkc1 Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase ( MAPK ) pathways and their upstream Rho-type small GTPases are important for regulating cell wall biogenesis and remodeling. In the cho1Δ/Δ mutant, both the Cek1 and Mkc1 MAPKs are constitutively activated, and they act downstream of the small GTPases Cdc42 and Rho1, respectively. Hyperactivation of Rho1 in wild-type cells increases unmasking and activation of both Cek1 and Mkc1. Moreover, independent hyperactivation of the MAP kinase kinase kinase Ste11 in wild-type cells leads to Cek1 activation and increased β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan exposure. The results suggest that upregulation of the Cek1 MAPK pathway causes unmasking, and may be responsible for unmasking in cho1Δ/Δ.
A genome-wide association study was conducted using neuropathologic data from 4,914 brain autopsies to investigate the molecular pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and related dementias. The study defined clinico-pathologic AD dementia or controls, assessed core neuropathologic features of AD (neuritic plaques, NPs; neurofibrillary tangles, NFTs), and evaluated commonly co-morbid neuropathologic changes: cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), Lewy body disease (LBD), hippocampal sclerosis of the elderly (HS), and vascular brain injury (VBI). Genome-wide significance was observed for clinico-pathologic AD dementia, NPs, NFTs, CAA, and LBD, with variants in and around the apolipoprotein E gene (APOE) showing a strong association. Additionally, genetic loci such as GALNT7, ABCG1, and KCNMB2 were associated with specific neuropathologic features. The study confirmed 12 of the 21 non-APOE genetic risk loci for clinically-defined AD dementia, including CR1, BIN1, CLU, and SORL1, which showed larger odds ratios in the clinico-pathologic sample. Correlation analysis revealed positive correlations between effect sizes for risk of AD dementia and NFTs or NPs, and a moderate negative correlation with VBI. The study discovered new genetic associations with specific neuropathologic features and aligned known genetic risk for AD dementia with specific neuropathologic changes in the largest brain autopsy study of AD and related dementias.
Despite decades of using urea as a denaturant in protein folding/unfolding studies, its kinetic role in the unfolding process has remained undefined. To address this, a set of 30 proteins representing all native folds were analyzed through extensive molecular dynamics simulations in the presence of urea. The results show that urea concentrates in the first solvation shell of quasi-native proteins, but with a density lower than that of the fully unfolded state. The presence of urea does not alter the spontaneous vibration pattern of proteins, but rather reduces the magnitude of such vibrations, leading to a slow down of atomic motions that opposes unfolding. Urea's stickiness and slow diffusion are crucial for unfolding, as long residence urea molecules placed around the hydrophobic core stabilize partially open structures generated by thermal fluctuations. The simulations indicate that urea actively favors unfolding by selecting and stabilizing partially unfolded microstates, slowly driving the protein conformational ensemble away from the native state. The study provides a robust and complete picture of the role of urea in destabilizing folded states of proteins and the molecular mechanisms by which it contributes to accelerating protein unfolding. The results are valid at the proteome level, irrespective of protein fold, presence or absence of disulphide bridges, and secondary structure composition.
The epidemiology of dengue disease in Colombia between 2000 and 2011 was characterized by a stable annual number of dengue fever cases, punctuated by major outbreaks in 2001-2003 and 2010. The geographical spread of dengue disease cases showed a steady increase, with most of the country affected by the 2010 outbreak. The majority of dengue disease cases recorded during the review period were among those under 15 years of age. Nationwide surveillance data revealed a 90% increase in the number of municipalities reporting dengue disease cases between 2000 and 2010, from 424 to 743. The incidence of dengue disease was generally low in south and south-east Colombia, attributed to the region's low population density. Dengue disease is a serious public health priority in Colombia, and control of the disease has been challenging. Between 2000 and 2010, there was a general increase in the annual number of dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) cases, followed by a significant decrease in 2011. Gaps in epidemiological knowledge regarding dengue disease in Colombia were identified, including the need for studies on asymptomatic dengue virus infection, primary versus secondary infections, and under-reporting of the disease. Improved understanding of the factors that determine disease expression and enable improvement in disease control and management is essential.
Tegumentary leishmaniasis (TL) is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites that affects the skin and/or mucosal tissues. Coinfections with other pathogens are common in TL patients, which can influence the clinical outcome of the disease. This review aims to summarize the frequency of TL coinfections in human populations, interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal models and human subjects, and the implications of TL coinfections for clinical practice. A total of 73 records were included in the review, consisting of 21 experimental studies in animals and 52 studies in human subjects. The review found that coinfections with Trypanosoma cruzi and helminths are common in TL patients, with frequencies ranging from 15% to 88% in Brazil and 41% in Argentina. However, the mechanisms of interaction between Leishmania and other pathogens are not well understood. Coinfections can lead to diagnostic errors and delays, and may affect the effectiveness and safety of antileishmanial treatment. The review highlights the need for further research to understand how coinfections interfere with the pathogenesis of TL and to develop effective diagnostic and treatment strategies.
The study investigated the impact of natural genetic variation in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on CD4∶CD8 lineage commitment and MHC expression in rats. Using two genetic models, the NIH-Heterogenous Stock (HS) rats and a panel of MHC-recombinant congenic strains, the researchers mapped Quantitative Trait Loci (QTLs) associated with variation in MHC class I and II protein expression and the CD4∶CD8 T cell ratio. Ten QTLs were identified across the genome, with QTLs for individual traits colocalizing within a region spanning the MHC. The QTLs were refined to two adjacent intervals of approximately 0.25 Mb in the MHC-I and II regions. An interaction between these intervals affected MHC class I expression, as well as negative selection and lineage commitment of CD8 single-positive (SP) thymocytes. The effect was mapped to the transporter associated with antigen processing 2 (Tap2) in the MHC-II region and the classical MHC class I gene (s) (RT1-A) in the MHC-I region. A recombination between RT1-A and Tap2, which occurred in 0.2% of the rats, revealed an interaction between these genes. Variants of Tap2 have previously been shown to influence the antigenicity of MHC class I molecules by altering the MHC class I ligandome. The study found that a restricted peptide repertoire on MHC class I molecules leads to reduced negative selection of CD8SP cells. This is the first study to show how a recombination between natural alleles of genes in the MHC influences lineage commitment of T cells.
The study analyzed hospital discharge records in Spain from 1997 to 2011 to characterize the evolution of Chagas disease in the country. Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a significant public health concern in Latin America, and Spain is the European country with the highest expected number of infected patients due to its large migrant population from Latin America. The study found that hospitalization rates for Chagas disease increased from 18 to 242.8 per 100,000 population between 1997-2004 and 2005-2011, respectively. The majority of hospitalizations (75.3%) were related to Chagas disease without organ complications, while 23.4% had organ complications, with heart complications being the most common (81.7%). The study identified several factors associated with hospitalizations with organ affectation, including being male, aged 45-64 years, and having a hospitalization cost above the median (3,065 euros). The study also found that the number of detected infections increased in Spain since 2005, with the predominant patient profile being asymptomatic women of fertile age. The results highlight the need for increased efforts towards early detection of T. cruzi infections to prevent organ complications. The study suggests that a systematic approach towards disease detection and control is necessary to address the growing burden of Chagas disease in Spain.
A novel systems-level approach called BlocBuster has been developed to efficiently construct genome-wide, allele-specific networks that accurately segregate homogenous combinations of genetic factors and test their associations with a given phenotype. The method employs a correlation measure customized for single nucleotide polymorphisms ( SNPs ) and returns a multi-faceted collection of values that captures genetic heterogeneity. BlocBuster was applied to analyze psoriasis, a complex disease with hundreds of associated genetic markers, and discovered a combinatorial pattern with an odds ratio of 3. 64 and Bonferroni-corrected p-value of 5. 01×10−16. This pattern was replicated in independent data, demonstrating the robustness of the method. The BlocBuster network identified a bloc of 17 SNP alleles within the major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) region that is significantly associated with psoriasis, improving upon previous results by providing a precise allelic pattern. The odds ratio for the entire bloc was 3. 45, whereas the highest odds ratio for any single SNP in the region was 2. 41. This study demonstrates BlocBuster's potential for discovering combinatorial genetic associations within heterogeneous genome-wide data, thereby transcending the limiting "small effects" produced by individual markers examined in isolation. The approach has the potential to improve the prediction of disease susceptibility and broaden our understanding of the pathogenesis underlying psoriasis.
Agenesis of the corpus callosum (ACC), cerebellar hypoplasia (CBLH), and polymicrogyria (PMG) are severe congenital brain malformations with largely undiscovered causes. A large-scale chromosomal copy number variation (CNV) discovery effort was conducted in 255 ACC, 220 CBLH, and 147 PMG patients, and 2,349 controls. The study found that significantly more ACC patients had rare genic CNVs over one megabase compared to controls (p = 1.48×10−3; odds ratio [OR] = 3.19; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.89–5.39). Rare genic CNVs were defined as those impacting at least one gene in less than 1% of the combined population of patients and controls. ACC patients also had a higher burden of rare CNVs impacting over 20 genes compared to controls (p = 0.01; OR = 2.95; 95% CI = 1.69–5.18). Independent qPCR confirmation showed that 9.4% of ACC patients had de novo CNVs, which preferentially overlapped de novo CNVs previously observed in patients with autism spectrum disorders (p = 3.06×10−4; OR = 7.55; 95% CI = 2.40–23.72). The study also confirmed and refined previously known CNVs, including the 8p23.1-p11.1 duplication present in 2% of the ACC cohort. Six novel CNVs were identified, each in a single patient, that are likely deleterious. One ACC patient with microcephaly had a paternally inherited deletion of 16p13.11 that included NDE1, and exome sequencing revealed a recessive maternally inherited nonsense mutation in the non-deleted allele of NDE1. This is the first systematic study of CNVs in congenital brain malformations, showing a much higher prevalence of large gene-rich CNVs in ACC than in CBLH and PMG.
Yorkie, a key effector of the Hippo signaling cascade, plays a crucial role in regulating the injury response in planarians. In a study using Schmidtea mediterranea, a freshwater planarian species with high regenerative capacity, researchers investigated the function of Yorkie in planarian regeneration. The results show that Yorkie ( RNAi ) animals exhibit hyper-activated and prolonged wound responses, characterized by increased stem cell proliferation and transcriptional wound response. Despite increased proliferation, stem cells in Yorkie ( RNAi ) animals do not exhibit a block in differentiation, and instead produce increased numbers of epidermal and muscle cells. The study suggests that Yorkie functions as a key molecule that integrates multiple aspects of the injury response, including proliferation, apoptosis, injury-induced transcription, and patterning. Yorkie ( RNAi ) animals also display de-repression of the wound program, leading to increased stem cell response through extrinsic signals. Furthermore, the study identifies novel wound-induced genes that are de-repressed in Yorkie ( RNAi ) animals compared to controls. The results indicate that Yorkie is essential for regulating the size and scale of the regenerating fragment, as Yorkie ( RNAi ) animals fail to remodel or scale correctly. Overall, the study provides new insights into the role of Yorkie in planarian regeneration and highlights its importance in regulating the injury response.
Exosomes secreted by EV71-infected cells contain viral genomic RNA and miR-146a, a cellular microRNA that suppresses type I interferon response. The study found that EV71 infection upregulates exosome secretion and results in differential packaging of the viral genomic RNA and miR-146a. Exosomal miR-146a is preferentially co-packaged with EV71 genomic RNA and can be transferred to and suppress type I interferon expression in the recipient cell, facilitating viral replication. The exosomal viral RNA can replicate in a new target cell while the exosomal miR-146a suppresses type I interferon response. The study also found that the IFN-stimulated gene factors (ISGs), BST-2/tetherin, are involved in regulating EV71-induced upregulation of exosome secretion. In vivo studies showed that exosomal viral RNA exhibits differential tissue accumulation compared to free virus particles. The findings suggest that exosomes secreted by EV71-infected cells selectively package high levels of miR-146a, which can be functionally transferred to and facilitate exosomal EV71 RNA replication in the recipient cells by suppressing type I interferon response. The study provides evidence that exosomes play a role in the transmission and replication of EV71 by modulating the host immune response.
The study investigated the molecular mechanism underlying the interaction between PTEN-induced kinase 1 (PINK1) and Parkin, two genes associated with early-onset Parkinson's disease (PD). PINK1 is a serine/threonine kinase with a predicted mitochondrial target sequence and a probable transmembrane domain, while Parkin is a RING-finger protein with ubiquitin-ligase (E3) activity. To explore their interaction, the researchers biochemically purified PINK1-binding proteins from human cultured cells and screened the genes encoding these binding proteins using Drosophila PINK1 (dPINK1) models. The study identified a PINK1-binding mitochondrial protein, PGAM5, which modulates the PINK1 pathway. Loss of Drosophila PGAM5 (dPGAM5) suppressed the muscle degeneration, motor defects, and shorter lifespan caused by dPINK1 inactivation, which is attributed to mitochondrial degeneration. However, dPGAM5 inactivation failed to modulate the phenotypes of parkin mutant flies. Conversely, ectopic expression of dPGAM5 exacerbated the dPINK1 and Drosophila parkin (dParkin) phenotypes. These results suggest that PGAM5 negatively regulates the PINK1 pathway related to maintenance of the mitochondria and that PGAM5 acts between PINK1 and Parkin or functions independently of Parkin downstream of PINK1. The study provides new insights into the molecular mechanism underlying the interaction between PINK1 and Parkin and suggests that PGAM5 may be a potential therapeutic target for PINK1-associated PD.
Interferon-γ (IFNγ) plays a crucial role in the early host immune defense against Mycobacterium ulcerans (M. ulcerans) infection in mice. M. ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer (BU), a chronic necrotizing human skin disease associated with the production of the cytotoxic macrolide exotoxin mycolactone. In an experimental BU mouse model, IFNγ knockout mice displayed a faster progression of the infection compared to wild-type mice, characterized by faster and more extensive tissue necrosis and oedema formation, as well as a significantly higher bacterial burden after five weeks of infection. This suggests that mice lacking IFNγ have a reduced capacity to kill intracellular bacilli during the early intra-macrophage growth phase of M. ulcerans. The results indicate that IFNγ-dependent activation of the bactericidal activity of macrophages helps to contain the infection during its largely intracellular early stages. The study supports the view that concepts for vaccine development against tuberculosis may also be valid for BU. The findings are consistent with previous reports on spontaneous healing of BU and a partial protective effect of Bacille Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccination in humans and experimentally infected mice, suggesting that clearance of the M. ulcerans infection by the immune system is possible, particularly before large clusters of mycolactone-producing extracellular bacteria have formed.
Mitochondrial respiration plays a crucial role in the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are implicated in various systemic diseases. However, the mechanism of ROS generation under hypoxic conditions is not fully understood. To address this knowledge gap, a new methodology for modeling mitochondrial electron transport was developed, allowing for the automated construction of large sets of differential equations. This approach facilitated the identification of two steady-state modes of operation (bistability) of respiratory complex III at the same microenvironmental conditions. Specifically, under normal conditions, complex III operates in a low ROS-producing mode, but temporal anoxia can switch it to a high ROS-producing state, which persists even after oxygen supply is restored. This bistability explains the mechanism of anoxia-induced cell damage. Experimental validation confirmed the existence of two different ROS-producing steady states in isolated mitochondria, with significantly higher ROS levels released upon reoxygenation after anoxia. The proposed method of differential equation construction enables the detailed mathematical analysis of complex bioenergetic systems, including the electron transport chain and central metabolism. This approach has the potential to facilitate the development of novel therapeutic strategies for oxidative stress and may be widely applied in systems biology studies. The findings of this study provide new insights into the mechanism of ROS generation under hypoxic conditions and highlight the importance of bistability in mitochondrial respiration.
The study investigates the regulatory effect of the terminal gap gene huckebein (hkb) on gap gene expression in the early embryo of Drosophila melanogaster. An integrative systems-level approach was used to analyze the quantitative expression data of Hkb protein, enabling its inclusion in gap gene circuit models. Gap gene circuits are mathematical models that extract regulatory information from spatial expression data by fitting the model to gap gene expression patterns. The study shows that considering variability in the data combined with analysis of parameter determinability significantly improves the biological relevance and consistency of the approach. The models are in agreement with earlier results and extend them in two important respects. Firstly, Hkb is involved in the regulation of the posterior hunchback (hb) domain, specifically required for the anterior shift in its posterior border. Secondly, gap gene circuits presented here are able to reproduce mutants of terminal gap genes, whereas previously published models were unable to reproduce any null mutants correctly. As a result, the models now capture the expression dynamics of all posterior gap genes and some variational properties of the system correctly. This is an important step towards a better, quantitative understanding of the developmental and evolutionary dynamics of the gap gene network.
A novel immunotherapy for Brucellosis in cows has been developed using phage lysates of Brucella abortus vaccine strains S19 and RB51. Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease causing significant economic losses worldwide, with no effective immunotherapy or biomarker for monitoring treatment efficacy currently available. The phage lysates, which retain maximum immunogenicity, were used to immunize 21 naturally Brucellosis-affected adult cows. The results showed that a single subcutaneous dose of 2 ml of the phage lysate cocktail eliminated live virulent Brucella from infected cattle within 3 months. The plasma level of Brucella-specific 223 bp amplicon was undetectable by RT-PCR, and the blood was negative for live Brucella by culture. The phage lysate of RB51 (RL) stimulated cell-mediated immunity (CMI), while the phage lysate of S19 (SL) induced a strong antibody response. In vitro restimulation of leukocytes from RL-immunized cattle induced interferon-gamma production. The ELISPOT assay detected interferon-γ-producing lymphocytes in peripheral blood lymphocytes from Brucellosis-affected cattle treated with lysates of vaccine strains of Brucella. This is the first report on the use of RB51 phage lysate for successful immunotherapy of Brucellosis in cattle and the minimally invasive monitoring of the efficacy of antibacterial therapy employing plasma RNA specific for live bacteria as a biomarker.
The study investigated the role of cyclin-dependent kinase 2 (Cdk2) in the DNA damage response in human cells. Using a mutant version of Cdk2 that is sensitive to inhibition by bulky adenine analogs, the researchers found that transient inhibition of Cdk2 after exposure to ionizing radiation (IR) enhances cell-killing. This suggests that Cdk2 activity is required for an effective DNA damage response. The study also identified Nbs1, a component of the Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 complex, as a substrate of Cdk2. Phosphorylation of Nbs1 at Ser432 by Cdk2 is necessary for normal DNA damage repair and checkpoint signaling. Inhibition of Cdk2 delayed and diminished Nbs1-Ser432 phosphorylation during S phase, and mutation of Ser432 to Ala or Asp increased IR-sensitivity. These findings indicate that Cdk2 plays a non-redundant role in the DNA damage response and that Nbs1 is a specific target of Cdk2. The study used chemical genetics to uncover the requirement for Cdk2 activity in response to DNA damage and to identify a specific target of Cdk2 within the DNA repair machinery. The results suggest that Cdk2 is needed to phosphorylate proteins de novo in response to DNA lesions, and that its activity is necessary for an effective DNA damage response.
The study aimed to identify functional variants associated with hematological traits by mapping open chromatin regions in megakaryocytic and erythroblastoid cell lines using the formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FAIRE) method. The researchers analyzed 62 genetic loci associated with hematological and cardiovascular traits, including coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction. They found that the two cell types exhibited distinct patterns of open chromatin, suggesting that cell-specific open chromatin can guide the identification of functional variants.

The study identified an open chromatin region at chromosome 7q22.3 in megakaryocytes but not erythroblasts, which harbors the common non-coding sequence variant rs342293 associated with platelet volume and function. Resequencing of this region in 643 individuals provided strong evidence that rs342293 is the only putative causative variant in this region. The researchers demonstrated that the C- and G-alleles of rs342293 differentially bind the transcription factor EVI1, affecting PIK3CG gene expression in platelets and macrophages. A protein-protein interaction network indicated that PIK3CG is associated with gene pathways involved in platelet membrane biogenesis and thrombus formation.

The study suggests that rs342293 is the functional common variant at this locus, providing a molecular mechanism by which a non-coding genome-wide association study (GWA) index SNP modulates platelet phenotype. The researchers also identified six putative functional variants associated with hematological and cardiovascular traits that fall into open chromatin regions. These findings highlight the importance of cell-specific open chromatin in identifying functional variants and provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying hematological and cardiovascular traits.
The effects of persistent sodium current (INaP) blockade in respiratory circuits depend on the pharmacological mechanism of action and network dynamics. Computer simulations were used to investigate the blockade of INaP in the pre-Bötzinger complex (pre-BötC) via two distinct mechanisms: pore obstruction by tetrodotoxin (TTX) and altered inactivation dynamics by riluzole (RZ). TTX directly blocks the Na+ pore, whereas RZ shifts INaP inactivation in the hyperpolarizing direction. In vitro blocking studies using TTX or RZ have suggested that INaP is critical for intrinsic bursting in pacemaker neurons and network rhythm generation in the isolated pre-BötC. However, simulations showed that RZ blockade of INaP fails to stop the rhythm, indicating that RZ may not effectively block INaP in the intact network. In contrast, simulations predict that complete blockade of INaP by TTX will stop the respiratory rhythm. The results also suggest that pre-I bursting in the intact network is likely dependent on both inhibitory network interactions and INaP, and that experimental TTX application in the intact network is predicted to terminate respiratory rhythmicity. These findings support a critical role for INaP in respiratory rhythmogenesis in vivo and highlight the importance of considering the mechanism of action when interpreting and simulating data relating to pharmacological blockade. The study provides a mechanistic explanation for seemingly contradictory experimental results and generates experimentally testable predictions.
The study investigated the role of microRNA-218 (miR-218) in gastric cancer (GC) metastasis. It was found that miR-218 expression is decreased in metastatic GC, along with its host gene Slit3. However, miR-218 negatively regulates Robo1, a Slit receptor, establishing a negative feedback loop. Decreased miR-218 levels eliminate Robo1 repression, activating the Slit-Robo1 pathway, which triggers tumor metastasis. The restoration of miR-218 suppresses Robo1 expression and inhibits tumor cell invasion and metastasis in vitro and in vivo. The Slit-miR-218-Robo1 regulatory circuit is disrupted in GC metastasis, suggesting that targeting miR-218 may provide a strategy for blocking tumor metastasis. Upregulation of Robo1 in response to decreased miR-218 induces a reactive upregulation of the Slit-Robo1 pathway, facilitating tumor cell invasion and metastasis. Robo1 is over-expressed in cancer cells and promotes tumor angiogenesis and metastasis via interaction with Slit. The inverse relationship between miR-218 and Robo1 expression was confirmed by immunohistochemistry in gastric cancer tissues and matched adjacent normal tissues. Robo1 was found to be a critical downstream target of miR-218, and its induction by a Robo1 mutant construct reversed miR-218-mediated suppression of tumor cell invasion. Knockdown of Robo1 gene expression reduced tumor cell invasion, similar to the restoration of miR-218. The study provides new insights into the metastatic mechanisms in GC and reveals a novel regulatory mechanism of receptor signaling.
The study investigated the effects of plasma cholesterol-lowering on atherosclerosis development and identified a network of cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis target genes. Atherosclerosis-prone mice with human-like hypercholesterolemia and a genetic switch to lower plasma lipoproteins (Ldlr−/−Apo100/100 Mttpflox/flox Mx1-Cre) were used for transcriptional profiling at 10-week intervals. The results showed that atherosclerotic lesions progressed slowly at first, then expanded rapidly, and plateaued after advanced lesions formed. Analysis of lesion expression profiles indicated that accumulation of lipid-poor macrophages led to the rapid expansion phase with accelerated foam-cell formation and inflammation. Genetic lowering of plasma cholesterol at this point prevented the formation of advanced plaques. Transcriptional profiling of the atherosclerotic arterial wall identified 37 cholesterol-responsive genes mediating this effect. Validation by siRNA-inhibition in macrophages incubated with acetylated-LDL revealed a network of eight cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis genes regulating cholesterol-ester accumulation. The network of cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis target genes and regulators of foam-cell formation identified in this study merits further attention for the development of novel atherosclerosis therapies. The study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the beneficial effects of plasma cholesterol-lowering on atherosclerosis development and identifies potential therapeutic targets for preventing the formation of advanced plaques.
A genome-wide screen for bacterial envelope biogenesis mutants in Escherichia coli has identified a novel factor, ElyC (YcbC), involved in the metabolism of the essential lipid carrier used for the biogenesis of cell wall and other bacterial surface polysaccharides. The screen, which used a quantitative and high-throughput assay, correctly identified numerous mutants known to be involved in envelope assembly and implicated 102 genes of unknown function as encoding factors that likely impact envelope biogenesis. Further analysis of ElyC and other hits from the screen is expected to provide new insights into the biogenesis of the Gram-negative envelope and the vulnerabilities in the system suitable for drug targeting. The screening assay is also adaptable to other organisms to study the biogenesis of different envelope architectures. The discovery of ElyC as a new envelope biogenesis factor validates the utility of the screening approach and highlights the importance of understanding the regulatory strategies used to coordinate the construction of the different envelope layers. Further study of these factors is likely to reveal new mechanisms underlying the envelope assembly process, which could serve as drug targets to block cell growth or render the envelope permeable to approved drugs currently ineffective against Gram-negative organisms. The findings of this study have significant implications for the development of new therapies to treat Gram-negative bacterial infections, which are becoming increasingly difficult to treat due to the rise of new resistance mechanisms.
The article presents a semi-supervised learning framework for fusing heterogeneous datasets from imaging studies of developing tissues into an integrated view of multivariable dynamics. The approach exploits the intrinsic geometry of high-dimensional datasets to synthesize developmental trajectories. The method was applied to a dataset of ∼ 1000 images of Drosophila embryos, each revealing the spatial position of nuclei and one or several components of the dorsal-ventral (DV) patterning network. Pairwise similarities between images were computed using the common channel, and a closed-form expression for the estimated values of all variables was obtained using harmonic extension. The reconstructed trajectories provide a continuous view of the joint dynamics of gene expression, subcellular protein localization, protein phosphorylation, and tissue morphogenesis. The result is a multivariable trajectory for the joint dynamics of tissue shape and five molecular components within the regulatory network that patterns the DV axis of the embryo. This approach can be readily adapted to other imaging modalities and forms a starting point for further steps of data analytics and modeling of biological dynamics. The method addresses the challenge of synthesizing data from different observations into coherent multivariable trajectories, which is a common task in various fields, including physics and social sciences. The reconstructed trajectories provide a basis for more advanced mechanistic studies of multivariable processes responsible for the highly reproducible dynamics of developmental pattern formation.
The study investigated the tissue localization and extracellular matrix degradation by snake venom metalloproteinases (SVMPs) of the PI, PII, and PIII classes. Immunohistochemical analyses revealed that PII and PIII SVMPs co-localized with type IV collagen in capillaries, arterioles, and post-capillary venules to a higher extent than PI SVMP, which showed a more widespread distribution in the tissue. The patterns of hydrolysis by these three SVMPs of laminin, type VI collagen, and nidogen in vivo differed, whereas the three enzymes showed a similar pattern of degradation of type IV collagen. This suggests that hydrolysis of type IV collagen is critical for the destabilization of microvessel structure leading to hemorrhage. Proteomic analysis of wound exudate revealed similarities and differences between the action of the three SVMPs. Higher extent of proteolysis was observed for the PI enzyme regarding several extracellular matrix components and fibrinogen, whereas exudates from mice injected with PII and PIII SVMPs had higher amounts of some intracellular proteins. The study provides novel clues for understanding the mechanisms by which SVMPs induce damage to the microvasculature and generate hemorrhage. The results support the hypothesis that the high hemorrhagic activity of PII and PIII SVMPs is at least partially due to the selective localization of these enzymes in the basement membrane of microvessels.
The homeotic gene abd-A in Drosophila melanogaster is subject to regulation by the noncoding RNA iab-8. The iab-8 RNA produces a microRNA that represses abd-A, but it also has a second, redundant repression mechanism that acts only in cis. This cis-repression is achieved through transcriptional interference with the abd-A promoter. The iab-8 RNA interferes with an abd-A enhancer that lies downstream of the iab-4186 breakpoint, and the major poly(A) site of the iab-8 RNA is located 1.1 kb upstream of the abd-A initiation site. The primary transcript of the iab-8 RNA likely continues past its poly(A) addition site. In embryos lacking Abd-B, ectopic expression of abd-A is observed in the epidermis of the eighth abdominal segment, but not in the central nervous system. The iab-8 RNA is responsible for repressing abd-A in neuronal cells. Rearrangement breaks that truncate the iab-8 RNA near its start site cause a dramatic derepression of abd-A in the CNS of the 8th abdominal segment. The iab-8 ncRNA is a 90 kb-long transcription unit that extends between Abd-B and abd-A, with a likely start site within the iab-8 regulatory region. RNA in-situ hybridizations detect an RNA in the 8th and 9th abdominal segments (parasegments 13 & 14). The iab-8 RNA represses abd-A through two mechanisms: production of the iab-8 miRNA (acting in trans) and a repressive function acting only in cis, which is achieved through transcriptional interference with the abd-A promoter.
