A computational model of neocortical tissue was used to investigate the mechanisms underlying different onset patterns of focal seizures. The model was validated using clinical recordings of focal seizures and was able to reproduce two distinct patterns: low amplitude fast ( LAF ) oscillations and high amplitude spikes ( HAS ). The results showed that LAF onset is initiated by independent patches of localized activity that slowly invade the surrounding tissue and coalesce over time. In contrast, HAS onset is a global, systemic transition to a coexisting seizure state triggered by a local event. This transition is enabled by an increase in the excitability of the surrounding tissue, which does not generate seizures on its own but can support seizure activity when incited. The difference in surrounding tissue excitability was found to explain the clinically reported difference in surgical outcomes. The model also demonstrated that changes in tissue excitability could be elucidated using active stimulation. The findings suggest that the excitability of the tissue surrounding the seizure core may play a determining role in the seizure onset pattern and surgical outcome. The model was able to reproduce the initial onset and evolution of the seizure, including the growing amplitude in the LAF pattern and the development of high-amplitude spiking activity. However, the model did not simulate the termination of the seizure.
In flowering plants, sperm cells are non-motile and are transported to the female gametes via the pollen tube, a structure formed by the male gametophyte. Upon arrival at the female gametophyte, two sperm cells are discharged into the receptive synergid cell to execute double fertilization. Recent studies have identified the first players involved in inter-gametophyte signaling to attract pollen tubes and arrest their growth. However, the physiological mechanisms leading to pollen tube burst and sperm discharge have remained elusive. This study describes the role of polymorphic defensin-like cysteine-rich proteins ZmES1-4 from maize in pollen tube growth arrest, burst, and explosive sperm release. ZmES4 is exclusively expressed in the cells of the female gametophyte and accumulates in vesicles at the secretory zone of mature synergid cells. Upon pollen tube arrival, ZmES4 is released and interacts with the intrinsic rectifying K+ channel KZM1, leading to channel opening and K+ influx. The influx of K+ results in water uptake and culminates in osmotic tube burst. The species-preferential activity of ZmES4 indicates that this mechanism represents a pre-zygotic hybridization barrier and may be a component of reproductive isolation in plants. Using RNAi knock-down and synthetic ZmES4 proteins, the study demonstrates that ZmES4 induces pollen tube burst in a species-preferential manner and identifies KZM1 as a direct target of ZmES4.
A novel oncolytic herpesvirus, R-LM249, has been engineered to selectively target and kill cancer cells expressing high levels of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER-2) oncoprotein. HER-2 is overexpressed in certain types of ovarian and breast cancers. In a preclinical study, R-LM249 was administered intraperitoneally (i.p.) to mice with disseminated HER-2+ ovarian and breast carcinomas. The results showed that R-LM249 effectively inhibited the growth of tumors in the peritoneal cavity, with 60% of mice remaining free from peritoneal diffusion and a 95% reduction in the total weight of neoplastic nodules. Additionally, R-LM249 strongly inhibited the growth of ovarian metastases of HER-2+ MDA-MB-453 breast cells and reduced brain metastases. Notably, R-LM249 was effective against HER-2+ cells that were resistant to the growth inhibition by trastuzumab, a commonly used HER-2-targeted therapy. The study demonstrates the therapeutic potential of R-LM249 in treating disseminated HER-2+ ovarian and breast carcinomas, particularly in the peritoneal cavity. The results suggest that R-LM249 could be a promising treatment option for patients with HER-2+ ovarian and breast cancers that have spread to the peritoneal cavity.
In eukaryotic cells, centrosomes serve as the poles of the mitotic spindle, and their duplication once per cell cycle is essential for bipolar spindle organization and proper chromosome segregation. A study has identified Sfi1, a conserved component of centrosomes, as the first cyclin-dependent kinase ( Cdk ) substrate required to restrict centrosome duplication to once per cell cycle. The research found that reducing Cdk1 phosphorylation of Sfi1 by changing its phosphorylation sites to nonphosphorylatable residues leads to defects in separation of duplicated spindle pole bodies ( SPBs, yeast centrosomes ) and inappropriate SPB reduplication during mitosis. This results in defects in bipolar spindle assembly, chromosome segregation, and growth. The study proposes that phosphoregulation of Sfi1 by Cdk1 has a dual function : promoting SPB separation for spindle formation and preventing premature SPB duplication. The protein phosphatase Cdc14 has the converse role of activating licensing, likely via dephosphorylation of Sfi1. After SPB duplication is complete, Cdk1 phosphorylates at least four Sfi1 C-terminal residues, allowing for SPB separation and bipolar spindle formation during mitosis. These residues remain phosphorylated during mitosis, restricting licensing of SPB duplication until downregulation of mitotic cyclin/Cdk1 at the end of mitosis. Dephosphorylation of Sfi1 by Cdc14 at the end of mitosis licenses the SPBs for the next cycle of G1 SPB duplication.
This study investigated the role of viral protein R ( Vpr ) in HIV-1 infection and its contribution to the development of AIDS. Using a human hematopoietic stem cell-transplanted humanized mouse model, the researchers demonstrated that Vpr causes G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells, which mainly consist of regulatory CD4+ T cells ( Tregs ). This results in Treg depletion and enhanced virus production during acute infection. The Vpr-dependent enhancement of virus replication and Treg depletion was observed in CCR5-tropic but not CXCR4-tropic HIV-1-infected mice, suggesting that these effects are dependent on the coreceptor usage by HIV-1. Immune activation was observed in CCR5-tropic wild-type but not in vpr-deficient HIV-1-infected humanized mice. The study found that Vpr takes advantage of proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells for enhancing viremia of CCR5-tropic HIV-1. Tregs exist in a higher cycling state than other T cell subsets, making them more vulnerable to exploitation by Vpr during acute HIV-1 infection. The results suggest that Vpr plays a crucial role in accelerating CCR5-tropic HIV-1 propagation during acute infection by utilizing CCR5+ proliferating CD4+ T cells including Tregs. The study provides direct evidence for the first time that Vpr positively affects HIV-1 replication by taking advantage of Tregs in vivo.
A 15-year longitudinal study on Plasmodium vivax population genetics in South Korea was conducted using microsatellite DNA markers to assess the population structure and temporal dynamics of parasite transmission. The study analyzed 14 microsatellite DNA loci from 163 isolates collected between 1994 and 2008. The results showed a gradual decrease in linkage disequilibrium (LD) levels and an increase in genetic diversity from 1994 to 2008. However, a drastic genetic change was observed in the South Korean P. vivax population during 2002 and 2003. This change was not attributed to relapse or asymptomatic parasite carriage, but rather to the continual introduction of P. vivax into South Korea from other parasite population sources. One possible source of this introduction is North Korea, particularly during 2002 and 2003. The study suggests that molecular epidemiology using microsatellite DNA of the P. vivax population is effective for assessing the population structure and temporal dynamics of parasite transmission, which can aid in the elimination of vivax malaria in endemic areas.
The study investigated the role of a splicing-competent intron in regulating transcription directionality in eukaryotes. It was found that the intron is an important regulator of promoter directionality, favoring the transcription of mRNA over upstream anti-sense transcripts (uaRNA) initiating from the promoter. Mutation of either the 5' or 3' splice site resulted in the reversal of promoter directionality, suggesting that the entire splicing-competent intron, not just the 5' splice site, regulates transcription directionality. ChIP analysis revealed the recruitment of termination factors near the promoter region in the presence of an intron, which was affected by the removal of the intron or mutation of splice sites. The study also demonstrated that gene looping is crucial for the recruitment of termination factors in the promoter-proximal region of an intron-containing gene. In a looping-defective mutant, despite normal splicing, the promoter occupancy of factors required for poly(A)-dependent termination of transcription was compromised, accompanied by a concomitant loss of transcription directionality. The results suggest that the intron-dependent gene looping places terminator-bound factors in the vicinity of the promoter region for termination of promoter-initiated upstream antisense transcription, thereby conferring promoter directionality. The study provides evidence that the transcription directionality of a subset of genes in yeast is dependent on the presence of a splicing-competent intron, which facilitates the recruitment of termination factors near the promoter region.
ZBED6 is a novel transcription factor derived from a domesticated DNA transposon that regulates IGF2 expression and muscle growth. A single nucleotide substitution in intron 3 of IGF2 in pigs leads to a 3-fold up-regulation of IGF2 in skeletal muscle, resulting in major effects on muscle growth, size of the heart, and fat deposition. The repressor of IGF2 expression was identified as ZBED6, which is specific to placental mammals and is derived from an exapted DNA transposon. Silencing of Zbed6 in mouse C2C12 myoblasts affects Igf2 expression, cell proliferation, wound healing, and myotube formation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing using C2C12 cells identified approximately 2, 500 ZBED6 binding sites in the genome, with a consensus motif that matches the established binding site in Igf2. Genes associated with ZBED6 binding sites are enriched for certain Gene Ontology classifications, including development and transcriptional regulation. The phenotypic effects in mutant pigs and ZBED6-silenced C2C12 myoblasts suggest that ZBED6 is an important transcription factor in placental mammals, affecting development, cell proliferation, and growth. ZBED6 binds to its target sites in IGF2, leading to repression of IGF2 expression in pig skeletal muscle and mouse C2C12 cells. Silencing of Zbed6 also leads to increased cell proliferation, faster myotube formation, and faster wound healing in C2C12 cells. The ability of ZBED6 to interact with chromatin and affect transcriptional regulation is likely derived from its ancestral transposase function.
The RNA editome in rhesus macaques has been comprehensively profiled using genome and transcriptome sequencing of multiple tissues from the same animal. The study identified 31,250 editing sites, with 99.8% being A-to-G transitions, and verified 96.6% of editing sites in coding regions and 97.5% of randomly selected sites in non-coding regions. The findings suggest that adenosine deamination is associated with the macaque editome, with A-to-G editing sites flanked by sequences with attributes of ADAR substrates. The sequence context and expression profile of ADARs were found to be relevant factors in determining the quantitative variance of RNA editing across different sites and tissue types. The study also detected substitution valleys of decreased divergence around editing sites, indicating evolutionary constraint in maintaining some editing substrates with their double-stranded structure. These results support the "continuous probing" model of RNA editing, which proposes that a small proportion of functional editing sites originate through tinkering. The macaque editome provides an informative framework for understanding RNA editing in humans and highlights RNA editing as a widespread functional regulation in primate evolution. The study also found intra-population conservation of the macaque editome and parallels of the editome across multiple primate species, suggesting that purifying selection may have shaped the RNA editome. Overall, the study provides a comprehensive and quantitative profile of the RNA editome in rhesus macaques, shedding light on the mechanisms and functional relevance of RNA editing in primates.
A new perceptual bias has been identified in two-alternative visual discrimination tasks, where observers read out the likelihood representation with low precision when discriminating grating spatial frequencies. In a two-alternative spatial frequency discrimination task, filtered visual noise significantly alters the perception of two known gratings, shifting perceived spatial frequency to lower and higher frequencies in low-pass and high-pass filtered noise conditions, respectively. Observers consider the log likelihood values of spatial frequencies that are a-priori unlikely to occur during the task, which lowers grating detectability and leads to a bias in perceived spatial frequency. The log likelihood functions are asymmetrical around the veridical grating frequency in the presence of low-pass and high-pass filtered noise. High overall performance and steep psychometric functions in the discrimination task indicate that observers base their decisions at least partially on the veridical grating spatial frequency. Grating detectability and discriminability were measured in the presence of filtered visual noise, revealing that filtered noise backgrounds dramatically alter the perception of grating spatial frequency. Embedding a grating in low-pass filtered noise causes the perceived spatial frequency of the grating to decrease, while high-pass filtered noise increases perceived grating spatial frequency. These findings suggest that observers evaluate likelihoods of a broad range of irrelevant frequencies and discard prior knowledge of stimulus alternatives when performing two-alternative discrimination.
In Caenorhabditis elegans, piwi-interacting RNAs ( piRNAs ) play a crucial role in defending the genome against foreign genetic elements. Recent studies have shown that piRNAs are derived from the processing of a long, polycistronic RNA precursor. However, this study reveals that each C. elegans piRNA represents a tiny, autonomous transcriptional unit. The minimal C. elegans piRNA cassette requires only a 21 nucleotide ( nt ) piRNA sequence and an ∼50 nt upstream motif with limited genomic context for expression. This upstream motif is necessary for independent expression of a germline-enriched, Piwi-dependent piRNA. The study demonstrates that a single nucleotide position within this motif directs differential germline enrichment. Over 70% of C. elegans piRNAs are selectively expressed in male or female germline, and comparison of the genes they target suggests that these two populations have evolved independently. The results indicate that C. elegans piRNA upstream motifs act as independent promoters to specify which sequences are expressed as piRNAs, how abundantly they are expressed, and in what germline. The study reveals that the number of transcriptional units encoding piRNAs rivals the number of mRNA coding genes in the C. elegans genome. The findings suggest that each 21U RNA locus encodes all the information necessary for driving independent, autonomous transcription from more than 15, 000 unique piRNA loci in C. elegans.
During Brucella infection, the bacteria replicate within host cells in endoplasmic reticulum ( ER )-derived vacuoles. The mechanisms by which Brucella acquires the ER-derived membrane for replication are not fully understood. This study investigated the role of the unfolded protein response ( UPR ) in Brucella intracellular life and identified a novel host factor, Yip1A, essential for the activation of the IRE1 pathway. The IRE1 pathway, but not the PERK and ATF6 pathways, of the UPR was activated in a time-dependent manner during Brucella infection, and the COPII vesicle components Sar1, Sec23, and Sec24D were upregulated. The biogenesis of ER-derived vacuoles was observed in the close proximity of replicating bacteria in Brucella-infected cells. Yip1A was found to be responsible for the phosphorylation of IRE1 through high-order assembly of Ire1 molecules at ER exit sites ( ERES ) under UPR conditions. In Yip1A-knockdown cells, Brucella failed to generate ER-derived vacuoles and remained in endosomal/lysosomal compartments. The autophagy-related proteins Atg9 and WIPI1, but not DFCP1, were required for the biogenesis of ER-derived membrane compartments. These findings indicate that the activation of the IRE1 pathway and the subsequent formation of ER-derived vacuoles are critical for Brucella to establish a safe replication niche, and that Yip1A is indispensable for these processes. The study proposes a model for intracellular Brucella replication that exploits the host UPR and ER-derived vacuole formation machineries, both of which depend on Yip1A-mediated IRE1 activation.
Tomato bushy stunt virus (TBSV) and carnation Italian ringspot virus (CIRV) recruit the cellular Vps34 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) into the large viral replication compartment. The kinase function of Vps34 is crucial for TBSV replication, suggesting that PI(3)P phosphoinositide is utilized by TBSV for building the replication compartment. Overexpression of PI(3)P phosphatase in yeast or plants inhibited TBSV replication on peroxisomal membranes and CIRV replication on mitochondrial membranes. The purified PI(3)P phosphatase also reduced TBSV replicase assembly in a cell-free system. Detection of PI(3)P with antibody or a bioprobe revealed the enrichment of PI(3)P in the replication compartment. Vps34 is directly recruited into the replication compartment through interaction with p33 replication protein. Gene deletion analysis in surrogate yeast host unraveled that TBSV replication requires the vesicle transport function of Vps34. In the absence of Vps34, TBSV cannot efficiently recruit the Rab5-positive early endosomes, which provide PE-rich membranes for membrane biogenesis of the TBSV replication compartment. Vps34 and PI(3)P are needed for the stability of the p33 replication protein, which is degraded by the 26S proteasome when PI(3)P abundance was decreased by an inhibitor of Vps34.
A study was conducted in Iquitos, Peru to assess the feasibility of feeding Aedes aegypti mosquitoes on dengue virus-infected human volunteers for vector competence studies. The study aimed to compare artificial and natural blood feeding methods based on rates of dengue virus (DENV) infection and dissemination within mosquitoes. Between 2011 and 2015, 58 participants, aged 5 years and older, with 5 or fewer days of fever, were enrolled from ongoing clinic- and neighborhood-based studies on dengue in Iquitos. Wild-type, laboratory-reared Aedes aegypti mosquitoes were fed directly on febrile individuals or on blood collected from participants that was either untreated or treated with EDTA. Mosquitoes were tested after approximately 14 days of extrinsic incubation for DENV infection and dissemination. The results showed that DENV infection and dissemination rates were not significantly different following direct and indirect-EDTA feeding, but were significantly lower for mosquitoes that fed indirectly on blood with no additive. Dissemination rates were similar across all feeding methods. No differences were detected in DENV infection or dissemination rates in mosquitoes fed directly on participants with different dengue illness severity. The study demonstrates the feasibility of using direct and indirect feeding methods for field-based studies on vector competence. Direct mosquito feeding is preferable in terms of logistical ease, biosecurity, and reliability. The study provides preliminary data on the ability of DENV from people with mild or inapparent disease to infect and disseminate within mosquitoes.
Biomedical researchers investigated the genetic basis of variability in response to topoisomerase II poisons in Caenorhabditis elegans, a model organism. They found that natural variation in the topoisomerase II enzyme, specifically a methionine-to-glutamine substitution at position 797 ( Q797M ), underlies differences in sensitivity to etoposide and other topoisomerase II poisons. The presence of a non-polar methionine at this residue increases hydrophobic interactions with the poison etoposide, leading to increased genomic instability. This residue is conserved from yeast to humans and is one of the few differences between the two human topoisomerase II isoforms ( hTOPIIα and hTOPIIβ ). The researchers used genome-edited human cell lines to show that the methionine residue in hTOPIIα contributes to differential toxicity of various topoisomerase II poisons, including teniposide and XK469. These results demonstrate the utility of C. elegans in understanding the genetics of drug responses and highlight the potential for personalized treatments based on genetic information. The findings also explain why hTOPIIα and hTOPIIβ are differentially affected by various poisons, providing insights into the mechanisms of drug susceptibility in human cells.
The study investigated the genetic mechanisms underlying lifespan determination in mammals by analyzing genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species, including long-lived African mole-rats (Bathyergidae) and short-lived rats. The researchers identified 250 positively selected genes (PSGs) associated with enhanced longevity, which showed an expression pattern consistent with the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging. This theory proposes that genes with beneficial effects in youth have detrimental effects in old age. The PSGs were found to be enriched for genes related to aging, including cellular respiration, metal ion homeostasis, and processes regulated by the mTOR pathway, such as translation, autophagy, and inflammation. Notably, the PSGs included RHEB and IGF1, central components of aging-relevant pathways, as well as genes previously unknown to be associated with aging, such as RHEBL1, AMHR2, PSMG1, and AGER. Protein homology modeling suggested functional consequences for amino acid changes under positive selection. The study's findings provide a resource for further investigation into the mechanisms linking identified genes and amino acids to aging and lifespan determination. The results are consistent with previous studies in other organisms, including worms, killifishes, and mice, which have shown that lower expression of genes related to these processes is associated with longer lifespan.
Researchers have developed a new Aedes albopictus transinfection, ARwP-M, by introducing the wMel Wolbachia strain into the ARwP line, which had previously been established by replacing the wAlbA and wAlbB Wolbachia strains with the wPip strain. The new transinfection showed a 100% rate of maternal inheritance of wMel and wPip Wolbachia. The study compared the infection and fitness parameters of ARwP-M, ARwP, and wild-type Aedes albopictus sharing the same genetic background. The results showed that survival, female fecundity, and egg fertility did not differ between the three Aedes albopictus lines. However, crosses between ARwP-M males and wild-type females were fully unfertile, while egg hatch in reverse crosses increased from 0 to about 17% with wild-type males aging from 3 to 17 days. When competing with wild-type males for wild-type females, ARwP-M males induced a level of sterility significantly higher than that expected for an equal mating competitiveness. The overall Wolbachia density in ARwP-M females was about 15-fold higher than in ARwP, mostly due to the wMel infection. This feature corresponded to a strongly reduced vector competence for chikungunya and dengue viruses, with transmission rates of 5% and 0% at 14 and 21 days post-infection, respectively. The vector competence for Zika virus did not show significant differences between ARwP-M and ARwP, but none of the tested ARwP-M females was capable of transmitting Zika virus. These findings suggest that the exploitation of Wolbachia could be used to suppress wild-type Aedes albopictus populations.
The study presents a novel approach to identifying peptide-mediated interactions in proteins using high-resolution three-dimensional (3D) structures. Current methods for discovering peptide motifs rely on their tendency to occur in disordered regions, but this work focuses on the observation that peptides adopt a well-defined structure upon binding to their partner domain. By analyzing 3D structures of known peptide-mediated interactions, the researchers found that the structure of the peptide can be as characteristic as the consensus motif, enabling the identification of target peptides even if they do not match established patterns. The study reveals that peptides involved in these interactions tend to have a stretched and elongated structure, unlike most other peptides of the same length. A Support Vector Machine (SVM) was implemented to search the set of protein interactions of known 3D structure and identify unnoticed peptide-mediated interactions. The analysis also derived consensus patterns for these interactions and compared them with established linear motif patterns and their binding domains. The results were cross-validated by scanning interactome networks from four model organisms, revealing significant over-representations for 64 domain-motif interactions, 46 of which had not been described before. The study provides a new strategy for identifying peptide-mediated interactions and highlights the importance of structural data in understanding protein recognition and specificity.
This study investigated the cellular mechanisms of impaired barrier function in environmental enteropathy (EE), a condition associated with growth failure, micronutrient malabsorption, and impaired responses to oral vaccines. Using confocal laser endomicroscopy (CLE), histology, immunohistochemistry, and mRNA sequencing of small intestinal biopsies from 49 adults with EE in Lusaka, Zambia, the researchers found virtually ubiquitous small intestinal damage. Epithelial defects were predominantly seen at the tips of villi and corresponded with leakage imaged in vivo by CLE. Circulating lipopolysaccharide (LPS) was correlated with cell shedding events and serum glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2). Zinc uptake from a test dose was attenuated in 64% of individuals and was reduced by HIV, but positively correlated with GLP-2. Transcriptomic analysis identified 23 differentially expressed genes in severe enteropathy, including protective peptides and proteins. Confocal endomicroscopy, claudin 4 immunostaining, and histology identified epithelial defects, which are probably sites of bacterial translocation. The study suggests that increased epithelial surface area increases the burden of translocation, and GLP-2 and other protective peptides may play an important role in mucosal protection in EE. Biomarkers of microbial translocation and inflammation were compared with confocal images and zinc uptake to explore barrier defects and identify potential biomarkers for further research.
The study investigated the molecular mechanism of superinfection exclusion (SIE) in turnip crinkle virus (TCV), a phenomenon where host cells block re-infection by the same or highly similar viruses. The research found that SIE in TCV is exclusively determined by p28, one of the two replication proteins encoded by the virus. p28 expressed from a TCV replicon exerted strong SIE to a different TCV replicon, and transiently expressed p28 delivered simultaneously with or ahead of a TCV replicon largely recapitulated this repressive activity. The study demonstrated that p28-mediated SIE is enhanced by C-terminal modifications and inversely correlates with the ability of p28 to complement the replication of a p28-defective TCV replicon. Furthermore, p28 in SIE-positive cells formed large, mobile punctate inclusions that trans-aggregated a non-coalescing, SIE-defective, yet replication-competent p28 mutant. The results support a model postulating that TCV SIE is caused by the formation of multimeric p28 complexes capable of intercepting fresh p28 monomers translated from superinfector genomes, thereby abolishing superinfector replication. This model could be applicable to other RNA viruses and offer novel targets for antiviral therapy. The study reveals that p28 acts both as a replication facilitator and a repressor, depending on its cellular concentration, and provides insights into the molecular mechanism of SIE in TCV.
Vaccination with a plasmid DNA encoding the Trypanosoma cruzi trans-sialidase (TS) gene has been shown to induce strong immune responses and provide protection against acute lethal challenge in mice. However, long-term protection has not been reported. To investigate whether the co-administration of a plasmid encoding IL-15 (pIL-15) could improve the duration of protection, mice were immunized with pTS in the presence or absence of pIL-15. The results showed that mice receiving pTS alone developed robust TS-specific IFN-γ responses and survived a lethal challenge given within the first 3 months following immunization. The addition of pIL-15 to pTS vaccination did not significantly alter T cell responses or protection during this early post-vaccination period. However, mice vaccinated with both pTS and pIL-15 challenged 6 months post-vaccination were significantly more protected against lethal T. cruzi challenges than mice vaccinated with pTS alone. Improved protection correlated with significantly higher numbers of TS-specific IFN-γ producing total and CD8+ T cells detected >6 months post-immunization. The addition of pIL-15 during genetic vaccination greatly improved long-term T cell survival, memory T cell expansion, and long-term protection against T. cruzi. These findings suggest that co-administration of pIL-15 with pTS can enhance long-term protection against T. cruzi, a complex intracellular protozoan pathogen.
In Trypanosoma brucei, a Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligase complex composed of Cullin4, the DNA damage-binding protein 1 homolog TbDDB1, and the WD40-repeat protein WDR1 controls the abundance of the Polo-like kinase homolog TbPLK. TbPLK plays essential roles in basal body segregation, flagellum attachment, and cytokinesis. WDR1 interacts with TbPLK through its C-terminal domain and with TbDDB1 through its N-terminal WD40 motif. Depletion of WDR1 inhibits bilobe duplication and basal body segregation, disrupts the assembly of the new flagellum attachment zone filament, and detaches the new flagellum. This is due to excessive accumulation of TbPLK in the basal body and the bilobe, leading to continuous phosphorylation of TbCentrin2 in the bilobe at late cell cycle stages. The results identify WDR1 as a TbPLK receptor in the Cullin4-DDB1 ubiquitin ligase complex for degrading TbPLK in the basal body and the bilobe after the G1/S cell cycle transition. This process promotes bilobe duplication, basal body separation, and flagellum-cell body adhesion. The CRL4WDR1 complex is responsible for degrading TbPLK in the basal body and the bilobe, and its depletion leads to defective bilobe duplication, flagellum attachment, and flagellum-cell body adhesion. WDR1 localizes to the basal body and the bilobe region during G1 and S phases, suggesting that CRL4WDR1 is primarily responsible for TbPLK degradation in these regions.
The DEAD box RNA helicase DDX3X plays a crucial role in the innate immune system, particularly in the context of antimicrobial immunity. Mice lacking DDX3X in the hematopoietic system exhibit altered leukocyte composition in bone marrow and spleen and are highly susceptible to Listeria monocytogenes infection. This suggests that DDX3X is essential for the innate immune response against Listeria. The sex-specific isoforms of DDX3, DDX3X and DDX3Y, contribute to innate immunity, with DDX3X having a more significant impact. The loss of DDX3X affects the innate immune system through its role in hematopoiesis and its regulation of the innate response to Listeria infections. RNA-Seq analysis revealed that DDX3X deficiency alters the expression of genes involved in the innate antimicrobial response of macrophages, with the extent of the effect depending on the sex chromosomes of the cells. DDX3X has been shown to regulate IFN-I transcription in cells infected with viruses or Listeria monocytogenes. The DEAD-box RNA helicase superfamily 2, to which DDX3X belongs, has widespread functions in RNA metabolism, including transcription, RNA processing, splicing, decay, and translation. These findings provide further evidence for the importance of DDX3X in innate immunity and suggest that it may contribute to sex-related differences in resistance to microbes and resilience to inflammatory disease.
A computational model of the insect pheromone transduction cascade in male moth olfactory receptor neurons (ORNs) has been developed. The model focuses on post-effector processes, including the production and degradation of second messengers (IP3 and DAG), the opening and closing of ionic channels, and Ca2+ extrusion mechanisms. The model takes into account the translocation of pheromone molecules from air to sensillum lymph, their deactivation and interaction with receptors, and G-protein and effector enzyme activation. The model captures the main features of the dose-response curves, including a wide dynamic range of six decades with amplitudes matching experimental data, short rising time, and long falling time. It also reproduces the second messenger kinetics. The model suggests that the two main types of depolarizing ionic channels play different roles at low and high pheromone concentrations. The DAG-gated cationic channel plays a major role in depolarization at low concentrations, while the Ca2+-gated Cl− channel plays a major role at middle and high concentrations. The model was fitted to experimental data by adjusting unknown parameter values. The results provide new insights into the mechanisms of pheromone transduction in insects and suggest several testable predictions for future research. The model builds on previous studies of olfactory transduction in vertebrates and takes into account recent findings on insect ORs, G-proteins, and effectors.
The study investigated the interactions between chromatin context, binding site sequence content, and sequence evolution in stress-induced p53 occupancy and transactivation. Genome-wide binding localizations of p53 and H3K4me3 were mapped in untreated and doxorubicin-treated human lymphoblastoid cells to examine the relationships among p53 occupancy, gene expression, H3K4me3, chromatin accessibility, ENCODE chromatin states, p53RE sequence, and evolutionary conservation. The results showed that the inducible expression of p53-regulated genes was associated with the steady-state chromatin status of the cell. Most highly inducible p53-regulated genes were suppressed at baseline and marked by repressive histone modifications or displayed CTCF binding. Weaker p53REs resided in open promoters, while stronger p53REs were located within enhancers and repressed chromatin. p53 occupancy was strongly correlated with similarity of the target DNA sequences to the p53RE consensus, but inversely correlated with pre-existing nucleosome accessibility and evolutionary conservation at the p53RE. Occupancy by p53 of REs that overlapped transposable element (TE) repeats was significantly higher and correlated with stronger p53RE sequences relative to non-TE-associated p53REs. However, binding at these elements was generally not associated with transactivation of adjacent genes. The study highlights the systematic interaction between chromatin status and p53RE context in the induced transactivation response, which appears to have been tuned via evolutionary processes that may have led to repression and/or utilization of p53REs originating from primate-specific transposon elements.
Biomedical researchers have reengineered a specific motif in bacterial two-component signaling systems to create a tunable threshold device. The motif consists of a single histidine kinase ( HK ) that reversibly phosphorylates two separate output response regulator ( RR ) proteins. This system allows for rapid signal termination and implements a sigmoidal signal-response relationship, where the steady-state levels of the phosphorylated output RR remain low until a threshold level of signal is crossed. Two mathematical conditions on system parameters are necessary for sigmoidal signal-response relationships, and key parameters control threshold levels and sensitivity of the signal-response curve. The researchers experimentally confirmed these findings by reconstituting the one HK-two RR motif in the Sinorhizobium meliloti chemotaxis pathway and measuring the resulting signal-response curve. The level of sigmoidality in this system can be controlled by the presence of the sink RR and an auxiliary protein that binds to the HK, yielding Hill coefficients of above 7. This reengineered system provides an ideal basis for developing threshold devices for synthetic biology applications. The findings have implications for understanding bacterial physiology and designing synthetic signaling circuits, and can be applied to any two-component signaling circuit where multiple response regulators compete for phosphorylation by a single phosphodonor.
Title: Single-cell RNA sequencing reveals intrinsic and extrinsic regulatory heterogeneity in yeast responding to stress

    Single-cell RNA sequencing was used to investigate transcript heterogeneity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells treated with and without salt stress. The study aimed to explore population variation and identify cellular covariates that influence the stress-responsive transcriptome. The results showed significant regulatory variation in individual yeast cells, both before and after stress. A subset of cells was found to decouple the expression of ribosomal protein genes from the environmental stress response, which was partly correlated with the cell cycle but unrelated to the yeast ultradian metabolic cycle.

    Live-cell imaging of cells expressing pairs of fluorescent regulators revealed both coordinated and decoupled nucleocytoplasmic shuttling. Transcriptomic analysis suggested that cells maintain a cellular filter against decoupled bursts of transcription factor activation but mount a stress response upon coordinated regulation, even in a subset of unstressed cells. The study also found variable activation of the Environmental Stress Response (ESR) and condition-specific regulators after stress, as well as heterogeneity in ESR activation in unstressed cells due to both coordinated and discordant induction of ESR regulators.

    The results provide new insights into heterogeneity in the yeast stress response and suggest that cell-to-cell variation in Msn2 activation could explain the heterogeneity in stress tolerance in an actively growing culture. However, it remains unclear if this variation correlates with broader transcriptome changes, if the magnitude of the response in unstressed cells mimics that seen in stressed cells, or if fluctuations in the response correlate with cell-cycle phase.
Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite responsible for African trypanosomiasis, accumulates in large numbers in the male reproductive organs of mice, including the epididymis, epididymal adipose tissue, and fibrous tunics of the testis. Fine needle aspiration cytology and histopathological analysis revealed that the parasites are associated with marked inflammatory cell infiltration, parasite degeneration, and severe tissue damage, including rupture of epididymal ducts. These findings suggest that the male reproductive organs are not immune-privileged sites for T. brucei, as previously thought. In fact, the parasites are exposed to a strong immune response in these organs, which may be related to reduced fertility. The epididymal adipose tissue and the stroma of the epididymis are the most parasitized areas, with a temporal increase in parasite density reaching 105 parasites per mg of organ at late stages of the disease. The detection of a high number of parasites in the male reproductive organs opens the possibility of using fine needle aspiration cytology as a complementary diagnostic tool for Animal African Trypanosomiasis. The study also shows that T. brucei infection is associated with disruption of the blood-testis and blood-epididymis barriers at later stages of the infection. Overall, the findings suggest that the male reproductive system is an important site for accumulation of trypanosomes, but the testis itself is not a major site of parasite accumulation.
The study investigated the plasticity of the chemoreceptor repertoire in Drosophila melanogaster by examining the expression of chemoreceptor genes in response to various environmental and physiological conditions. Using customized cDNA microarrays, the researchers found that chemoreceptor genes that are clustered in the genome undergo independent transcriptional regulation at different developmental stages and between sexes. The expression of distinct subgroups of chemoreceptor genes is sensitive to reproductive state and social interactions, and exposure to the odor of the opposite sex results in altered transcript abundance of chemoreceptor genes. These genes are distinct from those that show transcriptional plasticity when flies are allowed physical contact with same or opposite sex members. The analysis of covariance in transcript abundance of chemosensory genes across all environmental conditions revealed that they segregate into 20 relatively small, biologically relevant modules of highly correlated transcripts. This finely pixilated modular organization of the chemosensory subgenome enables fine-tuning of the expression of the chemoreceptor repertoire in response to ecologically relevant environmental and physiological conditions. The study provides a systematic description of the plasticity of the chemosensory window through which the fly experiences its chemical environment. The results demonstrate that the expression of chemoreceptor genes is highly sexually dimorphic and frequently sexually antagonistic, and the extent of transcriptional responses to changing conditions is heterogeneous among the chemoreceptor repertoire. This modular organization of the chemosensory transcriptome allows for finely tuned phenotypic plasticity of expression of the chemoreceptor repertoire under different environmental conditions.
The study investigated the relationship between meiotic recombination and nondisjunction in human oocytes. Previous research has shown that abnormal meiotic recombination is linked to the origin of human trisomies, specifically failure to recombine or recombination events located too near to or too far from the centromere. Immunofluorescence methodology was used to directly examine the meiotic recombination process in human fetal oocytes by analyzing crossover-associated proteins such as MLH1. The study analyzed 1035 prophase oocytes from 31 fetal ovarian samples and found that the number of MLH1 foci was lower than predicted from genetic linkage analysis. However, the localization pattern of MLH1 conformed to that expected for a crossover-associated protein. The study also found evidence for the presence of “vulnerable” crossover configurations in individual chromosomes, consistent with the idea that these are subsequently translated into nondisjunctional events in the adult oocyte. These findings suggest that direct analyses of crossover events in human fetal oocytes can reveal “vulnerable” crossover configurations that exhibit chromosome specificity consistent with data from trisomic conceptions. However, not all situations were as clear-cut, as no evidence was found for “spikes” in the proportion of extremely distal or proximal MLH1 foci on chromosome 21, despite the fact that proximal and distal exchanges are associated with maternal meiosis I and II-derived cases of trisomy 21.
The article explores the epidemiological consequences of immune sensitization by pre-exposure to vector saliva in the context of vector-borne diseases. Blood-feeding arthropods, such as mosquitoes, sand flies, and ticks, transmit diseases that impose significant public health and economic burdens. The saliva of these arthropods contains immunogenic compounds that facilitate feeding and can elicit an immune response in the host. Research suggests that pre-exposure to arthropod saliva can alter disease progression, with evidence from Leishmania, Plasmodium, and arboviral infections indicating that pre-sensitization can both exacerbate and limit infection symptoms. A general model of vector-borne disease was developed to investigate the impact of immune pre-sensitization on vector control. The results show that pre-sensitized infected hosts can increase in abundance when control efforts moderately increase vector mortality rates, potentially leading to greater than expected disease control if pre-sensitization leads to rapid clearance of infection. However, if pre-sensitization prolongs infection duration, vector control can increase the total number of infected hosts, which may go unnoticed unless active surveillance methods are used to detect sub-clinical individuals. Sensitivity analysis suggests that integrated vector management can mitigate these negative consequences. The study highlights the need to quantify how immune pre-sensitization modulates recovery and transmission rates in vector-borne diseases, as the effect of saliva pre-exposure on acute symptoms is well-studied for leishmaniasis but largely uncharted for other vector-parasite-host combinations.
This study investigated the effect of host immune responses on Leishmania amazonensis protein expression by comparing the proteomes of amastigotes isolated from BALB/c and BALB/c nude mice. Leishmaniasis is a significant disease affecting 12 million people worldwide, with Leishmania amazonensis being a major agent in Brazil. The researchers employed two-dimensional electrophoresis and mass spectrometry to analyze the proteomes of amastigotes from both mouse strains. The results showed 44 differentially expressed spots, including proteins related to oxidative/nitrosative stress and proteases, such as oligopeptidase B and tryparedoxin peroxidase, which are known Leishmania virulence factors. Notably, specific isoforms of these proteins were increased in parasites from nude mice, suggesting that T cells may restrain their post-translational modifications in BALB/c mice. In contrast, an isoform of HSP70 was increased in amastigotes from BALB/c mice. This study provides new insights into the regulation of Leishmania protein expression by host T cell-dependent responses and may help identify potential virulence factors and ways to regulate their expression. The findings have implications for understanding the immunopathology of Leishmania infections and may contribute to the development of new therapeutic strategies.
Activation-induced cytosine deaminase (AID) plays a crucial role in initiating immunoglobulin gene diversification and reprogramming CpG methylation in early development. However, AID is also highly mutagenic and can cause genomic instability, leading to chromosomal translocations in B cell malignancies. This study reveals that AID is cell cycle-regulated, with its nuclear degradation occurring more slowly in the G1 phase than in the S or G2-M phase. Mutations affecting regulatory phosphorylation or catalytic activity can alter AID stability and abundance. By fusing AID to tags that destabilize nuclear protein outside of G1 or S-G2/M phases, the researchers demonstrate that enforced nuclear localization of AID in G1 phase accelerates somatic hypermutation and class switch recombination, while compromising viability in S-G2/M phase cells. This suggests that cell cycle regulation determines the ability of cells to respond to AID-initiated DNA damage. The study also identifies AID derivatives that accelerate somatic hypermutation with minimal impact on viability, which could be useful tools for engineering genes and proteins by iterative mutagenesis and selection. Furthermore, the use of cell cycle tags to regulate nuclear stability may be generally applicable to studying DNA repair and engineering the genome.
Scientists have developed a new method to analyze how microbes break down plant polysaccharides, which are complex carbohydrates found in plant biomass. This method combines three techniques: carbohydrate-active enzyme (CAZyme) assays, RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), and anaerobic growth screening. The researchers applied this method to the bacterium Clostridium phytofermentans to study how it ferments various plant biomass components, including glucans, mannans, xylans, galactans, pectins, and arabinans. The results show that the bacterium ferments these polysaccharides with varying efficiencies and prioritizes the metabolism of preferred substrates. The researchers found that the bacterium up-regulates specific groups of CAZymes, transporters, and enzymes to metabolize the constituent sugars in response to different polysaccharides. A total of 56 up-regulated CAZymes were purified and tested for their activities, revealing that most polysaccharides are degraded by multiple enzymes, often from the same family, but with different rates, specificities, and cellular localizations. The researchers also identified synergies between enzymes acting on the same substrate with different catalytic mechanisms. This study provides new insights into how microbes degrade and metabolize plant biomass, which is essential for understanding the function of plant-degrading microbial communities and developing improved enzyme mixtures and recombinant microbes for industrial processing of plant biomass.
In Sierra Leone, three rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) were conducted between 2008 and 2010 in 12 districts co-endemic for lymphatic filariasis (LF) and onchocerciasis. The MDA was part of an integrated approach to manage both diseases. A midterm assessment was conducted in 2011 to evaluate the impact of the MDA on LF prevalence. The results showed a significant decrease in microfilaria (mf) prevalence from 2.6% (95% CI: 2.3-3.0%) at baseline to 0.3% (95% CI: 0.19-0.47%) after three rounds of MDA, representing an 88.5% reduction. Four districts (Bo, Moyamba, Kenema, and Kono) achieved a 100% decrease in mf prevalence, while seven districts experienced reductions ranging from 70.0% to 95.0%. Only Bombali district still had an mf prevalence of ≥1.0% (1.58%, 95% CI: 0.80-3.09%). The overall arithmetic mean mf density decreased by 65.4% among mf-positive individuals and 96.2% for the entire population examined. The results indicate that mf prevalence decreased to <1.0% in all but one of the 12 districts after three rounds of MDA. The study suggests that the integrated approach to managing onchocerciasis and LF has been effective in reducing LF prevalence in Sierra Leone.
High-throughput sequencing techniques, such as 16S rRNA gene profiling, have the potential to elucidate the complex inner workings of natural microbial communities. A key step in exploring such data is the identification of dependencies between members of these communities, which is commonly achieved by correlation analysis. However, the analysis of compositional data generated by these techniques can produce unreliable results due to the observed data taking the form of relative fractions of genes or species rather than their absolute abundances. Using simulated and real data from the Human Microbiome Project, the authors show that compositional effects can be widespread and severe, leading to many artifactual correlations among taxa and potentially opposite signs of true correlations. Community diversity is identified as a key factor modulating the acuteness of these compositional effects. To address this issue, the authors develop a new approach, called SparCC, capable of estimating correlation values from compositional data. SparCC is applied to infer a rich ecological network connecting hundreds of interacting species across 18 sites on the human body. The results show that the standard approach yields 3 spurious species-species interactions for each true interaction and misses 60% of the true interactions in the human microbiome data. The SparCC network is used as a reference to demonstrate the effectiveness of the new approach.
The study investigated the role of lysozyme and peptidoglycan modifications in the colonization of Streptococcus pneumoniae in the upper respiratory tract. Lysozyme is an antimicrobial enzyme present on mucosal surfaces that hydrolyzes bacterial peptidoglycan and has a cationic antimicrobial peptide activity. Two enzymes, PgdA and Adr, modify the peptidoglycan of S. pneumoniae and have been implicated in its resistance to lysozyme in vitro. The study found that the muramidase activity of lysozyme is responsible for its antimicrobial effect, and that both PgdA and Adr modifications are required for full resistance to lysozyme. Competition experiments in mice showed that wild-type pneumococci outcompeted a double mutant lacking both PgdA and Adr in mice with sufficient lysozyme, but not in mice deficient in lysozyme. In contrast, strains with single mutations in either PgdA or Adr had a competitive advantage over wild-type pneumococci in both lysozyme-sufficient and -deficient mice. These findings suggest that individual peptidoglycan modifications reduce fitness during colonization, but that the combination of modifications provides a significant survival advantage when lysozyme is abundant. The study highlights the importance of lysozyme and peptidoglycan modifications in dictating the composition of the microflora of the mucosal surface of the upper airway.
A new approach to diagnosing dengue fatal cases has been investigated using NS1 antigen capture tests in tissue specimens from 23 previously confirmed dengue fatal cases that occurred in Brazil in 2002. The study aimed to evaluate the usefulness of NS1 capture tests as an alternative tool for detecting dengue virus (DENV) in tissue specimens. A total of 74 tissue specimens were analyzed, including liver, lung, kidney, brain, heart, skin, spleen, thymus, and lymph nodes. Three tests for NS1 antigen capture were evaluated: Dengue Early ELISA, Platelia NS1, and the rapid test NS1 Ag Strip. The results showed that the NS1 Ag Strip was the most sensitive, detecting DENV in 78.3% (58/74) of the specimens, followed by Platelia NS1 (45.9%, 34/74) and Dengue Early ELISA (22.9%, 17/74). The NS1 Ag Strip was particularly effective in detecting DENV in liver (91.3%, 21/23), lung (71.4%, 10/14), kidney (100%, 4/4), brain (80%, 8/10), spleen (66.6%, 10/15), and thymus (100%, 3/3) tissues. The study demonstrates that DENV NS1 capture assays are a valuable approach to postmortem dengue confirmation and may be used as a clinical/pathological diagnostic tool. This is the first study to evaluate ELISA and ICT for detecting DENV antigens in tissues, providing a new approach for diagnosing dengue fatal cases.
A comprehensive molecular profiling study of 718 multiple myeloma (MM) patients from the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation CoMMpass study Interim Analysis 9 was conducted to elucidate differences in molecular alterations in MM as a function of self-reported race and genetic ancestry. The study utilized somatic whole exome and RNA-sequencing, as well as correlated clinical data. Somatic mutational analyses revealed significant differences in mutation frequency between African American (AA) and Caucasian (CA) cases, with BCL7A, BRWD3, and AUTS2 demonstrating higher mutation frequencies among AA cases. These genes are involved in translocations in B-cell malignancies. In contrast, TP53 and IRF4 mutation frequencies were higher among CA cases. The study also found a significant difference in TP53 mutation frequency among patients with higher European admixture in the dataset. The findings suggest that further validation and functional characterization of these genes in myeloma model systems could shed light on their potential role in myelomagenesis, particularly in patients of African descent. The study represents one of the most comprehensive genomics studies of MM in patients of African descent and highlights the need for deeper understanding of oncogenic processes driving MM pathogenesis in multi-ethnic cohorts to address disparities in incidence and outcomes observed among AA or otherwise African descent patients.
The study investigates the role of passenger mutations in cancer evolution, which are mutations that do not affect the reproductive rate of cancer cells. These mutations can provide valuable information about the evolutionary history of an individual cancer, serve as a molecular clock, and potentially become targets for immunotherapy or confer resistance to treatment. The researchers analyze the stochastic expansion of a population of cancer cells, describing the growth of primary tumors or metastatic lesions. They calculate the fixation probabilities and frequencies of successive passenger mutations, ordered by their time of appearance, and compute the likelihood of specific evolutionary trees to inform the phylogenetic reconstruction of cancer evolution in individual patients. The study also derives results looking backward in time, estimating the number of cancer cells present at the time when a given subclonal mutation arose. The researchers derive exact formulas for the expected numbers of subclonal mutations of any frequency and fit this formula to cancer sequencing data to estimate the ratio of birth and death rates of cancer cells during the early stages of clonal expansion. The study shows that the frequencies of the first and most abundant passenger mutations are influenced by both the mutation rate and the death-birth ratio of the cancer cells. The findings suggest that passenger mutations can be used to infer the parameters of the tumorigenic process and estimate the number of clonal mutations present in the first malignant cell.
Polyglutamine ( polyQ ) expansion in exon1 ( XN1 ) of the huntingtin protein is linked to Huntington's disease. When the number of glutamines exceeds a threshold of approximately 36–40 repeats, XN1 can readily form amyloid aggregates similar to those associated with disease. Molecular dynamics simulations were performed on monomeric XN1 with full flanking regions, a variant missing the polyproline regions, and an isolated polyQ peptide ( Qn ) to study the misfolding of XN1 toward amyloid aggregation. The results show that polyQ peptides have a positive correlation between their probability to form a β-rich misfolded state and their expansion length. The flanking regions of XN1 affect its probability to form a β-rich state compared to the isolated polyQ. The polyproline regions form polyproline type II helices and decrease the probability of the polyQ region to form a β-rich state. Additionally, by lengthening polyQ, the first N-terminal 17 residues are more likely to adopt a β-sheet conformation rather than an α-helix conformation. These findings provide a structural insight into XN1 misfolding and elucidate the possible role of the flanking sequences in XN1 aggregation. The study suggests that the polyQ and flanking regions in XN1 are strongly coupled in XN1 folding and misfolding, and that the flanking regions play a critical role in determining the structural rearrangement and aggregation mechanism of XN1.
The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) system is a primary defense mechanism used by eubacteria and archaea to protect against foreign nucleic acids, such as phages and conjugative plasmids. By analyzing hundreds of shotgun metagenomic datasets from the Human Microbiome Project (HMP), researchers have explored the distribution and diversity of known CRISPRs in human-associated microbial communities and discovered new CRISPRs. A targeted assembly strategy was developed to reconstruct CRISPR arrays that whole-metagenome assemblies failed to identify. This approach involved recruiting reads from each HMP dataset using the direct repeat consensus sequence of known CRISPR types and assembling the recruited reads into CRISPR loci. The unique spacer sequences were then extracted for analysis. The study identified 64 known and 86 novel CRISPRs, which were found to be largely body-site specific. For example, known streptococcal CRISPRs were identified in most oral microbiomes, with samples from the same individual and oral site sharing the most spacers. The study also demonstrated the potential applications of CRISPRs in tracing rare species and virus exposure in individuals. The results highlight the importance of effective identification and characterization of CRISPR loci in understanding the dynamic ecology of microbiomes. The targeted assembly strategy improved the detection of CRISPR elements in metagenomic datasets, identifying known CRISPRs in more human microbiome datasets compared to whole-metagenome assemblies.
A genome-wide analysis of Caenorhabditis elegans has identified light- and temperature-entrained oscillating transcripts that exhibit rhythmic expression with temperature-compensated 24-h periods. These transcripts are sustained under constant conditions, suggesting they are under circadian regulation. Light and temperature cycles drive gene expression and appear to entrain largely nonoverlapping gene sets. Mutations in a cyclic nucleotide-gated channel required for sensory transduction abolish both light- and temperature-entrained gene expression, implying that environmental cues act cell nonautonomously to entrain circadian rhythms. The study demonstrates circadian-regulated transcriptional rhythms in C. elegans and suggests that further analyses in this organism will provide new information about the evolution and function of this biological clock. The findings indicate that C. elegans has a circadian clock that is entrained by light and temperature, and that this model organism can be used to explore the evolution and function of this critical timekeeping mechanism. The study also reveals that genes implicated in metabolism are enriched in temperature-driven transcript sets, whereas genes implicated in circadian behaviors are enriched in entrained datasets. The TAX-2 cyclic nucleotide-gated channel subunit is required to transduce both light and temperature information to the clock, further supporting the existence of a circadian clock in C. elegans.
The Saccharomyces cerevisiae RAD3 gene, a homolog of human XPD, encodes a DNA helicase involved in nucleotide excision repair ( NER ) and transcription. Mutant alleles of RAD3 ( rad3-101 and rad3-102 ) exhibit partial defects in DNA repair and a hyper-recombination ( hyper-Rec ) phenotype. Previous studies suggested that the hyper-Rec phenotype is due to persistent single-stranded DNA gaps converted to recombinogenic double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) by replication. To further characterize the hyper-Rec phenotype, a system was developed to recover reciprocal products of mitotic recombination. The results show that rad3-101 and rad3-102 elevate the frequency of reciprocal crossovers about 100-fold. Mapping of these events revealed that three-quarters of crossovers reflect DSBs formed at the same positions in both sister chromatids ( double sister-chromatid breaks, DSCBs ), while the remainder reflect DSBs formed in single chromatids ( single chromatid breaks, SCBs ). The ratio of DSCBs to SCBs is similar to that observed for spontaneous recombination events in wild-type cells. Genome-wide analysis of 216 unselected genomic alterations, including crossovers, gene conversions, deletions, and duplications, revealed a significant association between the location of these recombination events and regions with elevated gamma-H2AX. A hotspot for deletions and duplications was found at the IMA2 and HXT11 genes near the left end of chromosome XV. These findings suggest that a subset of spontaneous events in wild-type cells may be initiated by incomplete NER reactions, and that DSCBs are a major source of mitotic recombination between homologous chromosomes.
Helicobacter pylori, a gastric pathogen, requires optimal expression of bacterial factors to adapt to the changing host environment during persistent infection. The bacterium has a large set of simple sequence repeats ( SSRs ) that generate heterogeneous populations through slipped strand mispairing ( SSM ), facilitating adaptation. This study investigated the role of an intergenically located T-tract in regulating the expression of the sialic acid binding adhesin ( SabA ). The T-tract is a repetitive DNA element that operates as a rheostat-like mechanism to fine-tune SabA promoter activity. The length of the T-tract was found to generate multiphasic output from the sabA promoter, altering H. pylori binding to sialyl-Lewis x receptors on gastric mucosa. Analysis of post-infection isolated clones revealed that the T-tract length is a highly variable feature in H. pylori, mirroring the host-pathogen interplay where the bacterium generates a set of clones from which the best-fit phenotypes are selected in the host. In silico and functional in vitro analyzes showed that the length of the T-tract affects the local DNA structure and binding of the RNA polymerase, through shifting of the axial alignment between the core promoter and UP-like elements. The study identified additional genes in H. pylori with T- or A-tracts positioned similarly to that of sabA, and variations in the tract length acted as rheostats to modulate cognate promoter output. This mechanism provides an alternative mechanism for transcriptional regulation in bacteria like H. pylori, which possesses a limited repertoire of classical trans-acting regulatory factors.
The JAK-STAT transcriptional regulator, STAT-5, plays a crucial role in the life cycle of high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) by activating the ATM DNA damage pathway to induce genome amplification in differentiating epithelial cells. Previous studies have shown that HPV proteins downregulate the expression of STAT-1, a member of the JAK-STAT family, to allow for stable maintenance of viral episomes in persistently infected cells. In contrast, this study reveals that HPV proteins activate STAT-5 phosphorylation without altering total protein levels. The activation of STAT-5 is necessary for HPV genome amplification and late gene expression in differentiating keratinocytes, as inhibition of STAT-5 phosphorylation by the drug pimozide abolishes viral genome amplification and late gene expression. The study also shows that the STAT-5β isoform is mainly responsible for this activity, which is mediated through the ATM DNA damage response. Furthermore, the study identifies the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ) as a downstream target of STAT-5 that contributes to the effects on members of the ATM pathway. The findings of this study provide new insights into the mechanisms by which HPV evades innate immune surveillance and establishes persistent infections, and highlight the importance of STAT-5 in promoting HPV viral replication. Overall, the study demonstrates that STAT-5 plays a critical role in the differentiation-dependent viral life cycle of HPV.
The study aimed to identify immunogenic Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi (S. Typhi) antigens expressed in chronic biliary carriers of S. Typhi in Kathmandu, Nepal. To achieve this, an immunoscreening technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology (IVIAT) was applied to study host-pathogen interactions in the biliary tract during S. Typhi carriage. The researchers hypothesized that S. Typhi surviving in the biliary tract of humans may express a distinct antigenic profile. Thirteen S. Typhi antigens that were immunoreactive in carriers, but not in healthy individuals from a typhoid endemic area, were identified. These antigens included putative membrane proteins, lipoproteins, and hemolysin-related proteins. One of the identified antigens, YncE (STY1479), an uncharacterized protein with an ATP-binding motif, gave prominent responses in the screen. The response to YncE in patients whose biliary tract contained S. Typhi was compared to responses in patients whose biliary tract did not contain S. Typhi, patients with acute typhoid fever, and healthy controls residing in a typhoid endemic area. The results showed that seven of 10 (70%) chronic carriers, 0 of 8 bile culture-negative controls (0%), 0 of 8 healthy Bangladeshis (0%), and 1 of 8 (12.5%) Bangladeshis with acute typhoid fever had detectable anti-YncE IgG in blood. Further evaluation of YncE and other antigens identified by IVIAT could lead to the development of improved diagnostic assays to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi carriers.
A new epigenetic phenomenon, termed trans-reactivation, has been discovered in which non-functional alleles of a gene can reactivate the expression of a wild-type copy of the same gene that is silenced by heterochromatin. This phenomenon was observed in Drosophila melanogaster, where non-functional alleles of the white gene were found to trans-reactivate the expression of a wild-type copy of white that was silenced by heterochromatin. The presence of homologous RNA molecules produced by the non-functional alleles was found to be essential for trans-reactivation, and mutations in genes involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing were shown to affect this process. Trans-reactivation was also found to be heritable, suggesting that it is a stable and long-lasting epigenetic change. The mechanisms of trans-reactivation appear to be distinct from previously characterized epigenetic reprogramming events, such as paramutation, transinduction, and transvection. Furthermore, the presence of non-functional white alleles was found to cause an increase in the expression of the wm4h gene and an opening of the chromatin structure at the wm4h locus. These findings suggest that trans-reactivation is a new level of gene expression control that is mediated by homologous RNA molecules in the context of heterochromatic genes. Overall, the discovery of trans-reactivation provides new insights into the complex regulation of gene expression and the role of RNA molecules in epigenetic control.
Boophilin, a multifunctional Kunitz protease inhibitor from the midgut of Rhipicephalus microplus, a tick vector of babesiosis, has been studied for its in vitro mode of action and anti-thrombotic activity. Boophilin was expressed in HEK293 cells and purified to homogeneity, and its interaction with thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein was investigated using amidolytic assays and surface plasmon resonance experiments. The results showed that Boophilin behaves as a classical, non-competitive inhibitor of thrombin with respect to small chromogenic substrates, with a Ki of approximately 100 nM. Boophilin also inhibits FXIa, preventing FIX activation, and kallikrein activity, indicating that it targets the contact pathway. Furthermore, Boophilin abrogates cathepsin G- and plasmin-induced platelet aggregation and partially affects elastase-mediated cleavage of Tissue Factor Pathway Inhibitor (TFPI). In addition, Boophilin inhibits carotid artery occlusion in vivo triggered by FeCl3 and promotes bleeding according to the mice tail transection method. These findings suggest that Boophilin plays a major role in keeping the midgut microenvironment at low hemostatic and inflammatory tonus, allowing ticks to successfully digest a blood meal, which is critical for metabolism and egg development. Boophilin is the first tick midgut FXIa anticoagulant also found to inhibit thrombosis.
The Spatially Explicit General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue (SEGMEnT) is a computational model developed to investigate the relationship between inflammation and tissue patterning in the gut. The model integrates multiple functional modules to simulate the cellular and molecular interactions that maintain and modify the enteric mucosal architecture. Specifically, SEGMEnT models the spatial dynamics of the crypt-villus tissue architecture as generated by the behavior of gut epithelial cells undergoing replication, migration, and differentiation. The model also incorporates the effect of inflammation on these morphogenic processes. SEGMEnT is designed to represent arbitrarily large and customizable epithelial surfaces and is a work in progress, representing a minimally sufficient set of components and interactions to achieve a face-valid representation of the mechanisms involved in maintaining the enteric mucosal architecture and its response to inflammation. The model reproduces healthy ileal mucosal dynamics and a series of morphogen knock-out/inhibition experiments, providing insight into clinically relevant cellular-molecular mechanisms. These include a putative role for PTEN/PI3K as a key point of crosstalk between inflammation and morphogenesis, the protective role of enterocyte sloughing in enteric ischemia-reperfusion, and chronic low-level inflammation as a driver for colonic metaplasia. The results suggest that SEGMEnT can serve as an integrating platform for the study of inflammation in gastrointestinal disease. The model proposes that a broad spectrum of intestinal disease can be unified by a view that the mucosal tissue architecture, as maintained by morphogenesis pathways, is subject to a series of control modules that balance the complex interplay of multiple functional objectives when in a state of health, but can become disturbed to generate pathological conditions.
The deployment of Wolbachia-infected Aedes aegypti mosquitoes has been proposed as a promising tool to mitigate arbovirus transmission. However, the success of this approach depends on the ability of Wolbachia to invade and establish itself in the local mosquito population. In a study conducted in the community of Tubiacanga, Rio de Janeiro, the wMelBr strain of Wolbachia was released for 20 consecutive weeks, but its frequency plateaued at around 40% after 7-19 weeks and dropped when releases stopped. The high maternal transmission rate of Wolbachia (97.56%) was observed, but the invasion trend was not affected by doubling releases or deploying mosquitoes with large wing length and low laboratory mortality. Further investigation revealed that the initial release of susceptible mosquitoes in a population highly resistant to pyrethroids jeopardized Wolbachia invasion. A new strain, wMelRio, was produced by backcrossing wMelBr females with males from the field to introduce pyrethroid resistance alleles, which successfully established in the population where wMelBr failed. The study highlights the importance of matching the local population genetics, particularly insecticide resistance background, to achieve Wolbachia invasion. The results suggest that Wolbachia deployment should be tailored to the insecticide resistance profile of the wild population to ensure its success.
The study investigated the role of the vaccinia B1 protein kinase in poxvirus replication and its interaction with the B12 pseudokinase. Experimental evolution of a B1 deletion virus led to the identification of mutations that enhanced viral fitness, including a loss-of-function mutation in the B12 pseudokinase. Characterization of the adapted viruses revealed that expression of full-length B12 led to a fitness reduction in viruses with a defect in B1, but had no apparent impact on wild-type virus or other mutant poxviruses. This suggests that B12 possesses a potent inhibitory activity that can be masked by the presence of the B1 kinase. Further investigation showed that B12 primarily localizes to the nucleus and reduces BAF phosphorylation in the absence of B1, indicating that B12 may enhance antiviral activity of BAF. The study presents novel evidence that a paralogous kinase-pseudokinase pair can exhibit an epistatic relationship in a virus, potentially serving to enhance B1 conservation during poxvirus evolution and orchestrate nuclear events during infection. The findings provide insights into poxvirus adaptation pathways and signal transduction circuitry, and raise questions regarding the underlying mechanism of action for the B12 pseudokinase and its regulation by B1. The study suggests that loss of B12 can suppress the fitness defects of B1 mutant viruses, but does not enhance replication of viruses containing a wild-type B1R gene, consistent with a model in which B12 acts as a repressor of vaccinia replication in a B1-dependent manner.
The study investigated the conformational behavior of two synthetic peptides, LK and EALA, with built-in secondary amphiphilicity in the presence of macroscopic and molecular interfaces. The peptides were designed to display amphiphilicity in an alpha-helix conformation, with hydrophobic and hydrophilic residues partitioned accordingly. Molecular dynamics simulations were performed to analyze the peptides' behavior in bulk water and in the presence of interfaces. The results showed that the peptides do not adopt a single, stable conformation in bulk water, but instead exhibit multiple conformations and secondary structure elements with short lifetimes. The alpha-helix conformation is not stable in bulk water, and the peptides display a variety of secondary structures, including partial alpha-helices. The presence of a macroscopic interface, such as a vacuum/water interface, leads to a strong partitioning of hydrophobic and hydrophilic residues, stabilizing the alpha-helical form for both peptides. The study also found that the peptides' aggregation behavior is affected by the presence or absence of an interface, as well as their surface charge and hydrophobicity. The results suggest that the conformational behavior of intrinsically disordered peptides is highly dependent on the environment, and that interfaces can play a crucial role in stabilizing specific conformations.
The Telomeric Repeats of Human Herpesvirus 6A (HHV-6A) Are Required for Efficient Virus Integration. Human herpesvirus 6A (HHV-6A) and 6B (HHV-6B) are ubiquitous betaherpesviruses that infect humans within the first years of life and establish latency in various cell types. Both viruses can integrate their genomes into telomeres of host chromosomes in latently infected cells. The molecular mechanism of viral integration remains elusive. Intriguingly, HHV-6A, HHV-6B and several other herpesviruses harbor arrays of telomeric repeats ( TMR ) identical to human telomere sequences at the ends of their genomes. The HHV-6A and HHV-6B genomes harbor two TMR arrays, the perfect TMR ( pTMR ) and the imperfect TMR ( impTMR ). To determine if the TMR are involved in virus integration, researchers deleted both pTMR and impTMR in the HHV-6A genome.
