Upon reconstitution, the TMR mutant virus replicated comparable to wild type ( wt ) virus, indicating that the TMR are not essential for HHV-6A replication. However, integration of HHV-6A was severely impaired in the absence of the TMR and the virus genome was lost rapidly, suggesting that integration is crucial for the maintenance of the virus genome. Individual deletion of the pTMR and impTMR revealed that the pTMR play the major role in HHV-6A integration, whereas the impTMR only make a minor contribution, allowing us to establish a model for HHV-6A integration. Taken together, our data shows that the HHV-6A TMR are dispensable for virus replication, but are crucial for integration and maintenance of the virus genome in latently infected cells.
Poxviruses are enveloped viruses that produce infectious particles without acquiring their internal lipid membrane by budding through cellular compartments. Instead, they generate immature particles from atypical crescent-shaped precursors whose architecture and composition are not well understood. Researchers have determined the 2. 6 Å crystal structure of vaccinia virus D13, a key structural component of the outer scaffold of viral crescents. D13 folds into two jellyrolls decorated by a head domain of novel fold and assembles into trimers that are homologous to the double-barrel capsid proteins of adenovirus and lipid-containing icosahedral viruses. When tethered onto artificial membranes, D13 forms a honeycomb lattice and assembly products structurally similar to the viral crescents and immature particles. The architecture of the D13 honeycomb lattice and the lipid-remodeling abilities of D13 support a model of assembly that exhibits similarities with the giant mimivirus. The findings suggest that the first committed step of poxvirus morphogenesis utilizes an ancestral lipid-remodeling strategy common to icosahedral DNA viruses infecting all kingdoms of life. Furthermore, D13 is the target of rifampicin and its structure will aid the development of poxvirus assembly inhibitors. The study reveals that the first morphogenesis step of poxviruses relies on an ancestral lipid-remodeling strategy found in a lineage of icosahedral DNA viruses. The scaffolding protein D13 is a driving force in this process and has the intrinsic ability to form immature-virion like particles in the absence of any other viral factors.
In Brachypodium distachyon (Brachypodium), a monocotyledonous plant, a mutation in the TAR2-LIKE (BdTAR2L) gene results in a dramatic elongation of seminal roots due to enhanced cell elongation. This phenotype contrasts with Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis), a dicotyledonous plant, where loss-of-function of TAA1/TAR activity leads to impaired root growth. The Brachypodium mutant, Bdtar2lhypo, displays elevated rather than reduced auxin levels, which does not appear to result from compensation by alternative auxin biosynthesis pathways. Instead, expression of YUCCA genes, which are rate-limiting for conversion of indole-3-pyruvic acid (IPA) to auxin, is increased in Bdtar2l mutants. Treatment with the ethylene precursor 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic-acid (ACC) suppresses Bdtar2lhypo root phenotypes and down-regulates BdYUCCA genes. Furthermore, BdYUCCA genes are up-regulated in a downstream ethylene-signaling component homolog mutant, Bd ethylene insensitive 2-like 1, which also displays a Bdtar2l root phenotype. These findings suggest that ethylene inhibits the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis in an IPA-dependent manner to confer auxin levels that are sub-optimal for root cell elongation in Brachypodium. The results reveal a delicate homeostasis of local auxin and ethylene activity to control cell elongation in Brachypodium roots and suggest alternative wiring of auxin-ethylene crosstalk compared to Arabidopsis.
The organization of promoter nucleosomes plays a crucial role in shaping the evolution of gene expression in species of the budding yeast. Research has shown that genes lacking a nucleosome-free region (OPN) vary widely in expression between species, whereas genes containing a depleted proximal nucleosome (DPN) exhibit conserved expression levels. To investigate whether early evolutionary dynamics contribute to this difference in divergence, scientists artificially selected for high expression of GFP-fused proteins. Surprisingly, selection was equally successful for both OPN and DPN genes, with approximately 80% of genes in each group stably increasing in expression by a similar amount. However, the two groups adapted through distinct mechanisms: DPN-selected strains duplicated large genomic regions, while OPN-selected strains favored trans mutations not involving duplications. Notably, when selection was removed, DPN genes rapidly reverted to wild-type expression levels, whereas OPN genes did not. These findings suggest that promoter organization constrains early evolutionary dynamics and biases the path of long-term evolution. The results also indicate that DPN and OPN genes respond differently to identical selection forces, with OPN genes being more adaptable due to their flexible promoter structure. Overall, the study highlights the importance of promoter nucleosome organization in shaping the evolution of gene expression.
The human T lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) trans-activator/oncoprotein Tax activates I-κB kinases (IKKs) and nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells (NF-κB), promoting cell proliferation and transformation. However, in most cells, Tax expression leads to the up-regulation of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors p21CIP1/WAF1 and p27KIP1, resulting in p53-/pRb-independent cellular senescence. This study demonstrates that p21CIP1/WAF1-/p27KIP1-mediated senescence constitutes a checkpoint against IKK/NF-κB hyper-activation. Senescence induced by Tax in HeLa cells is attenuated by mutations in Tax that reduce IKK/NF-κB activation and prevented by blocking NF-κB using a degradation-resistant mutant of I-κBα. RelA is shown to induce this senescence program by acting upstream of the anaphase promoting complex and RelB to stabilize p27KIP1 protein and p21CIP1/WAF1 mRNA, respectively. The HTLV-1 anti-sense protein HBZ down-regulates NF-κB, delaying or preventing the onset of Tax-induced senescence. The balance between Tax and HBZ expression determines the outcome of HTLV-1 infection, with robust HTLV-1 replication and elevated Tax expression driving IKK/NF-κB hyper-activation and triggering senescence, while HBZ modulates Tax-mediated viral replication and NF-κB activation, allowing HTLV-1-infected cells to proliferate, persist, and evolve. Inactivation of the senescence checkpoint can facilitate persistent NF-κB activation and leukemogenesis.
The frontal lobes play a crucial role in decision-making and executive control by selecting and coordinating goal-directed behaviors. However, current models of frontal executive function do not adequately explain human decision-making in everyday environments characterized by uncertainty, change, and open-ended situations. To address this issue, a computational model of human executive function was proposed, which predicts human decisions and their variations across individuals in naturalistic situations. The model reveals that the human frontal function monitors up to three or four concurrent behavioral strategies and infers their ability to predict action outcomes. When one strategy appears more reliable than others, it is chosen to guide the selection and learning of actions that maximize rewards. Otherwise, a new behavioral strategy is tentatively formed from those stored in long-term memory, probed, and if competitive, confirmed to drive action. The model suggests that the human executive function has a monitoring capacity limited to three or four behavioral strategies, which is compensated by a binary structure of executive control that promotes the exploration and creation of new behavioral strategies in ambiguous and unknown situations. The results support a model of human frontal function that integrates reasoning, learning, and creative abilities in the service of decision-making and adaptive behavior. The proposed model, called PROBE, clarifies how the human executive function regulates the exploration versus exploitation of behavioral rules and controls creativity in the service of adaptive behavior.
The article presents a new modeling approach called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations in Parameter Trajectories (ADAPT) to analyze the long-term effects of pharmacological interventions. ADAPT employs mathematical modeling to predict the dynamics of molecular adaptations by introducing a concept of time-dependent descriptions of model parameters. This approach integrates experimental data obtained during different stages of an intervention to provide an integrated understanding of the outcome of a pharmacological intervention or disease progression. ADAPT aims to dynamically link different experimentally observed phenotypes (phenotype snapshots) as a function of time. The method captures dynamic adaptations in molecular processes by inferring necessary changes in model parameters, which are therefore time-dependent. ADAPT was applied to a model of hepatic lipid and plasma lipoprotein metabolism to predict metabolic adaptations induced upon pharmacological treatment of mice with the liver X receptor (LXR) agonist T0901317. The analysis revealed a counter-intuitive insight concerning the function of scavenger receptor class B1 (SR-B1), a receptor that facilitates the hepatic uptake of cholesterol. Although activation of LXR promotes cholesterol efflux and excretion, the computational analysis showed that the hepatic capacity to clear cholesterol was reduced upon prolonged treatment. This prediction was confirmed experimentally by immunoblotting measurements of SR-B1 in hepatic membranes. The study demonstrates the potential of ADAPT to identify potential unwanted side effects and design new target interventions to prevent them.
The article proposes a new hypothesis for how the spinocerebellar systems and cerebellar cortex interact to support the coordination of multi-segmented limbs and bodies. The hypothesis suggests that the spinal circuitry provides useful recombinations of sensory and motor signals to the cerebellar cortex through its mossy fiber (MF) projections via the spinocerebellar tract (SCT) and spinocerebellar reticulotrigeminal tract (SRT) systems. These recombinations can be described as linear projections through aspects of the multi-dimensional sensorimotor input space. The granule cells in the cerebellar granule layer enhance the utility of these projections by allowing the Purkinje cells to establish piecewise-linear approximations of non-linear functions. This hypothesis provides a novel view on the function of the spinal circuitry and cerebellar granule layer, illustrating how the coordinating functions of the cerebellum can be supported by the recombinations performed by the neurons of the spinocerebellar systems. The authors argue that the close correspondence between sensor signals and motor command signals in individual neurons allows the spinocerebellar system to avoid superfluous recombinations and form ‘good enough’ recombinations with a high probability. The article aims to provide a theoretical explanation for how the spinocerebellar systems and cerebellar cortex can integrate across input dimensions necessary to achieve coordination of multi-segmented limbs and bodies.
The study investigated the regulation of microRNAs (miRNAs) in Aedes albopictus, a major vector of Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), during CHIKV infection. Using next-generation sequencing, the researchers identified 88 and 79 known miRNAs in uninfected and CHIKV-infected Aedes albopictus cell lines, respectively, as well as nine novel miRNAs. Comparison of the two libraries revealed differential expression of 77 common miRNAs, with eight miRNAs specifically altered by CHIKV infection. Putative targets of these regulated miRNAs were identified and classified into their pathways. The study found that CHIKV infection modified the miRNA profile of Aedes albopictus, highlighting the potential role of miRNAs in CHIKV pathogenesis. Further analysis revealed that four miRNAs (miR-100, miR-283, miR-305-3p, and miR-927) were over-expressed, while four miRNAs (miR-1000, miR-2b, miR-2c-3p, and miR-190-5p) were under-expressed in response to CHIKV infection. The study provides insights into the cellular modification by miRNAs during CHIKV infection and identifies potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies. The findings suggest that miRNAs play a crucial role in regulating gene expression and may be involved in various cellular processes, including cell development, proliferation, differentiation, host defense, fat metabolism, and apoptosis.
Cystic echinococcosis (CE), a parasitic infection affecting humans and livestock, poses a significant medical and economic burden in many developing countries, including Iran. This study aimed to estimate the monetary burden of CE in Iran using epidemiological and economic data from 2000-2009. The estimated mean number of surgical CE cases per year was 1,295, and the number of asymptomatic individuals living in the country was approximately 635,232. The overall annual cost of CE in Iran was estimated at $232.3 million, including both direct and indirect costs. The cost associated with human CE was estimated at $93.39 million, while the annual cost associated with CE in livestock was estimated at $132 million. The cost per surgical human case was estimated at $1,539. The economic impact of CE on Iran was found to be considerable, accounting for approximately 0.03% of the country's gross domestic product. The study highlights the need for the establishment of a CE surveillance system and implementation of a control program to reduce the economic burden of CE on the country. A cost-benefit analysis of different control programs is recommended to prioritize resource allocation for disease control and prevention.
A global analysis of mouse polyomavirus (MPyV) infection in mouse NIH3T6 cells has revealed dynamic regulation of viral and host gene expression. Deep sequencing was used to follow MPyV infection at various times after infection and analyze both viral and cellular transcriptomes. The results showed that both early-strand and late-strand RNAs were transcribed at all time points, indicating a transcriptional profile of the early-to-late switch. Novel insights into viral gene expression emerged, including widespread RNA editing of viral transcripts at late times in infection. By late times in infection, 359 host genes were significantly upregulated and 857 were downregulated. Gene ontology analysis indicated that transcripts involved in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated, while transcripts involved in extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc finger binding, SH3 domain, and GTPase activation were downregulated. The levels of several long noncoding RNAs were also altered, with the long noncoding RNA MALAT1 being downregulated and several other abundant noncoding RNAs being strongly upregulated. These findings provide a detailed picture of how viral gene expression changes throughout the life cycle of MPyV and how infection impacts host cell gene expression. The results also reveal new insights into viral gene regulation, including changes in apparent start sites of early transcripts and extensive RNA editing throughout the viral genome.
Metabolic Factors Limiting Performance in Marathon Runners: A Computational Study
    A significant proportion of marathon runners experience severe and performance-limiting depletion of physiologic carbohydrate reserves, known as "hitting the wall." Previous analyses have suggested that human glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon or that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete a marathon without "hitting the wall." However, a computational study demonstrates that the energetic constraints on endurance runners are more subtle and depend on several physiologic variables, including muscle mass distribution, liver and muscle glycogen densities, and running speed.

    The study presents an analytic approach to estimate the distance at which runners will exhaust their glycogen stores as a function of running intensity. This approach provides a basis for guidelines ensuring the safety and optimizing the performance of endurance runners by setting personally appropriate paces and prescribing midrace fueling requirements. The analysis also sheds light on important standards in marathon running, such as qualifying times for the Boston Marathon.

    The study shows that carbohydrate loading prior to marathon running influences performance by permitting runners to run at greater speeds without "hitting the wall." Typical levels of glycogen loading allow runners with a given aerobic capacity and leg muscle distribution to complete a marathon safely in four to five hours. The model incorporates the metabolic cost of running and the dependence of fat versus carbohydrate metabolism on relative exertion, revealing the functional dependencies of the distance required to run glycogen stores to depletion and the fastest pace at which a given distance can be run without exhausting glycogen stores.
Toxoplasma gondii is a parasite that infects a wide range of hosts, including humans, and exhibits significant genetic diversity, with three main clonal lineages (type I, II, and III) found in Europe and North America. However, in South America, a diverse array of other strains are present. The parasite's virulence, persistence, and ability to induce cytokine expression and modulate host gene expression vary widely among strains. This study aimed to investigate the molecular basis for these differences in pathogenesis, particularly in non-canonical strains, by infecting murine macrophages with 29 different Toxoplasma strains representing global diversity. The researchers used RNA-sequencing to determine host and parasite transcriptomes. The results showed large differences in the expression levels of known parasite effectors and chromosomal structural variation among strains. Additionally, novel strain-specifically regulated host pathways were identified, including the regulation of the type I interferon response by some atypical strains. The study found that IFNβ production by infected cells was associated with parasite killing, independent of interferon gamma activation, and dependent on endosomal Toll-like receptors in macrophages and the cytoplasmic receptor retinoic acid-inducible gene 1 (RIG-I) in fibroblasts. The findings provide a global insight into host cell and parasite transcriptional responses upon infection with both canonical and exotic Toxoplasma strains, allowing for the identification of novel strain-specific host cell responses and parasite effectors.
The recombination process in enteroviruses has been found to be a biphasic replicative process involving the generation of greater-than-genome-length ‘imprecise’ intermediates. A novel reverse genetic approach was used to investigate heterologous recombination in polioviruses, resulting in the isolation of intermediate chimeric intertypic polioviruses with extensive duplicated sequences at the recombination junction. Serial passage of these viruses yielded progeny with increased fitness that had lost the duplicated sequences. Mutations or inhibitors that altered polymerase fidelity or the coalescence of replication complexes affected the yield of recombinants, indicating that the process is replicative. The study proposes that extant recombinants result from an initial recombination event followed by a process of resolution, deleting extraneous sequences and optimizing viral fitness. This biphasic process has implications for our understanding of ‘evolution by duplication’ in positive-strand RNA viruses. An analysis of intertypic poliovirus type 1/type 3 recombinants revealed that 70% of genomes contained additional sequences, forming 85% of distinct sequence junctions analyzed. The majority of heterotypic recombinants contained additional sequences within the recombination region, suggesting that these imprecise recombinants may have a growth disadvantage. However, serial passage of these viruses yielded progeny with increased fitness that had lost the duplicated sequences. The study suggests that the recombination process in enteroviruses is a complex and dynamic process that can be influenced by factors such as polymerase fidelity and replication complex coalescence.
The study investigated the role of organic cation transporter 3 (Oct3) in the clearance of norepinephrine (NE) in white adipose tissue (WAT) and its impact on thermogenesis and lipolysis. The researchers found that Oct3 is highly expressed in WAT and has the highest uptake rate of NE compared to other known routes, such as sympathetic neurons or macrophages. Adipocytes in WAT express high levels of NE degradation enzymes, Maoa, Maob, and Comt, which provide the molecular basis for NE clearance by adipocytes together with its reuptake transporter Oct3. Ablation of Oct3 in mice resulted in higher body temperature, thermogenesis, and lipolysis compared to littermate controls. After prolonged cold challenge, WAT in Oct3-deficient mice showed stronger browning characteristics and elevated expression of thermogenic and mitochondrial biogenesis genes. The response involved enhanced β-adrenergic receptor (β-AR)/protein kinase A (PKA)/cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-responsive element binding protein (Creb) pathway activation. Inhibition of β-AR largely abolished the higher lipolytic and thermogenic activities in Oct3-deficient WAT, indicating NE overload in the vicinity of adipocytes. The study suggests that Oct3 governs β-AR activity as a NE recycling transporter in white adipocytes, offering potential therapeutic applications for metabolic disorders. Reduced functional alleles in human OCT3 were also associated with increased basal metabolic rate (BMR).
The heterochromatin-enriched HP1 proteins play a crucial role in regulating transcription by binding to methylated histone H3 tails through their chromo-domain (CD). However, in vivo and in vitro experiments have shown that the affinity of HP1 proteins to native methylated chromatin is relatively poor, suggesting the need for additional histone binding activities. The chromoshadow-domain (CSD) of HP1 proteins interacts with histone H3 at the entry/exit point of the nucleosome barrel, a region also contacted by the catalytic subunits of the human SWI/SNF complex, Brg1 and Brm. This interaction is essential for efficient SWI/SNF remodeling, which is inhibited in the presence of HP1 proteins. The antagonism between SWI/SNF and HP1 proteins is observed on interferon-regulated genes in vivo. Furthermore, SWI/SNF activity favors the loading of HP1 proteins to chromatin both in vivo and in vitro. The data suggest that HP1 chromoshadow-domains can benefit from the opening of nucleosomal structures to bind chromatin and that HP1 proteins use this property to detect and arrest unwanted chromatin remodeling. The interaction between HP1 and Brg1/Brm with the globular domain of histone H3 is required for HP1-mediated repression, indicating a complex interplay between these proteins in regulating chromatin structure and transcription.
The study investigated the property of self-containment in RNA molecules, which refers to the tendency of a particular RNA sequence to maintain its optimal secondary structure regardless of its surrounding nucleotide context. The researchers developed a scoring method called the self-containment index to measure this property. They found that microRNAs (miRNAs) exhibit high self-containment, consistent with the requirement for structural invariance imposed by the miRNA biogenesis pathway. In contrast, most other structured RNAs do not display high self-containment. Further analysis revealed a trend toward higher self-containment among clustered and conserved miRNAs, suggesting that high self-containment may be a characteristic of novel miRNAs acquiring new genomic contexts. The study also found that miRNAs display significantly enhanced self-containment compared to other functional RNAs, and that there is a trend toward natural selection for self-containment in most functional RNA classes. The researchers suggest that self-containment arises from selection for robustness against perturbations, invariance during biogenesis, and modular composition of structural function. They propose that analysis of self-containment will be important for both annotation and design of functional RNAs. A Python implementation and Web interface to calculate the self-containment index are available online.
The study identifies four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that limit the spread of necrotrophic fungal pathogens. Arabidopsis mutants defective in any of these TFs, namely ZFP2, BHLH99, PAP2, and AT1G66810, displayed increased disease susceptibility to Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina. Transcriptome analyses revealed that these mutants share a common transcriptional signature of 77 up-regulated genes. Several of these up-regulated genes encode peptides with a secretion signal, which were named PROVIR (provirulence) factors. Forward and reverse genetic analyses revealed that many of the PROVIR factors are important for disease susceptibility of the host to fungal necrotrophs. Over-expression of many PROVIR factors in Arabidopsis conferred increased susceptibility to P. cucumerina, while loss-of-function mutants conferred increased resistance. The TFs and PROVIRs identified in this study represent novel genetic determinants for plant disease susceptibility to necrotrophic fungal pathogens. These findings provide new insights into the molecular components and host processes that contribute to plant disease susceptibility. The study highlights the importance of understanding the intricate signaling system used by host cells to respond to invasions by pathogenic microorganisms.
The transcription factor FOXO1 plays a critical role in regulating uterine epithelial integrity and progesterone receptor expression, which are essential for successful embryo implantation. Ablation of Foxo1 in the uterine epithelium of mice using the progesterone receptor Cre ( PgrCre ) model resulted in infertility due to altered epithelial cell polarity and apoptosis, preventing the embryo from penetrating the luminal epithelium. Transcriptomic analysis revealed alterations in gene expression for transcripts involved in cell invasion, molecular transport, apoptosis, β-catenin ( CTNNB1 ) signaling pathway, and increased progesterone receptor ( PGR ) signaling. The increase in PGR signaling was attributed to PGR expression being retained in the uterine epithelium during the window of receptivity. Constitutive expression of epithelial PGR during this receptive period inhibited FOXO1 expression in the nucleus of the uterine epithelium. The reciprocal expression of PGR and FOXO1 was conserved in human endometrial samples during the proliferative and secretory phase. This study demonstrates that FOXO1 and PGR expression are interrelated and critical for embryo implantation. FOXO1 regulates the expression of multiple components of signaling pathways that establish the receptive phase, including activation of cell invasion, molecular transport, apoptosis, CTNNB1 signaling pathway, and inhibition of PGR signaling in the murine endometrial epithelium. These findings suggest that FOXO1 and PGR may be involved in a mutually regulatory relationship in the endometrial epithelium at the window of receptivity.
A geostatistical model was developed to investigate the spatial variation in monthly dengue cases in Bangladesh from 2000 to 2009. The model accounted for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal random effects, and was applied to district-level monthly reported dengue cases. The results showed that mean monthly temperature and its interaction with mean monthly diurnal temperature range, lagged by two months, were significantly associated with dengue incidence. Additionally, mean monthly rainfall at two months lag was positively associated with dengue incidence. Densely populated districts and districts bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated that 92% of annual dengue cases occurred between August and September, with 94% of cases identified in the capital Dhaka. However, less than half of the affected districts reported cases, with a higher proportion reported in high-incidence districts but dropping towards the end of the high transmission season. The study provides model-based estimates of the monthly geographical distribution of dengue cases in Bangladesh, accounting for under-reporting. The findings are expected to contribute to prioritizing and targeting dengue control and elimination interventions across Bangladesh.
Mice exhibit exploratory behavior in a novel environment by establishing a preferred place, known as a home base, characterized by high visit frequency and cumulative time spent. However, a new type of preferred place, called a knot, has been identified in mouse open field exploration. Knots are marked by high path tortuosity, with mice tracing tortuous paths full of twists and turns during sporadic visits. This behavior, termed knot-scribbling, is distinct from home base behavior and is often performed at the point of introduction into the arena. Knots are characterized by high path density, frequent visits without scribbling, and higher speed on the way into the knot than on the way out. Mice tend to perform knot-scribbling at the point of entry into the arena, even if they leave immediately after being placed there. The establishment of knots is enhanced by injecting mice with saline and placing them in an exposed portion of the arena, suggesting that stress and arousal consolidate a long-term contingency between a particular locale and knot-scribbling. Knots may serve as self-generated landmarks, allowing mice to obtain an overview of the environment and re-calibrate their locale map and compass directions. The vestibular input generated by knot-scribbling may also improve the interpretation of the visual scene. Knots are typically situated away from walls and are not characterized by the features of a home base, except for high speed during inbound and low speed during outbound paths.
Invasive fungal infections cause more deaths worldwide than malaria. A high-throughput screen identified the ergoline compound NGx04 as an antifungal agent with selectivity over mammalian cells. Chemogenomics analysis revealed that NGx04 targets the lipid transfer protein Sec14p, which is essential for the growth and virulence of pathogenic fungi such as Cryptococcus neoformans. Sec14p is involved in the secretion of virulence determinants necessary for the pathogenicity of C. neoformans, making it an attractive antifungal target. NGx04 inhibited the growth of two clinical isolates of C. neoformans and NGx04-related compounds showed equal or higher potency against this pathogen. Furthermore, NGx04 analogues exhibited fungicidal activity against a fluconazole-resistant C. neoformans strain. The Sec14p protein is highly conserved across fungal species, with 53% similarity between S. cerevisiae and C. neoformans proteins. Three of the four sites critical for NGx04 sensitivity are conserved in C. neoformans, suggesting that NGx04 binds to the fungal protein in a similar manner as in S. cerevisiae. These findings provide genetic evidence that NGx04 inhibits fungal Sec14p and initial data supporting NGx04 as a novel antifungal starting point.
Mefloquine, an antimalarial drug, has been found to possess promising antischistosomal properties in mice. In a study, mice infected with adult Schistosoma mansoni or S. japonicum were administered a single dose of mefloquine ( 200 or 400 mg/kg ) orally, resulting in high or complete total and female worm burden reductions ( 72. 3%–100% ). Notably, high worm burden reductions were also observed for young developing stages of S. mansoni and S. japonicum harbored in the mouse. Both mefloquine erythro-enantiomers resulted in high and comparable total and female worm burden reductions when given to mice with either a sub-patent or patent S. mansoni infection. The study suggests that mefloquine may be a novel antischistosomal drug based on an aminoalcohol functionality. Further research is needed to elucidate the mechanism of action and to study the effect of mefloquine on S. haematobium and other trematodes. Mefloquine is widely used to treat malaria, and it will be interesting to investigate its impact on schistosomiasis in areas where both diseases co-exist. The study highlights the potential of mefloquine as an alternative to the currently used antischistosomal drug, praziquantel, which may select for drug-resistant parasites.
The study aimed to map the geographical distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon using parasitological, serological, and clinical evidence to exclude other causes of lymphedema. Podoconiosis, a non-filarial elephantiasis, causes massive swelling of the lower legs and was identified as a neglected tropical disease by the World Health Organization in 2011. The study employed a multi-stage sampling design, stratifying the country by environmental risk of podoconiosis, and surveyed 76 villages from 40 health districts across the ten regions of Cameroon. A total of 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated in the study, and 83 individuals with lymphedema were identified. After applying a clinical algorithm to exclude filarial-associated lymphedema, 52 people were diagnosed with podoconiosis. The overall prevalence of podoconiosis was found to be 0.5% (95% CI: 0.4-0.7). The disease was found to be widespread in Cameroon, with at least one case identified in every region except the two surveyed villages in Adamawa. The prevalence ranged from 0.2% to 2.7% across the 40 health districts surveyed. The study demonstrates the low prevalence but almost nationwide distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon, highlighting the need for a health system response to the burden of the disease through case surveillance and morbidity management services. The findings support the inclusion of podoconiosis in routine screening for neglected tropical diseases at the primary healthcare level.
This study investigated the role of Notch signaling in the age-associated decrease in adhesion of germline stem cells (GSCs) to their niche in Drosophila. The results show that Notch signaling is increased with age in GSCs, leading to their removal from the niche. Clonal analysis revealed that GSCs with low levels of Notch signaling exhibit increased adhesiveness to the niche, out-competing their neighbors with higher levels of Notch. This increased adhesiveness is mediated by the regulation of E-cadherin expression. Experimental enhancement of Notch signaling in GSCs accelerates their age-dependent loss from the niche, and this loss is partially mediated by Sex lethal. However, disruption of Notch signaling in GSCs does not delay GSC loss during aging, nor does it affect BMP signaling, which promotes self-renewal of GSCs. Notably, Notch activation in the niche, which maintains niche integrity and mediates GSC retention, is reduced with age. This suggests that Notch signaling regulates GSC-niche adhesion both intrinsically and extrinsically. The study reveals a novel role of Notch signaling in controlling GSC-niche adhesion in response to aging and has implications for understanding metastatic cancer cells, in which Notch signaling suppresses cell adhesion. Overall, the findings indicate that Notch signaling promotes GSC aging and needs to be maintained at a relatively low level in young GSCs for their anchorage to the niche.
The conserved herpesvirus protein kinases (CHPKs) are a family of kinases encoded by eight human herpesviruses, including human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) and human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). These kinases share sequence and positional homology with the UL97 protein of HCMV, which has been shown to phosphorylate the retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor protein and lamin A/C. A functional complementation assay demonstrated that UL97 has authentic cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk)-like activity. To determine if this Cdk-like activity is shared by other CHPKs, the authors individually expressed epitope-tagged alleles of each protein in human cells and yeast cells. The results showed that the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus CHPKs, but not the alpha-herpesvirus homologs, can phosphorylate Rb and lamin A, disrupt the nuclear lamina, and display bona fide Cdk activity in yeast. These findings indicate that the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus CHPKs have Cdk-like functions, which have been termed v-Cdks. In contrast, the non-Cdk-related activities reported for UL97, such as dispersion of promyelocytic leukemia protein nuclear bodies (PML-NBs) and disruption of cytoplasmic or nuclear aggresomes, showed weak conservation among the CHPKs and did not segregate to specific viral families. These results suggest that the genomic and evolutionary conservation of these kinases has not been fully maintained at the functional level.
Systematic Review and Consensus Guidelines for Environmental Sampling of Burkholderia pseudomallei
    Burkholderia pseudomallei, a Tier 1 Select Agent and the cause of melioidosis, is a Gram-negative bacillus present in the environment in many tropical countries. A systematic review was conducted to update the risk map for melioidosis and propose international consensus guidelines for soil sampling. An international working party, the Detection of Environmental Burkholderia pseudomallei Working Party ( DEBWorP ), was formed during the VIth World Melioidosis Congress in 2010. PubMed was searched using MeSH terms: pseudomallei or melioidosis, and bibliographies were hand-searched for secondary references. The reported geographical distribution of B. pseudomallei in the environment was mapped and categorized as definite, probable, or possible. The methodology used for detecting environmental B. pseudomallei was extracted and collated. The review found that global coverage was patchy, with a lack of studies in many areas where melioidosis is suspected to occur. The sampling strategies and bacterial identification methods used were highly variable and not all were robust. To address these issues, consensus guidelines were developed to reduce the probability of false-negative results and provide affordable and ‘low-tech’ methodology applicable in both developed and developing countries. The proposed guidelines aim to provide the basis for an accurate and comprehensive global map of environmental B. pseudomallei.
The mechanism of membrane fusion by flaviviruses, such as dengue virus, involves large-scale domain rearrangements of the envelope glycoprotein (E) and a transition from dimers to trimers. A conformational intermediate, characterized by an outward rotation of the E ectodomain and reassociation into extended trimers, is believed to play a crucial role in this process. The ∼55-aa-residue membrane proximal "stem" of the E protein is thought to zip up along domain II, bringing together the transmembrane segments of the C-terminus and the fusion loops at the tip of domain II. Researchers have identified peptides derived from the stem of dengue-virus E that bind to a stem-less E trimer, which models a conformational intermediate. These peptides specifically block viral fusion in vitro and inhibit infectivity with potency proportional to their affinity for the conformational intermediate. The peptides bind virions before attachment and are carried with virions into endosomes, where acidification initiates fusion. A two-step model for the mechanism of fusion inhibition has been proposed, suggesting that targeting a viral entry pathway can be an effective way to block infection. The findings support and extend proposed mechanisms for how the E conformational change promotes membrane fusion, providing strategies for inhibiting flavivirus entry.
Biomedical researchers have developed a novel method for whole genome sequencing (WGS) of Vibrio cholerae directly from dried spotted filter paper. This approach enables the analysis of cholera strains in resource-limited settings, providing valuable information for public health policy and control measures. The study demonstrated that a minimum concentration of 0.02 ng/μL of V. cholerae DNA is sufficient for WGS, allowing for the recovery of close to a complete sequence of the V. cholerae O1 genome. The genomic data confirmed the presence or absence of genes of epidemiological interest, including cholera toxin and pilus loci. Furthermore, WGS identified a variety of diarrheal pathogens from alkaline peptone water (APW)-enriched specimen spotted filter papers, highlighting the potential for this technique to explore the gut microbiome and identify co-infections that may impact disease severity. The WGS results also mapped short reads from APW-enriched specimen and culture isolate spotted filter papers, providing molecular epidemiological sequence information on V. cholerae strains from remote, low-resource settings. The study's findings support the use of WGS for molecular epidemiological characterization of cholera outbreaks in remote and/or unstable areas, enabling the identification of specific virulence genes and the absence of genes implicated in important biological pathways of V. cholerae. This approach has the potential to inform public health policy and contribute to the control and elimination of cholera.
The study investigated the role of the cytoplasmic Dynein motor in regulating epithelial polarity in Drosophila follicle cells. A genetic screen identified Dynein as an essential regulator of apico–basal polarity, and further analysis revealed that it acts through the cytoplasmic scaffolding protein Stardust ( Sdt ) to localize the transmembrane protein Crumbs. The study found that Dynein is required for the apical targeting of specific Sdt mRNA isoforms, which is mediated by an alternatively spliced coding exon. The presence or absence of this exon corresponds to a developmental switch in Sdt mRNA localization, where apical transcripts are only found during early stages of epithelial development and unlocalized transcripts predominate in mature epithelia. This work demonstrates that Dynein is required for epithelial polarity and suggests that mRNA localization may have a functional role in regulating apico–basal organization. The study also introduces a unique mechanism in which alternative splicing of a coding exon controls mRNA localization during development. The findings are supported by a complementary study that examined the contributions of Dynein and Crumbs mRNA localization to apico–basal polarity regulation. The study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying epithelial polarity and highlights the importance of mRNA localization in regulating cell architecture.
This study provides the first evidence of intraclonal genetic exchange in Trypanosomatids, specifically in Leishmania infantum, using two fluorescent transgenic clones. The researchers developed transgenic L. infantum lines expressing drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters to investigate whether cells with identical genotypes can recognize each other and mate. The study found that both types of markers were successfully exchanged within the sand fly midgut of the natural vector Phlebotomus perniciosus when individuals from these species were fed with a mixture of parental clones. The hybrid progeny appeared to be triploid based on DNA content analysis and was stable throughout the complete parasite life cycle. Infections by the hybrid clone in BALB/c mice caused a reduction in parasite loads in both spleen and liver, and provided weight values similar to those obtained with uninfected mice. Spleen arginase activity was also significantly reduced relative to parental strains. The study demonstrates the ability of L. infantum to recognize the same genotype and mate, suggesting the existence of a non-obligate sexual cycle in the extracellular stage of the parasite within the sand fly vector. The yellow hybrid progeny is stable throughout the whole parasite life cycle but with a slower virulence, which correlates well with the lower arginase activity detected both in vitro and in vivo infections.
A recent study examined 63 Leishmania donovani strains isolated from patients with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) or HIV-VL co-infections in northwestern and southern Ethiopia. The strains were characterized using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) targeting three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS1), cysteine protease B (cpb), and HASPB (k26). The results showed that the k26-PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic origin. Most strains from northwestern Ethiopia produced a 290 bp product, while a minority (4/40) gave a 410 bp amplicon, all of which were isolated from patients with HIV-VL co-infections. In contrast, almost all strains (20/23) from southern Ethiopia produced a 450 bp amplicon. High-resolution melt (HRM) analysis distinguished the different PCR products. Sequence analysis revealed that the k26 repeat region in L. donovani is comprised of polymorphic 13 and 14 amino acid motifs, with the 13 amino acid peptide motifs being prevalent in L. donovani but rare in L. infantum. The number and order of the repeats in L. donovani vary between geographic regions, indicating considerable polymorphism in the HASPB repeat region (k26) among L. donovani strains from different regions in East Africa. These findings have implications for the design of diagnostic assays and vaccines based on this antigen.
A probabilistic model of HIV-1 copy-choice recombination has been developed to predict the distribution of breakpoints in the HIV-1 genome. The model is based on local sequence identity and accurately predicts the observed frequencies of inter-subtype recombination across much of the HIV-1 genome. In regions where the observed frequencies of breakpoints deviate from the predicted distribution, natural selection is inferred to be influencing the recombination pattern. The envelope gene is found to have a paucity of recombination breakpoints, suggesting that recombinants generated in this region are less likely to be successful. In contrast, breakpoints at a higher frequency than predicted by the model are found at either side of the envelope gene, indicating increased selection for these recombinants. These findings suggest that only a minority of recombination events appear to be of significance to the evolution of HIV-1. The model was applied to recombinant sequences from the HIV-1 pandemic and compared to the distributions of inter-subtype breakpoints derived from complete genome HIV-1 recombinants. The observed inter-subtype breakpoint frequencies fall within a 90% confidence interval across much of the HIV-1 genome. Regions that deviate from this expected distribution are inferred to include the breakpoints that are of greater importance as a consequence of the mosaic structures they have generated. The study provides a clear indication that the majority of recombinant breakpoints detected in the HIV-1 pandemic provide limited selective advantage, with the exception of specific genomic regions.
Title: Hierarchical Bayesian Inference for Concurrent Model Fitting and Comparison for Group Studies

A novel hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI) framework has been proposed to address the interdependent problems of model fitting and comparison in group studies. Previous research has relied on separate statistical methods to estimate individual variation in parameters over a population of subjects and to compare candidate models. However, this approach has limitations, as the relevant population for estimating parameters of a model depends on which other subjects express the model. The proposed HBI framework combines previous approaches and has important advantages for both parameter estimation and model comparison. Theoretical and experimental results show that the parameters estimated by HBI have smaller errors compared to other methods, and model comparison by HBI is robust against outliers and not biased towards overly simplistic models. Additionally, the fully Bayesian approach enables researchers to make inference on group-level parameters by performing HBI t-tests. The HBI framework is hierarchical, with parameters at the individual level regularized by statistics across all individuals in the group, and Bayesian, with uncertainties at both individual and group levels represented by probability distributions. This approach addresses issues of statistical inference over both parameters and models, which have remained elusive with previous hierarchical methods.
The development of the auditory circuitry in the mouse brainstem involves the coordinated action of rhombomeres (r) and their associated Hox genes. Rhombomeres r4 contribute to the formation of functionally linked sensory and motor components of the auditory system, including the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, posterior ventral cochlear nuclei (VCN), and motor olivocochlear neurons. The Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 genes play a crucial role in regulating the assembly of these components, and their inactivation leads to hearing impairments. Specifically, Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 mutant mice exhibit a loss of transmission of low-level auditory stimuli. In contrast, Hoxa2 regulates the Rig1 axon guidance receptor and controls contralateral projections from the anterior VCN to the medial nucleus of the trapezoid body, a circuit involved in sound localization. The results suggest that individual rhombomeres and their associated Hox codes control the assembly of distinct functionally segregated sub-circuits in the developing auditory brainstem. Furthermore, a single rhombomere, r4, contributes to various derivatives of the auditory pathway, which are distributed across several rhombomeres via selective migrations and structurally linked into functional circuits essential for proper hearing. Overall, the study highlights the importance of Hox genes in the assembly of sensorimotor functional circuits in the developing hindbrain.
The marine bacterium Saccharophagus degradans strain 2-40 (Sde 2-40) has been found to possess an extraordinary ability to degrade complex polysaccharides. The complete genome sequence of Sde 2-40 reveals an unusually large number of enzymes that can break down over 10 different complex polysaccharides. These enzymes exhibit novel combinations of catalytic and substrate-binding modules, suggesting adaptations that facilitate the depolymerization of complex polysaccharides in the marine environment. Notably, Sde 2-40 is the first sequenced genome of a marine bacterium capable of degrading plant cell walls, an important component of the carbon cycle that is not well-characterized in the marine environment.

Genomic, qRT-PCR, enzyme activity, and MS studies demonstrate that Sde 2-40 carbohydrases are regulated by multiple mechanisms, including glucose repression. The more complex the polysaccharide, the more enzyme systems are induced. Sde 2-40 has been shown to grow on plants as sole carbon sources while fully degrading them, making it the first marine prokaryote to do so. The bacterium is a member of the gamma-subclass of the phylum Proteobacteria and is related to cellulolytic nitrogen-fixing bacteria that are symbionts of shipworms. The discovery of Sde 2-40's enzymatic capabilities suggests a significant role in the marine carbon cycle, functioning as a "super-degrader" and mediating the breakdown of complex polysaccharides from plants, algae, and invertebrates.
The study investigated the infectivity of Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV) genotype I (GI) and genotype III (GIII) in Culex pipiens mosquitoes from China. The researchers found that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes were competent vectors for both GI and GIII JEV infection, with similar infection rates, growth kinetics, dissemination rates, and transmission rates. Both genotypes were detectable in the salivary glands of infected mosquitoes at similar transmission rates, suggesting the potential of Cx. pipiens mosquitoes for transmission of both genotype viruses. The study also showed that the infection rates and growth kinetics in orally infected Cx. pipiens mosquitoes showed no significant difference between GI- and GIII-infected groups. After the establishment of infection, Cx. pipiens mosquitoes disseminated both JEV genotypes to secondary organs at similar rates of dissemination. The results indicate that GI and GIII viruses have similar infectivity in Cx. pipiens mosquitoes, suggesting that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes from China may not play a critical role in JEV genotype shift. However, the conclusion is based on the use of a single representative JEV strain from each genotype, and further studies with more different GI and GIII JEV strains are needed to confirm this conclusion. The findings of this study provide insights into the role of Cx. pipiens mosquitoes in JEV transmission and genotype shift.
A two-year review of dengue deaths in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014 was conducted to investigate the epidemiology and clinical characteristics of fatal cases. The study analyzed 322 dengue deaths, with a mean age of 40.7 years and a majority of cases (72.5%) occurring in adults aged 15-59 years. The median duration of first medical contact and hospitalization was 1 and 3 days, respectively. Common co-morbidities among adults and the elderly included diabetes and hypertension. Warning signs such as lethargy and vomiting were reported, with lethargy being more common in children and abdominal pain in adults. However, 22.4% of cases did not exhibit any warning signs. Dengue shock syndrome (DSS) was the leading cause of death, accounting for over 70% of cases, followed by severe organ involvement and severe bleeding. The study found that DSS was the primary cause of death across all age groups. The review highlights the need for early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent dengue-related deaths. The study's findings emphasize the importance of strengthening the surveillance system to capture dengue-related deaths that occur outside of hospital settings. This study provides valuable insights into the epidemiology and clinical characteristics of fatal dengue cases in Malaysia, contributing to a better understanding of the disease and its management.
The study investigated the role of tissue-specific insulin signaling in mediating female sexual attractiveness in Drosophila melanogaster. Insulin signaling is a nutrient-sensing pathway that governs investment in survival versus reproduction. The researchers found that global manipulation of insulin signaling affects female sexual attractiveness, and this effect is mediated by insulin signaling in the fat body and ovarian follicle cells. The signals from these cells are integrated by pheromone-producing cells called oenocytes. The study demonstrated that functional ovaries are required for global insulin signaling effects on attractiveness, and manipulations of insulin signaling specifically in late follicle cells recapitulated effects of global manipulations. In contrast, modulation of insulin signaling in the fat body produced opposite effects on attractiveness, suggesting a competitive relationship with the ovary. The study also found that tissue-specific insulin signaling manipulations that changed attractiveness also changed fecundity in the corresponding direction, indicating that insulin pathway activity is a reliable link between fecundity and attractiveness cues. The cues themselves, cuticular hydrocarbons, responded distinctly to fat body and follicle cell manipulations, indicating independent readouts of the pathway activity from these two tissues. These findings suggest that female attractiveness results from an apparent connection between attractiveness cues and an organismal state of high fecundity, both of which are created by lowered insulin signaling in the fat body and increased insulin signaling in late follicle cells.
During the 2013-2015 Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in West Africa, the disease spread heterogeneously across Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. To investigate district-level transmissibility of EVD, a statistical modeling approach was applied to estimate the basic reproduction number (R0) for each affected district and country. The study used weekly incident case numbers to estimate growth rates during the early exponential phase of the outbreak. A mixed effects model was fitted to account for heterogeneity between and within countries, and R0 was calculated based on predicted individual growth rates and the reported serial interval distribution. The results showed that R0 ranged from 0.36 to 1.72 in Guinea, 0.53 to 3.37 in Liberia, and 1.14 to 2.73 in Sierra Leone at the district level. At the national level, R0 was estimated to be 0.97 (95% CI 0.77-1.18) for Guinea, 1.26 (95% CI 0.98-1.55) for Liberia, and 1.66 (95% CI 1.32-2.00) for Sierra Leone. The study found that socio-demographic variables related to urbanization, such as high population density and high wealth index, were positively associated with R0, suggesting that the consequences of fast urban growth in West Africa may have contributed to the increased spread of EVD. The findings support the notion of geographical heterogeneity in the transmission of EVD in West Africa and highlight the importance of considering local epidemic growth during large-scale multifocal epidemics.
The relationship between a protein’s rate of evolution and its structural properties, as well as its age, has been a topic of ongoing debate in the scientific community. A recent study investigated the interplay between these two factors using a large dataset of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins with mapped PDB structures. The results showed that previously observed correlations between structural properties and evolutionary rates, such as the relationship between solvent accessibility and rate, also hold within each age group. However, the study found that age plays a crucial role in modulating the relationship between solvent accessibility and rate, and that younger proteins tend to evolve faster than older proteins despite being less designable. Additionally, the study found that older proteins are more stable for their native structure and more robust to mutations than younger ones. The results suggest that several determinants, both intrinsic and historical, can interact to determine rates of protein evolution. Furthermore, the study ruled out the possibility that structural biases among age groups could explain the reported differences in evolutionary rates with age. Overall, the study provides new insights into the complex relationship between protein age and evolutionary rate, and highlights the importance of considering both intrinsic and historical factors in understanding protein evolution.
Polycomb-Like 3 (Pcl3) is a component of Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) that plays a crucial role in embryonic stem cell (ESC) self-renewal. Pcl3 interacts with Suz12, a core component of PRC2, and promotes the trimethylation of lysine 27 on histone H3 (H3K27me3), a mark associated with gene silencing. Knockdown of Pcl3 in ESCs leads to increased spontaneous differentiation, indicating that Pcl3 is essential for maintaining ESC self-renewal. Pcl3 also promotes the recruitment of PRC2 to a subset of its genomic sites, particularly CpG islands, which are regulatory regions of the genome. ChIP-seq analysis reveals that Pcl3 co-localizes with Suz12 at target loci, and depletion of Pcl3 decreases Suz12 binding at over 60% of PRC2 targets. The Tudor domain of Pcl3, which recognizes methylated histones, is essential for its function, as mutation of conserved residues within this domain compromises H3K27me3 formation. Pcl3 and its paralog, Pcl2, exist in different PRC2 complexes but bind many of the same PRC2 targets. Overexpression of Pcl3 increases H3K27me3 levels, while decreasing Pcl3 levels reduces H3K27me3 levels. These findings suggest that Pcl3 is a critical component of PRC2 that regulates ESC self-renewal, histone methylation, and the recruitment of PRC2 to specific genomic sites.
This study investigates the regulation of chemoreceptor gene expression in Caenorhabditis elegans in response to changes in feeding state. The chemoreceptor gene, srh-234, is specifically expressed in the ADL sensory neuron and its expression levels are dynamically modulated by the feeding state of the animal. The MEF-2 transcription factor is shown to act together with basic helix-loop-helix ( bHLH ) transcription factors to regulate srh-234 expression as a function of feeding state. A cis-regulatory MEF2 binding site is identified as necessary and sufficient for the starvation-induced downregulation of srh-234 expression, while an E-box site is required to drive srh-234 expression in ADL neurons. The bHLH transcription factors HLH-2, HLH-3, and HLH-4 are found to act in ADL neurons to regulate srh-234 expression. Additionally, the study reveals that the expression levels of srh-234 in ADL neurons are regulated remotely by MXL-3 and HLH-30 acting in the intestine, which is dependent on insulin signaling functioning specifically in ADL neurons. This non-cell-autonomous regulation involves a subset of insulin-like peptides. The results suggest that chemoreceptor gene expression is regulated by both cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous transcriptional mechanisms mediated by MEF2 and bHLH factors, allowing animals to fine-tune their chemosensory responses in response to changes in their feeding state.
This study investigated the association between the detection of Mycobacterium ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of Buruli ulcer (BU) disease in humans in an endemic area of southeastern Australia. Adult mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula in Victoria, Australia, from 2004 to 2009 and screened for M. ulcerans using real-time PCR. The number of laboratory-confirmed cases of BU in permanent residents of these towns was tallied to determine the average cumulative incidence of BU in each location. A strong dose-response relationship was found between the detection of M. ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of human disease, with a Pearson's correlation coefficient of 0.99 (95% CI, 0.92-0.99; p < 0.001). The results suggest that mosquitoes play a role in the transmission of M. ulcerans in southeastern Australia. This finding has implications for the development of intervention strategies to control and prevent BU. The study also highlights the importance of public health measures to minimize mosquito bites in residents and visitors to endemic areas. The results of this study strengthen the hypothesis that mosquitoes are involved in the spread of M. ulcerans to humans in southeastern Australia. The study's findings may also have implications for other BU endemic areas, such as Queensland and Africa, where the majority of BU cases occur globally.
A mutation in the gene encoding the mitochondrial Mg2+ channel MRS2 has been identified as the cause of demyelination in dmy/dmy rats. The mutation results from a G-to-A transition in the Mrs2 gene, which generates a novel splice acceptor site and leads to the functional inactivation of the mutant allele. Transgenic rescue with wild-type Mrs2-cDNA validated this finding. The Mrs2 gene encodes an essential component of the major Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria of yeast and human cells. In dmy/dmy rats, mitochondrial deficits were observed, including elevated lactic acid concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid, reduced ATP levels, and increased numbers of mitochondria in the swollen cytoplasm of oligodendrocytes. MRS2-GFP recombinant BAC transgenic rats showed that MRS2 was dominantly expressed in neurons rather than oligodendrocytes and was ultrastructurally observed in the inner membrane of mitochondria. These findings suggest that dmy/dmy rats suffer from a mitochondrial disease and that Mg2+ homeostasis in CNS mitochondria is essential for the maintenance of myelin. The demyelination observed in dmy/dmy rats is likely enhanced by activated microglia and astroglia. The Mrs2dmy mutation is a loss-of-function mutation of the Mrs2 gene, which encodes a Mg2+ transporter protein of the mitochondrial inner membrane. This study provides a unique model system to investigate the maintenance of myelin and the pathomechanisms underlying demyelination.
The current documentation standards of microarray gene expression signatures hinder their application in clinical practice due to inconsistencies in study-internal and study-external diagnoses. An analysis of eight publicly available clinical microarray studies revealed that discrepancies between study-internal and study-external diagnoses can be as high as 30% in the worst-case scenario and 18% on average. These discrepancies occur because documenting a signature is conceptually different from reporting a list of genes, and the exact quantitative specification of a classification rule alone does not define a signature unambiguously. To address this issue, the authors propose a documentation by value strategy that documents quantitative preprocessing information, which reduces the median discrepancy to 1%. This approach improves the consistency of diagnoses based on gene expression diagnostic signatures. The study highlights the importance of unambiguous documentation of signatures for their evaluation and application in clinical practice. The results suggest that better documentation of signatures can substantially improve the process of evaluating microarray gene expression diagnostic signatures and bringing them to clinical practice. The proposed documentation by value strategy is a crucial step towards making gene expression signatures a reliable tool for diagnosis and prognosis of disease.
The study presents crystal structures of amyloid-forming segments from the major curli subunit, CsgA, revealing steric zipper fibrils of tightly mated β-sheets. These findings demonstrate a structural link between curli and human pathological amyloids, such as Alzheimer’s disease-associated amyloid-β. Two D-enantiomeric peptides, originally developed to interfere with Alzheimer’s disease-associated amyloid-β, were found to inhibit CsgA fibrillation and reduce biofilm formation in Salmonella typhimurium. Furthermore, CsgA fibrils were shown to cross-seed fibrillation of amyloid-β, providing support for the proposed structural resemblance and potential for cross-species amyloid interactions. The study suggests a novel strategy for disrupting amyloid-structured biofilms and hypothesizes on the formation of self-propagating prion-like species originating from a microbial source that could influence neurodegenerative diseases. The findings provide structural insights into amyloidogenic regions important for curli formation and highlight the potential for repurposing anti-amyloid compounds as anti-biofilm agents. Curli proteins, produced by Enterobacteriaceae, mediate host cell adhesion and contribute to biofilm formation, promoting bacterial resistance to environmental stressors. The study’s results have implications for understanding the role of amyloids in biofilm formation and the development of new therapeutic strategies to target amyloid-structured biofilms.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a significant cause of encephalitis in most of Asia, with high case fatality rates and long-term neuropsychological sequelae among survivors. In the Philippines, the epidemiology of JE has not been well defined. A systematic review of literature and surveillance data from 2011 to 2014 was conducted to support consideration of JE vaccine introduction into the national schedule. The review identified 29 published reports and presentations on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic surveys, 18 reports of clinical cases, and 8 animal studies. The 18 clinical studies reported 257 cases of laboratory-confirmed JE from 1972 to 2013, with JEV being the causative agent in 7-18% of cases of clinical meningitis and encephalitis combined, and 16-40% of clinical encephalitis cases. JE predominantly affected children under 15 years of age, with 6-7% of cases resulting in death. Surveillance data from 2011 to 2014 identified 73 (15%) laboratory-confirmed JE cases out of 497 cases tested. The review demonstrates the endemicity and extensive geographic range of JE in the Philippines, supporting the use of JE vaccine in the country. Continued and improved surveillance is needed to quantify the burden of JE, guide prioritization of high-risk areas, and measure the impact of preventive measures. The evidence suggests that JE constitutes a significant public health burden in all regions of the Philippines, supporting consideration of inclusion of JE vaccine in the national immunization program.
A large-scale computational study was conducted to investigate the evolutionary origins of genetic robustness in bacterial species. The study analyzed the metabolic networks of hundreds of bacterial species across various simulated growth environments and found that variations in genetic robustness among species reflect ecological adaptations. The study decoupled metabolic robustness into two components: environmental-dependent and environmental-independent. The environmental-dependent component accounts for at least 20% of non-essential reactions and is associated with a species' lifestyle, with specialized species exhibiting higher robustness. In contrast, the environmental-independent component is associated with a species' intrinsic metabolic capacities, with higher robustness observed in fast-growing organisms or those with extensive secondary metabolite production. The study also identified reactions uniquely susceptible to perturbations in human pathogens, potentially serving as novel drug targets. The results suggest that the need to increase metabolic capacities has driven the evolution of genetic robustness in bacterial metabolic networks. The study's findings support the notion that environmental robustness contributes to genetic robustness, with a significant correlation observed between environmental robustness and the modularity of metabolic networks. Overall, the study provides new insights into the evolutionary origins of genetic robustness in bacterial species.
A randomised trial was conducted to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni (S. mansoni) infection on antibody responses to measles catch-up immunisation in pre-school children and the impact of praziquantel treatment on this outcome. The study, known as the Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunisation (IMoChI) study, took place in Entebbe, Uganda, and enrolled 193 S. mansoni-infected and 61 uninfected children aged 3-5 years. The children were randomised to receive praziquantel treatment 2 weeks before, at the time of, or 1 week after measles catch-up immunisation. Plasma anti-measles IgG levels were measured at enrolment, 1 week, and 24 weeks after immunisation. The results showed that S. mansoni-infected children had lower anti-measles IgG levels and a lower percentage of protective antibody levels compared to uninfected children at 1 week post-immunisation. However, among S. mansoni-infected children, those who received praziquantel treatment before or at the time of immunisation had higher anti-measles IgG levels compared to those who did not receive treatment. At 24 weeks post-immunisation, IgG levels did not differ between the trial groups, but tended to be lower among previously-infected children who remained S. mansoni stool-positive compared to those who became stool-negative. The study suggests that S. mansoni infection may impair antibody responses to measles immunisation, and that praziquantel treatment may improve the response.
The evolution of bacterial populations can be better understood through large-scale sequencing of population samples. However, traditional statistical methods for evolutionary inference, such as phylogenetic analysis, are limited when dealing with extensive sampling scenarios and high recombination rates. To address this, the authors introduce several statistical tools for detecting and representing recombination between populations, as well as a model-based description of population shape in sequence space. These tools are integrated with phylogenetic analysis to provide a more comprehensive understanding of bacterial population structure. The authors demonstrate the potential of this approach using extensive real data from the genus Neisseria, which exhibits high recombination rates and occasional horizontal gene flow between species. The statistical tools are implemented in the BAPS 5. 2 software, which is freely available for download. The authors emphasize the importance of interpreting the results with care, using complementary phylogenetic methods and auxiliary knowledge about the strains under investigation. The BAPS software is capable of capturing various biological signals hidden in molecular data, but requires careful interpretation of the identified populations. The authors validate their approach using a population sample of 5086 strains of Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria lactamica species, assuming a simplified evolutionary model of bacterial populations with a common local ancestor and a global ancestor. The results demonstrate the potential of the integrated approach for analyzing bacterial population structures on an unprecedented scale.
A computational model was developed to investigate the role of top-down beta rhythms in supporting selective attention. The model simulated sensory cortical areas and found that top-down beta rhythms, generated in higher cognitive areas and delivered to earlier sensory areas, can activate ascending synaptic projections from layer 5 ( L5 ) to layers 2/3 ( L2/3 ) and layer 4 ( L4 ). These projections are responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Slow-inhibitory interneurons in L5 were shown to resonate to the 20 Hz input and modulate activity in superficial layers in an attention-related manner. The model predicted that these cells play a critical role in attentional gain modulation, providing a potential mechanism by which cholinergic drive can support selective attention. The results suggest that top-down beta rhythms can enhance gamma rhythms in L2/3, reduce beta rhythms in L2/3, and increase spiking activity of L2/3 regular spiking ( RS ) cells when attention is focused on a specific region of interest ( RF ). This is consistent with neurophysiological findings that attention enhances neural responses to stimuli. The model proposes that interlaminar interaction, regulated by top-down beta rhythms, supports selective attention by biasing competition in superficial layers.
The article presents a new method for calibrating and predicting stochastic compartmental epidemic models using real-time surveillance data. The proposed method, Multiple Shooting for Stochastic systems (MSS), applies a linear noise approximation to describe the size of fluctuations and updates the belief about the true epidemic state using each new surveillance observation. The authors evaluate the accuracy of MSS using simulated outbreaks of a novel viral pathogen and compare its performance to three state-of-the-art benchmark methods. The results show that MSS produces accurate estimates of key epidemic parameters, such as mean duration of infectiousness, R0, and Reff, and can provide an accurate estimate of the unobserved number of infectious individuals during the course of an epidemic. MSS also allows for accurate prediction of the number and timing of future hospitalizations and the overall attack rate. The authors find that MSS significantly outperforms the benchmark methods in the majority of epidemic scenarios tested. The method addresses several major challenges inherent in parameter estimation and model-based prediction during outbreaks, where the true epidemic state can be only partially observed and the behavior of disease spread is most stochastic. The authors demonstrate the potential of MSS for improving predictions about the future course of epidemics.
The article presents a comprehensive study on the laws of concatenated perception in human visual processing. The research reveals that every instant of perception is influenced by a cascade of brain processes shaped by the history of sensory and decisional events. Using multilevel modeling and cross-validation approaches, the study investigates the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports during adjustment and forced-choice tasks. The results show that human visual perception is subject to two contrasting forces: low-level adaptation, which repels perception away from previous stimuli, and decisional traces, which attract perceptual reports toward the recent past. This hierarchy of serial dependence is characterized by "continuity fields" arising from the inertia of decisional templates, rather than low-level sensory processes. The study proposes a Two-process model of serial dependence, where the persistence of readout weights in a decision unit compensates for sensory adaptation, leading to attractive biases in sequential perception. The findings suggest that functionally distinct mechanisms operating at different stages promote the differentiation and integration of visual information over time. The study provides a unified account of serial dependence, highlighting the interplay between sensory adaptation and decisional inertia in shaping visual experience and reactions to environmental stimuli. The results have implications for understanding the neural mechanisms underlying human perception and decision-making.
The Clock-Cycle (CLK-CYC) heterodimer plays a crucial role in circadian transcription in Drosophila. To investigate the contribution of transcription to core circadian timekeeping, researchers analyzed the effects of a CYC-viral protein 16 (VP16) fusion protein in Drosophila. The addition of VP16 to the CLK-CYC complex significantly enhanced transcriptional activity compared to the wild-type CLK-CYC complex. This increased activity was observed in both S2 cells and flies expressing the CYC-VP16 fusion protein. The enhanced transcriptional activity resulted in increased levels of CLK-CYC direct target gene mRNAs, including those from the period (per) and timeless (tim) genes. Notably, the flies expressing CYC-VP16 exhibited a short period, suggesting that circadian transcription contributes to period determination. Further analysis of reporter gene expression in CYC-VP16-expressing flies revealed that the short period was due, at least in part, to a more rapid transcriptional phase. Importantly, the behavioral effects observed in CYC-VP16-expressing flies required a per promoter and were therefore unlikely to be a consequence of generally higher PER levels.
