These findings indicate that the timing of transcriptional activation, rather than the activation itself, is the key event responsible for the behavioral effects observed in CYC-VP16-expressing flies. Overall, the results suggest that circadian transcription plays a significant role in core circadian function in Drosophila.
The ability of horizontally acquired genes to confer new traits in different species is often attributed to their autonomous functionality. However, this study reveals that proteins preexisting in an organism can constrain the functionality of a horizontally acquired gene product if it operates on an ancestral pathway. The researchers investigated how the horizontally acquired pmrD gene product activates the ancestral PmrA/PmrB two-component system in Salmonella enterica but not in the closely related bacterium Escherichia coli. They found that the Salmonella PmrD protein binds to the phosphorylated PmrA protein ( PmrA-P ), protecting it from dephosphorylation by the PmrB protein, resulting in transcription of PmrA-dependent genes, including those conferring polymyxin B resistance. In contrast, the E. coli PmrD protein cannot activate the PmrA/PmrB system in E. coli, suggesting that the two species differ in an additional component controlling PmrA-P levels. The researchers discovered that the E. coli PmrB protein displays higher phosphatase activity towards PmrA-P than the Salmonella PmrB protein, and identified a PmrB subdomain responsible for this property. Replacement of the E. coli pmrB gene with the Salmonella homolog was sufficient to render E. coli resistant to polymyxin B under PmrD-inducing conditions. These findings demonstrate that quantitative differences in the biochemical activities of ancestral proteins can dictate the ability of a horizontally acquired gene product to confer species-specific traits, and suggest that horizontally acquired genes can potentiate selection at ancestral loci.
The differentiation of embryonic stem cells is a complex process initiated by the loss of pluripotency-associated transcripts and the induction of differentiation genes. To identify the causal genes that promote or inhibit differentiation, researchers have sought to detect differentially expressed genes at the early stages of differentiation. However, previous methods of identifying differentially expressed genes by comparing different cell types often include a large portion of genes that respond to, rather than regulate, the differentiation process. To address this limitation, a novel statistical approach called the Differentiation-Test was developed to analyze gene expression data obtained without prior separation of cell types. This method assumes that the differentiation process starts from a relatively homogeneous initial cell mixture and progresses into a more heterogeneous cell mixture with identifiable events of divergence of expression levels of certain genes during the process. The Differentiation-Test was applied to study the differentiation of mouse embryonic stem cells into embryoid bodies and identified Smarcad1 as a novel regulator of pluripotency and self-renewal. Smarcad1 was experimentally verified using short hairpin RNA ( shRNA ) to further study its role in differentiation. The Differentiation-Test was formalized as a statistical test that can be generally applied to analyze other differentiation processes. This approach has the potential to identify uncharacterized critical regulators of pluripotency and self-renewal, providing new insights into the complex mechanisms of cellular differentiation.
The article presents a novel method for unbiased functional clustering of gene variants using a phenotypic-linkage network. This approach addresses the issue of confounding bias in coding-sequence length, which can lead to false positive findings in functional studies. The authors demonstrate that genes implicated through de novo sequence variants tend to cluster together due to their longer coding-sequence length, resulting in exaggerated p-values. To control for this bias, the method integrates over 100,000 mammalian genotype-phenotype relations and exploits bio-ontologies through semantic similarity. The phenotypic-linkage network is shown to be superior to other gene networks in identifying functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease, even after accounting for significant sequencing study bias. The authors present a tool that can identify functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease and demonstrate its power to functionally subcluster gene variants underlying a polygenic disorder. The method has been tested with different data types and networks, and the results show that genes mutated in the same disease cluster more significantly in the integrated phenotypic-linkage network than in other gene networks. This approach is expected to enhance the interpretation of variants in next-generation sequencing studies and provide a more accurate understanding of the molecular pathways underlying complex diseases.
The Mexican government implemented an 8% tax on nonessential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100 g and a peso-per-liter tax on sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) in January 2014 to combat rising obesity and diabetes rates. This study evaluated the impact of these taxes on household packaged food purchases from January 2012 to December 2014 using data from The Nielsen Company’s Mexico Consumer Panel Services. The analysis included 6,248 households with an average follow-up period of 32.7 months. A longitudinal, fixed-effects model was used to examine changes in the volume of purchases of taxed and untaxed foods, adjusting for pre-existing trends, household characteristics, and contextual factors. The results showed that the mean volume of purchases of taxed foods decreased by 25 g (95% CI = -46, -11) per capita per month, or a 5.1% change beyond what was expected based on pre-tax trends, with no corresponding change in purchases of untaxed foods. Lower socioeconomic status (SES) households purchased 10.2% less taxed foods than expected, while medium SES households purchased 5.8% less taxed foods than expected. Higher SES households showed no statistically significant change in purchases. These findings suggest that the tax on nonessential energy-dense foods and SSBs led to a decline in the volume of taxed food purchases, with lower SES households being more responsive to the tax. However, the impact of the tax on overall energy intake, dietary quality, and food purchase patterns remains to be studied.
The article presents a biophysically plausible model of collision-sensitive neurons, specifically the Lobula Giant Movement Detector Neuron (LGMD) of the locust, which exhibits η-like response properties. The model, denoted as n-ψ, assumes that each information channel is noisy and has a response threshold. By pooling these channels, an approximative power law is obtained, which is a common characteristic of many brain functions. The authors demonstrate that this mechanism can successfully predict many response characteristics of the LGMD neuron, including its response to objects approaching on a collision course. The results show that the model is critically dependent on noise in the inhibitory pathway, but robust against noise in the excitatory pathway. The n-ψ model is based on its predecessor model Ψ, which used an exact power law for re-scaling the inhibitory input. However, the n-ψ model is more biophysically plausible and does not require an exact power law. The authors argue that a power law alone is insufficient to explain the LGMD's response properties, and that threshold smoothing, resulting from integrating many inhibitory inputs, is necessary to approximate a power law. The model suggests that the integration process, or pooling, could be carried out by the dendritic tree of the LGMD neuron. The preconditions for each channel are the presence of noise, uncorrelated across channels, and a response threshold. The n-ψ model provides a biophysically plausible explanation for the LGMD's response properties and highlights the importance of noise in the inhibitory pathway.
The National Buruli Ulcer Control Programme (NBUCP) in Cameroon was established in 2002 to combat the disease, which was first reported in the country in 1969. The programme aimed to detect cases early, confirm 70% of clinical cases by PCR, treat all active cases according to standard guidelines, and heal at least 95% of patients without limitation of joint movement. Between 2001 and 2014, 3700 cases of Buruli ulcer (BU) were notified, with the detection rate dropping significantly from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants. The number of BU-endemic health districts increased from two to 64, and five diagnostic and treatment centers are now functional, with two more planned for 2015. The health system has been strengthened, and research and education on BU have gained more interest in Cameroon. However, the reduction in programme resources and activities by major support partners has led to a steady drop in performance indicators since 2010. The programme's objectives have evolved over time, with the current goal being to reduce the suffering of the population due to BU and ensure accessibility to quality health services in endemic areas to reduce morbidity and disability linked to BU in Cameroon. Despite the progress made, the programme faces the major challenge of resource allocation, which needs to be addressed to improve control activities in the country.
The article investigates the effect of outcome valence on confidence judgments in human reinforcement learning. In two experiments, participants were more confident in their choices when learning to seek gains compared to avoiding losses, despite equal difficulty and performance between the two contexts. Computational modeling revealed that this bias is driven by the context-value, a dynamically updated estimate of the average expected-value of choice options, necessary to explain equal performance in the gain and loss domain. This biasing effect of context-value on confidence is domain-general and has important functional consequences. One such consequence emerges in volatile environments, where the flexibility of individuals’ learning strategies differs when outcomes are framed as gains or losses. The study suggests that profound asymmetries might exist between learning to avoid losses and learning to seek gains, despite apparent similar behavior. The findings have implications for our understanding of the flexibility of learning and decision-making processes in different contexts. The results also highlight the importance of investigating confidence judgments and their biases in reinforcement learning, as they can have critical consequences on learning strategies and decision-making processes. The study contributes to the growing body of research on confidence estimation in decision-making and prediction tasks, and provides new insights into the neural, computational, and behavioral mechanisms underlying confidence judgments in reinforcement learning contexts.
Alphaviruses, a family of positive-strand RNA viruses, have a non-structural protein 3 ( nsP3 ) that plays a crucial role in viral RNA replication. Despite its importance, the function of nsP3 is not well understood. Recent studies have identified a conserved proline-rich sequence motif in the carboxyterminal region of nsP3 that serves as a binding site for the Src-homology 3 ( SH3 ) domains of amphiphysin-1 and -2. Amphiphysins are host cell proteins that are involved in endocytosis and membrane trafficking. The interaction between nsP3 and amphiphysin is mediated by the PIPPPR motif in nsP3 and the SH3 domains of amphiphysin. This interaction is conserved across different alphaviruses, including Semliki Forest ( SFV ), Sindbis ( SINV ), and Chikungunya viruses. In infected cells, amphiphysin is recruited to the sites of RNA replication and is essential for viral RNA synthesis. Mutations in nsP3 that disrupt the amphiphysin SH3 binding motif or RNAi-mediated silencing of amphiphysin-2 expression resulted in impaired viral RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SFV. Infection of Balb/c mice with SFV carrying an SH3 binding-defective nsP3 was associated with significantly decreased mortality. These findings establish the SH3 domain-mediated binding of nsP3 with amphiphysin as an important host cell interaction that promotes alphavirus replication.
This study investigated the molecular epidemiology of chromoblastomycosis, a human disease caused by melanized fungi of the order Chaetothyriales, in Brazil. A total of 123 clinical strains from different endemic areas were analyzed using sequencing of the rDNA internal transcribed spacer region and partial cell division cycle and β-tubulin genes. The strains were divided into three clusters within the family Herpotrichiellaceae, which is known to comprise agents of the disease. The Fonsecaea cluster contained the most prevalent agents, with Fonsecaea pedrosoi being the most common, accounting for 80% of the strains, followed by Fonsecaea monophora (13%), Fonsecaea nubica (3%), and a single isolate of Fonsecaea pugnacius. Additional agents, including two novel species, were identified in the genera Rhinocladiella and Cyphellophora, with frequencies of 3% and 1%, respectively. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the agents of chromoblastomycosis were polyphyletic within the order Chaetothyriales, being dispersed in three different clades: jeanselmei-, bantiana-, and europaea-clades. The study highlights the diversity of agents causing chromoblastomycosis in Brazil and describes two novel species of black fungi causing the disease.
Infection with Listeria monocytogenes induces DNA breaks in host cells and activates the DNA damage response (DDR) signaling pathway. However, surprisingly, the DDR is only moderately activated in response to these breaks. Further investigation revealed that the listerial toxin listeriolysin O (LLO) plays a key role in dampening the DDR by degrading the sensor protein Mre11. Mre11 is a crucial component of the DDR pathway, responsible for detecting DNA damage. The degradation of Mre11 by LLO prevents the full activation of the DDR, allowing Listeria monocytogenes to replicate more effectively within the host cell. Consistent with this finding, deletion or inhibition of proteins involved in the DDR leads to increased levels of infection, demonstrating that the DDR acts as a negative regulator of Listeria monocytogenes infection. This study highlights the importance of the DDR in controlling bacterial infection and reveals a novel mechanism by which Listeria monocytogenes subverts the host's DNA damage response to facilitate its own replication. The findings suggest that the DDR is a critical component of the host's defense against Listeria monocytogenes infection, and that LLO-mediated degradation of Mre11 is a key strategy employed by the bacterium to evade the host's immune response.
A chemical library screen of epigenetic regulation identified bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) as a critical player in the replication of human herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2). The study found that treatment with pan-BD domain inhibitors, such as JQ1, enhanced both HSV-1 and HSV-2 infection. Further investigation revealed that JQ1 acts through BRD4, as knockdown of BRD4 expression ablated the effect of JQ1 on HSV infection. BRD4 regulates HSV replication by forming a complex with CDK9 and RNA polymerase II, and JQ1 promotes HSV-1 infection by allocating this complex to HSV gene promoters. Suppression of BRD4 expression or inhibition of CDK9 activity impeded HSV infection. The study demonstrates that BRD4 has an essential role in HSV infection and that JQ1 enhances HSV infection by switching BRD4 to transcription regulation of viral gene expression from chromatin targeting. Transient expression of BRD4 BD1 or BD1/2 domain had a similar effect to that of JQ1 treatment, suggesting that JQ1 promotes HSV infection by diverting BRD4 function due to BD1 blocking. The study also found that BRD4 regulates HSV infection by recruiting transcriptional factors for viral gene expression, and that BD1 inhibitors augment HSV infection by devoting those factors more efficiently to sites of viral gene transcription.
A cross-sectional study was conducted to investigate the microbial ecology of noma (cancrum oris), a devastating oral disease affecting over 140,000 malnourished children annually. High-throughput sequencing of 16S rRNA gene fragments from gingival fluid samples was used to catalog bacteria present in noma lesions and identify potential causative agents. The study included 60 samples from 12 healthy children, 12 children with noma (lesion and healthy sites), and 12 children with Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis (ANG) (lesion and healthy sites). The results showed that noma lesions were enriched with Spirochaetes and depleted of Proteobacteria compared to healthy individuals. In contrast, healthy sites from diseased mouths had similar proportions of Spirochaetes and Proteobacteria to healthy controls. Fusobacterium was not found to be more abundant in noma mouths, casting doubt on its role as a causative agent. The microbial community in noma lesions was dominated by Prevotella intermedia, which was less abundant in healthy sites from the same mouths. Multivariate analysis confirmed that bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites were significantly different. Several bacterial orders, including Erysipelotrichales, Clostridiales, Bacteroidales, and Spirochaetales, were identified as indicators of noma. These findings suggest that one or more microbes within these orders may be associated with the development of noma lesions. Future studies should include longitudinal sampling of viral and microbial components of this community to better understand the etiology of noma.
In Bacillus thuringiensis, quorum sensing plays a crucial role in coordinating adaptation properties, cell fate, and commitment to sporulation. The bacterium's infectious cycle in the insect host serves as a model to investigate the role of quorum sensing in natural conditions. The communication system is regulated by the RNPP family of proteins, including NprR, which acts as a transcription factor in the presence of its cognate signaling peptide NprX. NprR regulates a set of genes involved in the survival of B. thuringiensis in the insect cadaver. However, in the absence of NprX, NprR negatively controls sporulation by inhibiting the expression of Spo0A-regulated genes. This is achieved by preventing the KinA-dependent phosphorylation of Spo0F, thus delaying the initiation of the sporulation process. The structure of apo NprR reveals a highly flexible Rap-like structure, suggesting a molecular regulatory mechanism where key residues of NprR are directly and alternatively involved in its two functions. The binding of NprX switches NprR from a dimeric inhibitor of sporulation to a tetrameric transcriptional activator involved in the necrotrophic lifestyle of B. thuringiensis. This tight coordination of sporulation and necrotrophism ensures the survival and dissemination of the bacteria during host infection. The NprR-NprX regulation system functions as a typical Gram-positive quorum-sensing system, where NprX is the signaling peptide. This study reveals unexpected properties of NprR and NprX concerning their role in the developmental program of bacteria belonging to the B. cereus group.
Biomedical researchers have developed a novel approach to predict the efficacy of HIV inhibitors using proteochemometric models. These models combine chemical and protein target properties to improve the accuracy of treatment predictions for individual patients. The study utilized a large-scale clinical database containing over 300,000 drug-mutant bioactivity data points to train the models. The results showed that the proteochemometric models achieved a prediction error below 0.5 Log Fold Change, outperforming previously published sequence-based models in resistance classification and prediction of Log Fold Change. The models were also able to identify known and previously unpublished resistance-conferring mutations of HIV Reverse Transcriptase and Protease. Furthermore, the models were prospectively applied to the public HIV resistance database from Stanford University, achieving a correct resistance prediction rate of 84% on the full set. The study demonstrates the potential of proteochemometric models to accurately predict phenotypic resistance based on genotypic data, even for novel mutants and mixtures. Additionally, the models provide an applicability domain to inform users about the reliability of predictions. This approach has the potential to improve treatment outcomes for HIV patients by providing a more accurate and personalized treatment regimen. The models can be used to predict the activity of clinical ARV drugs on mutants not present in the dataset, enabling the treatment of patients with new, previously unseen genotypes.
A computational model of cell movement and chemotaxis based on pseudopod autocatalysis has been developed to test the explanatory and predictive powers of an alternative mechanism of eukaryotic chemotaxis. This mechanism proposes that pseudopods are generated by a self-generated cycle, which is modulated by chemoattractants rather than directly causing actin polymerization. The model reproduces a wide range of existing data on cell movement and chemotaxis, including cell polarization and persistence without stimuli, selection of accurate pseudopods in the presence of chemoattractant gradients, and bias of pseudopod position in low chemoattractant gradients. The model also predicts lateral pseudopod initiation in high gradients, which was experimentally confirmed in Dictyostelium cells. Furthermore, the model predicts that the angle between successive pseudopods at the front of the cell will increase in proportion to the difference between the cell's direction and the direction of the gradient, which was also experimentally confirmed. The results suggest that the mechanism behind chemotaxis relies on modification of intrinsic pseudopod behaviour rather than generation of new pseudopods or actin polymerization by chemoattractants. The model's simplicity and robustness to parameter changes emphasize that much of the complex behaviour of cells may be an emergent property derived from relatively simple pathways, implying a need for a change in experimental approach to understand chemotaxis.
The transmission of Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, by fleas can occur through two mechanisms: early-phase transmission (EPT) and biofilm-dependent transmission (BDT). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and is influenced by the type of rodent blood used for the infectious blood meal. To investigate the effect of host blood on EPT, fleas were fed bacteremic blood from mice, rats, guinea pigs, or gerbils, and the location and characteristics of the infection in the digestive tract and transmissibility of Y. pestis were assessed. The study found that fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea pig blood frequently regurgitated a portion of the infected blood meal into the esophagus within 24 hours of feeding, a phenomenon termed post-infection esophageal reflux (PIER). In contrast, PIER was rarely observed in fleas fed bacteremic mouse or gerbil blood. PIER was associated with the accumulation of a dense aggregate of Y. pestis, red blood cell stroma, and oxyhemoglobin crystals in the proventriculus. Fleas with PIER were more likely to appear partially blocked at their next feeding, with fresh blood retained in the esophagus. The study suggests that EPT results from regurgitation of Y. pestis from a partially obstructed flea foregut and that EPT and BDT can sometimes overlap. The results also indicate that the relative insolubility of the hemoglobin of rats and Sciurids and the slower digestion of their blood may promote regurgitative transmission, which may contribute to the prominence of these rodents in plague ecology.
The article presents a counterintuitive finding that positive correlations among neurons can significantly enhance the fidelity of population codes in the brain. Contrary to previous studies suggesting that correlations are detrimental to coding performance, the authors demonstrate that positive correlations can suppress discrimination errors by several orders of magnitude and increase the capacity of a population to encode stimuli by more than tenfold. This effect does not require unrealistically high correlation values and can occur in populations with a few tens of neurons. The authors attribute this phenomenon to a specific pattern of correlation that leads to a "lock-in" of response probabilities, eliminating variability in the subspace relevant for stimulus discrimination. This pattern, referred to as high-fidelity coding, is shown to benefit from heterogeneity in population activity. The authors suggest that this effect is a general feature of population coding and propose experimental tests to identify the specific pattern of correlation responsible for high-fidelity coding. The findings have implications for our understanding of how the brain represents and processes information, and highlight the importance of considering true population effects when studying neural coding.
A novel cholera conjugate vaccine has been developed using the O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) of Vibrio cholerae O1 Inaba strain PIC018 and a recombinant fragment of tetanus toxin heavy chain (OSP:rTTHc). The vaccine was prepared via squaric acid chemistry and assessed for its immunogenicity and protective efficacy in mice. The study evaluated various vaccine formulations, including different doses (10-50 μg), molar loading ratios of OSP to rTTHc (3:1, 5:1, 10:1), the presence or absence of an adjuvant, and different routes of immunization (intramuscular or intradermal). The results showed that immunized mice developed prominent anti-OSP and anti-TT serum IgG responses, as well as vibriocidal antibody and memory B cell responses. Intestinal lamina proprial IgA responses targeting OSP were also observed following intradermal vaccination. The study found that the vaccine induced 55% protective efficacy in a mouse survival cholera challenge model. Notably, the vaccine did not induce anti-squarate responses, and memory B cell and vibriocidal responses were blunted in mice receiving the highest dose of vaccine (50 μg). The findings suggest that the OSP:rTTHc conjugate vaccine is a promising candidate for the prevention of cholera, particularly in young children who respond poorly to polysaccharide antigens. The development of an effective cholera conjugate vaccine that induces high-level and long-term immune responses against OSP would be a significant advancement in cholera control strategies.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in Cameroon to investigate the cross-reactivity of immunochromatographic card tests (ICT) for lymphatic filariasis (LF) in areas with contrasting endemicity levels of Loa loa and Mansonella perstans. The study assessed the prevalence and intensity of Wuchereria bancrofti, L. loa, and M. perstans in 42 villages across three regions of the Cameroon rainforest domain. A total of 2190 individuals participated in the study, with 24 individuals testing positive for ICT, with prevalence rates ranging from 0% in the South-west to 2.1% in the North-west. However, no microfilariae (Mf) of W. bancrofti were found in the night blood of any individual with a positive ICT result or clinical lymphoedema. The study found a strong association between ICT positivity and high L. loa Mf intensity, with 21 subjects having more than 8,000 L. loa Mf/ml of blood. Additionally, a strong positive association was observed between the prevalence of L. loa and ICT positivity by area, with a rate of 1% or more of positive ICT results found only in areas with an L. loa Mf prevalence above 15%. In contrast, no association was found between ICT positivity and M. perstans prevalence or Mf density. The results suggest that the main confounding factor for positive ICT test card results is high levels of L. loa, indicating that W. bancrofti may be less prevalent in the Central African region than previously assumed.
The replication of SARS-CoV, a positive-strand RNA virus, occurs in the cytoplasm of infected host cells and is supported by a network of modified endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membranes. Using electron tomography of cryofixed infected cells, researchers have identified a unique reticulovesicular network that integrates convoluted membranes, double-membrane vesicles (DMVs), and "vesicle packets" formed by DMV merger. The convoluted membranes are primarily immunolabeled for viral replicase subunits, while double-stranded RNA, indicative of viral RNA synthesis, is localized to the interior of DMVs. However, no connection between the DMV interior and the cytosol was observed, raising questions about the mechanism of DMV formation and the actual site of SARS-CoV RNA synthesis. The study reveals that DMVs are not isolated vesicles but are part of a larger network of modified ER membranes, which also includes convoluted membranes not previously implicated in viral RNA synthesis. This reticulovesicular network is thought to organize viral replication and potentially hide replicating RNA from antiviral defense mechanisms. The findings provide new insights into the early stages of the coronavirus life cycle and its interactions with host cells. The study's ultrastructural description of the "replication network" will aid in further dissection of the coronavirus life cycle, complementing biochemical studies of the viral enzyme complex.
A recent study in Arabidopsis thaliana has provided direct genetic evidence for the role of suberin in forming an extracellular barrier that affects water relations and mineral nutrition in roots. The enhanced suberin1 (esb1) mutant, characterized by increased root suberin, was found to have reduced daytime transpiration rates and increased water-use efficiency during its vegetative growth period. These changes in suberin and water transport were associated with decreases in the accumulation of Ca, Mn, and Zn and increases in the accumulation of Na, S, K, As, Se, and Mo in the shoot. Grafting experiments confirmed that these phenotypes were the result of elevated root suberin. The study suggests that suberin acts as a barrier to the extracellular transport of both water and mineral ions in the root. Elevated suberin, as found in esb1, reduces both water movement to the shoot and water loss from the root back to the soil. The results provide strong experimental support for the standard model that suberin acts as an extracellular transport barrier limiting apoplastic radial transport of water and solutes. The study also suggests that elevation of root suberin may represent an approach to developing drought-resistant crops with improved water-use efficiency. Furthermore, the findings indicate that suberin plays a critical role in controlling both water and mineral ion uptake and transport to the leaves.
The kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation plays a crucial role in regulating the recovery and reproducibility of the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. A Continuous Time Markov Chain (CTMC) model, based on the biochemistry of rhodopsin activation and deactivation, was developed to investigate the dynamics of rhodopsin deactivation. The model was interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction and was able to reproduce both wild-type (WT) and mutant mouse responses with variable numbers of phosphorylation sites. The model showed that the randomness of the sojourn times in each phosphorylated state contributes to the coefficient of variation (CV) of the response, while the randomness of the number of rhodopsin turnoff steps has a negligible effect. This result contradicts the prevailing view that the larger the number of decay steps of rhodopsin, the more stable the photoresponse is. Instead, the model suggests that rhodopsin shutoff is responsible for the variability of the photoresponse, while the diffusion of second messengers acts as a variability suppressor. The results also indicate that the probability of rhodopsin dissociating without adding another phosphate increases with the number of phosphates present, consistent with in vivo observations. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying the reproducibility of the SPR and highlights the importance of rhodopsin deactivation in regulating photoresponse variability.
The article presents a novel mathematical framework for analyzing stochastic reaction networks in fluctuating environments. The framework allows for the uncoupling of the network from its dynamic environment by incorporating only the environment's effect onto the network into a new model. This is achieved through the marginalization of fluctuating extrinsic components, such as chemical species, to obtain a decoupled model. The corresponding process- and master equations are derived, enabling stochastic simulations to be performed. The authors demonstrate the significance of this approach using several case studies. The uncoupled dynamics provide a novel analytical tool to study how environmental stochasticity is propagated along coupled reaction networks. The total environmental noise is shown to split into two terms: one corresponding to the noise that is suppressed and a second term that quantifies the effective noise sensed by the target network. Additionally, the decoupled process can yield a significant reduction in computational effort in Monte Carlo simulations, especially when the environmental network is costly to simulate. This highlights the role of the provided framework as a general tool to split stochastic biochemical networks into individual parts that are easier to simulate. The framework enables the development of self-contained stochastic models that summarize all system behaviors attainable under all possible realizations of extrinsic fluctuations.
The article presents a novel closed-loop brain-machine interface (BMI) training architecture that enables robust control and adaptation using spike events. The architecture, termed adaptive optimal feedback-controlled (OFC) point process filter (PPF), incorporates an infinite-horizon optimal feedback-control (OFC) model of the brain’s behavior in closed-loop BMI control and a point process model of spikes. The OFC model infers the user’s motor intention during closed-loop decoder adaptation (CLDA), a process termed intention estimation, and is used to design an autonomous and dynamic assisted training technique. The point process model allows for neural processing, control, and decoder adaptation with every spike event and at a faster time-scale than current decoders.

    The authors conducted closed-loop experiments in a non-human primate over tens of days to dissociate the effects of the novel CLDA components. The results show that the OFC intention estimation improved BMI performance compared to current intention estimation techniques. OFC-assisted training allowed the subject to consistently achieve proficient control. Spike-event-based adaptation resulted in faster and more consistent performance convergence compared to batch-based methods and was robust to parameter initialization. The architecture also extended control to tasks beyond those used for CLDA training. These results have significant implications for the development of clinically-viable neuroprosthetics. The proposed architecture provides a unified and general control-theoretic CLDA framework within which intention estimation, assisted training, and adaptation can be performed across diverse BMI setups.
The study investigated the effect of stimulus structure on redundancy in the retina by measuring simultaneous responses from populations of retinal ganglion cells to natural and artificial stimuli with varying degrees of correlation. The results show that the retina maintains a moderate level of output correlation across a wide range of spatio-temporally correlated stimuli, from white noise checkerboards to natural movies. The amount of output correlation varies between stimuli, but the changes are much less than predicted by a non-adapting linear-nonlinear functional model. The retina does not fully decorrelate its input, even for the least correlated white noise checkerboard stimuli, indicating that some correlations are present between pairs of retinal ganglion cell spike trains. The study also found that the gain of retinal ganglion cells responding to correlated stimuli changes with "effective contrast," which is the standard deviation of the input to the nonlinearity in a linear-nonlinear model of ganglion cells. Furthermore, the results suggest that the retina may dynamically adjust its coding strategy to represent the new stimulus class efficiently. The findings are consistent with previous studies that examined pairwise correlations amongst retinal ganglion cell spike trains in specific stimulus conditions. Overall, the study provides new insights into how the retina processes and transforms stimulus correlations, shedding light on the neural mechanisms underlying visual perception.
An integrative multi-network and multi-classifier approach has been developed to predict genetic interactions, specifically synthetic lethal (SL) interactions, in yeast. SL interactions occur when a combination of mutations results in a surprising phenotype and are crucial for understanding functional redundancy, dissecting protein complexes, and exploring the mechanistic underpinnings of common human diseases. However, only a small proportion of gene pairs have been tested for genetic interactions due to the large number of possible combinations. To address this, the authors devised an approach that combines features from various data sources to characterize the relationships between pairs of genes. These features are independent of known SL interactions, unlike previous approaches. A non-parametric multi-classifier system was developed to predict SL interactions, enabling the simultaneous use of multiple classification procedures. Comprehensive experiments demonstrated that the SL-independent features in conjunction with the advanced classification scheme led to improved performance compared to the current state of the art method. The approach was used to derive the first yeast transcription factor genetic interaction network and predict SL interactions between all non-essential gene pairs in yeast. This integrative approach is expected to be more effective and robust in uncovering new genetic interactions in yeast and higher organisms like mouse and human, where very few genetic interactions have been identified.
The BRCA Challenge is a global data-sharing project initiated by the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH) to aggregate and interpret variants in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes. The project aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of genetic variation on cancer risk associated with these genes. The BRCA Exchange, a newly created website (www.brcaexchange.org), integrates over 20,000 variants, three times the number found in the next-largest public database, of which approximately 7,250 have expert classifications. The data set is based on shared information from existing clinical databases, population databases, and linked to a single point of access. The BRCA Challenge has brought together experts from the international Evidence-based Network for the Interpretation of Germline Mutant Alleles (ENIGMA) consortium, clinicians, diagnosticians, researchers, and database providers to advance understanding of BRCA1 and BRCA2 variation. Ongoing work includes data sharing with national centers, development of methods for extracting genetic variation from individual laboratory reports, and engagement with participant communities to understand the clinical significance of genetic variation in BRCA1 and BRCA2. The BRCA Challenge represents an important step in sharing and collaborative annotation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants to advance human health globally. The project has developed an open-access web portal, the BRCA Exchange, to improve data sharing and variant classification in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, ultimately improving clinical care for clinicians, patients, and their families.
Malaria, caused by the apicomplexan parasite Plasmodium, remains a significant threat to human health, resulting in approximately one million deaths annually. To maintain redox regulatory processes and pathogenicity, Plasmodium relies on an adequate redox balance. This study provides the first comprehensive map of redox compartmentation in Plasmodium falciparum by systematically studying the subcellular localization of major antioxidant and redox regulatory proteins. The results show that two plasmodial peroxiredoxins and a putative glyoxalase system are targeted to the apicoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid. Additionally, a complete picture of the compartmentation of thioredoxin- and glutaredoxin-like proteins is obtained. Notably, Plasmodium uses alternative translation initiation (ATI) to achieve differential targeting of the major antioxidant redox-enzymes, glutathione reductase and thioredoxin reductase. This dual localization of proteins affected by ATI is likely to occur in other Apicomplexa and may open new avenues for therapeutic intervention. The study provides a tool to better understand the cellular functions and interactions of the essential redox network in malaria parasites. Furthermore, it demonstrates the existence of ATI in apicomplexan parasites, which is used to translate protein isoforms with differing subcellular localization from a single gene. The findings offer great potential for the development of chemotherapeutic agents that target the redox equilibrium of Plasmodium.
The study investigated the role of non-native electrostatic interactions in the coupled folding and binding of PUMA, an intrinsically disordered protein, with its cellular partner Mcl-1. Using a structure-based coarse-grained model, the authors probed the importance of electrostatic interactions in the early and later stages of the binding process. The model was calibrated with experimental data on helical content and affinity, and shown to be consistent with previously published experimental data on binding rate changes with respect to ionic strength. The results suggest that intramolecular electrostatic interactions have a marginal influence on the unbound states of PUMA. However, intermolecular electrostatic interactions, particularly non-native electrostatic interactions, play a significant role in the formation of the initial encounter complex. The study reveals the binding mechanism in more detail than is possible using experimental data alone, and highlights the importance of non-native electrostatic interactions in describing the binding reactions of intrinsically disordered proteins. The findings also suggest that electrostatic interactions can be used to predict the results of mutational studies. The study used coarse-grained molecular dynamics simulations to describe the mechanism of interactions between PUMA and Mcl-1, and found that the binding process is accelerated by electrostatic interactions. The association rates decreased at higher ionic strengths, where charges are more efficiently screened from each other and electrostatic interactions weakened.
The study investigated the formation and motion of Polycomb (PC) bodies in Drosophila embryos during early development. PC bodies are nuclear structures that contain Polycomb group (PcG) proteins, which maintain the silencing of key developmental genes outside of their expression domains. Using a combination of immunostaining, immuno-FISH, and live imaging of GFP fusion proteins, the researchers found that PC bodies correspond to 3D structural counterparts of linear genomic domains identified in genome-wide studies. During early embryogenesis, PC and Polyhomeotic (PH) proteins progressively accumulate within PC bodies, which form on distinct euchromatin domains containing histone H3 tri-methylated on K27. Time-lapse analysis revealed two types of motion influencing the displacement of PC bodies and chromatin domains: long-range motions that may correspond to the movement of whole chromosome territories, and fast and highly constrained motions within smaller volumes. The fast motion of PC bodies and chromatin domains decreases in late developmental stages, suggesting a possible contribution of chromatin dynamics in the maintenance of stable gene silencing. The study also found that the motion of PC bodies is less sensitive to temperature than chromatin domains in late embryos, suggesting that Polycomb proteins may buffer environmental effects and contribute to the stability of Polycomb-dependent gene silencing during development.
The study used ultra-deep sequencing to investigate genome-wide mtDNA mutation loads in the liver of normally- and prematurely-aging mice. Mice homozygous for an allele expressing a proof-reading-deficient mtDNA polymerase ( mtDNA mutator mice ) had 10-times-higher point mutation loads than their wildtype siblings. The mtDNA mutator mice also had increased levels of a truncated linear mtDNA molecule, resulting in decreased sequence coverage in the deleted region. In contrast, circular mtDNA molecules with large deletions occurred at extremely low frequencies in mtDNA mutator mice and did not drive the premature aging phenotype. Sequence analysis showed that the main proportion of the mutation load in heterozygous mtDNA mutator mice and their wildtype siblings was inherited from their heterozygous mothers, consistent with germline transmission. The study found no increase in levels of point mutations or deletions in wildtype C57Bl/6N mice with increasing age, questioning the causative role of these changes in aging. Additionally, there was no increased frequency of transversion mutations with time in any of the studied genotypes, arguing against oxidative damage as a major cause of mtDNA mutations. The results suggest that most somatic mtDNA mutations occur as replication errors during development and do not result from damage accumulation in adult life.
A new type of Na+-driven ATP synthase membrane rotor has been identified in the anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum. This enzyme uses glutamate decarboxylation to generate a transmembrane gradient of Na+, which is directly coupled to ATP synthesis. The F1Fo-ATP synthase from F. nucleatum contains a novel Na+ recognition motif, shared by other human pathogens. Molecular modeling and free-energy simulations of the rotary element of the enzyme, the c-ring, indicate Na+ specificity in physiological settings. Activity measurements showed Na+ stimulation of the enzyme, either membrane-embedded or isolated, and ATP synthesis was sensitive to the Na+ ionophore monensin. The Na+ ion has a protective effect against inhibitors targeting the ion-binding sites, both in the complete ATP synthase and the isolated c-ring. Two identical crystal structures of the c11 ring were solved by X-ray crystallography at 2. 2 and 2. 6 Å resolution, at pH 5. 3 and 8. 7, respectively. Na+ ions occupy all binding sites, each coordinated by four amino acids and a water molecule. The structure reveals a new mode of ion coupling in ATP synthases and provides a basis for drug-design efforts against this opportunistic pathogen. The c-ring features two glutamate residues in each of its 11 ion-binding sites, instead of a single carboxylate side-chain as is typical. This motif implies that a proton is concurrently bound to all sites, although Na+ alone drives the rotary mechanism.
The study investigated the relationship between T cell receptor (TCR) and major histocompatibility complex (pMHC) interactions and T cell responses in vivo. TCR recognition of foreign peptides bound to pMHC molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) initiates adaptive cellular immunity. In vitro studies have shown that high-affinity binding and long-lived interactions between TCRs and pMHC correlate with high-potency T cell activation. However, the influence of TCR/pMHC interaction parameters on T cell responses in vivo is not well understood. The study tracked CD4+ T cell activation, effector, and memory responses to immunization with peptides exhibiting a range of TCR/pMHC half-lives and in vitro T cell activation potencies. Contrary to predictions from in vitro studies, the study found that optimal in vivo T cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate TCR/pMHC half-lives. The study observed diminished in vivo responses to the ligand with the longest TCR/pMHC half-life, associated with attenuation of intracellular signaling, expansion, and function over a broad range of time points. These results reveal a level of control over T cell activation in vivo not recapitulated in in vitro assays and highlight the importance of considering in vivo efficacy of TCR ligands in vaccine design. The study suggests that vaccination strategies aiming to elicit maximum-avidity TCR recognition with engineered peptide ligands may warrant reconsideration.
The genome of Nectria haematococca, a member of the Fusarium solani species complex, has been extensively studied. This species is known for its diverse biological properties, including the ability to cause disease in over 100 plant genera and opportunistic infections in humans. The genome of N. haematococca mating population VI (MPVI) consists of 17 chromosomes, ranging in size from 530 kb to 6.52 Mb, with a total physical size of 54.43 Mb. This genome is among the largest reported for ascomycetes, with 15,707 predicted genes. Two classes of genes have contributed to gene expansion in N. haematococca MPVI: specific genes not found in other fungi, including its closest sequenced relative, Fusarium graminearum, and genes present in multiple copies in N. haematococca MPVI but as single copies in other fungi. Some of these additional genes appear to have resulted from gene duplication events, while others may have been acquired through horizontal gene transfer. Supernumerary chromosomes 14, 15, and 17 were confirmed to be absent in some isolates and lacked chromosome-specific sequences found on their ends. These supernumerary chromosomes contain more repeat sequences, are enriched in unique and duplicated genes, and have a lower G+C content compared to other chromosomes. The gene expansion and large genome size of N. haematococca MPVI are consistent with its diverse range of habitats, and the presence of unique genes on supernumerary chromosomes may account for individual isolates having different environmental niches.
To elucidate the cellular mechanisms of alpha herpesvirus egress, a live-cell fluorescence microscopy method was developed to visualize the final transport and exocytosis of pseudorabies virus ( PRV ) particles in non-polarized epithelial cells. The method utilized total internal reflection fluorescence ( TIRF ) microscopy to selectively image fluorescent virus particles near the plasma membrane and a virus-encoded pH-sensitive probe to visualize the precise moment and location of particle exocytosis. Single-particle tracking and mean squared displacement analysis revealed that individual virus particles travel to the plasma membrane inside small, acidified secretory vesicles. Rab GTPases, specifically Rab6a, Rab8a, and Rab11a, were found to be present on the virus secretory vesicle and play a key role in the plasma membrane-directed secretory pathway. The vesicles underwent fast, directional transport directly to the site of exocytosis, which was most frequently near patches of LL5β, a complex that anchors microtubules to the plasma membrane. After exocytosis, particles remained tightly confined on the outer cell surface. The study proposes an integrated model that links together the intracellular transport pathways and exocytosis mechanisms that mediate alpha herpesvirus egress. The findings contradict previous studies and provide new insights into the dynamics and molecular mechanisms of viral egress.
This study investigated the impact of Enterobius vermicularis infection and mebendazole treatment on intestinal microbiota and host immune response in 109 primary school children. The results showed that pinworm infection was associated with increased intestinal bacterial diversity, which peaked after administration of mebendazole. At the phylum level, pinworm infection and mebendazole treatment were linked to a decreased relative abundance of Fusobacteria and an increased proportion of Actinobacteria. Specifically, the relative abundance of the probiotic Bifidobacterium increased after enterobiasis and mebendazole treatment. Intestinal secretory IgA ( SIgA ) levels were lower in the pinworm-infected group, but elevated in half of the mebendazole-treated group. Notably, a higher proportion of pre-treatment Salmonella spp. was associated with a non-increase in SIgA after mebendazole deworming treatment. These findings suggest that childhood exposure to pinworm and mebendazole is associated with increased bacterial diversity, an increased abundance of Actinobacteria including the probiotic Bifidobacterium, and a decreased proportion of Fusobacteria. The gut SIgA level was lower in the pinworm-infected group, but increased in half of the individuals after mebendazole deworming treatment. The study highlights the complex interactions between pinworm infection, intestinal microbiota, and host immune responses, and underscores the need for further research to elucidate the causal relationships between these factors.
A genome-wide association analysis was conducted to investigate the genetics of root length in Arabidopsis thaliana. The study found that the genomic narrow-sense heritability for root length in the examined population was statistically zero, indicating a low amount of additive genetic variance that could be captured by the genome-wide genotypes. As a result, no associations to root length could be found using standard additive-model-based genome-wide association ( GWA ) approaches. However, the broad-sense heritability for root length was significantly larger and primarily due to epistasis. An epistatic GWA analysis was performed to map loci contributing to the epistatic genetic variance, revealing four interacting pairs of loci involving seven chromosomal loci that passed a standard multiple-testing corrected significance threshold. The genotype-phenotype maps for these pairs showed epistasis that cancelled out the additive genetic variance, explaining why these loci were not detected in the additive GWA analysis. The study also estimated the false-positive risk using a new statistical approach, suggesting that half of the associated pairs were true positive associations. Experimental evaluation of candidate genes within the seven associated loci identified functional candidate genes that affected root development in four loci that were part of three of the pairs. The results highlight the importance of accounting for epistatic interactions in GWA analyses to detect contributing loci for complex traits.
The study analyzed 30,506 human mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) sequences to investigate the relationship between background mtDNA haplogroups and the occurrence and severity of disease-causing mtDNA mutations. The results showed that the mean pathogenicity score for known disease-causing mutations was significantly different between mtDNA macro-haplogroups. Several mutations were observed across all haplogroup backgrounds, while others were only observed on specific clades. The study found that disease-causing mutations were more frequent on young sequences and that genomes with two or more disease-causing mutations were more common than expected by chance. These findings suggest that the mtDNA background plays a role in recurrent mutation events that have been purified through natural selection in older populations. The study also found that the frequency of disease-causing mutations was lower in macro-haplogroup N sequences, indicating that the mtDNA sequence background influences the likelihood of acquiring or retaining a disease-causing mutation. The analysis of 57 disease-causing mutations on major haplogroups revealed that 10 (29.4%) showed statistical evidence of haplogroup clustering, suggesting that some disease-causing mutations may be rare sub-haplogroup markers rather than directly pathogenic. Overall, the study provides evidence that background mtDNA haplogroups are associated with the occurrence and severity of disease-causing mtDNA mutations.
The article presents a computational phase field model of collective cell motility that includes the mechanics of cell shape and a minimal chemical model for contact inhibition of locomotion (CIL). The model is used to study the interactions between cells migrating on micropatterned substrates, which restrict cell migration to linear, quasi-one-dimensional paths. The model is able to reproduce all possible outcomes of two-cell collisions, including cells reversing direction, sticking to each other, or walking past each other. The results show that a subtle balance between internal cell polarization, CIL, and cell-cell adhesion governs the collision outcome. The model identifies the parameters that control transitions between the different cases, including cell-cell adhesion, propulsion strength, and the rates of CIL. These parameters suggest hypotheses for why different cell types have different collision behavior and the effect of interventions that modulate collision outcomes. To reproduce the heterogeneity in cell-cell collision outcomes observed experimentally in neural crest cells, the model must either carefully tune its parameters or assume significant cell-to-cell variation in key parameters like cell-cell adhesion. The study highlights the importance of complementing minimal models of cells as self-propelled particles with increasingly detailed models for cell shape and mechanics. The results show that the coupling of detailed cell shape dynamics with biochemistry can lead to unintuitive behaviors, such as nonmonotonic effects of adhesion. The model can reproduce the four distinct phenotypes of cell-cell collisions observed in neural crest cells and healthy and metastatic epithelial cells.
The dissociation mechanism of thioredoxin (Trx) mixed disulfide complexes has been a topic of debate for over twenty years. To elucidate this process, the complex between Trx and its endogenous substrate, arsenate reductase (ArsC), was used as a model system. Theoretical reactivity analysis, molecular dynamics simulations, and biochemical complex formation experiments with Cys-mutants were employed to study Trx mixed disulfide dissociation. The results showed that conformational changes around the intermediate disulfide bring Cys32Trx in contact with Cys29Trx, activating it for nucleophilic attack. Cys32Trx was found to be more reactive than Cys82ArsC and directed its nucleophilic attack on the more susceptible Cys29Trx rather than Cys89ArsC. This study provides new insights into the universal thiol/disulfide exchange reaction mechanism, resulting in reduced substrate and oxidized Trx. The findings suggest that the nucleophilic attack of Cys32Trx on Cys29Trx is the favored reaction in the dissociation of the Trx-ArsC mixed disulfide complex. This mechanism is supported by the stabilization of Cys29Trx as a thiolate through hydrogen bonds in the active site of reduced Trx. The results have implications for understanding the regioselectivity of the nucleophilic attack of Cys29Trx on the Cys82ArsC-Cys89ArsC disulfide.
This study investigated how people use social information to learn about their own preferences, specifically in the context of inter-temporal preferences. The researchers proposed that personal tastes are not fixed personality characteristics, but rather uncertain beliefs that can be updated based on evidence, such as the preferences of others. They developed a taste-uncertainty (KU) model, which assumes that individuals maintain and update a distribution over their own taste and sample from it to make choices. The study tested this model in a large community study of 14-24 year olds, examining their discounting preferences, including decision variability, before and after observing another person's choices. The results provided evidence for taste uncertainty and Bayesian taste updating. Participants displayed decision variability that was better accounted for by a random-taste than by a response-noise model, and apparent taste shifts were well described by a Bayesian model taking into account taste uncertainty and the relevance of social information. The findings suggest that uncertainty about one's own preferences, reflected in behavioral variability in the absence of social influence, is an important basis for a subsequent preference shift. The study's results have implications for neuroscientific, clinical, and developmental research. The KU model provided a good fit to the data, and the dependence of preference-shift on choice variability and the decrease in taste uncertainty with age suggest that choice variability substantially reflects uncertain taste rather than just 'trembling hand' or taste-independent response noise.
In budding yeast, the process of filamentous growth, a complex differentiation response, is regulated by multiple pathways. A novel screening approach called secretion profiling was used to measure the release of the extracellular domain of Msb2p, the signaling mucin that functions at the head of the filamentous growth (FG) MAPK pathway. This approach revealed that many pathways that regulate filamentous growth, including RAS, RIM101, OPI1, and RTG, are also required for FG pathway activation. The regulation of these pathways sensitized the FG pathway to multiple stimuli and synchronized it with the global signaling network. Several regulators were found to be necessary for MSB2 expression, identifying the MSB2 promoter as a target "hub" where multiple signals converge. The histone deacetylase Rpd3p(L) was found to positively regulate FG pathway activity and filamentous growth by controlling accessibility to the MSB2 promoter. These findings provide the first glimpse of a global regulatory hierarchy among the pathways that control filamentous growth. The study suggests that systems-level integration of signaling circuitry coordinates other regulatory networks that control complex behaviors. The connections between the RIM101, OPI1, and RTG pathways to FG pathway regulation are entirely novel, and the RAS pathway and several other pathways converge on the promoter of the key upstream regulator MSB2 of the FG pathway. This suggests a systems-level coordination between the pathways that regulate filamentous growth.
The study investigated the role of gene expression changes in the evolution of divergent morphologies in filamentous fungi, specifically in the Sordariomycetes. The researchers cultured five species in a common garden environment and profiled genome-wide gene expression at five developmental stages. By reconstructing ancestral gene expression phenotypes, they identified genes with the largest evolved increases in expression across development. Knockout experiments in two divergent species showed altered fruiting body development in the species with increased expression. This approach proved more efficient than other gene deletion studies targeting whole genomes or gene families. The study also refined Bayesian networks of genes underlying fruiting body development, a poorly understood process in multicellular development. The results suggest that few developmental genes retain common phenotypes or stages of development, but numerous genes retain some function within the larger fruiting body developmental process. The study provides insights into the common and divergent developmental sources of homologous phenotypes and how novelty arises despite the constraints of extant gene interaction networks. By combining gene expression measurements with knockout phenotypes, the researchers were able to build a more rigorous understanding of the relationships among genes important to fruiting body development and how those relationships evolved. Estimation of gene expression phenotypes in ancestral lineages provides a means of identifying putative changes in gene expression that may be key to morphological and adaptive innovation.
The study investigated the use of square wave electroporation to introduce transgenes and other macromolecules into the eggs of Schistosoma mansoni, a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis. The researchers found that electroporation facilitated the introduction of reporter transgenes and virions into the eggs, resulting in higher transduction efficiency compared to soaking the eggs in the macromolecules alone. The study demonstrated that electroporation enabled the delivery of fluorescent short-interference RNA ( siRNA ), messenger RNA ( mRNA ) encoding firefly luciferase, and pseudotyped Moloney murine leukemia virus ( MLV ) virions into the eggs. The results showed that electroporation increased the copy number of proviral transgenes in miracidia hatched from virion-exposed eggs by 2-3 times compared to soaking alone. Additionally, the study found that electroporation of capped mRNA encoding luciferase resulted in detectable luciferase activity in eggs three hours after electroporation, whereas soaking alone did not. The findings suggest that square wave electroporation is a useful tool for introducing transgenes into the schistosome egg, which is an attractive target for germ line transgenesis due to the high ratio of germ to somatic cells. The study highlights the potential of targeting the schistosome egg for transgenesis, which could lead to the development of new strategies for controlling schistosomiasis.
A novel approach called Perturbation-based Markovian Transmission (PMT) model has been developed to study the dynamic properties of large macromolecular assemblies. This model involves probing the assembly with an initial perturbation and assuming that perturbations are transmitted through a Markovian process through the connected network defined by atomic and residue contacts. The PMT model enables the simultaneous monitoring of time-dependent responses of all residues from the moment of perturbation until equilibrium is reached, providing rich information on the dynamic behavior of the assembly. The model can also be modified to study signal transmission pathways by applying initial perturbation to restricted local regions, such as binding surfaces. This approach is particularly effective for very large macromolecular assemblies, requiring relatively small computational time. The PMT model was applied to the GroEL-GroES chaperone system, a large macromolecular assembly, and the results showed an accuracy of 71-84% when compared to independent experimental studies. The model identified pivot residues important for macromolecular movement, messenger residues key to signal mediation, and anchor residues crucial for binding interactions. The PMT model is a general approach that can be applied to other large macromolecular machineries, such as the virus capsid and ribosomal complex.
Caenorhabditis elegans N-glycan Core β-galactoside Confers Sensitivity towards Nematotoxic Fungal Galectin CGL2
    Caenorhabditis elegans nematodes fed with the mushroom galectin Coprinopsis cinerea CGL2 exhibited inhibited development, reproduction, and ultimately death. The nematotoxicity of CGL2 was dependent on its interaction with a fucose-containing glycoconjugate. A screen for CGL2-resistant worm mutants identified the glycoconjugate as a Galβ1,4Fucα1,6 modification of C. elegans N-glycan cores. Analysis of N-glycan structures in wild-type and CGL2-resistant nematodes confirmed this finding and led to the identification of a novel putative glycosyltransferase required for the biosynthesis of this glycoepitope. The X-ray crystal structure of a complex between CGL2 and the Galβ1,4Fucα1,6GlcNAc trisaccharide at 1.5 Å resolution revealed the biophysical basis for this interaction. The results suggest that fungal galectins play a role in the defense of fungi against predators by binding to specific glycoconjugates of these organisms. The identified ligand of CGL2 in C. elegans, Galβ1,4Fucα1,6 modification of the proximal GlcNAc of N-glycan cores, was originally discovered as a feature of octopus and squid rhodopsin and keyhole limpet hemocyanin. The physiological significance of this N-glycan modification is unknown, and the identification of a novel putative glycosyltransferase required for this modification may shed light on its distribution and function.
The existence of long-lived reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells is a major barrier to curing HIV. However, the effect of these reservoirs on the evolutionary dynamics of the virus has received little attention. This study presents a within-host quasispecies model that incorporates a long-lived reservoir and nests it into an epidemiological model of HIV dynamics. The results show that the presence of a latent reservoir can severely delay evolutionary dynamics within a single host, with longer delays associated with larger relative reservoir sizes and/or homeostatic proliferation of cells within the reservoir. This delay can fundamentally change the dynamics of the virus at the epidemiological scale. The study finds that the delay in within-host evolutionary dynamics can be sufficient for the virus to evolve intermediate viral loads consistent with maximizing transmission, rather than the very high viral loads predicted by previous models. This effect can be further enhanced if viruses similar to those that initiate infection are preferentially transmitted. The results depend strongly on within-host characteristics, such as the relative reservoir size, and the evolution of intermediate viral loads is observed only when the within-host dynamics are sufficiently delayed. The study concludes that the latent reservoir has important roles in both within- and between-host viral evolution.
This study investigated the mechanisms by which coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3) evades the host T cell response. Using transgenic CD4+ and CD8+ T cells as sensors, the researchers evaluated antigen presentation by CVB3 in vitro and in vivo. The results show that CVB3 almost completely inhibits antigen presentation via the MHC class I pathway, thereby evading CD8+ T cell immunity. In contrast, the presentation of CVB3-encoded MHC class II epitopes is relatively unencumbered, and CVB3 induces in vivo CD4+ T cell responses that are phenotypically normal. The CD4+ T cells display an effector phenotype, mature into multi-functional CVB3-specific memory cells, and expand dramatically following challenge infection. These findings have implications for the efficiency of antigen cross-presentation during coxsackievirus infection. The study used recombinant CVB3 encoding well-characterized CD8+ and/or CD4+ T cell epitopes from lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) to assess antigen presentation in vitro and in vivo. The results demonstrate that CVB3 profoundly inhibits the MHC class I antigen presentation pathway, providing a plausible explanation for the weakness of the primary CD8+ T cell response. In contrast, MHC class II presentation is relatively uninterrupted, and CVB3 induces both primary and memory CD4+ T cell responses.
A Phase 2 randomised controlled double-blind trial was conducted to investigate the efficacy of high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone (MP) in combination with oral prednisolone versus oral prednisolone alone in individuals with leprosy Type 1 reactions (T1Rs) and/or nerve function impairment (NFI). Forty-two participants were randomised to receive either three days of high-dose intravenous MP (1g) followed by oral prednisolone or oral prednisolone alone. The results showed no significant differences in the rate of adverse events or clinical improvement between the two groups. However, individuals treated with MP were less likely to experience deterioration in sensory function between day 29 and day 113 of the study compared to those treated with prednisolone alone. The study also found that 50% of participants required additional prednisolone despite treatment with 16 weeks of corticosteroids. The findings suggest that prolonged courses of corticosteroids may be necessary to treat T1Rs and NFI, and highlight the need to investigate risk factors for recurrence during and after corticosteroid treatment. The study did not demonstrate a larger therapeutic effect of MP compared to prednisolone alone on symptoms and signs of leprosy T1Rs and NFI.
The study investigated the effects of regulatory CD4+CD25highFoxP3+ T cells (Treg) on CD8+ T cell responses in chronic HIV infection. In contrast to Treg from HIV-negative controls, Treg from HIV-infected patients (Treg/HIV+) did not significantly inhibit polyclonal autologous CD8+ T cell function, suggesting a defect in the suppressive capacity of Treg/HIV+ or a lack of sensitivity of effector T cells in HIV infection. However, Treg/HIV+ inhibited the IFN-γ expression of autologous CD8+ T cells stimulated with recall CMV/EBV/Flu (CEF) antigens, but not HIV-Gag-specific CD8+ T cells. In cross-over cultures, Treg/HIV- inhibited the differentiation of either CEF- or Gag-specific CD8+ T cells from HIV-infected patients. The expression of PD-1 and PD-L1 was higher on Gag-specific CD8+ T cells compared to CEF-specific CD8+ T cells, and the expression of these markers did not change significantly after Treg depletion or co-culture with Treg/HIV-, unlike on CEF-specific CD8+ T cells. The results suggest that Treg/HIV+ have a defect in modulating both the differentiation and the expression of PD-1/PD-L1 molecules on HIV-specific CD8 T cells, which might contribute to the exhaustion of HIV-specific T cell responses. The study also found that HIV-specific CD8+ T cells were less sensitive to the suppressive effects of Treg compared to other recall antigen-specific CD8+ T cells.
The present study evaluated the potential of Wuchereria bancrofti glutathione-S-transferase (GST) as a vaccine candidate against lymphatic filariasis. The GST gene was cloned from the third-stage larval cDNA library of W. bancrofti and recombinant GST (rWbGST) was expressed and purified. Serum samples from individuals living in an endemic area were analyzed for their reactivity with rWbGST, revealing significant levels of anti-WbGST IgG antibodies in sera from endemic normal individuals compared to those who were microfilaraemic or showed symptoms of clinical pathology. Isotype analysis showed a predominance of IgG1 and IgG3 antibodies in endemic normal individuals. Functional analysis demonstrated that the rWbGST protein retained enzymatic activity and the antibodies in endemic normal sera could inhibit this activity. Similar results were obtained with anti-rWbGST antibodies raised in mice. Brugia malayi GST and WbGST showed significant sequence similarity, and vaccination studies in a jird model showed that approximately 61% protection could be achieved against a B. malayi L3 challenge infection in jirds immunized with rWbGST. These findings suggest that rWbGST is a potential vaccine candidate against lymphatic filariasis. The study also showed that the WbGST protein retained the enzymatic activity of GST, which appears to be critical for the survival of the parasite in the host. These results support the potential of WbGST as a vaccine candidate against lymphatic filariasis.
Title: No Unexpected CRISPR-Cas9 Off-Target Activity Revealed by Trio Sequencing of Gene-Edited Mice
    Abstract: CRISPR-Cas9 technologies have transformed genome-editing of experimental organisms and have immense therapeutic potential. Despite significant advances in our understanding of the CRISPR-Cas9 system, concerns remain over the potential for off-target effects. Recent studies have addressed these concerns using whole-genome sequencing ( WGS ) of gene-edited embryos or animals to search for de novo mutations ( DNMs ), which may represent candidate changes introduced by poor editing fidelity. Critically, these studies used strain-matched, but not pedigree-matched controls and thus were unable to reliably distinguish generational or colony-related differences from true DNMs. Here we used a trio design and whole genome sequenced 8 parents and 19 embryos, where 10 of the embryos were mutagenised with well-characterised gRNAs targeting the coat colour Tyrosinase ( Tyr ) locus. Detailed analyses of these whole genome data allowed us to conclude that if CRISPR mutagenesis were causing SNV or indel off-target mutations in treated embryos, then the number of these mutations is not statistically distinguishable from the background rate of DNMs occurring due to other processes. This work should support further efforts to develop CRISPR-Cas9 as a therapeutic tool. e. the parents of sequenced offspring were themselves not sequenced ) and thus were unable to reliably distinguish generational or colony-related differences from true DNMs. Here we assessed the impact of colony variation on the accuracy of detection of off-target CRISPR editing events. The regulation of stomatal aperture in plants is crucial for photosynthesis, water use efficiency, and agricultural crop yields. Blue light is one of the environmental signals that regulate stomatal aperture, and the signal transduction cascades linking light perception to stomatal opening response are still largely unknown. This study identifies two new players, Hypersensitive to Red and Blue 1 (HRB1) and Protein Phosphatase 7 (PP7), in the control of stomatal aperture. Mutations in either HRB1 or PP7 lead to misregulation of stomatal aperture and reduced water loss under blue light. Both HRB1 and PP7 are expressed in guard cells in response to light-to-dark or dark-to-light transitions. HRB1 interacts with PP7 through its N-terminal ZZ-type zinc finger motif and requires a functional PP7 for its stomatal opening response. HRB1 is phosphorylated in vivo, and PP7 can dephosphorylate HRB1. In the dark, HRB1 is mostly dephosphorylated in a protein complex of 193 kDa, and blue light increases the complex size to 285 kDa. In the pp7 mutant, this size shift is impaired, and HRB1 is predominantly phosphorylated. The study proposes that modification of HRB1 by PP7 under blue light is essential to acquire a proper conformation or to bring in new components for the assembly of a functional HRB1 protein complex. These findings may provide strategies for plants to enjoy the advantages of both constitutive and ABA-induced protection under water-limiting conditions.
The Mediator subunit MDT-15 plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression in response to ingested materials in Caenorhabditis elegans. MDT-15 is a component of the Mediator complex, a multisubunit complex that interacts with transcriptional regulatory factors to modulate gene expression.
