In C. elegans, MDT-15 has been shown to integrate the regulatory actions of the sterol response element binding protein SBP-1 and the nuclear hormone receptor NHR-49 on fatty acid metabolism. This study demonstrates that MDT-15 has a broader spectrum of activities and is involved in integrating metabolic responses to ingested materials, including xenobiotics and heavy metals. Depletion of MDT-15 or mutation of the mdt-15 gene abrogated the induction of specific detoxification genes in response to certain toxins, rendering the animals hypersensitive to toxin exposure. MDT-15 selectively affects stress responses related to ingestion, but not other stress responses such as thermotolerance. The study suggests that MDT-15 integrates several transcriptional regulatory pathways to monitor the availability and quality of ingested materials, including nutrients and xenobiotic compounds. The findings propose a model in which MDT-15 coordinates systemic adaptation to ingestion-related stress, ensuring maintenance of health and longevity. MDT-15 has been shown to interact with at least two metabolic regulatory factors, NHR-49 and SBP-1, and its functional defects did not abrogate other stress responses. The study also suggests that MDT-15 may integrate the transcriptional response to environmental stressors such as xenobiotics and heavy metals by employing a different set of regulatory factors.
The article presents a topological paradigm for hippocampal spatial map formation based on persistent homology theory in algebraic topology. The authors hypothesize that the temporal pattern of neuronal firing, particularly co-firing, is key to decoding spatial information and that a map encoded by co-firing will be based on connectivity and adjacency, i. e., it will be a topological map. To test this hypothesis, a simple model of hippocampal activity was simulated using computer simulations of rat trajectories in three topologically and geometrically distinct test environments. The simulations varied three parameters : firing rate, place field size, and number of neurons. A computational algorithm based on persistent homology theory was used to analyze the patterns of neuronal co-firing. The results show that the patterns of neuronal co-firing can convey topological information about the environment in a biologically realistic length of time. The simulations also reveal a “learning region” that highlights the interplay between the parameters in combining to produce hippocampal states that are more or less adept at map formation. The authors propose that this learning region provides a theoretical lens through which to view conditions that impair spatial learning by altering place cell firing rates or spatial specificity. The study suggests that a topological connectivity map can be effectively and reliably derived from neuronal spiking patterns using computational tools from algebraic topology.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) production involves the assembly of virions on or near lipid droplets, envelopment at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in association with components of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis, and egress via the secretory pathway. However, the cellular requirements for and mechanistic understanding of HCV secretion are incomplete. An RNA interference (RNAi) analysis of host factors for infectious HCV secretion and live cell imaging of HCV core trafficking were used to gain a detailed understanding of HCV egress. The RNAi studies identified multiple components of the secretory pathway, including ER to Golgi trafficking, lipid and protein kinases that regulate budding from the trans-Golgi network (TGN), VAMP1 vesicles and adaptor proteins, and the recycling endosome. The results support a model wherein HCV is infectious upon envelopment at the ER and exits the cell via the secretory pathway. Live cell imaging of HCV core trafficking using an infectious HCV with a tetracysteine (TC) tag insertion in the core protein (TC-core) revealed that TC-core traffics to the cell periphery along microtubules and localizes to the Golgi and recycling endosome. The majority of dynamic core traffics in association with apolipoprotein E (ApoE) and VAMP1 vesicles. This study identifies many new host cofactors of HCV egress and presents dynamic studies of HCV core trafficking in infected cells. The results suggest that HCV virions egress through the secretory pathway from the TGN to recycling endosomes to the plasma membrane.
This study investigated the role of the imprinted gene Grb10 in tumorigenesis, particularly in the context of the Neurofibromatosis I (NF1) tumor suppressor gene. NF1 heterozygous mice were mutagenized to model radiotherapy-associated second malignant neoplasms, and expression analysis of tumor cell lines identified Grb10 as widely absent. Polymorphism analysis revealed that the expressed allele of Grb10 was commonly lost in diverse Nf1 mutant tumors. Functional studies showed that restoring Grb10 in Nf1 mutant tumors decreased proliferation, colony formation, and downregulated Ras signaling. Conversely, Grb10 silencing in untransformed mouse embryo fibroblasts increased cell proliferation and Ras-GTP levels. Expression of a constitutively activated MEK rescued tumor cells from Grb10-mediated reduction in colony formation. In tumors, Grb10 loss independently promoted Ras pathway hyperactivation, leading to hyperproliferation, an early feature of tumor development. These findings demonstrate a novel role for an imprinted gene in tumorigenesis and suggest that mutations in imprinted genes should be considered with regard to parental origin. The study also identified Grb10 as a negative regulator of Ras signaling, contributing to Ras dysregulation in Nf1-mediated tumorigenesis. The results have implications for understanding the types of tumors that can arise after Grb10 loss and suggest that Grb10 loss may have tumor-promoting consequences in other oncogenic contexts.
The study investigated the neural mechanisms of Pavlovian fear conditioning in humans by examining autonomic nervous system (ANS) responses to conditioned stimuli. Pavlovian fear conditioning is an aversive learning process where a neutral stimulus becomes associated with an aversive event, leading to the prediction of threat from environmental cues. However, the computational understanding of this process is fragmented, with different models giving rise to opposing predictions for the trial-by-trial dynamics of learning. To address this, the study employed a statistical framework for psychophysiological modeling to obtain precise, trial-by-trial, single-subject estimates of ANS responses. The study considered previously proposed non-probabilistic models, a simple probabilistic model, and non-learning models, as well as different observation functions to link learning models with ANS activity. The results showed that a probabilistic learning model best explained ANS responses, with skin conductance (SCR) and pupil size responses (PSR) reflecting different quantities of the same model. SCR tracked a mixture of expected outcome and uncertainty, while PSR tracked expected outcome alone. The study provides systematic evidence that the formation and maintenance of Pavlovian threat predictions in humans may rely on probabilistic inference and includes estimation of uncertainty. This could inform theories of neural implementation of aversive learning.
In the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans, a new suppressor of the Cdc7p/SepH kinase, PomA, has been identified as a negative regulator of septation and conidiation. The septation initiation network ( SIN ), composed of a conserved SepH kinase cascade, plays a crucial role in fungal cytokinesis and asexual reproduction. The mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) pathway, which depends on successive signaling cascade phosphorylation to sense and respond to stress and environmental factors, is also involved in septation and conidiation. PomA, a putative protein kinase, localizes to the spindle pole body-like pattern and the tips of hyphal cells, and its deletion cures defects of septation and conidiation in the sepH1 mutant. Overexpression of PomA abolishes septation and conidiation. SepH positively regulates the phosphorylation of MAPK-HogA, while PomA reversely affects this process. The phosphorylation of HogA induced by osmotic stress bypasses the requirement of SepH to fulfill septation and conidiation. The findings demonstrate that crosstalk exists between the SIN and MAPK pathways, and PomA and SepH indirectly regulate HogA phosphorylation through affecting HogA-P upstream kinases. The study suggests that SepH and PomA coordinately regulate the phosphorylation of HogA, playing a key role in septation and conidiation. The results also imply that the phosphorylated activation of MAPK may play important roles in septation and conidiation.
The present study investigated the association between the presence of Leishmania RNA virus 1 (LRV1) and the mucosal manifestations of Tegumentary Leishmaniasis (TL) in 156 patients from Rondonia, Brazil. The patients were diagnosed with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL), mucosal leishmaniasis (ML), concomitant CL and ML, disseminated leishmaniasis (DL), and diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis (DCL) based on clinical and molecular diagnoses. The study found that LRV1 was detected in 71.1% of mucosal lesions and 36.7% of cutaneous lesions. The presence of LRV1 was significantly associated with the occurrence of mucosal leishmaniasis, with a ratio of 2.93 (95% CI 1.57-5.46, p < 0.001). The study also identified five Leishmania species: Leishmania (Viannia) braziliensis, Leishmania (V.) guyanensis, Leishmania (V.) lainsoni, Leishmania (Leishmania) amazonensis, and Leishmania (V.) shawi. The most frequent species was L. braziliensis, detected in 121 cases (77.6%). LRV1 was detected in L. braziliensis, L. guyanensis, L. amazonensis, L. lainsoni, and inconclusive samples. The study suggests that LRV1 is an important factor associated with the severity of mucosal leishmaniasis, but it is not the only factor contributing to the disease outcome. The findings provide new evidence on the relationship between LRV1 and the different species of Leishmania with the clinical manifestations of TL.
Type I interferon (IFN-I) plays a crucial role in protecting against pneumococcal invasive disease by inhibiting the transmigration of bacteria from the lung to the bloodstream. Mice lacking the type I interferon receptor (Ifnar1−/−) or treated with a neutralizing antibody against the type I interferon receptor exhibited enhanced development of bacteremia following intranasal pneumococcal infection, while maintaining comparable bacterial numbers in the lung. In contrast, treatment of mice with IFNβ or IFN-I-inducing synthetic double-stranded RNA (poly(I:C)) dramatically reduced the development of bacteremia following intranasal infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae. IFNβ treatment led to upregulation of tight junction proteins and downregulation of the pneumococcal uptake receptor, platelet activating factor receptor (PAF receptor). IFN-I reduced pneumococcal cell invasion and transmigration across epithelial and endothelial layers, and Ifnar1−/− mice showed overall enhanced lung permeability. These findings identify IFN-I as an important component of the host immune defense that regulates two mechanisms involved in pneumococcal invasion: PAF receptor-mediated transcytosis and tight junction-dependent pericellular migration. Ultimately, IFN-I limits the progression from a site-restricted lung infection to invasive, lethal disease by controlling the transition of pneumococci from the lung into the bloodstream.
The study presents a multi-layer neural network that utilizes rewarded and non-rewarded spike time-dependent plasticity (STDP) to learn a complex foraging task. The network consists of three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer, and an output layer. The hidden layer employs non-rewarded STDP, allowing neurons to respond to specific combinations of inputs and perform basic pattern classification. The output layer, which implements rewarded STDP, enables the network to learn discrimination between rewarding and punishing patterns without labeled training data. Synaptic noise facilitates trial-and-error learning, enabling the network to identify effective goal-oriented strategies. The study demonstrates that the combination of rewarded and non-rewarded STDP, along with homeostatic regulation mechanisms such as heterosynaptic plasticity, gain control, output balancing, and activity normalization, is sufficient to solve a complex foraging task involving pattern classification and decision-making. The results show that the multi-layered network outperforms previous models with a single plastic layer based on rewarded STDP. The study highlights the advantages of combining different plasticity mechanisms to achieve high learning performance in discrimination and decision-making tasks. The network's ability to learn and solve complex tasks without labeled training data suggests potential applications in artificial intelligence and machine learning. The study's findings provide insights into the properties of spiking neuronal networks with STDP that are sufficient to solve complex tasks.
The ETS transcription factor ELF5 has been identified as a key driver of lung metastasis in luminal breast cancer through the recruitment of Gr1+ CD11b+ myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs). In the mouse mammary tumor virus-Polyoma Middle T (MMTV-PyMT) model of luminal breast cancer, induction of ELF5 levels increased leukocyte infiltration, angiogenesis, and blood vessel permeability in primary tumors, leading to a significant increase in the size and number of lung metastases. MDSCs, a group of immature neutrophils, were found to be recruited to the tumor in response to ELF5 and played a crucial role in vasculogenesis and metastasis. Depletion of MDSCs using specific Ly6G antibodies prevented ELF5 from driving vasculogenesis and metastasis. Furthermore, expression signatures in luminal A breast cancers indicated that increased MDSC invasion and inflammation were correlated with ELF5 expression, and increased ELF5 immunohistochemical staining predicted shorter metastasis-free and overall survival of luminal A patients. In the MMTV-PyMT mouse model, increased ELF5 levels drove metastasis by co-opting the innate immune system. These findings implicate ELF5 as a defining factor in the acquisition of the lethal phenotype in luminal A breast cancer, particularly in the development of antiestrogen resistance. The results also suggest that ELF5 expression produces a similar response in human luminal A breast cancer to that observed in the ELF5-driven mouse PyMT model.
The interaction between chromatin loops plays a crucial role in determining the level of cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. Recent experiments have shown that the connection pattern, distance between regulatory elements, and communication form of chromatin loops influence gene expression. However, the effect of these factors on cell-to-cell variability in gene expression remains poorly understood. To address this issue, a stochastic model was developed to map the connection patterns between interacting DNA loops into a multistate model of gene expression. The model takes into account the rates of chromatin looping, which depend on the distance between regulatory elements and the distances between other pairs of regulatory elements. The results show that the complexity of transcription activation is mainly due to the ordered interactions among regulatory elements, including the formation of DNA loops and interactions between DNA loops. In the absence of communication form, nested loops promote gene expression but reduce expression noise, while alternating loops reduce the mean expression level but enlarge the noise compared to side-by-side loops. The study also found that facilitated tracking and direct looping have different effects on gene expression, with facilitated tracking performing better in controlling mean expression and tuning expression noise. However, this control or tuning is distance-dependent, and there is a limit loop length where the difference in effect between the two communication forms almost disappears. The analysis and results support the facilitated chromatin-looping hypothesis.
Metabolic engineering relies heavily on RNA technology to rewire metabolism and maximize production. However, the development of pure riboregulators, which repress gene expression without the need for a coexpressed protein, is hindered by the lack of clear design principles. To address this, researchers developed translation inhibiting RNAs ( tiRNAs ) from scratch to explore the feature space of repressing riboregulators. Twelve structural and thermodynamic features were defined, and six were retained after removing correlations from an in silico generated riboregulator library. Eighteen riboregulators were selected and co-expressed with two target untranslated regions to link the translation inhibiting RNA features to functionality. The resulting pure riboregulators showed repression down to 6% of the original protein expression levels. A partial least squares regression model was constructed and validated to link the properties of tiRNAs to gene repression, indicating that both structural and thermodynamic features are important for efficient gene repression. This approach enables a more reliable de novo forward engineering of effective pure riboregulators, expanding the RNA toolbox for gene expression modulation. The study provides a framework for the de novo design of pure riboregulators and highlights the importance of considering both structural and thermodynamic features in their development.
The article presents a study on the phenomenon of coherence potentials in the cortex, which are transient associations among neurons that underlie memory and behavior. The researchers recorded local field potential (LFP) activity at multiple sites within the cortex of awake monkeys and organotypic cultures of cortex. They found that when the composite activity of a local neuronal group exceeds a threshold, its activity pattern, as reflected in the LFP, occurs without distortion at other cortex sites via fast synaptic transmission. These large-amplitude LFPs, called coherence potentials, extend up to hundreds of milliseconds and mark periods of loss-less spread of temporal and amplitude information, similar to action potentials at the single-cell level. Coherence potentials have an additional degree of freedom in the diversity of their waveforms, providing a high-dimensional parameter for encoding information and allowing identification of particular associations. The study suggests that coherence potential propagation reflects a preservation of the temporal characteristics of the underlying neuronal activity, and that temporal properties of the LFP waveform often serve as better predictors of behaviors than spikes. The researchers propose that coherence potential propagation in vivo represents the transfer of meaningful information in the cortical network, analogous to the spread of ideas and behaviors in social networks.
A systematic genetic screen of fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe has been conducted to identify essential factors involved in nuclear size control. The study aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which nuclear size correlates with cell size. A total of 25 essential factors were identified that alter nuclear size, and bioinformatic analyses implicated RNA processing and LINC complexes in nuclear size control. The screen revealed a 35-fold range of cell volumes, with a constant nuclear volume to cell volume (N/C) ratio across this range. In small-scale pilot experiments, nuclear volume increased steadily with cell volume during the cell cycle, maintaining a constant N/C ratio throughout interphase. The results suggest that both the regulation of global cellular processes, such as nucleocytoplasmic transport and lipid biosynthesis, and the regulation of specific structural components of the nucleus are important for nuclear size control. In multicellular organisms, the nucleocytoplasmic ratio is generally restricted to a narrow range for cells of each type, and nuclear volume correlates with cell volume across a wide range of cell sizes in both budding and fission yeasts. The findings of this study provide new insights into the mechanisms of nuclear size control and highlight the importance of RNA processing and LINC complexes in this process.
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an effective treatment for neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s disease and essential tremor (ET). Traditional DBS involves delivering a constant frequency train of pulses via electrodes implanted in the brain. New ‘closed-loop’ approaches aim to improve efficiency, efficacy, and reduce side effects by delivering stimulation based on ongoing symptoms or brain activity. A key challenge is devising a stimulation strategy that minimizes oscillations in neural activity associated with motor disorders. To address this, a reduced coupled oscillator model was used to represent neurons in areas generating pathological oscillations. The model, based on the Kuramoto model, analyzed how a patient should respond to stimulation when neural oscillations have a given phase and amplitude. The results predict that the best stimulation strategy should be phase-specific and that stimulation should have a greater effect when applied when the amplitude of brain oscillations is lower. These predictions were compared with data from ET patients and a new hybrid strategy was proposed, combining phase-locked and adaptive DBS. The phase-dependent effects of stimulation predicted by the coupled-oscillator model have been shown to generalize to other models and have been observed in a biologically realistic model of a neural circuit generating oscillations related to Parkinson’s disease. However, these predictions have not been directly compared with the experimental effects of closed-loop DBS.
A new rapid loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) assay, named Biompha-LAMP, has been developed and evaluated for detecting Schistosoma mansoni in Biomphalaria glabrata snails, the intermediate host of the parasite. The LAMP assay targets a sequence of the S. mansoni ribosomal intergenic spacer 28S-18S rRNA and has a detection limit of 0.1 fg of S. mansoni DNA at 63°C for 50 minutes. The assay was evaluated using experimentally infected snails exposed to miracidia at different times post-exposure, including the early prepatent period, light infections, and detection of infected snails in pooled samples. DNA for LAMP assays was obtained using a commercial DNA extraction kit or a simple heat NaOH extraction method. The Biompha-LAMP assay was found to be specific, sensitive, and rapid, with the ability to detect S. mansoni DNA in all groups of snails without requiring complicated DNA extraction procedures. The assay is potentially adaptable as a cost-effective method for screening intermediate hosts infected with S. mansoni in both individual snails and pooled samples. The Biompha-LAMP assay could be suitable for large-scale field surveys for schistosomes control campaigns in endemic areas. The development of this assay addresses an important point in snail control interventions related to schistosomiasis elimination, which is the need for inexpensive, field-applicable diagnostic assays for large-scale screening of individual or pooled snails from transmission sites to detect the presence of schistosomes.
This study aimed to estimate the public sector costs of dengue control activities and hospitalizations in Colombo, the most heavily urbanized district in Sri Lanka, during the 2012 epidemic year. From the Ministry of Health's perspective, the total cost of dengue control and hospitalizations was estimated at US$3.45 million (US$1.50 per capita) in Colombo district. Personnel costs accounted for the largest share of the total costs of dengue control activities (79%) and hospitalizations (46%). The per capita cost of dengue control activities was US$0.42. The average costs per hospitalization ranged from US$216 to US$609 for pediatric cases and US$196 to US$866 for adult cases, depending on disease severity and treatment setting. This analysis is the first attempt to assess the economic burden of dengue response in the public health sector in Sri Lanka. The results suggest that dengue poses a significant economic burden on the public health sector in Sri Lanka. The study highlights the substantial resources used for dengue prevention and hospital care services, which represent an opportunity cost that can be reallocated to other health services. The estimated US$0.42 per capita cost of dengue prevention and control in Colombo corresponds to a monthly cost of US$0.03 per capita.
A Predominantly Neolithic Origin for European Paternal Lineages

    The origins of European paternal lineages have been a topic of debate, with some studies suggesting a Paleolithic origin and others proposing a Neolithic origin. A recent study has reevaluated the history of haplogroup R1b1b2 (R-M269), the most common European Y-chromosomal lineage, carried by approximately 110 million European men. The study found that the geographical distribution of microsatellite diversity within this haplogroup is best explained by its spread from a single source in the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic period. This contradicts previous studies that suggested a Paleolithic origin based on the haplogroup's high frequency in Western Europe.

    The study's findings indicate that most European Y chromosomes originate from the Neolithic expansion, making Europe a prime example of how technological and cultural change is linked with the expansion of a Y-chromosomal lineage. This pattern contrasts with the origins of maternally inherited mitochondrial DNA, which suggests a unique role for males in the transition. Other European haplogroups, such as E1b1b1 (E-M35) and J, also show evidence of Neolithic expansion. The study's results suggest that the great majority of European Y chromosomes have their origins in the Neolithic expansion.
The relationship between movement variability and the speed of motor learning has been a topic of interest in the field of motor control. Recent studies have suggested that increased movement variability may enhance motor learning, but a computational model of motor adaptation reveals that variability can have both positive and negative effects on learning. The model simulations show that increased variability does not necessarily lead to faster learning and may even slow it down in some cases. A meta-analysis of published papers found no statistical correlation between movement variability and learning rate across a wide range of experiments. The authors propose that the relationship between motor variability and learning rate may be task-specific and dependent on the factors that predominantly affect task performance. Computer simulations of error-based learning using an optimal learner model support this hypothesis, suggesting that the relationship between variability and learning rate can vary widely in motor adaptation. The results of four experiments conducted by the authors are qualitatively explained by taking into account sensory uncertainty or observation noise. The study by Wu et al. found that initial variability can predict the learning rate in both reinforcement learning tasks and motor adaptation tasks, providing evidence for a facilitatory effect of error-based motor adaptation. Overall, the findings suggest that motor variability is a complex factor that can have both positive and negative effects on motor learning, and further research is needed to understand the relative importance of the involved factors.
The RelA:CBP/p300 interaction plays a crucial role in NF-κB-driven transcription by regulating the expression of genes involved in immune and inflammatory responses, survival, and proliferation. RelA, a prominent NF-κB family member, interacts with CBP/p300 in a bipartite manner, with the DNA binding domain of RelA binding to the KIX domain of CBP/p300 and the transcriptional activation domain ( TAD ) of RelA binding to the TAZ1 domain of CBP/p300. A phosphorylation event at Ser276 of RelA is necessary for the former interaction to occur. The structure of the RelA–TA2:TAZ1 component of the RelA:CBP/p300 complex was determined by NMR spectroscopy, revealing the folding of RelA–TA2 upon binding to TAZ1 through well-conserved hydrophobic sites. Mutational and isothermal calorimetric analyses allowed the design of RelA-mutants that selectively abrogated the two distinct components of the RelA:CBP/p300 interaction. Studies using cell-based techniques, mathematical modeling, and genome-wide gene expression analysis showed that a major set of RelA-activated genes is affected by this interaction. The RelA:CBP/p300 interaction controls the nuclear response of NF-κB through a negative feedback loop of the NF-κB pathway. Chromatin analyses revealed constitutive recruitment of CBP/p300 to RelA target gene promoters, suggesting a possible role of CBP/p300 in recruiting RelA to its target promoter sites. Disrupting the RelA–TA2:TAZ1 component of the RelA:CBP/p300 interaction disturbed the temporal profile of nuclear activity of RelA and deregulated the expression of a subset of NF-κB-dependent genes.
The article introduces Time-Course Gene Set Analysis (TcGSA), a method for analyzing longitudinal gene expression data using predefined groups of genes. TcGSA is an extension of gene set analysis, which has been successfully applied in cross-sectional studies. The proposed method relies on random effects modeling with maximum likelihood estimates, allowing for the use of all available repeated measurements while handling unbalanced data due to missing at random (MAR) measurements. TcGSA is a hypothesis-driven approach that identifies a priori defined gene sets with significant expression variations over time, taking into account the potential heterogeneity of expression within gene sets. When comparing biological conditions, the method indicates if the time patterns of gene sets significantly differ according to these conditions. TcGSA was applied to two real-life datasets: an HIV therapeutic vaccine trial (DALIA-1 trial) and a study on influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. The results showed that TcGSA revealed significant changes in gene expression over time within 69 gene sets during vaccination, whereas standard univariate individual gene analysis and Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) for time series failed to detect any significant pattern change. TcGSA also identified 4 gene sets linked to the influenza vaccine, which were previously associated with the pneumococcal vaccine. A simulation study demonstrated the good statistical properties and increased power of TcGSA compared to other approaches. The method is made available for the community through an R package.
The spatial epidemiology and geographical distribution of Plasmodium vivax, a malaria parasite, have been poorly understood compared to Plasmodium falciparum. To address this knowledge gap, a systematic effort was undertaken to map the global endemicity of P. vivax in 2010. A spatiotemporal Bayesian model-based geostatistical approach was used to estimate endemicity age-standardised to the 1–99 year age range (PvPR1–99) within every 5×5 km resolution grid square. The model incorporated data on Duffy negative phenotype frequency to suppress endemicity predictions, particularly in Africa. The results show that endemicity was predicted within a relatively narrow range throughout the endemic world, with the point estimate rarely exceeding 7% PvPR1–99. The Americas contributed 22% of the global area at risk of P. vivax transmission, but high endemic areas were generally sparsely populated and the region contributed only 6% of the 2.5 billion people at risk (PAR) globally. In Africa, Duffy negativity constrained stable transmission to Madagascar and parts of the Horn, contributing 3.5% of global PAR. Central Asia was home to 82% of global PAR, with important high endemic areas coinciding with dense populations in India and Myanmar. South East Asia contained areas of the highest endemicity in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea and contributed 9% of global PAR. The study provides a detailed depiction of spatially varying endemicity, intended to contribute to a paradigm shift towards geographically stratified and evidence-based planning for P. vivax control and elimination.
Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that causes skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) and expresses several cell wall-anchored proteins that contribute to its virulence. Clumping factor B (ClfB) is one of these proteins, previously shown to facilitate S. aureus nasal colonization by binding to host ligands loricrin and cytokeratin 10 in the anterior nares. However, the role of ClfB in SSTIs has not been investigated until now. This study reveals that ClfB plays a crucial role in determining the structure and bacterial burden of skin abscesses during S. aureus infection. The interaction between ClfB and loricrin, a protein expressed within the abscess tissue, is essential for this process. Targeting ClfB with a model vaccine that induces both humoral and cellular responses leads to protection against S. aureus skin infection. These findings identify ClfB as an important antigen for future SSTI vaccines. The study demonstrates that ClfB is not only involved in nasal colonization but also in the pathogenesis of SSTIs, likely exerting its effect early in the infection process. The interaction between ClfB and loricrin appears to be specific to the skin, as no difference was observed in systemic S. aureus SSTIs. Overall, this study highlights the potential of ClfB as a vaccine target for preventing S. aureus SSTIs.
To achieve the 90-90-90 goals set by UNAIDS, a hybrid stochastic framework was developed to predict the efficacy of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against HIV. The framework integrates pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic factors, as well as viral characteristics, to a priori assess prophylactic strategies. As an example, the framework was applied to dolutegravir (DTG), a second-generation integrase inhibitor, to predict its efficacy in PrEP, PrEP "on demand," and post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). The simulations showed that once-daily PrEP with 50mg oral DTG prevented 99-100% of infections, and 85% of infections when 50% of dosing events were missed. PrEP "on demand" prevented 79-84% of infections, and PEP >80% when initiated within 6 hours after virus exposure and continued for as long as possible. The predicted 90% preventive concentrations can guide the release kinetics of currently developed DTG nano-formulations. The framework can be easily adapted to other PrEP candidates, and the simulations indicated that oral 50mg DTG is non-inferior to Truvada. The results suggest that initiating prophylaxis earlier has a more pronounced effect than prolonging PEP, arguing for the immediate start of PEP in case of known- or suspected HIV exposure. The hybrid stochastic framework provides a tool for the intelligent design of once-daily, episodic PrEP, as well as simulating the on- and offset of event-driven PrEP or long-acting injectable PrEP formulations.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) has been shown to induce autophagy to enhance its replication. However, the mechanisms by which HCV regulates the autophagic pathway remain unclear. This study investigated the role of Rubicon and UVRAG, two proteins involved in autophagy, in HCV replication. The results demonstrated that HCV infection induces the expression of Rubicon and UVRAG, which have opposing effects on autophagosome maturation. Rubicon inhibits the maturation of autophagosomes, leading to their accumulation in the early stages of infection, while UVRAG stimulates their maturation. The induction of Rubicon is prompt, whereas the induction of UVRAG is delayed, resulting in the accumulation of autophagosomes in the early time points of HCV infection. The role of Rubicon in inhibiting autophagosome maturation was confirmed by siRNA knockdown and over-expression experiments, which showed that suppression of Rubicon reduced HCV replication and its over-expression enhanced HCV replication. In contrast, over-expression of UVRAG facilitated autophagosome maturation and suppressed HCV replication. The study also found that the HCV NS4B protein is sufficient to induce Rubicon and autophagosomes. The results suggest that HCV differentially regulates the expression of Rubicon and UVRAG to temporally regulate autophagic flux and enhance its replication.
Cyclin Y-like 1 (CCNYL1), a newly identified member of the cyclin family, plays a crucial role in regulating spermatogenesis in mice. CCNYL1 is highly expressed in the testis and is approximately seven times more abundant than its homologue, Cyclin Y (CCNY). Male mice lacking CCNYL1 (Ccnyl1-/-) are infertile, whereas mice lacking CCNY (Ccny-/-) display normal fertility. Spermatozoa from Ccnyl1-/- mice exhibit impaired motility and structural defects, including a thinned annulus region and/or a bent head. In contrast, mice lacking CDK16, a cyclin-dependent kinase, display a similar phenotype to Ccnyl1-/- mice. CCNYL1 interacts with CDK16, increasing the stability and kinase activity of the complex. The interaction also alters the phosphorylation levels of CDK16, with several phosphorylation sites on the N-terminal region of CDK16 being essential for CCNYL1 binding and modulation of CDK16 kinase activity. These findings reveal a previously unrecognized role of CCNYL1 in regulating spermatogenesis through its interaction with CDK16. The CCNYL1 and CDK16 protein complex is essential for spermatogenesis and male fertility in mice, suggesting that CCNYL1 may be an ideal molecule for a male contraceptive or for the development of drugs that specifically inhibit CCNYL1 expression or CCNYL1/CDK16 activity.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) strains cause diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome due to toxin-mediated microvascular endothelial injury. EHEC hemolysin (EHEC-Hly), a virulence factor, exists in two forms: free and associated with outer membrane vesicles (OMVs). While the free toxin is lytic towards human endothelium, the biological effects of OMV-associated EHEC-Hly on microvascular endothelial and intestinal epithelial cells are unknown. This study investigated the effects of OMV-associated EHEC-Hly on human brain microvascular endothelial cells (HBMEC) and Caco-2 cells. The results show that OMV-associated EHEC-Hly does not lyse these cells but triggers their apoptosis. The toxin is internalized via dynamin-dependent endocytosis of OMVs and trafficked to endo-lysosomal compartments. Upon endosome acidification, EHEC-Hly escapes from the lysosomes and targets mitochondria, leading to a decrease in mitochondrial transmembrane potential and activation of caspase-9 and caspase-3, resulting in apoptotic cell death. This study reveals a novel mechanism of EHEC-Hly involvement in the pathogenesis of EHEC diseases, where OMV-mediated intracellular delivery allows the toxin to target mitochondria. The findings suggest that OMV-associated EHEC-Hly irreversibly injures human microvascular endothelial and intestinal epithelial cells, which are key players in the pathogenesis of EHEC-mediated diseases.
In the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe, a positive feedback loop exists between histone H2B ubiquitylation ( H2Bub1 ) and the positive transcription elongation factor b ( P-TEFb/Cdk9 ) to regulate transcript elongation by RNA polymerase II ( RNAPII ). H2Bub1 promotes site-specific methylation of histone H3 by the methyltransferase Set1, and also regulates gene expression through a methylation-independent mechanism. Chemical and genetic analyses indicate that lowering Cdk9 activity or preventing phosphorylation of its substrate Spt5 reduces H2Bub1 levels in vivo. Conversely, mutations in the H2Bub1 pathway impair Cdk9 recruitment to chromatin and decrease Spt5 phosphorylation. An Spt5 phosphorylation-site mutation combined with deletion of Set1 phenocopies morphologic and growth defects due to H2Bub1 loss, suggesting independent, partially redundant roles for Cdk9 and Set1 downstream of H2Bub1. Genome-wide analyses by chromatin immunoprecipitation demonstrate opposing effects of Cdk9 and H2Bub1 on distribution of transcribing RNAPII. The results imply that other pathways can modulate the functions of Cdk9 and H2Bub1 in transcript elongation, and suggest that P-TEFb activity is required to overcome repressive effects of histone modifications. The study reveals a novel function of a conserved, co-transcriptional histone modification and highlights the importance of balancing the opposing functions of Cdk9 and H2Bub1 to regulate elongation.
Yellow fever virus (YFV) remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in South America and Africa. A phylogenetic analysis of the prM/E gene region from 133 viral isolates sampled from 22 countries over 76 years revealed that the currently circulating strains of YFV originated in Africa within the last 1,500 years. The virus emerged in the Americas approximately 300-400 years ago, following the slave trade, and spread westwards across the continent, persisting in the jungles of South America. The phylogenetic analysis showed that YFV can be divided into two geographic groups, with distinct viral lineages observed in Africa and the Americas. The study found no major difference in evolutionary dynamics among viruses circulating in South America or Africa, and neither population exhibited the increases in virus diversity expected of epidemic expansion. The virus established a sylvatic enzootic cycle within the Amazon, Araguaia, and Orinoco river basins, vectored by Haemagogus and Sabethes mosquitoes. The introduction of YFV to the Americas is attributed to the slave trade, supported by gene sequence data and modern phylogenetic techniques for estimating divergence times. This study demonstrates the utility of gene sequence data in testing hypotheses of viral dispersal and demographics, and highlights the role of human migration in the spread of infectious disease.
The study investigated the pathogenesis of Streptococcus pneumoniae, a leading bacterial pathogen, in an infant mouse model of colonization, disease, and transmission, both with and without influenza A (IAV) co-infection. The research aimed to identify vulnerable points in the multiple steps involved in pneumococcal pathogenesis by analyzing population bottlenecks. The findings revealed that in the setting of IAV co-infection, the organism must pass through single-cell bottlenecks during bloodstream invasion from the nasopharynx within the host and in transmission between hosts. Passage through these bottlenecks was not associated with genetic adaptation by the pathogen. The bottleneck in transmission occurred between bacterial exit from one host and establishment in another, explaining why the number of shed organisms in secretions is critical to overcoming it. These observations demonstrate how viral infection and TLR-dependent innate immune responses drive bacterial contagion. The study employed an infant mouse model that recapitulates many of the key features of pneumococcal pathogenesis, including colonization, localized and systemic disease, and host-to-host transmission. The results suggest that IAV co-infection increases the burden of colonizing pneumococci, and the tight population bottleneck in the setting of IAV could be due to the selection of a subpopulation of pneumococci or passage through a bottleneck requiring selection among pre-existing variants.
The study aimed to evaluate the exposure to Phlebotomus orientalis bites in human populations from visceral leishmaniasis-endemic areas in Eastern Africa by testing antibody reactions against recombinant P. orientalis salivary antigens. Recombinant proteins derived from P. orientalis secreted salivary proteins were produced using bacterial and mammalian expression systems and tested as antigens for detecting anti-P. orientalis IgG in human sera. Human sera from Sudan and Ethiopia were screened using ELISA and immunoblotting to identify potential markers of exposure to P. orientalis bites. Two recombinant proteins, mYEL1 and mAG5, were identified as the most promising antigens, showing high correlation coefficients and specificity compared to whole sand fly salivary gland homogenate. The combination of both proteins increased the correlation coefficients and positive and negative predictive values of P. orientalis exposure. This study is the first to report screening human sera for anti-P. orientalis antibodies using recombinant salivary proteins. The recombinant salivary proteins mYEL1 and mAG5 proved to be valid antigens for screening human sera from both Sudan and Ethiopia for exposure to P. orientalis bites. The combination of equal amounts of these two proteins significantly increased the capability to detect anti-P. orientalis antibody responses. The study identified the combination of mYEL1 and mAG5 as a valid tool to screen sand fly exposure in humans from both Sudan and Ethiopia. This combination of stable recombinant proteins can substitute P. orientalis salivary gland homogenate, simplifying studies aimed at detecting antibodies in bitten people in endemic areas of visceral leishmaniasis.
Salmonella genomic island 1 (SGI1) is a mobile genetic element associated with multidrug resistance in clinical isolates of pathogenic Enterobacteriaceae. SGI1 is mobilized in trans by IncA and IncC plasmids (A/C plasmids) following its excision from the chromosome, an event triggered by the transcriptional activator complex AcaCD encoded by these helper plasmids. Although SGI1 is not self-transmissible, it carries three genes, traNS, traHS, and traGS, coding for distant homologs of the predicted mating pore subunits TraNC, TraHC, and TraGC, respectively, encoded by A/C plasmids. This study investigated the regulation of traNS and traHGS and the role of these three genes in the transmissibility of SGI1. Transcriptional fusion of the promoter sequences of traNS and traHGS to the reporter gene lacZ confirmed that expression of these genes is inducible by AcaCD. Mating experiments using combinations of deletion mutants of SGI1 and the helper IncC plasmid pVCR94 revealed complex interactions between these two mobile genetic elements. The study found that TraNS, TraHS, and TraGS are functional proteins that replace TraNC, TraHC, and TraGC in the mating pore encoded by IncC plasmids, and that remodeling of the IncC-encoded mating pore by SGI1 is essential to enhance transfer rate of SGI1 over the helper plasmid. TraGS was found to be crucial to allow DNA transfer between cells bearing IncC helper plasmids, suggesting that SGI1 disables an IncC-encoded entry exclusion mechanism.
The Saccharomyces cerevisiae polo-like kinase Cdc5 has been found to inhibit the hyperphosphorylation of the checkpoint kinase Rad53, leading to checkpoint adaptation. Checkpoint adaptation occurs when cells are presented with persistent or irreparable DNA damage and escape the cell-cycle arrest imposed by the DNA damage checkpoint. Overexpression of Cdc5 promotes faster adaptation, indicating that high levels of Cdc5 modulate the ability of the checkpoint to inhibit the downstream cell-cycle machinery. Cdc5 overproduction was found to have little effect on the early steps leading to Rad53 activation, including checkpoint sensor localization, Mec1-phosphorylation of Rad9, and formation of the Rad9-Rad53 complex. However, damage-induced hyperphosphorylation of Rad53 was significantly reduced, consistent with the observation that cell-cycle arrest is lost during adaptation. This suggests that Cdc5 acts to attenuate the DNA damage checkpoint through the loss of Rad53 hyperphosphorylation, allowing cells to adapt to DNA damage. This mechanism is likely conserved in vertebrates, as polo-like kinase homologs have been shown to inhibit the ability of Claspin to facilitate the activation of downstream checkpoint kinases. The timing of adaptation onset correlated with the loss of Rad53 activity, suggesting that adaptation may be a consequence of Cdc5-mediated checkpoint inhibition.
The Kirchhoff-Nernst-Planck (KNP) framework is a computational model that simulates the dynamics of ion concentrations and electrical potential in the extracellular space (ECS) of the brain on large spatiotemporal scales. This framework is essential for understanding pathological conditions such as seizures, stroke, and spreading depression, which are associated with substantial changes in ion concentrations in the ECS. The KNP framework circumvents charge-relaxation processes by assuming electroneutrality, making it feasible to run simulations on millimeter and second scales on a standard desktop computer. In contrast to previous models, the 3-D KNP framework predicts how ion concentrations vary in all spatial directions surrounding neuronal sources, allowing for a broader range of biological problems to be addressed. The KNP-scheme is the first simulation framework that can handle 3-D electrodiffusion in neuronal tissue at relatively large spatiotemporal scales without demanding excessive computer power. The framework was used to simulate the dynamics of ion concentrations and electrical potential surrounding a morphologically detailed pyramidal cell, demonstrating its efficiency. Future applications of the KNP framework to more complex and biologically realistic systems will be useful in exploring pathological conditions associated with large concentration variations in the ECS. The KNP framework can be used in a hybrid simulation setup where the dynamics of ion concentrations and electrical potential in the ECS are computed with KNP, while the neurodynamics is computed with the NEURON simulator tool.
A proposed budget cut to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) vector-borne diseases program has the potential to leave the country unprepared to handle emerging and existing mosquito-borne diseases such as dengue and West Nile virus. A mathematical model was used to evaluate the impact of delayed control responses to dengue epidemics in an economically developed urban environment, specifically the City of Cairns, Queensland, Australia. The results showed that halting mosquito surveillance can increase the management costs of epidemics by up to an order of magnitude compared to a strategy with sustained surveillance and early case detection. The study found that the total costs of preparedness through surveillance are far lower than the costs needed to respond to the introduction of vector-borne pathogens, even without considering the cost in human lives and well-being. The analysis suggests that the proposed budget cut could virtually paralyze surveillance and research activities for diseases already circulating in the US, such as dengue and West Nile virus, and jeopardize the capability of the existing health infrastructure for early detection of other exotic mosquito-transmitted pathogens. The study emphasizes the need for improved and sustainable systems for vector-borne disease surveillance and provides a science-based justification for re-assessing the current proposal to slash the CDC vector-borne diseases program budget.
In a prospective study conducted in western Nicaragua, researchers investigated the prevalence of dengue fever among children and adults presenting with acute febrile illness. A total of 740 patients, aged 1 year and above, were enrolled and tested for dengue IgG and IgM antibodies, as well as serotyped for dengue virus using reverse transcriptase-PCR. The results showed that 63.5% of the patients were seropositive for dengue at enrollment, with the seroprevalence increasing with age, reaching over 90% in individuals above 20 years. Acute dengue was identified in 5.1% of the patients, with serotypes 1 and 2 being the most common. Notably, only 8.1% of the confirmed cases were suspected clinically, highlighting the importance of dengue as a largely unrecognized cause of fever in the region. The study also found that dengue was the only flavivirus circulating in humans in Nicaragua during the study period, reducing the likelihood of serologic cross-reactions with other flaviviruses. The median age of patients with acute dengue was 16 years, and the symptoms and signs were similar to those of other acute febrile illnesses. The study's findings suggest that dengue is a significant public health concern in western Nicaragua, particularly given the region's vulnerability to the Zika virus, which is transmitted by the same vector and has been associated with severe congenital infections.
Arabidopsis leucine-rich repeat receptor–like kinase NILR1 plays a crucial role in the induction of innate immunity to parasitic nematodes. Plant-parasitic nematodes cause significant economic losses worldwide, and an effective plant defense against them relies on the recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns ( PAMPs ) by surface-localized receptors, leading to the activation of PAMP-triggered immunity ( PTI ). While PTI has been extensively studied in various plant-pathogen interactions, its role in plant-nematode interactions remains poorly understood. This study demonstrates that nematode-derived proteinaceous elicitors can induce PTI in Arabidopsis in a manner dependent on the common immune co-receptor BAK1. The researchers identified a leucine-rich repeat receptor-like kinase, NILR1, which is specifically regulated upon nematode infection and is essential for PTI responses initiated by nematodes. Loss-of-function mutants of NILR1 are hypersusceptible to a broad category of nematodes. NILR1 is the first example of an immune receptor involved in the induction of basal immunity ( PTI ) in plants or animals in response to nematodes. The study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying plant-nematode interactions and offers potential options for nematode control in crop plants.
The study investigated the effect of miltefosine, an anti-cancer drug, on the surface antigens of Schistosoma mansoni adult worms in vitro. The results showed that miltefosine treatment enhanced the exposure of worm surface antigens, which were recognized by rabbit anti-S. mansoni adult worm homogenate and anti-S. mansoni infection antisera in an indirect immunofluorescence assay. Four proteins reacting with the antibodies were identified as fructose-1,6 bisphosphate aldolase, Sm22.6, alkaline phosphatase, and malate dehydrogenase. These antibodies also bound to the surface of 3-hour schistosomula and induced immune agglutination of the parasites, suggesting a potential role in immune protection. The study reveals a novel mode of action of miltefosine as an anti-schistosome agent, where treatment unmasks parasite surface antigens not normally exposed to the host during infection. The antigens involved in this molecular mechanism could have potential as intervention targets, and antibodies against these antigens may act to increase the drug's anti-parasite efficacy and be involved in the development of resistance to re-infection. The findings of this study provide new insights into the mechanism of action of miltefosine and its potential as a treatment for schistosomiasis.
In the human opportunistic pathogen Bacillus cereus, the surface protein IlsA plays a crucial role in iron acquisition from host ferritin. Ferritin is a 24-mer nanocage protein that stores thousands of iron atoms within its cavity. IlsA binds to ferritin through direct interaction with the shell subunits, causing ferritin aggregation on the bacterial surface. Isothermal titration calorimetry data indicate that IlsA binds several types of ferritins, and UV-vis kinetic data show a significant enhancement of iron release from ferritin in the presence of IlsA. This is the first time a bacterial protein has been shown to alter the stability of the ferritin iron core. Disruption of the siderophore bacillibactin production drastically reduces the ability of B. cereus to utilize ferritin for growth and results in attenuated bacterial virulence in insects. A new model of iron acquisition in B. cereus is proposed, involving the binding of IlsA to host ferritin followed by siderophore-assisted iron uptake. The results highlight a possible interplay between a surface protein and a siderophore and provide new insights into host adaptation of B. cereus and general bacterial pathogenesis. Further experiments are needed to determine whether the ability of IlsA to bind ferritin is a universally conserved feature of the composite NEAT-LRR proteins found in other pathogenic bacteria.
A thermodynamically consistent model of the post-translational Kai circadian clock in the cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus has been developed. The clock is driven by a protein phosphorylation cycle consisting of three proteins: KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC. KaiC forms a homohexamer with two domains: CI and CII. The model proposes that ATP hydrolysis in the CI domain provides the thermodynamic driving force for the clock, switching KaiC between an active and inactive conformational state. Phosphorylation of the CII domain serves as a timer for the hydrolysis in the CI domain. The model also explains how KaiA acts as a nucleotide exchange factor to stimulate phosphorylation of KaiC and how the differential affinity of KaiA for different KaiC phosphoforms generates the characteristic temporal order of KaiC phosphorylation. In the inactive state, KaiC binds KaiB, stabilizing this state and leading to the sequestration of KaiA and KaiC dephosphorylation. A kinetic Monte Carlo algorithm was used to simulate the system, demonstrating that the model can describe a wealth of experimental data. The model provides a thermodynamically consistent explanation for the post-translational Kai circadian clock, resolving the long-standing question of how the clock is driven thermodynamically.
Hepatitis B virus (HBV) suppresses innate immune signaling to establish persistent infection. Although HBV is a DNA virus, its pre-genomic RNA (pgRNA) can be sensed by RIG-I and activates MAVS to mediate interferon (IFN) λ synthesis. However, the underlying mechanism explaining how HBV infection fails to induce interferon-αβ (IFN) synthesis remained uncharacterized. This study demonstrates that HBV induces parkin to recruit the linear ubiquitin assembly complex (LUBAC) to mitochondria and abrogates IFN β synthesis. Parkin interacts with MAVS, accumulates unanchored linear polyubiquitin chains on MAVS via LUBAC, to disrupt MAVS signalosome and attenuate IRF3 activation. This study highlights the novel role of parkin in antiviral signaling, which involves LUBAC being recruited to the mitochondria. Parkin silencing restores IFN β synthesis in HBV-expressing cells upon stimulation with RIG-I agonist pI:C. These findings establish the molecular mechanism of HBV-induced suppression of innate immunity and provide avenues of investigation on the role of mitochondrial dynamics in innate immunity. The study suggests that HBV-induced mitochondrially-localized Parkin interacts with MAVS and causes its ubiquitination, leading to the enrichment of M-1 linked polyubiquitin chains on MAVS, which disrupts its interaction with downstream TRAFs and abrogates IRF-3 activation.
The crystal structure of pfiT, a T-cell superantigen associated with human Crohn's disease, has been determined at 1.7Å resolution. PfiT, encoded by the pfiT gene of Pseudomonas fluorescens, is a novel enteric T-cell superantigen that stimulates the proliferation of human lymphocytes. The structure of pfiT reveals that it belongs to the TetR-family of DNA-binding transcription regulators, indicating that it represents a new family of T-cell superantigens. Both pfiT and its homolog, PA2885, bind to mammalian cells and interact with human class II MHC molecules, specifically HLA-DR, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DP. The binding of pfiT to HLA-DR is inhibited by anti-class II MHC antibodies, indicating that the interaction is class II MHC-specific. Competition studies show that pfiT and the superantigen Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen (MAM) compete for binding to HLA-DR, suggesting that their binding sites overlap. Furthermore, pfiT directly interacts with HLA-DR1, as demonstrated by GST-pfiT efficiently precipitating both endogenous and in vitro purified recombinant HLA-DR1 molecules. These findings suggest that pfiT is a structurally novel Crohn's disease-associated superantigen that plays a role in the pathogenesis of the disease. The discovery of pfiT and its interaction with class II MHC molecules provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying Crohn's disease.
This study investigated the role of allelic regulation in the heterogeneity of Nanog expression in embryonic stem cells (ESCs). Nanog is a key regulator of pluripotency and exhibits a disperse distribution within ESC populations. The authors developed a multiscale stochastic population balance equation framework to model the dynamics of Nanog expression, considering allelic control, gene expression noise, and random partitioning at cell division. The results showed that allelic regulation of Nanog leads to three distinct states of Nanog expression, which becomes bimodal when combined with transcriptional noise. The study found that initially uniform populations of ESCs gave rise to the same Nanog heterogeneity within ten cell cycles, regardless of their allelic expression pattern. Depletion of Nanog content in cells switching off both gene alleles was slower than the accumulation of intracellular Nanog after cells turned on at least one of their Nanog gene copies, indicating Nanog state-dependent dynamics. The study also highlighted the importance of allelic regulation in maintaining fractions of self-renewing cells with sufficient Nanog content to prevent aberrant loss of pluripotency. The findings suggest that allelic control of Nanog expression is a prime determinant of ESC population heterogeneity and warrant further investigation in the contexts of stem cell specification and cell reprogramming.
The article presents a study on the quantification and classification of Escherichia coli (E. coli) proteome utilization and unused protein costs across various environments. Using a combination of absolute and global proteomics data and a genome-scale model of E. coli, the researchers computed the environment-specific cost and utility of the proteome on a per-gene basis. The results show that nearly half of the proteome mass is unused in certain environments, and accounting for the cost of this unused protein expression explains more than 95% of the variance in growth rates of E. coli across 16 distinct environments. The study also reveals that reduction in unused protein expression is a common mechanism to increase cellular growth rates in adaptive evolution experiments. Furthermore, the classification of unused protein reveals that it encodes several nutrient- and stress-preparedness functions, which may convey fitness benefits in varying environments. The findings suggest that unused protein expression is the source of large and pervasive fitness costs that may provide the benefit of hedging against environmental change. The study provides a baseline understanding of the percentage of the microbial proteome that is un-utilized in a given environment and how much the un-utilized protein fraction can vary across environments. The results have implications for understanding the evolution and regulation of proteome expression in microbes.
A genome-wide association study (GWAS) was conducted in 3,955 Chinese, 2,034 Malays, and 2,146 Asian Indians to investigate the genetic architecture of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2D) in multi-ethnic cohorts from Southeast Asia. The study aimed to assess the transferability and relevance of previously identified T2D-associated loci in European populations to the three major ethnic populations of Asia, which comprise half of the world's population. A meta-analysis of the three studies revealed strong associations at the CDKAL1 and HHEX/IDE/KIF11 loci, which have consistently emerged in T2D studies across multiple global populations. However, the signals of association at CDKAL1 showed varying effect sizes across populations, with similar or larger effects in Chinese and Indian populations compared to European studies. Conditional analysis at these loci revealed evidence of locus and allelic heterogeneity, as well as variation in linkage disequilibrium between populations. These findings highlight the importance of surveying diverse racial/ethnic groups to fine-map causal variants and identify population-specific variants. The study demonstrates the value of GWAS in identifying novel genetic loci associated with T2D and underscores the need for further research to understand the genetic etiology of T2D in diverse populations.
In the basidiomycetous budding yeast Cryptococcus neoformans, nuclear division occurs in the daughter cell during mitosis. Aurora B kinase Ipl1 plays a crucial role in regulating this process. Ipl1 localizes to the nucleus upon breakdown of the nuclear envelope during mitosis and is essential for timely breakdown of the nuclear envelope. It also regulates structural integrity of microtubules. Depletion of Ipl1 results in compromised stability of cytoplasmic microtubules, leading to delayed kinetochore clustering and nuclear migration. An in silico model predicts that cytoplasmic microtubules and cortical dyneins promote atypical nuclear division in C. neoformans. The model also suggests that an effective cortical bias generated by cytosolic Bim1 and dynein regulates dynamics of kinetochore clustering and nuclear migration. In vivo alterations of Bim1 or dynein cellular levels delay nuclear migration. Ipl1 spatio-temporally influences Bim1 or/and dynein activity along with microtubule stability to ensure timely onset of nuclear division. The timely breakdown of the nuclear envelope by Ipl1 allows its own nuclear entry, facilitating spatio-temporal regulation of nuclear division during semi-open mitosis in C. neoformans. Ipl1 is essential for viability and orchestrates pre-anaphase nuclear movement from the mother cell to the daughter in C. neoformans. It maintains microtubule stability to facilitate timely kinetochore clustering and nuclear migration. Ipl1 spatio-temporally regulates cytoplasmic microtubules and spatial distribution of Bim1 and/or dynein in the cell.
This study investigated the role of a synonymous mutation in the RET proto-oncogene in an aggressive case of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). A patient with MTC harbored a somatic RET p.Cys634Arg mutation, a known driver mutation, and a germ-line RET p.Cys630= substitution, initially considered clinically irrelevant due to its synonymous nature. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) revealed that the RET mutations were in cis, with no evidence of gene amplification. Expression analysis showed increased RET transcript levels in the patient compared to seven other MTCs with the p.Cys634Arg mutation. Minigene expression assays demonstrated that the synonymous RET mutation was sufficient to explain the increased RET mRNA level. In silico analyses and RNA immunoprecipitation experiments revealed that the p.Cys630= variant created new exonic splicing enhancer motifs, enhancing SRp55 recruitment to the mutant allele, leading to more efficient maturation of its pre-mRNA and increased abundance of mature mRNA encoding a constitutively active RET receptor. These findings document a novel mechanism by which synonymous mutations can contribute to cancer progression. The study highlights the importance of considering the potential oncogenic effects of synonymous mutations, which are often filtered out from large-scale cancer genome studies.
A new bioinformatics system has been developed to remove contaminants and low-complexity genomic sequences from draft genomes of eukaryotic pathogens. This system was applied to a comprehensive database of sequenced eukaryotic pathogen genomes, resulting in a “clean” database for use with bioinformatics classification and analysis tools. The system was tested on 245 eukaryotic pathogen draft genomes, identifying and removing human, bacterial, archaeal, and viral sequences, as well as low-complexity genomic sequences that can lead to false positives. The cleaned database was found to provide better sensitivity and a dramatic reduction in false positives when used for metagenomic sample analysis compared to the original genomes. The system can be used on both complete and draft reference genomes, making it a valuable tool for improving the accuracy of metagenomic sequencing for diagnosis of human infections. The development of this system addresses the issue of contamination in published genomes, which has hindered the use of reference databases for accurate diagnosis. The cleaned database is now available for use in bioinformatics pipelines, including those intended for next-generation sequencing diagnostics, with decreased false positive and false negative rates.
The study investigated the genetic diversity and population structure of Trypanosoma brucei in Uganda to understand the epidemiology of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) and Nagana. A total of 269 T. brucei isolates were genotyped at 17 microsatellite loci and screened for the SRA gene, which confers human infectivity to T. b. rhodesiense. The results showed that the isolates from Uganda and southwestern Kenya can be partitioned into three distinct genetic clusters. Cluster 1 and 3 include isolates from central and southern Uganda, while cluster 2 contains mostly isolates from southwestern Kenya. These clusters are not sorted by subspecies designation, host, or date of collection. The analysis also revealed genetic admixture among the three clusters and long-range dispersal, indicating recent and possibly ongoing gene flow between them. The study found that the expansion of the disease to new foci in central Uganda occurred from the northward spread of T. b. rhodesiense (Tbr). Additionally, the results confirmed the emergence of human-infective strains (Tbr) from non-infective T. b. brucei (Tbb) strains of different genetic backgrounds and highlighted the importance of cattle as Tbr reservoirs in shaping the epidemiology of sleeping sickness in the region. The study's findings have implications for the control and prevention of HAT and Nagana in Uganda.
This study investigated the role of thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXNIP) in the inflammatory response to lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced endotoxic shock. Mice deficient in TXNIP (Txnip−/−) were found to be significantly more susceptible to LPS-induced endotoxic shock compared to wild-type mice. The increased susceptibility was attributed to excessive production of nitric oxide (NO) and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) in Txnip−/− macrophages. An iNOS inhibitor rescued Txnip−/− mice from endotoxic shock-induced death, indicating that NO is a major factor in TXNIP-mediated endotoxic shock. The study also found that Txnip−/− mice had reduced IL-1β secretion due to increased S-nitrosylation of the NLRP3 inflammasome. The results suggest that TXNIP regulates NO synthesis and NLRP3 inflammasome activation during endotoxic shock. The NF-κB/iNOS pathway was found to be involved in the regulation of NO production in the absence of TXNIP. Furthermore, excessive NO production in Txnip−/− mice inhibited NLRP3-dependent IL-1β secretion via direct S-nitrosylation of the NLRP3 inflammasome. Overall, the study demonstrates that TXNIP is a novel molecule that links NO synthesis and NLRP3 inflammasome activation during endotoxic shock. The findings suggest that TXNIP plays a critical role as a negative modulator of NO and iNOS expression during LPS-induced endotoxic shock.
ZTF-8, a protein conserved from worms to humans, has been identified as a novel factor involved in the repair of both mitotic and meiotic double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) as well as in meiotic DNA damage checkpoint activation in the C. elegans germline. ZTF-8 mutants exhibit sensitivity to γ-irradiation and hydroxyurea, mitotic nuclear arrest at S-phase accompanied by activation of the ATL-1 and CHK-1 DNA damage checkpoint kinases, and accumulation of both mitotic and meiotic recombination intermediates. This suggests that ZTF-8 functions in DNA damage response ( DDR ) and double-strand break repair ( DSBR ). ZTF-8 partially co-localizes with the 9-1-1 DDR complex and interacts with MRT-2/Rad1, a component of this complex. The human RHINO protein rescues the phenotypes observed in ztf-8 mutants, indicating functional conservation across species. ZTF-8 is proposed to promote repair at stalled replication forks and meiotic DSBs by transducing DNA damage checkpoint signaling via the 9-1-1 pathway. ZTF-8 localizes to both chromatin and the nucleolus, and changes in its subcellular localization in response to DNA damage support a role for ZTF-8 in DDR and DNA repair. Loss of ZTF-8 function results in partially impaired activation of germ cell apoptosis, reduced brood size, and accumulation of RAD-51 foci, all of which are rescued in transgenic worms expressing human RHINO. These findings define a conserved function for ZTF-8/RHINO in promoting genomic stability in the germline.
During neural tube development, motor neuron ( MN ) progenitors differentiate more rapidly than other progenitors. Using single cell transcriptomics, researchers investigated the transcriptional changes associated with the transition of neural progenitors into MNs. The study found that the MN determinant Olig2 plays a pivotal role in this process, particularly just prior to MN differentiation. Olig2 represses the expression of the Notch signaling pathway effectors Hes1 and Hes5, with Olig2 repression of Hes5 appearing to be direct and mediated by a conserved regulatory element within the Hes5 locus. This regulatory element restricts Hes5 expression in MN progenitors. The findings reveal a tight coupling between the regulatory networks that control patterning and neuronal differentiation, and demonstrate how Olig2 acts as a developmental pacemaker coordinating the spatial and temporal pattern of MN generation. The study also suggests that Notch signaling controls the transition between distinct phases of Olig2 expression by restraining Olig2 expression in MN progenitors. Inhibition of Notch signaling leads to an increase in Olig2 expression and neuronal differentiation, indicating that Olig2 up-regulation is necessary for MN development to proceed in a spatially and temporally controlled manner. These findings establish a mechanism by which neural patterning and neurogenesis intersect, with Olig2 modulating the Notch pathway to specify MN identity and determine the rate of differentiation.
A nonhuman primate model was used to investigate the role of T cells in protecting against the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza virus (H1N1pdm). Five rhesus macaques were first infected with a seasonal human H1N1 isolate to "prime" their cellular immunity. Four months later, these animals and seven naive controls were challenged with H1N1pdm. The results showed that the "primed" animals had a more rapid and robust T cell response to H1N1pdm, with activated T cells appearing in the blood and lung as early as two days post-inoculation. This response involved both CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and peaked earlier and at a higher magnitude than in naive animals. The "primed" animals also cleared H1N1pdm infection significantly earlier from the upper and lower respiratory tract than the naive animals, and before the appearance of H1N1pdm-specific neutralizing antibodies. The study suggests that cross-reactive T cell responses can mediate early clearance of an antigenically novel influenza virus in primates. The findings have implications for the development of vaccines that can induce such cross-reactive T cells to protect humans against severe disease caused by newly emerging pandemic influenza viruses. The results are consistent with previous studies in mice and ferrets, which have shown that cross-reactive T cells can provide protection against lethal challenge with H1N1pdm.
A novel Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) assay has been developed for the rapid and sensitive detection of Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever. The LAMP assay targets the repeated sequence IS1111a of the htpAB gene of C. burnetii using a universal primer set designed with PrimerExplorer V4 software. The sensitivity of the LAMP assay was evaluated using known quantities of recombined reference plasmids containing the targeted genes, with a detection limit of 1 copy per reaction. The specificity of the assay was determined using 26 members of the order Rickettsiae and 18 other common pathogens, with no cross-reaction observed. The LAMP assay was compared to real-time PCR in 24 blood samples, including 6 confirmed and 18 probable Q fever cases diagnosed by IFA serological assessment and real-time PCR. The results showed a positive rate of 33.3% for the LAMP assay and 8.3% for real-time PCR (P < 0.05) in unknown febrile patients, and 7.9% for the LAMP assay and 0.8% for real-time PCR (P < 0.01) in animals. The LAMP assay was also used to confirm Q fever in the Yi Li area, Xinjiang Province. The study concludes that the LAMP assay is a potential tool for the diagnosis of Q fever in humans and domestic animals, particularly in rural areas of China, due to its rapid and sensitive detection without the need for sophisticated equipment or complicated protocols.
Biomedical research has shown that cancers often exhibit gene expression profiles similar to those of undifferentiated embryonic stem cells (ESCs). However, the mechanisms controlling these expression programs have not been fully understood. A recent study explored transcriptional enhancers throughout hematopoietic cell development and derived cancers, revealing a novel class of regulatory epigenetic mutations known as embryonic stem cell-specific enhancers (ESSEs). These ESSEs are particularly enriched in a group of enhancers of the hematopoietic cell lineage and are prone to DNA methylation changes, indicative of their chromatin activity states. The study found that methylation of ESSEs is associated with gene transcriptional activity in cancer, with methylated ESSEs being hypermethylated in cancer relative to normal somatic cells and co-localized with silenced genes. Conversely, unmethylated ESSEs tend to be hypomethylated in cancer and associated with reactivated genes. Further analysis of a hypomethylated ESSE downstream to the VEGFA gene revealed a novel regulatory circuit affecting VEGFA transcript levels across cancers and patients. The study suggests that the discovered enhancer sites provide a framework for the reactivation of ESC genes in cancer. The results indicate that ES enhancers are specifically prone to methylation perturbations in cancers and that hypomethylation of ESSEs is associated with the up-regulation of ESC genes in cancer cells.
