The study highlights the importance of ribosome quality control pathways in modulating the effects of translation stalling compounds.
Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) induces widespread destruction of cellular messenger RNAs (mRNAs) to evade immune detection and block host gene expression. The viral protein SOX is responsible for this phenotype, but its mechanism of action remained unknown due to its lack of intrinsic ribonuclease activity. This study reveals that SOX stimulates cellular transcriptome turnover through a novel mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation. Transcripts in SOX-expressing cells exhibit extended poly(A) polymerase II-generated poly(A) tails and polyadenylation-linked mRNA turnover. SOX-induced polyadenylation changes correlate with its RNA turnover function, and inhibition of poly(A) tail formation blocks SOX activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly(A) binding proteins are critical cellular cofactors for SOX function, with the latter undergoing striking nuclear relocalization by SOX. This study demonstrates that KSHV SOX-induced host shutoff is linked to mRNA polyadenylation, a novel mechanism of host shutoff and a new model system to probe the regulation of poly(A) tail-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells. The findings suggest that SOX-induced alterations in mRNA processing events may render nascent RNAs targets of cellular quality control machinery, and that polyadenylation plays an integral role in SOX-mediated mRNA turnover.
Bacterial pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa induce the production of type III interferon (IFNλ) in the lung, which plays a crucial role in the innate immune response. The IFNλ receptor, IL-28R, is abundantly expressed in the respiratory tract and is essential for host defense against some viral pathogens. However, its role in the innate immune response to bacterial pathogens has not been well understood. Research has shown that IFNλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting the microRNA miR-21, leading to the upregulation of PDCD4, a protein that promotes inflammatory signaling. Mice lacking the IL-28R or PDCD4 had improved clearance of bacterial pathogens and reduced lung pathology compared to wild-type mice. In human epithelial cells, IFNλ inhibited miR-21 via STAT3, resulting in the upregulation of PDCD4. In vivo, 18 hours after infection, miR-21 was significantly reduced and PDCD4 was increased in the lungs of wild-type mice compared to IL-28R null mice. Infection of PDCD4 null mice with Staphylococcus aureus resulted in improved clearance, reduced pathology, and reduced inflammatory cytokine production. These findings suggest that IFNλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting miR-21 regulation of PDCD4 during bacterial pneumonia. The study highlights the importance of the IFNλ/IL-28R/PDCD4 pathway in the innate immune response to bacterial pathogens.
Mortality trends and risk factors in advanced stage-2 Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT) were investigated in a retrospective study of 781 naïve cases admitted to the National Reference Center for Human African Trypanosomiasis in the Democratic Republic of Congo between 1989 and 2012. The study aimed to identify predictors of death and assess the effectiveness of different treatment regimens. Death proportions were 17.2% in the standard melarsoprol schedule, 12.1% in the short schedule melarsoprol, 5.4% in the first-line eflornithine regimen, 9.1% in the NECT treatment regimen, and 36% in the group treated with eflornithine due to severe clinical status. After adjusting for treatment, death odds ratios were significantly associated with clinical dysfunction on admission (10.40), high protidorachy (2.14), presence of parasites in the cerebrospinal fluid (1.99), and high cytorachy (1.70). A multivariable analysis within treatment groups retained clinical status on admission and high protidorachy as significant predictors of death. The study highlights the importance of clinical manifestations in assessing disease severity and the need for an objective test to evaluate HAT clinical severity. The findings suggest that clinical status on admission and protidorachy are critical factors in determining mortality in advanced stage-2 HAT. The study's algorithm for initial clinical status assessment may serve as a basis for developing standardized assessment tools for HAT management and epidemiological reports.
A novel computer vision pipeline was developed to study the effects of isolation on social interaction dynamics in Drosophila melanogaster. The pipeline consists of a new imaging arena and an improved tracking algorithm that allows for the simultaneous tracking of a large number of flies. Automatic classification of touch and graph-based social network analysis were used to quantify changes in the social network in response to prior social isolation. The results showed that isolation significantly and swiftly enhanced individual and local social network parameters depicting near-neighbor relationships. Genome-wide molecular correlates of these behavioral changes were explored and found that gene expression alterations occurred largely on day one, primarily in metabolic genes. Metabolic changes were verified by an increase in lipid content in isolated flies. Behavioral changes due to isolation were found to be long-lasting, while changes in gene expression levels were transient. The study suggests that flies alter their physiology and behavior to promote social interactions with neighboring flies after only a single day of isolation. The individual fly parameter of walking distance was found to change early and persistently in response to isolation. This study provides a reliable toolset for studying the effects of isolation on group behavior, including molecular and genetic analysis, and individual and grouped physiological and behavioral analysis in Drosophila melanogaster.
A clinical pilot study was conducted in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization (WHO) diarrheal disease management guidelines on clinical guideline adherence in resource-limited settings. The study took place in a district and sub-district hospital during the fall 2015 cholera season, where both hospitals lacked scales, necessitating weight estimation. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period with a 10-day post-discharge follow-up. A total of 841 patients were enrolled, with 325 in the pre-intervention group and 516 in the intervention group. The primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for prescriptions of intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics, and zinc. During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids decreased at both hospitals, with risk ratios (RRs) of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. The proportion of prescriptions for the recommended antibiotic azithromycin increased at both hospitals, with RRs of 6.9 and 1.6, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased. Zinc adherence also increased. These findings demonstrate that a smartphone-based tool can improve guideline adherence. The study identified opportunities to improve clinical care, including better assessment, weight estimation, and fluid/antibiotic selection. The results support the hypothesis that technology-enabled decision-support tools can promote evidence-based practice in resource-limited settings.
The article presents empirical evidence that the metabolic theory of ecology (MTE) can effectively describe the temperature dependency of within-host parasite dynamics. The study used experimental data from Daphnia magna and its natural microsporidian parasite, Ordospora colligata, to examine the effects of temperature on host and parasite traits, their interactions, and the within-host parasite population dynamics. A mechanistic model of within-host parasite population dynamics was fitted to the data, incorporating MTE-based relationships for host aging and mortality, parasite growth, virulence, and equilibrium abundance. The model accurately predicted host survival, parasite growth, and the cost of infection across a range of temperatures, using fewer parameters than traditional discrete temperature modeling approaches. The results demonstrate the potential of linking simple metabolic models with a mechanistic host-parasite framework to predict temperature responses of parasite population dynamics at the within-host level. This approach provides a valuable tool for understanding the impacts of climate change on host-parasite interactions and disease dynamics. The study's findings support the use of MTE-based thermal relationships to inform classical models of host-parasite dynamics and estimate the net effect of temperature changes on disease prevalence and severity. The simplicity and generality of this framework make it a useful approach for predicting the outcomes and consequences of infections in light of climate change.
The redistribution of somato-dendritic inhibition by GABAergic interneurons plays a crucial role in shaping the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells ( PCs ). However, the contribution of various inhibitory cell types to neuronal information processing is not fully understood. This study proposes a functional role for a network motif consisting of parvalbumin- ( PV ), somatostatin- ( SOM ), and vasoactive intestinal peptide ( VIP ) -expressing interneurons. PV and SOM interneurons control the distribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition onto PCs, while mutual inhibition between VIP and SOM cells translates weak inputs to VIP interneurons into large changes in somato-dendritic inhibition of PCs. A computational model demonstrates that the neuronal and synaptic properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. The study also shows that the SOM-VIP motif allows transient inputs to persistently switch the circuit between two processing modes, in which top-down inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs are either integrated or cancelled. The findings suggest that the interplay between PV, SOM, and VIP interneurons acts as an amplifier that translates weak input onto VIP cells into large changes in the somato-dendritic distribution of inhibition onto PCs. This amplification is supported by mutual inhibition between SOM and VIP neurons, which enables switch-like spatial shifts of somato-dendritic inhibition.
Microbiome-wide association studies (MWAS) compare microbial abundances between two groups of samples to link specific microbes to host phenotypes, such as disease. However, abundance differences can reflect not only direct associations with the phenotype but also indirect effects due to microbial interactions. A study found that microbial interactions can generate a large number of spurious associations that provide no mechanistic insight. Using techniques from statistical physics, the researchers developed a method to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The method, called Direct Association Analysis (DAA), corrected the inflation of p-values in standard association tests and showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had a much higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate production, and the brain-gut axis as important factors in IBD. The study suggests that realistic microbial interactions produce a large number of spurious associations between particular members of the microbiome and phenotypes, which can be removed by a simple procedure based on maximum entropy models. The findings have implications for the interpretation of MWAS results and highlight the need to consider microbial interactions when studying the relationship between microbiota and host phenotypes.
This study compared the effect of Wolbachia infection on the replication and transmission of dengue virus (DENV) and West Nile virus (WNV) in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes using two different infection models: stable transinfected and transiently infected mosquitoes. The results showed that Wolbachia had a similar blocking effect on both viruses in both infection models, but the magnitude of the blocking effect was significantly lower in mosquitoes transiently infected with Wolbachia. Notably, no evidence was found for any enhancement of DENV or WNV (Kunjin strain) infection in Ae. aegypti infected with Wolbachia, suggesting that Wolbachia may be an effective and safe means for restricting transmission of these viruses. The study also found that Wolbachia density was lower in transiently infected mosquitoes compared to stably infected mosquitoes, which may explain the reduced DENV blocking phenotype observed in the transiently infected mosquitoes. The results of this study support the use of Wolbachia as a potential tool for controlling the spread of DENV and WNV, and highlight the importance of considering the host-Wolbachia interaction and the model of infection when studying the effect of Wolbachia on pathogen replication and transmission.
In C. elegans, the cilia shafts of amphid channel and phasmid sensory cilia are subdivided into two regions defined by different microtubule ultrastructure: a proximal doublet-based region adjacent to the transition zone (TZ) and a distal singlet-based region. This study investigated the biogenesis, structure, and composition of the C. elegans ciliary doublet region and the Inversin compartment (InvC). The results show that the InvC is conserved and distinct from the doublet region. The nphp-2 gene, the C. elegans Inversin homolog, and the doublet region genes arl-13, klp-11, and unc-119 are redundantly required for ciliogenesis. These genes can be sorted into two modules: nphp-2+klp-11 and arl-13+unc-119, which are antagonized by the hdac-6 deacetylase. The genes of this network modulate the sizes of the NPHP-2 InvC and ARL-13 doublet region. Glutamylation, a tubulin post-translational modification, is not required for ciliary targeting of InvC and doublet region components, but is modulated by nphp-2, arl-13, and unc-119. The ciliary targeting and restricted localization of NPHP-2, ARL-13, and UNC-119 do not require TZ-, doublet region-, and InvC-associated genes. NPHP-2 requires its calcium binding EF hand domain for targeting to the InvC. The study concludes that the C. elegans InvC is distinct from the doublet region, and that components in these two regions interact to regulate ciliogenesis via cilia placement, ciliary microtubule ultrastructure, and protein localization.
The polarity protein Scribble plays a crucial role in regulating myelination and remyelination in the central nervous system (CNS). Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendroglial development and is up-regulated in mature oligodendrocytes, where it is localized to both developing and mature CNS myelin sheaths. Knockdown of Scribble expression in cultured oligodendroglia results in disrupted morphology and myelination initiation. Conditional elimination of Scribble expression in the myelinating glia of transgenic mice also disrupts myelin initiation in the CNS, both during development and following focal demyelination. Furthermore, Scribble acts to negatively regulate myelin thickness and suppresses the extracellular signal-related kinase (ERK)/mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAP) kinase pathway. Scribble localizes to non-compact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier, where it is required for paranodal axo-glial adhesion. These findings demonstrate an essential role for the evolutionarily-conserved regulators of intracellular polarity in myelination and remyelination. The study suggests that Scribble function is compartmentalized through interactions with different protein complexes at sites of radial or longitudinal growth, and that it plays a critical role in myelin regeneration. The results also indicate that Scribble is restricted to non-compact myelin membranes, and its localization is consistent with a possible role in regulating axo-glial adhesion.
A novel peptide haemolysin, Listeriolysin S, has been identified in a subset of Lineage I Listeria monocytogenes strains. These strains are responsible for the majority of outbreaks of listeriosis. Listeriolysin S is a haemolytic and cytotoxic factor that contributes to the virulence of the pathogen, as demonstrated in murine- and human polymorphonuclear neutrophil-based studies. The gene cluster encoding Listeriolysin S is inducible and strain-variable, being present in a subset of isolates from Lineage I. In silico analysis reveals that gene clusters potentially encoding Sls-like factors are also present in other notorious Gram-positive pathogens, including Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridium botulinum. The biosynthetic enzymes SagBCD, responsible for Listeriolysin S production, function analogously to the microcin B17 modification machinery, McbBCD. The discovery of Listeriolysin S expands the family of modified virulence peptides (MVPs) and sheds light on the genetic basis for the enhanced virulence of a proportion of Lineage I L. monocytogenes strains. This study provides new insights into the pathogenesis of several important Gram-positive pathogens, including L. monocytogenes, S. aureus, and C. botulinum.
The study investigated the expression of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma granulomas caused by different causative agents. Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of macroscopic structures called grains, surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. Immunohistochemical analysis of surgical biopsies from 100 patients with confirmed mycetoma revealed that IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, while MMP-9 was detected mainly in Zones II and III. Notably, MMP-9 expression was higher in Actinomadura pelletierii and Streptomyces somaliensis biopsies compared to Madurella mycetomatis biopsies. A positive correlation was observed between IL-17 and MMP-9 expression levels (p = 0.001). The study also found that MMP-9 levels were directly proportional to disease duration (p < 0.001). However, no significant correlation was found between IL-17 levels and patients' demographic characteristics. The results suggest that IL-17 and MMP-9 are present in mycetoma granulomas and that their expression may be related to the severity of the disease. Further studies are needed to determine the roles of IL-17 and MMP-9 in granuloma formation and to provide insights into mycetoma immunopathogenesis.
The study investigated the molecular recognition mechanism of the Ewing's Sarcoma oncoprotein family (EAD), an intrinsically disordered protein (IDP) that exhibits features of "fuzziness". Fuzziness is characterized by polyvalency, sequence-insensitivity, and a dynamic ensemble of disordered bound-state conformations. The researchers hypothesized that EAD-target binding involves polycation-π interactions between the disordered EAD and basic residues on the target. To test this hypothesis, they evaluated the effects of EAD sequence variations on binding activity and developed a coarse-grained EAD chain model and an analytical model based on interaction between EAD aromatics and surface cations of a generic globular target. The results support the cation-π model and suggest that EAD-target binding is driven by a balance between EAD conformational entropy and favorable EAD-target cation-π contacts. The study provides a general conceptual framework for promiscuous target recognition by polyvalent IDPs, which are implicated in various diseases including cancer. The findings have implications for understanding the physical basis of molecular recognition by IDPs and the role of cation-π interactions in protein-protein interactions.
The study investigated the functional roles of two ATP-dependent proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2, in the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease. Previous research had shown that Lon-1 is upregulated in response to blood exposure in vitro, while Lon-2 is not. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Lon-1 and Lon-2 cluster separately due to differences in their substrate binding domains, suggesting distinct substrate specificities. Recombinant Lon-1 exhibited properties of an ATP-dependent chaperone-protease in vitro but failed to complement an Escherichia coli Lon mutant. In contrast, Lon-2 corrected two characteristic Lon-mutant phenotypes. These findings indicate that Lon-1 and Lon-2 have distinct functional roles in B. burgdorferi. Lon-2 appears to function similarly to the canonical Lon protease, involved in cellular homeostasis. Lon-1, on the other hand, may play a role in host adaptation, particularly during the transition from an arthropod to a warm-blooded host. This is supported by its upregulation in response to blood exposure and its unique presence in the Borrelia genus. The study suggests that Lon-1 may be involved in the remodeling of the spirochete outer surface during a blood meal in the tick. Overall, the results highlight the distinct functional roles of Lon-1 and Lon-2 in B. burgdorferi and their potential importance in the bacterium's life cycle.
The study investigated the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) in preventing Human Immunodeficiency Virus type-1 (HIV-1) infection. Fc gamma receptor (FcyR)-mediated antibody functions, including ADP, are thought to play a crucial role in controlling other viral infections. The researchers measured the ability of HIV-specific antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-1-decorated cells by phagocytes. Surprisingly, they found minimal or no ADP of virions with any of the antibodies tested. However, after coating virions with gp41 or gp41-derived peptides, gp41-specific monoclonal antibodies efficiently mediated phagocytosis. The study also found that a minimum of a few hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagocytosis, similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses that are readily phagocytosed. In contrast, virion-decorated cells were targets for ADP or trogocytosis in the presence of HIV-specific antibodies. The findings suggest that ADP of virions may not play a role in preventing HIV infection, likely due to the paucity of trimers and the inability of virion-bound antibody to cross-link FcyRs on phagocytes. However, ADP or trogocytosis could play a role in clearing HIV-infected cells and cells on the verge of infection. The study's results also suggest that FcγR-dependent functions other than ADP of free virions may be critical for maximal prevention or control of HIV-1 infection by antibody.
The global economic and health burden of human hookworm infection has been estimated using a computational simulation model. According to the study, hookworm infection resulted in 2,126,280 disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) in 2016, using 2004 disability weight estimates, and 4,087,803 DALYs, using 2010 disability weight estimates, excluding cognitive impairment outcomes. The total productivity losses ranged from $7.5 billion to $138.9 billion annually, using gross national income per capita as a proxy for annual wages, and from $2.5 billion to $43.9 billion, using minimum wage as a proxy for annual wages. The study found that the economic and health burden of hookworm infection exceeded published estimates for several diseases that have received more attention, such as rotavirus. The revised Global Burden of Disease study for 2010 reported 3,230,800 DALYs annually due to hookworm among all ages in 21 regions, including disability weights for additional hookworm outcomes and stratified by level of anemia. The study also found that certain large countries transitioning to higher income countries, such as Brazil and China, still face considerable hookworm burden. The global burden of hookworm infection was estimated to be $11.1 billion using a median likelihood of anemia, 2004 disability weight estimates, and gross national income per capita.
This study investigated the effects of hypoxia on axon pathfinding in the developing vertebrate central nervous system (CNS). Using zebrafish (Danio rerio) as a model organism, the researchers found that developmental hypoxia disrupts pathfinding of forebrain neurons, leading to errors in commissural axon crossing. The pathfinding defects were caused by activation of the hypoxia-inducible transcription factor (HIF1) pathway and were mimicked by chemical inducers of the HIF1 pathway or by expression of constitutively active HIF1α. The researchers identified ephrinB2a as a target of HIF1 pathway activation and showed that knockdown of ephrinB2a rescued the guidance errors. EphrinB2a was found to mediate the pathfinding errors via a reverse-signaling mechanism. Magnesium sulfate, used to improve neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm births, was found to protect against pathfinding errors by preventing upregulation of ephrinB2a. The study demonstrates that evolutionarily conserved genetic pathways regulate connectivity changes in the CNS in response to hypoxia and supports a potential neuroprotective role for magnesium. The findings suggest that hypoxia can specifically disrupt vertebrate axon pathfinding and that ephrinB2a is a primary mediator of HIF1 pathway activation.
This study investigated pulmonary abnormalities in mice infected with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM), using high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and histopathological analysis. Male BALB/c mice were intranasally inoculated with P. brasiliensis conidia or phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) as controls. HRCT scans were performed every four weeks to assess pulmonary lesions, lung density, and air structure, while histopathology and histomorphometry were used to analyze lung tissue. Three distinct patterns of lesions were identified: nodular-diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-tumoral. Lesions were predominantly located around the hilus and affected the left lung more frequently. At four weeks post-infection, HRCT revealed peri-bronchial consolidations and increased upper lung density in 80% of infected mice compared to controls. By eight and 12 weeks, consolidation progressed to involve middle lung regions. Histopathology confirmed that HRCT-detected consolidations corresponded to confluent granulomatous reactions, while nodules represented individual compact granulomas. By 16 weeks, confluent granulomas formed pseudo-tumoral masses that obstructed large bronchi. Discrete focal fibrosis was visible around granulomas by histopathology but not by HRCT. This study demonstrates the utility of conventional HRCT in evaluating and quantifying pulmonary damage in experimental PCM, reducing the need for animal sacrifice and providing a more rational approach to studying human lung disease.
Interferon-Gamma Release Assay (Modified QuantiFERON) as a Potential Marker of Infection for Leishmania donovani: A Proof of Concept Study
    A proof-of-concept study investigated the use of an interferon-gamma release assay (IFN-γRA) as a novel marker for latent Leishmania donovani infection. The study modified a commercial QuantiFERON kit to evaluate five different Leishmania-specific antigens: H2B, H2B-PSA2, H2B-Lepp12, crude soluble antigen (CSA), and soluble Leishmania antigen (SLA). The assay was tested on venous blood samples from 13 active visceral leishmaniasis (VL) patients, 15 cured VL patients, 11 non-endemic healthy controls, and 19 healthy endemic controls. The results showed that the SLA-based QuantiFERON assay had a sensitivity of 80% (95% CI = 54.81-92.95) and specificity of 100% (95% CI = 74.12-100) in detecting the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infection. The study found a positive IFN-γ response to stimulation with Leishmania antigen in patients with active VL, which contradicts the conventional finding of a non-proliferative antigen-specific response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells. The highest IFN-γ response was observed with the SLA antigen, with 84.6% of active VL patients showing a positive response. The study suggests that a whole-blood SLA-based QuantiFERON assay can be used to measure the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infection.
The CNFY toxin plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of Yersinia pseudotuberculosis by enhancing the translocation of antiphagocytic Yop effectors and inducing inflammatory responses that lead to tissue destruction, alteration of the intestinal microbiota, and bacterial clearance. However, suppression of CNFY function results in increased interferon-γ-mediated responses, which comprise non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities and tolerogenesis. This process is accompanied by a preterm reprogramming of the pathogen's transcriptional response towards persistence, giving the bacteria a fitness edge against host responses and facilitating the establishment of a commensal-type lifestyle. The removal of CNFY toxin is sufficient to dampen inflammation and evade the host's immune defense, favoring the establishment of Yersinia persistence. The CNFY-triggered process represents a double-edged sword, where the precise mechanisms that dampen inflammation and allow establishment of Yersinia-persistence are still unclear. The overall impact of CNFY suggests a set of immune responses, including differential levels of IL-6, immune modulators, bacteriocidal activities, and anti-inflammatory factors, which may contribute to this process. Suppression of CNFY function shifts the balance of bacteria-triggered inflammation and clearance mechanisms towards induction of immune suppression, promoting the establishment of asymptomatic, persistent infection.
A novel pathogenicity gene, DES1, has been identified in the rice blast fungus Magnaporthe oryzae, which plays a crucial role in suppressing the basal defenses of the host plant. The DES1 gene was discovered by screening for pathogenicity-defective mutants in a T-DNA insertional mutant library. Bioinformatic analysis revealed that DES1 encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown biochemical properties, and its homologs are conserved in filamentous Ascomycetes. Targeted gene deletion of DES1 did not affect developmental morphogenesis, including vegetative growth, conidial germination, appressorium formation, and appressorium-mediated penetration. However, the Δdes1 mutant was hypersensitive to exogenous oxidative stress and exhibited decreased activity and transcription levels of extracellular enzymes, including peroxidases and laccases. In addition, ferrous ion leakage was observed in the Δdes1 mutant. When interacting with a susceptible rice cultivar, rice cells inoculated with the Δdes1 mutant displayed strong defense responses, including the accumulation of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ), autofluorescent materials, and PR gene induction in neighboring tissues. The Δdes1 mutant showed a significant reduction in infectious hyphal extension and pathogenicity. Treatment with diphenyleneiodonium ( DPI ), an inhibitor of NADPH oxidases, suppressed ROS generation and reduced defense responses in plant tissues challenged with the Δdes1 mutant. Furthermore, the Δdes1 mutant recovered its normal infectious growth in DPI-treated plant tissues. These results suggest that DES1 functions as a novel pathogenicity gene that regulates the activity of fungal proteins, compromising ROS-mediated plant defense.
Biomedical researchers evaluated the accuracy of model-based geostatistics (MBG) predictions for Schistosoma haematobium infection in Ghana by comparing them with empiric prevalence values obtained from school surveys at 79 sites. The results showed that using the mean predicted values alone, 21 of the 25 empirically determined ‘high-risk’ schools requiring yearly praziquantel treatment would have been undertreated, and almost 20% of the remaining schools would have been treated despite empirically-determined absence of infection. This translates to 28% of the children in the 79 schools being undertreated and 12% receiving treatment in the absence of any demonstrated need. The study suggests that using the current predictive map for Ghana as a spatial decision support tool by aggregating prevalence estimates to the district level is not adequate for guiding the national program. However, the alternative of assessing each school in potentially endemic areas is not feasible. The researchers propose that predictive risk mapping should be an iterative process that incorporates empiric testing and model refining to create updated versions that meet the needs of disease control operational managers. The study highlights the importance of improving the understanding of the most appropriate way to use predictive risk maps to guide treatment delivery decisions, assessment techniques, and modelling approaches to schistosomiasis.
A heterogeneous mixture of F-series prostaglandins promotes sperm guidance in the Caenorhabditis elegans reproductive tract. These prostaglandins are synthesized from polyunsaturated fatty acid ( PUFA ) precursors provided in yolk lipoprotein complexes by Caenorhabditis elegans oocytes. Genetics and electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry were used to partially delineate F-series prostaglandin metabolism pathways. The results show that omega-6 and omega-3 PUFAs, including arachidonic and eicosapentaenoic acids, are converted into more than 10 structurally related F-series prostaglandins, which function collectively and largely redundantly to promote sperm guidance. Disruption of omega-3 PUFA synthesis triggers compensatory up-regulation of prostaglandins derived from omega-6 PUFAs. F-series prostaglandin synthesis in Caenorhabditis elegans involves biochemical mechanisms distinct from those in mammalian cyclooxygenase-dependent pathways, yet PGF2α stereoisomers are still synthesized. A conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme, whose human homolog is implicated in Bietti's Crystalline Dystrophy, negatively regulates prostaglandin synthesis. The results support the model that multiple cyclooxygenase-independent prostaglandins function together to promote sperm motility important for fertilization. This cyclooxygenase-independent pathway for F-series synthesis may be conserved. The study identifies a conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme that functions to inhibit prostaglandin metabolism, possibly by diverting their precursors into an alternative pathway. The results suggest that Caenorhabditis elegans oocytes secrete a blend of F-series prostaglandins for guiding sperm to the fertilization site.
The development of biotherapeutics is often hindered by their immunogenic potential, which can lead to reduced efficacy and increased risk of adverse reactions. To address this issue, researchers have developed algorithms that optimize proteins for reduced T cell epitope content and high-level function. An in silico analysis of this dual objective design space revealed that there is no single global optimum for protein deimmunization, but rather a spectrum of designs that exhibit tradeoffs between immunogenic potential and molecular function. The leading edge of this design space is the Pareto frontier, which represents the undominated variants that exhibit better performance in both criteria. The Pareto frontier of a therapeutic enzyme was designed, constructed, and evaluated experimentally, and various measures of protein performance were found to map a functional sequence space that correlated well with computational predictions. Eighteen Pareto optimal variants were produced and subjected to a rigorous experimental analysis of key performance parameters, providing new insights into the inherent tradeoffs linking the target enzyme's sequence, function, and immunogenic potential. This work outlines a design-based approach to functional deimmunization of biotherapeutic candidates, which may prove useful in augmenting, accelerating, and de-risking experimental deimmunization efforts. The results demonstrate that incremental deletion of T cell epitopes leads to a relative escalation in concomitant loss of function, highlighting the need for a global approach to protein deimmunization that considers the combined effects of all mutations on immunogenicity and function.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, elevated temperature has been found to increase the frequency of meiotic crossovers (COs), which are essential for proper chromosome segregation during sexual reproduction. COs occur when homologous chromosomes exchange DNA, and their frequency and distribution are regulated by intrinsic and extrinsic factors. The study demonstrates that heat-induced hyper-recombination is mediated by the Type I meiotic recombination pathway, which is sensitive to interference. This pathway is distinct from the Type II pathway, which is insensitive to interference. The research employed a pollen-based visual assay to show that thermal stress-induced COs are generated by the Type I pathway and act additively with Type II pathway perturbations, resulting in an enhanced hyper-recombination phenotype. Furthermore, the study found that the increase in meiotic CO frequency in response to temperature is not a universal response to stress and cannot be replicated by other factors, such as salt stress. The findings provide initial mechanistic insight into how environmental cues modulate plant meiotic recombination and may have practical applications in plant breeding. The study suggests that temperature-dependent modulation of meiotic CO frequency could aid plant breeding without editing the genome or requiring mutant backgrounds. However, the observed reduction in pollen viability at high temperatures may necessitate the use of more modest temperature increases.
Biomedical researchers face a significant challenge in navigating the vast and rapidly evolving scientific literature, particularly in molecular biomedicine. To address this challenge, a novel computational approach has been developed, which combines reading, reasoning, and reporting methods to facilitate analysis of experimental data. This approach, called the Hanalyzer, extracts information from external resources, tracks knowledge provenance, and enriches the knowledge by noting relationships between genes and calculating a combined reliability score. The Hanalyzer combines the knowledge network with a congruent network constructed from experimental data and visualizes the combined network in a tool that facilitates knowledge-based analysis. An implementation of the Hanalyzer was demonstrated on a large-scale gene expression array dataset relevant to craniofacial development, resulting in the creation of hypotheses regarding the roles of four genes never previously characterized as involved in craniofacial development. These hypotheses were validated by further experimental work. The Hanalyzer also includes a Cytoscape plugin, CommonAttributes, which allows users to trace the provenance of links in the knowledge network and access underlying data sources and publications. The approach can be used to identify functional explanations of a gene list by exploiting inferences not available in individual data sources and to generate novel hypotheses by highlighting linkages in the data that are not well supported by existing knowledge.
The study investigated the surface molecules of extracellular vesicles (EVs) secreted by the helminth pathogen Fasciola hepatica and their role in internalisation by host cells. Using a membrane-impermeable biotin reagent, 380 surface proteins were identified on two EV sub-populations (15k and 120k EVs), including virulence factors, membrane transport proteins, and molecules involved in EV biogenesis and trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis revealed that the 120k EVs originated from the parasite's endosomal system, while the 15k EVs were released from the gastrodermal epithelial cells lining the fluke gut. A lectin microarray strategy was used to profile the topology of major surface oligosaccharides on intact fluorogenically-labelled EVs, showing that the glycoconjugates exposed on the surface of the 15k and 120k EV sub-populations were identical but distinct from those on the parasite surface tegument. The EVs were resistant to exo- and endo-glycosidases, but treatment with the glyco-amidase PNGase F drastically remodelled the surface oligosaccharides and blocked EV uptake by host macrophages. In contrast, pre-treatment with antibodies against specific EV surface proteins (DM9-containing protein, CD63 receptor, and myoferlin) significantly enhanced EV internalisation by host cells. The study highlights the diversity of EV biogenesis and trafficking pathways used by F. hepatica and sheds light on the molecular interaction between parasite EVs and host cells.
The study investigated the role of Arabidopsis CDF2 in the regulation of primary microRNAs (pri-miRNAs) at both transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels. CDF2, a cycling DOF transcription factor, interacts with Dicer-like 1 (DCL1) and regulates the accumulation of a population of miRNAs. CDF2 binds directly to the promoters of some miRNA genes, acting as a transcription activator or repressor, and preferentially binds to pri-miRNAs regulated by itself, affecting DCL1-mediated processing of these pri-miRNAs. The study found that CDF2 regulates a group of pri-miRNAs at both transcriptional and posttranscriptional levels to maintain proper levels of mature miRNAs, which is essential for plant development. CDF2 was also found to regulate the expressions of components involved in miRNA biogenesis, suggesting that it may affect miRNA biogenesis through regulating the levels of these components. The study implicated that CDF2 might regulate biogenesis of miRNAs indirectly by regulating the expressions of miRNA processing proteins in addition to its direct roles in transcriptional and posttranscriptional regulations of pri-miRNAs. Furthermore, the study found that CDF2 regulates the expressions of miR156 and miR172, two widely studied miRNAs, which are involved in flowering. The results suggest that CDF2 plays a crucial role in the regulation of miRNA biogenesis and plant development.
Folliculogenesis, a critical process for providing ova for reproductive life, relies on bidirectional communication between the oocyte and granulosa cells. This communication is essential for regulating granulosa cell proliferation and the transport of metabolites from granulosa cells to the oocyte for biosynthesis. However, the underlying mechanism of establishing this communication is not well understood. This study reveals that oocyte geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GGPP), a metabolic intermediate involved in protein geranylgeranylation, plays a crucial role in establishing oocyte-granulosa cell communication. GGPP levels in oocytes increase during early follicular development, and its depletion impairs granulosa cell proliferation, primary-secondary follicle transition, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GGPP depletion inhibits Rho GTPase geranylgeranylation and its GTPase activity, leading to the accumulation of cell junction proteins in the oocyte cytoplasm and failure to maintain physical connection between oocyte and granulosa cells. Additionally, GGPP depletion blocks Rab27a geranylgeranylation, which may account for impaired secretion of oocyte materials such as Gdf9. Furthermore, GGPP administration restores defects in oocyte-granulosa cell contact, granulosa cell proliferation, and primary-secondary follicle transition in Ggpps depletion mice. These findings demonstrate that GGPP-mediated protein geranylgeranylation contributes to the establishment of oocyte-granulosa cell communication and regulates primary-secondary follicle transition, a key phase of folliculogenesis essential for female reproductive function.
A structural model of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) elongation complex with a complete transcription bubble has been generated to investigate the routes of nucleoside triphosphate (NTP) entry during transcription. The model was built by extending the DNA and nascent mRNA strands to 47 and 18 nucleotides in length, respectively, and was equilibrated using molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. The results suggest that the secondary channel is the major route for NTP entry during Pol II transcription, as the percentage of MD conformations containing enough space for NTP loading through the secondary channel is twice higher than that of the main channel. Energetic studies based on MD simulations with NTP loaded in the channels revealed that the diffusion of NTP through the main channel is disfavored by electrostatic repulsion between the NTP and the highly negatively charged backbones of nucleotides in the non-template DNA strand. The structural model of the Pol II elongation complex with a complete transcription bubble is crucial for understanding the NTP loading routes, as the non-template DNA part of the transcription bubble overlaps with the main channel and its conformation is absent in available crystal structures. The findings of this study provide new insights into the mechanism of Pol II transcription and highlight the importance of the secondary channel in NTP entry.
Dengue is a significant public health problem in Thailand and Cambodia, particularly among children under 15 years of age. Although dengue is a reportable disease in both countries, the true burden of the disease is likely underestimated due to underreporting. To estimate the magnitude of underrecognition and establish more accurate disease burden estimates, researchers analyzed laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient dengue cases from prospective cohort studies in Thailand and Cambodia. The studies found that the average annual incidence of laboratory-confirmed dengue was 23/1, 000 in Thailand and 41/1, 000 in Cambodia. Age-group specific multiplication factors ( MFs ) were calculated by comparing cohort study data to national surveillance data and ranged from 0. 4 to 29. These MFs were then applied to country-level reporting data to estimate the true number of dengue cases. The results indicated that in Thailand, a median of 229, 886 dengue cases occurred annually during 2003–2007, while in Cambodia, a median of 111, 178 cases occurred in children under 15 years of age. The average underrecognition of total and inpatient dengue cases was 8. 7 and 2. 6-fold in Thailand, and 9. 1 and 1. 4-fold in Cambodia, respectively. These findings suggest that national surveillance data significantly underrecognize the true burden of dengue disease. Calculating MFs by comparing prospective cohort study data to locally-reported national surveillance data is a useful approach to more accurately assess disease burden.
This study investigated the role of natural killer ( NK ) cells in promoting early CD8 T cell responses against cytomegalovirus ( MCMV ) infection. The researchers used congenic or mutant mice and wild-type versus genetically engineered viruses to examine the consequences of specific defects in NK cell function on antiviral CD8 T cell responses. The results showed that NK cells accelerate CD8 T cell responses against MCMV infection in vivo by limiting interferon-alpha/beta ( IFN-α/β ) production to non-immunosuppressive levels. This is achieved through the early control of MCMV, which reduces the activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDCs ) for cytokine production, preserves conventional dendritic cells ( cDCs ), and accelerates antiviral CD8 T cell responses. In contrast, exogenous IFN-α administration in resistant animals ablates cDCs and delays CD8 T cell activation in the face of NK cell control of viral replication. The study demonstrates that NK cell responses promote the accelerated generation of effector antiviral CD8 T cells during infection by preventing the generation of high, immunosuppressive levels of antiviral cytokines. The findings suggest that NK cells serve not only as effector lymphocytes but also as regulators of immune system function for defenses against viral infections. Overall, the study highlights the critical role of NK cells in promoting optimal initiation of antiviral CD8 T cell responses and preventing innate cytokine shock.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, the expression of 45S rRNA genes is tightly regulated, with only a subset of genes being transcribed under normal growth conditions. Researchers have identified four major rRNA gene variants in A. thaliana and found that disruption of the nucleolin-like protein gene ( Atnuc-L1 ) affects the expression of these variants. Specifically, one variant is induced, while the others are repressed or remain unaltered in Atnuc-L1 mutants. Notably, the most highly represented rRNA gene variant, which is normally inactive in wild-type plants, is reactivated in Atnuc-L1 mutants. The study shows that the accumulated pre-rRNAs in Atnuc-L1 mutants originate from RNA Polymerase I transcription and are processed accurately. Furthermore, disruption of the AtNUC-L1 gene leads to a loss of symmetrical DNA methylation at rRNA genes without affecting histone epigenetic marks. These findings reveal a novel mechanism for rRNA gene transcriptional regulation, in which the nucleolin protein plays a crucial role in controlling active and repressed rRNA gene variants in Arabidopsis. The study suggests that AtNUC-L1 binds to rRNA gene promoter sequences and directs rRNA transcription from the transcription initiation site. The results also indicate that AtNUC-L1 co-localizes with only approximately half of the rRNA loci in the nucleus of wild-type plants, suggesting that it may only associate with potentially transcriptionally active rRNA genes.
The human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) UL29/28 protein interacts with components of the nucleosome remodeling and deacetylase (NuRD) complex, which promotes the accumulation of immediate-early RNA. Histone deacetylation plays a crucial role in regulating HCMV gene expression. Using a rapid immunoisolation method coupled with mass spectrometry, candidate HDAC1-interacting proteins were identified, including HCMV-coded proteins pUL38 and pUL29/28. Reciprocal immunoprecipitations confirmed the interaction between pUL38 and pUL29/28 with HDAC1. HDAC1 is part of the NuRD complex, and pUL29/28 and pUL38 associated with the MTA2 component of NuRD. Knockdown of RBBP4 and CHD4 constituents of NuRD inhibited HCMV immediate-early RNA and viral DNA accumulation, suggesting that multiple components of the NuRD complex are necessary for efficient HCMV replication. The growth of pUL29/28- or pUL38-deficient viruses could not be rescued by treating infected cells with the deacetylase inhibitor trichostatin A. Transient expression of pUL29/28 enhanced the activity of the HCMV major immediate-early promoter in a reporter assay, regardless of pUL38 expression. The induction of the major immediate-early reporter activity by pUL29/28 required functional NuRD components, consistent with the inhibition of immediate-early RNA accumulation after knockdown of RBBP4 and CHD4. These findings suggest that pUL29/28 modifies the NuRD complex to stimulate the accumulation of immediate-early RNAs.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is a major cause of pneumonia in infants, and understanding the immune response to RSV infection is crucial for developing effective countermeasures. This study aimed to elucidate the antibody repertoire following primary RSV infection in young children and its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. Whole-genome-fragment phage display libraries (GFPDL) expressing linear and conformational epitopes in the RSV fusion protein (F) and attachment protein (G) were used to profile infant sera prior to and following RSV infection. The results showed modest changes in the anti-F epitope repertoires post-RSV infection, while a 100-fold increase in the number of bound phages was observed for anti-G antibodies. The G-reactive epitopes spanned the N- and C-terminus of the G ectodomain, along with increased reactivity to the central conserved domain (CCD). Panels of F and G antigenic sites were synthesized to evaluate sera from young children, adolescents, and adults in SPR real-time kinetics assays. A steady increase in RSV-F epitope repertoires from young children to adults was observed, with several novel epitopes identified in pre-fusion F and an immunodominant epitope in the F-p27. In contrast, antibody responses to RSV-G were high following early RSV infection in children but declined significantly in adults. These findings suggest unlinked evolution of anti-F and anti-G responses and provide evidence for immune pressure-driven evolution of RSV-G, which could inform the development of effective countermeasures, including vaccines.
Emodepside, a veterinary anthelmintic, has been shown to have potent macrofilaricidal effects against adult Brugia malayi, a species that causes lymphatic filariasis. Whole-parasite motility measurement and patch-clamp analysis revealed that emodepside inhibits motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. RNA interference (RNAi) knockdown experiments suggested that the SLO-1 K channel is the target of emodepside. Further investigation using heterologously expressed slo-1 isoforms in Xenopus laevis oocytes revealed that the slo-1f isoform, found in male muscles, is more sensitive to emodepside than the slo-1a isoform found in female muscles. Selective RNAi of the slo-1a isoform in female worms increased emodepside potency. In silico modeling identified an emodepside binding pocket in the RCK1 region of the SLO-1 channel, which is affected by alternative splicing in different species of filaria. The study highlights the importance of evaluating sex-dependent effects of anthelmintic compounds to prevent under-dosing of one or the other gender of nematodes. Emodepside has completed first-in-human safety and tolerability studies and is being developed for the treatment of onchocerciasis, a disease caused by Onchocerca volvulus. The results of this study provide new insights into the mode of action of emodepside and its potential as a macrofilaricide.
The Global Program to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (LF) relies on rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) to determine where annual mass drug administration for LF is required and when it can be stopped. However, Loa loa (Loiasis) cross-reactivity with LF RDTs has hindered LF elimination in Loiasis-endemic areas. To address this issue, researchers used the DH6.5 antibody to immunoaffinity purify Loa loa antigens from the sera of individuals with a positive RDT due to Loiasis. Immunoblot analysis revealed many circulating AD12/DH6.5-reactive antigens, and proteomic analysis identified multiple L. loa proteins in LF RDT-positive Loiasis sera. These included both secreted and somatic proteins, suggesting they may be released by dying L. loa adult worms and/or microfilariae. Unlike the single high molecular weight Wuchereria bancrofti circulating filarial antigen present in the blood of persons with bancroftian filariasis, reactive L. loa antigens appeared to be only transiently present in the blood of a subset of persons with Loiasis. These differences can be used to differentiate positive results generated by both species and may lead to improved diagnostic tests for LF and Loiasis. The study suggests that Loiasis cross-reactivity with W. bancrofti RDTs is due to the death of L. loa microfilariae and/or adult worms releasing multiple AD12 glycoproteins into circulation, and that an imbalance between release and clearance of these antigens accounts for their detection in the circulation of some Loiasis patients.
The study identifies a novel ciliary GTPase, RAB-28, associated with the BBSome and intraflagellar transport (IFT) in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. Using whole-organism RNA-Seq libraries, the researchers discovered a signature expression profile highly enriched for transcripts of known ciliary proteins, including FAM-161, CCDC-104, and RPI-1, which were confirmed to be cilium-localized in worms. From a list of 185 candidate ciliary genes, the study uncovered orthologues of human MAP9, YAP, CCDC149, and RAB28 as conserved cilium-associated components. Further analysis of C. elegans RAB-28 revealed that this small GTPase is exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons, where it dynamically associates with IFT trains. The study found that inactive GDP-bound RAB-28 displays no IFT movement and diffuse localization, whereas GTP-bound RAB-28 concentrates at the periciliary membrane in a BBSome-dependent manner and undergoes bidirectional IFT. Functional analyses revealed that while cilium structure, sensory function, and IFT are seemingly normal in a rab-28 null allele, overexpression of predicted GDP or GTP locked variants of RAB-28 perturbs cilium and sensory pore morphogenesis and function. The study presents a new approach for identifying ciliary proteins and unveils RAB28 as an IFT-associated cargo with BBSome-dependent cell autonomous and non-autonomous functions at the ciliary base.
The article presents a study on how the brain represents the outside world using neural responses from cells with stereotyped receptive fields. The researchers used hippocampal place cells as a model system to investigate what can be learned about a space of stimuli using only the action potentials (spikes) of these cells. The results show that one can extract global features of the environment and construct an accurate representation of space, up to an overall scale factor, that can be used to track the animal's position. This is achieved without knowing the place fields or any other functions relating neural responses to position. The study found that simply knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals a surprising amount of structure in the underlying stimulus space. This may enable the brain to construct its own internal representations. The researchers demonstrated that the simple knowledge of which groups of hippocampal place cells fire together is enough to extract global topological features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of physical space, including the animal's position within it. This can be done without prior knowledge of actual place fields or any other independent measurements of position. The study suggests that coarse features of population spiking activity can provide a great deal of information about a physical environment.
The study investigated the role of the NLRP3 inflammasome and IL-1β in the pathogenesis of viral fulminant hepatitis (FH) in mice infected with the murine hepatitis virus strain-3 (MHV-3). The results showed that wild-type mice infected with MHV-3 exhibited severe disease and high mortality, accompanied by significant elevation of IL-1β expression in the serum and liver. In contrast, mice deficient in the IL-1β receptor (IL-1R1-/-) or treated with IL-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1Ra) showed reduced virus replication, disease progression, and mortality. The study also found that IL-1R1 deficiency impaired the production of fibrinogen-like protein-2 (FGL2) in macrophages and reduced CD45+Gr-1high neutrophil infiltration in the liver. Furthermore, mice deficient in p47phox, a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) oxidase subunit, exhibited reduced NLRP3 inflammasome activation and subsequent IL-1β secretion during viral infection. Mice deficient in NLRP3 and Caspase-1, essential components of the inflammasome complex, also showed reduced IL-1β induction and ameliorated hepatitis. The study demonstrated that the ROS/NLRP3/IL-1β axis plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of viral FH, suggesting that targeting this pathway may lead to the development of efficient treatments for human viral FH and other severe inflammatory diseases.
In a study conducted in Malawi, researchers used multiplex real-time PCR to investigate the association between hookworm infections and severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children. The results showed that 34.1% of severely anemic cases and 27.0% of non-severely anemic controls had hookworm infections, with a significantly higher prevalence of Ancylostoma duodenale (26.1%) compared to Necator americanus (4.9%). The study found that moderate and high-load A. duodenale infections were positively associated with severe anemia, with adjusted odds ratios of 2.49 and 9.04, respectively. Additionally, iron deficiency was positively associated with the intensity of A. duodenale infection, with adjusted odds ratios of 3.63, 16.98, and 44.91 for low, moderate, and high-load infections, respectively. The study highlights the need for quantitative and species-specific screening of hookworm infections to combat severe anemia and iron deficiency in children living in resource-poor settings. The results suggest that A. duodenale is a key factor in the etiology of severe anemia and iron deficiency in Malawian pre-school children, and that multiplex real-time PCR is a powerful diagnostic tool for public health research in this area. The study's findings have significant implications for the development of targeted interventions to address the burden of hookworm infections in sub-Saharan Africa.
During Caenorhabditis elegans meiosis, DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) can be repaired via homologous recombination ( HR ) or non-homologous end joining ( NHEJ ). However, only HR can generate the interhomolog crossovers ( COs ) necessary for meiotic chromosome segregation. COM-1, the homolog of CtIP/Sae2/Ctp1, is identified as a crucial regulator of DSB repair pathway choice during C. elegans gametogenesis. COM-1-deficient germ cells repair meiotic DSBs via the error-prone NHEJ pathway, resulting in a lack of COs, extensive chromosomal aggregation, and near-complete embryonic lethality. In contrast to its yeast counterparts, COM-1 is not required for Spo11 removal and initiation of meiotic DSB repair, but instead promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting the NHEJ complex Ku. COM-1 acts parallel to the nuclease EXO-1 to promote interhomolog HR at the early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase and safeguards timely CO formation. Both COM-1 and EXO-1 are dispensable for RAD-51 recruitment at the late pachytene stage, when homolog-independent repair pathways predominate. The study reveals the potentially lethal properties of NHEJ during meiosis and identifies a critical role for COM-1 in NHEJ inhibition and CO assurance in germ cells.
This study investigated the humoral immune response of goats to Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, after aerosol exposure. A caprine model of melioidosis was developed to characterize the immune response and identify immunogenic proteins for diagnostic and vaccine development. Outbred goats were infected with B. pseudomallei via intratracheal aerosol, and antigenic protein profiling was generated from the infecting strain MSHR511. Humoral immune responses were analyzed by ELISA and western blot, and antigenic proteins were identified by mass spectrometry. The results showed a greater humoral response with IgG antibodies compared to IgM antibodies throughout the course of the infection. Pre-infection sera showed reactivity to multiple immunogenic proteins, and after infection, the number of IgG reactive proteins increased as the disease progressed. Early-stage infection showed immune reaction to chaperone proteins GroEL, EF-Tu, and DnaK, which were detected in all serum samples after infection. The heat shock protein GroEL1 elicited the strongest goat antibody immune response compared to other antigens. An overall proteomic comparison between the goat model and human sera showed that many immune-reactive proteins are common between humans and goats with melioidosis. The study demonstrates that the B. pseudomallei aerosol challenge induced an increasing and diverse antibody response over the disease progress in the goats, and the results provide insights into the humoral response to B. pseudomallei in an experimental goat model for melioidosis.
The activation of cyclin B1–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk1) is a crucial event that initiates mitotic entry in human cells. A positive feedback loop at the end of G2 phase triggers the activation of Cdk1, which is then inactivated by the anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome (APC/C)-dependent destruction of cyclin B1 in metaphase, allowing mitotic exit and cell division. However, the kinetics of Cdk1 activation during mitosis have been poorly understood. Using a novel approach, researchers have quantified the temporal development of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity in single cells by measuring dephosphorylation of Cdk1 and phosphorylation of the APC/C3 target. The results show that cyclin B1–Cdk1 continues to be activated after centrosome separation and that cytoplasmic cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity can be maintained even when cyclin B1 translocates to the nucleus in prophase. A model describing cyclin B1–Cdk1 activation in human cells reveals a bistable circuit, with distinct thresholds for cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity controlling successive mitotic events. The study proposes that gradually increasing cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity after centrosome separation is critical to coordinate mitotic progression. The findings suggest that mitotic cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity needs to further increase after mitotic entry and pass a threshold before metaphase to allow activation of the machinery required for efficient mitotic progression and initiation of mitotic exit.
The development of a neutralizing antibody (Nab)-based vaccine against human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) remains a significant challenge due to the virus's high genetic diversity. HIV-1 superinfection (SI), defined as sequential infections from different source partners, has been shown to lead to a broader and more potent Nab response compared to single infection. However, it is unclear whether SI impacts epitope specificity and whether the epitopes targeted after SI differ from those targeted after single infection. This study examined the post-SI Nab responses in 21 Kenyan women who were exposed to subtypes A, C, and D and superinfected after a median time of approximately 1.07 years following initial infection. Plasma samples were collected at a median time point of approximately 2.72 years post-SI. The study focused on four main epitopes on the HIV-1 Envelope, including the CD4-binding site, a V1/V2 glycan, the N332 supersite in V3, and the membrane proximal external region of gp41. Using standard epitope mapping techniques, the study found that SI did not induce a dominant Nab response to any one of these epitopes in the 21 women. Computational sera delineation analyses also suggested that 20 of the 21 superinfected women's Nab responses could not be ascribed a single specificity with high confidence. These findings are consistent with a model in which SI with diverse subtypes promotes the development of a broad polyclonal Nab response, providing support for vaccine designs using multivalent HIV immunogens to elicit a diverse repertoire of Nabs.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is a leading cause of neurological disabilities in children worldwide. The virus dysregulates the Notch signaling pathway in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs), which are essential for fetal brain development. Hairy and Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes1) is a critical downstream effector of Notch signaling that regulates NPC fate and differentiation. In this study, researchers investigated the effect of HCMV infection on Hes1 protein levels in NPCs. They found that HCMV infection downregulates Hes1 protein levels through the HCMV 72-kDa immediate-early 1 protein (IE1), which assembles a ubiquitination complex and promotes Hes1 ubiquitination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase. This leads to proteasomal degradation of Hes1. The study also identified Sp100A, a component of PML nuclear bodies, as another target of IE1-mediated ubiquitination. The C-terminal acidic region of IE1, spanning amino acids 451 to 475, is required for IE1/Hes1 physical interaction and IE1-mediated Hes1 ubiquitination. The findings suggest a novel mechanism linking downregulation of Hes1 protein to neurodevelopmental disorders caused by HCMV infection. This study also identifies IE1 as the first potential HCMV-encoded E3 ubiquitin ligase, providing new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying HCMV-induced neurodevelopmental disorders.
This study investigated the relationship between transcription factor binding and gene expression in Drosophila embryos across four species: D. melanogaster, D. yakuba, D. pseudoobscura, and D. virilis. The researchers used ChIP-seq to measure genome-wide binding of four transcription factors involved in early anterior-posterior patterning and mRNA-seq to quantify gene expression. The results showed that mRNA levels are more conserved than individual transcription factor binding events, and changes in gene expression are poorly explained by changes in adjacent transcription factor binding. However, highly bound sites, sites bound by multiple factors, and sites near genes are conserved more frequently than other binding sites, suggesting that a significant amount of transcription factor binding is weak or non-functional and not subject to purifying selection. The study found that transcription factor binding has diverged considerably within the Drosophila genus, with relatively few regions bound by any factor in all four species. The researchers identified two potential genetic sources of binding divergence, including alterations of specific motifs for the transcription factors BCD, HB, GT, and KR. The study also found that mRNA levels are highly correlated between species, with the correlation decaying with phylogenetic distance. Overall, the results suggest that transcription factor binding has undergone extensive divergence in Drosophila embryos, with little effect on downstream gene expression.
A large-scale epidemiological study was conducted in two primary health centres in Thanjavur district, India, to assess the impact of eight rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) for lymphatic filariasis. The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the current monitoring and evaluation guidelines for the programme to eliminate lymphatic filariasis. The study found that the prevalence and intensity of microfilariae (Mf) in the surveyed population were 0.2% and 0.004, respectively, while the corresponding values for antigenaemia (Ag) were 2.3% and 17.3 Ag-units. Although the Mf levels in the survey and sentinel/spot check sites were less than 1%, and Ag levels were less than 2% in children, the study identified 7 "residual" and 17 "transmission" hotspots. These hotspots were characterized by Mf prevalence of 1% or more, irrespective of Ag status in children, and at least one Ag-positive child born during the MDA period. The study also found that antigenaemic persons were clustered both at household and site levels. The results suggest that the current monitoring and evaluation guidelines may miss sites with transmission potential and that a threshold value of 1% Ag-prevalence in children may be a more suitable indicator for stopping MDA. The study highlights the need for developing good surveillance strategies for detecting hotspots and adopting evidence-based sampling strategies and evaluation unit size for transmission assessment surveys.
A systematic literature review was conducted to assess the community-effectiveness of temephos, an organophosphate larvicide, in controlling dengue vectors and disease transmission when used as a single intervention or in combination with other interventions. The review included 27 studies, of which 11 were single intervention studies and 16 were combined intervention studies. The results showed that temephos was effective in reducing entomological indices when used as a single intervention, but this effect was not sustained over time or was absent when used in combination with other chemical vector control methods. The community-effectiveness of temephos was found to be dependent on various factors, including the quality of delivery, water turnover rate, type of water, and environmental factors such as organic debris, temperature, and exposure to sunlight. Additionally, the timing of temephos deployment and its need for reapplication, as well as behavioral and operational factors, were identified as limitations. There was no evidence to suggest that temephos use is associated with reductions in dengue transmission. The review highlights that temephos is one of the most widely used interventions against dengue vectors worldwide, but its effectiveness can vary greatly. The lack of data relating reductions in entomological indices to reductions in dengue transmission remains a significant knowledge gap in the area of dengue epidemiology and vector control efficacy.
The Ctf19 kinetochore subcomplex and the replication fork-associated factor, Csm3, play crucial roles in the establishment of cohesion at the pericentromere in budding yeast. The pericentromere is a region surrounding the centromere where cohesin, a protein complex that holds sister chromatids together, is most abundant. The Ctf19 complex and Csm3 act through distinct mechanisms to mediate pericentromeric cohesion. Components of the Ctf19 complex, including Iml3 and Chl4, direct the increased association of cohesin with the pericentromere. In contrast, Csm3 is essential for ensuring the functionality of cohesin in holding sister centromeres together. Cells lacking Csm3 show additive cohesion defects in combination with mutants in the Ctf19 complex. Delaying DNA replication rescues the cohesion defect observed in cells lacking Ctf19 complex components, but not Csm3. The Ctf19 complex ensures additional loading of cohesin at centromeres prior to passage of the replication fork, thereby ensuring its incorporation into functional linkages through a process requiring Csm3. This dedicated pathway of cohesin loading is essential to ensure that cohesin is in place prior to passage of the replication fork early in S phase. The Ctf19 complex and Csm3 are highly conserved, suggesting that a similar mechanism of kinetochore-driven cohesion establishment may operate in other organisms.
A recent study investigated the serum metabolome and lipidome changes in adult patients with primary dengue infection using liquid chromatography- and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. The study analyzed serum samples from 44 patients at three stages of infection: early febrile, defervescence, and convalescence. The analysis identified 60 differential metabolites, primarily free fatty acids, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids, which were associated with perturbed metabolic pathways such as fatty acid biosynthesis and β-oxidation, phospholipid catabolism, and steroid hormone pathway. The study found that phospholipids and sphingolipids were significantly perturbed during the early stages of infection and normalized to control levels at the convalescent stage, suggesting their potential utility as prognostic markers. The analysis revealed that DENV infection causes temporally distinct serum metabolome and lipidome changes, and many of the differential metabolites are involved in acute inflammatory responses. The study suggests that early anti-inflammatory responses work in concert to modulate early pro-inflammatory processes, preventing the host from developing pathologies due to excessive or prolonged inflammation. The findings provide a detailed description of the metabolome changes in patients with acute dengue infection and offer a global molecular view of the underlying mechanisms of dengue pathogenesis. The study's results may be used to monitor disease progression and evaluate the efficacy of therapeutic interventions.
This study aimed to map and analyze global Neglected Tropical Disease (NTD) research with an affiliation to Germany using co-authorship networks. A SCOPUS database search was conducted for articles with German author affiliations published between 2002 and 2012 on kinetoplastid and helminth diseases. The analysis identified 1, 187 publications with at least one German author affiliation out of 26, 833 worldwide publications addressing 11 diseases. From these, 4, 007 individual authors and 863 research institutions were extracted to construct co-author networks. The majority of co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries and Brazil. Collaborations with partners on the African continent were scattered. NTD research within Germany was distributed among 220 research institutions. Strong performers on an individual level were identified using classic parameters and social network analysis. The research network characteristics varied strongly between diseases. The share of NTD publications with German affiliations is approximately half of its share in other fields of medical research. A geospatial analysis of research collaborations with partners abroad can support decisions to strengthen research capacity, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. Identifying knowledge hubs within individual researcher networks complements traditional scientometric indicators to identify opportunities for collaboration. The findings contribute to the prioritization of efforts in German NTD research at a time of impending local and global policy decisions.
The Haitian Ministry of Public Health and Population, in collaboration with international partners, has successfully implemented a mass drug administration (MDA) program to control lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) since 2000. By 2012, the program had reached full national scale, achieving 100% geographical coverage for LF and consistently exceeding epidemiological targets for both LF and STH. The program's success can be attributed to several key elements, including strong community awareness through a multi-channel communication and education campaign, community trust in voluntary drug distributors, directly observed treatment, easy access to treatment posts, and quality data collection. These strategies have resulted in a significant reduction in the burden of infection, with 45 communes reaching the target threshold for stopping treatment for LF. The program has also established a strong foundation for ongoing STH control. By leveraging sustained international support, Haiti has made steady progress toward LF elimination and is poised to address future challenges, such as maintaining control of STH infections after the LF treatment platform ceases and ensuring morbidity management for patients with lymphatic filarial disease. The program's success highlights the importance of evidence-based implementation strategies, community engagement, and directly observed treatment in achieving high treatment coverage and reducing the burden of NTDs.
In the alphaproteobacterium Sinorhizobium meliloti, proper regulation of the cell cycle is crucial for coordinating genome replication, segregation, and cell division. During symbiosis with legume hosts, S. meliloti undergoes cellular differentiation, resulting in massive genome amplification, cell branching and/or elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. The master regulator CtrA plays a key role in this process, similar to its function in Caulobacter crescentus. However, the regulatory circuit driving cell cycle progression in S. meliloti is not well characterized.
