Furthermore, co-expression of ToMV 130K protein with TOM1 and ARL8 in yeast resulted in the detection of RNA 5′-capping activity in the membrane fraction, which was undetectable or very weak when the 130K protein was expressed alone or with either TOM1 or ARL8. These results suggest that TOM1 and ARL8 are components of ToMV RNA replication complexes and play crucial roles in activating the replication proteins' RNA synthesizing and capping functions.
Inhibitory interneurons play a crucial role in shaping the firing patterns of principal neurons in various brain systems, including the locust olfactory circuit. Two basic motifs of inhibition have been identified: feed-forward ( FF ) and feedback ( FB ) inhibition. In the locust, a subset of lateral horn interneurons ( LHNs ) was thought to provide FF inhibition onto Kenyon cells ( KCs ) to maintain their sparse firing. However, a single inhibitory cell, the giant GABAergic neuron ( GGN ), has been found to be the primary source of inhibition in the mushroom body, and its inhibition is mediated by a FB loop including KCs and the GGN. To clarify the differences between FF and FB inhibition, a model of the locust olfactory system was developed. The results showed that both inhibitory motifs can maintain sparse KC responses and provide optimal odor discrimination. However, only FB inhibition can create a phase response consistent with in vivo data. The findings suggest that GGN is potentially capable of providing the primary source of inhibition to KCs. The study highlights the importance of understanding how inhibitory motifs impact post-synaptic neuronal activity, which could reveal unknown inhibitory structures within biological networks. The results also indicate that GGN-mediated inhibition affects both KCs and LHNs, although they respond differently to odor presentations. Overall, the study provides general rules for FF versus FB inhibition and sheds light on the role of GGN in the locust olfactory circuit.
A novel dual combined real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) assay has been developed for the diagnosis of lyssavirus infection, including rabies, in animals and humans. The assay combines two complementary techniques: a probe-based (TaqMan) RT-qPCR for detecting the rabies virus species (pan-RABV RT-qPCR) and a second reaction using an intercalating dye (SYBR Green) to detect other lyssavirus species (pan-lyssa RT-qPCR). The performance parameters of this combined assay were evaluated with a large panel of primary animal samples covering almost all the genetic variability encountered at the viral species level. The method was also evaluated for the diagnosis of human rabies on 211 biological samples, including saliva, skin, and brain biopsies. The assay detected all 41 human cases of rabies tested and confirmed the sensitivity and interest of skin biopsy (91.5%) and saliva (54%) samples for intra-vitam diagnosis of human rabies. The method was successfully implemented in two rabies reference laboratories in enzootic countries (Cambodia and Morocco). This combined RT-qPCR method constitutes a relevant, useful, and validated tool for the diagnosis of rabies in both humans and animals, and represents a promising tool for lyssavirus surveillance. The assay has high sensitivity and specificity, and is able to detect a large panel of animal lyssavirus samples.
In the Eastern Region of Ghana, an outbreak of tsetse-transmitted trypanosomiasis resulted in over 50% losses of domestic pigs in 2007. To mitigate this issue, a control trial was conducted from May to October 2007 to assess the efficacy of insecticide-treated mosquito fences in controlling tsetse flies. Two villages were selected, one as a control and the other as an experimental site where 24 pigsties were protected with insecticide-treated mosquito fences. The fences, made of 100 cm high, 150 denier polyester with 100 mg/m2 deltamethrin and a UV protector, were attached to surrounding timber poles and planks. Bi-monthly monitoring of tsetse densities using geo-referenced bi-conical traps showed a reduction of over 90% in the protected village within two months, with further reductions exceeding 95% in subsequent months. In contrast, the tsetse population in the control village remained unaffected, displaying only seasonal variations. The trypanosome prevalence in pigs was also significantly reduced in the protected village, decreasing from 76% to 16% after three months and to 8% after six months, compared to 84% and 60% in the control group, respectively. These findings suggest that insecticide-treated mosquito fences are an effective and sustainable method for controlling tsetse flies and reducing the risk of trypanosomiasis in domestic pigs in resource-poor areas of Ghana.
A survey of 441 biomedical journal articles published between 2000 and 2014 found a lack of reproducibility and transparency in the scientific literature. Only one study provided a full protocol, and none made all raw data directly available. Replication studies were rare, with only four identified, and only 16 studies had their data included in a subsequent systematic review or meta-analysis. The majority of studies did not mention funding or conflicts of interest, although there was a significant decrease in the percentage of articles with no statement of conflict from 94.4% in 2000 to 34.6% in 2014. In contrast, the percentage of articles reporting statements of conflicts or no conflicts increased over the same period. Articles published in clinical medicine journals were more likely to lack information on funding and to have private funding compared to other fields. The study found no significant differences between replication, article citation for systematic review and/or meta-analysis, and statements of conflict. However, articles in clinical medicine journals were more likely to not mention funding and less likely to have a PubMed Central reference number (PMCID) compared to other fields. The study provides baseline data to compare future progress in improving reproducibility and transparency in the scientific literature.
During primary pneumonic plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, a biphasic progression occurs, with an initial pre-inflammatory phase allowing bacterial growth in the absence of host inflammation, followed by a pro-inflammatory phase characterized by extensive neutrophil influx, inflammatory cytokine storm, and severe tissue destruction. To investigate the early host cell targets of Y. pestis during primary pneumonic plague, a FRET-based probe was used to quantify the injection of effector proteins by the Y. pestis type III secretion system. The results show that Y. pestis targets alveolar macrophages early during infection of mice, followed by a switch in host cell preference to neutrophils. Depletion of approximately 92% of alveolar macrophages had little to no effect on bacterial burden in the lung, suggesting that macrophages are not involved in limiting Yersinia survival in the lung. In contrast, the ability of Y. pestis to create a localized protective environment in the lungs early during pneumonic plague suggests that it deactivates host innate immune responses. The study demonstrates that Y. pestis targets innate immune cell populations early in the lung via type III secretion of Yop effectors, and that neutrophil influx is unable to limit bacterial growth in the lung and is ultimately responsible for the severe inflammation during the lethal pro-inflammatory phase. These findings provide new insights into the early host cell targets of Y. pestis during primary pneumonic plague.
A study was conducted in an urban area in Southeast Brazil to evaluate the performance of serology in identifying asymptomatic visceral leishmaniasis (VL) infection in a cohort of 136 participants with a two-year follow-up period. Blood samples were collected in 2001 and tested using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) with three different antigens: Leishmania infantum and Leishmania amazonensis crude antigens, and rK39 recombinant protein. The results were compared to molecular biology techniques, including PCR with Leishmania-generic primer followed by hybridization using L. infantum probe, and PCR with specific primer to L. donovani complex. The study found that kala-azar patients showed high reactivity in ELISAs, while asymptomatic individuals presented low reactivity against the antigens tested. The rK39 antigen showed higher specificity (73.7%) than Leishmania amazonensis (52.6%) and Leishmania infantum antigens (36.8%), but lower sensitivity (26.5%). The study concluded that serological tests were inaccurate for diagnosing asymptomatic infections compared to molecular methods, which may lead to misclassification bias in population studies. The results suggest that studies using serological assays to estimate prevalence, evaluate intervention programs, or identify risk factors for Leishmania infection may have had their results compromised. The study highlights the importance of using molecular techniques for accurate diagnosis of VL, particularly in asymptomatic cases.
This study employed microarray analysis to investigate the silencing of long terminal repeat (LTR) retrotransposons in mouse embryonic stem cells. The researchers used Illumina and Affymetrix gene expression microarray platforms to monitor the expression of retrotransposons and identified the histone deacetylase Hdac1 as a component of the retrotransposon silencing machinery in these cells. The study also revealed that multiple silencing mechanisms, including DNA methylation, Eset-mediated histone modification, and Ring1B/Eed-containing polycomb repressive complexes, are independently targeted to retrotransposons in embryonic stem cells. Furthermore, the analysis suggested that different genomic copies of the same retrotransposon can be differentially sensitive to these silencing mechanisms, and that a complex interplay between silencing mechanisms represses retrotransposon loci in germ cells and embryonic stem cells. The study also identified new target retrotransposons for polycomb repressive complexes and Hdac1 histone deacetylase in mouse embryonic stem cells, and demonstrated that between one and two thirds of all retrotransposons in the mouse genome are represented by probes on the microarray platforms analyzed. The findings of this study provide new insights into the regulation of retrotransposons in mammals and highlight the importance of multiple silencing mechanisms in protecting the mammalian genome from retrotransposition.
Arabidopsis thaliana cryptochrome 2 (CRY2) plays a crucial role in mediating light control of flowering time. CRY2 interacts with CIB1, a bHLH protein, in response to blue light to activate the transcription of Flowering Locus T (FT). In vitro, CIB1 binds to the canonical E-box (CACGTG) with higher affinity than to non-canonical E-box (CANNTG) sequences. However, in vivo, CIB1 binds to the chromatin region of the FT promoter, which contains non-canonical E-box sequences. The study reveals that CRY2 also interacts with at least CIB5 in response to blue light, but not in darkness or in response to other wavelengths of light. Genetic analysis demonstrates that CIB1, CIB2, CIB4, and CIB5 act redundantly to activate FT transcription and are positive regulators of CRY2-mediated flowering. Furthermore, CIB1 and other CIB proteins form heterodimers, which have a higher binding affinity to non-canonical E-box sequences than CIB homodimers. This heterodimerization explains why CIB1 and other CIBs bind to non-canonical E-boxes at the FT promoter in vivo. The expression of CIB proteins is specifically regulated by blue light, consistent with the hypothesis that different CIB proteins play similar roles in CRY2-mediated blue light signaling. The study demonstrates that CIBs function redundantly in regulating CRY2-dependent flowering and that different CIBs form heterodimers to interact with non-canonical E-box DNA in vivo.
An economic analysis was conducted to evaluate the impact of overseas and domestic treatment and screening options for intestinal helminth infections among US-bound refugees from Asia. The study examined the costs and benefits of four interventions: no program, domestic screening and treatment, overseas presumptive treatment with albendazole and ivermectin, and overseas albendazole and domestic screening for Strongyloides. A decision tree model was developed to estimate the cost and health impacts of these interventions on an annual cohort of 27,700 US-bound Asian refugees. The results showed that the "No Program" option was the least expensive but also the least effective, with 145 outpatient cases, 4 hospitalizations, and 0.67 deaths discounted over a 60-year period. In contrast, the "Overseas Albendazole and Ivermectin" option was the most effective, reducing outpatient cases, deaths, and hospitalizations by around 80% at an estimated net cost of $458,718 per death averted. The study found that overseas presumptive treatment for US-bound refugees is a cost-effective intervention that is less expensive and at least as effective as domestic screening and treatment programs. The addition of ivermectin to albendazole reduced the prevalence of chronic strongyloidiasis and the probability of rare but potentially fatal disseminated strongyloidiasis. The results suggest that overseas presumptive treatment with albendazole and ivermectin is the most effective option for reducing the burden of intestinal helminth infections among US-bound refugees from Asia.
A new species of microsporidian parasite, Nematocida displodere, has been discovered in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. This parasite exhibits a unique tissue tropism, infecting and replicating in multiple host tissues, including the epidermis, muscle, neurons, intestine, coelomocytes, and seam cells. In contrast, previously described microsporidian parasites of C. elegans, such as Nematocida parisii and Nematocida sp. 1, exclusively infect and replicate in the intestine. The life cycle of N. displodere has been characterized, including pathogen entry, intracellular replication, and exit. The parasite's genome has been sequenced and compared to those of N. parisii and Nematocida sp. 1, revealing that N. displodere is the earliest diverging species of the Nematocida genus. Notably, over 10% of the proteins encoded by the N. displodere genome belong to a single species-specific family of RING-domain containing proteins of unknown function, which may mediate interactions with the host. The discovery of N. displodere provides a powerful whole-animal model to investigate factors responsible for pathogen growth in different tissue niches. This study highlights the complexity of host-microbe interactions and the diversity of tissue tropism exhibited by microsporidian parasites.
The Cockayne syndrome complementation group B (CSB) protein plays a crucial role in transcription-coupled DNA repair, a process essential for maintaining genome stability. Mutations in CSB are associated with Cockayne syndrome, a devastating disease characterized by premature aging, sun sensitivity, and neurological and developmental defects. Research has shown that CSB belongs to the SWI2/SNF2 family of ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers, but the extent of its chromatin remodeling activity and its role in DNA repair was unknown. This study reveals that CSB repositions nucleosomes in an ATP-dependent manner and that this activity is significantly enhanced by NAP1-like histone chaperones, which are identified as new CSB-binding partners. The study demonstrates that chromatin remodeling by the combined activities of CSB and NAP1-like chaperones is necessary for efficient transcription-coupled DNA repair. Furthermore, the study shows that chromatin remodeling and repair protein recruitment mediated by CSB are separable activities. The findings of this study provide new insights into the functions of chromatin remodeling by CSB in transcription-coupled DNA repair and the underlying mechanisms of Cockayne syndrome. The study also highlights the collaboration between CSB and NAP1-like histone chaperones, adding a new dimension to our understanding of how ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers and histone chaperones regulate chromatin structure.
A recent study has generated a detailed map of epigenetic variation in the human genome by identifying clusters of CpG sites with high inter-individual variation, termed Variably Methylated Regions (VMRs). VMRs were found to occur preferentially at enhancers and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs) in five purified cell types. While most VMRs have high heritability, a subset shows highly correlated variation in trans, forming co-regulated networks with low heritability that differ between cell types and are enriched for specific transcription factor binding sites and biological pathways relevant to each tissue. For example, in T cells, a network of 95 co-regulated VMRs was identified, enriched for genes involved in T-cell activation, while in fibroblasts, a network of 34 co-regulated VMRs was found, comprising all four HOX gene clusters and enriched for control of tissue growth. In neurons, a network of 18 VMRs was identified, enriched for roles in synaptic signaling. The study also demonstrated that some VMR networks are responsive to environmental conditions, with methylation levels at these loci changing in a coordinated fashion in trans dependent on cellular growth. Notably, environmentally-responsive VMRs showed a strong enrichment for imprinted loci, suggesting that these are particularly sensitive to environmental conditions. Overall, the study provides a comprehensive map of common epigenetic variation in the human genome, highlighting the interplay between genetic and environmental factors in shaping epigenetic variation.
The diagnostic sensitivity of dengue rapid test assays can be significantly enhanced by using a combined antigen and antibody testing approach. A study evaluated the performance of a newly developed Panbio Dengue Early Rapid test for non-structural protein 1 (NS1) in combination with a commercial IgM/IgG rapid test. The test was evaluated in a retrospective study in Vietnam with 198 acute laboratory-confirmed positive and 100 negative samples, and in Malaysia with 263 laboratory-confirmed positive and 30 negative samples. The results showed that the sensitivity and specificity of the test in Vietnam were 69.2% (95% CI: 62.8% to 75.6%) and 96% (95% CI: 92.2% to 99.8%), respectively. In Malaysia, the performance was similar, with 68.9% sensitivity (95% CI: 61.8% to 76.1%) and 96.7% specificity (95% CI: 82.8% to 99.9%). When the Dengue Early Rapid test was used in combination with the IgM/IgG test, the sensitivity increased to 93.0%. The study found that using dengue NS1 antigen detection in combination with anti-glycoprotein E IgM and IgG serology can significantly increase the sensitivity of acute dengue diagnosis and extend the possible window of detection to include very early acute samples. The results suggest that the Panbio Dengue Early Rapid test is a sensitive and specific rapid test for dengue NS1, and its use in combination with an IgM/IgG rapid test can provide optimal diagnostic sensitivity for acute dengue.
A new computational method, Transat, has been developed to predict the conserved helices of functional RNA structures, including transient, pseudo-knotted, and alternative structures. Traditional RNA structure prediction methods assume a unique functional RNA structure and do not account for features required for in vivo folding. To address this limitation, Transat uses a comparative approach to detect conserved helices of high statistical significance in evolutionarily related RNA genes. The method has been comprehensively evaluated and shown to predict the structural features of known reference structures, including pseudo-knotted and alternative configurations. Transat can also identify unstructured sub-sequences bound by other molecules and provide evidence for new helices that may define folding pathways. The results support the notion that homologous RNA sequences not only assume similar reference RNA structures but also fold similarly in vivo. Unlike existing methods, Transat works in a comparative way, highlighting conserved features and not requiring a detailed knowledge of the cellular environment. This approach has the advantage of not being able to predict features as a function of time, but it provides a more accurate representation of RNA folding pathways in vivo. The predictions made by Transat are expected to enable more comprehensive and systematic studies of RNA folding pathways and alternative structural configurations, providing useful input to the design and interpretation of future experiments.
The highly buffered Arabidopsis immune signaling network conceals the functions of its components by allowing different parts of the network to compensate for the loss of one another’s functions when targeted and disabled by pathogen effectors. A network reconstitution strategy was employed to resolve systems-level regulatory mechanisms underlying the Arabidopsis transcriptome response to the immune stimulant flagellin-22 ( flg22 ). This approach involved disassembling and stepwise reassembling the plant immune network that mediates Pattern-Triggered-Immunity ( PTI ). The results show widespread evidence of interactions among major sub-networks, known as sectors, in the flg22-responsive transcriptome. These interactions result in network buffering, which conceals the identity of network components. The regulatory mechanisms resolved by this approach reveal unexpected patterns for how the jasmonate ( JA ), ethylene ( ET ), phytoalexin-deficient 4 ( PAD4 ), and salicylate ( SA ) signaling sectors control the transcriptional response to flg22. The study demonstrates that many of these regulatory mechanisms are not detectable by traditional genetic approaches, such as single-gene null-mutant analysis. Similar to potential pathogenic perturbations, null-mutant effects on immune signaling can be buffered by the network. The findings highlight the effectiveness of a systems biology approach, network reconstitution, in elucidating the dynamical component functions of the plant immune signaling network. This approach can help decipher the regulation of complex networks, such as the plant immune signaling network, which is highly resilient against perturbations.
The Drosophila optic placode undergoes neuroepithelial patterning to give rise to the larval eye primordium and the optic lobe primordium during embryonic development. A genetic network regulates the balance between larval eye and optic lobe precursors, as well as between primary and secondary photoreceptor ( PR ) precursors. The proneural factor Atonal ( Ato ) specifies larval eye precursors, while the orphan nuclear receptor Tailless ( Tll ) is crucial for the specification of optic lobe precursors. The Hedgehog and Notch signaling pathways act upstream of Ato and Tll to coordinate neural precursor specification in a timely manner. The correct spatial placement of the boundary between Ato and Tll is required to control the precise number of primary and secondary PR precursors. Notch signaling also controls a binary cell fate decision to define PR subtype identity. During embryonic development, the Drosophila optic placode produces both larval eye PRs and optic lobe precursors. The boundary between these two groups of cells is established by the non-overlapping expression patterns of Ato and Tll. The Notch and Hedgehog signaling pathways interact with transcriptional regulators to define distinct PR and non-PR domains of the larval eye and optic lobe primordium. Notch signaling is also required for regulating PR cell number and maintaining epithelial cell fate of the optic lobe primordium. Inhibiting Notch signaling leads to a complete transformation of the optic placode to PRs of the larval eye.
Human Beta Defensin 1 (hBD1), a ubiquitously expressed endogenous antimicrobial peptide, has been found to exhibit distinct antimicrobial mechanisms depending on its redox state. The reduced form of hBD1 (hBD1red) forms a net-like structure that entraps bacteria, preventing their transmigration, whereas the oxidized form (hBD1ox) does not. Electron microscopy revealed the presence of this net-like structure surrounding bacteria treated with hBD1red, but not hBD1ox. A transmigration assay demonstrated that hBD1-derived nets capture bacteria and inhibit their migration, independent of bacterial killing. This mechanism is distinct from that of other defensins, such as Paneth cell-derived human α-defensin 6 (HD6), which requires cysteines for net formation. In contrast, cysteines are necessary for net formation by hBD1red. The presence of these nets can completely prevent the migration of hBD1-resistant pathogens and are stable in the presence of human duodenal secretion with high amounts of proteases. The redox-dependent function of hBD1 serves as an additional mechanism of action, providing host protection by entrapping bacteria in extracellular net structures and preventing bacterial invasion. This study highlights the multifunctional activities of hBD1, including distinct antimicrobial mechanisms from a single peptide, and provides new insights into the modes of action of endogenous host defense molecules.
The Lowe syndrome protein OCRL1 plays a crucial role in endocytosis in the zebrafish pronephric tubule, a model for the mammalian renal tubule. A deficiency in OCRL1 results in impaired endocytosis, characterized by reduced apical uptake of fluid phase markers and low molecular weight proteins from the glomerular filtrate. This defect is associated with reduced abundance of early endocytic compartments and enlarged vacuolar endosomes in the sub-apical region of pronephric cells. Furthermore, the levels of the scavenger receptor megalin are decreased in OCRL1-deficient embryos, which is consistent with reduced recycling within the endocytic pathway. Cell polarity within the pronephric tubule remains unaffected in mutant embryos. The catalytic activity of OCRL1 is required for renal tubular endocytosis, and suppression of PIP5K rescues the endocytic defect in OCRL1-deficient embryos. This indicates that PIP5K is a potential therapeutic target for Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease. These findings provide the first evidence that OCRL1 regulates endocytic trafficking in vivo and support the hypothesis that endocytic defects are responsible for the renal tubulopathy in Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease. The results also reveal a critical role for PtdIns(4,5)P2 levels in endocytic trafficking in the renal tubule.
A cross-sectional sero-survey was conducted in the Kilombero river valley in southern Tanzania to investigate the presence and determinants of inter-epidemic Rift Valley fever (RVF) transmission in livestock. The study aimed to establish baseline information on exposure status to RVF virus (RVFV) in livestock during the inter-epidemic period and assess the relationship between RVF seropositivity, animal characteristics, and environmental factors. A total of 1680 cattle, sheep, and goats were randomly selected and tested for RVFV antibodies using two commercial ELISA kits. The overall seroprevalence was 11.3%, with 5.5% in animals born after the 2006/07 RVF outbreak and 22.7% in animals present during the outbreak. A linear increase in prevalence was observed in post-epidemic annual cohorts, indicating a constant exposure and presence of active foci of recent transmission. Nine inhibition-ELISA positive samples were also positive for RVFV IgM antibodies, indicating recent infection. The spatial distribution of seroprevalence exhibited a few hotspots, and animals living >15 km from the flood plain were more likely to have antibodies than those living <5 km away. The study found no association between RVF seropositivity and species, breed, herd composition, grazing practices, or altitude. The findings indicate post-epidemic transmission of RVFV in the study area, highlighting the need for active serological surveillance to detect inter-epidemic transmissions.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, utilizes a contractile vacuole complex (CVC) to regulate its osmolarity, despite being an obligate intracellular pathogen. The CVC is also involved in the trafficking of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins to the plasma membrane, which is essential for host invasion. Rab11, a small GTPase, localizes to the CVC and plays a crucial role in this process. A dominant-negative mutant of TcRab11 (GFP-TcRab11DN) localized to the cytosol, and epimastigotes expressing this mutant were less responsive to hyposmotic and hyperosmotic stress. However, they were still able to differentiate into metacyclic forms and infect host cells. GPI-anchored trans-sialidase (TcTS), mucins of the 60–200 KDa family, and trypomastigote small surface antigen (TcTSSA II) co-localized with GFP-TcRab11 to the CVC during transformation of intracellular amastigotes into trypomastigotes. Parasites expressing GFP-TcRab11DN prevented TcTS from reaching the plasma membrane, and were less infective compared to wild-type cells. Exogenous recombinant active TcTS and a sialic acid donor partially rescued the infectivity of trypomastigotes. These results reveal the roles of TcRab11 in osmoregulation and trafficking of trans-sialidase to the plasma membrane, and a novel unconventional mechanism of GPI-anchored protein secretion in T. cruzi.
A phase III clinical trial was conducted to evaluate the immunogenicity and safety of a purified chick-embryo cell rabies vaccine (PCECV) administered according to a shortened post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) 4-site/1-week intradermal regimen compared to the currently recommended 2-site/Thai Red Cross (TRC) regimen. The study enrolled 443 healthy individuals aged 1 year and above, who were randomized into four groups to receive intradermal PCECV with or without human rabies immunoglobulin (HRIG) administration. The primary objective was to assess the non-inferiority of the 4-site/1-week regimen to the 2-site/TRC regimen in terms of rabies virus neutralizing antibody (RVNA) concentrations ≥0.5 IU/mL at day 49. The results showed that the 4-site/1-week regimen was non-inferior to the 2-site/TRC regimen, with a difference in percentage of participants with adequate RVNA concentrations of -1% (95% CI: -2.4-0.0) at day 49. RVNA geometric mean concentrations were 18 IU/mL in the 4-site/1-week groups and 12 IU/mL in the 2-site/TRC groups at day 14, and subsequently declined in all groups. The 2 regimens had similar safety profiles, with no vaccination-related serious adverse events reported. The study suggests that the 4-site/1-week regimen might be an alternative to current recommendations, offering potential benefits in terms of improved cost-efficiency and compliance to vaccination.
The study investigated the dynamic spatiotemporal organization of the salience network (SN) in the human brain using high-resolution functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data from the Human Connectome Project and novel graph-theoretical techniques. The SN, anchored in the anterior insula and dorsal anterior cingulate cortex, plays a crucial role in detecting goal-relevant events and facilitating access to cognitive resources. The study found that the SN demonstrated high levels of flexibility in time-varying connectivity with other brain networks, including the frontoparietal network (FPN), cingulate-opercular network (CON), and ventral and dorsal attention networks (VAN and DAN). The dynamic functional interactions of the SN were among the most spatially varied in the brain, and SN nodes maintained a consistently high level of network centrality over time, indicating that this network is a hub for facilitating flexible cross-network interactions. The time-varying connectivity profiles of the SN were distinct from all other prefrontal control systems, and temporal flexibility of the SN uniquely predicted individual differences in cognitive flexibility. These findings were also observed in a second retest dataset, demonstrating the robustness of the results. The study provides new insights into the distinct dynamic functional architecture of the SN and its role in facilitating interactions with multiple functional systems, supporting a wide range of cognitive processes in the human brain.
The SV40 late protein VP4 has been identified as a viroporin that plays a crucial role in the release of the nonenveloped virus SV40 from host cells. The protein is expressed at late times during the viral life cycle, corresponding to the time of cell lysis. To investigate the function of VP4, water-soluble VP4 was expressed and purified as a GST fusion protein from bacteria. Purified VP4 was found to efficiently bind and disrupt biological membranes, forming pores of approximately 3 nm in diameter. The central hydrophobic domain of VP4 was essential for membrane binding and disruption, and the protein displayed a preference for membranes composed of lipids that replicate the composition of plasma membranes over nuclear membranes. Phosphatidylethanolamine, a lipid found in bacterial membranes, inhibited the membrane perforation activity of VP4. The disruption of membranes by VP4 involved the formation of pores in mammalian cells, including permissive SV40 host cells. These results support a central role of VP4 in the perforation of cellular membranes to trigger SV40 viral release. The study provides new insights into the poorly understood process of nonenveloped viral release and highlights the importance of VP4 in the life cycle of SV40. The findings suggest that VP4 acts as a viroporin, directly disrupting cellular membranes to facilitate the release of viral particles.
A DNA vaccine based on the NS1 antigen (pcTPANS1) has been shown to induce protection against dengue virus (DENV) in mice. The vaccine, which contains the signal peptide sequence from human tissue plasminogen activator fused to the DENV2 NS1 gene, elicits both cellular and humoral immune responses. The study aimed to elucidate the contribution of these responses to protective immunity against DENV. Results showed that pcTPANS1 induces considerable levels of anti-NS1 antibodies and T cell responses, including activation of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. Passive immunization with anti-NS1 antibodies conferred partial protection in mice infected with low virus load, but this protection was abrogated with increased viral dose. Depletion of CD4+ cells in immunized mice completely abolished protection. Transfer experiments revealed that animals receiving CD4+ T cells combined with anti-NS1 antiserum, both obtained from vaccinated mice, survived virus infection with survival rates not significantly different from pcTPANS1-immunized animals. These findings suggest that the protective immune response induced by the expression of NS1 antigen mediated by pcTPANS1 requires cooperation between CD4+ T cells and humoral immunity. The study provides new insights into the immunity elicited by DENV NS1 antigen and offers a prospect for vaccine development against dengue.
The ComRS system is a cell-to-cell communication system in Gram-positive bacteria that plays a crucial role in regulating competence for natural DNA transformation in streptococci. The system consists of the transcription factor ComR, which is activated by the binding of its associated pheromone XIP, the mature form of the comX/sigX-inducing-peptide ComS. The crystal structure analysis of ComR from Streptococcus thermophilus, combined with mutational analysis and in vivo assays, reveals that XIP-binding induces the release of the sequestered HTH domain and ComR dimerization, allowing DNA binding. This activation mechanism is conserved and specific to ComR orthologues, demonstrating that ComR is not an Rgg protein as initially proposed, but rather a new member of the RNPP family. The identification of XIP and ComR residues important for competence activation provides a crucial step towards the design of antagonistic strategies to control gene exchanges among streptococci. The ComR regulon includes the comS and comX genes, which are essential for competence in streptococci. This study provides a detailed molecular mechanism of the ComR activation process and offers opportunities to engineer well-controlled peptide-based expression systems in streptococci and other Gram-positive bacteria. The ComRS system is distinct from the two-component signaling system ComDE, which regulates competence in Streptococcus pneumoniae via σX in response to the extracellular Competence-Stimulating-Peptide (CSP).
The prokaryotic pentameric ligand-gated ion channel ELIC has been functionally characterized by electrophysiology and X-ray crystallography. ELIC is activated by a class of primary amines, including the neurotransmitter GABA, at high micro- to millimolar concentrations. These ligands bind to a conserved site and evoke currents that slowly desensitize over time. ELIC forms cation-selective channels with properties similar to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. The high single-channel conductance and simple functional behavior of ELIC make it an attractive model system for studying general mechanisms of ion conduction and gating in this important family of neurotransmitter receptors. A library of molecules was screened to identify agonists of ELIC, and a bound ligand was located in a crystal structure. The functional properties of the channel were characterized by electrophysiology, revealing that ELIC is activated by a range of primary amines, including alkylamines, aminothiols, aminoalcohols, bromoamines, diamines, and GABA. ELIC is a cation-selective channel that is impermeable to anions, and its ion conduction properties are closely related to those of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, serotonin receptors, and GLIC. The crystal structure of ELIC, obtained in the absence of ligands, is thought to represent a non-conducting conformation of the channel, but its relationship to the resting or desensitized state of the channel is still unclear.
The study investigated the progression from eczema/atopic dermatitis (AD) to asthma, a phenomenon known as the "atopic march." Researchers found that mice with skin-barrier defects developed AD-like skin inflammation and were susceptible to allergic asthma. Thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP), a cytokine overexpressed by skin keratinocytes, was identified as the systemic driver of bronchial hyper-responsiveness. Mice with keratinocyte-specific deletion of RBP-j, which sustained high systemic levels of TSLP, developed a severe asthmatic phenotype upon antigen-induced allergic challenge. Elimination of TSLP signaling in these animals blocked the atopic march, demonstrating that high serum TSLP levels were required to sensitize the lung to allergic inflammation. Furthermore, outbred K14-TSLPtg mice, which maintained high systemic levels of TSLP without developing skin pathology, were found to be sufficient to trigger the atopic march, sensitizing the lung airways to inhaled allergens in the absence of epicutaneous sensitization. These findings suggest that in addition to early treatment of primary skin-barrier defects, selective inhibition of systemic TSLP may be key to blocking the development of asthma in AD patients. The study also showed that TSLP overexpression in mouse skin led to an AD-like pathology and that TSLP was necessary to predispose RBP-j-deficient animals to the asthmatic phenotype. Concomitant removal of the IL7Rα subunit of the TSLP receptor in RBP-jCKO mice prevented the atopic march despite persistent AD-like pathology and elevated serum IgE levels.
The genome of Thermotoga maritima, a hyperthermophilic bacterium, was analyzed using a multi-omics approach that integrated genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic data with bioinformatics tools. This analysis revealed several distinctive properties of the T. maritima genome compared to other bacteria. The genome has a high number of genes per transcription unit (3.3), a low number of putative non-coding RNAs (12), and few transcription units with multiple transcription start sites (3.7%). The promoters and ribosome binding sites in T. maritima show increased sequence conservation compared to other bacteria. The 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) have an atypical bimodal length distribution, consisting of "Short" 5'UTRs (11-17 nt) and "Common" 5'UTRs (26-32 nt). Transcriptional regulation in T. maritima is limited by a lack of intergenic space for the majority of transcription units. Furthermore, a high fraction of annotated genes are expressed independently of growth state, and there is a linear correlation between mRNA and protein abundance (Pearson r = 0.63, p < 2.2 × 10^(-16) t-test). These properties are hypothesized to be a reflection of T. maritima's hyperthermophilic lifestyle and may provide insights into the evolutionary trajectory of microbial life on Earth. The multi-omics approach used in this study is applicable to many microbial species and can facilitate quantitative and comparative analysis of annotated features across microbial species.
The study investigated how visual context influences the perception of a target bar in a display. Human observers were shown a briefly presented stimulus and asked to judge whether a target bar was present at the center of the display. The target bar had a known orientation and shape, but its contrast was either weak or missing at the target location. The results showed that observers were more likely to perceive a target when the context had a weaker rather than stronger contrast. When the context could perceptually group well with the target, weak contrast contextual bars biased observers to perceive a target relative to the condition without context, as if filling in the target. In contrast, high-contrast contextual bars biased observers to perceive no target, regardless of whether they grouped well with the target. A Bayesian model of visual inference was used to account for the data, illustrating that context influences perception in two ways: biasing observers' prior belief that a target should be present according to visual grouping principles, and biasing observers' internal model of the likely input contrasts caused by a target bar. The model suggests that the context does not influence the perceived target contrast, but rather the bias to perceive the target's presence. This implies that cortical areas beyond the primary visual cortex are responsible for visual inferences. The study also found that the filling-in bias is stronger when the contextual bars have weaker contrasts and when the target is seen as more likely to group with the context as a straight line.
Biologists have long been puzzled by the prevalence of cooperation in nature, particularly in the production of costly common goods, as it is vulnerable to exploitation by defectors who consume the common good without contributing fairly. However, a recent study suggests that defectors can actually create conditions that rescue cooperation from defector-induced destruction. The researchers used an individual-based approach to model stochastic birth, death, migration, and mutation events in a structured population. They found three mechanisms through which defectors can lead to the rescue of cooperation. First, during defector-induced population collapse, defectors occasionally go extinct before cooperators by chance, allowing cooperator-only populations to grow. Second, defectors cause population extinction, creating empty locations that support cooperator but not defector migrants, leading to the survival of cooperators. Third, resource limitation, precipitated by defectors, selects for rare mutants adapted to this limitation, further reducing local population size and favoring cooperation. These factors lead to the counterintuitive result that the initial presence of defectors can sometimes improve the survival of cooperators compared to when defectors are initially absent. The study predicts that in a structured population, small population sizes precipitated by defectors provide a "built-in" mechanism for the persistence of cooperation.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, an opportunistic pathogen, poses a significant challenge to the mucosal barrier. In patients with compromised epithelial barriers, infections can develop. Research has shown that P. aeruginosa adheres almost exclusively to multi-cellular junctions in a polarized epithelium, where it binds to extruded apoptotic cells or apoptotic bodies. This dead cell tropism is independent of the type of cell death, as P. aeruginosa also binds to necrotic cells. The bacteria are then internalized through efferocytosis, a process in which surrounding epithelial cells engulf and dispose of extruded apoptotic cells. Intracellularly, P. aeruginosa inhabits an efferocytic phagosome that acquires lysosomal features and is ultimately killed. The study proposes that elimination of P. aeruginosa through efferocytosis is a host defense mechanism. The findings have implications for the study of cystic fibrosis, a condition characterized by an increased number of apoptotic cells and ineffective efferocytosis. The research highlights the ability of epithelial cells to eliminate P. aeruginosa through efferocytosis, suggesting that this process may be part of a host defense mechanism against this opportunistic pathogen.
During Drosophila embryonic development, the assembly of the gonad involves the migration of Primordial Germ Cells ( PGCs ) to the Somatic Gonadal Precursor cells ( SGPs ). The PGCs must traverse the midgut wall and migrate through the mesoderm to reach the SGPs, guided by local repulsive cues and attractive signals from the SGPs. The hedgehog ( hh ) pathway gene shifted ( shf ) plays a crucial role in directing PGC migration by facilitating the long-distance transmission of Hh through the proteoglycan matrix. shf is expressed in the gonadal mesoderm and is required for PGC migration, as demonstrated by loss- and gain-of-function experiments. The hmgcr-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway generates the PGC attractant produced by the SGPs and other tissues when hmgcr is ectopically expressed. The production of this attractant depends on shf and another hh pathway gene, gγ1. Ectopic expression of hmgcr in the nervous system promotes the release and transmission of Hh ligand from these cells into the underlying mesodermal cell layer, where Hh can contact migrating PGCs. The potentiation of Hh by hmgcr appears to depend on cholesterol modification. These findings suggest that shf and the hmgcr-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway work together to orchestrate PGC migration during Drosophila embryonic development.
A recent study investigated the cytotoxic capacity of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells in individuals vaccinated with a replication-incompetent adenovirus serotype 5 (Ad5) HIV-1 recombinant vaccine. The study aimed to understand the mechanisms underlying protection from HIV infection or immune control over HIV replication. The researchers measured granzyme B target cell activity and HIV-1-infected CD4+ T-cell elimination in vaccine recipients, HIV-negative individuals, and chronically infected patients, including long-term nonprogressors (LTNP). The results showed that HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell recall cytotoxic responses were readily detectable in vaccinees at a median of 331 days following the last immunization. However, the magnitude of these responses was not related to the number of vaccinations or the percentages of cytokine-secreting T-cells. Notably, vaccine recipients carrying the HLA class I alleles B*27, B*57, or B*58, associated with immune control over HIV replication in chronic infection, exhibited significantly higher cytotoxic responses. These findings suggest that protective HLA class I alleles may lead to better outcomes in both chronic infection and following immunization due to more efficient priming of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell cytotoxic responses. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell cytotoxicity and highlights the importance of HLA class I alleles in vaccine-induced immune responses.
The article presents a formal model of the coevolution of jointly intentional behavior and cumulative culture, demonstrating that the emergence of shared intentions is closely linked to the advancement of technology and culture. The shared intentionality hypothesis suggests that the evolution of modern human cognition was facilitated by the development of collaborative behavior among early hominins. This is supported by evidence that the emergence of shared intentions coincided with significant technological advancements, such as the evolution of composite tool manufacture and grammatical language. The authors propose that the ability to undertake jointly intentional behavior is a key factor in the rapid advancement of technology and culture. In their model, individuals with the ability to share intentions (SI type individuals) can adjust their strategies in tandem with their neighbors to mutual benefit. The results show that jointly intentional behavior leads to faster convergence to improved technological norms. Conversely, in the absence of opportunities for significant technological improvement, the ability to undertake jointly intentional behavior is selected against. This model provides a unified explanation for the suppression or emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans, as well as a potential cause of inter-species diversity in the prevalence of such behavior. The findings suggest that an environment rich in coordination problems is conducive to the emergence of jointly intentional behavior.
The loss of miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci in mice results in oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, a condition characterized by low sperm count, aberrant sperm morphology, and impaired motility. This condition is the leading cause of human sub/infertility. The miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci are specifically and highly expressed in post-mitotic male germ cells and are critical for spermatogenesis. Deletion of these loci impairs both meiosis and the final stages of spermatozoa maturation. Analysis of miR-34bc−/−;449−/− pachytene spermatocytes reveals a small cohort of deregulated genes that are highly enriched for miR-34 family target genes. The loss of miR-34bc/449 does not block spermatogenesis but impairs several developmental transitions, resulting in oligoasthenoteratozoospermia. Histological analysis of miR-34bc−/−;449−/− mice shows a thinning of the epithelium within the seminiferous tubules and a drop in the quantity and quality of mature sperm. The motility of miR-34bc−/−;449−/− sperm is severely affected, and the sperm are of aberrant morphology. This study identifies the miR-34 family as the first functionally important miRNAs for spermatogenesis whose deregulation is causal to oligoasthenoteratozoospermia and infertility. The findings suggest that the miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci have multiple functions during spermatogenesis, regulating both meiosis and the later stages of spermiogenesis.
Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 (EcN) has been used therapeutically for over a century, but the determinants of its probiotic properties remain unclear. EcN produces two siderophore-microcins (Mcc) responsible for an antagonistic activity against other Enterobacteriaceae, as well as the genotoxin colibactin encoded by the pks island. Colibactin is a virulence factor and a putative pro-carcinogenic compound. To decouple the antagonistic activity of EcN from its genotoxic activity, researchers investigated the role of the pks-encoded ClbP, the peptidase that activates colibactin. They found that ClbP is required for the antagonistic activity of EcN and that the transmembrane helices of ClbP, not the periplasmic peptidase domain, are involved in this activity. A single amino acid substitution in ClbP inactivated the genotoxic activity but maintained the antagonistic activity. In an in vivo salmonellosis model, this point mutant reduced the clinical signs and fecal shedding of Salmonella similarly to the wild-type strain. The ClbP-dependent antibacterial effect was also observed in vitro with other E. coli strains that carry both a truncated form of the Mcc gene cluster and the pks island. The interplay between colibactin, salmochelin, and siderophore-Mcc biosynthetic pathways suggests that these genomic islands were co-selected and played a role in the evolution of E. coli from phylogroup B2. This co-evolution illustrates the fine margin between pathogenicity and probiotic activity, and the need to address both the effectiveness and safety of probiotics. Decoupling the antagonistic from the genotoxic activity by specifically inactivating ClbP peptidase domain opens the way to the safe use of EcN.
Cryptococcus neoformans, an opportunistic pathogen responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths annually, relies on glycans for survival in the host and pathogenesis. Nucleotide sugar transporters ( NSTs ) mediate the exchange of activated sugars for nucleoside monophosphates, a critical step in glycan biosynthesis. The major virulence factor of C. neoformans is its polysaccharide capsule, composed of glucuronoxylomannan ( GXM ) and glucuronoxylomannanogalactan ( GXMGal ), which acts as a physical barrier against host defenses and an immune modulator. Xylose, a neutral monosaccharide, is a significant component of the capsule. Two transporters, Uxt1 and Uxt2, have been identified as specific for the xylose donor, UDP-xylose, and are required for xylose incorporation into the capsule and proteins. These transporters are also necessary for C. neoformans to cause disease in mice, although not for fungal viability in the context of infection. The study provides insights into the substrate specificity of NSTs and a synthetic pathway that may be targeted for therapy, contributing to our understanding of fundamental glycobiology. The findings have implications for deciphering the mechanisms of cryptococcal pathogenesis and host response.
The development of an open-access global database for mapping, control, and surveillance of neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) is crucial for targeting control interventions, monitoring, and evaluation. Currently, there is a lack of a georeferenced global database providing open-access to available survey data for NTDs. To address this gap, a database was developed to store location-specific prevalence data and survey details for NTDs, with an initial focus on schistosomiasis in Africa. The database was created by systematically searching the literature, contacting Ministries of Health and research institutions in schistosomiasis-endemic countries, and extracting, georeferencing, and storing the data in a MySQL database with a web interface. At the beginning of 2011, the database contained over 12,000 georeferenced schistosomiasis survey locations from 35 African countries. The database is now expanded to a global repository, including other NTDs such as soil-transmitted helminthiasis and leishmaniasis. The open-access, spatially explicit NTD database offers opportunities for disease risk modeling, targeting control interventions, disease monitoring, and surveillance, as well as detailed geostatistical analyses of disease distribution in space and time. The development of this database demonstrates the feasibility of establishing and running a global NTD database, which should be expanded without delay. The database is available at http://www.gntd.org.
This study investigated whether chronic helminth infection exacerbates Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) infection in cotton rats, a natural host for the filarial nematode Litomosoides sigmodontis. The researchers hypothesized that chronic helminth infections, which induce a Th2 immune shift and immunoregulatory milieu, would suppress Th1 immunity necessary for controlling MTB infection. However, the study found that chronic L. sigmodontis infection did not exacerbate MTB infection in cotton rats. Immunological responses, histological studies, and quantitative mycobacterial cultures were assessed two months after MTB challenge in cotton rats with and without chronic L. sigmodontis infection. The results showed that spleen cell proliferation and interferon gamma production in response to purified protein derivative were similar between co-infected and MTB-only infected animals. Furthermore, MTB loads and the occurrence and size of lung granulomas were not increased in co-infected animals. Histological examinations and quantitative MTB cultures from two independent experiments demonstrated equivalent or reduced mycobacterial burden in co-infected animals compared to those infected with only MTB. These findings suggest that chronic filaria infections do not worsen MTB infection in the cotton rat model. The study's results indicate that filaria eradication programs may not facilitate MTB control, but also suggest that worm-derived therapies for autoimmune diseases may not substantially increase the risk for infections.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the degenerin/epithelial sodium channel ( DEG/ENaC ) family represents one of the largest families of ion channels, yet the physiological functions of these proteins remain poorly understood. This study investigated the role of ppk23, a member of the DEG/ENaC family, in chemosensory functions and courtship behavior in Drosophila. The results show that ppk23 is expressed in a subpopulation of sexually dimorphic gustatory-like chemosensory bristles that are distinct from those involved in feeding-related gustatory responses. Disrupting ppk23 or inhibiting activity of ppk23-expressing neurons did not alter gustatory responses, but instead delayed the initiation and reduced the intensity of male courtship behavior. Furthermore, mutations in ppk23 altered the behavioral response of males to the female-specific aphrodisiac pheromone 7, 11 ( Z ), 11 ( Z ) -Heptacosadiene. These findings indicate that ppk23 and the cells expressing it play an important role in the peripheral sensory system that determines sexual behavior in Drosophila. The study suggests that ppk23 is a potential candidate for a pheromone receptor or a key component of the pheromonal signaling cascade. The results also indicate that DEG/ENaC signaling contributes to sensory functions underlying sex-related behaviors and reveal a novel physiological function for this important family of ion channels.
Mitochondrial tRNA import plays a crucial role in ensuring proper mitochondrial translation across diverse phyla, including protozoa, fungi, higher plants, and humans. However, the regulation of this process remains poorly understood. In the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas, a correlation was found between mitochondrial codon usage and the nature and amount of imported tRNAs. This led to the hypothesis that tRNA import might be a dynamic process adapting to the mitochondrial genome content. To investigate this, the Chlamydomonas mitochondrial genome was manipulated by introducing point mutations to modify its codon usage. The results showed that codon usage modification led to reduced levels of mitochondrial translation and decreased levels and activities of respiratory complexes. These effects were linked to limitations in the pool of tRNAs in mitochondria, indicating that tRNA mitochondrial import cannot be rapidly regulated in response to a novel genetic context. Instead, the steady-state levels of imported tRNAs in mitochondria appear to result from a co-evolutionary adaptation between the tRNA import mechanism and the requirements of the mitochondrial translation machinery. The study suggests that the information residing in the mitochondrial DNA defines the levels of imported tRNAs, allowing for optimal mitochondrial translation. These findings have implications for understanding the regulation of mitochondrial translation and the co-evolution of mitochondrial and nuclear genomes.
Biomedical research has revealed new patterns of glucose dysregulation in diabetes and prediabetes through the use of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM). Current methods for quantifying blood glucose dysregulation rely on single-time-point measurements or average measures of overall glycemia, neglecting glucose dynamics. This study employed CGM to evaluate postprandial glucose elevations, types of patterns, and variability between individuals given an identical nutrient challenge. Measurement of insulin resistance and secretion highlighted the highly variable physiology underlying dysglycemia between individuals. An analytical framework was developed to group individuals according to specific patterns of glycemic responses, called "glucotypes," which revealed heterogeneity within traditional diagnostic categories of glucose regulation. The study found that even individuals considered normoglycemic by standard measures exhibit high glucose variability using CGM, with glucose levels reaching prediabetic and diabetic ranges 15% and 2% of the time, respectively. Glucose dysregulation, as characterized by CGM, is more prevalent and heterogeneous than previously thought and can affect individuals considered normoglycemic by standard measures. The interindividual variability in glycemic responses to standardized meals highlights the personal nature of glucose regulation. A model for identifying potential mechanisms of personal glucose dysregulation and a webtool for visualizing and classifying individualized glucose patterns into glucotypes were developed. The study suggests that an increase in glucose variability might precede the currently used measures defining abnormal glucose levels, representing an earlier stage of "prediabetes."
The Raf-like mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase kinase kinase (MAPKKK) EDR1 has been identified as a negative regulator of plant defense responses and cell death in Arabidopsis. However, the mechanisms by which EDR1 functions and its relationship to MAP kinase cascades have remained unclear. This study reveals that EDR1 physically interacts with the MAPK kinases MKK4 and MKK5, and negatively regulates the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade. The interaction between EDR1 and MKK4/MKK5 requires the N-terminal domain of EDR1, and EDR1 also negatively affects the protein levels of MKK4, MKK5, MPK3, and MPK6. Furthermore, the study shows that edr1 mutants have highly activated MPK3/MPK6 kinase activity and higher levels of MPK3/MPK6 proteins than wild-type plants. The results also indicate that MKK4 and MKK5 are key players in plant immunity responses, as mkk4 and mkk5 loss-of-function mutants display enhanced susceptibility to powdery mildew and edr1-mediated resistance requires MKK4 and MKK5 function. Over-expression of MKK4 or MKK5 causes edr1-like resistance and mildew-induced cell death, suggesting that the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade plays a crucial role in fine-tuning plant innate immunity. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of plant defense and cell death, and highlight the importance of EDR1 and the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade in regulating plant innate immunity.
The article presents a computational framework based on Gaussian processes for spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. The framework is designed to identify highly nonlinear dependencies and make reliable predictions. It combines spatial and temporal similarity matrices to obtain a larger similarity matrix between location and time period pairs. A Gaussian process regression model is then trained using the combined similarity matrix and reported cases counts to make predictions under three different scenarios: temporal, spatial, and spatiotemporal prediction. The proposed framework is tested on Turkey’s country-wide surveillance data set of Crimean–Congo hemorrhagic fever, a vector-borne infectious disease with a high case fatality rate. The results show that the Gaussian process formulation outperforms two standard machine learning algorithms, random forests and boosted regression trees, under temporal, spatial, and spatiotemporal prediction scenarios. The framework has the potential to contribute to public health policy making by providing reliable computational tools to understand disease dynamics and predict future cases. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of Gaussian processes in capturing complex dependencies and making accurate predictions, making it a valuable approach for infectious disease modeling.
The article presents a mathematical model to investigate the transmission dynamics of Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) among ruminants in Northeastern Africa and the Middle East. The model takes into account the effects of seasonality and socioeconomic factors, such as the Eid al Adha feast, on the transmission and dispersal of the disease. The results indicate that human activities associated with the festival, combined with climatic factors like rainfall and hydrological variations, contribute to the spread of the disease. The model also shows that sporadic outbreaks may occur when abundant livestock are recruited into areas at risk from RVF due to the demand for the festival and when abundant numbers of mosquitoes emerge. The numerical results present the transmission dynamics of the disease over both short and long periods of time, particularly during the festival time. The study also investigates the impact of festival- and seasonal-driven factors, such as the number of livestock imported daily, animal transportation speed, and death rate induced by ceremonial sacrifices, on the patterns of disease outbreaks in each patch. The results suggest that when the time for festival preparation starts earlier than usual, the risk of massive disease outbreaks rises, particularly in the patch where the religious ceremony will be held. The model can be used to predict the disease outbreaks and provide information to local governments on how to effectively control the transmission of the disease pathogen.
Between 1984 and 2010, the incidence of human anthrax in Azerbaijan underwent significant spatial and temporal changes. Initially, the disease showed an increasing trend during the Soviet governance era, peaking in the mid-1990s with an annual percent change of +11.95%. Following the initiation of a preemptive livestock vaccination program in 1996, the incidence of human anthrax began to decline at a rate of -35.24%. The geographic distribution of the disease also shifted eastward over time, with cases initially concentrated in the west and south during the Soviet era, followed by a shift towards the capital city of Baku in the mid-1990s. During the preemptive vaccination period, the disease remained primarily concentrated in eastern and northern Azerbaijan. The study's findings highlight the need for continued control measures in livestock to mitigate the occurrence of human anthrax. The shifting patterns of the disease also underscore the importance of an integrated "One Health" approach that takes into account the changing geographic distribution of the disease. The study's results are consistent with previous research documenting changes in the occurrence of zoonotic diseases following the dissolution of the Soviet Union. The re-emergence of anthrax in the Caucasus region raises concerns over the potential trans-boundary spread of the disease.
The molecular basis of polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) interactions with the Shaker voltage-gated potassium (KV) channel has been investigated using microsecond molecular dynamics simulations. The study aimed to elucidate the mechanism by which PUFAs modulate the channel's voltage-sensitivity, which can provide effective treatment against refractory epilepsy through a ketogenic diet. The simulations revealed a putative PUFA binding site in the open state of the channel, located at the protein-lipid interface in the vicinity of the extracellular halves of the S3 and S4 helices of the voltage-sensor domain (VSD). The lipophilic PUFA tail exhibited non-specific hydrophobic interactions in the hydrophobic central core of the protein-lipid interface, while the carboxylic head group displayed specific interactions with polar/charged residues at the extracellular regions of the S3 and S4 helices, encompassing the S3-S4 linker. In contrast, saturated fatty acids (SFAs) showed increased conformational flexibility in their polyunsaturated carbon tails compared to saturated carbon chains, which may explain the specificity of PUFA action on channel proteins. These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanism of PUFA interactions with the Shaker KV channel, shedding light on the potential therapeutic applications of PUFAs in treating refractory epilepsy.
Scientists have developed a screening pipeline to identify antiparasitic agents targeting Cryptosporidium parvum inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH). Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite responsible for significant disease burden in children in developing countries and life-threatening enteritis in AIDS patients. Current treatments are ineffective, and the parasite's experimental tractability has hindered the discovery of novel therapeutics. The researchers genetically engineered Toxoplasma gondii, a related parasite, to serve as a model for C. parvum infection, allowing for a rapid assessment of anti-parasitic potential and target specificity. A fluorescence-based assay of host cell proliferation and a C. parvum growth assay utilizing automated high-content imaging analysis were also developed to further evaluate compounds. The pipeline was used to evaluate C. parvum IMPDH inhibitors and identified a subset of 1,2,3-triazole ethers with excellent in vivo selectivity in the T. gondii model and improved anti-cryptosporidial activity. Two promising candidates, A103 and A110, were identified, which are >100× more potent than the current standard for anticryptosporidial activity, paromomycin. The screening pipeline provides a valuable tool for the discovery of novel antiparasitic agents targeting C. parvum IMPDH.
A genome-wide association study was conducted to identify genetic loci associated with primary tooth development during infancy. The study analyzed data from 4,564 individuals from the 1966 Northern Finland Birth Cohort and 1,518 individuals from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children. Five loci were identified at a significance level of P<5×10−8, and five additional loci showed suggestive association at P<5×10−6. The identified loci included genes linked to tooth and other organ development, such as KCNJ2, EDA, HOXB2, RAD51L1, IGF2BP1, HMGA2, and MSRB3. These genes have roles in organogenesis, growth, and developmental processes, and some have been implicated in cancer. Mutations in three of these genes, KCNJ2, EDA, and IGF2BP1, have been associated with altered organogenesis and development in other systems. The study also found that a variant within the HOXB gene cluster was associated with occlusion defects requiring orthodontic treatment by age 31 years. The findings suggest that genetic determinants of early tooth eruption may influence dental occlusion later in life. The study provides new insights into the genetic architecture of primary dentition and has implications for the study of other developmental and organogenic processes.
The trisomy of human chromosome 21 (Hsa21) causes Down syndrome (DS), a condition characterized by intellectual disability, locomotor deficits, and altered muscle tone. In contrast, complete monosomy of Hsa21 is lethal, and only partial monosomy or mosaic monosomy is seen. To identify dosage-sensitive genes involved in DS and monosomy 21 phenotypes, researchers created two new mouse models: Ts3Yah, carrying a tandem duplication, and Ms3Yah, carrying a deletion of the Hspa13-App interval syntenic with 21q11.2-q21.3. The study found that trisomy and monosomy of this region alter locomotion, muscle strength, mass, and energetic balance. Gene expression profiling of skeletal muscles revealed global changes in the regulation of genes implicated in energetic metabolism, mitochondrial activity, and biogenesis. These genes were downregulated in Ts3Yah mice and upregulated in Ms3Yah mice. The shift in skeletal muscle metabolism correlated with a change in mitochondrial proliferation without an alteration in respiratory function. However, reactive oxygen species (ROS) production from mitochondrial complex I decreased in Ms3Yah mice, while membrane permeability of Ts3Yah mitochondria slightly increased. The study suggests that the Hspa13-App interval controls metabolic and mitochondrial phenotypes in muscles as a consequence of changes in the dose of Gabpa, Nrip1, and Atp5j. The results indicate that copy number variation in the Hspa13-App region has a peripheral impact on locomotor activity by altering muscle function.
A quantitative model of the G protein-gated K+ channel (GIRK1/2) has been developed to elucidate the mechanisms of its basal and evoked activities. The model accurately recapitulates GIRK1/2 currents in Xenopus oocytes, HEK293 cells, and hippocampal neurons, and correctly predicts the dose-dependent activation of GIRK1/2 by coexpressed Gβγ. The model reveals that between 3 and 4 Gβγ dimers are available for each GIRK1/2 channel, while available Gαi/o decreases from ~2 to less than one Gα per channel as GIRK1/2 density increases. The persistent Gβγ/channel ratio suggests a strong association of GIRK1/2 with Gβγ, but not Gα, consistent with recruitment to the cell surface of Gβγ, but not Gα, by GIRK1/2. The analysis suggests a maximal stoichiometry of 4 Gβγ but only 2 Gαi/o per one GIRK1/2 channel. The unequal association of GIRK1/2 with G protein subunits and the cooperative nature of GIRK gating by Gβγ underlie the complex pattern of basal and agonist-evoked activities, allowing GIRK1/2 to act as a sensitive bidirectional detector of both Gβγ and Gα. The model fully accounts for the inverse correlation between basal (Ibasal) and agonist activation index (Ra) previously observed in heterologous systems and in hippocampal neurons.
A novel computational model called PrediTALE has been developed to predict the target genes of transcription activator-like effectors (TALEs) in plant-pathogenic Xanthomonas bacteria. TALEs are secreted into host cells, where they act as transcriptional activators to support bacterial virulence. The model accounts for recent findings on TALE targeting, including frame-shift binding by repeats of aberrant lengths and flexible strand orientation of target boxes relative to the transcription start of the downstream target gene. PrediTALE is trained on quantitative data and can account for dependencies between adjacent repeat-variable diresidues (RVD) positions. The model is benchmarked using RNA-seq data after Xanthomonas infection in rice and shows an overall improvement in prediction performance compared to previous approaches. Genome-wide predictions using PrediTALE enable the identification of novel targets independently of existing gene annotations, including previously missing non-coding RNAs. The model predicts several unique target genes, some of which are highly promising for further experimental validation. The results demonstrate that accurate computational predictions of TALE target boxes are required for elucidating virulence targets of TALEs that support bacterial infection of host plants. Genome-wide scans for putative target boxes using PrediTALE can recover known targets from promoterome-wide scans and detect putative targets independent of existing gene annotations.
Title: High-confidence assessment of functional impact of human mitochondrial non-synonymous genome variations by APOGEE

    APOGEE is a machine-learning algorithm designed to predict the pathogenicity of human mitochondrial non-synonymous genome variations with high confidence. Mitochondrial DNA contains 24,189 possible non-synonymous amino acid changes, but only a small subset has been functionally evaluated, while the pathogenicity of the majority has been assessed in-silico using software predictors. However, these tools have been found to be incongruent. To address this issue, APOGEE was developed to outperform existing prediction methods.

    The APOGEE algorithm was built on a training set of 864 known mitochondrial variants, with 100 sets of variants drawn randomly and with replacement. Performance metrics were calculated on out-of-bag test sets, as well as for individual predictors. The frequency of coevolving amino acids and mean MI Z-score for each amino acid site were computed for all 24,189 non-synonymous amino acid changes and made available through MitImpact. Variants were grouped into training and test sets to build and verify the APOGEE classifier.

    APOGEE's operating logic is based on the classification model of the Logistic Model Tree (LMT), which feeds third-party predictors with features related to 13 mitochondrial proteins, such as multi-alignments and amino acid conservation estimates. The reasoning strategy was tuned on finely curated, non-overlapping, training sets of variations, and the predicting model was based on decision tree learning to provide investigable rules of pathogenicity. This approach aims to provide a high-confidence assessment of the functional impact of human mitochondrial non-synonymous genome variations.
Dengue virus (DENV) nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) has been shown to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of dengue infection. A recent study has demonstrated that DENV NS1 can activate platelets via Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), leading to thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage. The study found that DENV supernatant, but not Zika virus supernatant, induced P-selectin expression and phosphatidylserine exposure in human platelets, which were abolished when NS1 was depleted from the DENV supernatant. Recombinant NS1 from all four serotypes of DENV also induced platelet activation, which was blocked by anti-NS1 F(ab')2, anti-TLR4 antibody, a TLR4 antagonist, and a TLR4 signaling inhibitor. The activation of platelets by DENV NS1 promoted subthreshold concentrations of adenosine diphosphate (ADP)-induced platelet aggregation and enhanced platelet adhesion to endothelial cells and phagocytosis by macrophages. Furthermore, DENV-induced thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage were attenuated in TLR4 knockout and wild-type mice when NS1 was depleted from DENV supernatant. These results suggest that the binding of DENV NS1 to TLR4 on platelets can trigger its activation, which may contribute to thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage during dengue infection. The study highlights the central role of DENV NS1 in the complex interplay of dengue pathogenesis, including thrombocytopenia, vascular leakage, and cytokine storm.
The article presents a mathematical analysis of the dynamic control loops regulating vasomotor tone, blood volume, and mean arterial pressure in the body. The analysis focuses on the interactions between the arginine vasopressin (AVP) system, the atrial natriuretic peptide system (ANP), and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). The study reveals the presence of two regulatory mechanisms that perform the same qualitative function: one affects blood pressure by regulating vasoconstriction, and the other affects blood volume.
