Both mechanisms are candidate oscillators consisting of a negative-feedback loop of a monotone system, which can exhibit stable or oscillatory instability. A subsystem, including ANP and AVP stimulation of vascular smooth muscle cells, is also identified as a candidate oscillator composed of a monotone system with multiple negative feedback loops. The study shows that the oscillatory potential of this subsystem is higher when the delays along all feedback loops are comparable. The results provide insight into the physiological mechanisms governing long-term homeostasis of blood hydraulic parameters, which operate based on dynamical loops of interactions. The analysis suggests that the physiological mechanisms regulating blood pressure and volume are arranged into a complex of equivalent loop systems, consisting of candidate oscillators with a single equilibrium point. The study highlights the loop arrangement and its dynamic function in the AVP-ANP-RAAS endocrine control of body fluids and blood pressure.
Thromboembolic disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. A novel mechanism regulating thrombus growth has been identified, related to the formation of a fibrin cap. The study investigated protein transport through a fibrin network, an important component of a thrombus, by integrating experiments with model simulations. The results showed that network permeability and protein diffusivity are crucial factors determining the transport of proteins through the fibrin network. Model simulations, calibrated using experiments in microfluidic devices and accounting for the permeable structure of the fibrin cap, demonstrated that thrombin generated inside the thrombus is washed downstream through the fibrin network, limiting exposure of platelets on the thrombus surface to thrombin. The fibrin cap also restricts the approach of resting platelets in the flowing blood to the thrombus core, impairing platelet activation and limiting thrombus growth. The formation of a fibrin cap prevents small thrombi from developing into life-threatening events. The study highlights the importance of spatial distributions of hemostatic activators, such as thrombin, in regulating thrombogenesis. The findings suggest that the fibrin network overlaying a thrombus limits thrombus growth by affecting protein transport and separating resting platelets from regions of high thrombin concentration. Overall, the study provides justification for a previously unrecognized mechanism limiting growth of small asymptomatic thrombi.
Invariant natural killer T ( iNKT ) cells play a crucial role in controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) replication during infection. However, the mechanisms by which iNKT cells exert their antimicrobial activity are not fully understood. This study investigated the role of iNKT cells in limiting Mtb growth in co-culture with infected macrophages. The results showed that iNKT cell activation, as measured by CD25 upregulation and IFNγ production, was primarily driven by IL-12 and IL-18 produced by infected macrophages. In contrast, iNKT cell control of Mtb growth was found to be CD1d-dependent and independent of IL-12, IL-18, and IFNγ. Furthermore, iNKT cell control of Mtb replication was also independent of TNF and cell-mediated cytotoxicity. Instead, the study identified granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) as a novel mediator of iNKT cell antimicrobial activity. iNKT cells produced GM-CSF in vitro and in vivo in a CD1d-dependent manner during Mtb infection, and GM-CSF was found to be both necessary and sufficient to control Mtb growth. These findings suggest that GM-CSF production is a key effector function of iNKT cells in controlling Mtb infection, and highlight the importance of CD1d-dependent TCR-mediated signaling in iNKT cell antimicrobial activity.
The study investigated the self-regulation of Candida albicans population size during gastrointestinal (GI) colonization. Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that is a common component of human intestinal flora. Genes expressed by fungi grown within a host were studied to gain insight into C. albicans colonization. The EFH1 gene, encoding a putative transcription factor, was found to be highly expressed during growth of C. albicans in the intestinal tract. Unexpectedly, an efh1 null mutant exhibited increased colonization of the murine intestinal tract, whereas an EFH1 overexpressing strain exhibited reduced colonization of the intestinal tract and oral cavity of athymic mice. When inoculated into the bloodstream of mice, both efh1 null and EFH1 overexpressing strains caused lethal infections. In contrast, other mutants were attenuated in virulence following intravenous inoculation but exhibited normal levels of intestinal colonization. The results suggest that expression of EFH1 regulates the level of colonizing fungi, favoring commensalism as opposed to candidiasis. Furthermore, different genes are required in different host niches, and the pathways that regulate gene expression during host colonization can differ from those used during laboratory growth. The study highlights the importance of EFH1 in determining the population size of C. albicans during colonization and its potential role in reducing the likelihood of C. albicans infection.
Immunization with irradiated malaria sporozoites is a highly effective strategy against liver stages of the malaria parasite, but the mechanisms behind this approach are not fully understood. A recent study investigated the role of prolonged antigen presentation in the development of protective CD8+ T cell responses against malaria liver stages. The study used TCR transgenic cells specific for the malaria circumsporozoite protein, a leading vaccine candidate, and found that sporozoite antigen persists for over 8 weeks after immunization. This persistence was detected in lymphoid organs and was dependent on the presence of CD11c+ cells. The study showed that prolonged antigen presentation enhanced the magnitude of the CD8+ T cell response in several ways. Firstly, reducing the time primed CD8+ T cells were exposed to antigen in vivo severely reduced the final size of the developing memory population. Secondly, fully developed memory cells expanded in previously immunized mice but not when transferred to naïve animals. Finally, persisting antigen was able to prime naïve cells, including recent thymic emigrants, to become functional effector cells capable of eliminating parasites in the liver. These findings suggest that the optimal development of protective CD8+ T cell immunity against malaria liver stages is dependent on the prolonged presentation of sporozoite-derived antigen. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying the success of irradiated sporozoite immunization and highlights the importance of antigen persistence in the development of protective CD8+ T cell responses.
Biodegradable nanocarriers coated with polymyxin B (PBCAnp-polB) were evaluated for their leishmanicidal and antibacterial potential. PBCAnp-polB were fabricated by anionic polymerization and characterized by Dynamic Light Scattering, Nanoparticle Tracking Analysis, and vertical diffusion cell. The nanoparticles had a size of 261.5 ± 25.9 nm, low polydispersity index, and a ζ potential of 1.79 ± 0.17 mV, which remained stable for at least 45 days. The 50% drug release from PBCAnp-polB was 6-7 times slower than free polymyxin B, indicating a prolonged release profile. In vitro evaluations showed that polymyxin B alone reduced Leishmania amazonensis amastigote infection of macrophages at 10 μg/mL, but complete parasite elimination was not achieved, even at higher concentrations. In contrast, PBCAnp-polB demonstrated leishmanicidal activity and surpassed polymyxin B activity, with an IC50 value of 6.0 μg/mL. Additionally, PBCAnp-polB showed antimicrobial activity against E. coli, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella, while polymyxin B maintained its activity against these bacteria. The results suggest that PBCAnp-polB is a promising antileishmanial and antimicrobial drug delivery system, particularly for the prevention and treatment of secondary infections associated with cutaneous Leishmania amazonensis lesions.
A historical cohort study was conducted in Belo Horizonte, Brazil to investigate prognostic factors for death from visceral leishmaniasis (VL). The study analyzed data from the Reportable Disease Information System-SINAN (Brazilian Ministry of Health) for the period 2002-2009. Multivariate logistic regression models were used to identify variables associated with death from VL. Two models were developed: Model 1 (2002-2009) included variables present in both SINAN versions, and Model 2 (2007-2009) included additional variables from the Net version. In Model 1, weakness, Leishmania-HIV co-infection, and age ≥60 years were significantly associated with a greater risk of death from VL. In Model 2, bleeding, other associated infections, jaundice, and age ≥60 years were associated with an increased likelihood of death from VL. A prognostic score was developed using the variables from Model 2, which showed a predictive performance of 71.4% sensitivity, 73.7% specificity, 28.9% positive predictive value, 94.5% negative predictive value, and 75.6% area under the receiver operating characteristic curve. The study found that the factors associated with death from VL were weakness, Leishmania-HIV co-infection, other associated infections, bleeding, jaundice, and age ≥60 years. These findings are in agreement with the Brazilian Ministry of Health, which considers age <6 months or >65 years, jaundice, bleeding, and co-morbidities, including bacterial infections, as factors associated with death from VL.
The Arabidopsis regulatory leucine-rich repeat receptor-like kinase (LRR-RLK) BAK1 plays a crucial role in plant growth, cell death, and innate immunity. A novel allele of BAK1, bak1-5, was found to differentially regulate three BAK1-dependent signaling pathways. The bak1-5 mutant was severely impaired in innate immune signaling mediated by the BAK1-dependent receptor kinases FLS2 and EFR, but not in brassinosteroid (BR) signaling or cell death control. In contrast to the RD kinase BRI1, the non-RD kinases FLS2 and EFR have low kinase activity and are unable to trans-phosphorylate BAK1 in vitro. Furthermore, kinase activity is dispensable for the ligand-induced heteromerization of FLS2 or EFR with BAK1 in planta. The specific suppression of FLS2- and EFR-dependent signaling in bak1-5 requires BAK1-5 kinase activity. The results demonstrate a phosphorylation-dependent differential control of plant growth, innate immunity, and cell death by BAK1. The study reveals key differences in the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of ligand-binding RD and non-RD receptor kinases. The importance of the heteromerization with BAK1 in plant innate immunity is substantiated by the targeting of the ligand-induced BAK1-FLS2 interaction by the bacterial virulence effector AvrPto to block PTI signaling. The function of BAK1 in cell death control and innate immunity appears to be independent of its function in BR signaling.
The article presents a novel approach to modeling the response of cancer cells to anticancer treatments using a combination of experimental and computational methods. Time-lapse live cell microscopy and flow cytometric data were used to track the cell cycle and subsequent generations of human ovarian cancer cells treated with X-rays. A computational model was developed to render the proliferative process, incorporating modules that describe the functional activity of main pathways causing arrest, repair, and cell death in each phase of the cell cycle. The model was tested with time-course measures taken in parallel with flow cytometry and time-lapse live cell microscopy, spanning a wide range of X-ray doses. The final model provided a complete in silico rendering of the cycling process following X-ray exposure, offering separate and quantitative measures of the dose-dependence of G1, S, and G2/M checkpoint activities in subsequent generations. This approach enabled the reconciliation of known effects of ionizing radiations and provided new insights into the response of cancer cells to treatment. The method allows for a detailed study of the mechanisms underlying the response to anticancer treatment at the cell population level, accounting for inter-cell variability. The model can be used to apply different types of modules in each phase and test models at the complexity level justified by the available data. This approach has the potential to improve our understanding of cancer cell biology and inform the development of more effective anticancer therapies.
Primary Coenzyme Q (CoQ) Deficiency in Pdss2 Mutant Mice Causes Isolated Renal Disease
    A study investigated the effects of primary CoQ deficiency in mice with a missense mutation in the Pdss2 gene, which encodes an enzyme involved in CoQ biosynthesis. Homozygous mutations in Pdss2 have been associated with severe neuromuscular disease and nephrotic syndrome in humans. The study found that mice with the Pdss2kd/kd genotype exhibited significantly lower levels of CoQ9 and CoQ10 in kidney homogenates compared to control mice. Disease manifestations in these mice originated specifically in glomerular podocytes, as renal disease was observed in Podocin/cre, Pdss2loxP/loxP knockout mice but not in conditional knockouts targeted to renal tubular epithelium, monocytes, or hepatocytes. Liver-conditional B6.Alb/cre, Pdss2loxP/loxP knockout mice had undetectable CoQ9 levels, impaired respiratory capacity, and altered intermediary metabolism, but did not exhibit overt disease. These findings suggest that disease manifestations of CoQ deficiency are related to tissue-specific respiratory capacity thresholds, with glomerular podocytes displaying the greatest sensitivity to Pdss2 impairment. The study demonstrates that renal disease in Pdss2kd/kd mice results from podocyte-specific Pdss2 dysfunction, and that the inflammatory response is not the primary cause of the renal disease. The availability of B6.Pdss2loxP/loxP mice will permit future investigations into the specific sites of CoQ deficiency and tissue damage in other tissues, such as the central nervous system and skeletal muscle.
The article reports that determinative developmental cell lineages in two protostomes and one deuterostome exhibit robustness to cell deaths due to environmental and genetic perturbations. Phenotypic robustness is a key characteristic of life, but its underlying mechanisms and evolutionary origins are not well understood. The study demonstrates that cell lineage robustness arises from several features of the cell lineages, including their shallowness, topology, early ontogenic appearances of rare cells, and non-clonality of most cell types. These features underlie the robustness of the cell lineages to necrosis and cell division program failure, which represent environmental and genetic disturbances, respectively. The study provides experimentally testable hypotheses on the organizing principles of developmental cell lineages and opens the door to characterizing systemic properties of complex cell lineages. The findings reveal a new mechanism of phenotypic robustness that manifests at the supracellular level and is a unique feature of multicellular organisms. This mechanism complements subcellular and cellular mechanisms of robustness to form a multi-layer defense system against environmental and genetic perturbations. The study also provides a novel explanation of the contribution of ontogenesis to phenotypic robustness and suggests that cell lineage robustness can arise as an adaptation to certain disturbances in ontogenesis. The results have important implications for understanding development, evolution, and carcinogenesis.
The article presents EmbryoPhenomics, an open-source high-throughput platform for phenomics in aquatic embryos. The platform consists of an Open-source Video Microscope (OpenVIM) and a Python package Embryo Computer Vision (EmbryoCV). OpenVIM captures high-resolution videos of multiple embryos under controlled environmental conditions, while EmbryoCV extracts phenomic data for morphological, physiological, behavioral, and proxy traits during embryonic development. The platform is demonstrated in a series of experiments assessing chronic, acute, and multistressor responses to environmental change (temperature and salinity) in over 30 million images of over 600 embryos of two species with different patterns of development. The results show that EmbryoCV successfully extracted phenome-level data from 95% of the images, producing high-dimensional data describing morphological, physiological, and behavioral embryo responses. EmbryoPhenomics is shown to be capable of acquiring and processing data capturing functional, temporal, and spatial responses in the earliest, most dynamic life stages. The platform is versatile and can be applied to a broad range of experimental designs, from 2-week to 24-hour experiments, and can be used to study embryonic development in a manner befitting phenomics. The results demonstrate high concordance between manually and EmbryoCV-determined measures of embryo spatial and temporal characteristics. EmbryoPhenomics has the potential to be game-changing for those interested in studying development and phenomics, particularly in the context of assessing complex organismal responses to environmental change.
Malaria parasites (Plasmodium spp.) undergo significant changes in metabolism as they transition between their complex life cycles in mosquito and human hosts. Using stable isotope labeling, targeted metabolomics, and reverse genetics, researchers investigated stage-specific changes in Plasmodium berghei carbon metabolism. The study found that glutamine serves as the primary input into the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle in both asexual and sexual blood stages, and is essential for complete male gametogenesis. Additionally, glutamine catabolism and key reactions in intermediary metabolism and CoA synthesis are crucial for the ookinete to oocyst transition in the mosquito. These findings highlight significant metabolic differences between Plasmodium species and underscore the importance of integrating metabolomics data with other platforms to inform drug discovery and design. The study also suggests that inhibitors of the TCA cycle, currently being investigated for asexual inhibition of the malaria parasite, may also have transmission-blocking capacity. The results provide new insights into the metabolic flexibility of different Plasmodium mosquito stages and the impact of parasite metabolism on development in the mosquito vector. Overall, the study contributes to our understanding of Plasmodium metabolism and identifies potential targets for transmission-blocking intervention strategies.
Incoherent feedforward loops ( IFFLs ) are a common motif in biological signaling pathways that enable cells to differentiate between pulsatile and sustained signals in the regulation of downstream gene expression. IFFLs consist of an input that simultaneously activates an output and an inhibitor of the output, allowing the system to exhibit temporal adaptation and desensitize to sustained inputs. This property enables the system to distinguish between input signals with varying temporal profiles. However, the ability of IFFLs to process oscillatory signals is limited by two constraints. The kinetics of the IFFL components dictate the input range for which the network can decode pulsatile dynamics, and a match between the network parameters and input signal characteristics is required for optimal "counting" of oscillatory signals. The authors used quantitative modeling to examine the ability of IFFLs to process oscillatory signals and found that the network's ability to translate pulsatile dynamics is limited by these constraints. The study highlights the importance of understanding how cells process oscillatory signals and has implications for the design of synthetic gene circuits for this purpose. The IFFL motif is found downstream of divergent signals in both social amoeba and mammalian cell differentiation, suggesting a general role in processing transient or oscillatory signals.
Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is a leading cause of serious febrile illness in rural Southeast Asia. However, research into its basic mechanisms of cell biology and pathogenicity has been hindered by its obligate intracellular nature, requiring specific methodologies for propagation and analysis. To address this, a clinical isolate of O. tsutsugamushi was grown in cultured mouse embryonic fibroblast ( L929 ) cells, and bacterial growth was measured using an O. tsutsugamushi-specific qPCR assay. A standardised method for comparing the viability of O. tsutsugamushi after purification, treatment, and propagation under various conditions was developed. The study presents a body of data to support improved techniques for propagation, purification, and storage of this organism, which will be useful for improving clinical isolation rates and performing in vitro cell biology experiments. A simplified growth assay was used to compare the growth of O. tsutsugamushi across a range of conditions, allowing for the quantification of bacterial levels by extracting total DNA and measuring the exact genome copy number using a primer/probe set specific to a short region within the O. tsutsugamushi 47kDa Htra single copy gene. These findings will be useful to researchers working on O. tsutsugamushi and other obligate intracellular pathogens, such as those in the Rickettsiales and Chlamydiales families.
This study investigated the safety and efficacy of the antihelminthic drug praziquantel (PZQ) in children aged 1–5 years, who are currently excluded from schistosome control programs due to a lack of PZQ safety data in this age group. A total of 104 Zimbabwean children aged 1–5 years were treated with PZQ tablets, and side effects were assessed by questionnaire administered to their caregivers within 24 hours of treatment. Treatment efficacy was determined 6 weeks after PZQ administration through schistosome egg counts in urine. The study found that PZQ treatment significantly reduced schistosome infection levels in 1–5 year olds, with an egg reduction rate (ERR) of 99% and a cure rate (CR) of 92%. These results were comparable to the efficacy of PZQ in 6–10 year olds, where ERR was 96% and CR was 67%. Only 3.8% of the children reported side effects within 24 hours of taking PZQ treatment, which included stomach ache, loss of appetite, lethargy, and inflammation of the face and body. The study suggests that PZQ treatment is as safe and efficacious in children aged 1–5 years as it is in older children aged 6–10 years, where PZQ is the drug of choice for control of schistosome infections. These findings support the inclusion of pre-school children and infants in schistosome-control programs.
A genome-wide functional screen in Drosophila melanogaster was conducted to identify genes involved in Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis. The screen used a Ras85DV12-driven tumorigenesis model and RNAi-mediated knockdown to assay the role of a large number of previously unexplored genes in Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis in vivo. This approach allowed for the identification of multiple novel and evolutionarily conserved pathways controlling Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis. Human gene orthologs of the fly hits were significantly downregulated in thousands of primary tumors, revealing novel prognostic markers for human epithelial tumors. Of the top 100 candidate tumor suppressor genes, 80 were validated in secondary Drosophila assays, including many known cancer genes and multiple novel candidate genes that cooperate with Ras-driven tumorigenesis. The top hit, Tetraspanin 29Fb, was mechanistically characterized and found to regulate EGFR signaling, epithelial architecture, and restrain tumor growth and invasion. Low expression of the confirmed hits significantly correlated with the KRASG12 mutation status and poor prognosis in pancreatic cancer. This study provides a starting point for the identification of novel genes and pathways involved in tumor suppression and metastasis of Ras-driven epithelial cancers. The findings have implications for the development of novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets for a diverse range of epithelial tumors.
The wtf gene family in Schizosaccharomyces pombe contains meiotic drivers that subvert gametogenesis to increase their transmission into progeny. The wtf13 gene, found in lab stocks, is a meiotic driver that generates a diffusible poison and a spore-specific antidote, killing spores that do not inherit it. A suppressor of wtf13, wtf18-2, arose spontaneously in the lab and encodes a protein that acts via molecular mimicry of the wtf13 antidote. Wtf18-2 rescues only the spores that inherit it, selfishly gaining a transmission advantage while dampening the drive of wtf13. This establishes a novel paradigm for meiotic drive suppressors and provides insight into the mechanisms and evolution of drive systems. Four other wtf genes have been identified as meiotic drivers in wild isolates of S. pombe, all acting to kill spores that do not inherit them. At least one of these genes, wtf4, causes meiotic drive by a poison and antidote mechanism. The wtf18-2 protein does not act indiscriminately to prevent spore destruction, but rather rescues only the spores that inherit it. This is a departure from the prevailing hypothesis that suppressors of killer meiotic drivers work indiscriminately. The results suggest that at least some wtf genes encode only antidotes and can act as suppressors of wtf drive genes.
Biomedical researchers have developed an algorithm to predict gene expression differences among human individuals using only their genotype information. The algorithm uses training expression and genotype data from a set of individuals to predict the expression of genes in unseen test individuals based on their genotype in the local genomic vicinity of the predicted gene. Notably, the predictions are robust and agree well between the training and test sets, even when the training and test sets consist of individuals from distinct populations. The algorithm can predict the expression of a relatively small number of genes, but the robust nature of the predictions means that the identity and quantitative degree to which genes can be predicted is known in advance. An extension of the algorithm incorporates heterogeneous types of genomic annotations to differentially weigh the importance of the various genetic variants. Assigning higher weights to variants with particular annotations such as proximity to genes and high regional G/C content can further improve the predictions. Genes that are successfully predicted have higher expression and more variability across individuals, providing insight into the characteristics of the types of genes that can be predicted from their cis genetic variation. The algorithm's ability to predict gene expression changes among individuals based on their genetic sequence variation is a major goal in understanding the susceptibility to different diseases and phenotypes.
The study investigated the cause of competitive suppression of an avirulent clone of Plasmodium chabaudi (AS) by a virulent clone (AJ) in immuno-deficient and competent mice. Using dynamical-model based Bayesian inference, the researchers tested whether competitive suppression was caused by clone-specific differences in adaptive immune clearance of merozoites and parasitised red blood cells (RBCs), background loss of merozoites and parasitised RBCs, RBC age preference, RBC infection rate, burst size, and within-RBC interference. The results showed that only one parameter, the ratio of background loss rate of merozoites to invasion rate of mature RBCs, needed to be clone-specific to predict the data. This parameter was found to be the same for both clones in single-clone infections but different between the clones in mixed infections. The size of this difference was largest in immuno-competent mice and smallest in immuno-deficient mice, which explains why competitive suppression was alleviated in immuno-deficient mice. The study found that competitive suppression acts early in infection, even before the day of peak parasitaemia. The results suggest that the innate immune response clearing merozoites is the most likely mediator of competitive interactions between virulent and avirulent clones, and that there may be an interaction between the clones and the innate immune response that induces changes in the strength of its clearance of merozoites.
The Origin-Dependent Inverted-Repeat Amplification (ODIRA) model proposes that a replication error at pre-existing short, interrupted, inverted repeats in genomic sequences generates an extrachromosomal, inverted dimeric, autonomously replicating intermediate. This intermediate subsequently integrates into the genome by homologous recombination, creating an inverted triplication without loss of distal chromosomal sequences. The model was tested using a combination of in vitro and in vivo approaches in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The results show that the proposed replication error, the ligation of leading and lagging nascent strands to create "closed" forks, can occur in vitro at short, interrupted inverted repeats. The removal of molecules with two closed forks results in a hairpin-capped linear duplex that replicates in vivo to create an inverted, dimeric plasmid. This plasmid integrates into the genome by homologous recombination, creating an inverted triplication. The ODIRA model can also explain the generation of human, de novo, inverted amplicons with a 2:1 mixture of sequences from both homologues of a single parent. This feature is readily explained by a plasmid intermediate that arises from one homologue and integrates into the other homologue prior to meiosis. The tests of key features of ODIRA lend support to this mechanism and suggest further avenues of enquiry to unravel the origins of interstitial, inverted copy number variations pivotal in human health and evolution.
This study provides a comprehensive analysis of translation initiation in cells infected with influenza virus. The authors investigate the extent and impact of alternate translation initiation, where translation can initiate at non-canonical start codons in response to stressful stimuli. Using ribosome profiling with the initiation inhibitor lactimidomycin, the authors experimentally delineate translation initiation sites in a human lung epithelial cell line infected with influenza virus. They identify several candidate sites of alternate initiation in influenza mRNAs, all of which occur at AUG codons downstream of canonical initiation codons. One of these candidate downstream start sites truncates 14 amino acids from the N-terminus of the N1 neuraminidase protein, resulting in loss of its cytoplasmic tail and a portion of the transmembrane domain. This truncated neuraminidase protein is expressed on the cell surface during influenza virus infection, is enzymatically active, and is conserved in most N1 viral lineages. The authors also perform evolutionary analyses that suggest selection against non-canonical initiation at CUG codons in influenza virus lineages that have adapted to mammalian hosts. Overall, the study systematically maps the landscape of translation initiation during influenza virus infection and sheds light on the evolutionary forces shaping this landscape.
Enteric bacterial pathogens, such as Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC), cause foodborne disease, resulting in significant economic and health burdens. EHEC can lead to severe bloody diarrhea and potentially fatal kidney disease (hemolytic uremic syndrome) for which there is no effective treatment or prophylaxis. EHEC and other enteric pathogens utilize a type III secretion system (T3SS) to inject virulence proteins (effectors) into host cells, which subvert host cell function to promote diarrheal disease and bacterial transmission. However, the mechanisms by which these effectors bind to host proteins and disrupt normal intestinal epithelial cell function have not been fully characterized. This study investigated the binding of E. coli O157:H7 T3SS effectors, NleH1 and NleH2, to the human ribosomal protein S3 (RPS3), a subunit of nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells (NF-κB) transcriptional complexes. The study found that NleH1 and NleH2 bind to RPS3 in the cytoplasm, but not in cell nuclei, and that the N-terminal region of both proteins is required for binding. NleH1, but not NleH2, reduced the nuclear abundance of RPS3 without altering the p50 or p65 NF-κB subunits or affecting the phosphorylation state or abundance of the inhibitory NF-κB chaperone IκBα. NleH1 repressed the transcription of a RPS3/NF-κB-dependent reporter plasmid, while NleH2 stimulated RPS3-dependent transcription. A region of NleH1 (N40-K45) was identified as responsible for the inhibitory activity of NleH1 toward RPS3. Deleting nleH1 from E. coli O157:H7 produced a hypervirulent phenotype in a gnotobiotic piglet model of Shiga toxin-producing E. coli infection. The study suggests that NleH may disrupt host innate immune responses by binding to a cofactor of host transcriptional complexes.
Transcription factor (TF) binding to its DNA target site is a fundamental regulatory interaction. The current dominant model used to represent TF binding specificities is the position-specific scoring matrix (PSSM), which assumes independence between binding positions. However, this simplifying assumption does not hold in many cases. A novel probabilistic method, feature motif models (FMMs), is presented to model TF-DNA interactions based on log-linear models. FMMs use sequence features to represent TF binding specificities, where each feature may span multiple positions. The mathematical formulation of the model and an algorithm for learning its structural features from binding site data are developed. A discriminative motif finder is also devised to discover de novo FMMs that are enriched in target sets of sequences compared to background sets. The approach is evaluated on synthetic data and the widely used TF chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) dataset of Harbison et al. The algorithm is then applied to high-throughput TF ChIP data from mouse and human, revealing sequence features that are present in the binding specificities of mouse and human TFs. The results show that FMMs explain TF binding significantly better than PSSMs. The FMM learning and motif finder software are available at http://genie.weizmann.ac.il/. FMMs are a generalization of the PSSM model, enabling complex position dependencies to be captured, as well as other high-level features such as palindromes.
The study investigated the regulation of sympathetic nervous activity in humans and chimpanzees by examining the adrenergic α2C receptor (ADRA2C) gene. Knockout mice for this gene exhibit physiological and behavioral alterations associated with the fight-or-flight response. The study found that the neuronal expression of ADRA2C is lower in humans and chimpanzees compared to other primates. Using three-dimensional chromatin structure analysis, a cis-regulatory region was identified whose DNA sequences have been accelerated in humans and chimpanzees. This region contains two neuron-restrictive silencer factor (NRSF) binding motifs, each harboring a polymorphism. Genotyping and analysis of population genome data revealed that the derived allele has reached fixation in humans and chimpanzees but not in bonobos or macaques. CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing and reporter assays showed that both derived nucleotides repress ADRA2C, likely by increasing NRSF binding. The study also detected signatures of recent positive selection for lower neuronal ADRA2C expression in humans. The findings suggest that there has been selective pressure for enhanced sympathetic nervous activity in the evolution of humans and chimpanzees. The study used a combination of transcriptomic, epigenomic, and population genomic data to identify selected regulatory variants responsible for human- and chimpanzee-specific repression of ADRA2C. The results indicate that the repression of ADRA2C is mediated by different mechanisms in humans and chimpanzees, with humans exhibiting DNA methylation and chimpanzees showing H3K27me3 marks.
The C4 photosynthetic pathway is a highly complex trait that has evolved independently in at least 60 species across monocotyledons and dicotyledons, resulting in a 50% increase in productivity in tropical and subtropical areas. To investigate the genetic networks underlying this trait, a new informatics framework was developed to enable deep evolutionary comparison of gene expression in species lacking reference genomes. This framework was applied to two independent C4 lineages, Cleome gynandra and Zea mays, whose last common ancestor diverged 140 million years ago. A cohort of 3,335 genes representing conserved components of leaf and photosynthetic development was identified, and genes encoding proteins of the C4 cycle were found to be recruited into networks defined by photosynthesis-related genes. Notably, homologous transcription factors were used to induce C4 photosynthesis and maintain cell-specific gene expression in both species, despite their wide evolutionary separation. A core molecular signature associated with leaf and photosynthetic maturation was also identified, which is likely shared by angiosperm species derived from the last common ancestor of monocotyledons and dicotyledons. These findings suggest that parallel evolution of trans-factors underpins the repeated appearance of C4 photosynthesis, and that deep evolutionary comparisons of gene expression can reveal novel insights into the molecular convergence of complex phenotypes. Furthermore, the shared transcription factors between independent C4 lineages are key targets for engineering the C4 pathway into C3 crops such as rice.
During the 2013-2016 Ebola virus (EBOV) epidemic in West Africa, Europe, and North America, several health care workers (HCWs) were infected, highlighting the need for a better understanding of EBOV infection patterns in different body compartments to develop new countermeasures. A study was conducted on a HCW infected with EBOV in Sierra Leone, who was hospitalized in a high-isolation facility in Italy. The study aimed to explore the persistence of EBOV-specific negative sense genomic RNA (neg-RNA) and positive sense RNA (pos-RNA), including replication intermediate (antigenomic-RNA) and messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules, in the upper and lower respiratory tract, as compared to plasma. The results showed that pos-RNA and neg-RNAs persisted in the lower respiratory tract even after viral clearance from plasma, suggesting possible local replication. The study found that the levels of EBOV total RNA, neg-RNA, and pos-RNA decayed over time, with significant differences between plasma and respiratory samples. The detection of pos-RNA together with neg-RNA in sputum supported the concept of active viral replication within the respiratory tract, rather than plasma spill-over or prolonged RNA stability. The study's findings are consistent with a recent review of post-mortem examinations of fatal filoviral infections, which provided evidence of viral replication within the respiratory tract. The results suggest that EBOV can replicate in human airway tissues, which has implications for understanding human-to-human transmission and developing effective intervention strategies.
The ectodomain of the glycoprotein (GPC) from the Candid#1 (Cd#1) vaccine strain of Junin virus (JUNV) has been found to contribute to the attenuation of Machupo virus (MACV) in mice lacking interferon-alpha/beta/gamma receptor (IFN-αβ/γ R-/-). A recombinant, chimeric MACV (rMACV/Cd#1-GPC) expressing the Cd#1 GPC is completely attenuated in a murine model and protects animals from lethal challenge with MACV. However, a rMACV with a single F438I substitution in the transmembrane domain (TMD) of GPC, equivalent to the F427I attenuating mutation in Cd#1 GPC, was attenuated in a murine model but genetically unstable. To investigate the requirement of different domains of Cd#1 GPC for successful attenuation of MACV, several rMACVs were rescued expressing the ectodomain of GPC from Cd#1 either alone (MCg1), along with the TMD F438I substitution (MCg2), or with the TMD of Cd#1 (MCg3). All rMACVs exhibited similar growth curves in cultured cells. In mice, MCg1 displayed significant reduction in lethality compared to rMACV, while MCg2 and MCg3 were completely attenuated and induced neutralizing antibody against Cd#1. The results suggest that the ectodomain of Cd#1 GPC plays an indispensable role in the full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMACV/Cd#1 GPC. This study provides new insights into the development of vaccine candidates for MACV and other New World arenaviruses.
The study investigated the role of point mutations in the centromeric histone 3 variant (CENH3) in Arabidopsis thaliana. CENH3 is essential for the segregation of sister chromatids during mitosis and meiosis. To understand the functional constraints of CENH3, researchers complemented a null allele with various mutant alleles, each inducing a single amino acid change in conserved residues of the histone fold domain. The results showed that many of these transgenic missense lines displayed wild-type growth and fertility on self-pollination but exhibited post-zygotic death and uniparental inheritance when crossed with wild-type plants. This phenomenon is similar to the genome elimination syndromes observed with chimeric CENH3 and CENH3 from diverged species. The study also demonstrated that a single point mutation is sufficient to generate a haploid inducer, providing a simple method for identifying non-transgenic haploid inducers in existing mutagenized collections of crop species. An in silico search for previously identified point mutations in CENH3 revealed an Arabidopsis line carrying the A86V substitution within the histone fold domain, which produced post-zygotic death and uniparental haploids when crossed to wild-type plants. The findings suggest that altering single conserved amino acid residues in the histone fold domain of CENH3 results in fit and fertile plants that display post-zygotic incompatibility and produce haploids when crossed to wild-type plants.
This study investigated the role of alternative splicing (AS) in the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) into cardiac precursors. The researchers modified the H9 hESC line to allow for the selection of pluripotent hESCs and cardiac progenitors. Exon-level microarray expression data from undifferentiated hESCs and cardiac and neural precursors were used to identify splice isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common cardiac/neural differentiation expression patterns. The results showed that AS events corresponded to pathways involved in cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle checkpoint control, as well as genes with serine/threonine kinase and helicase activity. Using the AltAnalyze program, the researchers identified novel changes in protein domain and microRNA binding site architecture that were predicted to affect protein function and expression. These changes included an enrichment of splice isoforms that oppose cell-cycle arrest in hESCs and promote calcium signaling and cardiac development in cardiac precursors. The study suggests that AS may influence lineage commitment and hESC maintenance at the level of specific splice isoforms and microRNA regulation. The results also imply that the loss of pluripotency corresponds to AS of genes that regulate transcription, cell-cell contact formation, and metabolism, while cardiac-enriched events favor contractile pathways, inhibition of neurogenesis, and Wnt signaling. Overall, the study provides new insights into the role of AS in the differentiation of hESCs into cardiac precursors and identifies potential targets for driving the expression of pluripotent cells to distinct lineages.
Trehalose-6-phosphate (T6P) synthase OtsA and T6P phosphatase OtsB2 play a crucial role in the biosynthesis of trehalose in Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis). To assess the potential of T6P phosphatase as a drug target, researchers generated a conditional mutant of M. tuberculosis that allowed for the regulated silencing of the otsB2 gene. The results showed that otsB2 is essential for the growth of M. tuberculosis in vitro and during the acute infection phase in mice, but not during the chronic infection phase. The accumulation of T6P, the substrate of OtsB2, was found to be toxic to the cells, leading to self-poisoning. Blocking T6P production in a ΔotsA mutant abrogated the essentiality of otsB2, suggesting that T6P accumulation is the primary cause of otsB2 essentiality. The accumulation of T6P also led to a global upregulation of over 800 genes, which may result from an increase in RNA stability. A genome-wide screen for synthetic lethal interactions with otsA identified numerous genes, revealing additional potential drug targets that could be used in combination with OtsB2 inhibitors to minimize the emergence of resistance. The study highlights the importance of understanding the remodeling of trehalose metabolism in M. tuberculosis during infection and the potential of T6P phosphatase as a drug target.
Trypanosoma cruzi proline racemase (TcPR) has been identified as a promising target for therapies against Chagas' disease, a life-threatening illness affecting 11-18 million people. Current treatments have poor efficacy and safety profiles, making the development of new drugs urgent. TcPR is believed to modulate the exposure of critical residues that elicit a host mitogenic B-cell response, contributing to parasite persistence and immune system evasion. To understand the conformational changes associated with substrate binding to TcPR, advanced accelerated molecular dynamics simulations were employed to extend the effective simulation time and capture large-scale motions. The results revealed potential conformational epitopes located in the vicinity of newly identified transient binding pockets. The newly identified open TcPR conformations, along with the knowledge of the closed to open interconversion mechanism, advance our understanding of TcPR function. Conservation and fragment mapping analyses indicate that the mitogenic properties of TcPR are likely associated with the exposure of conserved conformational epitopes around previously unidentified binding pockets. These findings provide new insights for future structure-based drug discovery and constitute an important step toward the rationalization of the molecular basis behind the mitogenic B-cell response of TcPR. The results suggest that TcPR represents a promising target for therapies that may more efficiently combat Chagas' disease.
The development of an inducible and reversible mouse genetic rescue system has been achieved through the creation of a binary approach based on Tet-dependent regulatory technology. This system, named iKO, allows for the efficient production of reversible and inducible gene knockout and rescue in mice. The iKO system consists of two genetically modified mouse lines: a knockout (KO) line with a tetracycline-dependent transactivator replacing the endogenous target gene, and a line with a tetracycline-inducible cDNA of the target gene inserted into a tightly regulated genomic locus. By treating the mice with doxycycline, the target gene can be turned on and off at will. The system has been engineered for high-throughput, large-scale, and cost-effective production of iKO mice. As a proof of concept, iKO mice were created in the apolipoprotein E (ApoE) gene, allowing for sensitive and quantitative phenotypic analyses. The results demonstrated reversible switching of ApoE transcription, plasma cholesterol levels, and atherosclerosis progression and regression. The iKO system shows stringent regulation and is a versatile genetic system that can easily incorporate other techniques and adapt to a wide range of applications. This system complements existing inducible gene expression approaches and provides certain advantages, including reversibility, high efficiency, streamlined production, and flexibility. The iKO system has the potential to be used for a wide range of applications, including modeling human conditions such as hypercholesterolemia and atherosclerosis.
The study investigated the genetic response of the placental environment to Trypanosoma cruzi infection in a murine model using two different strains: K98, a clone of the non-lethal myotropic CA-I strain, and VD, isolated from a human case of congenital infection. Microarray analysis was performed to compare gene expression in placentas from uninfected animals and those infected with either strain. The results showed that the "Secretory Granule" pathway was down-regulated in both infected groups, while the "Innate Immune Response" and "Response to Interferon-gamma" pathways were up-regulated in VD-infected placentas but not in K98-infected placentas. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) revealed that metabolic processes, transcription, and macromolecular transport were down-regulated in infected placentas, and some pathways related to cascade signaling had opposite regulation in VD and K98 groups. Furthermore, VD strain showed a stronger tropism to the placental organ, with detection of parasite DNA and RNA, indicating living parasites. These findings suggest that the placental environment responds differently to T. cruzi infection depending on the parasite genotype, with a strong immune response in VD-infected placentas that may contribute to controlling infection and preventing congenital transmission. The study provides new insights into the genetic response of the placental environment to T. cruzi infection and highlights the importance of considering the parasite genotype in understanding the risk of congenital transmission.
A seven-year cycle of Sindbis virus (SINV) outbreaks in northern Europe has been hypothesized based on reported human cases of polyarthritis and rash, also known as Ockelbo disease in Sweden and Pogosta disease in Finland. To investigate this hypothesis, mosquito abundance and SINV prevalence in vector mosquitoes from an endemic area in central Sweden were evaluated. Mosquitoes were collected from the River Dalälven floodplains during the years before, during, and after the hypothesized 2002 outbreak year and assayed for virus on cell culture. The obtained isolates were partially sequenced and analyzed using Bayesian maximum clade credibility and median joining network analysis. The results showed a significant increase in SINV prevalence in both enzootic and bridge-vector mosquitoes in 2002, with infection rates of 10.0/1000 in Culex torrentium/pipiens and 0.62/1000 in Aedes cinereus. Sequence analysis revealed that all isolates belonged to the SINV genotype I (SINV-I) and showed local maintenance of four SINV-I clades in the River Dalälven floodplains over the years. The findings suggest that increased SINV-I prevalence in vector mosquitoes constitutes the most valuable outbreak marker for further scrutinizing the hypothesized seven-year cycle of SINV-I outbreaks and the mechanisms behind. The study provides the first objective markers for SINV polyarthritis outbreaks in northern Europe.
The study investigated the interaction of multiple coding mechanisms in the locust olfactory system, specifically the transformation of dense, transiently synchronized spike trains in the antenna lobe ( AL ) into a sparse representation in the mushroom body ( MB ). Recordings from the MB demonstrated highly specific responses to odors in Kenyon cells ( KCs ), with typically only a few KCs from the recorded population responding reliably to a specific odor. Different odors induced responses in different KCs. A biologically plausible model was used to explore the possibility that plasticity may control and tune synaptic weights of inputs to the mushroom body to ensure the specificity of KCs' responses to familiar or meaningful odors. The results showed that plasticity at the synapses between the AL and the MB efficiently regulated the delicate tuning necessary to selectively filter the intense AL oscillatory output and condense it to a sparse representation in the MB. Activity-dependent plasticity drove the observed specificity, reliability, and expected persistence of odor representations. This suggests a role for plasticity in information processing and makes a testable prediction about synaptic plasticity at AL-MB synapses. The findings are consistent with a recent set of experimental results supporting a pre-synaptic mechanism of plasticity between Kenyon cells and mushroom body extrinsic neurons as a critical process in olfactory memory.
The Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene Expression (STAGE) study aimed to identify functionally associated genes involved in the development of coronary artery disease (CAD). The study analyzed transcriptional profiles from five CAD-relevant tissues, including liver, skeletal muscle, visceral fat, atherosclerotic arterial wall, and unaffected arterial wall, from 278 patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Two-way clustering revealed 60 tissue clusters, with one cluster in atherosclerotic arterial wall and one in visceral fat segregating patients into two groups differing in coronary stenosis extent (P=0.008 and P=0.00015, respectively). The associations were validated by analyzing carotid atherosclerosis expression profiles, with 27 genes in the two clusters relating to coronary stenosis confirmed (n=16/17, P<10−27 and P<10−30). The transendothelial migration of leukocytes (TEML) pathway was overrepresented in all three clusters, referred to as the atherosclerosis module (A-module). The A-module was found to be genetically enriched with CAD risk by 1.8-fold (P<0.004) in three independent cohorts. The transcription co-factor LIM domain binding 2 (LDB2) was identified as a potential high-hierarchy regulator of the A-module, supported by subnetwork analysis, cellular and lesion expression of LDB2, and expression of 13 TEML genes in Ldb2-deficient arterial wall. The A-module appears to be important for atherosclerosis development, and LDB2 merits further attention in CAD research.
A two-loop transcriptional feedback mechanism has been identified in the cyanobacterial circadian clock of Synechococcus. This mechanism involves the KaiC protein, a central component of the circadian clock, which undergoes different phospho-states during the 24-hour day-night cycle. Specifically, threonine and double phosphorylated KaiC hexamers activate the transcription of the kaiBC gene, while unphosphorylated KaiC hexamers suppress its transcription. This two-loop feedback mechanism is able to reproduce existing experimental observations, including the effects of knockout or overexpression of kai genes. The model simulations suggest that the peak expression ratio of the positive and negative components of kaiBC expression is the main factor in how the different two-loop feedback models respond to removal or overexpression of kai genes. The proposed TTFL/PTO model, which combines a post-translational oscillator with a transcriptional/translational feedback loop, provides a comprehensive explanation for the regulation of kaiBC expression and its role in the cyanobacterial circadian clock. This model has the potential to reveal how the circadian output pathways allow the KaiC protein to control several hundred rhythmically regulated genes in the cyanobacterial genome. The findings have parallels with two-loop feedback structures found in the mammalian clock, highlighting the conserved nature of circadian clock mechanisms across different organisms.
The study investigated the characteristics of HIV-2 reservoirs in individuals infected with HIV-2, a virus known for its low pathogenicity and replicative potential. The researchers analyzed peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from 14 antiretroviral-naive HIV-2-infected individuals, including 12 non-progressors and 2 progressors. The results showed that HIV-2 DNA was undetectable in monocytes from all individuals, but was quantifiable in transitional-memory CD4 T-cells (TTM) from 4 individuals and in central-memory CD4 T-cells (TCM) from only 1 individual. HIV-2 DNA levels in PBMCs positively correlated with those in TTM, but not TCM. Reactivation of HIV-2 was observed in cells from only 3 individuals. The study also found that TCM had a lower expression of CXCR6 transcripts and a higher expression of TRIM5 transcripts compared to TTM. These findings suggest that HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 reservoirs by the lack of monocytic infection and a limited infection of TCM associated with a lower expression of the CXCR6 co-receptor and a higher expression of the restriction factor TRIM5. The results provide new insights into the low pathogenicity of HIV-2 infection and suggest mechanisms similar to those reported in other models of attenuated HIV/SIV infection. The study highlights the importance of understanding the determinants of the atypical distribution of HIV-2 reservoirs among memory CD4 T-cells.
The article presents the Attentional Routing Circuit (ARC) model, a mechanistic description of selective attentional processing in the cortex. The model is implemented in spiking neurons and maps computations for selective attentional processing to specific neuron types and laminar circuitry. The ARC model provides a unified explanation of various attentional effects, including shifting and shrinking of receptive fields, increases in responses without changes in selectivity for non-spatial features (response gain), and the effect on contrast-response functions being better explained as a response-gain effect than as contrast-gain. The model is consistent with a wide array of available data and makes several specific and quantifiable predictions. The ARC's mechanisms for selective routing predict that spatial attention only affects neural spatial selectivity, without altering selectivity for other feature dimensions, distinguishing it from the normalization model. The model also predicts that an increasing proportion of neurons at each higher cortical level will show attentional modulation, with the magnitude of modulation increasing in higher cortical areas. The ARC is demonstrated to quantitatively match several observed forms of attentional modulation in macaque studies, providing a single mechanism that unifies the above forms of attentional modulation.
A large-scale whole exome sequencing study was conducted to investigate the genetic contribution to atrial fibrillation (AF), a common and heritable arrhythmia. The study analyzed data from 1,734 individuals with AF and 9,423 controls from four community-based cohorts, including the Framingham Heart Study, Cardiovascular Health Study, Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities Study, and NHLBI-GO Exome Sequencing Project. None of the 99,404 common variants evaluated was significantly associated with AF after adjusting for multiple testing. However, a common missense variant in the SYNPO2L gene (rs3812629, p.Pro707Leu) was identified as the most significantly associated variant, with an odds ratio of 1.27 (95% CI 1.13-1.43, P = 6.6x10-5). This variant lies at a known AF susceptibility locus and is in linkage disequilibrium with a top marker from prior analyses at the locus. The study did not observe significant associations between rare variants and AF in gene-based tests, and individuals with AF did not display any statistically significant enrichment for common or rare coding variation in previously implicated AF genes. The results suggest that large-effect coding variation is not the predominant mechanism underlying AF, and further evaluation is needed to determine whether the identified variant in SYNPO2L is causally related to AF. The study highlights the need for large sample sizes or populations enriched for large genetic effects to identify biologically meaningful coding variation underlying AF.
Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 human cases of alveolar echinococcosis (AE) caused by Echinococcus multilocularis were detected in Poland. The cases were verified by clinical, epidemiological, and laboratory criteria, with 83 (68.6%) classified as confirmed, 16 as probable, and 22 as possible. The majority of cases (76) were diagnosed in an advanced stage of the disease, with the liver being the primary location of AE in all cases. In 30 (24.8%) patients, the disease had spread to other organs. The mean age at diagnosis was 47.7 years, with a sex ratio of 0.86:1.0 (male to female). The disease was fatal in 23 (19%) patients, with a mean age at death of 54.1 years. A total of 94 patients were treated with albendazole, and 73 (60%) underwent surgical operation, including 15 liver transplantations. The study found a continuous increase in the detection rate of AE cases over the two-decade period. The results suggest that AE is an emerging disease in Poland, which is the fourth country in Europe with over 120 cases detected. The study highlights the need for a wider national program to implement screening in high-risk areas and increase public awareness of the possibility of contracting E. multilocularis, as well as training primary care physicians to recognize the risk of AE for early detection.
The study investigated the molecular mechanism of the zinc-sensing zinc uptake regulator (Zur) protein in Escherichia coli (E. coli) at each of the known Zur-regulated genes. The researchers solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PznuABC promoter and found that Zur represses gene expression by forming a highly cooperative binding of two adjacent dimers to the promoter. This cooperative binding requires a pair of asymmetric salt bridges between Arg52 and Asp49′ that connect otherwise independent dimers. The study also identified a new member of the Zur-regulon, pliG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc-responsive manner. The pliG promoter forms stable complexes with either one or two Zur dimers with significantly less protein-DNA cooperativity than observed at other Zur-regulon promoters. The in vitro Zur-DNA binding affinity at each of four Zur-regulon promoters reveals a 10,000-fold variation in binding constants. The degree of Zur repression observed in vivo parallels this trend, spanning a 100-fold difference. The study suggests that the number of ferric uptake regulator (Fur)-family dimers that bind within any given promoter varies significantly and that the thermodynamic profile of the Zur-DNA interactions directly correlates with the physiological response at different promoters. The findings provide strong support for the idea that the thermodynamics of an ensemble of protein-DNA interactions play a dominant role in the physiological control of gene regulation networks.
A spatially explicit metapopulation model and cattle trade analysis were used to investigate the recurrent circulation of Rift Valley Fever Virus (RVFV) in the Anjozorobe district of Madagascar highlands following a 2008-2009 outbreak. The study aimed to understand the key determinants of this unexpected recurrent transmission. Observational data collected in the area showed that Aedes mosquitoes, the primary vector of RVFV, were absent, and the overall mosquito abundance was low due to unfavorable climatic conditions. However, a three-year serological and virological follow-up in cattle revealed a recurrent RVFV circulation. A spatial deterministic discrete-time metapopulation model combined with cattle trade network was designed to reproduce the local conditions. Three scenarios were analyzed: (i) RVFV overwintering due to direct transmission between cattle when viraemic cows calve, (ii) low-level vector-based circulation during winter, and (iii) a combination of both mechanisms. Multi-model inference methods selected a model incorporating both low-level RVFV winter vector-borne transmission and direct transmission between animals when viraemic cows calve. This model satisfactorily reproduced field observations, attributing 84% of cattle infections to vector-borne transmission and 16% to direct transmission. The results suggest that interweaving between agricultural works in rice fields, seasonality of vector proliferation, and cattle exchange practices are key elements for understanding RVFV circulation in this area. The study highlights the importance of considering both vector-borne and direct transmission mechanisms in understanding the epidemiology of RVFV in the Madagascar highlands.
The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is a highly invasive and aggressive daytime-biting mosquito that poses a significant public health threat in its expanding range. To understand the historical and contemporary movements of Ae. albopictus in the Indo-Pacific region, researchers analyzed 13 nuclear microsatellite loci from 911 individuals and mitochondrial COI sequences. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) was employed to test competing historical routes of invasion of Ae. albopictus within the Southeast Asian/Australasian region. The results suggest that Ae. albopictus was most likely introduced to New Guinea via mainland Southeast Asia, before colonizing the Solomon Islands via either Papua New Guinea or Southeast Asia. The analysis also indicates that the recent incursion into northern Australia's Torres Strait Islands was seeded chiefly from Indonesia. A recently colonized population in the Torres Strait Islands has undergone rapid temporal changes in its genetic makeup, which could be the result of genetic drift or represent a secondary invasion from an unknown source. The study reveals high spatial genetic structure and high gene flow between some geographically distant populations, with the species' genetic structure in the region favoring a dispersal pattern driven mostly by human movements. The study provides a more widespread sampling distribution of the species' native range, revealing more spatial population structure than previously shown, and presents the most probable invasion history of Ae. albopictus in the Australasian region using ABC analysis.
In a cross-sectional study conducted in Mwanza Region, North-Western Tanzania, researchers investigated the impact of Schistosoma mansoni infection on the quality of life and physical fitness of 572 schoolchildren aged 7-8 years. The study found that 58.7% of the children were infected with S. mansoni, with an average intensity of 207.3 eggs per gram of feces. Most infections were light, while 16.4% were heavy. Girls had significantly higher infection intensities than boys. The study also found that 30.1% of the children were anemic, but there was no association between S. mansoni infection and anthropometry, liver or spleen pathology. However, children with S. mansoni infection had a significantly lower score in the emotional dimension of quality of life compared to uninfected children. In contrast, infected children had a higher VO2 max (a measure of physical fitness) compared to uninfected children. In multivariable linear regression analyses, age, S. mansoni infection, hemoglobin, and VO2 max were significant predictors of emotional quality of life, while physical quality of life, height, age, and hemoglobin were significant predictors of VO2 max. The study concluded that S. mansoni infection had a significant effect on the emotional dimension of quality of life, but not on physical fitness. The findings suggest that the PedsQL tool may not be a useful measure of schistosome-related morbidity, and further studies are needed to refine the tool to focus on aspects of quality of life affected by schistosome infections.
This study compared the effects of mucosal, subcutaneous, and intraperitoneal inoculation routes on Leptospira infection in adult rats. Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the spirochete Leptospira, with wild rodents, including the brown rat (Rattus norvegicus), serving as the main reservoir. The intraperitoneal route has been used in previous studies, but it is a non-natural route of infection in rat colonies, and the details of transmission between rats remain unknown. The study aimed to investigate the effects of mucosal and subcutaneous inoculation routes on renal colonization and urinary excretion of Leptospira infection compared to the intraperitoneal route. The results showed that Leptospira infection was asymptomatic using each inoculation route, and antibody production was similar regardless of renal colonization. The observed renal colonization rates were 8/8, 5/8, and 1/8 for the intraperitoneal, mucosal, and subcutaneous inoculation routes, respectively. Mucosal inoculation was found to be more efficient for renal colonization associated with urinary excretion than the subcutaneous route and induced a slower-progressing infection than the intraperitoneal route. These findings can facilitate understanding of the infection modalities in rats and may help explain the heterogeneity of renal carriage in rat colonies from the same region. Future studies of other natural inoculation routes in rat models will increase knowledge of rat-rat disease transmission and allow investigation of infection kinetics.
This study investigates the role of Annexin A2 (AnxA2) in modulating the inflammatory response during polymicrobial sepsis. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition characterized by excessive inflammation, tissue injury, and organ dysfunction. The researchers used a cecal ligation and puncture (CLP) model to induce sepsis in mice and found that AnxA2-deficient (anxa2-/-) mice exhibited increased pro-inflammatory cytokines, neutrophil infiltration, and decreased bacterial clearance compared to wild-type mice. Furthermore, AnxA2 deficiency led to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) and interleukin-17A (IL-17A) levels. Site-directed mutagenesis revealed that cysteine 9 of AnxA2 is crucial for regulating ROS levels. The study also found that ROS is responsible for elevated IL-17A levels and subsequent exaggerated inflammatory response. Depletion of IL-17 via CRISPR/Cas9 knockout strategy down-regulated inflammation and conferred protection against sepsis in anxa2-/- mice. The findings suggest that AnxA2 modulates the inflammatory response in sepsis via an AnxA2-ROS-IL-17 axis, providing new insights into the regulation of sepsis pathophysiology. The study highlights the potential therapeutic value of targeting AnxA2 or IL-17 in sepsis treatment.
The study investigated the role of microRNA-155 (miR-155) in the anti-HIV-1 effects of Toll-Like Receptor 3 (TLR3) stimulation in macrophages. HIV-1 infection of macrophages plays a key role in viral pathogenesis and progression to AIDS. Polyinosine-polycytidylic acid (poly(I:C)) and bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS), ligands for TLR3 and TLR4, respectively, have been shown to decrease HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages (MDMs). The study found that poly(I:C)- and LPS-stimulation of MDMs abrogated infection by CCR5-using, macrophage-tropic HIV-1, and by vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudotyped HIV-1 virions. Suppression of infection did not correlate with differential effects on CD4 or CCR5 expression, type I interferon induction, or production of pro-inflammatory cytokines or β-chemokines. Microarray analysis and quantitative reverse transcription (RT)-PCR revealed increased miR-155 levels in MDMs upon TLR3/4-stimulation, and a miR-155 specific inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly(I:C)-stimulated MDMs. Ectopic miR-155 expression remarkably diminished HIV-1 infection in primary MDMs and cell lines. The study suggests that miR-155 exerts an anti-HIV-1 effect by targeting several HIV-1 dependency factors involved in post-entry, pre-integration events, leading to severely diminished HIV-1 infection.
This study investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying the rhythmic growth of Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings in response to daily light/dark cycles. The researchers used DNA microarrays to analyze the transcriptome of Arabidopsis seedlings under various growth conditions and mutant backgrounds. The results showed that a group of plant hormone-associated genes are coexpressed at the time of day when hypocotyl growth rate is maximal. This expression is correlated with the presence of a cis-acting element ( CACATG ) in phytohormone gene promoters, which is sufficient to confer diurnal and circadian expression patterns in vivo. The study also found that both internal coincidence of phytohormone signaling capacity and external coincidence with darkness are required to coordinate wild-type growth. The circadian clock indirectly controls growth by permissive gating of light-mediated phytohormone transcript levels to the proper time of day. This temporal integration of hormone pathways allows plants to fine-tune phytohormone responses for seasonal and shade-appropriate growth regulation. The study suggests that the circadian clock acts upstream of light signaling to gate phytohormone gene expression during the early evening, and that the circadian clock and light signaling pathways interact to coordinate the expression of biosynthetic, catabolic, receptor, and signaling genes from multiple phytohormone pathways. Overall, the study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the rhythmic growth of plants in response to daily light/dark cycles.
Genetically modifying the gut microbiota of Rhodnius prolixus, the primary vector of Chagas disease, has been explored as a potential strategy for sustainable vector control. Researchers used Escherichia coli HT115 (DE3) expressing double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) for the Rhodnius heme-binding protein (RHBP) and catalase (CAT) to induce RNA interference (RNAi) in the insect. The results showed that feeding nymphs and adult triatomine stages with E. coli HT115 (DE3) expressing dsRNA for RHBP and CAT led to significant gene knockdown in various tissues, including the fat body, anterior and posterior midgut, and ovaries. The RNAi effect was systemic and temporal, with RHBP expression reduced by 99% three days after feeding and returning to normal levels 10 days after feeding. CAT expression was reduced by 99% and 96% in the ovary and posterior midgut, respectively, five days after ingestion. The study also found that mortality rates increased by 24-30% in first instars fed RHBP and CAT bacteria, molting rates were reduced by 100% in first instars and 80% in third instars, and oviposition was reduced by 43% (RHBP) and 84% (CAT). Furthermore, feeding females 10^5 CFU/mL of the natural symbiont, Rhodococcus rhodnii, transformed to express RHBP-specific hairpin RNA reduced RHBP expression by 89% and reduced oviposition. These findings suggest that modifying the insect microbiota to induce systemic RNAi in R. prolixus may result in a paratransgenic strategy for sustainable vector control.
In a study conducted on the Thai-Burmese border, fever in pregnancy was found to be a leading cause of maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality. Between 2004 and 2006, approximately 5% of pregnant women attending antenatal clinics experienced febrile episodes, with malaria being the primary cause in 55.5% of these cases. However, despite the decline in malaria incidence in the region, it remains the leading cause of fever in pregnancy. Arthropod-borne diseases, including malaria, rickettsial infections, and dengue, as well as zoonotic diseases like leptospirosis, accounted for nearly half of all febrile illnesses in pregnant women. Coinfections were observed in 3.9% of women, with malaria and rickettsia being the most common combination. Pyelonephritis was also a common cause of fever, affecting 19.7% of women. Scrub and murine typhus were associated with poor pregnancy outcomes, including stillbirth and low birth weight. The study highlights the need for a better understanding of the causes of febrile illness in pregnant women in rural tropical areas to reduce maternal and neonatal morbidity and mortality. The findings suggest that pregnant women on the Thai-Burmese border who do not have malaria, pyelonephritis, or respiratory tract infection should be treated with azithromycin, which is effective against typhus and leptospirosis.
The study examined the relationship between maternal age and recombination rate in humans using a panel of 69 French-Canadian pedigrees with over 600,000 markers genotyped. The results showed a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age, which was localized in the middle section of chromosomal arms and near subtelomeric regions. This effect was observed on nine chromosomes in the French-Canadian cohort and on two chromosomes in the Hutterites. The study suggests that chromosome-specific effects may be critical determinants of the complex relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans, and that these effects may vary among populations due to genetic differences in factors regulating the recombination machinery. The findings support the hypothesis that protection against non-disjunction provided by recombination becomes less efficient with advancing maternal age, which can contribute to higher rates of aneuploidy in older women. The study proposes a model that reconciles these findings with reported associations between maternal age and recombination in cases of trisomies. The results highlight the importance of considering chromosome-specific effects in understanding the mechanisms involved in human trisomies and the impact of maternal age on recombination rates. Overall, the study provides new insights into the complex relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans.
A novel approach to induce innate memory in macrophages in vivo has been developed using interferon-γ (IFN-γ) priming. Unlike traditional trained immunity models, this method results in a prolonged innate memory-like phenotype in macrophages that persists for at least 70 days post-immunization and provides complete protection against secondary challenge in the absence of adaptive immune cells. RNA-seq analysis of IFN-γ primed macrophages revealed a rapid up-regulation of IFN-γ and STAT1 signaling pathways following secondary challenge, leading to enhanced cytokine recall responses that are pathogen-specific and dependent on changes in histone methylation and acetylation. Notably, increased STAT1 binding to promoter regions of genes associated with protective anti-fungal immunity was observed in immunized, unchallenged pulmonary macrophages, correlating with their ability to quickly respond to secondary challenge. This study demonstrates an alternative mechanism to induce macrophage innate memory in vivo that facilitates pathogen-specific vaccine-mediated immune responses. The findings suggest that immunization strategies driving memory-like innate immune responses may provide a novel and effective mechanism for inducing vaccine-mediated protection in immunocompromised patients.
