Furthermore, the study highlights the importance of the STAT1 pathway in memory-like innate priming and its correlation with training in the context of microbial infection rather than microbial by-products.
Polycomb repressive complexes (PRCs) play a crucial role in transcriptional repression and developmental regulation in both plants and animals. In Arabidopsis, the depletion of different members of PRCs causes both overlapping and unique phenotypic defects. However, the underlying molecular mechanism determining the target specificity and functional diversity of PRCs is not sufficiently characterized. This study aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism of PRCs in Arabidopsis by comparing the changes of tri-methylation at H3K27 in mutants deprived of various key PRC components. The results show that CURLY LEAF (CLF), a major catalytic subunit of PRC2, coordinates with different members of PRC1 in the suppression of distinct plant developmental programs. The expression of flower development genes is repressed in seedlings preferentially via a non-redundant role of CLF, which specifically associates with LIKE HETEROCHROMATIN PROTEIN1 (LHP1). In contrast, the expression of embryo development genes is repressed by PRC1-catalytic core subunits AtBMI1 and AtRING1 in common with PRC2-catalytic enzymes CLF or SWINGER (SWN). The context-dependent role of CLF corresponds well with the change in H3K27me3 profiles and is remarkably associated with differential co-occupancy of binding motifs of transcription factors (TFs), including MADS box and ABA-related factors. The study proposes that different combinations of PRC members distinctively regulate different developmental programs, and their target specificity is modulated by specific TFs.
A high-resolution phenotypic landscape of the RNA polymerase II (Pol II) trigger loop (TL) has been generated by quantitatively phenotyping nearly all TL single variants in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The study reveals three mutant classes with distinct distributions among TL residues, linked to transcription defects or various stresses. Mutations disrupting an intra-TL hydrophobic pocket, proposed to provide a mechanism for substrate-triggered TL folding, confer phenotypes consistent with pocket disruption and increased catalysis. Additionally, allele-specific genetic interactions among TL and TL-proximal domain residues support the contribution of the funnel and bridge helices to TL dynamics.

The phenotypic landscape sheds light on the functional contribution of TL residues to its dynamics, catalysis, and evolutionary constraints. The study expands the current scope of existing deep mutational scanning studies and can be generalized to study most, if not all, of the yeast proteins. The results indicate that both intra-TL interactions and TL interactions with nearby domains are critical for TL function. Coupled with structures of partially folded TL states, these genetic studies support a multi-step TL folding model for the promotion of catalysis. The study identifies many predicted gain-of-function (GOF) and loss-of-function (LOF) TL variants, some of which are predicted to confer epistatic interactions. The findings provide insights into the dynamic conversion between TL states and their critical functions in transcriptional activity.
The study investigated the pathogenesis of rabies virus (RV) in mice after intravenous (i.v.) and intramuscular (i.m.) inoculation with two RV strains: DOG4, associated with dogs, and SB, associated with silver-haired bats. The results showed that while both strains caused lethal encephalopathy after i.m. infection, only SB caused a lethal infection after i.v. inoculation. Immunohistochemical analysis revealed that i.v.-administered SB directly infected the forebrain, with the earliest affected regions being hypothalamic nuclei connected by neurosecretory fibers to the circumventricular organs neurohypophysis and median eminence. The study suggests that hematogenous spread of SB can lead to a fatal encephalopathy through direct retrograde invasion of the central nervous system (CNS) at the neurovascular interface of the hypothalamus-hypophysis system. This alternative mode of virus spread has implications for post-exposure prophylaxis of rabies, particularly with silver-haired bat-associated RV. The study highlights the importance of considering hematogenous spread in the pathogenesis of RV and its potential role in the development of lethal encephalopathy.
The H1N1 subtype of influenza A virus has caused significant morbidity and mortality in humans since its first documented global pandemic in 1918. To understand the evolutionary history of this virus, researchers analyzed 71 complete genome sequences of A/H1N1 viruses sampled between 1918 and 2006. The study found that segmental reassortment has played a crucial role in the genomic evolution of A/H1N1 since 1918. Specifically, an A/H1N1 isolate from the 1947 epidemic acquired novel PB2 and HA genes through intra-subtype reassortment, which may explain the abrupt antigenic evolution of this virus. Similarly, the 1951 influenza epidemic may have been associated with reassortant A/H1N1 viruses. These findings suggest that intra-subtype reassortment is a more important process in the evolution and epidemiology of H1N1 influenza A virus than previously realized. The study also highlights the importance of reassortment in generating viruses with pandemic potential, as seen in the emergence of H2N2 and H3N2 strains in 1957 and 1968. The results of this study provide new insights into the evolutionary history of A/H1N1 and have implications for our understanding of the epidemiology of this virus.
A computational model of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) circuitry and nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) function was used to investigate the principal pathway of nicotine action. The study aimed to determine whether nicotine exerts its reinforcing action through direct stimulation of dopamine (DA) cells or disinhibition mediated through desensitization of nAChRs on GABAergic interneurons. The model illustrated that α4β2-containing nAChRs on either DA or GABA cells can mediate the acute effects of nicotine. The study accounted for both in vitro and in vivo data and predicted the conditions necessary for either direct stimulation or disinhibition to be the origin of DA activity increases. The rate of endogenous acetylcholine input was found to be crucial in determining the evoked DA response for both mechanisms. The results suggest that the VTA mediates the acute rewarding properties of nicotine and propose an acetylcholine dependence hypothesis for nicotine reinforcement. The study identified that low endogenous cholinergic input rates are necessary for direct stimulation, while high cholinergic inputs are required for disinhibition. The findings reconcile in vitro and in vivo data and provide a framework for understanding the mechanisms of nicotine action in the VTA. The study highlights the importance of the GABAergic cells in the action of nicotine and proposes key experiments to disentangle the contribution of both mechanisms.
A randomized controlled phase IIa trial was conducted in Kabul, Afghanistan to evaluate the efficacy of high-frequency electrocauterization (EC) and hydrogel wound care with or without DAC N-055 in treating anthroponotic cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) caused by Leishmania (L.) tropica. The study included 113 patients with CL, who were randomly assigned to two groups: one received EC followed by daily moist-wound-treatment (MWT) with polyacrylate hydrogel containing DAC N-055 (group I), and the other received EC followed by MWT without DAC N-055 (group II). The primary outcome was the time needed for complete lesion epithelialization. Biopsies were taken before EC, after wound closure, and six months later for parasitological and histopathological analysis. The mean duration for complete wound closure was similar in both groups (43.1 days in group I and 42 days in group II). However, in patients with Leishmania-positive biopsies after wound closure, the addition of DAC N-055 resulted in faster wound epithelialization (37.2 days vs. 58.3 days). Superinfections occurred at the same rate in both groups (8.8%), but reulcerations were more common in group II (18.5% vs. 10.2%). In vitro, DAC N-055 showed a leishmanicidal effect on both pro- and amastigotes. The study suggests that EC plus MWT is a more effective treatment for CL than intralesional antimony injections, and the addition of DAC N-055 may further accelerate wound closure and reduce relapse rates.
A genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosophila S2 cells was conducted to identify factors functionally linked to the RAS/MAPK cascade. The screen led to the identification of 101 validated hits, including most of the previously known factors associated with this pathway. Epistasis experiments were performed on individual candidates to determine their position relative to core pathway components, revealing several new factors acting at different steps along the pathway. Unexpectedly, most hits were found to work downstream of MEK and specifically influence MAPK expression. These hits mainly consist of constitutive splicing factors, suggesting that splicing plays a specific role in establishing MAPK levels. Further characterization of two representative members of this group revealed that they act by regulating mapk alternative splicing. The study provides an unprecedented assessment of the factors modulating RAS/MAPK signaling in Drosophila and suggests that pathway output does not solely rely on classical signaling events, but also on the regulation of MAPK levels. Core splicing components were found to specifically impact alternative splicing. The screen also identified five novel components acting upstream of RAF and several new factors acting at the RAS-RAF and RAF-MEK intervals. The results indicate that the regulation of RAS/MAPK signaling is more complex than previously thought and highlights the importance of splicing in modulating pathway output.
Title: Molecular Epidemiology Reveals Genetic Diversity amongst Isolates of the Cryptococcus neoformans/C. gattii Species Complex in Thailand

    A retrospective study of 498 Cryptococcus neoformans and C. gattii isolates from Thailand was conducted to gain a more detailed understanding of cryptococcosis in the country. The majority of the isolates (94.8%) were identified as C. neoformans molecular type VNI, regardless of their source, including clinical (94.6%), environmental (98.8%), and veterinary (86.2%) isolates. Multilocus Sequence Type (MLST) analysis revealed a total of 20 sequence types (ST) in Thailand, with ST30 for C. gattii and ST82, ST83, ST137, ST141, ST172, and ST173 for C. neoformans being unique to Thailand. Most C. gattii isolates were ST7=VGIIb, which is identical to the less virulent minor Vancouver island outbreak genotype, indicating Thailand as a potential stepping stone in the global spread of this outbreak strain. The study found a greater genetic diversity and a wider range of major molecular types among Thai cryptococcal isolates than previously reported. The majority of C. neoformans isolates were from HIV patients (88.5%), while C. gattii was mainly a primary pathogen in immunocompetent patients. The study highlights the importance of further research on the epidemiology and virulence of the Cryptococcus neoformans/C. gattii species complex for proper disease management in Thailand.
The study investigated the role of transcription factor (TF) variation in the evolution of regulatory networks across 12 Drosophila species spanning approximately 45 million years of evolution. The researchers focused on the Cys2-His2 zinc finger (C2H2-ZF) TFs, the largest class of metazoan TFs. They found that a significant fraction of C2H2-ZF 1-to-1 orthologs exhibit variations that can affect their DNA-binding specificities. These variations include loss and recruitment of C2H2-ZF domains, as well as diverging DNA-contacting residues in approximately 44% of domains shared between Drosophila melanogaster and other fly species. The diverging DNA-contacting residues show evidence of functional constraint, tending to be conserved across phylogenetic clades and evolving slower than other diverging residues. These variations were rarely found as polymorphisms within a population of D. melanogaster flies, indicating their rapid fixation. The predicted specificities of these dynamic domains gradually change across phylogenetic distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. The study suggests that a subset of highly dynamic and largely unstudied TFs are a likely source of regulatory variation in Drosophila and other metazoans. The findings challenge the assumption that 1-to-1 orthologous TFs are always highly conserved and provide evidence that binding specificity modifications in single-copy TFs may play an important role in the regulatory evolution of Drosophila and other higher metazoans.
The development of serotype-specific PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assays for Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A, the causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers, is crucial for rapid and accurate diagnosis in clinical and public health laboratories. However, existing PCR protocols often rely on non-optimal validation steps and use multiple markers for each targeted serotype. In this study, a new family of repeated DNA sequences, CRISPR (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats), was used as a serotype-specific target to develop a conventional multiplex PCR assay and EvaGreen-based real-time singleplex PCR assays for the detection and differentiation of serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A from cultured isolates. The assays were validated on a large collection of strains from diverse genetic groups, geographic origins, and time periods, as well as on 70 strains of bacteria frequently encountered in bloodstream infections. The results showed 100% sensitivity and specificity for each protocol. The CRISPR targets were found to be highly stable and specific, making them suitable for the specific detection of all populations of serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A. The developed assays are expected to facilitate the rapid and accurate identification of these two major serotypes in a wide range of clinical and public health laboratories with access to PCR technology. The CRISPR-based PCR assays can be used with DNA from cultured isolates, and with modifications, they can be adapted for use with clinical and other samples.
Mice with T cell-specific gene ablation of Notch1 (N1), Notch2 (N2), or both (N1N2ΔCD4Cre) were infected with the protozoan parasite Leishmania major to investigate the role of Notch signaling in Th1 cell differentiation. Mice lacking both N1 and N2 (N1N2ΔCD4Cre) developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia, with impaired secretion of IFNγ by draining lymph node CD4+ T cells and increased secretion of IL-5 and IL-13 Th2 cytokines. In contrast, mice with single inactivation of N1 or N2 in their T cells were resistant to infection and developed a protective Th1 immune response. This suggests that CD4+ T cell expression of N1 or N2 is redundant in driving Th1 differentiation. Notch signaling was found to be required for the secretion of IFNγ by Th1 cells, and this effect was independent of CSL/RBP-Jκ, the major effector of Notch receptors. Mice with a RBP-Jκ deletion in their T cells were able to develop IFNγ-secreting Th1 cells, kill parasites, and heal their lesions. The study demonstrates a crucial role for RBP-Jκ-independent Notch signaling in the differentiation of a functional Th1 immune response following L. major infection. The findings have implications for the development of new vaccines and immunotherapeutic targets towards Leishmania pathology and other infections requiring a protective IFNγ-secreting CD4+ Th1 immune response.
This study investigated whether pre-existing infection with the parasitic worm Schistosoma mansoni increases susceptibility to systemic infection with the simian-human immunodeficiency virus (SHIV-C) in rhesus macaques. Two groups of animals, one consisting of normal monkeys and the other harboring S. mansoni, were challenged intrarectally with decreasing doses of R5-tropic SHIV-C. The results showed that systemic infection occurred in parasitized monkeys at viral doses that remained sub-infectious in normal hosts. Specifically, the 50% animal infectious (AID50) SHIV-C dose was 17-fold lower in parasitized animals compared to controls. Coinfected animals also had significantly higher peak viral RNA loads and increased viral replication in CD4+ central memory cells. These findings provide the first direct evidence that acute schistosomiasis significantly increases the risk of de novo AIDS virus acquisition. The study suggests that control of helminth infections may be a useful public health intervention to help decrease the spread of HIV-1. The results have significant implications for areas of the world where both parasitic worms and HIV-1 are endemic, such as sub-Saharan Africa, where more than 62% of the world's HIV/AIDS cases occur. The study's findings support the suggestion that better control of helminth infections may favorably impact efforts to reduce the spread of HIV/AIDS.
The article presents a biophysical model of cholinergic modulation in the cortex, focusing on the role of acetylcholine (ACh) in regulating neural excitability and network dynamics. The model consists of Hodgkin-Huxley type neurons with an M-current regulated by ACh, which reduces spike-frequency adaptation (SFA) and shifts the phase response curve (PRC). The results show that changes in neural excitability and network structure interact to create three distinct functional regimes: localized asynchronous, traveling asynchronous, and traveling synchronous patterns of activity. These regimes are qualitatively consistent with experimental observations of cortical activity during slow-wave sleep (SWS), REM sleep, and waking states. The model demonstrates that the level of ACh determines how sensitive network activity is to synaptic heterogeneity and that ACh-induced changes in SFA level and PRC shape occur over differing values of gKs¯. The findings suggest that ACh plays a crucial role in determining patterns of cortical activity and functional differences arising from these patterns. The model also shows that large-scale spatio-temporal dynamics can be induced by ACh-mediated SFA, and that neural networks composed of highly excitable cells will be more responsive to synaptic heterogeneities. The results provide insights into the role and significance of ACh in determining patterns of cortical activity during different sleep and wake states.
The study investigated the impact of mutations in Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway genes on esophageal carcinogenesis. Esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) develops in an inflammatory microenvironment with reduced microbial diversity. The researchers hypothesized that mutations targeting the TLR pathway could disrupt innate immune signaling and promote tumorigenesis. They analyzed whole-genome sequencing data from 171 EAC patients and found that non-synonymous mutations affected the TLR pathway in 25/171 (14.6%) tumors. TLR mutant cases were associated with more proximal tumors and metastatic disease, indicating possible clinical significance. The study also validated these findings in an external EAC dataset and in other solid tumor types exposed to microbiomes, including uterine endometrioid carcinoma, cutaneous melanoma, colorectal adenocarcinoma, and stomach adenocarcinoma. TLR4 was the most frequently mutated gene, with 11 mutations in 10/171 (5.8%) EAC tumors. The TLR4 mutants E439G, S570I, F703C, and R787H were confirmed to have impaired reactivity to bacterial lipopolysaccharide with marked reductions in signaling by luciferase reporter assays. The study suggests that TLR pathway genes are recurrently mutated in EAC, and TLR4 mutations may play a role in disease pathogenesis in a subset of patients.
The development of the taste system in mice has been investigated using a novel approach combining in silico and in vivo analyses. The study aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of taste cell differentiation in developing taste buds. Taste receptor calcium signaling molecules ( TRCSMs ) were found to colocalize within developing circumvallate papillae ( CVP ), suggesting a common regulatory network for TRCSM transcription. Computational analysis of the upstream regulatory regions of TRCSMs identified Hes1 as a likely common regulatory factor. The role of Hes1 in taste system development was further examined in vivo. Expression profile analyses revealed that decreased expression of nuclear HES1 correlated with the expression of type II taste cell markers. In Hes1−/− mutants, the CVP displayed over 5-fold more TRCSM-immunoreactive cells than in wild-type littermates after stage E18. These findings suggest that Hes1 plays a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing taste buds. The study provides new insights into the molecular regulation of taste system development and highlights the importance of Hes1 in this process. The results support the possibility that Hes1 is a common regulator of taste bud cell differentiation and provide a foundation for further investigation into the mechanisms of taste cell development.
The activation of OsEIL1 on YUC8/REIN7 transcription and auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation in rice early seedling development. In rice, ethylene and auxin interact to regulate root growth and development, but their interaction is distinct from that in Arabidopsis. The study found that OsEIL1 directly activates the expression of YUC8/REIN7, a gene involved in auxin biosynthesis. YUC8/REIN7 catalyzes the conversion of indole-3-pyruvic acid ( IPA ) to indole-3-acetic acid ( IAA ), a key step in auxin biosynthesis. The study used a YUC activity inhibitor to show that ethylene-inhibited primary root elongation is dependent on YUC-based auxin biosynthesis. A rice ethylene-insensitive mutant, rein7-1, was identified, which has a truncated YUC8/REIN7 gene and reduced auxin biosynthesis. Overexpression of YUC8/REIN7 enhanced ethylene sensitivity in the roots. The study also found that ethylene induces YUC8/REIN7 expression and promotes auxin accumulation in roots. Addition of low concentrations of IAA rescued the ethylene response in the rein7-1 mutant, demonstrating that ethylene-inhibited root elongation depends on IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis. These findings reveal a model of interaction between ethylene and auxin in rice seedling primary root elongation and provide new insights into ethylene signaling in rice. The study highlights the importance of YUC8/REIN7 in auxin biosynthesis and ethylene-inhibited root elongation in rice early seedlings.
A nationwide epidemiological study was conducted in Saudi Arabia to investigate the incidence of non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) diseases. The study collected 527 NTM isolates over a 24-month period and analyzed them against clinical and demographic data. The results showed that 75.1% of the isolates were of pulmonary origin, with 44.7% having proven clinical significance. A total of 34 NTM species, including 17 rare species, were identified, with M. simiae (22.6%), M. fortuitum (18.1%), and M. abscessus (17.8%) being the most prevalent. Notably, 27 new cases of clinically relevant M. riyadhense were detected. The study also identified rare clinical events caused by M. wolinskyi, M. holsaticum, M. duvalii, and M. monacence. Diabetes mellitus and a previous history of tuberculosis were found to be independent risk factors associated with NTM diseases. The study highlights the emerging challenge of NTM disease spectrum and pathogen diversity in Saudi Arabia, emphasizing the need for immediate development of diagnostic infrastructures and disease management plans. The findings suggest that the Saudi population is vulnerable to NTM diseases, and a detailed management plan for mycobacterial disease control is necessary. The study also underscores the importance of addressing the emergence of new pathogens, such as M. riyadhense, and difficult-to-treat species like M. simiae.
Chronological lifespan (CLS) in yeast is dependent on the accumulation of storage carbohydrates, which is mediated by the kinases Yak1, Mck1, and Rim15. When yeast cells are starved of glucose or other macronutrients, they exit the mitotic cell cycle and acquire characteristics specific to quiescent cells to ensure longevity. A subset of the yeast deletion library was screened to identify the molecular determinants that orchestrate quiescence entry and lifespan extension. In addition to previously characterized Rim15, Mck1, and Yak1 kinases, the SNF1/AMPK complex, cell wall integrity pathway, and cell cycle regulators were found to be necessary for proper quiescence establishment and CLS extension. The CLS of signaling mutants and single, double, and triple mutants of RIM15, YAK1, and MCK1 correlates well with the amount of storage carbohydrates but poorly with transition-phase cell cycle status. The combined removal of glycogen and trehalose biosynthetic genes severely reduces CLS, while overexpression of GSY2 and TSL1 or supplementation of trehalose to the growth medium ameliorates the severe CLS defects. The kinases Yak1, Rim15, and Mck1 mediate the TOR1-regulated accumulation of storage carbohydrates and CLS extension, and their levels of intracellular reactive oxygen species are cooperatively controlled. The data support the hypothesis that metabolic reprogramming to accumulate energy stores and the activation of anti-oxidant defense systems are coordinated by Yak1, Rim15, and Mck1 kinases to ensure quiescence entry and lifespan extension in yeast.
Influenza A virus (IAV) hemagglutinin (HA) glycosylation has been found to play a crucial role in compensating for fitness defects resulting from escape from anti-HA neutralizing antibodies. Using the primerID method of error-correcting viral population sequencing, researchers revealed that antibody-free propagation following antigenic escape rapidly selected viruses with mutations that modulated receptor binding avidity through the addition of N-linked glycans to the HA globular domain. This finding expands our understanding of the viral mechanisms that maintain fitness during antigenic evolution to include glycan addition. The study highlights the immense power of high-definition virus population sequencing to reveal novel viral adaptive mechanisms. The results suggest that glycosylation can compensate for fitness costs imposed by escape substitutions elsewhere on HA, increasing the viability and emergence potential of antibody-escape variants. Furthermore, the study reveals that glycosylation can also play a role in increasing the fitness of antigenic escape variants by restoring optimal HA receptor interactions, even in the absence of antibody selective pressure. These findings shed light on the unique mutational plasticity of influenza HA and highlight the remarkable potential of highly accurate virus population sequencing and high-definition forward genetics for exploring viral evolution.
The article presents a comprehensive analysis of 13 ventricular myocyte models to identify targets that exhibit favorable rate dependence. Reverse rate dependence is a problematic property of antiarrhythmic drugs that prolong the cardiac action potential (AP), resulting in reduced arrhythmia suppression at fast rates and increased arrhythmia risk at slow rates. To address this issue, the study simulated populations of myocytes with varying properties and analyzed population results statistically to predict the rate-dependent effects of changes in multiple model parameters. An average of 40 parameters were tested in each model, and effects on AP duration were assessed at slow (0.2 Hz) and fast (2 Hz) rates. The analysis identified a variety of forward rate-dependent (FRD) ionic current perturbations and generated specific predictions regarding their mechanisms. For instance, an increase in L-type calcium current is FRD when accompanied by indirect, rate-dependent changes in slow delayed rectifier potassium current. The study also found that inward rectifier potassium current and the sodium-potassium pump are the two targets most likely to produce FRD AP prolongation. A statistical analysis of results from the 13 models demonstrated that models displaying minimal rate-dependent changes in AP shape have little capacity for FRD perturbations, whereas models with large shape changes have considerable FRD potential. This can explain differences between species and between ventricular cell types. The study provides new insights into the determinants of AP duration rate dependence and illustrates a strategy for the design of potentially beneficial antiarrhythmic drugs.
This study presents a novel approach to Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PheWAS) using International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision (ICD-10) codes and biological test results to identify genetic polymorphisms associated with a quantitative trait, thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) activity, in patients treated with thiopurine drugs. The authors developed two aggregation methods for ICD-10 codes, an ICD-10 hierarchy and a mapping to existing ICD-9-CM based PheWAS codes, and analyzed 11 biological test results using discretization algorithms. The study included 442 patient records from a French academic hospital between 2000 and 2013, representing 10,252 ICD-10 codes and 72,711 biological test results. The results from the ICD-9-CM based PheWAS codes and ICD-10 hierarchy codes were concordant, and cross-validation with biological test results validated the ICD phenotypes. The study identified associations between very high TPMT activity and iron-deficiency anemia (p = 0.0004) and diabetes mellitus (p = 0.0015). The authors describe an original method to perform PheWAS on a quantitative trait using both ICD-10 diagnosis codes and biological test results to identify associated phenotypes. This approach allows for the identification of new subgroups of patients who require personalized clinical and therapeutic management in the field of pharmacogenomics. The study highlights the potential of PheWAS to discover new associations between genetic polymorphisms and clinical data in the context of thiopurine treatment.
A systematic review and meta-analysis of 156 animal studies on stem cell transplantation in traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) was conducted to evaluate the efficacy of stem cells in restoring neurological function. The analysis included 45 different stem cell preparations, with only one study using autologous stem cells. The results showed that allogeneic stem cell treatment significantly improved both motor (effect size: 27.2%, 95% CI: 25.0-29.4%) and sensory (effect size: 26.3%, 95% CI: 7.9-44.7%) outcomes in animal models of SCI. However, the efficacy of stem cell implantation was influenced by various factors, including the route of delivery, differentiation before implantation, and the presence of immunosuppression. The analysis also found that the location of injury, method of injury induction, and presence of immunosuppression had an impact on motor outcomes. Furthermore, studies that did not report blinded assessment of outcome gave inflated estimates of efficacy. The results suggest that stem-cell-based therapies may offer promise in treating SCI, but the impact of compromised internal validity and publication bias may lead to an overestimation of efficacy. The study highlights the need for rigorous reporting of measures to reduce bias and the importance of considering the conditions under which animal experiments demonstrate greatest efficacy.
Soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections, caused by Ascaris lumbricoides, hookworm, and Trichuris trichiura, affect over a billion people worldwide. Preventive chemotherapy, which involves repeated administration of anthelmintic drugs to at-risk populations, is the primary control strategy. However, this approach does not prevent reinfection. A systematic review and meta-analysis were conducted to assess the patterns and dynamics of STH reinfection after drug treatment. The analysis included 51 studies that reported STH infection rates pre- and post-treatment. The results showed that at 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment, the prevalence of A. lumbricoides reinfection reached 26%, 68%, and 94% of pretreatment levels, respectively. For T. trichiura, the respective reinfection prevalence were 36%, 67%, and 82%, and for hookworm, 30%, 55%, and 57%. The prevalence and intensity of reinfection were positively correlated with pretreatment infection status. The study found that STH reinfections occur rapidly after treatment, particularly for A. lumbricoides and T. trichiura. The findings suggest that frequent anthelmintic drug administrations are necessary to maximize the benefit of preventive chemotherapy. Integrated control approaches emphasizing health education and environmental sanitation are needed to interrupt transmission of STH.
Title: Investigating the deregulation of metabolic tasks via Minimum Network Enrichment Analysis (MiNEA) as applied to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease using mouse and human omics data

    Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) encompasses a spectrum of metabolic syndromes, from simple steatosis to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. To identify the molecular-level deregulation underlying these phenotypes, researchers have employed pathway enrichment analysis (PEA). However, PEA relies on predefined pathway maps, which are subject to biases associated with different pathway annotations and cannot capture the complex interactions of genome-scale metabolic networks (GEMs).

    To address these limitations, a new framework called Minimum Network Enrichment Analysis (MiNEA) has been developed. MiNEA generates all possible alternative minimal networks (MiNs) composed of reactions pertaining to various metabolic subsystems that can synthesize a target metabolite. By applying MiNEA to GEMs, researchers can identify deregulated MiNs and key regulators in different NAFLD phenotypes, such as fatty liver and liver inflammation, in both humans and mice.

    Using condition-specific transcriptomics data from liver samples, MiNEA identified key deregulations in the synthesis of cholesteryl esters, cholesterol, and hexadecanoate in both humans and mice. The analysis also revealed that key regulators of the hydrogen peroxide synthesis network were regulated differently in humans and mice. Furthermore, MiNEA demonstrated the general and specific characteristics of the different NAFLD phenotypes. The MiNEA framework is applicable to any GEM and target metabolite, making it a flexible tool for studying condition-specific metabolism in various diseases or organisms.
The olfactory system faces the challenge of identifying a vast array of odors independent of their intensity. Primacy coding, where the odor identity is encoded by the receptor types that respond earliest, is proposed as a compact and informative representation that can be efficiently interpreted by the brain. A simple model of primacy coding was analyzed using numerical simulations and statistical descriptions. The results show that the encoded information depends strongly on the number of receptor types included in the primacy representation, but only weakly on the size of the receptor repertoire. The representation is independent of odor intensity and the transmitted information is useful for performing typical olfactory tasks with performance comparable to experimentally measured values. The model also suggests that a smaller receptor repertoire can be advantageous for discriminating odors in certain situations. Furthermore, the model predicts that overly sensitive receptor types can dominate the response and render the entire array useless, indicating the need for receptor arrays to adapt to environmental changes. Primacy coding is found to be more useful than simple binary and normalized coding due to the sparsity of odor representations being independent of odor statistics. This efficient odor representation is independent of odor intensity and may aid in identifying odors in the olfactory cortex. The results suggest that the primacy code formed in the olfactory bulb is more useful for identifying odors in the subsequent olfactory cortex than simple alternatives. The model predicts that receptors are only useful if their likelihood to respond to incoming odors is similar.
The study investigated the neutralization profiles of broadly neutralizing HIV monoclonal antibodies (bnMAbs) targeting different regions of the HIV envelope (Env) spike. Using a panel of 278 pseudoviruses in a CD4 T-cell assay and 117 viruses in the TZM-bl assay, the researchers found that bnMAbs targeting the V2 apex of Env and gp41 were more likely to display non-sigmoidal neutralization curves that plateaued at less than 100% neutralization. In contrast, bnMAbs targeting the high-mannose patch epitopes were less likely to show this behavior. The study also found that two CD4 binding site (CD4bs) antibodies showed this behavior relatively infrequently. The phenomenon of incomplete neutralization was observed in a large peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC)-grown molecular virus clone panel derived from patient viral swarms. Additionally, five bnMAbs were compared against an 18-virus panel of molecular clones produced in 293T cells and PBMCs and assayed in TZM-bl cells, with examples of plateaus less than 90% seen with both types of virus production. The results suggest that incomplete neutralization and non-sigmoidal neutralization curves are possible for all HIV bnMAbs against a wide range of viruses produced and assayed in both cell lines and primary cells. This has implications for the use of antibodies in therapy and as tools for vaccine design. The study highlights the importance of understanding the mechanisms underlying incomplete neutralization and non-sigmoidal neutralization curves, which may be influenced by factors such as glycan heterogeneity and conformational heterogeneity of the Env trimer.
The article presents a computational model of human central metabolism to elucidate how cancer cells utilize glucose and glutamine to promote growth. The model reveals that at high glutamine utilization rates, oxidative glucose utilization is decreased, while lactate production from glutamine is enhanced. This metabolic pattern is optimal for maximizing biomass and ATP production, requiring a branched tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and redox-controlled metabolic reactions. The model predicts that glutamine-dependent reductive carboxylation cooperates with the production of lipids and proteins. Experimental validation in a K-ras transformed cell line confirms the computational results, demonstrating glutamine-induced metabolic changes. The findings suggest that the competition between glucose and glutamine utilization may play a crucial role in cancer cell growth. The model identifies boundary conditions that promote the emergence of cancer metabolic rewiring, characterized by enhanced aerobic glycolysis (Warburg effect) and glutamine utilization for biosynthesis. Systematic evaluation of metabolic network wirings under different nutritional conditions reveals that this metabolic pattern is optimal for biomass and ATP production. The results provide new insights into the logic of metabolic reprogramming underlying cancer cell growth and suggest that this metabolic rewiring may occur in various tumor cell lines.
Interactome Analyses Identify Ties of PrPC and Its Mammalian Paralogs to Oligomannosidic N-Glycans and Endoplasmic Reticulum-Derived Chaperones
    A quantitative investigation of the cellular prion protein ( PrPC ) interactome was conducted in a cell culture model permissive to prion replication. The study also extended to Doppel ( Prnd ) and Shadoo ( Sprn ), two mammalian PrPC paralogs, to facilitate recognition of relevant interactors. The results established a similar physiological environment for the three prion protein family members in neuroblastoma cells and suggested direct interactions amongst them. Multiple interactions between PrPC and the neural cell adhesion molecule, the laminin receptor precursor, Na/K ATPases, and protein disulfide isomerases ( PDI ) were confirmed, reconciling previously separate findings. Validation experiments established that interactions of PrPC with PDIs may extend beyond the endoplasmic reticulum and play a hitherto unrecognized role in the accumulation of PrPSc. A hypothesis was presented suggesting that PrPC organizes its molecular environment by binding to adhesion molecules harboring immunoglobulin-like domains, which recognize oligomannose-bearing membrane proteins. Bioinformatic methods and literature mining were used to explore the known cellular localization of candidate interactors. The majority of these proteins co-purified with all three bait proteins, indicating a highly similar molecular environment for the three members of the mammalian prion protein family in mouse neuroblastoma cells. The study suggests that members of the prion protein family may be embedded in specialized membrane domains characterized by an extended molecular network supporting functions in adhesion control, lactate metabolism, and cell fusion events. Biochemical interactions among the members of the mammalian prion protein family exist.
During influenza virus infection, a robust type 1 pro-inflammatory cytokine immune response is typically induced in the respiratory tract. However, the production of type 2 cytokines, including interleukin ( IL ) -5, has also been observed. IL-5 is a prototypical type 2 cytokine that plays a crucial role in eosinophil maturation and egress from the bone marrow. In a mouse model of influenza virus infection, IL-5 was found to be transiently released into the infected airways along with a significant accumulation of eosinophils in the lungs, particularly during the recovery phase following virus clearance. The cellular source of IL-5 was identified as group 2 innate lymphoid cells ( ILC2 ) that infiltrate the infected lungs. The production of IL-5 by ILC2 was found to be regulated by NKT cells and alveolar macrophages, which produce IL-33, a cytokine that enhances IL-5 production by ILC2. The interaction between ILC2 and IL-33 producing NKT cells and alveolar macrophages leads to the abundant production of IL-5 by ILC2, resulting in the accumulation of eosinophils in the lungs during the recovery phase of influenza infection. This study provides new insights into the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of IL-5 production during respiratory virus infection.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (iNTS) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of iNTS disease in Asia are not well-documented. This study retrospectively analyzed 102 cases of iNTS infections in an infectious disease hospital in Southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. The majority of patients (71%) were HIV-infected adults, with 71% being male and 33% reporting intravenous drug use. The most commonly identified serovars were Salmonella Enteritidis (ST11) and Salmonella Typhimurium (ST19, 34, and 1544), which accounted for 43% and 30% of all cases, respectively. Salmonella Typhimurium was significantly more common in HIV-infected individuals (p = 0.003). Isolates from HIV-infected patients were more likely to exhibit reduced susceptibility to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole than HIV-negative patients (p = 0.037). The mortality rate was 28%, with HIV infection being a significant risk factor for death (p = 0.039). The study highlights that iNTS disease is a severe infection in Vietnam, with a high mortality rate, and that HIV infection is a major risk factor for both infection and death. The findings suggest that continued surveillance is necessary to monitor for the emergence or introduction of multidrug-resistant strains or strains with enhanced virulence.
Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) have been trained to detect viral and phage structural proteins with high accuracy. The ANNs were designed to classify phage protein sequences based on amino acid frequencies and protein isoelectric points. The networks were trained on a dataset of phage and viral-encoded genes and were able to correctly classify a large fraction of test cases with high specificity and sensitivity. The ANNs were also able to identify specialized families of proteins, such as major capsid and tail proteins, with high accuracy. To experimentally validate the ANN predictions, several ORFs with no significant similarities to known sequences that were predicted to be structural proteins were examined by transmission electron microscopy, and some self-assembled into structures resembling virion structures. The ANNs are valuable tools for identifying phage and potential prophage structural proteins that are difficult or impossible to detect by other bioinformatic analysis. The networks will be particularly useful when sequence data is available but in vitro propagation of the phage may not be practical or possible. The ANNs have the potential to aid in the detection and diagnosis of disease, vaccine development, and understanding the physiological impact of viruses on microbial communities and human health.
The interferon-stimulated gene product oligoadenylate synthetase-like protein (OASL) has been identified as an interacting partner of Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) ORF20 protein. ORF20 is a member of the herpesviral core UL24 family, and its function and role in the viral life cycle were not well understood. Quantitative affinity purification coupled to mass spectrometry (q-AP-MS) revealed that OASL interacts with ORF20, and this interaction is conserved among all ORF20 isoforms and multiple ORF20 homologs of the UL24 family in other herpesviruses. Characterization of OASL interacting partners by q-AP-MS identified a similar interactome to that of ORF20, including ribosomal proteins. Both ORF20 and OASL copurified with 40S and 60S ribosomal subunits, and when co-expressed, they associated with polysomes. ORF20 enhanced RIG-I-induced expression of endogenous OASL in an IRF3-dependent but IFNAR-independent manner. Notably, OASL has been characterized as an interferon-stimulated gene with antiviral activity against some viruses, but its role in gammaherpesvirus infections was unknown. The study found that OASL enhanced infection of KSHV, and during infection with a KSHV ORF20stop mutant, OASL-dependent enhancement of infectivity was lost. These data suggest that ORF20 usurps the function of OASL to benefit KSHV infection.
A prospective study was conducted to determine the prevalence and presentation of Lassa virus disease (LVD) in febrile children with and without convulsions in an endemic area of Nigeria. The study included 913 consecutive febrile children aged 1 month to 15 years admitted to the Children’s Emergency Room of Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital over a 1-year period. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13/373 (3.5%; 95% CI = 1.9%, 5.7%) in febrile admissions, with 3/108 (2.8%) in children with convulsions and 10/265 (3.8%) in those without convulsions. The odds ratio of LVD in children with convulsions versus those without was 0.73 (95% CI = 0.2, 2.7), indicating no significant association between LVD and convulsions. However, vomiting (OR = 0.09; 95% CI = 0.01, 0.70) and bleeding (OR = 39.56; 95% CI = 8.52, 183.7) were significantly associated with an increased prevalence of LVD. The study highlights the importance of LVD as a cause of fever, including undifferentiated fever, in children in endemic areas, and underscores the need for a high index of suspicion in diagnosis. The findings suggest that screening febrile children with undifferentiated fever in endemic areas for LVD could be an important medical and public health control measure.
The study investigated the role of the karrikin receptor KAI2 in regulating drought resistance in Arabidopsis thaliana. Mutations in KAI2 resulted in hypersensitivity to water deprivation, characterized by increased rates of water loss, drought-induced cell membrane damage, enlarged stomatal apertures, and higher cuticular permeability. Transcriptomic, physiological, and biochemical analyses revealed that kai2 mutants have reduced anthocyanin biosynthesis during drought and are hyposensitive to abscisic acid ( ABA ) in stomatal closure and cotyledon opening assays. Genome-wide transcriptome analysis identified genes associated with the observed physiological and biochemical changes in kai2 plants under both well-watered and dehydration conditions. The data suggest crosstalk between ABA- and KAI2-dependent signaling pathways in regulating plant responses to drought. A comparison with the strigolactone receptor mutant d14 ( DWARF14 ) indicated that strigolactones also contribute to plant drought adaptation, although not by affecting cuticle development. The findings suggest that chemical or genetic manipulation of KAI2 and D14 signaling may provide novel ways to improve drought resistance. The study provides evidence for a KAR/KL-KAI2-SCFMAX2 signaling cascade in regulating plant drought adaptation through controlling cell membrane stability, stomatal movement, cuticle development, and anthocyanin production. KAI2-mediated signaling positively regulates drought resistance in Arabidopsis by activating downstream genes involved in cuticle formation, stomatal closure, anthocyanin biosynthesis, and membrane integrity.
The study investigated the role of insulin receptors (SjIRs) in the growth, development, sexual maturation, and egg production of adult Schistosoma japonicum, a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis japonica. The researchers cloned and partially characterized the SjIRs and demonstrated that human insulin can bind to the L1 subdomain of the recombinant SjIR1 and SjIR2 proteins. Using RNA interference (RNAi), they knocked down the expression of SjIRs in adult S. japonicum in vitro and observed a significant decrease in glucose uptake, reduced transcription of downstream genes associated with glucose metabolism and schistosome fecundity, and a decrease in fecal egg production. In vaccine/challenge experiments, recombinant SjLD1 and SjLD2 depressed female growth, intestinal granuloma density, and fecal egg production in S. japonicum-infected mice. These findings suggest that the insulin pathway plays a crucial role in the growth and development of S. japonicum and that targeting the SjIRs may be an effective strategy for developing a vaccine against schistosomiasis japonica. The study provides further evidence for the potential of the SjIRs as veterinary transmission-blocking vaccine candidates against zoonotic schistosomiasis in China and the Philippines. The results also support the idea that schistosomes exploit host insulin for growth and development, highlighting the importance of the insulin signaling pathway in these parasites.
Title: Interspecific Hybridization Yields Strategy for South Pacific Filariasis Vector Elimination

    Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a significant cause of disability in the South Pacific, where over 96% of the 1.7 million population is at risk of infection. Current mass drug administration (MDA) efforts have reduced LF prevalence, but mosquito vector biology complicates the MDA strategy. In some regions, MDA alone may not be sufficient to attain LF elimination. The primary vector, Aedes polynesiensis, is difficult to control using existing methods. This study demonstrates that interspecific hybridization and introgression result in an A. polynesiensis strain (‘CP’ strain) that is stably infected with the endosymbiotic Wolbachia bacteria from Aedes riversi. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays show that CP males are equally competitive, leading to population elimination when introduced into wild-type A. polynesiensis populations. This finding supports the feasibility of a vector elimination strategy as a supplement to ongoing MDA efforts. The strategy involves inundative releases of bi-directionally incompatible males to induce sterility in A. polynesiensis females, resulting in vector population elimination. The South Pacific geography is ideal for this approach, as mosquitoes are an obligate host for W. bancrofti, and anti-vector interventions are recognized as a supplemental method to break the LF transmission cycle.
The study aimed to estimate the public health burden of rhodesiense Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) in Urambo District, Tanzania, in terms of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) and financial costs. Data from 143 patients admitted to Kaliua Health Centre in 2004 for HAT treatment were analyzed. The direct medical and indirect costs incurred by patients and the health services were calculated, and DALYs were estimated using methods recommended by the Global Burden of Disease Project. The study found that the DALY estimate for HAT in Urambo District was 215.7 (95% CI: 155.3-287.5) without age-weighting and 281.6 (95% CI: 209.1-362.6) with age-weighting. When 45% under-reporting was included, the results were 622.5 (95% CI: 155.3-1098.9) and 978.9 (95% CI: 201.1-1870.8), respectively. The costs of treating 143 patients were estimated at US$ 15,514, with patients paying US$ 3,673 and the health services US$ 11,841. The indirect non-medical costs for the 143 patients were estimated at US$ 9,781. The study highlights the significant burden of HAT on affected rural communities in Tanzania and emphasizes the need for location- and disease-specific burden estimates to address the focal nature of the disease in certain areas.
The Ngly1 gene encodes a cytoplasmic peptide:N-glycanase that is highly conserved among eukaryotes and plays a critical role in mammals. Mice with a knockout of the Ngly1 gene exhibit severe systemic symptoms and are embryonic lethal in a C57BL/6 background. However, the lethality of Ngly1-deficient mice is partially rescued by the additional deletion of the Engase gene, which encodes another de-N-glycosylating enzyme that leaves a single GlcNAc at glycosylated Asn residues. Furthermore, a change in the genetic background of C57BL/6 mice by crossing with an outbred mouse strain ( ICR ) also partially rescues the embryonic lethality of Ngly1-deficient mice. Viable Ngly1-deficient mice in a C57BL/6 and ICR mixed background exhibit a severe phenotype reminiscent of the symptoms of NGLY1-deficiency in human subjects, which is strongly suppressed by the additional deletion of Engase. The defects observed in Ngly1/Engase-deficient mice and Ngly1-deficient mice in a C57BL/6 and ICR mixed background closely resemble some of the symptoms of patients with an NGLY1-deficiency. These findings suggest that Ngly1- or Ngly1/Engase-deficient mice could serve as a valuable animal model for studying the pathogenesis of NGLY1-deficiency and that cytoplasmic ENGase may be a potential therapeutic target for this genetic disorder.
The study investigated the role of gene expression noise in spatial patterning during Drosophila segmentation, focusing on the hunchback (hb) gene, which is activated by the Bicoid (Bcd) protein gradient. The researchers used a stochastic model of the hb promoter to examine how promoter structure and transcriptional dynamics affect noise amplitude and distribution. The model was fit to data from wild-type (WT) embryos, a self-regulation mutant (hb14F), and lacZ reporter constructs with different portions of the hb promoter. The results showed that WT hb output noise is primarily dependent on the transcription and translation dynamics of its own expression, rather than on Bcd fluctuations. The study also found that the multiple Bcd binding sites in the hb promoter and their strengths play a role in buffering noise, particularly in the absence of self-regulation. The model was robust to variations in Bcd binding site number across different fly species. The findings suggest that promoter structure and regulatory dynamics, such as self-feedback, multiple regulatory sites, and cooperativity, contribute to the reproducibility and determinacy of spatial patterning in early development. The study provides insights into how noise is controlled in spatial gene expression patterns, which is a fundamental problem in developmental biology. The model can be used to investigate noise generation in the hb expression dynamics, including the relative contributions of binding site number and strength, binding cooperativity, self-regulation, and protein diffusion.
This study investigates the strength of selection against Neanderthal introgression in modern human populations. The authors develop a novel method to estimate the genome-wide average strength of selection and the density of selected sites using estimates of Neanderthal allele frequency in modern humans. The results confirm that East Asians had higher initial levels of Neanderthal ancestry than Europeans, even after accounting for selection. The study finds that the majority of purifying selection against Neanderthal ancestry acts on many weakly deleterious alleles. These alleles were effectively neutral in Neanderthals but became selected against after entering human populations of larger effective size. This suggests that differences in effective population size may play a more significant role in shaping levels of introgression than previously thought. The study proposes that the accumulation of weakly deleterious alleles in Neanderthals, which were purged after introgressing into the human population, contributed to the observed patterns of Neanderthal ancestry in modern humans. The results have implications for understanding how populations remain distinct after secondary contact and suggest that nearly neutral dynamics and differences in effective population size are important determinants of levels of introgression across species and along the genome. The study enhances our understanding of how selection shaped the genomic contribution of Neanderthal to our genomes and sheds light on the nature of Neanderthal–human hybridization.
The HIV-1 promoter within the viral long terminal repeat ( LTR ) plays a crucial role in regulating viral gene expression and replication. Stochastic fluctuations in viral gene expression, amplified by the Tat positive feedback loop, can contribute to the formation of either a productive, transactivated state or an inactive state. In a significant fraction of cells harboring an integrated copy of the HIV-1 model provirus, this bimodal gene expression profile is dynamic, with cells spontaneously switching between active ( Bright ) and inactive ( Off ) expression modes. The HIV-1 promoter contains cis-acting Sp1 and NF-κB elements that regulate gene expression via the recruitment of both activating and repressing complexes. Using model lentivirus variants with mutations introduced in the Sp1 and NF-κB elements, researchers employed flow cytometry, mRNA quantification, pharmacological perturbations, and chromatin immunoprecipitation to reveal significant functional differences in contributions of each site to viral gene regulation. The Sp1 sites were found to stabilize both the Bright and the Off states, promoting noisy gene expression and reduction in the regulation of histone acetylation and deacetylation. In contrast, the NF-κB sites exhibit distinct properties, with κB site I serving a stronger activating role than κB site II. Mutations in any of the Sp1 sites yielded a 6-fold higher frequency of clonal bifurcation compared to that of the wild-type promoter. These results suggest that each Sp1 and NF-κB site differentially contributes to the regulation of viral gene expression, and Sp1 sites functionally “dampen” transcriptional noise and modulate the frequency and maintenance of this model of viral latency.
Title: Phylogenetic and Functional Assessment of Orthologs Inference Projects and Methods
    Summary: A comparative study was conducted to evaluate the accuracy of nine leading orthology projects and methods, including COG, KOG, Inparanoid, OrthoMCL, Ensembl Compara, Homologene, RoundUp, EggNOG, and OMA, as well as two standard methods, bidirectional best-hit and reciprocal smallest distance. The study involved mapping millions of sequences, handling hundreds of millions of predicted pairs of orthologs, and computing tens of thousands of trees. The results showed that OMA and Homologene performed best in phylogenetic analysis and functional analysis with high specificity. At lower functional specificity but higher coverage, OrthoMCL outperformed Ensembl Compara, and to a lesser extent, Inparanoid. EggNOG provided the largest coverage for coarse-grained functional categories but was not specific enough for phylogenetic or detailed function analyses. The study also found that Ensembl Compara's sophisticated tree reconstruction/reconciliation approach was sometimes outperformed by pairwise comparison approaches, and bidirectional best-hit often outperformed projects with more complex algorithms. The study provides guidance for orthology data users, introduces new methodology for verifying orthology, and sets performance standards for current and future approaches.
The development of novel therapeutics for schistosomiasis is urgently needed due to the emergence of resistance to the current treatment, praziquantel. To address this challenge, a computational drug repurposing pipeline was developed, supported by phenotypic screening. This approach identified several protein kinases as potential new biological targets for schistosomiasis, as they play a crucial role in the parasite's biological processes. The kinomes of Schistosoma japonicum, Schistosoma mansoni, and Schistosoma haematobium were elucidated, and compared to the human kinome, to identify potential targets of existing inhibitors unique to Schistosoma species. This led to the identification of novel targets and suggested approved drugs that might inhibit them, including bosutinib, dasatinib, and imatinib, as well as new inhibitors such as vandetanib, saracatinib, tideglusib, alvocidib, and dinaciclib. Additionally, 22 newly identified targets were suggested, including CHK1, CDC2, WEE, PAKA, and MEK1. The primary and secondary targets in Schistosoma of these approved drugs were also suggested, enabling the development of novel therapeutics against schistosomiasis. This study demonstrates the potential of computational drug repurposing and phenotypic screening in identifying new targets and inhibitors for schistosomiasis, a neglected tropical disease.
The study investigated the folding and binding mechanism of the pKID domain of the transcription factor CREB to the KIX domain of the co-activator CBP. Simulations of a topology-based Gō-type model predicted a coupled folding and binding mechanism, with the existence of partially bound intermediates. Transition-path and Φ-value analyses revealed that the binding transition state resembles the unstructured state in solution, indicating that CREB becomes structured only after committing to binding. This is in contrast to models where binding occurs to pre-structured conformations that exist in the unbound state at equilibrium. The study found that increasing the amount of structure in the unbound pKID reduces the rate of binding, suggesting a “fly-casting”-like process. The inclusion of attractive non-native interactions resulted in the formation of non-specific encounter complexes that enhance the on-rate of binding, but do not significantly change the binding mechanism. The simulations are in agreement with a recently reported nuclear magnetic resonance study and aid in the interpretation of the experimental binding kinetics. The results suggest that being unstructured can confer an advantage in protein target recognition. The study provides new insights into the folding and binding mechanism of the pKID/KIX complex and has implications for understanding the regulation of gene expression.
A systematic review was conducted to analyze the prevalence and intensity of Schistosoma mansoni infection in children in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) countries and territories between 1942 and 2014. The review included 132 articles with 1,242 prevalence and 199 intensity of infection data points. The majority of the data came from Brazil (69.7%), which showed several 'hot spots' with high prevalence. The results indicate that Brazil, Venezuela, Suriname, and Saint Lucia need to update their national programs to target the elimination of Schistosoma mansoni transmission by 2020. In contrast, Antigua and Barbuda, Dominican Republic, Guadeloupe, Martinique, Montserrat, and Puerto Rico may have interrupted transmission, but follow-up surveys are needed to verify this status. The review highlights the need for improved reporting and standardization of monitoring and evaluation methodologies used in schistosomiasis programs. Meeting the regional elimination goal will require additional and improved epidemiological data by age group and sex. The review also emphasizes the importance of assessing both prevalence and intensity of infection, as recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO), to control morbidity and eliminate schistosomiasis as a public health problem.
Heterosexual transmission of HIV-1 subtype C is characterized by a genetic bottleneck that selects a single viral variant, the transmitted/founder (TF), during most transmission events. To investigate viral characteristics influencing HIV-1 transmission, researchers sequenced 167 near full-length viral genomes and generated 40 infectious molecular clones (IMC) from six linked heterosexual transmission pairs near the time of transmission. The results showed that consensus-like genomes sensitive to donor antibodies were selected for during transmission in these six transmission pairs. However, TF variants did not demonstrate increased viral fitness in terms of particle infectivity or viral replicative capacity in activated peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and monocyte-derived dendritic cells (MDDC). Additionally, resistance of the TF variant to the antiviral effects of interferon-α (IFN-α) was not significantly different from that of non-transmitted variants from the same transmission pair. These findings suggest that neither in vitro viral replicative capacity nor IFN-α resistance discriminated the transmission potential of viruses in the quasispecies of these chronically infected individuals. The study supports the hypothesis that within-host evolution of HIV-1 in response to adaptive immune responses reduces viral transmission potential. The results also indicate that factors other than IFN-α resistance are the dominant determinants of transmission fitness in these pairs.
Filarial parasites have been shown to induce lymphangiogenesis and lymphatic remodeling in the absence of an adaptive immune system in murine models. However, severe irreversible lymphedema and elephantiasis appear to require an intact adaptive immune response in human infections. To investigate how filarial parasites directly influence the lymphatics, human lymphatic endothelial cells (LEC) were exposed to filarial antigens, live parasites, or infected patient serum. The results showed that live filarial parasites or filarial antigens induced significant LEC proliferation and differentiation into tube-like structures in vitro. Furthermore, serum from patients with patent filarial infections and those with longstanding chronic lymphatic obstruction induced increased LEC proliferation compared to sera from uninfected individuals. The differentiation of LEC into tube-like networks was associated with increased levels of matrix metalloproteases and inhibition of their tissue inhibitors. Gene expression analysis revealed that filarial parasites altered the expression of genes involved in cellular organization and development, as well as those associated with junction adherence pathways, leading to decreased trans-endothelial transport. These findings suggest that filarial parasites directly induce lymphangiogenesis and lymphatic differentiation, providing insight into the mechanisms underlying the pathology seen in lymphatic filariasis. The study demonstrates that filarial proteins stimulate LEC to undergo proliferation and differentiation into tube-like structures, involving matrix metalloproteases and tissue inhibitors of matrix metalloproteases.
The Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA) method enables the amplification of genomic DNA from single cells, eliminating the need for laboratory culture. To improve the efficiency and specificity of MDA, researchers used a microfluidic device to isolate individual Escherichia coli cells and amplify their genomic DNA in 60-nanoliter reactions. The results showed that reducing the reaction volume from microliters to nanoliters significantly lowered nonspecific synthesis caused by contaminant DNA templates and primer interactions. The quality of genome amplification was assessed using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) and found to be comparable to standard 50-microliter volumes. Furthermore, amplification bias was greatly reduced in nanoliter volumes, providing a more even representation of all sequences. High-throughput pyrosequencing of single-cell amplicons from both microliter and nanoliter volumes produced high-quality sequence data, demonstrating a straightforward route to sequencing genomes from single cells. This approach has significant implications for the study of microbial ecology and evolution, as it allows for the recovery of whole genome sequences from single cells that cannot be obtained in pure culture. The combination of MDA and emulsion PCR sample preparation may also improve specificity, making it a powerful approach for single-cell sequencing applications. Overall, the use of nanoliter reactors improved the efficiency and specificity of MDA, enabling the generation of high-quality sequence data from single cells.
This study investigated the relationship between hantavirus host assemblages and human disease in the Atlantic Forest of South America. The researchers analyzed 283 rodent capture records and used geographically weighted models to examine the influence of landscape structure on hantavirus host proportions. The results showed that hantavirus host proportions were more positively influenced by landscape diversity than by a particular habitat or agricultural matrix type. Local small mammal diversity was also found to positively influence known pathogenic hantavirus host proportions, suggesting that a plasticity to habitat quality may be more important for these hosts than competition with native forest-dwelling species. In contrast, defaunation intensity did not correlate with the proportion of hosts of potentially pathogenic hantavirus genotypes in the community, indicating that non-defaunated areas can also be hotspots for hantavirus disease outbreaks. The spatial match between host hotspots and human disease vulnerability was found to be 17%, while coldspots matched 20%. The study suggests that disease surveillance must be reinforced in the southern and southeastern regions of the biome where the highest predicted hantavirus host proportion and levels of vulnerability spatially match. The findings also indicate that there may be more complex rodent community dynamics and interactions with human disease than currently hypothesized. Overall, the study highlights the importance of considering landscape diversity and local small mammal diversity in understanding hantavirus host assemblages and human disease in the Atlantic Forest.
Infection with flaviviruses, such as Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), Dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV), requires the pro-survival BCL2 protein BCLXL for cell survival. BCLXL suppresses the expression of the pro-survival protein MCL1, thereby delaying apoptosis in infected cells. This delay is crucial for viral dissemination to neighboring cells, leading to high pathogenicity. Inhibition of BCLXL, either through treatment with BCLXL inhibitors or deficiency of the BCLXL gene, induces BAX/BAK-dependent apoptosis in infected cells. Furthermore, impairment of BCLXL accelerates apoptosis in cells infected with flaviviruses, reducing viral dissemination and chemokine production. In vivo, haploinsufficiency of the BCLXL gene or administration of BH3 mimetic compounds increased survival rates after challenge with JEV infection and suppressed inflammation. The results suggest that BCLXL plays a critical role in the survival of cells infected with flaviviruses and may provide a novel antiviral target to suppress the propagation of Flaviviridae viruses. The study proposes a model in which flavivirus infection reduces MCL1 expression, while BCLXL delays apoptosis, allowing for viral dissemination and high pathogenicity. Inhibition of BCLXL, on the other hand, induces apoptosis and reduces viral dissemination, leading to low pathogenicity in vivo.
This study estimated the economic impact of canine rabies in Viet Nam from 2005 to 2014. The analysis included direct and indirect costs of rabies in dogs, livestock, and humans, as well as post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), dog vaccination efforts, and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). The study found that the total economic impact of canine rabies in Viet Nam over the 10-year period was over $719 million USD, with PEP-related costs accounting for 92% of the total burden. Canine rabies resulted in between 36,560 and 45,700 DALYs, measured in years of life lost (YLL), and a total of 914 human deaths were reported over the study period. The cost per dog vaccinated was $1.75 USD. The results indicate that canine rabies impacts in Viet Nam are consistent with those reported in other Asian countries, with large expenditures on PEP and minimal investments in dog vaccination. The study suggests that coordinated veterinary public health campaigns that prevent human rabies through dog vaccination are more cost-effective than suppressing disease through PEP administration. The findings highlight the need for increased investment in dog vaccination efforts to reduce the economic burden of canine rabies in Viet Nam.
The Type II Secretion System (T2SS) is a molecular machine responsible for the secretion of fully-folded protein substrates across the bacterial outer membrane. A key component of the T2SS is the secretin, a multimeric outer membrane protein that forms the secretion pore. Research has identified three distinct forms of T2SSs based on the sequence characteristics of their secretin pores. Two of these forms, the Klebsiella-type and Vibrio-type, are distinguished by the pilotin that mediates their transport and assembly into the outer membrane. A novel pilotin, AspS, has been identified in Vibrio cholerae, which is structurally unrelated to the pilotins found in Klebsiella and other bacteria. The crystal structure of AspS reveals that it binds to a specific targeting sequence in the Vibrio-type secretins, enhancing the kinetics of secretin assembly. Homologs of AspS are found in all species of Vibrio, as well as in a few strains of Escherichia and Shigella that have acquired a Vibrio-type T2SS. The presence of AspS is correlated with the presence of Vibrio-type secretins and AcfD/SslE substrates in diverse bacteria, suggesting that some bacteria have acquired a complete functional unit of secretin-pilotin-substrate incorporated with the rest of the T2SS operon. Biochemical analysis demonstrates that AspS binds to an S-domain sequence in the Vibrio-type secretins, with sequence analysis distinguishing the S-domains of the Klebsiella-type and Vibrio-type secretins. The phylogeny of the Vibrio-type secretins is reflected in the phylogenetic relationships for the AspS sequences.
The OmpL37 surface-exposed protein is expressed by pathogenic Leptospira during infection and has been found to bind to human skin and vascular elastin. The study investigated the functional roles of three transmembrane outer membrane proteins, OmpL36, OmpL37, and OmpL47, which were recently identified on the leptospiral surface. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay revealed that OmpL37 exhibits dose-dependent and saturating binding to human skin and aortic elastin, as well as fibrinogen, fibrinogen fragment D, plasma fibronectin, and murine laminin. The binding to human skin elastin by both recombinant OmpL37 and live Leptospira interrogans is specifically enhanced by rabbit antiserum for OmpL37, suggesting the involvement of OmpL37 in leptospiral binding to elastin and the possibility that host-generated antibodies may promote rather than inhibit the adherence of leptospires to elastin-rich tissues. OmpL37 is recognized by acute and convalescent leptospirosis patient sera and Leptospira-infected hamster sera, and the protein is detected in pathogenic Leptospira serovars but not in saprophytic Leptospira. These findings suggest that OmpL37 is a novel elastin-binding protein of pathogenic Leptospira that may be promoting attachment of Leptospira to host tissues. The study hypothesizes that OmpL37 might be involved in the pathogenesis of leptospirosis, facilitating the attachment of leptospires to an inner elastin-rich layer of the skin exposed by abrasion during the initial stage of infection.
The article presents a model to calculate the probability of polyreactive antibodies 4E10 and 2F5 disabling a gp41 trimer after T cell-HIV adhesion. These antibodies, isolated from HIV-1 infected individuals, recognize epitopes in the membrane proximal external region (MPER) of gp41 that are transiently exposed during viral entry. The model predicts that for these antibodies to be effective at neutralization, the time to disable an epitope must be shorter than the time the antibody remains bound in a stably bound complex, approximately five minutes or less for 4E10 and 2F5. The study investigates the role of avidity in neutralization and shows that 2F5 IgG, but not 4E10, is more effective at neutralization than its Fab fragment, attributed to 2F5 interacting more stably with the viral membrane. The model elucidates the parameters that determine the ability of these antibodies to disable epitopes and proposes an extension to analyze neutralization data. The extended model predicts the dependencies of neutralization on the rate constants that characterize antibody binding, the rate of fusion of gp41, and the number of gp41 bridges between the virus and target cell at the start of the pre-hairpin intermediate. Analysis of neutralization experiments indicates that only a small number of gp41 bridges must be disabled to prevent fusion, but the model cannot determine the exact number from neutralization experiments alone.
A longitudinal study was conducted in three hyperendemic onchocerciasis foci in Mali and Senegal to assess the feasibility of onchocerciasis elimination with ivermectin treatment.
