The study involved 15 to 17 years of annual or six-monthly ivermectin treatment, followed by final evaluations up to 5 years after the last treatment. Skin snip surveys were conducted in 131 villages, examining 29,753 people and analyzing 492,600 blackflies for the presence of Onchocerca volvulus larvae. The results showed a declining trend in infection and transmission levels after the last treatment, with two sites achieving zero microfilaria prevalence and vector infectivity rate 3 to 4 years after treatment cessation. In the third site, where infection levels were initially high, a consistent decline in infection and transmission to very low levels was observed 3 to 5 years after stopping treatment. All infection and transmission indicators were below postulated thresholds for elimination. The study established the proof of principle that onchocerciasis elimination with ivermectin treatment is feasible in at least some endemic foci in Africa. The study's findings have informed the transition from onchocerciasis control to elimination in Africa, with nearly all endemic areas under annual ivermectin treatment and control of the disease as a public health problem achieved in most areas.
Human rhinovirus, a common cause of the common cold, is a non-enveloped virus that must deliver its genome across a cell membrane without the aid of membrane fusion. The small myristoylated capsid protein VP4 plays a crucial role in this process, interacting with the cell membrane and facilitating the delivery of the viral RNA genome into the cytoplasm. In this study, recombinant C-terminal histidine-tagged human rhinovirus VP4 was produced and shown to induce membrane permeability in liposome model membranes. Dextran size-exclusion studies, chemical crosslinking, and electron microscopy revealed that VP4 forms a multimeric membrane pore with a channel size consistent with the transfer of single-stranded RNA. The membrane permeability induced by recombinant VP4 was influenced by pH and was comparable to that induced by infectious virions. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the involvement of VP4 in cell entry and suggest that VP4 could be a novel antiviral target for the picornavirus family. The study demonstrates that VP4 forms a multimeric, size-selective membrane pore, with dimensions consistent with the transport of viral RNA, and provides a model system for further exploration of VP4 as an antiviral target.
Francisella tularensis ( Ft ) is a highly infectious Gram-negative bacterium that causes tularemia, a disease designated as a class A select agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The lipid A structure of Ft is similar to that of Francisella novicida ( Fn ), a pathogen of mice. Researchers identified three enzymes required for Fn lipid A carbohydrate modifications : flmF1, flmF2, and flmK. Mutants lacking galactosamine ( flmF2 ) or galactosamine/mannose ( flmK ) addition to their lipid A were attenuated in mice by both pulmonary and subcutaneous routes of infection. Aerosolization of the mutants ( flmF2 and flmK ) provided protection against challenge with wild-type ( WT ) Fn, while subcutaneous administration of only the flmK mutant provided protection from challenge with WT Fn. Infection of an alveolar macrophage cell line by the flmK mutant induced higher levels of tumor necrosis factor-α ( TNF-α ) and macrophage inhibitory protein-2 ( MIP-2 ) compared to infection with WT Fn. Bone marrow–derived macrophages ( BMMø ) from Toll-like receptor 4 ( TLR4 ) and TLR2/4 knockout mice infected with the flmK mutant produced significantly higher amounts of interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) and MIP-2 than BMMø infected with WT Fn. However, production of IL-6 and MIP-2 was undetectable in BMMø from MyD88−/− mice infected with either strain. The researchers hypothesize that the ability of the flmK mutant to activate pro-inflammatory cytokine/chemokine production and innate immune responses mediated by the MyD88 signaling pathway may be responsible for its attenuation, leading to the induction of protective immunity by this mutant.
The (p)ppGpp-binding GTPase Era promotes rRNA processing and cold adaptation in Staphylococcus aureus. Era is a ribosome-associated GTPase that acts as a molecular switch to coordinate ribosome assembly. In Staphylococcus aureus, Era is not essential for growth but is important for 30S ribosomal subunit assembly. Protein interaction studies reveal that Era interacts with the 16S rRNA endonuclease YbeY and the DEAD-box RNA helicase CshA. Both Era and CshA are required for growth at suboptimal temperatures and rRNA processing. Era and CshA also form direct interactions with the (p)ppGpp synthetase RelSau, with RelSau positively impacting the GTPase activity of Era but negatively affecting the helicase activity of CshA. In its GTP-bound form, Era acts as a hub protein on the ribosome to direct enzymes involved in rRNA processing/degradation and ribosome subunit assembly to their site of action. This activity is impeded by multiple components of the stringent response, contributing to the slowed growth phenotype synonymous with this stress response pathway. The stringent response can also impact RA-GTPase function through direct interactions of RelSau with both Era and CshA. These interactions suggest that Era acts as a guide for rRNA/ribosome maturation enzymes to their substrates, promoting rRNA processing and cold adaptation in Staphylococcus aureus.
The study investigated the effects of anthrax lethal toxin (LT) on mice and the role of neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS) in mediating cardiac damage. Mice deficient in nNOS (nNOS−/−) were found to be more susceptible to LT-induced mortality compared to wild-type (WT) mice and mice deficient in other nitric oxide synthases (iNOS and eNOS). The increased sensitivity of nNOS−/− mice was independent of macrophage sensitivity to toxin and cytokine responses. Histopathological analyses revealed that LT induced architectural changes in the hearts of nNOS−/− mice, including novel inter-fiber spaces, endothelial necrosis, and inter-myocyte edema. Electron microscopic analyses showed similar pathological changes in the hearts of both nNOS−/− and WT mice, with varying severity and timing. Biomarkers of cardiac injury, such as myoglobin, cardiac troponin-I, and heart fatty acid binding protein, were elevated in LT-treated mice as early as 6 hours after toxin injection. Echocardiography indicated a reduction in ejection fraction following LT treatment in both nNOS−/− and WT mice, suggesting decreased contractile function in the heart. The study suggests that the heart is an early target of LT in mice and that nNOS plays a protective role against LT-mediated cardiac damage. The results also indicate that nitric oxide scavenging may be a potential therapeutic strategy to mitigate cardiac damage caused by LT.
Scientists have developed a method for introducing targeted gene disruptions in the human-parasitic threadworm Strongyloides stercoralis using the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing tool. This breakthrough enables the study of gene function in parasitic nematodes, which are responsible for some of the most common neglected tropical diseases affecting over 1 billion people worldwide. The researchers used CRISPR-Cas9 to disrupt the S. stercoralis twitchin gene unc-22, resulting in nematodes with severe motility defects. The mutations were resolved by homology-directed repair when a repair template was provided, and deletions occurred when the template was omitted. The Ss-unc-22 mutations were heritable, allowing the researchers to pass the mutant nematodes through a host and recover mutant progeny. A similar approach was used to disrupt the unc-22 gene in the rat-parasitic nematode Strongyloides ratti. The study demonstrates the applicability of CRISPR-Cas9 to parasitic nematodes, paving the way for future studies of gene function in these medically relevant but previously genetically intractable parasites. This achievement provides a valuable tool for understanding the biology of parasitic nematodes and may lead to the development of new treatments for diseases caused by these parasites.
A novel mathematical model has been developed to describe the effects of ribosome drop-off on translation rate and polysome profile during protein synthesis. Ribosome drop-off is a well-established phenomenon that plays a crucial role in translational accuracy and nutrient starvation responses. The model predicts that ribosome premature termination can lead to non-intuitive ribosome density profiles, such as an increase in ribosome density from the 5’ to the 3’ end of the mRNA. Importantly, the model reveals that the effects of ribosome drop-off on translation rate are mRNA-specific, with mRNAs that present ribosome queues being less affected by drop-off than those that do not. Furthermore, among mRNAs without ribosome queues, resilience to drop-off correlates positively with elongation rate, suggesting that sequences using fast codons are less affected by ribosome drop-off. A genome-wide analysis of Saccharomyces cerevisiae confirms these predictions, showing that mRNAs coding for proteins involved in the translation machinery are highly resilient to ribosome drop-off under favourable growth conditions. In contrast, mRNAs coding for regulatory and stress-related proteins are less resilient to ribosome drop-off under physiological conditions. The model provides a framework for analyzing variations in translational efficiency of individual mRNAs and explains mRNA-specific variations in ribosome density emerging from ribosome profiling studies. The results highlight the importance of accounting for ribosome drop-off in modeling and interpreting ribosome profiling data to accurately estimate translation rates.
The World Health Organization’s current strategy for addressing soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in children involves routine deworming of school and pre-school aged children to control morbidity. However, this approach may not be sufficient to interrupt transmission due to persistent reservoirs of infection in untreated individuals and the environment. To accelerate transmission interruption, alternative strategies of mass drug administration (MDA) are being explored. The DeWorm3 trial aims to investigate the feasibility of interrupting STH transmission using MDA. The trial involves three years of high treatment coverage followed by two years of surveillance to assess whether transmission interruption has occurred. However, determining whether transmission interruption is unlikely at earlier timepoints would be beneficial to reduce continuous monitoring efforts in settings where interruption is unlikely and to avoid bounce-back to pre-treatment levels. A stochastic, individual-based simulation model was employed to simulate the DeWorm3 community-based cluster-randomized trial. The analysis suggests that all clusters should be assessed for transmission interruption after two years of surveillance, unless transmission interruption can be effectively ruled out through evidence of low treatment coverage. The results indicate that a tight range of homogeneous prevalence estimates following high coverage MDA across clusters does not allow for discrimination between bounce-back or transmission interruption within 24 months following cessation of MDA.
A conjugate vaccine for cholera made from Vibrio cholerae O1 (Ogawa) O-Specific Polysaccharide (OSP) and recombinant tetanus toxoid heavy chain fragment (TThc) was evaluated in mice. The study aimed to assess the immunogenicity and protective efficacy of the vaccine. Mice were immunized intramuscularly with OSP:TThc or OSP alone, with or without dmLT, a non-toxigenic immunoadjuvant derived from heat labile toxin of Escherichia coli. The results showed significant serum IgG antibody responses targeting OSP following a single immunization in mice receiving OSP:TThc with or without adjuvant. Anti-LPS IgG responses were detected following a second immunization in these cohorts. In contrast, no anti-OSP or anti-LPS IgG responses were detected in mice receiving un-conjugated OSP with or without immunoadjuvant, or in mice receiving immunoadjuvant alone. Serum anti-OSP IgM responses were detected in mice receiving OSP:TThc with or without immunoadjuvant, and in mice receiving unconjugated OSP. Administration of OSP:TThc and adjuvant also induced memory B cell responses targeting OSP and resulted in 95% protective efficacy in a mouse lethality cholera challenge model. The study demonstrates that the cholera conjugate vaccine is protectively immunogenic and induces anti-OSP memory B cell responses in mice, suggesting its potential to induce long-term protective immunity, particularly in young children who respond poorly to polysaccharide antigens.
In a study using a neutropenic mouse model of microbial gastrointestinal colonization and dissemination, Candida albicans was found to inhibit the virulence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa by suppressing the expression of P. aeruginosa pyochelin and pyoverdine genes. These genes play a critical role in iron acquisition and virulence in P. aeruginosa. Deletion of both pyochelin and pyoverdine genes in P. aeruginosa attenuated its virulence. Candida albicans secreted proteins directly suppressed P. aeruginosa pyoverdine and pyochelin expression and inhibited P. aeruginosa virulence in mice. Heat-killed Candida albicans had no effect on P. aeruginosa. Oral iron supplementation restored P. aeruginosa virulence in mice colonized by both Candida albicans and P. aeruginosa. Candida albicans secreted proteins inhibited P. aeruginosa-mediated cytotoxic effects against cultured human colonocytes and significantly reduced P. aeruginosa virulence. The findings suggest that Candida albicans can modulate Pseudomonas aeruginosa virulence in the intestine through the suppression of pyochelin and pyoverdine gene expression. This novel observation highlights the complexities of polymicrobial, polykingdom infections and identifies a potential therapeutic target for preventing microbial disease. Candida albicans secreted proteins were sufficient to inhibit P. aeruginosa pyochelin and pyoverdine gene expression and decrease P. aeruginosa’s cytotoxic effect on colonocytes in vitro. Oral administration of Candida albicans secreted proteins protected mice from P. aeruginosa infection. Oral iron supplementation restored P. aeruginosa virulence in mice colonized by both Candida albicans and P. aeruginosa.
Biomedical research has shown that escape mutant (EM) viruses, which evade CD8+ T cell recognition, are frequently observed following infection with HIV-1 or SIV. These EM viruses are often less replicatively fit compared to wild-type (WT) viruses, as demonstrated by reversion to WT upon transmission to a naïve host and association with lower viral loads in vivo. However, the rate and timing of reversion is highly variable. A study investigated the reversion to WT of SIV and SHIV viruses containing minor amounts of WT virus in pigtail macaques using a sensitive PCR assay. The results showed that infection with mixes of EM and WT virus containing ≥10% WT virus results in immediate and rapid outgrowth of WT virus at SIV Gag CD8 T cell epitopes within 7 days of infection. In contrast, infection with biologically passaged SHIVmn229 viruses with much smaller proportions of WT sequence, or a molecular clone of pure EM SIVmac239, demonstrated a delayed or slow pattern of reversion. The diversity of the infecting inoculum determines the timing of reversion to WT virus, which in turn predicts the outcome of infection. The delay in reversion of fitness-reducing CD8 T cell escape mutations in some scenarios suggests opportunities to reduce the pathogenicity of HIV during very early infection.
In a study of yeast strains collected from Evolution Canyon, Israel, researchers found that a subset of diploid yeast strains exhibited an extremely high tolerance to the heavy metal cadmium. The cadmium resistance was primarily caused by an enhanced function of the metal efflux pump PCA1, which is encoded by the PCA1 gene. Molecular analyses revealed that mutations in the PCA1 promoter sequence were responsible for the enhancement, while mutations in the coding region had a minor effect. Reconstruction experiments showed that three single nucleotide substitutions in the PCA1 promoter increased its activity and thus enhanced cadmium resistance. The critical nucleotides found in the EC strains were conserved and functionally important for cadmium resistance in other yeast species, suggesting that they represent an ancestral type. However, these nucleotides had diverged in most Saccharomyces cerevisiae populations, which gave cells growth advantages under conditions where cadmium is low or absent. The study provides a rare example of a selective sweep in yeast populations driven by a tradeoff in metal resistance. The findings suggest that the reduced cadmium resistance in most S. cerevisiae populations is likely due to regulatory fine-tuning that allows cells to maintain a certain level of cadmium efflux activity without compromising their fitness under normal conditions.
The study aimed to identify major oncogenic pathways in gastric cancer (GC) with significant relationships to patient survival. Using gene expression signatures, the researchers devised an in silico strategy to map patterns of oncogenic pathway activation in 301 primary gastric cancers. Three oncogenic pathways (proliferation/stem cell, NF-κB, and Wnt/β-catenin) were found to be deregulated in the majority (>70%) of gastric cancers. These findings were functionally validated in a panel of gastric cancer cell lines. Patient stratification by oncogenic pathway combinations showed reproducible and significant survival differences in multiple cohorts, suggesting that pathway interactions may play an important role in influencing disease behavior. The study demonstrated that individual GCs can be successfully taxonomized by oncogenic pathway activity into biologically and clinically relevant subgroups. The researchers developed an in silico method to map activation levels of different pathways in cohorts of complex primary tumor profiles and validated this pathway-directed classification approach using proof-of-concept examples from breast cancer. This method was then applied to GC to evaluate eleven oncogenic pathways previously implicated in gastric carcinogenesis. The results suggest that predicting pathway activity by expression signatures permits the study of multiple cancer-related pathways interacting simultaneously in primary cancers, at a scale not currently achievable by other platforms. Gastric cancer, the second leading cause of global cancer mortality, is a molecularly heterogeneous disease with deregulation of canonical oncogenic pathways such as E2F, K-RAS, p53, and Wnt/β-catenin signaling occurring with varying frequencies.
The study investigated the relationship between stress-induced DNA duplex destabilization (SIDD) and regulatory regions of stress response genes in Escherichia coli K12. Using SIDD analysis, the researchers found that strongly destabilized sites occur preferentially in intergenic regions containing promoters, but rarely in coding regions. They then examined the SIDD properties of genes grouped in different functional categories and found that strong SIDD sites are statistically significantly overrepresented in the upstream regions of genes encoding transcriptional regulators. In particular, the upstream regions of genes that directly respond to physiological and environmental stimuli are more destabilized than those of genes not involved in these responses. Furthermore, if a pathway is controlled by a transcriptional regulator whose gene has a destabilized 5′ flank, the genes (operons) in that pathway also usually contain strongly destabilized SIDD sites in their 5′ flanks. This association was observed in 38 of 43 genomes of free-living bacteria, but in only four of 18 genomes of endosymbionts or obligate parasitic bacteria. The results suggest that strong SIDD sites 5′ to participating genes may be involved in transcriptional responses to environmental changes, which are known to transiently alter superhelicity. The study proposes that these SIDD sites are active and necessary participants in superhelically mediated regulatory mechanisms governing changes in the global pattern of gene expression in prokaryotes in response to physiological or environmental changes.
In the filamentous ascomycete Podospora anserina, a network of high-mobility group ( HMG )-box transcription factors plays a crucial role in regulating the sexual cycle. Systematic deletion analysis of the 12 HMG-box genes in P. anserina revealed that 11 out of 12 genes are involved in the sexual cycle. PaHMG5, an ortholog of SpSte11 from Schizosaccharomyces pombe, is a pivotal activator of mating-type genes in P. anserina. PaHMG9 is a repressor of several phenomena specific to the stationary phase, including hyphal anastomoses. Transcriptional analyses of HMG-box genes in HMG-box deletion strains indicated that PaHMG5 is at the hub of a network of several HMG-box factors that regulate mating-type genes and mating-type target genes. This network also controls fertility genes that are not regulated by mating-type transcription factors. PaHMG5 and SpSte11 are conserved transcriptional regulators of mating-type genes, although P. anserina and S. pombe diverged 550 million years ago. The P. anserina and S. pombe mating-type genes and their upstream regulatory factor form a module of HMG-box genes analogous to the SRY/SOX9 module, revealing a commonality of sex regulation in animals and fungi. The study provides new insights into the role and relationships of HMG-box genes in P. anserina and highlights the critical role of HMG-box members in sexual reproduction in fungi.
During the 2013–2016 West African Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic, there was a pressing need to determine the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors’ body fluids and the potential risk of transmission, including sexual transmission. An observational cohort study was conducted in Sierra Leone to investigate the presence of Ebola virus in semen and other body fluids of EVD survivors. The study was initiated within five months of initial protocol discussions and consisted of two phases. The first phase assessed the persistence of Ebola virus in semen of 100 adult men, while the second phase evaluated the persistence of virus in multiple body fluids (semen, vaginal fluid, menstrual blood, breast milk, urine, rectal fluid, sweat, saliva, and tears) of 120 men and 120 women. The study demonstrated the need to implement semen testing programs among EVD survivors and informed national and global guidelines in real-time. Strong community engagement facilitated the rapid implementation of the study during the epidemic. However, challenges were encountered, including unforeseen duration of follow-up, complexity of interpreting and communicating laboratory results to survivors, and the urgency of translating research findings into public health practice. The study tools and lessons learned accelerated the implementation of semen testing programs in EVD-affected countries and informed studies examining the persistence of Zika virus. The study highlights the importance of research in the public health response to an epidemic of a poorly characterized disease, emphasizing the need for adequate resources to be rapidly made available to answer critical research questions.
The article presents a study on predicting the chemical environments of bacteria, specifically Escherichia coli, based on their chemotaxis sensory system. The researchers used in vivo fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) experiments and information theory to analyze the dose-response curves of the chemotactic sensory pathway. They found that maximizing mutual information implies maximizing the alignment of cell trajectories with the gradient (chemotactic index) and hence the drift velocity of cells swimming up the gradient. The study suggests that chemotactic E. coli typically encounters exponential gradients in its natural habitat, as its pathway has evolved to maintain perception in these conditions. The researchers also reevaluated the phenomenological Weber's law and its generalizations to the Weber-Fechner law and fold-change detection (FCD) to predict the average gradients cells experience. They used information theory and simulations to obtain full distributions of gradients, considering limitations of information transmission from both cell-external and internal noise. The results indicate broad distributions of exponential gradients, leading to log-normal stimuli and maximal drift velocity. This study provides a first step towards deciphering the chemical nature of complex, experimentally inaccessible cellular microenvironments, such as the human intestine. The findings connect a large number of phenomenological laws with information theory at the molecular level, shedding light on the design principles of sensory systems.
The lifespan of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), which are responsible for the long-term supply of blood cells, was previously thought to be indefinite due to their self-renewal capacity. However, recent evidence suggests that genetically identical HSCs within the same animal can differ in lifespan, indicating that lifespan is predetermined and HSC-intrinsic. A new model based on reliability theory was developed to account for the diversity of lifespans of HSCs. Using clonal repopulation experiments and computational-mathematical modeling, the study found that the repopulation failure kinetics of each HSC are largely anti-persistent, or mean-reverting, processes. This means that failure rates repeatedly increase during population-wide division events and are counteracted and decreased by repair processes. However, in the long-run, a crossover from anti-persistent to persistent behavior occurs, leading to rapid clonal extinction due to a slow increase in the mean failure rate of self-renewal. The study also found that the lifespan of each HSC depends on the amplitudes and frequencies of fluctuations in the failure rate kinetics, with shorter and longer lived HSCs differing significantly in their pre-programmed ability to dissipate perturbations. The findings suggest that the lifespan of HSCs is determined by preprogrammed differences in repair capacity. The study's results have implications for understanding aging in HSCs and other non-homogenous, hierarchically organized cell systems.
Antibodies play a crucial role in providing protective immunity against chronic helminth infections, which affect approximately one-third of the world's population. However, the mechanisms by which antibodies target these large multicellular parasites have remained unclear. This study investigated the mechanisms of antibody-mediated immunity following challenge infection with the natural murine parasite Heligmosomoides polygyrus bakeri (Hp). The results show that helminth-specific antibodies induce the rapid trapping of tissue-migrating larvae and prevent tissue necrosis. Mice lacking antibodies or activating Fc receptors harbored highly motile larvae, developed extensive tissue damage, and accumulated fewer Arginase-1 expressing macrophages around the larvae. Antibodies together with helminth larvae reprogrammed macrophages to express wound-healing associated genes, including Arginase-1, and the Arginase-1 product L-ornithine directly impaired larval motility. Notably, antibody-induced expression of Arginase-1 occurred independently of IL-4Rα signaling, indicating a novel IL-4Rα-independent mechanism of alternative macrophage activation. This mechanism, referred to as helminth-antibody activated macrophages (HAAM), mediates anti-helminth immunity and prevents tissue disruption caused by migrating larvae. The study demonstrates a novel effector function of antibodies in activating macrophages to modulate the expression of genes associated with the alternatively activated phenotype, providing new insights into the mechanisms of antibody-mediated immunity against helminths.
DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) pose a significant threat to genome integrity and cell survival. Cells respond to DSBs by initiating repair programs that involve enzymatic DNA restoration, chromatin remodeling, and checkpoint activation. The exposed DNA ends are initially protected by the Ku70-Ku80 complex (Ku complex) until a repair pathway is chosen and corresponding proteins are recruited. Homologous recombination (HR) is the most accurate method for repairing DSBs, involving the use of an intact copy of the broken locus as a template. However, the early steps of HR, including resection from DSB ends that generates recombinogenic single strands, have been difficult to visualize due to the need for a non-intrusive method that does not interfere with the process.

A new visualization tool, the ParB-INT system, has been developed to address this challenge. This system uses protein oligomerization rather than operator multiplicity to form visible foci, allowing for real-time analysis of resection in single living cells. By applying this tool to the HO cleavage of the MAT locus on Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosome III, researchers have provided the first real-time analysis of resection in single living cells. The results show that resection in a yku70 mutant begins approximately 10 minutes earlier than in wild-type cells, defining this as the period of commitment to homology-dependent repair. The study also reveals a transient confinement of the damaged chromatin region during the early steps of resection, consistent with the need to keep DNA ends in contact. The ParB-INT system has the potential to be widely applicable to fine-scale analysis of genome organization, dynamics, and function in normal and pathological contexts.
Epidemiological modeling of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, was conducted to estimate the rate of re-inoculation in humans and assess the frequency of reinfections during the acute and chronic stages of the disease. A stochastic agent-based model was implemented to fit epidemiological data from Argentinean rural villages where mixed infections by different genotypes of T. cruzi reached 56% in humans. The model predicted an annual reinfection rate of 0. 032 ( 0. 008–0. 042 ) per individual, with 98. 4% of reinfections occurring in the chronic phase. The parasite was found to evade the adaptive immune response in at least 20% of re-inoculation events. As a result, the risks of reinfection during the chronic stage of the disease were estimated to be around 14% ( 4%–18% ) and 60% ( 21%–70% ) after 5 and 30 years, respectively, with most individuals being re-infected 1–3 times overall. The low rates of reinfection were attributed to the weak efficiency of the stercorarian mode of transmission rather than a highly efficient adaptive immune response. These estimates have implications for vaccine development and understanding the higher risk of chronic disease manifestations in infected individuals living in endemic areas. The study highlights the importance of mathematical and computational models in inferring the rate and timing of T. cruzi reinfections from epidemiological field data.
Dengue virus (DENV) infections can result in a range of clinical outcomes, from asymptomatic or subclinical infection to severe forms such as dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS). A study investigated the relationship between pre-existing immune responses and the clinical outcome of subsequent DENV infection in a cohort of school-aged Thai children. Blood samples were collected from the children before and after the peak DENV transmission season, and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were stimulated in vitro with DENV to measure the secretion of 30 cytokines. The results showed significant differences in cytokine production based on the type of DENV used for stimulation and the occurrence of clinical illness. Specifically, higher levels of IL-15 and MCP-1 were found in PBMC from subjects who later developed symptomatic DENV infection, while IL-6 was produced by PBMC from all subjects who subsequently developed symptomatic infection, but only 59% of subjects with subclinical infection. In contrast, lower levels of IL-12, IL-2R, MIP-1α, RANTES, GM-CSF, and TNFα were found in PBMC from subjects with symptomatic infection. These findings suggest the existence of both protective and pathologic immune profiles associated with the clinical outcome of DENV infection. The study's results may have implications for evaluating immune responses to dengue vaccines and understanding the mechanisms controlling differential clinical outcomes in DENV infections.
In the Drosophila wing imaginal disc, the Hedgehog ( Hh ) signaling pathway plays a crucial role in patterning along the anterior–posterior axis. While Hh is traditionally viewed as a classical morphogen that regulates gene expression in a concentration-dependent manner, a direct correspondence between Hh concentration thresholds and the borders of gene expression patterns has not been demonstrated. This study provides evidence that the interpretation of Hh signaling depends on the history of exposure to Hh and proposes that a single concentration threshold is sufficient to support multiple outputs. Using mathematical modeling, the authors predict that at steady state, only two domains can be defined in response to Hh, suggesting that the boundaries of two or more gene expression patterns cannot be specified by a static Hh gradient. Computer simulations suggest that a spatial “overshoot” of the Hh gradient occurs, which is a transient state in which the Hh profile is expanded compared to the Hh steady-state gradient. This overshoot is thought to result from the Hh-dependent up-regulation of the receptor, Patched ( Ptc ), and is required to distinguish different spatial domains of gene expression in response to Hh. The authors propose a new model of pattern formation that takes into consideration gradient dynamics to explain Hh-dependent patterning of the wing disc. This model suggests that the Hh gene network architecture plays an instructional role in the establishment of patterns of gene expression.
The article describes the positional cloning and characterization of a new mouse mutation, Lightweight (Lwt), isolated in an N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea (ENU) forward mutagenesis screen for animals with enhanced locomotor activity. The Lwt allele disrupts the homolog of the Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) unc-79 gene. While Lwt/Lwt homozygotes are perinatal lethal, Lightweight heterozygotes are dramatically hypersensitive to acute ethanol exposure. Experiments in C. elegans demonstrate a conserved hypersensitivity to ethanol in unc-79 mutants and extend this observation to the related unc-80 mutant and nca-1;nca-2 double mutants. Lightweight heterozygotes also exhibit an altered response to the anesthetic isoflurane, reminiscent of unc-79 invertebrate mutant phenotypes. In addition, Lightweight heterozygotes are mildly hyperactive when exposed to a novel environment, are smaller than wild-type animals, exhibit increased food consumption, and have a leaner body composition. Notably, Lightweight heterozygotes voluntarily consume more ethanol than wild-type littermates. The acute hypersensitivity to and increased voluntary consumption of ethanol observed in Lightweight heterozygous mice, in combination with the observed hypersensitivity to ethanol in C. elegans unc-79, unc-80, and nca-1;nca-2 double mutants, suggests a novel conserved pathway that might influence alcohol-related behaviors in humans.
The Anopheles gambiae immune response against Plasmodium falciparum, the etiological agent of human malaria, has been identified as a potential source of anti-Plasmodium genes and mechanisms to control malaria transmission. The Imd pathway, a conserved immune signaling pathway, has been shown to have potent anti-P. falciparum activity. Silencing the expression of caspar, a negative regulator of the Imd pathway, or over-expressing rel2, an Imd pathway-controlled NF-kappaB transcription factor, confers a resistant phenotype on A. gambiae mosquitoes. To further explore this mechanism, the authors used RNA interference to singly or dually silence caspar and other components of the Imd pathway, identifying genes participating in the anti-Plasmodium signaling module regulated by Caspar. These genes, including TEP1, APL1, and LRIM1, represent potential targets to achieve over-activation of the pathway. The Imd pathway was found to be most potent against the parasite's ookinete stage, with reasonable activity against early oocysts and lesser activity against late oocysts. Caspar silencing alone was sufficient to induce a robust anti-P. falciparum response even in the absence of resident gut microbiota. The study highlights the physiological considerations integral to implementing Imd pathway manipulation in A. gambiae to limit malaria transmission and reveals nuances in the Imd-directed immune response against P. falciparum.
The study investigated the anti-fibrotic potential of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BMMSCs) in a mouse model of pulmonary paracoccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. BMMSCs have been considered a promising therapy for fibrotic diseases, including pulmonary fibrosis. In this study, BMMSCs were isolated and purified from BALB/c mice and administered intravenously to mice infected with P. brasiliensis at 8 weeks post-infection. The results showed that BMMSCs treatment did not have an anti-fibrotic effect, but rather exacerbated pulmonary fibrosis. Histopathological examination revealed an increase in granulomatous inflammatory areas and fibrocytes count in BMMSCs-treated mice. Additionally, soluble collagen and fibrosis-related genes expression, such as collagen-3α1, TGF-β3, MMP-8, and MMP-15, were significantly increased in BMMSCs-treated mice. Furthermore, human fibroblasts stimulated with homogenized lung supernatants from infected and BMMSCs-transplanted mice showed a higher expression of collagen I. In contrast, the combined therapy of BMMSCs and itraconazole (ITC) reduced the expression of TIMP-1 and MMP-13 genes and decreased the amount of soluble collagen in the lungs. These findings suggest that BMMSCs may not be effective in treating pulmonary fibrosis caused by P. brasiliensis infection, and that their interaction with the fungus may promote collagen expression and tissue remodeling.
A recent study investigated the seasonal dynamics of phlebotomine sand fly species that are proven vectors of Leishmania infantum in the Mediterranean subregion. The study aimed to provide a baseline for future investigations on sand fly population dynamics that may impact leishmaniasis transmission due to ongoing climate changes. A consortium of partners from eight Mediterranean countries conducted entomological investigations in sites where L. infantum transmission was recently reported from 2011 to 2013. The study analyzed data from 99,000 collected specimens, resulting in the description of seasonal dynamics of 56,000 sand flies belonging to six L. infantum vector species.

The study found that the time of sand fly appearance and disappearance differed between sites, and seasonal densities showed variations in each site. Significant correlations were found between latitude/mean annual temperature of sites and the first month of sand fly appearance, which ranged from early April to the first half of June, and the type of density trend, varying from a single peak in July/August to multiple peaks increasing in magnitude from May through September. The period of potential exposure to L. infantum in the Mediterranean subregion was associated with a regular bell-shaped density curve, with a wide peak center encompassing the July-September period, and falling between early May to late October for more than 99% of values.

The study also found a common pattern of nocturnal females' activity, whose density peaked between 11 pm and 2 am, and identified a higher potential risk for L. infantum transmission in the June-October period (97% relative vector density). However, the risk was not equally distributed throughout the region, with density waves of adults occurring earlier and more frequently in southern territories.
Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, has been found to replicate in monocytes isolated from healthy donors. Microarray analysis revealed that O. tsutsugamushi altered the expression of over 4, 500 genes in monocytes, including the upregulation of type I interferon, interferon-stimulated genes, and genes associated with the M1 polarization of macrophages. The bacterium also induced the expression of apoptosis-related genes and promoted cell death in a small percentage of monocytes. Live O. tsutsugamushi organisms were necessary for the type I interferon response and apoptosis, and enhanced the expression of M1-associated cytokines. These findings were related to the transcriptional changes detected in mononuclear cells isolated from patients with scrub typhus, who showed upregulation of 613 genes, including interferon-related genes, and features of M1 polarization. The study demonstrates that monocytes are polarized in vitro and ex vivo following exposure to O. tsutsugamushi, and highlights the role of interferon-mediated activation of monocytes and their subsequent polarization into an M1 phenotype in the pathogenesis of scrub typhus. The results suggest that O. tsutsugamushi induces a specific M1 phenotype and stimulates a type I IFN response in monocytes, which may be associated with the inflammatory complications of scrub typhus. The study provides new insights into the pathogenesis of scrub typhus and may lead to the development of new diagnostic tools for the disease.
A spiking neural model originally developed to describe olfactory association in fruitflies (Drosophila melanogaster) has been adapted to account for the ability of desert ants (Cataglyphis velox) to rapidly learn visual routes through complex natural environments. The model, which simulates the neural architecture of the insect mushroom body (MB), demonstrates that it can learn to distinguish between on-route and off-route images in a realistic visual learning task. The MB has been extensively studied in the context of olfactory associative learning, but its role in visual learning has not been well understood. The model used three stages of processing, with olfactory inputs producing a spatio-temporal pattern in the antennal lobe, consistent with evidence in flies and other insects. The simulation showed that the MB can learn over 80 on-route images, reconstructed from real ant viewpoints in their natural habitat, and reliably distinguish them from highly similar images obtained when looking off-route. The network required almost no modification to perform the complex function of supporting navigation under realistic conditions, despite being originally developed for simple olfactory associative learning in flies. The study suggests that the neural architecture of the ant MB could plausibly form the substrate for the familiarity algorithm of Baddeley et al. The theoretical storage capacity of the ant MB has been estimated at hundreds of independent images, based on the key computational principles of the circuit, including one-shot learning of sparse codes.
Plants have evolved unique defense mechanisms to protect themselves from disease, including the ability to replace damaged organs through their flexible developmental program. In Arabidopsis, cauline leaves infected with the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae undergo abscission, or shedding, as a defense mechanism. The abscission response is triggered by the pathogen's type III secretion system and requires the HAESA/HAESA-like 2, INFLORESCENCE DEFICIENT IN ABSCISSION, and NEVERSHED genes. Additionally, phytoalexin deficient 4, enhanced disease susceptibility 1, salicylic acid induction-deficient 2, and senescence-associated gene 101 plants with mutations in genes necessary for bacterial defense and salicylic acid signaling fail to abscise cauline leaves normally. Bacteria that physically contact the abscission zone trigger a strong abscission response, while long-distance signals are also sent from distal infected tissue to the abscission zone. A threshold model regulating cauline leaf defense is proposed, where minor infections are handled by limiting bacterial growth, but when an infection is deemed out of control, cauline leaves are shed. Salicylic acid is found to regulate both pathogen- and drought-triggered leaf abscission. The study defines a new model system for studying pathogen-triggered leaf abscission in Arabidopsis and begins to explain the genetics governing this process. The abscission pathway is required for all known forms of inducible leaf abscission in Arabidopsis, and salicylic acid production or signaling is necessary for proper pathogen-triggered leaf abscission to occur.
Retinal starburst amacrine cells (SACs) play a crucial role in detecting image motion direction in the retina. To investigate the mechanisms underlying direction selectivity (DS) in SAC dendrites, researchers used somatic whole-cell recordings and Fourier analysis to measure electrical responses to expanding and contracting circular wave visual stimuli. The results showed that SACs generate larger dendritic Ca2+ signals when motion is from their somata towards their dendritic tips than for motion in the opposite direction. This direction selectivity persists even in the presence of GABA and glycine receptor antagonists, suggesting that inhibitory network interactions are not essential. The presence of harmonic frequency components indicates nonlinearity, which is likely due to the activation of voltage-gated channels. Compartmental modeling suggests that dendritic DS in SACs can be computed by the dendrites themselves, relying on voltage-gated channels and a dendritic voltage gradient, which provides the spatial asymmetry necessary for direction discrimination. Optical recordings of visual stimulus-evoked Ca2+ signals also showed that dendritic sectors can be activated independently, with the strongest [Ca2+] increases in the distal portions of the dendrites, near the output synapses. These findings indicate that SAC dendrites can generate DS signals independently of lateral inhibitory interactions, relying on intrinsic mechanisms involving voltage-gated channels and a dendritic voltage gradient.
The mechanisms of pathogenesis, infective dose, and virulence in human parasites were investigated in a study that analyzed data from 43 different human pathogens across various taxonomic groups. Contrary to the hypothesis that pathogens with distantly acting immune modulators are more virulent, the study found no significant relationship between case fatality rate or severity of infection and the mechanism of pathogenesis. However, a significant negative correlation was observed between infective dose and case fatality rate, indicating that pathogens with lower infective doses are associated with higher case fatality rates. The study also found that pathogens infecting hosts through wounded skin result in significantly higher case fatality rates compared to those inhaled or ingested. Furthermore, the results showed that pathogens using locally acting molecules have lower infective doses than those using distantly acting molecules, but are not less virulent. The study highlights the importance of mechanistic details in understanding the variation in parasite traits such as infective dose and virulence. The findings suggest that broad-scale comparative analyses can explain the variation in these traits, and that the mode of transmission and route of infection also play a significant role in determining infective dose and virulence. Overall, the study provides new insights into the mechanisms of pathogenesis and the factors that influence the virulence of human parasites.
This study investigated the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the development of Schistosoma mansoni, a parasitic helminth that causes schistosomiasis. The researchers used a novel bioinformatics tool, Sylamer, to analyze the 3'-untranslated regions (3'-UTRs) of transcripts differentially expressed between the juvenile and adult stages of the parasite. They found that the miR-277/4989 family target sequence was significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult worms. A novel miRNA, sma-miR-4989, was identified, and its genomic location suggested that it forms a miRNA cluster with sma-miR-277. The expression of sma-miR-277/4989 miRNAs was found to be up-regulated in adults, while their predicted targets were down-regulated in paired adult worms but remained unchanged in immature females. Additionally, sma-miR-4989 was expressed in tegumental cells near the oesophagus gland and throughout the male worms' body. The results suggest that sma-miR-277/4989 may play a dominant role in post-transcriptional regulation during the development of juvenile worms and are involved in the sexual development of female schistosomes. The study provides evidence for the role of miRNAs in the intra-mammalian development of S. mansoni and highlights the importance of miR-277/4989 in regulating gene expression changes underlying the development of juveniles and sexual maturation.
A 5-year surveillance of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARSr-CoV) in a cave inhabited by horseshoe bats in Yunnan Province, China, has revealed a rich gene pool of SARSr-CoVs with high genetic diversity in the S gene, ORF3, and ORF8 regions. The full-length genomes of 11 newly discovered SARSr-CoV strains, together with previous findings, show that the SARSr-CoVs circulating in this single location are highly diverse in the S gene, ORF3, and ORF8. Importantly, strains with high genetic similarity to SARS-CoV in the hypervariable N-terminal domain (NTD) and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the S1 gene, the ORF3 and ORF8 region, respectively, were all discovered in this cave. Additionally, SARSr-CoV strains from this cave were more closely related to SARS-CoV in the non-structural protein genes ORF1a and 1b compared to those detected elsewhere. Recombination analysis shows evidence of frequent recombination events within the S gene and around the ORF8 between these SARSr-CoVs. Cell entry studies demonstrated that three newly identified SARSr-CoVs with different S protein sequences are all able to use human ACE2 as the receptor, further exhibiting the close relationship between strains in this cave and SARS-CoV. This work provides new insights into the origin and evolution of SARS-CoV and highlights the necessity of preparedness for future emergence of SARS-like diseases. The findings suggest that the direct progenitor of SARS-CoV may have originated after sequential recombination events between the precursors of these SARSr-CoVs.
The faecal egg count reduction test (FECRT) is a widely used method for detecting drug resistance in human soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections. However, recent evidence suggests that density-dependent fecundity may impact the accuracy of FECRT data. Density-dependent fecundity refers to the phenomenon where the reproductive output of female worms increases as their population density decreases. This phenomenon has been observed in canine hookworms and is likely to occur in human STHs as well. The relaxation of density-dependent constraints on egg production after drug treatment may lead to an increase in egg output from surviving worms, resulting in an underestimation of drug efficacy. The degree of underestimation will depend on the extent to which egg output is constrained prior to treatment and the ability of worms to increase their egg output. This may lead to varying effects on drug efficacy measurements within a group of potential FECRT candidates. To improve the measurement of relative drug efficacy, it is suggested to omit cases with the heaviest infections from FECRTs, as these cases may have the greatest potential to increase their egg output upon removal of density-dependent constraints. The potential impact of worm reproductive biology on the utility of FECRT as a resistance detection tool highlights the need to develop new drug resistance monitoring methods that examine direct drug effects on isolated worms or changes in worm genotypes.
This study investigated the role of epithelial heparan sulfate (HS) in regulating Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) signaling during lung development. The researchers found that deletion of HS synthetase Ext1 in epithelial cells resulted in expanded branching tips and reduced branching number in the lung. This was associated with increased FGF10 expression and FGF signaling activity, suggesting a cell non-autonomous mechanism. Further analysis revealed reduced SHH signaling activity in mutant lungs, which was not due to decreased SHH expression or protein stability, but rather reduced production of biologically active SHH proteins. The study also showed that reactivating SHH signaling in mutant lungs rescued the tip dilation phenotype and attenuated FGF signaling. These findings highlight the critical role of epithelial HS in maintaining SHH signaling activity and lung morphogenesis. The results suggest that HS produced by epithelial cells is essential for regulating the SHH-FGF10 signaling cascade, which is crucial for proper lung development. The study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying lung branching morphogenesis and identifies HS as a key player in this process. Overall, the study demonstrates the importance of epithelial HS in regulating SHH signaling and lung development.
The article evaluates the effectiveness of paired-end sequencing strategies for detecting genome rearrangements in cancer. Paired-end sequencing is a technique that assesses genome rearrangements and structural variation on a genome-wide scale, particularly useful for detecting copy-neutral rearrangements such as inversions and translocations. The authors derive a formula for the probability that a fusion gene exists in a cancer genome given a collection of paired-end sequences from this genome. They use this formula to compute fusion gene probabilities in several breast cancer samples and find that they can accurately predict fusion genes with a relatively small number of fragments of large size. The authors also demonstrate how the ability to detect fusion genes depends on the distribution of gene lengths and evaluate how different parameters of a sequencing strategy impact breakpoint detection, breakpoint localization, and fusion gene detection, even in the presence of errors that suggest false rearrangements. The results will be useful in calibrating future cancer sequencing efforts, particularly large-scale studies of many cancer genomes enabled by next-generation sequencing technologies. The study highlights the importance of maximizing the probability of detecting fusion genes with the least amount of sequencing, taking into account factors such as the number and length of end-sequenced clones, the length of genes that are fused, and possible errors in breakpoint localization.
Chemotaxis, the ability of cells to sense the direction of chemical gradients and respond by polarizing and migrating toward attractants, involves the coordinated action of separable but interrelated processes: motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. A mathematical model has been developed to recreate the behaviors of chemotactic cells by implementing these processes in terms of reaction-diffusion equations. The model consists of three modules: an excitable network that accounts for random migration, a local excitation, global inhibition module that biases the direction of excitability in response to uniform stimuli and gradients, and a polarization module linked to the excitable network through the cytoskeleton that allows unstimulated cells to move persistently and cells in gradients to acquire distinct sensitivity between front and back. Simulations using a mechanical model of the cell cortex implemented in the level set framework demonstrate the migration and accompanying changes in cellular morphology. The model is able to recreate most of the behaviors of chemotactic cells, including the ability to respond to combinations of uniform stimuli and gradients, and the acquisition of distinct sensitivity between front and back in cells in gradients. By varying the strengths of various feedback loops in the model, cellular behaviors that mirror those of genetically altered cell lines can be obtained. The results suggest that adaptation is not absolutely required for chemotaxis, and that the model can capture the complex biphasic responses observed in cells without an adaptation mechanism.
TDRD6 (Tudor containing protein 6) is a male germ line-specific protein essential for the structure of chromatoid bodies (ChBs), elongated spermatid development, and male fertility. In meiotic prophase I spermatocytes, TDRD6 interacts with PRMT5, a protein arginine methyl transferase that supports splicing. TDRD6 also associates with SmB, a spliceosomal core protein, in an arginine methylation-dependent manner. In TDRD6-deficient diplotene spermatocytes, PRMT5 association with SmB and arginine dimethylation of SmB are significantly reduced. As a result, the assembly of spliceosomes is impaired, featuring 3.5-fold increased levels of U5 snRNPs. In the nucleus, these deficiencies in spliceosome maturation correlate with decreased numbers of SMN-positive bodies and Cajal bodies involved in nuclear snRNP maturation. Transcriptome analysis of TDRD6-deficient diplotene spermatocytes reveals high numbers of splicing defects, including aberrant usage of introns and exons, as well as aberrant representation of splice junctions. These findings demonstrate a novel function of TDRD6 in spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing in prophase I spermatocytes. The study suggests that TDRD6 plays a central role in the regulation of spliceosome maturation and mRNA splicing during spermatogenesis.
Title: A Bayesian Model of Acquisition and Clearance of Bacterial Colonization Incorporating Within-Host Variation

A Bayesian model has been developed to estimate the rates of acquisition and clearance of bacterial colonization in a host. The model provides probabilities of whether two strains should be considered the same, allowing for the determination of bacterial clearance and acquisition from genomes sampled over time. Unlike previous approaches, this model does not rely on a fixed genetic distance threshold to determine the relationship between isolates. Instead, it uses a fully probabilistic approach that automatically provides uncertainty estimates for all relevant quantities.

The model is based on population genetic simulation and uses a combination of Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) for inference. It has been validated through simulations and applied to a collection of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) isolates from a longitudinal clinical study.

The study of colonization dynamics is critical for understanding host health, as colonizing bacteria can serve as a reservoir for transmission to other hosts and can give rise to invasive strains. Whole-genome sequencing has provided a detailed measure of genetic distance between isolates, which can be used to infer the relationship between them. However, previous approaches have been inadequate to account for the diversity of the underlying within-host evolving population, the time intervals between consecutive measurements, and the uncertainty in the estimated acquisition and clearance rates. The new Bayesian model addresses these limitations and provides a robust and accurate method for determining bacterial clearance and acquisition from genomes sampled over time.
Plants generate new organs through the activity of stem cells called meristems. The shoot apical meristem initiates leaves, flowers, and lateral meristems in highly ordered patterns via phyllotaxis. The active transport of the plant hormone auxin plays a major role in this process. Current hypotheses propose that cellular hormone transporters of the PIN family create local auxin maxima at precise positions, leading to organ initiation. However, different concepts have been proposed to explain how auxin transporters create hormone fluxes to distinct regions within the plant. The canalization hypothesis suggests that auxin transporters amplify and stabilize existing fluxes, which could be initiated by local diffusion. For the shoot apical meristem, a second hypothesis proposes that hormone is systematically transported towards areas with the highest concentrations. This implies two different mechanisms for PIN allocation in the membrane. To test these hypotheses, computational modelling was used to simulate auxin transport at the shoot meristem. The results show that a flux-based polarization hypothesis is able to explain auxin transport at the shoot meristem, providing a unifying concept for the control of auxin distribution in the plant. Auxin is transported throughout the plant by carriers at the cell plasma membranes, creating fluxes that lead to local hormone maxima and minima. At the shoot apical meristem, auxin importers and exporters are mainly expressed at the meristem surface. The flux-based hypothesis remains a potential unifying mechanism for auxin transport throughout the plant.
The search for diagnostic biomarkers for visceral leishmaniasis (VL) has been enhanced by the availability of high-quality sequenced genomes and bioinformatic tools. To develop improved point-of-care diagnostic tests, researchers combined wet lab experiments with in silico searches. Immunoblots revealed L. donovani protein bands detected by IgG1 from VL patients, and mass spectrometry (MS) was used to confidently identify these antigens. In silico algorithms were employed to search for evidence of constitutive protein expression and presence of antigenic domains or high accessibility to B-cells. Multiple high-scoring predicted epitopes from shortlisted proteins were screened in peptide arrays, and the most promising candidate was tested in RDT prototypes using VL and non-endemic healthy control (NEHC) patient sera. Over 90% of the proteins identified from immunoblots did not satisfy the selection criteria and were excluded from downstream epitope mapping. The most reactive peptide identified had a sensitivity of 84% (95% CI 60-97%) for IgG1 with Sudanese VL sera on RDT prototypes, and none of the NEHC sera were positive. This study demonstrates the potential of in silico searches to reduce the output of wet lab experiments, focusing on promising candidates containing selected protein features. By predicting epitopes in silico, the researchers screened a large number of peptides using arrays, identifying the most promising one, which showed promising results of both sensitivity and specificity on a small sample size. This proof-of-concept strategy can be applied to the development of more robust IgG1 RDTs for monitoring clinical status in VL.
A large multiregional cohort of 317 patients with cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) from Syria, Pakistan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia, and Iran was reviewed to investigate the incidence of caseating granulomas, a characteristic typically associated with mycobacterial infections such as tuberculosis (TB). The study found that 195 (61.5%) of the cases exhibited granulomas, with 49 (25.2%) being caseating, 9 (4.6%) suppurative, and 137 (70.2%) tuberculoid without necrosis. Caseating and tuberculoid granuloma groups were significantly different in terms of geographical source, with more cases harboring caseating granulomas in Saudi Arabia (p<0.0001). Histologically, both groups differed in the distribution of their Ridley's pattern (RP), with a doubling RP3 in caseating granulomas (31% vs. 15%) and a doubling of RP5 in tuberculoma group (38% vs. 19%). The time needed to achieve healing (RP5) was shorter in the tuberculoid group (4.0 vs. 6.2 months). The study found no association between granuloma type and parasitic index, CL species, or other variables. The results suggest that CL should be considered part of the differential diagnosis for cases with caseating granulomas in endemic regions, particularly in areas where TB is also prevalent. The study also found that cases of CL with caseating granulomas showed a slower healing process, with no association with specific species, which may be due to a worse host immune response or more aggressive Leishmania strains.
Positional cloning of the zinc finger domain transcription factor Zfp69 has identified it as a candidate gene for the diabetogenic effect of the mouse QTL Nidd/SJL, which aggravates and accelerates obesity-associated diabetes in the NZO strain. A critical interval on distal chromosome 4 was identified by interval-specific congenic introgression of SJL into diabetes-resistant C57BL/6J mice, and subsequent reporter cross with NZO mice. Analysis of the 10 genes in the critical interval revealed a striking allelic variance of Zfp69, with a retrotransposon (IAPLTR1a) disrupting the gene in NZO and C57BL/6J mice, resulting in a truncated mRNA lacking the coding sequence for the KRAB and Znf-C2H2 domains. In contrast, the diabetogenic SJL, NON, and NZB alleles generated a normal mRNA. When combined with the B6.V-Lepob background, the diabetogenic Zfp69SJL allele produced hyperglycemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma and liver triglycerides. Furthermore, mRNA levels of the human orthologue of Zfp69, ZNF642, were significantly increased in adipose tissue from patients with type 2 diabetes. These findings suggest that Zfp69 is the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of Nidd/SJL, and that retrotransposon IAPLTR1a contributes substantially to the genetic heterogeneity of mouse strains. Expression of the transcription factor in adipose tissue may play a role in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.
The article proposes an integrated model of the regulatory network and signalling pathways controlling T helper (Th) cell differentiation. The model accounts for the core control of Th cell differentiation and is based on a logical formalism due to the qualitative nature of most available data. The authors use an original model reduction approach and a stable state identification algorithm to cope with the size and complexity of the resulting network. To assess the effects of heterogeneous environments on Th cell differentiation, the authors perform systematic simulations considering various prototypic environments. The model predicts the existence of stable states corresponding to canonical Th1, Th2, Th17, and Treg subtypes, as well as transient hybrid cell types that co-express combinations of Th1, Th2, Treg, and Th17 markers in an environment-dependent fashion. The logical analysis highlights the nature of these cell types and their relationships with canonical Th subtypes. The model can be used to explore novel differentiation pathways in silico. The authors note that previous models of Th cell differentiation assume cross-inhibiting master transcription factors to generate canonical Th subtypes, thereby precluding cell plasticity. In contrast, the proposed model allows for the prediction of alternative cell differentiation pathways arising from the concerted action of signalling pathways and transcriptional regulatory networks.
The study presents a thermodynamic model of transcription factor binding to investigate the mechanisms controlling genome-wide patterns of transcription factor binding during early Drosophila development. The model evaluates the contribution of different biophysical forces to the binding of five regulators of early embryonic anterior-posterior patterning in Drosophila melanogaster. Predictions based on DNA sequence and in vitro protein-DNA affinities alone achieve a correlation of ∼0. 4 with experimental measurements of in vivo binding. Incorporating cooperativity and competition among the five factors, and accounting for spatial patterning by modeling binding in every nucleus independently, has little effect on prediction accuracy. However, incorporating experimental measurements of genome-wide DNA accessibility into the model dramatically improves predictions to a correlation of 0. 6–0. 9 for various factors across known target genes. The results show that in regions of open chromatin, binding can be predicted almost exclusively by the sequence specificity of individual factors, with a minimal role for protein interactions. The study suggests that a combination of experimentally determined chromatin accessibility data and simple computational models of transcription factor binding may be used to predict the binding landscape of any animal transcription factor with significant precision. The model is applied to predict the genome-wide binding across 4, 251 genes for which gene expression data is available, and a strong relation is found between the model's ability to accurately predict the binding landscape of transcription factors and gene expression levels.
In Drosophila imaginal discs, the basic helix-loop helix ( bHLH ) transcription factors Daughterless ( Da ) and Extramacrochaetae ( Emc ) play a crucial role in regulating cell cycle progression. Specifically, Emc controls the G2/M transition and subsequent cell proliferation through the transcriptional regulation of the cdc25 phosphatase string. This regulatory activity is mediated by the interaction between Emc and Da, where Emc downregulates Da to trigger mitosis. The ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced levels of Emc or high levels of Da is sufficient to rescue the proliferative defects seen in these mutant cells. Furthermore, the data suggest that Da acts as a transcriptional repressor of string, indicating that Emc controls cell proliferation by regulating the activity of Da. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms underlying cell cycle regulation in Drosophila imaginal discs and highlight the importance of Emc and Da in controlling the balance between proliferation and differentiation. The study demonstrates that the interaction between Emc and Da is essential for regulating the G2/M transition and cell cycle progression in epithelial cells of the imaginal discs. This regulatory mechanism is conserved in eukaryotic cells and has implications for understanding the development processes that occur in both physiological and pathological conditions, such as cancer.
The study presents a comprehensive pipeline for systematic discovery of signaling networks in Saccharomyces cerevisiae using interventional phosphoproteome data. The pipeline combines phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, and causal relationship discovery to identify key proteins involved in specific pathways and infer signaling networks. To address the limitations of phosphoproteomics, such as sampling limitations and missing data, the authors propose a customized analysis pipeline that partially compensates for these issues. The dataset used for this study was generated using SILAC ( Stable Isotope Labeling with Amino acids in Cell culture ) technique with interventional experiments ( kinase-dead mutations ). The analysis identified 5 high-confidence proteins from meta-analysis and 19 hub proteins from correlation analysis, all of which are involved in stress responses. Nine of these proteins have direct or indirect evidence of involvement in filamentous growth. Four predicted proteins ( Nth1p, Pbi2p, Pdr12p, and Rcn2p ) were validated by interventional phenotypic experiments, showing differential invasive growth. The study demonstrates that interventional phosphoproteome studies can provide new insights into signaling pathways involved in biological processes such as yeast filamentous growth. The proposed pipeline can be applied to other interventional studies via different experimental platforms, suggesting candidate proteins for further investigation.
The regulation of the Drosophila X chromosome in the male germline has been a topic of interest in understanding the evolution of heteromorphic sex chromosomes. The study aimed to investigate how the X chromosome is regulated in the Drosophila melanogaster male germline, specifically examining dosage compensation and meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI). The results show that X chromosome-wide dosage compensation appears to be absent from most of the Drosophila male germline, contradicting previous reports. Additionally, microarray analysis found no evidence for X chromosome-specific inactivation during meiosis. The study also confirmed that the expression of transgene reporters driven by autosomal spermatogenesis-specific promoters is strongly reduced when inserted on the X chromosome versus the autosomes, but this difference in expression is established in premeiotic cells and persists in meiotic cells. The magnitude of the X-autosome difference in transgene expression cannot be explained by the absence of dosage compensation, suggesting a previously unrecognized mechanism limits expression from the X during spermatogenesis in Drosophila. These findings resolve several previously conflicting reports and have implications for patterns of genome evolution and speciation in Drosophila. Overall, the study provides new insights into the regulation of the Drosophila X chromosome in the male germline and highlights the complexity of sex chromosome regulation in this species.
The study investigates the early stages of Citrobacter rodentium infection in mice, a model for human enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) infections. The research reveals that the development of colonic C. rodentium attachment and effacement (A/E) lesions, which determine the severity of infection, is critically dependent on early bacteria-host interactions. These lesions originate from a limited number of single-bacterial epithelial infection events that occur within the first 18 hours of infection. The study shows that the initiation of colonic C. rodentium microcolonies is restricted to an early stage of infection, and these early-established, clonally-renewing A/E lesions trigger a local innate immune response that protects the epithelium from de novo A/E lesion formation by luminal bacteria. This innate immune response is mediated by TLR-MyD88/Trif-dependent signaling and is induced specifically by virulent C. rodentium in a virulence gene-dependent manner. The study demonstrates that the establishment phase of C. rodentium pathogenesis in vivo is restricted to a very short window of opportunity that determines both disease geography and severity. The findings suggest that colonic A/E lesions depend on local cell-to-cell spread and not continuous re-seeding from planktonic luminal colonizers, and that the epithelium-adherent population of C. rodentium is derived from a very small founder population, subject to a population bottleneck.
The article presents a Bayesian method for estimating the overlap between two populations of fixed size from incomplete samples. The method takes into account the rates of subsampling and produces unbiased and Bayes-optimal estimates of overlap. It also provides a framework for computing the uncertainty of its estimates and can be used prospectively in study planning to quantify the tradeoff between sampling effort and uncertainty. The method is particularly relevant in the ecology and genomic epidemiology of malaria, where it can be used to estimate the overlap between Plasmodium falciparum parasites. The approach is based on Bayesian inference and assumes that the total number of objects, species, or genes in each population is known. This is a special case of the more general β-diversity problem. The method is contrasted with existing non-probabilistic indices, coefficients, and metrics, which implicitly treat species counts as complete and lead to bias. The article presents a validation of the method and discusses its potential applications, including the analysis of multigene antigen families in Plasmodium spp. and general studies of β-diversity in multigene families. The method can be improved by incorporating larger whole-genome datasets as prior information over the distribution of repertoire sizes.
The active state mechanics of eukaryotic protein kinases are regulated by a set of highly conserved electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions. Using cAMP-dependent protein kinase as a model, researchers have identified a salt bridge between a lysine from the β3-strand and a glutamate from the αC-helix, as well as an electrostatic interaction between the phosphorylated activation loop and αC-helix and an ensemble of hydrophobic residues of the Regulatory spine and Shell. These interactions are essential for the active state mechanics, but surprisingly, the highly conserved lysine residue in the β3-strand is not required for phosphoryl transfer. Instead, it acts as a structural ATP sensor that facilitates the active state mechanics by coordinating the transition of the β-sheet region of the N-lobe and linking it with the αC-helix. The researchers used biochemical, biophysical, and computational techniques to study the interactions and found that the absence of the salt bridge and electrostatic interaction between the activation loop and αC-helix can be compensated by the R-spine and Shell through hydrophobic interactions. They also showed that repositioning the positive lysine onto the G-loop can rescue the catalytic activity. These findings provide new insights into the regulation of the active state mechanics of eukaryotic protein kinases and highlight the importance of electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions in this process.
American Samoa conducted seven rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) for lymphatic filariasis (LF) from 2000-2006 under the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis. To assess the effectiveness of post-MDA surveillance, two survey designs were compared: a school-based survey of children aged 6-7 years and a community-based survey targeting individuals aged ≥8 years. In 2016, a systematic school-based Transmission Assessment Survey (TAS) was conducted in 29 elementary schools, and a cluster survey was conducted in 28 villages on the two main islands. Blood samples were collected to test for circulating filarial antigen (CFA) using the Alere Filariasis Test Strip. The school-based TAS identified nine antigen-positive children, with an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 0.7% (95% CI: 0.3-1.8). In contrast, the community-based survey identified 102 antigen-positive people, with an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 6.2% (95% CI: 4.5-8.6). The community-based survey also found that CFA prevalence increased with age and was higher in males. The school-based TAS had limited sensitivity and negative predictive value but high specificity and positive predictive value for identifying villages with ongoing transmission. The community-based survey was more effective in identifying antigen-positive individuals of all ages and foci of high antigen prevalence.
