Both surveys confirmed recrudescence of LF transmission in American Samoa 10 years after the last round of MDA.
In zebrafish, sex determination is a complex process influenced by multiple genetic and environmental factors. Recent studies have shown that oocytes play a crucial role in maintaining the female sex phenotype in adult zebrafish, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. This study investigated the role of two oocyte-produced signaling molecules, Bmp15 and Gdf9, in female sex determination and maintenance in zebrafish. The researchers generated targeted mutations in the genes encoding Bmp15 and Gdf9 and found that females deficient in Bmp15 undergo sex reversal during the mid- to late-juvenile stage and develop as fertile males. In contrast, females deficient in Gdf9 did not exhibit sex reversal. The study also showed that estrogen production is necessary for female development and that Bmp15 likely regulates estrogen biosynthesis by promoting the development of estrogen-producing granulosa cells in the oocyte follicle. The researchers propose a model in which the oocyte-somatic gonad interaction stabilizes cyp19a1a expression and estrogen production in the somatic gonad, thereby maintaining the female sex phenotype. This study provides the first mechanistic insights into how oocytes regulate the maintenance of sex in zebrafish and identifies Bmp15 as a key player in this process. The findings have implications for our understanding of sex determination and maintenance in other fish species.
Hox proteins play a crucial role in controlling morphogenetic diversity along the anterior-posterior body axis of animals by regulating target genes in a highly localized manner. To achieve this high-regulatory specificity, Hox proteins are thought to co-operate with other transcription factors to activate or repress their target genes in a context-specific manner. However, only a few of these factors have been identified. This study investigates the regulation of the cell death gene reaper ( rpr ) by the Hox protein Deformed ( Dfd ) in Drosophila. The results show that Dfd requires at least eight functionally diverse transcriptional regulators to properly regulate rpr expression in the anterior part of the maxillary segment. These regulators include Apt, Gcm, Ems, En, Slp1, Brk, Doc1, and Disco. The study suggests that context-dependent combinations of Hox proteins and other transcription factors on small, modular Hox response elements ( HREs ) are responsible for the proper spatio-temporal expression of Hox targets. This implies that a large number of transcription factors are directly involved in Hox target gene regulation in vivo. The findings support the idea that Hox target gene regulation involves complex formation between Hox proteins and assisting co-regulatory factors, and that the ability of a broadly expressed Hox protein to regulate a target gene in a proper spatial and temporal context is achieved by the Hox-independent recruitment of context-specific transcription factors to cis-regulatory sequences present in compact HREs.
The study investigated the genetic requirements for signaling from an autoactive plant NB-LRR intracellular innate immune receptor, ADR1-L2. ADR1-L2 is a coiled-coil (CC)-NB-LRR protein that functions upstream of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation in several defense contexts. The protein can act as a "helper" to transduce specific microbial activation signals from "sensor" NB-LRRs. The study generated an autoactive missense mutation, ADR1-L2D484V, in a small homology motif termed MHD. Expression of ADR1-L2D484V leads to dwarfed plants with increased disease resistance and constitutively high SA levels. The morphological phenotype also requires an intact P-loop, suggesting that these ADR1-L2D484V phenotypes reflect canonical activation of this NB-LRR protein. Signaling from ADR1-L2D484V does not require NADPH oxidase and is negatively regulated by EDS1 and AtMC1. Transcriptional regulation of ADR1-L2D484V is correlated with its phenotypic outputs, which are both SA-dependent and -independent. The genetic requirements for ADR1-L2D484V activity resemble those that regulate an SA-gradient-dependent signal amplification of defense and cell death signaling initially observed in the absence of LSD1. Importantly, ADR1-L2D484V autoactivation signaling is controlled by both EDS1 and SA in separable, but linked pathways. The study proposes a genetic model that provides insight into an SA-dependent feedback regulation loop, which includes ADR1-L2.
The RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) pathway plays a crucial role in transcriptional silencing in Arabidopsis. Recent studies have shown that the SU(VAR)3-9 homolog SUVH9 and the double-stranded RNA-binding protein IDN2 are components of the RdDM pathway. However, the mechanism by which SUVH9 interacts with MORC6, a protein that mediates transcriptional silencing, remains unclear. This study investigates the relationship between SUVH9, IDN2, and MORC6 in transcriptional silencing. The results show that SUVH2 and SUVH9 can act in the same pathway as MORC6 or synergistically with MORC6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. IDN2 also interacts with MORC6 and mediates the silencing of a subset of MORC6 target loci. Furthermore, other RdDM components, including Pol IV, Pol V, RDR2, and DRM2, are required for transcriptional silencing at a subset of MORC6 target loci. The study also demonstrates that the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex components SWI3B, SWI3C, and SWI3D interact with MORC6 and SUVH9, and mediate transcriptional silencing. These findings suggest that the RdDM components are involved not only in DNA methylation but also in MORC6-mediated heterochromatin condensation, which enhances transcriptional silencing at methylated genomic regions. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms of transcriptional silencing in Arabidopsis and highlights the importance of the RdDM pathway in regulating gene expression.
This study investigated the role of heat shock protein 90 ( Hsp90 ) in vertebrate development using zebrafish as a model organism. Hsp90 is a molecular chaperone that plays a crucial role in protein folding and stability, and its function has been shown to buffer genetic variation in Drosophila and plants. The researchers found that partial inhibition of Hsp90 function in zebrafish revealed previously unobserved developmental anomalies, including severe structural eye malformations reminiscent of anophthalmia, microphthalmia, and nanophthalmia complex in humans. In contrast to Drosophila, Hsp90 inhibition in zebrafish decreased developmental stability, as indicated by increased asymmetric presentation of anophthalmia, microphthalmia, and nanophthalmia and sunrise phenotypes. The study also showed that inbreeding of offspring from selected unaffected carrier parents led to significantly elevated malformation frequencies and revealed the oligogenic nature of this phenotype. Analysis of the sunrise pax6b mutation suggests a molecular mechanism for the buffering of mutations by Hsp90. The results imply that mild perturbation of Hsp90 function at critical developmental stages may underpin the variable penetrance and expressivity of many developmental anomalies where the interaction between genotype and environment plays a major role. The study highlights the importance of understanding the molecular events that can alter the balance between cryptic and overt phenotypes.
The study identifies and functionally characterizes N-terminally acetylated proteins in Drosophila melanogaster. Amino-terminal acetylation is a common protein modification found throughout the tree of life, where the N-terminus of a nascent polypeptide chain becomes co-translationally acetylated after the removal of the initiating methionine residue. The researchers analyzed amino-terminal peptides from proteins extracted from Drosophila Kc167 cells and detected over 1,200 mature protein N-termini. They found that N-terminal acetylation occurs in insects with a similar frequency as in humans. The study proposes the (X)PX rule, which indicates the prevention of acetylation under all circumstances, as the sole true determinant for N-terminal acetylation. This rule can be used to genetically engineer a protein to study the biological relevance of the presence or absence of an acetyl group. The researchers applied the assay by expressing mutated proteins as transgenes in cell lines and in flies, demonstrating a straightforward strategy to systematically study the functional relevance of N-terminal acetylations in cells and whole organisms. The (X)PX rule is proposed to be of general validity in lower and higher eukaryotes, suggesting its applicability to study the function of N-terminal acetylation in all species. The study provides a comprehensive compilation of mature protein N-termini from Drosophila melanogaster, showing that N-terminal acetylation follows the same rules as in other eukaryotes and occurs with a lower frequency than in humans but at a higher frequency than in yeast.
RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) plays a crucial role in producing abundant tRNA molecules during cellular proliferation, development, and cancer. However, the mechanisms of RNAP III termination and its link to high transcription output are not fully understood. To investigate this, researchers used two tRNA-mediated suppression systems to screen for RNAP III mutants with gain- and loss-of-termination phenotypes in Schizosaccharomyces pombe. A total of 122 point mutations were identified and mapped to a 3.9 Å structure of yeast RNAP III elongation complex. The mutations cluster in the active center bridge helix and trigger loop, as well as the pore and funnel, indicating the involvement of the RNA cleavage domain of the C11 subunit in termination. Purified RNAP III from a readthrough mutant exhibited increased elongation rate, supporting a kinetic coupling model where elongation rate is inversely related to termination efficiency. The mutants showed good correlations between terminator readthrough in vitro and in vivo, and surprisingly, amounts of transcription in vivo. The results suggest that the mobile elements of the RNAP III active center, including C11, are key determinants of termination, and that some mutations activate RNAP III for overall transcription. These findings have implications for understanding RNAP III activation in disease, as similar mutations have been observed in spontaneous cancer.
Researchers have developed a method to predict protein-protein interactions mediated by SH2 domains using the structure of SH2-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm. This approach was shown to perform similarly to experimentally derived consensus sequences and substitution matrices in predicting known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH2 domains. The method was used to provide a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH2 domains with known structure, filtered on secondary structure and phosphorylation state. The predictions were validated using literature-derived SH2 interactions and a probabilistic score obtained from a naive Bayes integration of information on coexpression, conservation of the interaction in other species, shared interaction partners, and functions. The predictions led to a new hypothesis for the role of SH2 domains in signaling. The FoldX algorithm was also shown to predict the in vitro binding thermodynamics of protein-phosphopeptide complexes for nine different SH2 domains, demonstrating its applicability for genome-wide predictions. The results suggest that the FoldX algorithm is a useful alternative to peptide library experiments for the prediction of SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions. The portability of this method to other SH2 domains remains to be shown, and future prediction methods should account for both the biophysics and biology of SH2 domains. A set of predicted in vivo protein-protein interactions for nine SH2 domain-containing proteins was annotated with supporting information, providing a resource for further experimental testing.
Human cyclophilin 40 (CyP40), a cis/trans peptidyl-prolyl isomerase (PPIase), has been identified as a potential therapeutic agent for neurodegenerative disorders characterized by the accumulation of amyloidogenic proteins. The study demonstrates that CyP40 dissolves tau amyloids in vitro and reduces tau oligomers and tangles in a mouse model of tau accumulation, preserving neuronal health and cognition. Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy revealed that CyP40 interacts with tau at sites rich in proline residues. Furthermore, CyP40 was able to interact with and disaggregate other aggregating proteins that contain prolines. The PPIase activity of CyP40 is essential for its disaggregation activity, as a CyP40 variant lacking PPIase activity was unable to disaggregate amyloids in vitro. The study also describes a unique structural property of CyP40 that may permit disaggregation to occur in an energy-independent manner. The results suggest that strategies to induce or deliver CyP40 to the central nervous system could potentially halt or rescue cognitive deficits associated with neurotoxic amyloids. The study identifies CyP40 as a novel human protein disaggregase and demonstrates its capacity to dissolve intracellular amyloids. The findings have implications for the development of therapeutic interventions for tauopathies and other amyloidogenic disorders.
The article presents an integrative approach for modeling and simulating heterocyst pattern formation in cyanobacteria filaments using systems biology. Heterocyst differentiation in cyanobacteria is a simple example of cellular differentiation and pattern formation in multicellular organisms. Despite experimental studies on the evolution and sustainment of heterocyst patterns and the genetic circuit underlying single cyanobacterium behavior under nitrogen deprivation, there is a theoretical gap connecting these processes. To address this issue, the authors formulate the genetic circuit of a single cyanobacterium into a set of differential equations describing the time evolution of molecular product concentrations. This allows them to study the behavior of a single cyanobacterium under different external conditions and simulate the dynamics of cyanobacteria filaments by coupling their genetic circuits via molecular diffusion. The results show that including diffusion and noisy external conditions in the computational model can reproduce the main features of heterocyst pattern formation and sustainment in cyanobacteria filaments as observed experimentally. The model connects the diffusion of combined nitrogen along the filament with the dynamical properties of the underlying genetic circuit of each single cyanobacterium, capturing both the development and maintenance of heterocyst patterns. The study demonstrates that noise plays an important role in the onset of differentiation, enabling the development of characteristic heterocyst patterns for a wide range of model parameters. This reveals that cyanobacteria filaments have developed an efficient response to noisy environmental conditions.
The Community Directed Treatment with Ivermectin (CDTI) program has been implemented in Cameroon for over 15 years to combat onchocerciasis, a disease causing debilitating eye and skin lesions with significant psychosocial and economic impacts. Despite this effort, onchocerciasis prevalence remains above the non-transmission threshold in many areas. A cross-sectional survey was conducted in three Cameroonian health districts to investigate the association between people's perceptions of the CDTI program, their beliefs about onchocerciasis, and their adherence to ivermectin treatment. The study found that adherence to ivermectin was comparable in two districts, Bafang and Bafia, but lower in Yabassi. Perceptions of the CDTI program, particularly the commitment of community drug distributors and the organization of ivermectin distribution campaigns, were strongly associated with adherence to ivermectin. In contrast, misconceptions about onchocerciasis transmission, such as the belief that onchocerciasis is caused by poor hygiene or high sugar intake, were not strongly associated with adherence. The study highlights the importance of addressing community perceptions and misconceptions about the CDTI program and onchocerciasis transmission in order to improve adherence to ivermectin treatment. Local health authorities are recommended to involve communities more in the implementation of the CDTI program and to emphasize the effectiveness of ivermectin in addition to education and sensitization on onchocerciasis.
The study investigated the relative contribution of DNA methylation and genetic variants on protein biomarkers for human diseases such as cancer, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease. A total of 121 protein biomarkers were analyzed in relation to DNA methylation at 470,000 genomic positions and over 10 million SNPs. Epigenome-wide association study (EWAS) and genome-wide association study (GWAS) analyses were performed on between 698 and 1033 samples, depending on data availability. The results identified 124 and 45 loci with significant associations between DNA methylation and protein biomarkers, and between SNPs and protein biomarkers, respectively. Most GWAS loci were cis-regulatory, whereas most EWAS loci were located in trans. Eleven EWAS loci were associated with multiple biomarkers, including one in NLRC5 associated with CXCL11, CXCL9, IL-12, and IL-18 levels. However, all EWAS signals that overlapped with a GWAS locus were driven by underlying genetic variants, and three EWAS signals were confounded by smoking. The study found that cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers appeared to have an effect on DNA methylation levels, but not vice versa. The results suggest that DNA methylation has a limited direct effect on biomarkers of complex diseases, and instead reflects the underlying pattern of genetic variants, specific environmental exposures, or represents secondary effects of the pathogenesis of disease.
The study reveals that varicella zoster virus (VZV) potently impairs the ability of natural killer (NK) cells to respond to target cell stimulation in vitro, leading to a loss of both cytotoxic and cytokine responses. This impairment is not limited to VZV-infected NK cells, but also affects VZV antigen-negative NK cells that are exposed to the virus in culture. The study demonstrates that direct contact between NK cells and VZV-infected inoculum cells is required for this effect. Profiling of the NK cell surface receptor phenotype shows that functional receptor expression is predominantly stable, and inhibited NK cells are still capable of releasing cytotoxic granules when the stimulation signal bypasses receptor/ligand interactions and early signaling. However, VZV co-culture leads to perturbation of the degranulation signaling cascade and repression of interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF) production. The study also shows that herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1), a closely related virus, exhibits a similar capacity to infect NK cells and render them unresponsive to target cell stimulation, although it differentially targets cytokine production compared to VZV. These findings contribute to a growing understanding of pathogen inhibition of NK cell function and reveal a previously unreported strategy employed by VZV to manipulate the immune response.
Apparent motion (AM) is a phenomenon where two stimuli alternately presented at different locations can evoke a percept of a stimulus continuously moving between the two locations. The neural mechanism underlying AM is thought to involve increased activation of primary visual cortex (V1) neurons tuned to locations along the AM path. However, evidence for this remains inconclusive. AM masking, which refers to the reduced detectability of stimuli along the AM path, has been taken as evidence for AM-related V1 activation. However, this can also be explained by predictive coding models, which predict that responses to stimuli presented on the AM path are suppressed when they match the spatio-temporal prediction of a stimulus moving along the path. The present study investigated the effect of AM on the detection of target gratings presented along the AM path. The results show that AM impairs the detection of a target presented on the AM path when the target's orientation matches the inducers' orientation. A population code model of early visual processing, based on a standard contrast normalization model, was developed to explain the findings. The model predicts strong suppression of early sensory responses during AM, consistent with the theoretical framework of predictive coding. The results suggest that AM-related activation in early visual cortex is too small to cause masking or be perceived as motion, and that orientation-tuned suppression of responses in early visual cortex is the major cause of AM masking. This suppression may be explained by predictive coding models of cortical processing, proposing that higher-level predictions of motion are generated, which "explain away" lower-level responses to expected sensory input.
The HTLV-1 oncoprotein Tax plays a crucial role in CD4+ T cell transformation by activating the NF-κB pathway and inducing NF-κB target genes. To elucidate the molecular mechanism of Tax-induced IKK activation, researchers reconstituted Tax-stimulated IKK activation in a cell-free system to dissect the essential cellular components for primary IKK activation by Tax. The study revealed that Tax functions as a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, catalyzing the assembly of free mixed-linkage polyubiquitin chains with the help of UbcH2, UhcH5c, or UbcH7. These free polyubiquitin chains directly activate IKK by binding to the NEMO subunit of IKK. This biochemical function of Tax clarifies the confusion surrounding HTLV-1-induced IKK-NF-κB activation and identifies the essential cellular factors hijacked by HTLV-1. The study provides new insights into the molecular mechanism of Tax-induced IKK activation, which utilizes minimal cellular ubiquitination components for NF-κB activation. The findings have significant implications for understanding HTLV-1-mediated transformation and may shed light on the development of therapeutics for adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL) and tropical spastic paraparesis/HTLV-1-associated myelopathy (TSP/HAM).
The relationship between the number of individuals introduced to found a population (propagule pressure) and the establishment success of alien species has been investigated in a systematic and quantitative review using Bayesian meta-analytical methods. The study found a positive mean effect of propagule pressure on establishment success across a broad range of taxa and life histories, including invertebrates, herbaceous plants, long-lived trees, and terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates. However, establishment success was most critically dependent on propagule pressures in the range of 10-100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect size was associated primarily with different analytical approaches, with some evidence of larger effect sizes in animal rather than plant introductions. In contrast, no variation was accounted for in any analysis by the scale of study (field to global) or methodology (observational, experimental, or proxy) used. The results reveal remarkable consistency in the form of the relationship between propagule pressure and alien population establishment success. The study highlights the importance of propagule pressure as a determinant of establishment success and provides insights into the factors influencing the strength and shape of this relationship.
Interleukin 17A (IL-17), a cytokine involved in chronic and severe inflammatory diseases, has been shown to enhance the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the degradation of encoding mRNAs. The degradation of these mRNAs depends on proteins (AUBPs) that target AU-rich elements in the 3′-untranslated region of mRNAs and facilitate either mRNA decay or stabilization. A novel ribonucleoprotein complex is formed between AUBPs and the target mRNA in the presence of microRNA16 (miR16), leading to the degradation of the target mRNA. However, IL-17 attenuates miR16 expression and promotes the binding of stabilizing AUBPs over destabilizing AUBPs, resulting in reduced mRNA decay. This indicates that miR16, independent of a seed sequence, directs the competition between degrading and stabilizing AUBPs for target mRNAs. The interactions between AUBPs, miR16, and the target mRNA depend on specific RNA sequences and structural restraints. IL-17 exerts its function by changing the contribution of miR16 and AUBPs. The findings suggest that modulation of AUBP-miR16 mediated regulation of gene expression by IL-17 depends on the specific mRNA target, limiting miR16 usage and differential participation of the AUBPs. IL-17 may affect many other cellular processes, given that AUBPs affect expression of about 8% of the human transcriptome and miR16 is ubiquitously expressed.
The study investigated the association between bovine and human trypanosomiasis in newly affected sleeping sickness areas of Uganda. The research was conducted in Kaberamaido and Dokolo Districts, where the acute zoonotic form of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) has been spreading rapidly. Cattle act as long-term reservoirs of human-infective Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, showing few signs of morbidity but posing a significant risk to human health. The study examined the relationship between human T. b. rhodesiense infection and human-infective and non-human T. brucei s.l. circulating in cattle at the village level. The results showed that the sleeping sickness status of a village had a significant effect on the likelihood of T. brucei s.l. infection in cattle, with higher odds of infection in case villages compared to non-case villages. Additionally, cattle age was found to be a significant factor, with cattle between 18-36 months and over 36 months having significantly higher odds of T. brucei s.l. infection than those under 18 months of age. The study also found a significant association between village human sleeping sickness status and the detection of T. b. rhodesiense in village cattle, with a higher likelihood of detection in case villages. The findings suggest that a high village-level prevalence of T. brucei s.l. is associated with a higher likelihood of detecting T. b. rhodesiense in a herd, providing a useful means of determining risk at the village or parish level in endemic districts in Uganda.
The NSL complex, which contains the histone H4 lysine 16-specific acetyltransferase MOF, plays a crucial role in regulating housekeeping genes in Drosophila. A comprehensive ChIP-seq analysis of four NSL complex members (NSL1, NSL3, MBD-R2, and MCRS2) across the Drosophila melanogaster genome revealed that the majority (85.5%) of NSL-bound genes are constitutively expressed across different cell types. These genes are characterized by increased abundance of histone modifications H4K16ac, H3K4me2, H3K4me3, and H3K9ac in gene promoter regions, as well as a well-defined nucleosome-free region and broad transcription initiation patterns. Furthermore, ChIP-seq analyses of RNA polymerase II (Pol II) in NSL1- and NSL3-depleted cells demonstrated that both NSL proteins are required for efficient recruitment of Pol II to NSL target gene promoters. The observed Pol II reduction coincides with compromised binding of TBP and TFIIB to target promoters, indicating that the NSL complex is required for optimal recruitment of the pre-initiation complex on target genes. Genes that undergo the most dramatic loss of Pol II upon NSL knockdowns tend to be enriched in DNA Replication-related Element (DRE). The NSL complex preferentially targets genes that are constitutively expressed, also referred to as housekeeping genes, and exhibits elevated levels of H3K4me2/3, H3K9ac, and H4K16ac, as well as a distinctive arrangement of the nucleosome-free region and dispersed transcription initiation patterns.
Researchers have developed a transgenic mouse model to study facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FSHD), a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4Z4 macrosatellite repeats and ectopic expression of DUX4, a germline transcription factor. The model consists of two transgenic mouse lines: one carrying a D4Z4 genomic region from a contracted pathogenic FSHD1 allele and one carrying a normal-sized, non-pathogenic allele. The results show that somatic epigenetic silencing of DUX4 is an evolutionarily conserved mechanism, and contracted D4Z4 repeat arrays are silenced less efficiently, leading to a variegated expression pattern of DUX4 protein in skeletal muscle nuclei. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) and DNA methylation analyses indicate a relative chromatin relaxation of the D4Z4 repeats in mice carrying the contracted allele compared to those carrying the normal-sized allele. This is consistent with the observed DUX4 expression pattern, accurately modeling the difference between FSHD patients and control individuals. The transgenic mice recapitulate important epigenetic and DUX4 expression attributes seen in patients and controls, including high DUX4 expression levels in the germline, incomplete epigenetic repression in somatic tissue, and FSHD-specific variegated DUX4 expression in sporadic muscle nuclei associated with D4Z4 chromatin relaxation. These mice represent a valuable animal model for FSHD and will be useful for studying the molecular mechanisms underlying the disease and testing new therapeutic intervention strategies.
Malaria vaccine candidate Apical Membrane Antigen-1 (AMA1) has been shown to induce protection, but only against parasite strains closely related to the vaccine. To overcome this limitation, researchers developed a vaccine containing four diverse allelic proteins (AMA1 Quadvax or QV), which elicited polyclonal rabbit antibodies that inhibited the invasion of four vaccine and 22 non-vaccine strains of Plasmodium falciparum. Compared to a strain-specific, monovalent, 3D7 AMA1 vaccine, QV induced higher levels of broadly inhibitory antibodies associated with increased conserved face and domain-3 responses and reduced domain-2 response. Inhibitory monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) raised against QV reacted with a novel cross-reactive epitope at the rim of the hydrophobic trough on domain-1, which mapped to the conserved face of AMA1 and encompassed the 1e-loop. These mAbs were ∼10-fold more potent than previously characterized AMA1-inhibitory mAbs and inhibited AMA1 binding to its ligand RON2. Another novel mAb, 1E10, which bound to domain-3, was broadly inhibitory and blocked the proteolytic processing of AMA1. These findings suggest that vaccination with a few diverse antigenic proteins could provide universal coverage by redirecting the immune response towards conserved epitopes. The identification of novel inhibition susceptible regions and epitopes can form the basis for improving the antigenic breadth and inhibitory response of AMA1 vaccines.
The displacement of the mitotic spindle to one side of a cell is crucial for many cells to divide unequally. A conserved mitotic progression mechanism, involving the anaphase-promoting complex ( APC ), its activator Cdc20/Fizzy, its degradation target cyclin, and cyclin-dependent kinase ( CDK ), has been identified as a timer for spindle displacement in the Caenorhabditis elegans zygote. Mitotic spindle displacement begins at a precise time, soon after chromosomes congress to the metaphase plate. Reducing the function of the proteasome, the APC, or Cdc20/Fizzy delays spindle displacement, while inactivating CDK in prometaphase causes the spindle to displace early. The consequence of experimentally unlinking spindle displacement from this timing mechanism is the premature displacement of incompletely assembled components of the mitotic spindle. This study demonstrates that the timing of spindle displacement is precisely regulated in the C. elegans zygote and that the proteasome and the APC time spindle displacement primarily through their roles in inactivating CDK. The results suggest that negative regulation of CDK activity by the proteasome, FZY-1, and the APC serves as a previously unrecognized timer for mitotic spindle displacement. This regulation of spindle displacement by CDK activity results in an approximately 60–90-s delay in spindle displacement, allowing spindle assembly to complete before cortical forces pull the spindle away from the center of the cell. This study provides the first demonstration that mitotic progression times spindle displacement in the asymmetric division of an animal cell.
A genome scan was conducted to identify genes showing evidence of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia in Tibetan and Andean populations. High-altitude hypoxia poses severe physiological stress on the human body, and populations living in high-altitude regions such as the Tibetan Plateau and the Andean Altiplano have developed unique circulatory, respiratory, and hematological adaptations. Although the physiological responses to high-altitude hypoxia have been well characterized, the underlying genetic basis remains unknown. The study used four population genetic statistics to detect signatures of natural selection and identified selection-nominated candidate genes and gene regions in the Tibetan and Andean populations separately. The results showed that the Tibetan and Andean patterns of genetic adaptation are largely distinct from one another, with both populations showing evidence of positive natural selection in different genes or gene regions. One gene, EGLN1 ( also known as PHD2 ), previously known to be important in cellular oxygen sensing, shows evidence of positive selection in both Tibetans and Andeans, but with differing patterns of variation between the two populations. The study suggests that several key HIF-regulatory and targeted genes are responsible for adaptation to high altitude in Andeans and Tibetans, and several different chromosomal regions are implicated in the putative response to selection. These findings provide a basis for future genotype-phenotype association studies to confirm the role of selection-nominated candidate genes and gene regions in adaptation to altitude.
Inverted DNA repeats (IRs) near a double-strand DNA break (DSB) can alter the repair pathway from accurate gene conversion to break-induced replication (BIR), leading to genetic instability. IRs can form unusual DNA structures when present in single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) formed by DSB resection. The type of structure formed depends on the length of the spacer separating the IRs: long (1-kb) spacers lead to inter-molecular single-strand annealing (SSA) and the formation of inverted dimers, while short (12-bp) spacers result in intra-molecular SSA and fold-back (FB) structures. Both types of structures interfere with accurate DSB repair by gene conversion and channel repair into BIR, promoting genomic destabilization. The processing of FBs containing short versus long ssDNA loops involves different protein complexes: MRX-Sae2 for short loops and Rad1-Rad10 for long loops. The presence of IRs near a DSB promotes BIR and decreases the frequency of gene conversion, leading to chromosomal rearrangements. This study highlights the mechanisms of genomic destabilization resulting from re-routing DSB repair into unusual pathways by IRs, which are abundant in the human genome. The findings may contribute to understanding IR-mediated genomic destabilization associated with human disease. The choice of DSB repair pathway is critical for maintaining genomic integrity, as some pathways result in mutations and chromosomal rearrangements, while others do not.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause both acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts. Chronic P. aeruginosa infections are thought to be caused by bacterial biofilms, which are highly structured, multicellular communities encased in an extracellular matrix that enable long-term survival in the host. To study P. aeruginosa biofilm infections in vivo, researchers developed an animal model using Drosophila melanogaster as the host. In this model, P. aeruginosa biofilms localized to and were visualized in dissected Drosophila crops at 24 hours post-infection. The biofilms had a characteristic aggregate structure and an extracellular matrix composed of DNA and exopolysaccharide. P. aeruginosa cells recovered from in vivo grown biofilms had increased antibiotic resistance relative to planktonically grown cells. Biofilm formation was dependent on the expression of the pel exopolysaccharide genes, as a pelB::lux mutant failed to form biofilms. The pelB::lux mutant was more virulent than PAO1, while a hyperbiofilm strain ( PAZHI3 ) demonstrated less virulence than PAO1. Biofilm formation by strains PAO1 and PAZHI3 in the crop was associated with the induction of diptericin, cecropin A1, and drosomycin antimicrobial peptide gene expression 24 hours post-infection. In contrast, infection with the non-biofilm forming strain pelB::lux resulted in decreased AMP gene expression in the fly. These results provide novel insights into host-pathogen interactions during P. aeruginosa oral infection of Drosophila and highlight the use of Drosophila as an infection model for studying P. aeruginosa biofilms in vivo.
The vasopressin receptor 1a gene (Avpr1a) plays a crucial role in mediating vasopressin-mediated social behaviors and exhibits striking differences in neural expression patterns between species. The genomic mechanisms contributing to these differences are not well understood. This study used homologous recombination in mice to investigate the relative contribution of the proximal 5′ flanking sequence and microsatellite variation to Avpr1a gene expression and behavior. The results show that the proximal 5′ flanking sequence makes a modest contribution to species differences in vasopressin 1a receptor (V1aR) distribution, and that variation in V1aR distribution impacts stress-coping behavior in the forced swim test. Additionally, the study found that the vole Avpr1a microsatellite structure contributes to Avpr1a expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring a subset of the inter- and intra-species differences observed in central V1aR patterns in voles. This is the first direct evidence that polymorphic microsatellite elements near behaviorally relevant genes can contribute to diversity in brain gene expression profiles. However, the results suggest that many features of species-specific expression patterns are mediated by elements outside of the immediate 5′ flanking region of the gene. The study demonstrates that the vole Avpr1a is an ideal model locus for exploring the genomic mechanisms contributing to diversity in brain gene expression and behavior.
Activation-Induced Cytidine Deaminase (AID) induces double-strand breaks (DSBs) at immunoglobulin switch (S) regions and the c-MYC oncogene in yeast THO mutants, which are impaired in messenger RNA (mRNP) biogenesis. AID-mediated deamination of cytosines at S sequences in yeast is channeled by the Ung1 activity into DSBs, similar to mammalian B cells, which are then repaired by Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ). The c-MYC oncogene, sharing features with S sequences, acts as a hotspot of recombination in yeast THO mutants. This study demonstrates that AID acts in yeast at heterologous S and c-MYC transcribed sequences, leading to DSBs that cause chromosomal translocations via NHEJ. AID-induced translocations are strongly enhanced in yeast THO null mutants, consistent with the idea that AID-mediated DSBs depend on R-loop formation. The study provides new insights into the role of mRNP biogenesis in preventing genome rearrangements and the mechanism of AID-mediated genome instability. It also shows that yeast cells, like mammalian B cells, have the factors and pathways required to channel AID-mediated DNA lesions into DSBs responsible for NHEJ-dependent genome rearrangements and Class Switch Recombination (CSR). A model yeast system has been developed to study the molecular mechanisms mediated by AID leading to DSBs at S regions and the c-MYC oncogene, opening new perspectives in understanding AID-mediated rearrangements.
During asymmetric cell division in Escherichia coli, the coordination between cell division and chromosome replication is crucial for producing viable progeny. However, cells lacking proper positioning of their cell division planes can still successfully propagate. This study investigated how these cells partition their chromosomes into daughters during asymmetric divisions. Using quantitative time-lapse imaging, the authors found that DNA translocase, FtsK, can pump up to 80% of the chromosome ( 3. 7 Mb ) between daughters at an average rate of 1700±800 bp/s. Pauses in DNA translocation were rare, and no reversals were observed at experimental time scales of a few minutes. The majority of DNA movement occurred at the latest stages of cell division when the cell division protein ZipA had already dissociated from the septum, and the septum had closed to a narrow channel with a diameter much smaller than the resolution limit of the microscope ( ~250 nm ). The authors suggest that the narrow constriction is necessary for effective translocation of DNA by FtsK. This study demonstrates that E. coli cells are capable of repositioning their chromosomes when their cell division plane is not properly localized. The results also imply that DNA located within the constriction realizes a cell-cycle checkpoint that prevents daughters from separating from each other.
The article presents a mathematical framework based on integer linear programming (ILP) for the selection of an optimal set of peptides for epitope-based vaccines (EVs). EVs have a wide range of applications, including therapeutic and prophylactic approaches for infectious diseases and cancer. The development of an EV is based on the knowledge of target-specific antigens from which immunogenic peptides, called epitopes, are derived. However, the number of epitopes that can be included in an EV is limited due to regulatory, economic, and practical concerns. Additionally, the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) binding these epitopes is highly polymorphic, making the optimal selection of epitopes an important optimization problem. The proposed ILP framework allows the formulation of various flavors of the vaccine design problem and the efficient identification of optimal sets of epitopes. The framework selects the set of epitopes with the maximum likelihood of eliciting a broad and potent immune response from a user-defined set of predicted or experimentally determined epitopes. The ILP approach is demonstrated to outperform a simple greedy strategy and a previously suggested evolutionary algorithm, with runtimes on the order of seconds for typical problem sizes. The framework is flexible enough to account for variants of the problem, including personalized vaccines, and is the first epitope selection framework to find the optimal solution.
The study investigated the role of interleukin-7 (IL-7) in facilitating HIV-1 transmission to cervico-vaginal tissue ex vivo. IL-7 is a cytokine present in semen, and its concentration is increased in HIV-1-infected individuals. The researchers simulated an in vivo situation by depositing HIV-1 on cervico-vaginal tissue in combination with IL-7 at concentrations comparable to those found in semen of HIV-1-infected individuals. The results showed that IL-7 significantly enhanced virus replication in ex vivo infected cervico-vaginal tissue and lymphoid tissue explants. Analysis of T cells isolated from infected tissues revealed that IL-7 reduced CD4+ T cell depletion by preventing apoptosis and increasing the expression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2. Additionally, IL-7 increased the fraction of cycling CD4+ T cells. The study suggests that high levels of seminal IL-7 in vivo may facilitate the survival of the founder pool of HIV-1-infected cells in the cervico-vaginal mucosa at the initial stage of infection, promoting local expansion and dissemination of HIV infection. The findings indicate that IL-7 may play a significant role in HIV-1 male-to-female transmission, making the female lower genital tract mucosa more susceptible to HIV-1 acquisition.
Zika virus ( ZIKV ) induces the production of virus-specific small RNAs in Aedes aegypti cells, including both exogenous short interfering RNAs ( exo-siRNAs ) and PIWI-interacting RNAs ( piRNAs ). The exo-siRNA pathway is considered a key antiviral response mechanism in mosquitoes, and ZIKV-specific siRNAs were found to be loaded into the effector protein Argonaute 2 ( Ago2 ). However, knockdown of Ago2 did not enhance ZIKV replication, suggesting that the exo-siRNA pathway may not be the primary antiviral response to ZIKV. In contrast, a Dcr2-knockout cell line showed enhanced ZIKV replication, indicating that the exo-siRNA pathway is involved in the antiviral response. ZIKV-specific piRNA-sized small RNAs were also detected, but they lacked the characteristic piRNA ping-pong signature motif and were bound to Ago3 but not Piwi5 or Piwi6. Silencing of Ago3, Piwi5, or Piwi6 did not enhance ZIKV replication, but silencing of Piwi4 displayed antiviral activity. The expression of ZIKV capsid protein amplified the replication of a reporter alphavirus, but unlike yellow fever virus capsid protein, it did not inhibit the exo-siRNA pathway. These findings elucidate ZIKV-mosquito RNAi interactions that are important for understanding its spread. The results suggest that the exo-siRNA pathway plays a role in the antiviral response to ZIKV in Aedes aegypti cells.
In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, a cross-sectional study was conducted to investigate the association between Sporothrix species and clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis. A total of 50 patients with different clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis were analyzed, and their isolates were studied using phenotypic and genotypic methods. The results showed that Sporothrix brasiliensis was associated with atypical clinical presentations, including disseminated cutaneous infection without underlying disease, hypersensitivity reactions, and mucosal infection. In contrast, patients infected with Sporothrix schenckii sensu stricto presented with less severe and more localized disease, similar to the majority of previously described sporotrichosis cases. Notably, patients infected with S. brasiliensis required shorter durations of itraconazole treatment (median 16 weeks) compared to those infected with S. schenckii (median 24 weeks). These findings suggest that Sporothrix species are linked to different clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis and that S. brasiliensis is effectively treated with oral itraconazole. This study provides new information on the clinical implications of the recent changes in the taxonomy of Sporothrix and highlights the importance of careful speciation of Sporothrix isolates to guide clinical care. The results of this study contribute to a better understanding of the complex relationship between Sporothrix species and clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis.
The mammalian genome was previously thought to be more pervasively transcribed than currently annotated genes suggest. However, a recent study used single- and paired-end RNA-Seq and tiling arrays to assess the quantity and composition of transcripts in human and mouse tissues. The results indicate that most transcripts outside of known exons and non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) are fragments of pre-mRNAs located within introns. Furthermore, the chromosomal locations of the majority of intergenic transcripts are near known genes, suggesting alternative cleavage and polyadenylation site usage, promoter- and terminator-associated transcripts, or new alternative exons. In fact, reads that bridge splice sites identified 4,544 new exons, affecting 3,554 genes. The study also found that most intergenic and intronic transcripts have very low sequence coverage, with 70-80% of the transcribed area detected by a single RNA-Seq read in only one sample, consistent with random placement. In contrast, tiling arrays are ill-suited to accurately detect transcripts expressed at low levels. The majority of non-exonic transcripts in RNA-Seq data are associated with known genes, including thousands of new alternative exons and hundreds of alternative promoters. A genome-wide analysis of de novo splice junctions revealed 2,789 previously uncharacterized transcript fragments, 1,259 of which map to intergenic regions. Overall, the study concludes that while there are bona fide new intergenic transcripts, their number and abundance are generally low compared to known exons, and the genome is not as pervasively transcribed as previously reported.
Scientists have developed a novel method to enhance the thermostability of the Bacillus subtilis YtvA LOV domain, a flavin mononucleotide-based fluorescent protein. The YtvA LOV domain, also known as Flavin mononucleotide-based Fluorescent Protein (FbFP), has potential applications in studying anaerobic microorganisms, particularly thermophilic ones. However, its moderate thermostability limits its use in high-temperature environments. To address this issue, a combined computational and experimental approach was employed to increase the thermostability of FbFP. The method involves five steps: single mutant computer screening, experimental evaluation, computational redesign, experimental reevaluation, and multiple mutations combination. This approach resulted in a 31°C increase in the melting temperature (Tm) of FbFP, making it more suitable for use in thermophilic systems. The method was found to be effective, with a success rate of 62%, and identified eight thermostable sites, five of which are located at the dimeric interface. The mutant V120I showed the highest thermostability, with a Tm of 54.2°C. This study provides a new tool for enhancing protein thermostability, which can be particularly useful when conventional methods, such as directed evolution, fail. The approach can be applied to other important proteins where other methods have difficulties, offering a promising solution for protein engineering.
A study was conducted to investigate the diversity of Lutzomyia sand fly species and their infection rates by Leishmania and Wolbachia on Barro Colorado Island, Panama. The island is located in the central watershed of the Panama Canal and is a region where cutaneous leishmaniasis is a continuous health threat for residents, tourists, and the international research community. The study used DNA sequences to determine the diversity and probable phylogenetic relationships of the Phlebotominae occurring in the understory of the island. The results supported 18 morphology-based species determinations and revealed the presence of two possible "cryptic" species. Leishmania DNA was detected in 43.3% of Lu. trapidoi, 26.3% of Lu. gomezi individuals, and in 0% of the other 18 sand fly species. The Leishmania infecting Lu. trapidoi and Lu. gomezi was identified as Leishmania (viannia) naiffi, a species previously unknown in Panama but recognized as a type of cutaneous leishmaniasis vectored broadly across northern and central South America. Distinct strains of Wolbachia were detected in three of 20 sand fly species, including Lu. trapidoi, in which it frequently co-occurred with Leishmania. The study suggests that Lu. trapidoi and Lu. gomezi are likely vectors of leishmaniasis to humans or other mammal species, and that Le. naiffi may have recently expanded its range to include the Isthmus of Panama. The occurrence of Leishmania and Wolbachia in Lu. trapidoi identifies one important vector of the disease as a potential target for gene introductions using Wolbachia population sweeps.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) reactivation in dendritic cells (DCs) is a significant clinical concern due to its devastating consequences. This study investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying HCMV reactivation, focusing on the role of mitogen and stress-activated kinase (MSK) family and cAMP response element-binding protein (CREB). The results show that ERK-mediated reactivation is dependent on the MSK family, which is recruited to the viral major immediate early promoter (MIEP) through CREB binding. CREB binding to the MIEP provides a target for MSK recruitment, and MSK-mediated phosphorylation of histone H3 is required to promote histone de-methylation and the subsequent exit of HCMV from latency. The study used an adenovirus vector approach to directly associate the ERK-MSK relationship with CREB-histone H3 phosphorylation and the induction of IE gene expression from latency. The results demonstrate that IE gene expression from latency in DCs is acutely sensitive to MSK chemical inhibition and that reactivation of HCMV involves the phosphorylation of histones bound to the latent MIEP. Furthermore, the study provides in vivo evidence for a functional interaction between MSK and CREB at promoters, which is essential for controlling the gene expression of HCMV. The findings suggest that specific inhibition of the interaction between CREB and MSKs could provide a therapeutic strategy for preventing HCMV reactivation.
The ribosome biogenesis factor Nol11 plays a crucial role in vertebrate ribosome biogenesis and craniofacial development. Nol11 is strongly expressed in the developing cranial neural crest (CNC) of both amphibians and mammals, and its knockdown in Xenopus results in impaired pre-rRNA transcription and processing, increased apoptosis, and abnormal development of craniofacial cartilages. The study reveals a novel requirement for Nol11 in craniofacial development and provides further insight into the evolutionarily conserved relationship between specific ribosome biogenesis factors and the control mechanisms that regulate CNC survival and development. The findings demonstrate that Nol11 is essential for optimal pre-rRNA transcription and processing in Xenopus, and that its knockdown leads to activation of the nucleolar stress response and p53 stabilization. The study also shows that inhibition of p53 rescues the craniofacial phenotype but not the underlying ribosome biogenesis defect, indicating an evolutionarily conserved control mechanism through which ribosome-impaired craniofacial cells are removed. The results suggest that excessive activation of this mechanism impairs craniofacial development. The study presents the first frog model of a ribosomopathy and provides further insight into the clinically important relationship between specific ribosome biogenesis proteins and craniofacial cell survival. Overall, the findings highlight the importance of Nol11 in vertebrate ribosome biogenesis and craniofacial development.
A high-density protein microarray approach was used to identify seroreactive proteins of Leptospira interrogans serovar Copenhageni in 274 individuals, including 80 acute-phase, 80 convalescent-phase patients, and 114 healthy control subjects from regions with endemic, high endemic, and no endemic transmission of leptospirosis. The protein microarray chip comprised 2,421 proteins, representing 61% of the Leptospira interrogans proteome. A nitrocellulose line blot assay was performed to validate the accuracy of the protein microarray results. The study identified 16 antigens that can discriminate between acute cases and healthy individuals from a region with high endemic transmission of leptospirosis, and 18 antigens that distinguish convalescent cases. Some of the identified antigens, such as LipL32, the non-identical domains of the Lig proteins, GroEL, and Loa22, are already known to be recognized by sera from human patients, serving as proof-of-concept for the serodiagnostic antigen discovery approach. Novel antigens, including the hypothetical protein LIC10215, showed good sensitivity and specificity rates for both acute- and convalescent-phase patients. The study is the first large-scale evaluation of immunodominant antigens associated with naturally acquired leptospiral infection, and novel as well as known serodiagnostic leptospiral antigens were identified. The novel antigens may have potential use in the development of new tests and the improvement of currently available assays for diagnosing leptospirosis. Further research is needed to assess the utility of these antigens in more deployable diagnostic platforms.
This study investigated the role of melanization in mosquito defense against the entomopathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana using Anopheles gambiae as a model. Melanization is a potent immune effector mechanism in arthropods, but its contribution to anti-fungal defense remains poorly understood. The study found that melanin formed on all stages of B. bassiana, including conidia, germ tubes, and hyphae, but rarely aborted fungal growth. Silencing TEP1 and CLIPA8, key regulators of Plasmodium and bacterial melanization, abolished melanin formation on hyphae but not on germinating conidia or germ tubes. The study suggests that melanization of early fungal stages is cell-mediated, while late-stage melanization is a humoral response dependent on TEP1 and CLIPA8. Microscopic analysis revealed that TEP1 is associated with the surfaces of hyphae and that both TEP1 and CLIPA8 are required for recruiting phenoloxidase to these surfaces. Furthermore, fungal proliferation was more rapid in TEP1 and CLIPA8 knockdown mosquitoes, which exhibited increased sensitivity to natural B. bassiana infections. The study concludes that the mosquito melanization response significantly retards B. bassiana growth and dissemination, a finding that may be exploited to design transgenic fungi with enhanced bio-control activities against mosquitoes.
The study investigated the potential of four compounds, bafilomycin (BAF), mycophenolic acid (MPA), castanospermine (CAS), and deoxynojirimycin (DNJ), to inhibit dengue virus (DENV) infection in the mosquito vector Aedes aegypti. The compounds were tested for their ability to block DENV infection in the mosquito midgut using various treatment methods, including direct injection, ingestion through sugar feeding or blood feeding, and RNA interference (RNAi). The results showed that BAF and MPA were effective in inhibiting DENV infection, with BAF reducing titers in the midgut by 56% and MPA reducing titers by 60% at 7 days post-infection. In contrast, CAS and DNJ did not affect susceptibility to the virus. RNAi-mediated silencing of vATPase subunit genes and the IMPDH gene also resulted in reduced DENV infection, indicating that BAF- and MPA-mediated virus inhibition occurred through the inhibition of these DENV host factors (HFs). The study found that the route and timing of BAF and MPA administration were crucial, and treatment after exposure to the virus diminished the antiviral effect of these compounds. The results provide proof-of-principle that chemical inhibition or RNAi-mediated depletion of DENV HFs, specifically vATPase and IMPDH, can be used to suppress DENV infection in adult Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, which may lead to a reduction in DENV transmission.
The Role of Cell Volume in the Dynamics of Seizure, Spreading Depression, and Anoxic Depolarization
    A recent study investigated the effects of cell volume on neuronal dynamics in the context of seizure, spreading depression, and anoxic depolarization. By incorporating cell swelling, dynamic ion concentrations, and oxygen supply into Hodgkin-Huxley type spiking dynamics, the researchers demonstrated the spontaneous transition between epileptic seizure and spreading depression states as the cell swells and contracts in response to changes in osmotic pressure. The study revealed a dynamical definition for the physiological ceiling that separates seizure from spreading depression, as well as a second ceiling that demarcates spreading depression from anoxic depolarization. The results highlight the neuroprotective role of glial K buffering against seizures and spreading depression, and provide novel insights into anoxic depolarization and the relevant cell swelling during ischemia. The study argues that the dynamics of seizures, spreading depression, and anoxic depolarization lie along a continuum of the repertoire of the neuron membrane, which can be understood only when dynamic ion concentrations, oxygen homeostasis, and cell swelling in response to osmotic pressure are taken into consideration. The findings demonstrate the feasibility of a unified framework for a wide range of neuronal behaviors, which may be of substantial importance in understanding and potentially developing universal intervention strategies for these pathological states.
The study investigated the role of the NLRP3 inflammasome in the response to Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (P. brasiliensis) infection. P. brasiliensis is the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, a systemic mycosis prevalent in Latin America. The study found that murine bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDCs) responded to P. brasiliensis yeast cells by releasing the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1β in a spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk), caspase-1, and NLRP3-dependent manner. The activation of the NLRP3 inflammasome was also dependent on potassium efflux, reactive oxygen species production, phagolysosomal acidification, and cathepsin B release. Furthermore, the study demonstrated that IL-1β signaling plays a crucial role in killing P. brasiliensis by murine macrophages. The results suggest that the NLRP3 inflammasome senses and responds to P. brasiliensis yeast cells infection and plays an important role in host defense against this fungus. The study also showed that IL-1β production by BMDCs infected with P. brasiliensis requires NLRP3 inflammasome-dependent activation of caspase-1. Additionally, the study found that IL-1β-mediated signaling is essential for the activation of macrophage fungicidal activity against P. brasiliensis. Overall, the study highlights the importance of the NLRP3 inflammasome in the host response to P. brasiliensis infection.
Toxoplasma gondii is a brain-tropic parasite that infects most nucleated cells, including astrocytes and neurons, both in vitro and in vivo. However, in vivo studies have shown that Toxoplasma is primarily found in neurons, suggesting that neurons may be the primary target cell for the parasite. To investigate this theory, a novel Toxoplasma-mouse model was developed to mark and track host cells that interact with parasites, even if the interaction is transient. Using this model, it was found that Toxoplasma shows a strong predilection for interacting with neurons throughout central nervous system (CNS) infection. This predilection remained even in the presence of interferon-γ depletion, infection with parasites resistant to the major mechanism by which murine astrocytes clear parasites, or when parasites were directly injected into the brain. These findings suggest that neurons are not incidentally infected, but rather are Toxoplasma's primary in vivo target. The study also found that neurons consistently make up the majority of the GFP+ parenchymal CNS cells, regardless of time point or infecting strain, contradicting the "astrocyte-killing" model of CNS-Toxoplasma interactions. The results of this study provide new insights into the host cell-pathogen dynamics of Toxoplasma infection and have implications for the development of therapies to eliminate persistent pathogens.
A free-boundary model of actin-myosin contractility has been developed to explain the turning behavior of motile cells undergoing lamellipodial motility. The model consists of force-balance and myosin transport equations that account for isotropic contraction proportional to myosin density, viscous stresses in the actin network, and constant-strength viscous-like adhesion. The contraction generates a spatially graded centripetal actin flow that reinforces the contraction via myosin redistribution and causes retraction of the lamellipodial boundary. Actin protrusion at the boundary counters the retraction, and the balance of protrusion and retraction shapes the lamellipodium. The model analysis shows that initiation of motility depends on three dimensionless parameter combinations representing myosin-dependent contractility, a characteristic viscosity-adhesion length, and a rate of actin protrusion. When contractility is sufficiently strong, cells break symmetry and move steadily along either straight or circular trajectories. The motile behavior is sensitive to conditions at the cell boundary. The contractile mechanism of motility supports robust cell turning in conditions where short viscosity-adhesion lengths and fast protrusion cause an accumulation of myosin in a small region at the cell rear, destabilizing the axial symmetry of a moving cell. The model predicts that the aspect ratio of a steadily moving cell varies between 1 and 3, in agreement with experimental observations.
The article presents a novel technique for assessing the confidence levels of interactions in protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks obtained from experimental studies. The technique utilizes a geometric graph model, which is the best fitting network model for PPI networks, to predict new interactions and guide future biological experiments. The approach achieves a specificity of 85% and sensitivity of 90%, outperforming existing PPI network post-processing techniques. The method is applied to the human PPI network, downloaded from BioGRID, and predicts 251 interactions, a statistically significant fraction of which correspond to protein pairs sharing common Gene Ontology (GO) terms. A statistically significant portion of the predicted interactions are validated in the HPRD database and the newer release of BioGRID. The data and Matlab code implementing the methods are freely available online. The technique detects false positives and false negative interactions in PPI data sets, including those obtained from yeast-2-hybrid (Y2H) and tandem affinity purification (TAP) experiments, which are known to have high levels of noise and incompleteness. The method does not require multiple PPI datasets or a priori information about individual proteins, such as binding domains, structure, function, chemical properties, or sequence. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of the geometric graph model in assessing the confidence levels of known interactions and predicting novel ones in PPI networks.
A Drosophila model for myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) has been established to investigate the role of interactions between expanded CTG and CAG repeat transcripts in disease pathogenesis. The study reveals that co-expression of CTG and CAG expanded repeats leads to dramatically enhanced toxicity in flies, accompanied by the generation of 21-nt triplet repeat-derived siRNAs. These small RNAs target the expression of CAG-containing genes, such as Ataxin-2 and TATA binding protein (TBP), which bear long CAG repeats in both flies and humans. The findings suggest that the generation of triplet repeat-derived siRNAs may significantly contribute to toxicity in human repeat expansion diseases where anti-sense transcription occurs. The study also demonstrates that non-coding, uninterrupted CTG repeats confer length-dependent toxicity when expressed in brain and muscle in flies, recapitulating key features of the human disease DM1. Furthermore, the co-expression of CTG and CAG expanded repeats results in novel pathogenesis, including the generation of dcr-2 and ago2-dependent 21-nt triplet repeat-derived siRNAs. These results indicate that anti-sense repeat transcripts may play a significant role in the pathogenesis of trinucleotide repeat diseases, including DM1, and highlight the potential of Drosophila as a model system for studying human neurological and neurodegenerative diseases.
The soft rot phytopathogen Pectobacterium wasabiae SCC3193 has been reclassified from Pectobacterium carotovorum based on genomic analysis and proteome comparisons with other sequenced soft rot bacteria. The strain was originally isolated from a diseased potato stem in Finland in the early 1980s and has since been used as a model strain in soft rot research. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Pectobacterium wasabiae has been present in potato fields worldwide, including Europe and potentially North America, although it has gone unnoticed. A combination of genomic approaches and in planta experiments identified novel virulence determinants of Pectobacterium wasabiae SCC3193, including a putative transcriptional regulator SirB, two partially redundant type VI secretion systems, and two horizontally acquired clusters containing predicted virulence genes. The absence of a type III secretion system is a distinctive feature separating Pectobacterium wasabiae from other soft rot bacteria. Genome comparison also revealed other traits that may be related to life in planta or specific environmental conditions, such as a predicted benzoic acid/salicylic acid carboxyl methyltransferase of eukaryotic origin. These findings indicate that Pectobacterium wasabiae has a reservoir of unknown traits that may be utilized during the poorly understood latent stage of infection. The revised phylogeny and novel virulence determinants of Pectobacterium wasabiae SCC3193 provide a solid basis for further investigation of the virulence, distribution, and phylogeny of soft rot bacteria.
This study investigated the systemic alterations of mitochondrial protein expression in response to mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) depletion using network analysis of gene expression data. Mitochondrial protein repertoire varies depending on the cellular state, and protein component modifications caused by mtDNA depletion are related to a wide range of human diseases. The researchers used a data-integrative approach to select reliable mitochondrial proteins for network analysis and discovered that up-regulated and down-regulated proteins were organized into two predominant subnetworks with distinct biological processes. The down-regulated network modules were involved in typical mitochondrial functions such as energy production, metabolism, and protein folding, while up-regulated proteins were responsible for mtDNA repair and regulation of mt protein expression and transport. Comparisons of proteome and transcriptome data revealed that mtDNA-depleted cells attempted to compensate for mtDNA depletion by modulating the coordinated expression/transport of mt proteins. The results demonstrate that mt protein composition changed to remodel the functional organization of mitochondrial protein networks in response to dysfunctional cellular states. This study provides a framework for understanding how cells respond to mitochondrial dysfunctions and can be valuable to the computational biology community working on gene expression and proteomics analysis. The findings suggest that eukaryotic cells can monitor and respond to changes in mt conditions through alterations of nuclear gene expression.
The article presents a novel method to deduce the kinetics of protein synthesis in vivo from transition rates measured in vitro. The method involves two main components: the kinetic distance, a quantitative measure of the similarity between in-vitro and in-vivo kinetics, and a constrained minimization procedure that reproduces a known global property, such as the overall in-vivo speed. The kinetic distance depends logarithmically on the transition rates and can be interpreted in terms of the underlying free energy barriers. The authors apply this method to protein synthesis by ribosomes, a key process of gene expression, using a codon-specific Markov model with three reaction pathways. They determine the individual transition rates in vitro and predict the in-vivo rates by minimizing the kinetic distance between the in-vitro and in-vivo processes. The predicted in-vivo rates are validated by three independent sets of in-vivo data, including codon-dependent translation speeds, codon-specific translation dynamics, and missense error frequencies. The results show good agreement between theory and experiment without adjusting any fit parameters. The deduced in-vivo rates lead to smaller error frequencies than the known in-vitro rates, primarily due to an improved initial selection of tRNA. The method is computationally simple and can be applied to any biomolecular process with detailed information about the in-vitro kinetics.
The study investigated the microevolution of Helicobacter pylori during prolonged infection of single hosts and within families. The researchers sequenced an average of 39,300 base pairs in 78 gene fragments from 97 isolates, including 34 pairs of sequential samples and single isolates from 29 individuals from 10 families. The results showed that the accumulation of sequence diversity increased with time of separation in a clock-like manner in the sequential isolates. Using Approximate Bayesian Computation, the researchers estimated the rates of mutation, recombination, mean length of recombination tracts, and average diversity in those tracts. The estimates indicated that the short-term mutation rate is 1.4×10−6 to 4.5×10−6 per nucleotide per year, with three times as many substitutions introduced by recombination as by mutation. The long-term mutation rate over millennia is 5–17-fold lower, partly due to the removal of non-synonymous mutations due to purifying selection. The study also found that the short-term mutation rates vary dramatically in different bacterial species, spanning a range of several orders of magnitude. The results provide a robust estimate of the mutation rate over years to decades and highlight the importance of purifying selection in shaping the evolution of H. pylori over longer time periods.
Melanopsin, a photopigment found in a subset of retinal ganglion cells (mRGCs), has been shown to play a crucial role in non-image-forming visual responses, such as circadian photoentrainment and pupillomotor movements. However, its contribution to conventional visual pathways has remained unclear. This study aimed to investigate the role of melanopsin in the thalamo-cortical visual system. Using new reporter lines, the authors found that mRGC projections are more extensive than previously thought, extending across the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus (dLGN), the origin of thalamo-cortical projection neurons. In mice lacking rods and cones, melanopsin input to the dLGN and visual cortex was found to support physiological light responses. Furthermore, using chromatic stimuli to isolate melanopsin-derived responses in mice with an intact visual system, the authors revealed strong melanopsin input to approximately 40% of neurons in the LGN that showed sustained activation to a light step. This melanopsin input was found to support irradiance-dependent increases in the firing rate of these neurons. In melanopsin knockout mice, the ability to accurately encode stimulus irradiance was impaired. These findings establish melanopsin-based photoreception as a significant source of sensory input to the thalamo-cortical visual system, providing unique irradiance information and allowing visual responses to be retained even in the absence of rods and cones. The study suggests that melanopsin may support vision in individuals with retinal degeneration and identifies mRGCs as a potential origin for aspects of visual perception.
HIV-1 infection is associated with a profound depletion of mucosal memory CD4+ T cells, which play a crucial role in regulating isotype switching and transepithelial transport of antibodies. This study investigated whether the depletion of CD4+ T cells in HIV-1-infected individuals affects humoral responses to antigens encountered at mucosal surfaces. A comprehensive protein microarray analysis of systemic humoral responses to intestinal microbiota revealed reduced IgG responses to antigens derived from Proteobacteria and Firmicutes, but not Bacteroidetes. Intestinal secretions of antiretroviral therapy-treated HIV-1-infected individuals exhibited elevated IgM levels and decreased IgA/IgM and IgG/IgM ratios of antibodies specific to microbial and food antigens. These findings indicate reduced competence of mucosal B cells for class switch recombination from IgM to other isotypes, limiting their capacity to react to changing antigenic variety in the gut lumen. The decreased availability of microbiota-specific IgA and IgG may contribute to the translocation of microbial antigens across the intestinal mucosal barrier and their systemic dissemination, driving chronic inflammation in HIV-1-infected individuals. The study also found a significant increase in IgM levels and a decrease in IgG/IgM and IgA/IgM ratios of antibodies specific to mucosal microbial antigens in intestinal secretions of antiretroviral therapy-treated HIV-1-infected individuals, indicative of a lack of help for class switch recombination. This dysregulation of mucosal humoral responses may have significant consequences by promoting local inflammation and mucosal barrier damage.
The article proposes a new model for population dynamics in ecosystems where resources are redistributed after a catastrophic collapse of a dominant species. The model, called the "Kill-the-Winner" (KtW) model, assumes that populations grow exponentially until they reach a carrying capacity, at which point a catastrophic collapse occurs, freeing up resources for other species. The system is characterized by "diversity waves," where the population diversity peaks at the beginning of each wave and exponentially decreases afterwards. The emergent dynamics of the system is characterized by a bimodal time-aggregated distribution of species abundances, with a lower peak formed by recently collapsed or newly introduced species and an upper peak formed by species that have not yet collapsed. The system also exhibits a scale-free tail of the time-aggregated population distribution with a universal exponent of 1.7. The model is robust to variations in the rules of the model, including diffusion between multiple environments, species-specific growth and extinction rates, and bet-hedging strategies. The long-term growth rate of each species is exactly zero, making the classic definition of fitness in terms of long-term exponential growth rate inappropriate. The model provides a general framework for systems driven by redistribution of rate-limiting resources freed up by episodic catastrophes.
Predicted Auxiliary Navigation Mechanism of Peritrichously Flagellated Chemotactic Bacteria
    Chemotactic movement of Escherichia coli is a well-studied paradigm of simple behavior. The chemotaxis system is expected to be strongly optimized due to its significant competitive advantage and high evolution rates in bacteria. Bacteria follow gradients by performing temporal comparisons of chemoeffector concentrations along their runs. A sensory system detects concentration differences and transmits them to modulate the rotation of flagellar motors, decreasing the probability of a tumble and reorientation if the perceived concentration change during a run is positive.
