This regulation of tumble probability is sufficient to explain chemotactic drift of a population up the gradient, and is commonly assumed to be the only navigation mechanism of chemotactic E. coli. However, computer simulations predict the existence of an additional mechanism of gradient navigation in E. coli. The simulations suggest that not only the tumbling probability but also the degree of reorientation during a tumble depend on the swimming direction along the gradient. This fine tuning of tumbling angle results in a dramatic enhancement of the cellular drift velocity along the gradient. The study demonstrates a new level of optimization in E. coli chemotaxis, which arises from the switching of several flagellar motors and a resulting fine tuning of tumbling angle. This strategy is likely to be used by other peritrichously flagellated bacteria with similar chemotaxis behavior.
This study investigates the role of Stat3 signaling in the development and homeostasis of medullary thymic epithelial cells (mTECs). mTECs are essential for establishing central tolerance by expressing self-peptides that delete autoreactive thymocytes or divert them into the regulatory T cell lineage. Activation of the NFκB signaling pathway in mTEC precursors is crucial for mTEC maturation and proliferation, resulting in proper medullary region formation. The study reveals that Stat3-mediated signaling also plays a key role in mTEC development and homeostasis. Expression of a constitutively active Stat3 transgene targeted to the mTEC compartment increases mTEC cellularity and bypasses the requirement for signals from positively selected thymocytes to drive medullary region formation. Conversely, conditional deletion of Stat3 disrupts medullary region architecture and reduces the number of mTECs. Stat3 signaling promotes the survival of immature MHCIIloCD80lo mTEC precursors, but does not affect mTEC proliferation. The study demonstrates that, in addition to the NFκB pathway, Stat3-mediated signals play an essential role in regulating mTEC cellularity and medullary region homeostasis. The findings suggest that Stat3 activation is indispensable for optimal development and maintenance of the thymic medullary compartment.
The article presents a genome-wide identification of small noncoding RNAs (sRNAs) in the human pathogen Clostridium difficile (C. difficile). Using an in silico approach, 511 sRNA candidates were identified in both intergenic and coding regions of the C. difficile genome. To validate these predictions, RNA-seq and differential 5'-end RNA-seq were used to globally identify C. difficile sRNAs and their transcriptional start sites at three different growth conditions: exponential growth phase, stationary phase, and starvation. This approach identified 251 putative regulatory sRNAs, including 94 potential trans-riboregulators, 91 cis-antisense RNAs, and 66 riboswitches. Expression of 35 sRNAs was confirmed by gene-specific experimental approaches. Some sRNAs showed growth phase-dependent expression profiles, and 16 predicted c-di-GMP-responsive riboswitches were found to be involved in coordinated control of motility and biofilm formation. Additionally, abundant sRNAs encoded by multiple C. difficile CRISPR loci were detected, which may be important for C. difficile survival in bacteriophage-rich gut communities. The study provides a comprehensive understanding of sRNA regulation in C. difficile and highlights the potential diversity of RNA-based mechanisms controlling key steps during the infection cycle of this emergent enteropathogen. The findings provide a firm basis for future RNome characterization and identification of molecular mechanisms of sRNA-based regulation of gene expression in C. difficile.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) core protein downregulates the abundance of liver-specific microRNA miR-122 by promoting its destabilization via the inhibition of GLD-2, a non-canonical cytoplasmic poly(A) polymerase. The decrease in miR-122 expression results in the dysregulation of its known functions, including its proviral activity for HCV. High-throughput sequencing of small RNAs from human liver biopsies revealed that the 22-nucleotide prototype miR-122 is modified at its 3' end by 3'-terminal non-templated and templated nucleotide additions. The proportion of miR-122 isomers bearing a single nucleotide tail of any ribonucleotide decreased in liver specimens from patients with HCV. These single-nucleotide-tailed miR-122 isomers display increased miRNA activity and stability compared to the 22-nt prototype miR-122. The HCV core protein specifically inhibits GLD-2, and its interaction with GLD-2 in the cytoplasm is responsible for miR-122 downregulation. Inhibition of GLD-2 by the HCV core protein affects multiple miRNAs in addition to miR-122 by decreasing the proportion of mono-adenylated isomers. Analysis of miR-122 expression levels in human liver biopsies from healthy subjects and patients with HCV revealed decreased miR-122 levels in liver specimens from patients. The results demonstrate that HCV infection interferes with miR-122 3'-end tailing in liver tissues, and the HCV core protein inhibits this modification.
In a study of wild African lions in the Serengeti, researchers have found evidence of acquired immunity to Trypanosoma brucei, a parasite that causes disease in humans and livestock throughout sub-Saharan Africa. The study discovered a distinct peak and decrease in age prevalence of T. brucei s.l. infection in lions, which is consistent with an exposure-dependent increase in cross-immunity following infections with the more genetically diverse species, T. congolense s.l. This cross-immunity appears to allow lions to clear most infections of T. brucei s.l. by 3-5 years of age and eliminate all infections of T. brucei rhodesiense by the age of 6 years. The findings suggest that frequent re-exposure to each trypanosome species through tsetse bites accelerates the onset and extent of immunity, resulting in lower prevalence in areas of high-tsetse exposure. The study provides the first epidemiological evidence of acquired immunity to trypanosomes in any host species and challenges the long-held assumption that immunity to trypanosomes is impossible. The results have significant implications for the development of vaccines against trypanosomiasis, a disease caused by T. brucei rhodesiense, which is the causative agent of human sleeping sickness. The discovery of acquired immunity in lions generates a new perspective on existing data and future research in this field, particularly in regions where cattle act as a major reservoir of human infection, such as East Uganda.
A computational model of the human coagulation cascade was developed and validated using 21 published datasets generated from two different in vitro coagulation models. The model, composed of 92 proteins and 148 protein–protein interactions, accurately simulated platelet activation and thrombin generation profiles in the presence and absence of natural anticoagulants, with a mean correlation of 0. 87 across all trials. Sensitivity analysis revealed that fluid and surface phase factor X/activated factor X ( fX/FXa ) activity and thrombin-mediated platelet activation were fragile, while factor IX/activated factor IX ( fIX/FIXa ) and factor VIII/activated factor VIII ( fVIII/FVIIIa ) activation and activity were robust. These findings are consistent with current therapeutic strategies, as anti-fX/FXa and direct thrombin inhibitors are important classes of anticoagulants. The model also predicted that fIX/FIXa activity is robust, which is supported by both in vitro and in vivo experimental evidence. Overall state sensitivity coefficients, which measure the robustness or fragility of a given mechanism, were calculated using a Monte Carlo strategy. The results support the working hypothesis that computationally derived points of fragility of human relevant cascades can be used as a rational basis for target selection despite model uncertainty. Preliminary simulations of simultaneous platelet activation and thrombin formation were consistent with the results of a cell-based coagulation assay, and the model is the first to simultaneously describe all 21 datasets, including coupled platelet and thrombin activation and the activity of three different anticoagulants, using minimal parameter variation.
The article presents a quantitative analysis of bacteriophage-host dynamics in an in vitro system using Campylobacter jejuni and a virulent phage. The study aims to understand the non-linear kinetics of phage-bacteria interactions, which is crucial for the successful application of phage therapy. Phage therapy involves using bacteriophages as antimicrobial agents to control pathogenic bacteria. The authors combine experimental and modeling approaches to examine the kinetics of phage-bacteria interactions and test a pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) model against in vitro data. The results show that even a simple model fits the data surprisingly well and confirms the importance of inundation and proliferation thresholds in phage therapy. These thresholds are critical parameters that determine the effectiveness of phage treatment. The study also highlights the emergence of phage-insensitive populations of C. jejuni, which can lead to the resurgence of bacterial populations. The authors emphasize the need for a threshold-based understanding of phage-bacteria interactions for phage therapy. The study demonstrates the importance of combining empirical studies with kinetic models to gain a deeper understanding of phage therapy. The findings suggest that in vitro systems are essential for building a meaningful picture of the kinetic properties of in vivo phage therapy. The study contributes to the development of a theoretical framework for understanding the non-linear kinetic properties of phages as self-replicating pharmaceuticals.
A novel Toll-Like Receptor (TLR) has been identified in the freshwater snail Biomphalaria glabrata, which plays a crucial role in the snail's immune response to the parasitic flatworm Schistosoma mansoni. Schistosomiasis, caused by S. mansoni, affects over 260 million people worldwide, particularly in tropical and sub-tropical regions. The snail's immune response is essential for protecting against schistosome infection, but few specific snail immune factors have been identified and functionally characterized. This study reports the first functional characterization of a snail TLR, named BgTLR, which is involved in the cellular immune response of B. glabrata following challenge with S. mansoni. BgTLR was identified through a peptide screen of snail immune cell surface proteins that differed in abundance between B. glabrata snails with different compatibility phenotypes to S. mansoni challenge. The S. mansoni-resistant strain of B. glabrata (BS-90) displayed higher levels of BgTLR compared to the susceptible (M-line) strain. Transcript expression of BgTLR was found to be highly responsive in BS-90 snails when challenged with S. mansoni, increasing 27-fold relative to a non-immune control gene. Knockdown of BgTLR in BS-90 snails via targeted siRNA oligonucleotides resulted in a significant alteration of the resistant phenotype, yielding patent infections in 43% of the normally resistant snails. These results demonstrate that BgTLR is an important snail immune receptor that influences infection outcome following S. mansoni challenge.
In French Polynesia, Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis mosquitoes are primary vectors of infectious diseases such as dengue, chikungunya, Zika, and Bancroftian filariasis. To assess the risk of disease transmission and evaluate the efficacy of vector control programs, researchers developed an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) test to detect and quantify immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies against salivary gland extracts (SGE) of Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis in human populations. A cross-sectional study conducted in Tahiti and Moorea islands revealed that 98% and 68% of individuals had developed IgG antibodies against Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis SGE, respectively. In contrast, 97% of individuals from metropolitan France, not exposed to these Aedes mosquitoes, had no IgG antibodies against SGE of either mosquito species. The ELISA test showed no cross-reactivity between Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis SGE, indicating that the IgG response to salivary gland extracts is a valid and specific biomarker of human exposure to the bites of Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis. This new immuno-epidemiological tool is expected to enhance understanding of human exposure to mosquito bites, identify areas with high disease transmission risk, and evaluate the efficacy of novel vector control strategies in Pacific islands and other tropical settings.
The success of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) as a pathogen is attributed to its ability to adapt to the intracellular environment of human macrophages. Research has shown that this adaptation involves interference with the metabolic machinery of the host cell. Temporal profiling of metabolic flux in macrophages infected with differently virulent Mtb strains revealed that the pathogen targets a core subset of host reactions to integrate pathways facilitating macrophage survival with those promoting Mtb sustenance. This integration provides an axis where host- and pathogen-derived factors converge to define determinants of pathogenicity. The study found that the requirement for macrophage survival sensitizes TB susceptibility to the glycemic status of the individual, while mediation by the pathogen ensures that the virulence properties of the infecting strain contribute to the resulting pathology. The findings suggest that circulating glucose levels also contribute to pathogenicity by influencing macrophage apoptosis, revealing an additional facet to the relationship between diabetes and TB. The study highlights the importance of metabolic intervention in dictating the pathology of TB, supporting a reevaluation of existing paradigms for understanding Mtb pathogenicity. The research provides new insights into the complex interplay between host and pathogen, and has implications for the development of effective vaccines and treatments against TB.
ZHP-3, the Caenorhabditis elegans ortholog of the budding yeast ZIP3 gene, plays a crucial role in crossover recombination during meiosis. The protein's localization is highly dynamic, shifting from along the length of the synaptonemal complex (SC) to an asymmetric localization on the SC and eventually becoming restricted to foci that mark crossover recombination events. A zhp-3::gfp transgene partially complements a null mutation, revealing a separation of function: while the fusion protein promotes nearly wild-type levels of recombination, aneuploidy among the progeny is high, indicating defects in meiotic chromosome segregation. The structure of bivalents is perturbed in this mutant, suggesting that the chromosome segregation defect results from an inability to properly remodel chromosomes in response to crossovers. The smo-1 mutants exhibit phenotypes similar to zhp-3::gfp mutants at higher temperatures, and smo-1; zhp-3::gfp double mutants exhibit more severe meiotic defects than either single mutant, consistent with a role for SUMO in the process of SC disassembly and bivalent differentiation. The study proposes that coordination of crossover recombination with SC disassembly and bivalent formation reflects a conserved role of Zip3/ZHP-3 in coupling recombination with SC morphogenesis. The identification of ZHP-3 and/or SUMO targets on meiotic chromosomes will refine our understanding of how chromosome structure is remodeled to accompany reciprocal exchange.
Aedes albopictus, a tropical invasive mosquito species, has become a public health concern in temperate regions of Europe and the US due to its ability to transmit exotic arboviruses and cause nuisance problems. This study investigated the effects of eco-climatic factors on the abundance and dynamics of Ae. albopictus in metropolitan and sub-urban/rural sites in Rome, Italy, which was colonized in 1997 and is now one of the most infested metropolitan areas in Southern Europe. Longitudinal adult monitoring was conducted along a 70 km transect across and beyond the metropolitan area, and two fine-scale spatiotemporal datasets were analyzed to examine the impact of climatic and socio-environmental variables on Ae. albopictus abundance and dynamics.

The results showed that highly anthropized habitats were associated with high adult abundance in both metropolitan and sub-urban/rural areas, with "small green islands" corresponding to hotspots of abundance in metropolitan areas only. A bimodal seasonal dynamics was observed, with a second peak of abundance in autumn due to heavy rains and permissive temperatures. The study found that an increase in vegetation cover was negatively associated with mosquito abundance in both environments. The results suggest that public mosquito control measures should be prioritized in temperate urban areas where nuisance, human-mosquito contact, and risk of local arbovirus transmission are higher, and highlight potential public health risks after the summer months typically associated with high mosquito densities.
The study investigated the role of phthiocerol dimycocerosates ( DIM ) in the invasion of macrophages by Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ). DIM are major virulence factors of Mtb, particularly during the early stages of infection. Using Mtb mutants deleted for genes involved in DIM biosynthesis, the researchers found that DIM participate in both receptor-dependent phagocytosis of Mtb and the prevention of phagosomal acidification. The effects of DIM required a state of membrane fluidity, as demonstrated by experiments with cholesterol-depleting drugs that abolished the differences in phagocytosis efficiency and phagosome acidification between wild-type and mutant strains. The insertion of a new cholesterol-pyrene probe in living cells showed that the polarity of the membrane hydrophobic core changed upon contact with Mtb, while the lateral diffusion of cholesterol remained unaffected. This effect was dependent on DIM and consistent with the effect observed following DIM insertion in model membranes. The study proposes that DIM control the invasion of macrophages by Mtb by targeting lipid organization in the host membrane, thereby modifying its biophysical properties. The DIM-induced changes in lipid ordering favor the efficiency of receptor-mediated phagocytosis of Mtb and contribute to the control of phagosomal pH, creating a protective niche for the bacteria. The study highlights the importance of DIM in the pathogenesis of Mtb and provides new insights into the mechanisms of Mtb invasion of host cells.
The article presents a novel systematic analysis of the dynamics of small neural networks composed of homogeneous populations of excitatory and inhibitory firing-rate neurons. The authors develop a method to study the local and global bifurcations of neural activity in these networks, which is largely analytically tractable. They find that for strong inhibition, these networks exhibit complex dynamics due to the formation of multiple branching solutions of the neural dynamics equations that emerge through spontaneous symmetry-breaking. This phenomenon is a finite-size effect of the network and reveals qualitative differences between mesoscopic cortical circuits and their mean-field approximation. The most significant consequence of spontaneous symmetry-breaking is the ability of mesoscopic networks to regulate their degree of functional heterogeneity, which is thought to help reduce the detrimental effect of noise correlations on cortical information processing. The authors extend previous work on the analysis of small neural networks by deriving exact expressions of the bifurcation manifolds and relaxing the constraints on synaptic weights. Their method allows for the study of networks composed of a few tens of neurons, which is the lower bound of the mesoscopic scale. The results provide new insights into the dynamics of small neural networks and highlight the importance of considering finite-size effects in the study of neural circuits.
This study investigated the presence and viability of Leishmania parasites in extralesional sites of patients with dermal leishmaniasis. To determine the viability of parasites, the researchers used Leishmania 7SLRNA as a target for polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification. The results showed that Leishmania 7SLRNA genes and transcripts were detected in extralesional tissues, including blood monocytes, tonsils, and normal skin, in 100% and 73% of patients, respectively. The copy number of 7SLRNA transcripts was correlated with the dose and time-dependent reduction of parasite viability in response to Glucantime, confirming the validity of this target as a marker of viability. The study also found that 7SLRNA transcripts were most frequently detected in monocytes, followed by tonsil swabs and healthy skin aspirates. The detection and quantification of parasites in extralesional tissues are important for determining the status of infection, monitoring treatment, and resolving gaps in the understanding of the natural history of human infection. The study demonstrated that amplification of 7SLRNA transcripts detects the presence of live parasites, allowing for a parasitological diagnosis to be achieved. The findings suggest that viable Leishmania parasites are present in extralesional sites, including blood monocytes, tonsils, and normal skin, during active dermal leishmaniasis, and that Leishmania 7SLRNA is an informative target for clinical and epidemiologic investigations of human leishmaniasis.
The study investigated the relationship between chromatin features and DNA replication timing in Drosophila using a comprehensive data collection of 95 chromatin binding proteins (CBPs) and histone modifications (HMs). A quantitative statistical model was developed to predict DNA replication timing based on linear combinations of chromatin features. The results showed that combinations of HMs and their pairwise interactions are key to achieving accurate predictions, suggesting that combinatorial HM patterns contribute to the regulation of DNA replication timing. The model was able to predict replication timing with high accuracy genome-wide and across cell types, reaching 80% of the full model accuracy using six model terms. Independent feature importance and model analyses led to the derivation of a simplified, biologically interpretable model of the relationship between chromatin landscape and replication timing. Furthermore, the study demonstrated that pairwise combinations of HMs can predict differential DNA replication timing across different cell types. The findings provide support for the existence of combinatorial HM patterns for DNA replication and reveal cell-type independent key elements thereof, which may contribute to elucidating the regulatory mode of this fundamental cellular process.
Title: Air Travel Is Associated with Intracontinental Spread of Dengue Virus Serotypes 1–3 in Brazil

    Dengue virus, which infects 390 million people annually and causes at least 25,000 deaths, is a significant public health concern in tropical and subtropical regions. This study investigated the spatial dynamics of dengue virus serotypes 1, 2, and 3 in Brazil by analyzing complete genome sequences. The results indicate that new lineages of these serotypes are introduced to Brazil approximately every 7-10 years, with the Caribbean region being the primary source of these introductions. The new lineages then disperse at a rate of approximately 0.5 km/day.

    A statistical analysis of evolutionary, epidemiological, and ecological data suggests that aerial transportation of humans and/or vector mosquitoes, rather than Aedes aegypti infestation rates or geographical distances, is the primary driver of dengue virus spread in Brazil. The study used 178 Brazilian genome sequences to determine the factors underlying dengue virus dispersal on a countrywide scale. The results indicate that air travel plays a significant role in the spread of dengue virus within Brazil, with periodic dengue serotype-specific peaks in incidence coinciding with the introduction of new lineages every 7-10 years. The study highlights the importance of air traffic fluxes in the spatial spread of dengue virus within Brazil and underscores the need for caution when making predictions about viral emergence.
The study investigated how differences in receptive field (RF) organization across three parallel sensory maps in weakly electric fish influence correlations between the activities of electrosensory pyramidal neurons. The researchers used a combination of mathematical modeling and in vivo electrophysiology to examine the relationship between RF structure and correlated neural activity. Contrary to predictions based on RF center size and overlap, the study found that electrosensory pyramidal neurons across all three segments displayed nearly identical correlations. To explain this result, the researchers incorporated the effects of RF surround in their model and found that multiple RF structures gave rise to similar levels of correlation. The study suggests that RF center overlap alone does not determine correlations, which has important implications for understanding how RF structure influences correlated neural activity. The results show that the sign and magnitude of correlations are largely determined by the relative strength of positively and negatively correlated inputs. The study highlights the importance of considering the effects of RF surround in understanding neural correlations and provides new insights into the neural code. The findings have implications for understanding how sensory information is encoded and processed in the brain.
The Sign Rule and Beyond: Boundary Effects, Flexibility, and Noise Correlations in Neural Population Codes provides a comprehensive analysis of the impact of noise correlations on population coding in sensory neurons. The study investigates how coding performance varies as a function of noise correlations, with all other aspects of the problem held constant. The results yield unifying insights into the role of noise correlations, summarized in the form of theorems and illustrated with numerical examples involving neurons with diverse tuning curves. The main contributions of the study are threefold. First, the sign rule (SR) is generalized to prove that if noise correlations between pairs of neurons have opposite signs compared to their signal correlations, coding performance will improve compared to the independent case. This holds for three different metrics of coding performance and for arbitrary tuning curves and levels of heterogeneity. Second, the SR is shown to be a necessary but not sufficient condition for good coding, and a diverse set of correlation structures can improve coding, many of which violate the SR. Third, a novel set of necessary and sufficient conditions is provided under which coding performance will be as good as it would be if there were no noise present at all. The study provides a general mathematical setup that makes no assumptions about the shapes or heterogeneity of neural tuning curves or variances in neural responses, offering insights into the problem of population coding.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa exoproducts play a significant role in determining the efficacy of antibiotics against Staphylococcus aureus in chronic coinfections. A study investigated the impact of P. aeruginosa on S. aureus antibiotic susceptibility using a panel of P. aeruginosa burn wound and cystic fibrosis (CF) lung isolates. The results showed that P. aeruginosa alters S. aureus susceptibility to bactericidal antibiotics in a variable, strain-dependent manner. The study identified three independent interactions responsible for antagonizing or potentiating antibiotic activity against S. aureus: P. aeruginosa LasA endopeptidase potentiates lysis of S. aureus by vancomycin, rhamnolipids facilitate proton-motive force-independent tobramycin uptake, and 2-heptyl-4-hydroxyquinoline N-oxide (HQNO) induces multidrug tolerance in S. aureus through respiratory inhibition and reduction of cellular ATP. The production of these factors varies between clinical isolates and corresponds to the capacity of each isolate to alter S. aureus antibiotic susceptibility. Furthermore, the study demonstrated that vancomycin treatment of a S. aureus mouse burn infection is potentiated by the presence of a LasA-producing P. aeruginosa population. These findings suggest that antibiotic susceptibility is complex and dependent not only on the genotype of the pathogen being targeted but also on interactions with other microorganisms in the infection environment. The study highlights the importance of considering these interactions to improve the treatment of polymicrobial infections.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection is associated with thrombocytopenia and platelet dysfunction, which can contribute to complications such as bleeding and plasma leakage. Two observational cohort studies conducted in Indonesia investigated the mechanisms of platelet clearance in DENV infection. The studies found that adult patients with DENV had higher plasma concentrations of von Willebrand factor (VWF) antigen and active VWF, and that circulating platelets had bound more VWF to their membrane. The amount of platelet-VWF binding correlated well with platelet count. Furthermore, sialic acid levels in DENV patients were significantly reduced, as assessed by the binding of Sambucus nigra lectin (SNA) and Maackia amurensis lectin II (MAL-II) to platelets. The neuraminidase inhibitor oseltamivir reduced VWF-induced platelet desialylation. The data demonstrate that excessive binding of VWF to platelets in DENV results in neuraminidase-mediated platelet desialylation and platelet clearance. The study suggests that oseltamivir might be a novel treatment option for severe thrombocytopenia in DENV infection. Platelet sialylation was not altered by in vitro exposure of platelets to DENV nonstructural protein 1 or cultured DENV. The binding of VWF to glycoprotein 1b on platelets using the VWF-activating protein ristocetin resulted in the removal of platelet sialic acid by translocation of platelet neuraminidase to the platelet surface.
A comprehensive annotation of bidirectional promoters in the human genome has been conducted to identify co-regulation among breast and ovarian cancer genes. Bidirectional promoters are regulatory regions that control the expression of two adjacent genes with transcription start sites directed away from each other. The study used a database of spliced-expressed sequence tags ( ESTs ) to identify the most complete collection of human transcripts under the control of bidirectional promoters. A rigorous screen of the spliced EST data revealed new bidirectional promoters, many of which functioned as alternative promoters or regulated novel transcripts. The analysis showed a highly significant enrichment of bidirectional promoters in genes implicated in somatic cancer, including a substantial number of genes implicated in breast and ovarian cancers. Using microarray expression data from 79 human tissues, the study verified regulatory networks among genes controlled by bidirectional promoters. Subsets of these promoters contained similar combinations of transcription factor binding sites, including evolutionarily conserved ETS factor binding sites in ERBB2, FANCD2, and BRCA2. The study suggests that bidirectional promoters may regulate co-expression patterns among groups of genes, and that misregulation of these promoters could play a pivotal role in cancer development. The findings have implications for understanding the molecular events that contribute to disease, particularly in breast and ovarian cancers.
Title: Numerous Transitions of Sex Chromosomes in Diptera
    Summary: 
    A comprehensive genomic analysis of 37 fly species across 22 Diptera families reveals a striking diversity of sex chromosome configurations. While Diptera flies typically exhibit XY sex chromosomes and a conserved karyotype, the study uncovers over a dozen distinct sex chromosome arrangements. The small dot chromosome is found to be the sex chromosome in many species, suggesting it is the ancestral karyotype of higher Diptera. However, some species exhibit undifferentiated sex chromosomes, while others have a different chromosome replacing the dot as the sex chromosome or have up to three chromosomal elements incorporated into the sex chromosomes. Additionally, some species display female heterogamety ( ZW sex chromosomes ). Transcriptome analysis indicates that dosage compensation has evolved multiple times in flies through the up-regulation of the single X chromosome in males. Furthermore, X chromosomes show a deficiency of genes with male-biased expression, possibly due to sex-specific selective pressures. These findings provide a rich resource for studying sex chromosome biology in a comparative manner and demonstrate that similar selective forces have shaped the evolution of sex chromosomes in diverse fly taxa. The study suggests that sex chromosomes have been lost, gained, rearranged, or replaced multiple times over the course of Diptera evolution, highlighting the dynamic nature of sex chromosome evolution in flies.
The study investigated the presence of Zika virus (ZIKV) antibodies in mothers from Hawaii who delivered babies with and without microcephaly between 2009 and 2012. Blood samples from six mothers who gave birth to babies with microcephaly and 12 mothers who gave birth to healthy babies were tested for ZIKV IgM and IgG antibodies using commercially available ELISA kits. The results showed that one mother who delivered a baby with microcephaly tested positive for ZIKV IgM antibody (16.6%), and three mothers tested positive for ZIKV IgG antibody (50%). ZIKV IgG antibody-positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with microcephaly than mothers who were negative for ZIKV IgG antibodies, with an odds ratio of 11.0 (95% CI = 0.8-147.9, p = 0.083). Similarly, ZIKV IgM antibody-positive mothers were also more likely to deliver babies with microcephaly than mothers who were negative for ZIKV IgM antibody, with an odds ratio of 6.8 (95% CI = 0.2-195.1, p = 0.333). These findings provide further evidence of a link between ZIKV infection and microcephaly and suggest that ZIKV-positive cases and associated microcephaly may have occurred in the United States as early as 2009. The study's results are consistent with previous reports of ZIKV outbreaks in Southeast Asia, the Pacific Islands, and Africa.
The study aimed to source-track Mycobacterium ulcerans (MU) infections in the Ashanti Region, Ghana, by matching Variable Number Tandem Repeat (VNTR) profiles of MU in human samples to those in the environment. Environmental samples were collected from 10 water bodies in four Buruli ulcer (BU) endemic communities. Four VNTR loci in the MU Agy99 genome were used to genotype environmental MU ecovars and those from 14 confirmed BU patients within the same study area. The results showed that MU was present in three different types of water bodies, with significantly higher levels in biofilm samples. Four MU genotypes (W, X, Y, and Z) were typed in both human and environmental samples, while other reported genotypes were only found in water bodies. Animal trapping identified one mouse with a lesion characteristic of BU, which was confirmed as an MU infection. The study suggests that patients may have been infected from community-associated water bodies and that small mammals within endemic communities could be susceptible to MU infections. The findings indicate that M. ulcerans transmission could involve several routes where humans have contact with risk environments, which may be further compounded by water bodies acting as vehicles for disseminating strains. The study highlights the importance of considering the environmental component in understanding the transmission of MU infections.
The global distribution and drivers of alien bird species richness were investigated using an extensive database of 27,723 distribution records for 971 alien bird species worldwide. The study found that the locations of origin and introduction of alien birds were initially driven by European colonialism, mainly from Britain, but recent introductions involve more species and countries and are driven by increasing economic activity. The results show that alien bird species richness is highest at midlatitudes and is strongly determined by anthropogenic effects, particularly the number of species introduced, known as colonisation pressure. Environmental drivers also play a significant role, with native and alien species richness being positively associated. The study demonstrates that colonisation pressure is a key factor in understanding alien species richness and that areas with high native species richness are not resistant to colonisation by alien species at the global scale. The findings highlight the ongoing threats to global environments from species introductions. The study used a combination of abiotic, biotic, and anthropogenic variables to identify the determinants of alien species richness and found that both human and biotic factors influence global patterns of alien species richness in birds. The results provide new insights into the global distribution of alien bird species and the drivers of their richness.
Upstream Binding Factor (UBF) is a multi-HMGB-box protein that plays a crucial role in the transcription of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes by RNA polymerase I (RPI/PolI). Previous studies have shown that UBF is essential for the recruitment of the pre-initiation complex SL1/TIF1B and the active epigenetic state of rRNA genes. However, its role in RPI transcription has been questioned due to its poor DNA sequence selectivity and ability to form nucleosome-like nucleoprotein complexes.

    Conditional deletion of UBF in mouse embryos revealed that it is essential for embryo development beyond the morula stage. In cell cultures, conditional deletion of UBF showed that it is required for rRNA gene transcription and defines the active chromatin conformation of both gene and enhancer sequences. Loss of UBF prevents the formation of the SL1/TIF1B pre-initiation complex and recruitment of the RPI-Rrn3/TIF1A complex, and is accompanied by the recruitment of H3K9me3, canonical histone H1, and HP1α.

    Unexpectedly, genes retain penta-acetyl H4 and H2A.Z, suggesting that even in the absence of UBF, rRNA genes can maintain a potentially active state. In contrast to canonical histone H1, binding of H1.4 is dependent on UBF, indicating a positive role in gene activity. Loss of UBF also induces the formation of a large sub-nuclear structure resembling the nucleolar precursor body (NPB) of oocytes and early embryos, which contains rRNA synthesis and processing factors but does not associate with the rRNA gene loci (NORs).
This study investigates the role of Wingless/Wnt (Wg) signaling in adult intestinal compartmentalization in Drosophila. Contrary to the conventional model, which suggests that Wg secretion and movement are essential for long-range signaling in tissue patterning, the authors found that a membrane-tethered form of Wg produced viable adults with largely normal external morphology, indicating that Wg secretion and movement may be dispensable for tissue patterning. However, further investigation in the adult intestine revealed that the critical roles of Wg during adult intestinal development, including regulation of target gene activation, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell fate specification, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling crosstalk with the Decapentaplegic pathway, are all disrupted by Wg tethering. These findings provide new evidence that supports the requirement for the direct, long-range action of Wg in tissue patterning. The study highlights the importance of Wg signaling gradients in the adult intestine, which demarcate all major boundaries between compartments, and suggests that Wg movement is critical for proper Wg pathway activation during adult gut development. The results have implications for our understanding of animal development, tissue homeostasis, and Wnt-driven disease, and may uncover general principles that determine the contexts in which the long-range action of Wnt is essential.
The study investigated the role of the urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA) in the pathogenesis of invasive Group A streptococcal (GAS) infection. It was found that uPA contributes to plasmin recruitment and subsequent invasive disease initiation in vivo. In the absence of a source of host plasminogen activators, streptokinase (Ska) was required to facilitate cell surface plasmin acquisition by GAS. However, in the absence of Ska, host activators were sufficient to promote cell surface plasmin acquisition by GAS strain 5448 during incubation with plasminogen or human plasma. Furthermore, GAS were able to mediate a significant increase in the activation of zymogen pro-uPA in human plasma. A previously undescribed transgenic mouse model of infection was employed to assess the contribution of uPA to invasive GAS disease. Both C57/black 6J and AlbPLG1 mice expressing the human plasminogen transgene were significantly more susceptible to invasive GAS disease than uPA−/− mice. The observed decrease in virulence in uPA−/− mice was found to correlate directly with a decrease in bacterial dissemination and reduced cell surface plasmin accumulation by GAS. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of GAS pathogenesis and research aimed at therapeutic targeting of plasminogen activation in invasive bacterial infections.
Helicobacter pylori exploits a unique repertoire of type IV secretion system (T4SS) components for pilus assembly at the bacteria-host cell interface. The cag pathogenicity island (cag PAI) encodes components of the T4SS that translocates the bacterial oncoprotein CagA into gastric epithelial cells. CagL, CagI, and CagH are specialized components of the cag T4SS that bind the host receptor α5β1 integrin and are encoded by contiguous genes in the cag PAI. These proteins are detectable on the bacterial surface and are required for CagA translocation into host cells and H. pylori-induced IL-8 secretion by gastric epithelial cells. Scanning electron microscopy analysis reveals that these proteins are involved in the formation of pili at the interface between H. pylori and gastric epithelial cells. A ΔcagI and ΔcagL mutant strain fails to form pili, whereas a ΔcagH mutant strain exhibits a hyperpiliated phenotype and produces pili that are elongated and thickened compared to those of the wild-type strain. A conserved C-terminal hexapeptide motif is present in CagH, CagI, and CagL, and deletion of these motifs results in abrogation of CagA translocation and IL-8 induction, and the C-terminal motifs of CagI and CagL are required for formation of pili. These results indicate that CagH, CagI, and CagL are components of a T4SS subassembly involved in pilus biogenesis and highlight the important role played by unique constituents of the H. pylori cag T4SS.
Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a chronic disease of cattle caused by Mycobacterium bovis, a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex group of bacteria. To develop a long-term solution for controlling the disease, researchers have prioritized the development of a cattle vaccine against bTB. A recent study aimed to identify host correlates of protection by analyzing the global gene transcriptome of vaccinated cattle. Calves were vaccinated with BCG or a heterologous BCG prime adenovirally vectored subunit boosting protocol, and their protective efficacy was determined after Mycobacterium bovis challenge. The study found that 668 genes were differentially expressed in vaccinated-protected cattle compared to vaccinated-unprotected and unvaccinated control cattle. Cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction was the most significant pathway related to this dataset, with interleukin-22 (IL-22) expression identified as the dominant surrogate of protection, alongside interferon-gamma (INF-γ). The importance of IL-22 as a predictor of vaccine efficacy was further confirmed by RT-qPCR in an independent set of PBMC samples from BCG-vaccinated and unvaccinated calves. These findings suggest that IL-22 plays a crucial role in protection against bTB and may serve as a biomarker for predicting vaccine efficacy. This study contributes to the development of a cattle vaccine against bTB and highlights the potential of IL-22 as a predictive biomarker for vaccine success.
In Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic intestinal epithelial cells, non-centrosomal microtubule organizing centers (ncMTOCs) play a crucial role in regulating microtubule organization and dynamics. The γ-tubulin ring complex (γ-TuRC) and AIR-1/Aurora A are essential centrosomal microtubule nucleators that localize to the apical ncMTOC. The core γ-TuRC component GIP-1/GCP3 is required to recruit other γ-TuRC components, including MZT-1/MZT1, to the apical ncMTOC. In contrast, AIR-1 and MZT-1 are specifically required to recruit γ-TuRC to the centrosome, but not to centrioles or the apical ncMTOC. Surprisingly, microtubules remain robustly organized at the apical ncMTOC upon γ-TuRC and AIR-1 co-depletion, and upon depletion of other known microtubule regulators. However, loss of GIP-1 removes a subset of dynamic EBP-2/EB1–marked microtubules, and the remaining dynamic microtubules grow faster. These results suggest that different microtubule organizing centers use discrete proteins for their function, and that the apical ncMTOC is composed of distinct populations of γ-TuRC-dependent and -independent microtubules that compete for a limited pool of resources.
Title: Comparison of Phasing Strategies for Whole Human Genomes
    A study compared 11 different approaches to phasing human genomes, which involves determining the origin of maternal and paternal chromosomes. Most human sequencing initiatives do not directly phase the genome due to costs and complexities. The study used the Genome-In-A-Bottle (GIAB) phased version of the NA12878 genome as a gold standard to evaluate the performance of various phasing strategies. The approaches included laboratory-based assays and computational methods that reconstruct phase information from sequencing reads and population-level haplotype frequency information.

    The study assessed the performance of the 11 approaches using metrics such as switch error rates, haplotype block lengths, and phasing accuracy. The results suggest that a hybrid approach combining population-based phasing, genome-wide sequencing read data, and a large reference panel of variant and haplotype frequencies provides a fast and efficient way to produce highly accurate phase-resolved individual human genomes. The inclusion of parental genotype data within a population-based phasing strategy can provide a ten-fold reduction in phasing errors. A majority voting scheme for constructing a consensus haplotype combining multiple predictions was also considered for enhanced performance and site coverage. The study identified DNA sequence signatures associated with genomic regions harboring phasing switch errors, including regions of low polymorphism or SNV density. The results indicate that hybrid computational approaches to phasing a single genome are accurate and cost-effective, nearly matching or surpassing laboratory-based approaches.
This study investigated the role of ATPase activity in the type-III protein secretion system of Salmonella enterica. Type-III protein secretion systems are used by gram-negative pathogens to secrete proteins into host cells. The flagellar type-III secretion apparatus utilizes both the proton motive force (PMF) and ATP hydrolysis to energize substrate unfolding and translocation. The study found that mutations that increased the PMF and flagellar substrate levels allowed for the formation of functional flagella in the absence of type-III ATPase activity. Additionally, increased PMF bypassed the requirement of the Salmonella pathogenicity island 1 (SPI-1) virulence-associated type-III ATPase for secretion. These results suggest that ATPase activity is not universally required for protein export via type-III secretion systems. The study proposes that the function of the T3SS-associated ATPase complex is to deliver secretion substrates to the export apparatus and ensure efficient substrate unfolding. The findings have important implications for the evolution of the bacterial flagellum and type-III secretion systems. The study demonstrates that type-III protein secretion can occur efficiently in the absence of ATPase activity, revealing the dispensability of ATPase activity in the type-III protein export process.
The emergence of switch-like behavior in gene regulatory networks (GRNs) is crucial for various biological functions, including cellular differentiation and cell cycle control. However, determining the network topologies that can exhibit bistability remains a challenge due to the vast variety of GRNs for a small number of components. A comprehensive in silico survey using chemical reaction network theory was conducted to investigate the capacity for bistability in over 40,000 simple networks formed by two transcription factor-coding genes and their associated proteins. The analysis revealed that approximately 90% of these GRN models can exhibit bistability for certain reaction rate constants, including several circuits without transcription factor cooperativity. A topological sorting of the two-gene family of networks identified eleven minimal bistable networks that do not contain smaller bistable subnetworks. These findings suggest that the capacity for switch-like behavior in GRNs arises with relative ease and is not easily lost through network evolution. The systematic application of chemical reaction network theory to bistable network identification in real biological systems was demonstrated by integrating publicly available data from Saccharomyces cerevisiae, predicting several GRNs to behave in a bistable fashion. The study highlights the potential of this approach to provide hypotheses for further experimentation and guidance for systems with available interaction data.
Mutations in the HYAL2 gene, which encodes the enzyme hyaluronidase 2, have been identified as a new genetic cause of orofacial clefting in humans and mice. Hyaluronidase 2 is responsible for degrading extracellular hyaluronan, a critical component of the developing heart and palatal shelf matrix. The study found that mutations in HYAL2 lead to reduced levels of the enzyme, resulting in craniofacial abnormalities, including submucosal cleft palate, in both humans and mice. Additionally, cor triatriatum sinister and hearing loss were identified as incompletely penetrant features in affected humans and mice, respectively. The study highlights the importance of hyaluronidase enzymes in human and mouse development and reveals a previously unrecognized pathway involved in the pathogenesis of orofacial clefting, myopia, and cor triatriatum sinister. The findings demonstrate that a deficiency of the HA-degrading enzyme HYAL2 is a novel cause of syndromic orofacial clefting in humans and submucosal cleft palate in mice, and define the first molecular explanation for cor triatriatum sinister in humans. The study provides evidence of the importance of HYAL2 for normal heart development in humans and mice, and identifies mutation of HYAL2 as the first described molecular mechanism for cor triatriatum sinister in humans.
The regeneration of mechanosensory tip links in auditory hair cells is essential for sound detection in the inner ear. Current models propose a static composition of the tip link, consisting of protocadherin 15 ( PCDH15 ) at the lower end and cadherin 23 ( CDH23 ) at the upper end. However, this study reveals that functional tip links can have at least two molecular compositions : PCDH15/CDH23 and PCDH15/PCDH15. During regeneration, shorter tip links containing nearly equal amounts of PCDH15 at both ends appear first and mediate mechanotransduction currents of normal amplitude but abnormal Ca2+-dependent decay. The mature PCDH15/CDH23 tip link composition is re-established later, concomitant with complete recovery of adaptation. This two-step molecular remodeling process may underlie the formation of tip links in the developing hair bundle, their turnover in the mature bundle, and their regeneration after intense acoustical stimulation. The study used a novel implementation of backscatter electron scanning microscopy to visualize immuno-gold particles and stereocilia links of only a few nanometers in diameter. The findings provide a molecular mechanism for regeneration and maintenance of mechanosensory function in postmitotic auditory hair cells and could help identify elusive components of the mechanotransduction machinery.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection can cause a spectrum of clinical manifestations, ranging from mild dengue fever (DF) to life-threatening dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF). To understand the mechanisms that trigger the transition from DF to DHF, researchers conducted a mass spectrometry-based metabolomic profiling of sera from adult DF and DHF patients at the critical and recovery phases of infection. The study identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites between DF and DHF patients at the critical phase, including bile acids, purines, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Notably, bile acids were found to be up to 5-fold higher in DHF patients compared to DF patients, and were correlated with liver injury markers aspartate transaminase (AST) and alanine transaminase (ALT). Uric acid, the most abundant antioxidant in the blood, was observed to be 1.5-fold lower in DHF patients, suggesting a decreased capacity for endogenous antioxidant defense and elevated oxidative stress. In the recovery phase, eight metabolites remained significantly altered in DHF patients, indicating a potential prolonged adverse impact on the liver due to DENV infection. The study provides insights into the mechanisms of DHF pathogenesis and identifies altered metabolic pathways linked to DHF, which may serve as novel therapeutic targets for dengue management.
The study identifies and characterizes the guanosine 5’-monophosphate reductase (GMPR) enzyme in Trypanosoma brucei, a protozoan parasite responsible for African trypanosomiasis. The GMPR enzyme catalyzes the conversion of guanosine 5’-monophosphate (GMP) to inosine 5’-monophosphate (IMP), playing a crucial role in maintaining the intracellular balance of purine nucleotides. The researchers found that the GMPR protein in T. brucei is localized to glycosomes and possesses a unique insertion of a tandem repeat of the cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) domain, which is absent in mammalian and bacterial GMPRs. The recombinant protein of T. brucei GMPR exhibits distinct enzymatic properties compared to its mammalian counterparts, including different affinities for GMP and NADPH, and is activated by the addition of monovalent cations such as K+ and NH4+. Furthermore, the study shows that the monophosphate form of the purine nucleoside analog ribavirin inhibits T. brucei GMPR activity. The results suggest that the mechanism of the GMPR reaction in T. brucei is distinct from that in host organisms. The study also demonstrates the inhibitory effect of ribavirin on the proliferation of trypanosomes in a dose-dependent manner, indicating the potential of ribavirin as a new therapeutic agent against African trypanosomiasis.
Sodium channel blockers are used to control electrical excitability in cells as a treatment for conditions such as epileptic seizures and cardiac arrhythmia. To develop the next generation of drugs that can selectively target one of the nine types of voltage-gated sodium channels expressed in the body, a better understanding of how current channel blockers work is required. This study used molecular dynamics simulations to elucidate the position at which the sodium channel blocking drugs benzocaine and phenytoin bind to the protein NavAb, a bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel. The results show that both drugs have two likely binding sites in the pore, characterized by nonspecific, hydrophobic interactions: one just above the activation gate and one at the entrance to the lateral lipid-filled fenestrations. Three independent methods found the same sites, suggesting that binding to the activation gate is slightly more favorable than at the fenestration. The study also found that both drugs can pass through the fenestrations into the lipid with only small energy barriers, suggesting that this can represent the long-postulated hydrophobic entrance route for neutral drugs. The simulations highlight the importance of a number of residues in directing drugs into and through the fenestration, and in forming the drug binding sites. These findings provide new insights into the mode of action of sodium channel inhibitors and have implications for the development of new drugs that can selectively target one of the nine types of voltage-gated sodium channels expressed in the body.
The study investigated the role of MyD88 signaling in specific cell types during intestinal infection with Citrobacter rodentium (C. rodentium). MyD88 is a key adaptor molecule in the Toll-like receptor and IL-1 receptor signaling pathways, which are essential for inducing protective host responses against bacterial infections. However, the cell type-specific contribution of MyD88 to intestinal immunity against C. rodentium was poorly understood. To address this knowledge gap, the authors employed a novel mouse model that allowed for the cell type-specific reactivation of functional MyD88 expression in MyD88-deficient mice. The results showed that MyD88 signaling in dendritic cells (DCs) was sufficient to activate intestinal DCs, induce the early group 3 innate lymphoid cell (ILC3) response, and promote the development of colonic Th17/Th1 cells in response to C. rodentium infection. In contrast, restricting MyD88 signaling to macrophages, T cells, or ILC3 did not induce efficient intestinal immune responses. Notably, the study also found that MyD88 signaling in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) partially protected mice during intestinal infection, associated with enhanced epithelial barrier integrity and increased expression of antimicrobial peptides and acute phase proteins. These findings suggest that MyD88 signaling in DCs and IECs is essential and sufficient to induce a full spectrum of host responses against C. rodentium infection.
The article explores the use of anti-Ov16 IgG4 antibody prevalence as an indicator for evaluating and making decisions in onchocerciasis elimination programmes. Onchocerciasis is targeted for elimination in Africa through annual or biannual ivermectin mass drug administration (MDA). An immunodiagnostic test based on the detection of human IgG4 antibodies to the Onchocerca volvulus-specific antigen Ov16 is recommended for determining whether transmission is interrupted and mass treatment can stop. A mathematical model, ONCHOSIM, was extended to include output on the Ov16 antibody serostatus of individuals. The model assumes that seroconversion is triggered by the first worm establishing in the host, with seroconversion occurring before maturation, after maturation, or only after the start of microfilariae (mf) production. The study investigates the relationship between post-MDA Ov16 antibody prevalence in children, measured one year after the last round of MDA, and the duration and coverage of MDA, mf prevalence in the population, and the probability that onchocerciasis is eventually eliminated. The results show that both mf prevalence in the population aged 5 years and above and Ov16 antibody prevalence in children under 10 declined with increasing duration of MDA. The association between these indicators and the model-predicted probability of elimination was found to depend on baseline endemicity levels, assumptions regarding the trigger of seroconversion, and diagnostic test characteristics. The study highlights the importance of understanding the dynamics of Ov16 antibody responses for accurate interpretation of seroprevalence data and precise estimation of the endpoint for MDA.
The study investigated the acquisition of drug resistance and dependence by prions, misfolded proteins that can cause neurodegenerative diseases. The researchers found that prion strains can change their properties when propagated in different environments. For example, when swainsonine-sensitive 22L prions were propagated in PK1 cells in the presence of swainsonine, drug-resistant variants emerged. This suggests that prions constitute quasi-populations comprising a range of variants with different properties, from which the fittest are selected in a particular environment. The study also showed that prion populations developed heterogeneity even after biological cloning, indicating that mutation-like processes occur at the conformational level.

The researchers investigated whether it was possible to select swainsonine-resistant variants of RML prions, which are naturally swainsonine-sensitive. They found that this was not possible with the standard line of PK1 cells, but in certain PK1 sublines, swainsonine-resistant and even swainsonine-dependent populations could be isolated. These populations could be passaged indefinitely in PK1 cells, even in the absence of the drug, without losing swainsonine dependence. The misfolded prion protein associated with a swainsonine-dependent variant was less rapidly cleared in PK1 cells than that associated with its drug-sensitive counterpart, indicating that structural differences of the misfolded PrP underlie the properties of the prions.

The study suggests that propagation of prions in the presence of an inhibitory drug may not only cause the selection of drug-resistant prions but also of stable variants that propagate more efficiently in the presence of the drug. These adaptations are most likely due to conformational changes of the abnormal prion protein.
The study exhaustively analyzed a genotype-phenotype map for a space of 1015 metabolisms that encodes all possible subsets of 51 reactions in central carbon metabolism. Using flux balance analysis, the researchers predicted the viability of these metabolisms on 10 different carbon sources, resulting in 1024 potential metabolic phenotypes. The analysis revealed that although viable metabolisms with any one phenotype comprise a tiny fraction of genotype space, their absolute numbers exceed 109 for some phenotypes. Metabolisms with any one phenotype typically form a single network of genotypes that extends far or all the way through metabolic genotype space, where any two genotypes can be reached from each other through a series of single reaction changes. The minimal distance of genotype networks associated with different phenotypes is small, allowing for the potential to reach metabolisms with novel phenotypes – viable on new carbon sources – through one or few genotypic changes. The study also found that increasing metabolic complexity enhances the potential for both evolutionary conservation and evolutionary innovation. Furthermore, the analysis showed that the neighborhoods of different metabolisms viable on the same carbon source contain different novel phenotypes, which may depend on where in metabolic genotype space a viable metabolism is located.
The study analyzed the genetic variation and phylogeography of the Triatoma dimidiata complex, a group of triatomine bugs that transmit Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, across the Mexican Neotropics. The researchers analyzed two fragments of the ND4 gene and found that the lowest genetic diversity of T. dimidiata occurs in areas with high historical anthropic modification, where T. cruzi infection prevalence is also highest. The study identified three haplogroups (1, 2, and 3) with differential Trypanosoma cruzi and Discrete Typing Unit (DTU) infections. Haplogroups 1 and 3 had higher T. cruzi prevalence than expected, while haplogroup 2 had lower prevalence. The researchers also found significant differences in DTU infection frequencies between haplogroups 1 and 3, but not in haplogroup 2. The study estimated the divergence of the complex from its most recent common ancestor (MRCA) to be between 0.97 and 0.85 million years ago (MYA), with primary divergence of haplogroups 2 and 3. The effective population size of Mexican haplogroups 1 and 2 increased between 0.02 and 0.03 MYA. The study supports previous ecological niche evidence for the complex's origin surrounding the Tehuantepec Isthmus and provides evidence for recent divergence of the three primary dimidiata haplogroups, with differential T. cruzi infection frequency and DTU specificity, which are important components of vector capacity.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is a rodent-borne disease primarily caused by two hantaviruses, Hantaan virus (HTNV) and Seoul virus (SEOV), in China. Environmental factors significantly influence the risk of contracting hantavirus infections, mainly through their effects on rodent population dynamics and human-rodent contact. A 10-year (2006-2015) field surveillance study in Chenzhou, a hantavirus hotspot, aimed to clarify the environmental risk factors favoring rodent-to-human transmission. The study analyzed 709 cases of HFRS, rodent species, and environmental data from satellite images and meteorological stations to quantify the relationships among environmental factors, rodent species, and HFRS occurrence. The results showed that rodent species played different roles across various land types, with all species associated with transmission risks. Rattus norvegicus and R. flavipectus were associated with HFRS risk in grassland, while M. musculus and R. flavipectus were associated with this risk in built-on land. The rodent community composition was also associated with environmental variability. Predictive risk models based on these significant factors were validated, indicating that cultivated land represented the highest risk for HFRS incidence. The study suggests that the spatial heterogeneity of HFRS disease may be influenced by rodent community composition, which is associated with local environmental conditions. Therefore, future work should focus on preventing HFRS in moist, warm environments.
Activating mutations in the HRAS proto-oncogene can cause Costello syndrome (CS), a congenital disease characterized by growth retardation, tumor predisposition, and developmental delay. The majority of CS cases are caused by heterozygous c.34G>A (p.Gly12Ser) mutations in HRAS. However, a new germline p.Gly12Val mutation, c.35_36GC>TG, was identified in a 12-year-old boy with attenuated CS. Analysis of the HRAS cDNA showed high levels of exon 2 skipping, which was confirmed using wild-type and mutant HRAS minigenes. The mutation was found to disrupt the function of a critical Exonic Splicing Enhancer (ESE) and create an Exonic Splicing Silencer (ESS), leading to exon 2 skipping. The splicing efficiency of HRAS exon 2 is dependent on the binding of splicing stimulatory proteins, such as SRSF2, to the critical ESE. The majority of cancer- and CS-causing mutations are located in exon 2 and affect splicing differently. The phenotype in CS and somatic cancers is not only determined by the different transforming potentials of mutant HRAS proteins but also by the efficiency of exon 2 inclusion resulting from the different HRAS mutations. A splice-switching oligonucleotide (SSO) that blocks access to the critical ESE was shown to cause exon 2 skipping and halt the proliferation of cancer cells, suggesting a potential for the development of new anti-cancer therapies based on SSO-mediated HRAS exon 2 skipping.
The study investigated the role of METTL3-mediated N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification in mammalian cerebellar development. METTL3 is a key factor in the formation of m6A, the most abundant modification on mRNAs. Researchers found that specific inactivation of Mettl3 in the mouse nervous system caused severe developmental defects in the brain, resulting in cerebellar hypoplasia. This was due to drastically enhanced apoptosis of newborn cerebellar granule cells (CGCs) in the external granular layer (EGL). METTL3 depletion led to loss of m6A modification, causing extended RNA half-lives and aberrant splicing events, which in turn resulted in dysregulation of transcriptome-wide gene expression and premature CGC death. The study revealed that METTL3 is an essential regulator of cerebellar neurogenesis and development. Transcriptome-wide gene expression dysregulation induced by m6A depletion in the absence of METTL3 resulted in CGCs apoptosis and cerebellum hypoplasia. The findings indicate that METTL3-mediated m6A serves as a key regulator in modulating the development of the central nervous system at the post-transcriptional level in mammals. The study suggests that METTL3 plays a critical role in regulating the development of the mammalian cerebellum, and its dysregulation can lead to severe cerebellar developmental defects.
The study investigated the role of combinatorial binding of transcription factors OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG in human and mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells. These transcription factors are essential for maintaining the pluripotency of ES cells and their ability to differentiate into any cell type of the developing embryo. The researchers found that combinatorial binding of OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG is strongly associated with the co-localization of the transcriptional co-activator Mediator, H3K27ac, and increased expression of nearby genes in ES cells. Furthermore, they observed that the same loci bound by OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG in ES cells frequently drive expression in early embryonic development. A comparison of mouse and human ES cells revealed that while less than 5% of individual binding events for OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG are shared between species, about 15% of combinatorial binding events and 53-63% of combinatorial binding events at enhancers active in early development are conserved. These findings suggest that the combination of OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG binding is critical for transcription in ES cells and likely plays an important role in embryogenesis by binding at conserved early developmental enhancers. The study also suggests that the fast evolutionary rewiring of regulatory networks mainly affects individual binding events, whereas "gene regulatory hotspots" bound by multiple factors and active in multiple tissues throughout early development are under stronger evolutionary constraints.
The AML1/ETO oncogenic transcription factor, generated by a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 8 and 21, plays a crucial role in the initiation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) by recruiting co-repressor complexes to DNA. AML1/ETO interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, AML1, by directly targeting AML1 binding sites. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling revealed that AML1/ETO co-localizes with AML1, demonstrating that the fusion protein follows the binding pattern of the wild-type protein but does not function primarily by displacing it. The DNA binding profile of the E-protein HEB was grossly rearranged upon expression of AML1/ETO, and the fusion protein was found to co-localize with both AML1 and HEB on many of its regulated targets. Furthermore, the level of HEB protein was increased in both primary cells and cell lines expressing AML1/ETO. The results suggest a major role for the functional interaction of AML1/ETO with AML1 and HEB in transcriptional regulation determined by the fusion protein. AML1/ETO was found to target DNA through E-box motifs as a result of physical interactions with transcription factors of the E-protein family, particularly HEB/TCF12. The co-occurrence of AML1 and HEB is significantly associated with regulation of gene expression by AML1/ETO, suggesting that common binding regions for the three transcription factors are relevant to AML1/ETO function.
The study investigated the role of Leishmania donovani histone acetyltransferase 2 (HAT2) in regulating cell cycle progression. HAT2 was found to acetylate histone H4K10 in vitro and in vivo, and its depletion resulted in growth and cell cycle defects, as well as poor survival in host cells. Real-time PCR and DNA microarray analyses revealed that downregulation of cyclins CYC4 and CYC9 were responsible for S phase and G2/M defects in HAT2-depleted cells, respectively. Reporter assays showed that CYC4 and CYC9 have their own specific promoters, which were activated in a cell cycle-dependent manner. Chromatin immunoprecipitation assays and nuclear run-on analyses confirmed that CYC4 and CYC9 were transcriptionally activated from their own promoters at specific cell cycle stages. The study suggests that there are two tiers of gene regulation in Leishmania donovani: transcription of polycistronic units primarily initiates at divergent strand switch regions (dSSRs) constitutively, while a subset of genes have their own promoters that are activated in a cell cycle-dependent manner. This second tier of regulation is more sensitive to H4K10 acetylation levels, resulting in downregulation of expression in HAT2-depleted cells. The study provides new insights into gene regulation in Leishmania donovani and highlights the importance of stringent modulation of CYC4 and CYC9 expression in cell cycle progression.
The study investigated how humans infer on the intentions of others during social interactions using a meta-Bayesian modeling framework. In an economic game, 16 pairs of volunteers played a probabilistic reinforcement learning task, with one participant receiving additional information and issuing a recommendation. The game was structured to vary the adviser's incentives to provide helpful or misleading information over time. The results showed that the players' behavior was best explained by hierarchical learning, where they inferred the volatility of the adviser's intentions to optimize their predictions about the validity of the advice. The players' estimates of volatility also affected their trial-by-trial variability in decisions, with participants relying more on their estimates of advice accuracy when they believed the adviser's intentions were stable. The model predicted the players' interpersonal reactivity index scores, explicit ratings of the advisers' helpfulness, and the advisers' self-reports on their chosen strategy. The study suggests that humans employ hierarchical generative models to infer on the changing intentions of others, use volatility estimates to inform decision-making in social interactions, and integrate estimates of advice accuracy with non-social sources of information. The Bayesian framework can quantify individual differences in these mechanisms from simple behavioral readouts, which may be useful in future clinical studies of maladaptive social cognition. The study also found that players who interacted with advisers whose intentions were changing to maximize their own winnings showed more pronounced values, indicating a stronger coupling between the two hierarchical learning levels.
The article reports on the urbanization of scrub typhus disease in South Korea, specifically in Seoul, the largest metropolitan city. Scrub typhus, an endemic disease in Asia, has traditionally been considered a rural disease. However, indigenous urban cases have been observed in Seoul, which may have significant public health implications due to the city's large population. Using national notifiable disease data from 2010 to 2013, the study identified 88 cases of urban scrub typhus in Seoul. The possible sites of infection were mountainous areas, city parks, the vicinity of one's own residence, and riversides. Chigger mites were collected in Gwanak mountain, one of the suspected infection sites, and 87.4% of them were identified as Helenicula miyagawai, which was found to be infected with Orientia tsutsugamushi Boryong strain. The clinical features of the patients were mild, with low APACHE II scores and low complication rates. The study suggests that urban scrub typhus needs to be considered as one of the differential febrile diseases in endemic areas and a target for prevention. The presence of the Boryong genotype in the chigger mites collected within Seoul was confirmed, and further identification of causative strains from multiple areas will help to characterize the overall status of the disease. The study highlights the possibility that scrub typhus can spread into urban areas under high incidence pressure from surrounding areas.
The study investigated the role of the Caenorhabditis elegans HEN1 RNA-methyl-transferase homolog, HENN-1, in the stability and function of two endogenous RNA interference (RNAi) pathways: the 26G and 21U pathways. HENN-1 is involved in the methylation of the 3' ends of small RNA (sRNA) molecules, which is crucial for their stability. The results show that HENN-1 has differential effects on the two pathways. In the germline, the stability of 21U RNAs, which are the Caenorhabditis elegans piRNAs, is only mildly affected by the loss of methylation. In contrast, most 26G RNAs display reduced stability and increased 3'-uridylation frequencies in the absence of HENN-1. Furthermore, the study found that specifically ERGO-1-bound 26G RNAs are modified by HENN-1, while ALG-3/ALG-4-bound 26G RNAs are not. Global gene expression analysis of henn-1 mutants revealed mild effects, including down-regulation of many germline-expressed genes. The study suggests that the effects of reduced 26G RNA levels on gene expression are indirect, and that HENN-1 plays a crucial role in the stabilization of ERGO-1-bound 26G RNAs. These findings refine our understanding of endogenous RNAi in Caenorhabditis elegans and the roles of Hen1-like enzymes in these pathways.
Title: Genomics Meets Glycomics—The First GWAS Study of Human N-Glycome Identifies HNF1α as a Master Regulator of Plasma Protein Fucosylation

    A genome-wide association study (GWAS) and high-throughput glycomics analysis of 2,705 individuals in three population cohorts revealed that common variants in the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1α (HNF1α) and fucosyltransferase genes FUT6 and FUT8 influence N-glycan levels in human plasma. The study found that HNF1α and its downstream target HNF4α regulate the expression of key fucosyltransferase and fucose biosynthesis genes. Furthermore, HNF1α was shown to be both necessary and sufficient to drive the expression of these genes in hepatic cells. This mechanism has implications for the regulation of immunity, embryonic development, and protein folding, as well as for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying cancer, coronary heart disease, and metabolic and inflammatory disorders. The study highlights a new role for HNF1α as a master transcriptional regulator of multiple stages in the fucosylation process.
