HNF1α and HNF4α were found to regulate the expression of fucosyltransferase genes, including FUT6 and FUT8, and the biosynthesis of GDP-fucose, a rate-limiting step in protein fucosylation. These findings provide new insights into the complex processes that regulate glycosylation and have significant implications for our understanding of various diseases.
This study investigated the role of single-stranded RNA in stabilizing the DNA binding of Centromere Protein C (CENPC), a key inner kinetochore protein in maize. CENPC plays a crucial role in the attachment of chromosomes to the cytoskeleton during cell division. The researchers found that a localized region of 122 amino acids in CENPC is responsible for DNA binding, and that this binding is exquisitely sensitive to single-stranded RNA. Long, single-stranded nucleic acids strongly promote the binding of CENPC to DNA, and the types of RNAs that stabilize DNA binding match in size and character the RNAs present on kinetochores in vivo. The data suggest that centromeric RNA helps to recruit CENPC to the inner kinetochore by altering its DNA binding characteristics. The study used a combination of in vitro and in vivo studies to show that maize CENPC has both DNA-binding and RNA-binding capacities, and that the DNA/RNA-binding domain is localized to the exon duplication region. The researchers propose that CENPC is first recruited to kinetochores by protein-protein contacts and then converted to a functional DNA binding protein by centromeric RNA. These findings support the view that RNA facilitates or stabilizes the association of kinetochore proteins with centromeric DNA and implicate CENPC as a primary target of this activity.
A genome-wide association study (GWAS) identified genetic variants associated with birth weight (BW), childhood obesity (CO), and childhood body mass index (CBMI). The study examined the role of the placental transcriptome and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) in mediating the genetic causes of these traits. The results showed that GWAS loci associated with BW, CO, and CBMI were significantly enriched for placental eQTLs, with 6.76, 4.83, and 2.26-fold enrichments, respectively. Notably, only placental eQTLs contributed significantly to both anthropometric outcomes at birth (BW) and childhood phenotypes (CO/CBMI). The study identified eight, six, and one transcripts that colocalized with BW, CO, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. The findings suggest that placental transcription in utero plays a key role in determining postnatal body size and may hold new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity. The study highlights the importance of the placenta as a critical organ for fetal development and postnatal health, and demonstrates that integrative genomics can be a powerful tool for mining GWAS results to understand the mechanisms controlling these traits. The results also support the hypothesis that genetically controlled in utero expression patterns linked to BW, CO, and CBMI are important for understanding the mechanisms controlling these traits and developing clinical prevention strategies.
Post Kala-azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a chronic condition that occurs in approximately 10-20% of patients who have successfully treated Visceral Leishmaniasis (VL) in India, and up to 50-60% in Sudan. PKDL is a dermal manifestation characterized by macular, maculopapular, or nodular rash caused by Leishmania donovani. Unlike VL, PKDL is not life-threatening, but it is highly relevant in the context of VL elimination. A study conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India, aimed to determine the actual disease burden of PKDL, compare three diagnostic tools for PKDL case detection, and assess the pattern of lesion regression after treatment. The study found a prevalence rate of 27.5% among antileishmanial antibody-positive cases. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) was found to be highly sensitive (88.46%) for case confirmation. However, skin lesions persisted in most cases after treatment completion, gradually disappearing within 6-12 months post-treatment. Reappearance of lesions was noted in two cases after 1.5 years of miltefosine treatment. The study suggests that a significant number of PKDL patients would remain undiagnosed without active mass surveys, highlighting the need for such surveys in other endemic areas to attain the ultimate goal of eliminating Kala-azar. A well-designed study with a higher number of samples is essential to establish whether PKDL patients are free from parasites after treatment and to determine which PKDL patients need treatment for a longer period.
Pneumococcal Competence Coordination Relies on a Cell-Contact Sensing Mechanism

    A recent study has elucidated the mechanisms underlying pneumococcal competence development in liquid cultures of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Competence is an inducible genetic program that enables horizontal gene transfer and genome plasticity in pneumococci. The study found that competence development in pneumococcal populations is a two-step process, initiated by a self-activated cell fraction that arises via a growth time-dependent mechanism. This fraction of cells over-expresses the Competence Stimulating Peptide (CSP), which then induces competence in the rest of the population through cell-to-cell contact.

    The study demonstrated that CSP remains bound to cells during competence development and that the rate of competence development corresponds to the propagation of competence by contact between activated and quiescent cells. The researchers also found that the membrane protein ComD retains CSP, limiting its free diffusion in the medium. This suggests that competence initiator cells originate stochastically in response to stress, forming a distinct subpopulation that then transmits CSP by cell-cell contact.

    The study proposes a cell-contact sensing mechanism for pneumococcal competence development, where a fraction of cells initially switches to CSP over-expression and then induces competence in the rest of the population through cell-to-cell contact. This mechanism promotes horizontal gene transfer and genome plasticity in pneumococci, contributing to their ability to evade vaccines, antibiotics, and host immune defenses. The study provides new insights into the mechanisms underlying pneumococcal competence development and highlights the importance of cell-to-cell contact in this process.
The human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) L2 protein acts as a chaperone to facilitate the trafficking of the viral genome (vDNA) from endosomes to the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and eventually the nucleus, where HPV replication occurs. To reach the nucleus, the L2/vDNA complex must translocate across limiting intracellular membranes. A novel system based on subcellular compartmentalization of the enzyme BirA and its cognate substrate was developed to detect membrane translocation of L2-BirA from incoming virions. The results show that L2 translocation requires transport to the TGN and is strictly dependent on entry into mitosis, coinciding with mitotic entry in synchronized cells. Cell cycle arrest causes retention of L2/vDNA at the TGN, and only release and progression past G2/M enables translocation across the limiting membrane and subsequent infection. Microscopy of EdU-labeled vDNA reveals a rapid and dramatic shift in vDNA localization during early mitosis, with vDNA egressing from the TGN to a pericentriolar location and accumulating there through prometaphase. By metaphase and throughout anaphase, the vDNA is seen bound to the mitotic chromosomes, ensuring distribution into both daughter nuclei. Mutations in a newly defined chromatin binding region of L2 potently blocked translocation, suggesting that translocation is dependent on chromatin binding during prometaphase. This represents the first time a virus has been shown to functionally couple the penetration of limiting membranes to cellular mitosis, explaining in part the tropism of HPV for mitotic basal keratinocytes.
The article presents a mathematical framework for estimating the relative transmissibility (transmission fitness) of one strain of a pathogen compared to another using data from competitive mixtures animal models. The framework is applied to influenza experiments in ferrets, where animals are co-infected with a mixture of two strains, and the mixture is observed over time and multiple generations of transmission. The method assesses the relative transmissibility between two strains of influenza, which is crucial in various contexts, including seasonal/seasonal interactions, seasonal/pandemic interactions, and NAI-resistant/NAI-sensitive interactions. The framework also provides an estimate for the size of the transmitted inoculum. The authors demonstrate the framework's behavior using data from ferret transmission studies and suggest how to optimize experimental design for assessing transmissibility. The method has wide applicability in influenza research and can be extended to other viral and bacterial pathogens. The framework indicates potential improvements in competitive-mixtures experimental design, including the use of multiple donor ferrets and the estimation of the number of successfully infecting units transferred from the donor to the recipient. This information is essential for parameterizing epidemiological models of influenza transmission that consider the emergence and spread of NAI-resistant strains.
This study investigates the convergence of light and abscisic acid (ABA) signaling on the ABI5 promoter in Arabidopsis thaliana. The authors show that BBX21, a B-box protein previously implicated in seedling photomorphogenesis, also plays a role in ABA signaling. Genetic data indicate that BBX21 acts upstream of several ABA INSENSITIVE (ABI) genes and ELONGATED HYPOCOTYL 5 (HY5) in ABA control of seed germination. The study reveals that BBX21 negatively regulates ABI5 expression by interfering with HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. Additionally, ABI5 was found to directly activate its own expression, and BBX21 negatively regulates this activity by directly interacting with ABI5. The results suggest that BBX21 coordinates with HY5 and ABI5 on the ABI5 promoter, integrating light and ABA signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana. This study provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the cross-talk between light and ABA, which is essential for plant adaptation and survival. The findings indicate that multiple transcription factors in the light signaling pathway may regulate ABA responses by regulating ABI5 expression. The study highlights the importance of understanding how plants integrate external signals with internal regulatory pathways to respond to environmental cues.
The Mediator complex is a conserved co-regulator of RNA polymerase II that plays a crucial role in eukaryotic gene expression. This study investigated the functions of the Mediator complex in Candida albicans, a pathogenic fungus. The researchers focused on the Middle domain subunit Med31, the Head domain subunit Med20, and Srb9/Med13 from the Kinase domain. They found that the C. albicans Mediator shares some roles with model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schizosaccharomyces pombe, including functions in stress response and the regulation of genes by the activator Ace2. However, the C. albicans Mediator also has additional roles in the transcription of virulence-related genes, such as those involved in morphogenesis and the expression of cell wall adhesins. The Mediator subunits Med31, Med20, and Srb9/Med13 contribute to key virulence attributes of C. albicans, including filamentation and biofilm formation. Furthermore, Med31 affects the virulence of C. albicans in a worm infection model. The study also found that the roles of Med31 and Srb9/Med13 in the expression of cell wall adhesins differ between S. cerevisiae and C. albicans, suggesting distinct Mediator-dependent control of adhesion in these two yeast species. These findings provide new insights into the functions of the Mediator complex in C. albicans and its role in shaping species-specific gene expression.
The fitness landscape of antibiotic tolerance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms was investigated using genome-wide functional profiling of a complex mutant population in biofilm and planktonic growth conditions with and without tobramycin. The study aimed to quantify the contribution of each locus to antibiotic tolerance under these two states. The results revealed large sets of mutations that contribute to antibiotic tolerance predominantly in the biofilm or planktonic setting only, providing insights into the differences and similarities between biofilm and planktonic antibiotic tolerance. A mixed population-based experimental design was used to recapitulate the complexity of natural biofilms and revealed clinically observed behaviors, including the emergence of quorum sensing-deficient mutants. The study found that the cellular state contributes substantially to the antibiotic tolerance of biofilms, providing a rational foundation for the development of novel therapeutics against P. aeruginosa biofilm-associated infections. The results showed that while there is a considerable overlap between the loci that modulate antibiotic tolerance in biofilm and planktonic cells, the relative importance of most genes is state-specific. For example, the vast majority of mutants with the strongest fitness advantages in the biofilm state also have only a weak to moderate advantage in the planktonic state. Overall, the study provides a comprehensive understanding of the genetic determinants of antibiotic tolerance in P. aeruginosa biofilms and planktonic cells.
A new algorithm called Flexible and dynamic Algorithm for Model Selection (FAMoS) has been developed to analyze complex systems dynamics in large model spaces. The algorithm is designed to overcome the challenges of analyzing biological systems with many interacting components and limited information about their dynamics. FAMoS uses a combination of local and non-local search methods to prevent getting stuck in local minima of the model space. The algorithm was tested and validated using simulated data and shown to be flexible in handling different model structures. It was also applied to experimental data on cell proliferation dynamics of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells cultured under different conditions, revealing dynamical changes in proliferation potential. The results indicated that the proliferation potential was reduced in tissue-like 3D ex vivo cultures compared to suspension cultures. FAMoS is a useful tool for data-oriented evaluation of complex model spaces and can be applied to a wide range of biological problems due to its flexibility in handling various model structures. The algorithm addresses the limitations of existing model selection algorithms, which often rely on exhaustive searches of the total model space or compare a preselected number of models. FAMoS provides a systematic description of experimentally observed dynamics and identifies relevant factors and processes that determine a system's behavior. Its ability to efficiently search large model spaces makes it a valuable contribution to various research questions in biology.
A 12-month follow-up study was conducted in Bolivia to evaluate the efficacy of benznidazole (BNZ) treatment in school-age children infected with Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease. The study involved 103 seropositive children who received a 60-day treatment regimen of 5 mg/kg/day BNZ. Blood samples were collected at seven time points during and after treatment, and serology, conventional PCR (cPCR), and quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) were performed to assess treatment efficacy. Additionally, plasma levels of Th1/Th2/Th17 cytokines, including IL-17A, were measured. The results showed that 73 children completed the treatment, with 6 (11%) showing both cPCR and qPCR positivity, 24 (42%) showing cPCR negativity but qPCR positivity, and 27 (47%) showing both cPCR and qPCR negativity. IL-17A levels were significantly higher in seropositive children before treatment compared to age-matched seronegative children and decreased to normal levels one year after treatment. Furthermore, IL-17A levels were positively correlated with parasite counts detected by qPCR throughout the follow-up period. Notably, IL-17A levels in non-reactive subjects were significantly higher than in reactive or ambiguous subjects at the 12-month time point, suggesting that IL-17A may be a useful biomarker for detecting persistent infection and treatment response. These findings highlight the potential of IL-17A as a biomarker for evaluating treatment efficacy in Chagas disease.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary causative agent of bacterial meningitis, contains a diminutive transposon called the Correia element ( CE ) that occupies almost 2% of its genome. Bioinformatic analysis revealed eight subtypes of the CE with four distinct types of ends. Transcriptional analysis using PCR and a lacZ reporter system showed that two ends in particular encode strong promoters. The activity of the strongest promoter is determined by a recurrent polymorphism at the right end of the element. The Correia elements can drive transcription of adjacent genes and may express small non-coding RNAs. Pair-wise comparisons between three meningococcal genomes revealed that no more than two-thirds of Correia elements maintain their subtype at any particular locus due to recombinational class switching between elements in a single strain. This process may represent a hitherto unrecognized mechanism for phase variation in the meningococcus. The strain-to-strain variability of the Correia elements and the large number of strong promoters encoded by them allows for potentially widespread effects within the population as a whole. The study defines the strength of the promoters encoded by the eight subtypes of Correia ends, providing a resource to predict the transcriptional effects of a particular subtype at a given locus. The Correia elements may contribute to the development or persistence of hypervirulent lineages that are the source of most global meningococcal disease. Correia end subtype switching has the potential to act as a mechanism for phase variation, in which the transcription of genes under the influence of a CE is modulated by the recombination-mediated switching of Correia promoters.
The maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostrophus produces a host-selective toxin, T-toxin, which promotes high virulence to maize carrying Texas male sterile cytoplasm (T-cms). ChLae1 and ChVel1, orthologs of the Aspergillus spp. regulatory proteins LaeA and VeA, were found to regulate T-toxin production, virulence, oxidative stress response, and development in C. heterostrophus. T-toxin production is significantly increased in the dark in wild-type (WT) strains, whereas Chvel1 and Chlae1 mutant toxin levels are much reduced in the dark compared to WT. Expression of T-toxin biosynthetic genes (Tox1) is up-regulated in the dark in WT, while dark-induced expression is much reduced in Chvel1 and Chlae1 mutants. Overexpression of ChVEL1 and ChLAE1 increases T-toxin production and Tox1 gene expression in the dark and in light, respectively. ChLae1 and ChVel1 positively regulate T-toxin biosynthesis, pathogenicity, and super virulence, oxidative stress responses, sexual development, and aerial hyphal growth, and negatively control melanin biosynthesis and asexual differentiation. Deletion of ChLAE1 or ChVEL1 reduces tolerance to H2O2, and Chlae1 and Chvel1 mutants show decreased aerial hyphal growth, increased asexual sporulation, and female sterility. ChLAE1 overexpression strains are female sterile, while ChVEL1 overexpression strains are more fertile than WT. ChLae1 and ChVel1 repress expression of 1,8-dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN) melanin biosynthesis genes, and accordingly, melanization is enhanced in Chlae1 and Chvel1 mutants, and reduced in OE strains.
The mechanism of functional asymmetry in bacterial Nav channels has been investigated using a combination of non-equilibrium simulation data and two-dimensional equilibrium unperturbed landscapes generated by umbrella sampling and Weighted Histogram Analysis Methods for multiple ions traversing the selectivity filter of bacterial NavAb channel. The results indicate that two or three extracellular K+ ions can block the entrance to the selectivity filter of NavAb in the presence of applied forces in the inward direction, but not in the outward direction. This block state occurs in an unstable local minimum of the equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscape of two K+ ions that can be ‘locked’ in place by modest applied forces. In contrast, three Na+ ions move favorably through the selectivity filter together as a unit in a loose “knock-on” mechanism of permeation in both inward and outward directions, with no similar local minimum in the two-dimensional free-energy landscape of two Na+ ions for a block state. The non-equilibrium simulations predict that the useful work required to break the K+ block is equivalent to large applied potentials experimentally measured for two bacterial Nav channels to induce inward currents of K+ ions. These findings illustrate how inclusion of non-equilibrium factors in the simulations can provide detailed information about mechanisms of ion selectivity that is missing from mechanisms derived from either crystal structures or equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscapes. The results are consistent with electrophysiological measurements of bacterial Nav channels and provide new insight into the mechanism of selective ion permeation in bacterial Nav channels.
This study investigated the intracellular spread of rabies virus in dogs with the furious and paralytic forms of the disease. The results show that the furious form of rabies has a more rapid viral colonization of the cerebral hemispheres compared to the paralytic form, as measured by viral antigen within neuronal cell bodies and viral RNA levels. The study used image analysis to quantify the amount of rabies viral antigen in cell processes at different levels of the spinal cord, brain stem, and cerebrum in a cohort of naturally infected non-vaccinated dogs. The findings indicate that the amount of rabies viral antigen in cell processes decreases in a rostral direction, following the pattern for the amount of antigen in neuronal cell bodies and the percentage of involved cell bodies. However, there was a delay in cell process involvement following cell body involvement, suggesting that replication occurs in the cell body region and subsequent transport out to cell processes. Notably, greater amounts of antigen were seen in cell processes in dogs with the furious form compared to the paralytic form at all anatomic levels examined. This suggests that intracellular transport of the virus may be slower in the paralytic form, resulting in slower viral propagation. The results are consistent with previous studies showing greater inflammation in the paralytic form, which may be related to host-specific differences in intracellular virus transport.
The study investigated the genomic binding sites of the zinc-finger protein CTCF in Drosophila, with a focus on the Bithorax complex (BX-C). Chromatin immunopurification coupled with genomic microarray analysis was used to identify CTCF binding sites in representative regions of the Drosophila genome, including the BX-C, the Antennapedia complex, and the 3-Mb Adh region. The analysis revealed that CTCF binding sites map precisely to known insulator elements Mcp, Fab-6, and Fab-8 in the BX-C, suggesting a common CTCF-dependent mechanism for the functioning of these insulators. In addition, CTCF binding sites were found to correlate with boundaries of regulatory domains, allowing the identification of three additional presumptive insulator elements, "Fab-2," "Fab-3," and "Fab-4." These findings indicate that CTCF is directly associated with all known or predicted insulators in the BX-C, with the possible exception of Fab-7. The study also compared the locations of CTCF sites with characterized Polycomb target sites and histone modification, providing support for the domain model of BX-C regulation. Overall, the results suggest that CTCF plays a crucial role in the regulation of transcription in Drosophila, and that its binding sites are essential for the functioning of insulators in the BX-C.
The study provides a detailed mechanism of an induced-fit process at atomic resolution in the enzyme-peptide deformylase (PDF) using a slow and tight-binding inhibitor-enzyme system, actinonin-PDF. Crystal structures of the initial open state and final closed state, as well as intermediate mimics, were solved to reconstruct the sequence of events from the encounter complex to the key-lock binding state of the enzyme. Ligand-induced reshaping of a hydrophobic pocket drives closure of the active site, which is then "zipped up" by additional binding interactions. The study integrates biophysical, computational, and kinetic analyses to provide a comprehensive understanding of the slow-binding mechanism. Actinonin, a slow and tight-binding inhibitor of PDF, exhibits unique inhibitory properties, including selective potency and long-lasting effects, making it a promising therapeutic candidate. The study highlights the importance of conformational changes in enzyme catalysis, where substrate binding is often coupled to conformational changes that alter the local environment of the active site to align reactive groups for efficient catalysis. The findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of slow and tight-binding inhibitors, which are favored for use as therapeutics due to their unique properties. The study also sheds light on the broader area of receptor-ligand interactions, where induced-fit mechanisms play a crucial role.
The study investigates the role of cortically-controlled population stochastic facilitation in guiding sensory transfer across the thalamic gateway. The thalamus serves as the primary relay station for sensory information to the cerebral cortex, with each cortical cell receiving input from multiple thalamic cells. However, the influence of cortical feedback on thalamic cells is often overlooked during sensory processing. Using dynamic-clamp techniques in thalamic slices in vitro, the researchers implemented a hybrid retino-thalamo-cortical pathway combining biological cells and simulated circuits. The study found that the transfer efficiency of sensory input transmission depends on three key factors: the number of thalamocortical cells involved in the convergence from thalamus to cortex, the statistics of corticothalamic synaptic bombardment, and the level of correlation imposed between converging thalamic relay cells. Counterintuitively, the results show that retinocortical signal transfer efficiency increases when the level of correlation across thalamic cells decreases. This suggests that the transfer efficiency of relay cells could be selectively amplified when they become desynchronized by cortical feedback. The study proposes that active decorrelation of background synaptic activity in the thalamic layer provides a powerful optimization mechanism controlling the efficiency of retinocortical signal transfer. A stochastic facilitation process emerging at the whole thalamic population level enhances global sensory information transfer in the presence of decorrelated corticogeniculate feedback bombardment. This process may be the basis for attentional modulation of sensory signals at the thalamic level.
The putative DNA demethylase NMAD-1 plays a critical role in regulating DNA replication and repair during meiosis in Caenorhabditis elegans. NMAD-1 mutants exhibit reduced fertility, defects in prophase I of meiosis, and an increased incidence of males due to defective chromosomal segregation. RNA sequencing of the nmad-1 germline revealed reduced induction of DNA replication and DNA damage response genes during meiosis, coupled with delayed DNA replication, impaired DNA repair, and increased apoptosis of maturing oocytes. Immunoprecipitation and mass spectrometry identified NMAD-1 binding proteins, including topoisomerase TOP-2, which co-localizes with NMAD-1 on chromatin. The majority of TOP-2 binding to chromatin depends on NMAD-1, suggesting that NMAD-1 functions at DNA replication sites to regulate DNA replication and repair during meiosis. NMAD-1 binds to the same sites on chromatin in the germline as TOP-2 and physically interacts directly with TOP-2 both in vitro and in vivo. The nmad-1 deletion and catalytic mutant strains have impaired fertility, an increased incidence of males, elevated RAD-51 foci, and reduced replication rates, indicating that NMAD-1's demethylation activity at DNA is central to its role in meiosis. These findings suggest that NMAD-1 regulates DNA replication and repair during meiosis by interacting with TOP-2 and other proteins involved in these processes.
The study identifies adipocyte plasma membrane-associated protein (APMAP) as a novel modulator of human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection. HCMV is a ubiquitous pathogen that can cause significant morbidity in newborns and immunocompromised patients. Despite its large genome and complex glycoprotein complexes, the mechanism of HCMV infection remains poorly understood. The researchers found that APMAP is necessary for HCMV infection in both epithelial cells and fibroblasts, and that knockdown of APMAP expression significantly reduced HCMV infection in these cells. Conversely, ectopic expression of human APMAP in cells refractory to HCMV infection, such as canine MDCK and murine NIH/3T3 cells, promoted HCMV infection. Biochemical studies suggest that APMAP interacts with gH/gL containing glycoprotein complexes at low pH and mediates the nucleus translocation of tegument protein pp65. The results indicate that APMAP plays a role in the early stage of HCMV infection and functions as a modulator promoting HCMV infection in multiple cell types. The study provides new insights into the complex HCMV infection mechanism and identifies APMAP as an important player in this process. The findings suggest that APMAP could be a potential target for the development of novel therapeutic strategies against HCMV infection.
The article presents a minimal model of lineage commitment for hematopoietic progenitors that integrates both extrinsic and intrinsic cues. The model suggests that cytokine-mediated positive receptor feedback can induce a "switch-like" response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation, providing robustness to both bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced differentiation or decommitment. The model supports both the instructive and stochastic theories of commitment, indicating that cell fates are driven by lineage-specific transcription factors but can be strongly biased by cytokine signaling. The simulations show that the kinetics of differentiation to a mature cell state depend on the starting progenitor state and the route of commitment chosen. The model also demonstrates good agreement with lineage-specific receptor expression kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a computational framework that can integrate both classical and alternative commitment paths in hematopoiesis observed experimentally. The study highlights the importance of extrinsic regulation in instructing lineage choice and processing conflicting extracellular cues, showing that cell-fate decisions can be stochastic but are strongly biased by external cues. The model's topology was informed by experimental studies on lineage-specific receptors and transcription factors, and it provides insights into the molecular events that direct lineage commitment at the stem cell stage or at the multipotent progenitor level.
The ultrastructure of Bunyamwera virus (BUNV), the prototypic member of the Orthobunyavirus genus, has been elucidated using electron cryo-tomography. BUNV virions display a pleomorphic shape with a locally ordered lattice of glycoprotein spikes, each protruding 18 nm from the viral membrane. The glycoprotein spikes become disordered upon introduction to an acidic environment. A three-dimensional model of the trimeric pre-fusion glycoprotein spike was derived to 3-nm resolution using sub-tomogram averaging. The glycoprotein spike consists mainly of the putative class-II fusion glycoprotein and exhibits a unique tripod-like arrangement. Protein-protein contacts between neighboring spikes occur at membrane-proximal regions and intra-spike contacts at membrane-distal regions. This trimeric assembly deviates from previously observed fusion glycoprotein arrangements, suggesting a greater than anticipated repertoire of viral fusion glycoprotein oligomerization. The study provides evidence of a pH-dependent conformational change that occurs during orthobunyaviral entry into host cells and a blueprint for the structure of this group of emerging pathogens. The glycoprotein sequences of BUNV are conserved with those of more pathogenic relatives, indicating a high degree of structural similarity between viruses. This study provides the first detailed 3-D structural analysis of an orthobunyavirus and a model for this large group of medically important viruses.
Title: ABCC5, a Gene That Influences the Anterior Chamber Depth, Is Associated with Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma

    A genome-wide association study (GWAS) was conducted on 5,308 individuals of Asian descent to identify genes associated with anterior chamber depth (ACD), a key risk factor for primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG). The study found a significant association between a variant in the ABCC5 gene (rs1401999) and ACD, with a per-allele effect size of -0.045 mm (P=8.17×10−9). This association was also observed in a separate case-control study of 4,276 PACG cases and 18,801 controls, with a per-allele odds ratio (OR) of 1.13 (95% CI: 1.06-1.22, P=0.00046). The association was strengthened when a subgroup of controls with open angles was included in the analysis (per-allele OR=1.30, P=7.45×10−9).

    The study suggests that genetic variants influencing ACD may contribute to the risk of PACG. The ABCC5 gene is expressed in anterior segment structures relevant to PACG, such as the iris, ciliary body, and lens. Conditional analyses with previously implicated PACG loci showed no change in the association, indicating that the ABCC5 variant is a novel risk factor for PACG. The study provides further clues to the genetic mechanisms underlying PACG, a major cause of blindness in Asia.
The study identifies the first examples of developmental enhancers conserved between deuterostomes and protostomes, two distinct clades of bilaterian animals. These enhancers, termed bilaterian conserved regulatory elements ( Bicores ), show sequence and gene synteny conservation between the two clades. Bicores are predicted to act as response elements to signaling pathways and have been shown to drive expression of transcriptional repressors in the vertebrate central nervous system. The study suggests that Bicores are developmental enhancers that encode complex patterns of transcription factor binding sites. Bicore1, one of the identified enhancers, is predicted to function as a Bmp responsive element and drives expression in the developing central nervous system in vertebrates. The discovery of Bicores provides a new avenue for exploring how developmental logic is encoded in the genome and how this logic evolves. However, the small number of identified Bicores implies extensive cis-regulatory rewiring between the protostome and deuterostome clades. Further research is needed to determine the true extent of cis-regulatory sequence and function conservation underlying animal development. As more genomes are sequenced and our understanding of cis-regulatory logic improves, it is predicted that additional Bicores will be discovered.
Vaccination has a minimal impact on the intrahost diversity of H3N2 influenza viruses, according to a study that analyzed patient-derived viruses from a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of vaccine efficacy. The researchers used next-generation sequencing to characterize the diversity of influenza A virus and define the impact of vaccine-induced immunity on within-host populations. The study found that the vast majority of intrahost single nucleotide variants were rare and that very few were found in more than one individual. Most samples had fewer than 15 single nucleotide variants across the entire genome, and the level of diversity did not significantly vary with day of sampling, vaccination status, or pre-season antibody titer. Phylogenetic analysis of consensus hemagglutinin and neuraminidase sequences showed no stratification by pre-season hemagglutination inhibition and neuraminidase inhibition titers, respectively. The study suggests that seasonal influenza vaccination has little impact on intrahost diversity in natural infection and that vaccine-induced immunity may be only a minor contributor to antigenic drift at local scales. The findings are consistent across three H3N2 seasons and do not support the idea that vaccine-induced immunity serves as a potent selective pressure for novel influenza variants at the individual or community level. The study contributes to a better understanding of the evolutionary forces that shape the genetic structure of viral populations within hosts and ultimately give rise to novel antigenic variants at the host population level.
The study investigated the efficacy of live attenuated Leishmania donovani (LdCen-/-) parasites in generating a protective immune response against visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in young and aged mice. The results showed that LdCen-/- parasites induced a strong innate and adaptive immune response in both age groups, characterized by the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and the activation of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. In young mice, LdCen-/- immunization led to a significant reduction in parasite burden in the spleen and liver after challenge with virulent L. donovani parasites. However, in aged mice, the adaptive immune response was reduced compared to young mice, resulting in less protection against the parasite. Despite this, LdCen-/- immunization still induced a significant but diminished host protective response in aged mice. The study found that the innate response in bone marrow-derived dendritic cells from both young and aged mice was enhanced after LdCen-/- infection, but the adaptive response in aged mice was lower than in young mice. The results suggest that LdCen-/- immunization can induce a protective immune response against VL in both young and aged mice, but the response is less effective in aged mice due to a reduced adaptive immune response. The study highlights the potential of LdCen-/- parasites as a vaccine candidate for VL, particularly in young individuals.
The study generated chimeras between enteric and respiratory enteroviruses (EVs) to investigate the role of capsid proteins in viral tropism, acid sensitivity, and optimal growth temperature. The chimeras were created by exchanging capsid proteins between EV-D68, a respiratory EV, and EV-D94, an enteric EV. The results showed that capsid proteins are necessary and sufficient to determine acid sensitivity and restricted tropism of the respiratory EV, as well as its optimal growth temperature. In contrast, non-structural proteins modulate the innate immune response in tissues. The study found that EV-D94 with the capsid and 2A protease or the capsid only of EV-D68 were viable, and functional assays indicated that capsid proteins determine acid sensitivity and tropism in cell lines and tissues. Additionally, capsid genes were shown to participate in determining the optimal growth temperature, as EV-D94 temperature adaptation relied on single mutations in VP1, while constructs with EV-D68 capsid could not adapt to higher temperatures. The study also demonstrated that EV-D68 maintains residual binding-capacity after acid-treatment despite a loss of infectivity. These findings provide new insights into the biophysical properties of EVs and may aid in the development of therapeutic targets for vaccine or antiviral treatment. The study highlights the importance of capsid proteins in determining the phenotypic diversity of EVs, one of the world's most prevalent pathogens.
The Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) glycoprotein gE-gI acts as a transmembrane Fc receptor on the surface of infected cells and virions, binding to human immunoglobulin G (hIgG). gE-gI can facilitate antibody bipolar bridging (ABB), a process where the antigen-binding fragments (Fabs) of IgG bind a viral antigen while the Fc region binds to gE-gI. The interaction between IgG Fc and gE-gI is pH-dependent, with binding occurring at basic pH but not acidic pH. This suggests that IgG bound to gE-gI at the cell surface would dissociate and be degraded in acidic endosomes/lysosomes if endocytosed. To investigate the fate of viral antigens associated with gE-gI-bound IgG, an in vitro model system was developed using 4-D confocal fluorescence imaging of ABB complexes with transferrin or epidermal growth factor as intracellular trafficking markers. The results showed that cells expressing gE-gI and the viral antigen HSV-1 gD endocytosed anti-gD IgG and gD in a gE-gI-dependent process, resulting in lysosomal localization. This suggests that gE-gI can mediate the clearance of infected cell surfaces of anti-viral host IgG and viral antigens to evade IgG-mediated responses, representing a general mechanism for viral Fc receptors in immune evasion and viral pathogenesis.
The transcriptome profiles of the protoscoleces ( PSCs ) of Echinococcus granulosus, the causative agent of cystic hydatid disease ( CHD ), were investigated using Roche 454 sequencing technology and in silico secretome analysis. The study aimed to elucidate the potential functions of the excretory-secretory proteins ( ESPs ) released by the parasite. A total of 26, 514 nonredundant sequences were generated, of which 22, 910 ( 86. 4% ) were mapped to the newly published E. granulosus genome and 17, 705 ( 66. 8% ) were distributed within the coding sequence ( CDS ) regions. The analysis predicted 2, 280 ESPs, of which 138 were involved in carbohydrate metabolism and 124 in protein metabolism. Eleven ESPs were identified as intracellular enzymes regulating glycolysis/gluconeogenesis ( GL/GN ) pathways, while 44 antigenic proteins, 25 molecular chaperones, and four proteases were highly represented. Additionally, many proteins were found to be significantly enriched in development-related signaling pathways, such as the TGF-β receptor pathways and insulin pathways. These findings provide valuable information on the metabolic adaptation of E. granulosus to its hosts, which can be used to aid the development of novel intervention targets for hydatid treatment and control. The study contributes to a deeper understanding of host-parasite interactions and adds supplementary knowledge regarding the genomics of E. granulosus.
In Aspergillus nidulans, the transcription factor NirA plays a crucial role in the regulation of nitrate assimilation genes. When nitrate is absent, NirA is predominantly cytosolic and inactive, whereas its presence leads to rapid nuclear accumulation and transcriptional activity. Mass spectrometry analysis revealed that in the absence of nitrate, a conserved methionine ( Met169 ) in NirA's nuclear export sequence ( NES ) is oxidized to methionine sulfoxide ( Metox169 ). This oxidation is dependent on FmoB, a flavin-containing monooxygenase, and is independent of thioredoxin and classical methionine sulfoxide reductases. Exposure to nitrate leads to the rapid reduction of NirA-Metox169 to Met169. Replacement of Met169 with isoleucine resulted in partial loss of NirA activity and insensitivity to FmoB-mediated nuclear export, while replacement with alanine transformed the protein into a permanently nuclear and active transcription factor. Co-immunoprecipitation analysis and subcellular localization studies suggested that Met169 oxidation leads to a change in NirA conformation. The results indicate that in the presence of nitrate, the activation domain of NirA is exposed, while the NES is masked by a central portion of the protein ( nitrate responsive domain, NiRD ), restricting active NirA molecules to the nucleus. In the absence of nitrate, Met169 oxidation leads to loss of protection by the NiRD, NES exposure, and relocation of the inactive NirA to the cytosol.
The article explores how functional constraints shape the evolution of mammalian voltage-gated sodium channels. The primary function of these channels is to allow the propagation of action potentials. Mathematical models suggest that sodium channel properties need to be tightly constrained for an action potential to propagate. There are nine mammalian genes encoding voltage-gated sodium channels, many of which are highly similar in sequence. This similarity implies that their functional properties are also similar, consistent with the idea that these properties are tightly constrained. However, the multiplicity of genes encoding sodium channels raises the question of why there are so many. The article demonstrates that the simplest theoretical constraints bounding sodium channel diversity – the requirements of membrane excitability and the uniqueness of the resting potential – act directly on constraining sodium channel properties. The authors compare the predicted constraints with functional data on mammalian sodium channel properties collected from the literature, including 172 different sets of measurements from 40 publications, wild-type and mutant, under various conditions. The data from all channel types, including mutants, obeys the excitability constraint, while channels expressed in muscle tend to obey the constraint of a unique resting potential, whereas channels expressed in neuronal tissue do not. The excitability properties alone distinguish the nine sodium channels into four different groups that are consistent with phylogenetic analysis. The calculations suggest interpretations for the functional differences between these groups.
Biomedical researchers have identified the influenza virus polymerase as a promising target for novel antiviral drugs due to its role in viral replication and transcription. The polymerase is a heterotrimeric enzyme consisting of subunits PA, PB1, and PB2, and its unique cap-snatching mechanism can be inhibited by targeting either the PB2 cap-binding or PA endonuclease domains. The PA endonuclease domain, in particular, has been shown to be a viable target for antiviral drugs, as its inhibition can directly stall viral replication at an early stage. To develop more effective inhibitors, researchers have obtained high-resolution X-ray co-crystal structures of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 (pH1N1) PA endonuclease domain with a series of specific inhibitors, including four diketo compounds and a green tea catechin. These compounds chelate the two critical manganese ions in the active site of the enzyme, highlighting the potential for structure-based optimization of inhibitors. The binding modes of the different compounds and a mononucleotide phosphate have been compared, revealing the plasticity of certain structural elements in the active site cavity and the importance of substituent groups in binding to distinct sub-pockets. These findings will inform the design of more potent inhibitors targeting the cap-snatching endonuclease activity of influenza virus polymerase, ultimately contributing to the development of novel and efficacious influenza therapeutics.
The study aimed to develop an effective immunization protocol for producing potent polyspecific antisera against three medically important vipers: Calloselasma rhodostoma, Cryptelytrops albolabris, and Daboia siamensis. Four horses were immunized with a mixture of the three viper venoms using a "low dose, low volume multi-site" immunization protocol. The antisera showed a rapid rise in ELISA titers against the three venoms and reached a plateau at around the 8th week post-immunization. The in vivo neutralization potency of the antisera against the three venoms was 10.40, 2.42, and 0.76 mg/ml, respectively, which was higher than the minimal potency limits set by the Queen Saovabha Memorial Institute (QSMI). The polyspecific antisera also effectively neutralized the procoagulant, hemorrhagic, necrotic, and nephrotoxic activities of the viper venoms. The study demonstrated the successful production of potent, truly polyspecific antisera against the three vipers using the low dose, low volume multi-site immunization protocol. The commercial polyspecific antivenom in the form of F(ab')2 has been produced from the hyperimmune (HP) antisera by QSMI. This potent antivenom is expected to help save the lives of many victims of envenomation by the three and other related vipers in Southeast Asian countries.
The Salmonella effector protein SseI, translocated into host cells by the Salmonella Pathogenicity Island 2 (SPI2) type III secretion system (T3SS), is required for Salmonella typhimurium to maintain a long-term chronic systemic infection in mice. SseI inhibits normal cell migration of primary macrophages and dendritic cells (DC) in vitro, and this inhibition requires the host factor IQ motif containing GTPase activating protein 1 (IQGAP1), an important regulator of cell migration. SseI binds directly to IQGAP1 and co-localizes with this factor at the cell periphery. The C-terminal domain of SseI is similar to PMT/ToxA, a bacterial toxin that contains a cysteine residue critical for activity. Mutation of the corresponding residue in SseI (C178A) eliminates SseI function in vitro and in vivo, but not binding to IQGAP1. Infection with wild-type (WT) S. typhimurium suppressed DC migration to the spleen in vivo in an SseI-dependent manner. Examination of spleens from mice infected with WT S. typhimurium revealed fewer DC and CD4+ T lymphocytes compared to mice infected with ΔsseI S. typhimurium. These results demonstrate that SseI inhibits normal host cell migration, which ultimately counteracts the ability of the host to clear systemic bacteria. SseI's mechanism of action involves the interaction with IQGAP1, an important regulator of the cytoskeleton and cell migration.
The study investigated the role of the mobile genetic element SCCmec-encoded psm-mec RNA in regulating the virulence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The researchers found that psm-mec RNA suppresses the translation of the agrA gene, which encodes a positive transcription factor for the production of phenol-soluble modulin α (PSMα), a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. PSMα is responsible for the high virulence of community-acquired MRSA (CA-MRSA) compared to hospital-associated MRSA (HA-MRSA). The study demonstrated that psm-mec RNA specifically binds to agrA mRNA and inhibits its translation, leading to reduced PSMα expression. In contrast, HA-MRSA strains with mutations in the psm-mec promoter or lacking the psm-mec gene exhibited increased PSMα expression and virulence. Deletion of psm-mec from HA-MRSA strains carrying intact psm-mec resulted in increased expression of AgrA and PSMα, and enhanced virulence in mice. The study suggests that the absence of psm-mec is a genetic determinant of the high virulence property of CA-MRSA, and that psm-mec RNA plays a crucial role in suppressing MRSA virulence. Furthermore, the study proposes that identifying psm-mec mutations could be a novel method for predicting the virulence properties of MRSA strains. The findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the virulence of MRSA and highlight the importance of psm-mec RNA in regulating S. aureus virulence.
Scientists have investigated the phenomenon of antibody-mediated disease enhancement (ADE) in the context of dengue virus (DENV) infection, where maternal antibodies can increase the severity of disease in offspring upon primary infection with a heterologous or homologous DENV serotype. To replicate this phenomenon in a mouse model, researchers used type I interferon ( IFN ) receptor-deficient mice ( A129 ) born to DENV1-immune mothers and infected them with DENV2. The results showed that these mice exhibited enhanced disease severity, characterized by increased virus titers, extensive vascular leakage, and eventual death. However, to better mimic the natural human immune response, the researchers sought to reproduce this model in a less immunocompromised background. They found that 5-week-old A129 mice born to DENV1-immune mothers succumbed to a DENV2 infection within 4 days, which was sub-lethal in mice born to naïve mothers. Clinical manifestations included extensive hepatocyte vacuolation, moderate vascular leakage, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Anti-TNFα therapy completely protected the mice and correlated with healthy hepatocytes, while blocking IL-6 did not impact the virus titers or disease outcome. This A129 mouse model of ADE may help elucidate the mechanisms involved in dengue pathogenesis and evaluate the efficacy of vaccine and therapeutic candidates. The model also has the potential to investigate the protective or enhancing properties of vaccination-induced maternal antibodies in infants and the possible interference of maternal antibodies on vaccination efficacy in babies and young children.
A systematic review and meta-analysis was conducted to identify factors associated with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in humans in the Americas. The review included 51 studies and found that male sex was associated with VL in studies using the leishmanin skin test for diagnosis and in those where the clinical disease was the outcome. In contrast, male sex was not associated with VL when serological diagnosis was applied. Younger individuals were less frequently infected than adults but were more prone to illness. The presence of dogs at home, higher dog seropositivity in nearby areas, lower socioeconomic status, and highly vegetated areas were also associated with L. infantum infection. However, the presence of chickens in the house and nutritional status were not associated with VL. Ecological studies showed consistent evidence that dog seropositivity is associated with human VL, emphasizing the relevance of dogs as a marker of the occurrence of VL among humans. The review highlights the need for studies to be conducted in new areas of the continent with improved methodological quality to investigate the patterns identified and their causes, as well as variables for which knowledge is poor. The findings of this review should be taken into account in developing more effective and well-targeted control measures for VL in the Americas.
Inhalation of Francisella tularensis ( Ft ) leads to acute and fatal pneumonia in mice, with the lung cytokine environment favoring exponential Ft replication. However, the mechanisms underlying acute pathogenesis and death remain unclear. This study investigated the sequential and systemic host immune response in pulmonary tularemia and found that an overt innate cellular response to Ft, rather than overwhelming bacterial burden or cytokine production, drives tissue pathology and host mortality. Lethal infection with Ft elicits medullary and extra-medullary myelopoiesis, resulting in the recruitment of large numbers of immature myeloid cells ( IMC ) and myeloid-derived suppressor cells ( MDSC ) to the lungs. These cells fail to mature and die, leading to necrotic lung damage, loss of pulmonary function, and host death that is partially dependent on immature Ly6G+ cells. In contrast, during sub-lethal infection with Ft, the pulmonary cellular response is characterized by a predominance of mature neutrophils and monocytes, which are required for protection against Ft. The study reveals that the nature of the myeloid cell response may be the primary determinant of host mortality versus survival following Francisella infection. Further, eliciting a mature phagocyte response provides transient but dramatic innate protection against Ft SchuS4. The findings suggest that differences in host mortality versus survival may be reflected not primarily by control of bacterial load, but by the nature of the innate myeloid cell response during the acute phase of infection.
The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is a global invader and vector of medically important arboviruses such as chikungunya, dengue, and Zika. To understand the complex colonization pattern of this mosquito, researchers combined classical population genetics analyses and Approximate Bayesian Computation (ABC) approaches to reconstruct the demographic history of Aedes albopictus populations from representative countries in Southeast Asia and recently colonized areas. The results indicate that populations in Southeast Asia, including China, Thailand, and Japan, maintain high genetic connectivity, revealing their ancestral common origin. China appears to be the oldest population. In contrast, the invasion process in La Réunion, America, and the Mediterranean Basin is primarily supported by a chaotic propagule distribution, which maintains a relatively high genetic diversity within adventive populations. Independent and trans-continental introductions of Ae. albopictus may have facilitated the rapid establishment of adventive populations through admixture of unrelated genomes, resulting in a great amount of intra-population variability. This variability may extend to the genetic mechanisms controlling vector competence, potentially contributing to the efficient transmission of arboviruses and outbreak establishment. The study provides valuable information on the origins of populations from various regions and highlights the importance of considering the interactions between genetic factors and environmental landscapes in assessing the risk of arbovirus outbreaks.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a pathogen commonly associated with chronic wound infections, has been found to exhibit reduced virulence functions and biofilm formation capabilities in clinical isolates from human wounds. Contrary to previous assumptions, these findings suggest that bacterial fitness in chronic wounds is not mediated by virulence or biofilm functions. Instead, genes involved in anaerobic growth, metabolic and energy pathways, and membrane integrity were critical for bacterial fitness in experimental mouse wounds. High-density bacterial growth conditions were found to be a key factor in mediating bacterial fitness in wounds, both in the presence and absence of a host. These results shed light on the bacterial functions necessary for chronic wound infections and the stresses that affect bacterial fitness in wounds. The study suggests that the predominant stresses on bacteria in wounds may be applied by the bacteria themselves, rather than the host, and that overlapping functions may counteract both bacterial and host-applied stresses. The findings also raise the possibility that chronic wounds may be relatively permissive environments where bacterial nutrient acquisition and growth do not depend on invasive or toxic functions. The study used a diabetic mouse model, which is relevant to human wound pathogenesis, and found that Pseudomonas aeruginosa inhibited wound-healing in the model, directly linking infection to disease. These results provide new insights into the pathogenesis of chronic wound infections and suggest potential therapeutic targets to compromise wound infection pathogenesis.
A prospective study was conducted at the Center for Teaching, Research and Tertiary Referral for Bancroftian Filariasis (NEPAF) to evaluate the occurrence of intrascrotal lymphangiectasia, gross appearance/consistency of the testis, and the efficacy of complete excision of hydrocele sac in patients living in a bancroftian filariasis endemic area. The study included 1,128 patients with uni- or bilateral filarial hydrocele (Group-1) and a comparison group of 218 patients who had undergone hydrocele-sac-sparing hydrocelectomy elsewhere (Group-2). The results showed that the hydrocele recurrence rates in Group-1 and Group-2 were 0.3% and 19.3%, respectively (p<0.001). Per-surgically leaking or leak-prone dilated lymphatic vessels were seen in 30.9% and 46.3% of patients in Group-1 and Group-2, respectively (p=0.081). The testicles were abnormal in shape, volume, and consistency in 18% and 35.7% of patients from Group-1 and Group-2, respectively (p=0.025). The study suggests that lymph fluid from ruptured dilated lymphatic vessels is an important component of chronic filarial hydrocele fluid that threatens the integrity of the testis in an adult population living in bancroftian filariasis endemic areas. The authors recommend complete excision of hydrocele sac and suture or excision of leaking or leak-prone dilated lymphatic vessels to avoid hydrocele recurrence.
A deubiquitinating enzyme (DUB) from the parasitic nematode Trichinella spiralis, TsUCH37, has been identified and characterized. TsUCH37 is a cysteine protease that is putatively orthologous to the human protein UCH-L5. The enzyme was identified using an activity-based probe, HA-Ub-VME, which revealed DUB activity in lysate of T. spiralis L1 larvae. Immuno-precipitation and LC/MS/MS analysis identified peptides with sequence homology to five conserved human DUBs, including UCH-L5, UCH-L3, HAUSP, OTU 6B, and Ataxin-3. The predicted gene encoding TsUCH37 was cloned, and recombinant protein was expressed and purified. The deubiquitinating activity of TsUCH37 was verified using the Ub-AMC assay. Co-precipitation experiments showed that TsUCH37 associates with putative T. spiralis proteasome components, including the yeast Rpn13 homologue ADRM1. The UCH inhibitor LDN-57444 specifically inhibited recombinant TsUCH37 and reduced the viability of cultured L1 larvae. These findings suggest that the interaction of TsUCH37 with the proteasome has been conserved throughout evolution. The study highlights the potential use of inhibitor compounds to elucidate the role of UCH enzymes in T. spiralis infection and their investigation as therapeutic targets for trichinellosis.
The study investigated the anti-trypanosomal activity of non-peptidic nitrile-based cysteine protease inhibitors against the CL Brener strain of Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease. Three nitrile-based cysteine protease inhibitors were found to exhibit anti-trypanosomal activity in the 0. 1 μM to 1 μM range, with two compounds showing EC50 values of 0. 12 μM and 0. 25 μM. These values were significantly lower than the corresponding Ki values measured against cruzain, a recombinant form of cruzipain, suggesting a putative polypharmacological profile towards cysteine proteases. The study also evaluated cathepsin K inhibitors based on a cyclohexane dicarboxamide scaffold and found that two compounds exhibited significantly greater anti-trypanosomal activity than expected based on their cruzain inhibitory activity. The results suggest that the anti-trypanosomal effects of the most potent compounds may be due to inhibition of one or more cysteine proteases, including isoforms such as cruzipain-2, which have not yet been identified as potential targets for therapeutic intervention. The study highlights the potential of non-peptidic nitrile-based cysteine protease inhibitors as antichagasic agents and suggests that phenotypic screening libraries for discovery of antichagasic agents should include potent inhibitors of cathepsin K.
Maize (Zea mays L.) is a crucial cereal crop and a model organism for studying genetics, evolution, and domestication. A sequence-ready fingerprinted contig-based physical map was constructed to cover 93.5% of the maize genome, with 86.1% aligned to the genetic map. This map contains 25,908 genic markers, enabling the alignment of nearly 73% of the anchored maize genome to the rice genome. The distribution pattern of expressed sequence tags correlates with recombination, and in collinear regions, 1 kb in rice corresponds to an average of 3.2 kb in maize. However, maize has a 6-fold genome size expansion, which can be attributed to its recent polyploid origin, resulting in most rice regions corresponding to two regions in maize. Inversions account for the majority of chromosome structural variations during subsequent maize diploidization. Additionally, evidence of ancient genome duplication predating the divergence of maize and rice progenitors was found. The paleoethnobotany of the maize genome indicates that the progenitors of modern maize contained ten chromosomes. Comparative restricted fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) mapping across cereals showed that two maize chromosome sets aligned with one chromosome each of rice and sorghum, demonstrating a whole genome duplication event. The maize genome is thought to have emerged from tetraploidization of several ancient duplicated regions, with multiple duplication events contributing to its complex duplication pattern. Genome rearrangements have occurred since the divergence of maize and rice, as shown by synteny analysis.
The study aimed to investigate the de novo generation of infectious prions in vitro using the protein misfolding cyclic amplification (PMCA) procedure. Prions are proteinaceous infectious agents responsible for Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies (TSEs), and the prion hypothesis suggests that they are composed of a misfolded version of the prion protein (PrPSc) that replicates in the absence of nucleic acids by inducing the misfolding of the cellular prion protein (PrPC). The study found that under standard PMCA conditions, de novo generation of PrPSc was not observed, supporting the use of the technology for diagnostic applications. However, modifications to the PMCA procedure allowed for the generation of PrPSc in the absence of pre-existing PrPSc in different animal species at a low and variable rate. The de novo generated PrPSc was found to be infectious when inoculated into wild-type hamsters, producing a new disease phenotype with unique clinical, neuropathological, and biochemical features. These findings provide additional evidence in support of the prion hypothesis and suggest that prion diversity is not restricted to those currently known, and that new forms of infectious protein foldings may be produced, resulting in novel disease phenotypes. The study also highlights the potential of PMCA as a tool for studying the mechanism of sporadic prion disease.
A novel neurally based model, the Angular Velocity Detector Unit (AVDU), has been developed to estimate angular velocity (AV) in the bee brain. The model is capable of quantitatively reproducing experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering in free-flying honeybees, including previously unaccounted for manipulations of behavior. The AVDU is fitted using electrophysiological data and tested using behavioral data. The model suggests that the AV response can be considered as an evolutionary extension to the optomotor response. The detector is tested behaviorally in silico with the corridor-centering paradigm, where bees navigate down a corridor with gratings on the walls. The results show that the detector reproduces the invariance of the average flight path to the spatial frequency and contrast of the gratings, including deviations from perfect centering behavior. Additionally, the summed response of the detector to a unit distance movement along the corridor is constant for a large range of grating spatial frequencies, demonstrating that the detector can be used as a visual odometer. The AVDU is proposed as an extension of the optomotor pathway, allowing different detectors to be constructed by drawing selectively from a pool of elementary motion detectors with varying response timescales and calculating the desired final response by combining the selected responses.
A long-term follow-up study of 50 human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) patients from the Ivory Coast has revealed that untreated infections by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, the main agent of sleeping sickness, do not always result in a fatal outcome. Among 11 patients who refused treatment after initial diagnosis, 10 showed parasite clearance using microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) over a 15-year period. Most of these patients (7/10) also displayed decreasing serological responses, becoming progressively negative to trypanosome variable antigens. Two alternative natural progressions of HAT were observed: progression to an apparently aparasitaemic and asymptomatic infection associated with strong long-lasting serological responses, and progression to an apparently spontaneous resolution of infection with negative results in parasitological tests and PCR. These findings suggest that trypanotolerance exists in humans, as is widely accepted for animals. The study's results are based on clinical, serological, molecular, and parasitological investigations combining field diagnostic tools and highly specific and sensitive laboratory tests. The study's findings have significant implications for future research in the field of HAT, particularly in understanding the natural evolution of T. b. gambiense infection in its human host.
This study investigated the role of p53 disruption in the carcinogenic effect of ionizing irradiation on hematopoietic progenitor cells in vivo. The researchers used mouse models to determine whether irradiation selects for p53-deficient hematopoietic progenitors. They found that p53 disruption does not provide a selective advantage in an unstressed hematopoietic system or in previously irradiated bone marrow allowed to recover from irradiation. However, upon irradiation, p53 disruption confers a dramatic selective advantage, leading to the long-term expansion of p53-deficient clones and increased lymphoma development. The selection for p53-deficient cells is attributed to several factors, including protection from acute irradiation-induced ablation of progenitor cells, prevention of irradiation-induced loss of clonogenic capacity for stem and progenitor cells, improved long-term maintenance of progenitor cell fitness, and the disabling/elimination of competing p53 wild-type progenitors. These findings indicate that the carcinogenic effect of ionizing irradiation can be partly explained by increased selection for cells with p53 disruption, which protects progenitor cells from immediate elimination and long-term reductions in fitness following irradiation. The study suggests that the causal link between radiation exposure, p53 disruption, and cancers involves selection for p53 loss rather than irradiation-induced mutagenesis at loci encoding proliferation control genes.
The study investigated the role of Schistosoma mansoni SmKI-1 serine protease inhibitor in parasite development and its potential as a therapeutic molecule against inflammatory diseases. SmKI-1 was found to possess inhibitory activity against trypsin and neutrophil elastase (NE) through its Kunitz domain. Molecular docking studies revealed a complete blockage of NE's active site by SmKI-1's Kunitz domain. Recombinant SmKI-1 significantly inhibited NE's ability to kill schistosomes. Gene suppression of SmKI-1 in S. mansoni larvae resulted in impaired parasite development in vitro and in vivo. The study also demonstrated SmKI-1's anti-inflammatory potential in murine models of inflammatory diseases, including acetaminophen-mediated liver damage and gout arthritis. Treatment with SmKI-1 reduced neutrophil recruitment, elastase activity, and overall pathological score in these models. Additionally, SmKI-1 inhibited early events that trigger neutrophil recruitment in pleural cavities of mice in response to carrageenan. These findings suggest that SmKI-1 is a key protein in S. mansoni survival and has the potential to inhibit neutrophil function as a therapeutic molecule against inflammatory diseases. SmKI-1's ability to interact with elastase's catalytic site and inhibit enzyme activity may be an immune evasion mechanism developed by the parasite. The study highlights the potential of SmKI-1 as a therapeutic target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.
A novel method has been developed for accurately modeling large transmembrane helical (TMH) protein structures from distant homologues with distinct loop and TMH conformations. This method was tested in two blind predictions and a large benchmark of 50 TMH protein homolog pairs with diverse topology, size, and sequence identity. The results show that the method improves most starting templates and achieves near-atomic accuracy prediction of membrane-embedded regions. The method was first-ranked in the GPCR-DOCK blind prediction contests for the adenosine A2AR and chemokine CXCR4 receptors. In the benchmark, the method was able to improve most starting templates to reach near-atomic accuracy prediction in the TMH regions. The technique was also tested in two challenging blind predictions of membrane receptor structures, GPCR-DOCK 2008 for the adenosine receptor (A2AR) and GPCR-DOCK 2010 for the chemokine receptor (CXCR4). The results suggest that the method is useful for rebuilding and refining X-ray structures of membrane receptors where functionally important loop regions have missing densities or are often deleted to facilitate crystallization. The method has the potential to be useful for the atom-level modeling and design of a large fraction of structurally uncharacterized TMH proteins from a wide range of structural homologues. This is particularly important for the design of more effective therapeutics and receptors with novel function for systems/synthetic biology applications that rely on atomic-resolution information.
Listeria monocytogenes, the causative agent of listeriosis, has been found to switch from an active, motile lifestyle to a persistent state in epithelial cells during prolonged infections. In human hepatocytes and trophoblast cells, L. monocytogenes ceases to produce the actin-nucleating protein ActA and becomes trapped in lysosome-like vacuoles called Listeria-Containing Vacuoles (LisCVs). Subpopulations of bacteria within these vacuoles resist degradation and enter a slow, non-replicative state. The bacteria can cycle between the vacuolar and actin-based motility stages, and when ActA is absent, they enter a "viable but non-culturable" state, making them undetectable by conventional colony counting methods. Exposure to high doses of gentamicin selects for vacuolar and "viable but non-culturable" bacteria. These findings suggest that L. monocytogenes can persist in a subset of epithelial cells, potentially leading to asymptomatic carriage, prolonged incubation periods of listeriosis, and increased survival during antibiotic therapy. The ability of L. monocytogenes to adopt a vacuolar lifestyle in epithelial cells may have significant implications for understanding the pathogenesis of listeriosis and developing effective treatment strategies. The study highlights the need to revisit the intracellular lifecycle of L. monocytogenes in light of its ability to live in vacuoles.
A neuromechanistic model of auditory bistability was developed to study the dynamics of alternations in auditory streaming after the build-up phase. The model incorporates sound-evoked A1 responses as input to a competition network, where perceptual states are identified in the neuronal dynamics rather than pre-assigned to phenomenological units. The inclusion of NMDA-like synaptic dynamics enables temporal binding from one triplet to the next to deal with gaps in the periodic sound input. The model predicts that manipulations of the frequency difference between tones A and B should affect the dominance durations of the stronger percept more than those of the weaker percept. This prediction was confirmed with psychoacoustic experiments, and the behavioral data was used to further constrain and improve the model, achieving quantitative agreement between experimental and modeling results. The model provides a platform that can be extended to consider other stimulus conditions, including the effects of context and volition. The study focuses on accurately reproducing the dynamics of alternations after the build-up phase, distinguishing it from existing auditory models. Model parameters controlling the balance between adaptation and noise were tuned to match the statistics of perceptual durations, and A1 responses were interpreted in a statistical model using neurometric functions that mimic the time course of build-up. The model suggests that inputs should be dynamic and depend on perceptual state, rather than simply increasing stimulus strength to favor the attended percept.
A novel method for assessing the allergenicity of Schistosoma mansoni proteins has been developed using a humanised Rat Basophilic Leukaemia (RBL) reporter cell line (RS-ATL8) in combination with a cell-free in vitro translation system. This system enables the rapid translation of S. mansoni proteins within 90 minutes, allowing for the assessment of potential allergenicity without the need for purification. The method involves incubating the translated proteins with serum from infected individuals and measuring Luciferase activity in the RS-ATL8 reporter cell line, which indicates cellular activation by the suspected allergen. The suitability of this system was demonstrated using well-characterised plant and parasitic allergens, including Par j 2, SmTAL-1, and IPSE/alpha-1. SmTAL-1 was found to activate the basophil reporter cell line, while SmTAL2, used as a negative control, did not. This method offers an accessible way to assess the potential allergenicity of anti-helminthic vaccine candidates and is suitable for medium- to high-throughput studies using infected individual sera. The technology has the potential to unravel the entire allergome of S. mansoni and other medically important parasites, leading to a better understanding of the basis of allergenicity and the relationship between parasite-specific IgE and host protection mechanisms at the molecular level.
This study investigates the effects of transposable element (TE) divergence on gene and TE expression in a hybrid dysgenic syndrome of Drosophila virilis. Hybrid dysgenesis occurs when TEs inherited from the father are not matched with a pool of corresponding TE silencing PIWI-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) provided by the female germline, leading to germline damage and sterility. The study characterizes the effects of TE profile divergence between parents on offspring using the D. virilis syndrome as a model. The results show that divergence in the TE landscape is associated with persisting differences in germline TE expression between genetically identical females of reciprocal crosses, which are transmitted to the next generation. Furthermore, chronic and persisting TE expression coincides with increased levels of genic piRNAs associated with reduced gene expression. The study also demonstrates that gene expression is idiosyncratically influenced by differences in the genic piRNA profile of the parents, which arise through polymorphic TE insertions.
