These findings support a model in which early germline events in dysgenesis establish a chronic, stable state of both TE and gene expression in the germline that is maintained through adulthood and transmitted to the next generation. Overall, the results suggest that divergence in the TE profile is associated with diverse piRNA-mediated transgenerational effects on gene expression within populations.
The study investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying Fragile X Tremor Ataxia Syndrome (FXTAS), a neurodegenerative disorder caused by expansion of a CGG trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene. Researchers found that overexpression of histone deacetylases (HDACs) 3, 6, or 11 suppressed CGG repeat-induced neurodegeneration in a Drosophila model of FXTAS. This suppression resulted from selective transcriptional repression of the CGG repeat-containing transgene. The study also showed that histone acetyltransferase (HAT) inhibitors repressed FMR1 mRNA expression to control levels in pre-mutation carrier cell lines and extended lifespan in CGG repeat-expressing Drosophila. The results suggest that the CGG repeat expansion in FXTAS promotes chromatin remodeling in cis, leading to increased expression of the toxic FMR1 mRNA. Furthermore, the study found increased acetylation of histones at the FMR1 locus in pre-mutation carriers compared to control or FXS-derived cell lines. This epigenetic change correlates with elevated FMR1 mRNA expression in pre-mutation cell lines. The findings provide a disease model for FXTAS and suggest that HAT inhibitors or HDAC activators might be used to selectively repress transcription at the FMR1 locus. The study's results also indicate that alterations in chromatin structure at the FMR1 locus are dynamic and modifiable, and that various genetic and pharmacologic manipulations of histone acetylation can change the level of transcription in human cells and animal models.
The study investigated the role of host genetics in controlling CD8 T cell function and lethal immunopathology during chronic viral infection. MHC alleles and the degree of MHC heterogeneity were found to be associated with enhanced CD8 T cell function and viral control during human chronic infection. To examine the impact of MHC heterogeneity versus non-MHC host genetics on the development of chronic viral infection, an F1 cross of B10. D2 x B6 ( D2B6F1 ) and BALB. B x BALB/c ( BCF1 ) mice were infected with the clone-13 ( Cl-13 ) strain of lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus ( LCMV ). The results showed that both H-2bxd D2B6F1 and BCF1 mice demonstrated increased viral control compared to homozygous mice. However, H-2bxd D2B6F1 mice on a C57BL genetic background exhibited mortality following Cl-13 infection. CD8 T cell depletion prevented mortality in Cl-13-infected D2B6F1 mice, indicating that mortality was CD8 T-cell-dependent. The study found that D2B6F1 mice maintained more CD8 T cell effector cytokine production and exhibited reduced expression of the T cell exhaustion marker PD-1. Furthermore, D2B6F1 mice induced a larger Th1 response than BCF1 mice and Cl-13-induced mortality in D2B6F1 mice was also dependent on CD4 T-cell-mediated IFN-γ production. The results suggest that increased functionality of the CD8 T cell response allowed for more rapid viral clearance at the cost of enhanced immunopathology dependent on both MHC diversity and the genetic background of the host.
This study investigated the genetic characteristics of Bacillus anthracis isolated from northwestern China from 1990 to 2016. A total of 106 strains were analyzed using canonical single-nucleotide polymorphism (canSNP) analysis and multilocus variable-number tandem repeat analysis (MLVA) with 15 markers. The results showed that five sublineages/subgroups of B. anthracis were detected, including A. Br. 001/002, A. Br. Vollum, A. Br. Aust94, A. Br. Ames, and A. Br. 008/009. These sublineages were found in various provinces, including Xinjiang, Shaanxi, Gansu, Qinghai, and Inner Mongolia. However, the geographical distribution of the B. anthracis populations exhibited different canSNP characteristics from those of the strains isolated before 1990 in China. The A. Br. Ames subgroup was also observed to be scattered from Inner Mongolia to other provinces. MLVA15 genotypes were assigned to all 106 strains, and 21 of these types were first observed in this study. The strains collected from anthrax outbreaks in the recent decade were classified as subgroups A. Br. 001/002 and A. Br. Ames and identified as genotypes MLVA15-28, MLVA15-30, MLVA15-31, MLVA15-38, MLVA15-CHN3, and MLVA15-CHN18. The study found that the diversification of MLVA genotypes and the geographical distribution of B. anthracis populations is gradually becoming balanced across northwestern China. This study provides preliminary survey results regarding the population diversity of B. anthracis in China, which will help promote the prevention and control of this important disease.
Goblet cells in the intestinal epithelium play a crucial role in defending against enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli and related pathogens that cause severe diarrheal disease. During infection, goblet cells produce various mediators, including Resistin-like Molecule (RELM)-β, which is strongly induced in response to Citrobacter rodentium, a related mouse pathogen. RELM-β acts as a CD4+ T cell chemoattractant, recruiting these immune cells to the infected colon, where they drive a protective increase in intestinal epithelial cell (IEC) proliferation through the production of interleukin-22 (IL-22). Mice lacking the RELM-β gene (Retnlb-/-) suffer increased mortality and mucosal ulceration due to deep pathogen penetration of colonic crypts and impaired IEC hyper-proliferation. Enema delivery of RELM-β to Retnlb-/- mice restores CD4+ T cell recruitment, increases IL-22 levels, and promotes IEC proliferation, reducing mucosal pathology. These findings demonstrate that RELM-β and goblet cells play a critical role in recruiting CD4+ T cells to the colon to protect against enteric pathogens, in part via the induction of increased IEC proliferation. This study expands the role attributed to goblet cells in providing host defense against enteric bacteria and highlights the importance of RELM-β in recruiting immune cells to the site of infection.
The interaction between the C-terminal motif of norovirus VPg and the HEAT-1 domain of eukaryotic initiation factor 4G (eIF4G) is essential for translation initiation in noroviruses, a major cause of gastroenteritis in humans. Norovirus RNA lacks a 5´ m7G cap and internal ribosome entry site (IRES), and instead relies on the VPg protein covalently attached to the 5´-end of the viral RNA to interact with eIFs in the host cell. Using pull-down assays, fluorescence anisotropy, and isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC), the study demonstrates that a 20-amino acid stretch at the C-terminus of murine norovirus (MNV) VPg mediates direct and specific binding to the HEAT-1 domain within the 4GM fragment of eIF4G. This interaction is conserved in all known noroviruses. Fine mutagenic mapping suggests that the MNV VPg C-terminus may interact with eIF4G in a helical conformation. NMR spectroscopy was used to define the VPg binding site on eIF4G HEAT-1, which was confirmed by mutagenesis and binding assays. The study also shows that this site is non-overlapping with the binding site for eIF4A on eIF4G HEAT-1. The functional significance of the VPg-eIF4G interaction was demonstrated by the ability of fusion proteins containing the C-terminal peptide of MNV VPg to inhibit in vitro translation of norovirus RNA but not cap- or IRES-dependent translation. These findings define important structural details of a functional interaction between norovirus VPg and eIF4G and reveal a binding interface that might be exploited as a target for antiviral therapy.
The evolution of gene clusters in bacterial genomes has been a topic of interest in the scientific community, with several explanations proposed to account for their formation. The selfish operon model suggests that clustered arrangements of genes are more easily transferred to other species, improving the prospects for survival of the cluster. In contrast, the persistence model proposes that genes in close proximity are less likely to be disrupted by deletions. To investigate the conditions under which gene clusters can evolve, the authors developed computational models to study the selfish operon model, a Moran process with natural selection for gene clustering and genome inversion events, and a model that includes selection and inversion. The results show that gene clusters fail to evolve under a wide range of conditions, but can occur under certain conditions such as a low number of genes in the pathway, a high population size, and a high horizontal transfer rate in the case of the selfish operon model. The selfish operon model remains a viable explanation for the evolution of gene clusters under these conditions. However, the model is unable to explain the observation that genes in clusters are sometimes arranged in the order of biochemical reactions, suggesting that multiple mechanisms may be involved. The persistence model, which proposes that clustered genes are less likely to be disrupted by deletions, is an alternative explanation for the clustering of essential genes.
Malaria, a disease caused by the parasite Plasmodium falciparum, poses significant health and economic burdens in tropical regions. Pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to severe consequences of the infection due to the specific adhesion of parasite-infected erythrocytes in the placenta. This adhesion is mediated by a unique variant of PfEMP1, a parasite-encoded, hyper-variable antigen, called VAR2CSA. VAR2CSA binds to chondroitin sulfate A on syncytiotrophoblasts in the intervillous space of placentas. The gene encoding VAR2CSA is only expressed in the presence of a placenta, suggesting that its expression is actively repressed in men, children, or non-pregnant women. A small upstream open reading frame (uORF) in the var2csa gene acts to repress translation of the resulting mRNA, revealing a novel form of gene regulation in malaria parasites. This translational repression is reversible, allowing high levels of protein translation upon selection, potentially enabling parasites to upregulate expression of this variant antigen in the presence of the appropriate host tissue. Further studies into the mechanisms used by malaria parasites to regulate VAR2CSA expression will provide insights into the molecular basis of the host-parasite interactions underlying the pathogenesis of the disease. The conservation of the var2csa gene in most Plasmodium falciparum isolates and its presence in the chimpanzee parasite Plasmodium reichenowi suggest a selective pressure acting on preservation of this gene.
A genome-wide microarray analysis was conducted on whole blood RNA from 34 dengue virus (DENV)-infected children in Nicaragua to investigate the transcriptional profiles of peripheral blood immune cells. The study aimed to elucidate the pathophysiology of severe versus non-severe manifestations of DENV infection. Gene expression analysis identified differentially regulated genes between clinical subgroups, with striking transcriptional differences observed between dengue patients with and without shock, particularly in the expression of mitochondrial ribosomal proteins associated with protein biosynthesis. In dengue hemorrhagic fever patients, a subset of differentially expressed genes encoded neutrophil-derived anti-microbial peptides associated with innate immunity. A meta-analysis of the dataset in conjunction with previously published datasets confirmed that DENV infection in vivo is associated with large changes to protein and nucleic acid metabolism. Notably, the interferon response observed in vitro was not consistently observed in in vivo patient samples, suggesting a transient interferon response by days 3-6 of illness. The study highlights important differences between different manifestations of severity during DENV infection and identifies commonalities. A meta-analysis of larger datasets across multiple studies may lead to better prediction of disease manifestation via a systems biology approach. The study also identified a distinct molecular profile between Nicaraguan dengue patients with shock and those with dengue hemorrhagic fever, as well as between severe and non-severe dengue cases. A total of 32 genes were significantly different between severe and non-severe dengue cases, with 25 genes more highly expressed in severe patients and 7 genes more highly expressed in non-severe patients.
The study investigated the host entry mechanisms of Murid Herpesvirus-4 ( MuHV-4 ), a lymphotropic rhadinovirus related to Kaposi's Sarcoma-associated Herpesvirus. MuHV-4 was found to target the olfactory neuroepithelium for host entry in vivo. The virus exploits the presence of heparan sulfate ( HS ) on the apical neuronal cilia of the olfactory neuroepithelium for binding and entry. In contrast, the respiratory epithelium, which also expresses HS, was bound poorly by incoming virions. The olfactory neuroepithelium is composed of neurons, sustentacular cells, and basal precursor cells, and MuHV-4 was found to infect both neurons and sustentacular cells. The infection ratio of sustentacular cells to neurons was approximately 3.6:1. The study suggests that the olfactory neuroepithelium provides an important site for herpesvirus entry, and that HS binding is a key component of this process. The findings imply that neuroepithelial-targeted, HS-based interventions could provide a general means of herpesvirus infection control. The study also highlights the specificity of MuHV-4 infection to the olfactory neuroepithelium, as virions lacking HS binding proteins poorly infect transformed epithelial cells and lungs. Overall, the study provides new insights into the host entry mechanisms of MuHV-4 and the role of the olfactory neuroepithelium in herpesvirus infection.
The study reveals a novel regulatory circuit involving CRP-cAMP in the silencing of Salmonella virulence genes under non-permissive conditions. CRP-cAMP, a widely established metabolic regulator, modulates the expression of HilD, the master regulator of Salmonella invasion, at the post-transcriptional level. This regulation occurs through a newly identified regulatory motif within the 3' untranslated region (3'UTR) of the hilD gene. The study shows that CRP-cAMP-deficient Salmonella strains exhibit a strong upregulation of SPI-1 genes in the mid-logarithmic growth phase and are unable to secrete SPI-1 T3SS effector proteins, indicating a role for CRP-cAMP in the regulation of Salmonella virulence. In vivo and in vitro assays indicate that the Hfq-dependent sRNA Spot 42 is under the transcriptional repression of CRP-cAMP and, when this repression is relieved, exerts a positive effect on hilD expression. Spot 42 targets the 3'UTR of the hilD transcript through its unstructured region III. The study highlights the biological relevance of the hilD 3'UTR as a hub for post-transcriptional control of Salmonella invasion gene expression. The CRP-cAMP-mediated regulation of hilD does not occur at the transcriptional initiation level but rather at the post-transcriptional level through the long 3'UTR of hilD. The study suggests that CRP-cAMP is a regulator tailored to mediate rapid responses to environmental changes and may be relevant for HilD-mediated regulation of virulence in response to environmental conditions encountered during the infection process.
The study investigated the relationship between CAG/CTG repeat instability, chromatin structure, and transcription at the Huntington’s disease (HD) locus in R6/1 and R6/2 HD transgenic mouse lines. CAG/CTG expansions are responsible for HD and myotonic dystrophy 1, and their instability in somatic tissues accelerates disease progression. The study found that CAG instability rates were higher in R6/2 tissues compared to R6/1 matched-samples. High transgene expression levels and chromatin accessibility correlated with increased CAG instability in R6/2 mice. Transgene mRNA and H3K4 trimethylation at the HD locus were increased, while H3K9 dimethylation was reduced in R6/2 tissues relative to R6/1 matched-tissues. Notably, the levels of elongating RNA Pol II at the HD locus, but not the initiating form of RNA Pol II, were tissue-specific and correlated with CAG instability levels. H3K36 trimethylation, a mark associated with transcription elongation, was specifically increased at the HD locus in the striatum and not in the cerebellum. These findings suggest that transcription modulates somatic CAG instability in vivo and that transcription elongation is regulated in a tissue-dependent manner, contributing to tissue-selective CAG instability. The study also indicates that the integration site of the transgene influences repeat instability, affecting chromatin structure and transcriptional activity.
Enterovirus 71 ( EV71 ) is a highly virulent enterovirus that can cause severe neurological complications in humans. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying its ability to disseminate in humans are not well understood. To investigate this, researchers analyzed the genomic features of EV71 in an immunocompromised host with disseminated disease, comparing five full-length genomes sequenced from different sites of infection. Three nucleotide changes were identified within a five-day period : a non-conservative amino acid change in VP1 ( L97R ), a conservative substitution in protein 2B ( A38V ), and a silent mutation in protein 3D ( L175 ). Infectious clones containing these mutations were constructed and tested in vitro, revealing that the VP1 L97R substitution conferred a replicative advantage in neuroblastoma cells. This mutation was frequently associated with a second non-conservative mutation ( E167G or E167A ) in the VP1 EF loop in neuroblastoma cells. Comparative models of the EV71 VP1 variants suggested that the substitutions may alter interactions with host cell receptors. The study found that the VP1 BC loop region of EV71 plays a critical role in cell tropism, independent of EV71 lineage, and may have contributed to dissemination and neurotropism in the immunocompromised patient. These findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying EV71 infection and may have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies.
Pheromone Recognition and Selectivity by ComR Proteins among Streptococcus Species
    The ComRS system is a quorum sensing mechanism that regulates natural transformation, or competence, in the Gram-positive bacteria genus Streptococcus. This process allows bacteria to acquire new traits, such as antibiotic resistance, through the uptake of extracellular DNA. The ComRS system consists of a peptide (ComS) that is processed, secreted, and imported into the cytoplasm, where it binds and activates the transcription factor ComR. ComR then engages in a positive feedback loop to express ComS and the alternative sigma-factor SigX. Although ComRS is present in most Streptococcus species, the sequences of ComS/XIP and ComR diverge significantly, suggesting a mechanism for species-specific communication.

    To study cross-talk between Streptococcal species and the molecular interaction between ComR and XIP, an interdisciplinary approach was undertaken. A 'test-bed' assay was developed to measure the activity of different ComR proteins in response to cognate and heterologous XIP peptides in vivo. The results revealed distinct ComR classes of strict, intermediate, and promiscuous specificity among species. An X-ray crystal structure of ComR from S. suis was solved to understand the interaction with XIP and identify structural features that may explain XIP recognition. Site-directed mutagenesis was used to probe the apo conformation of the XIP-binding pocket, which is lined by a variable and conserved face. The conserved face contributes to ligand binding, while the variable face discriminates among XIP peptides. These findings provide a model for XIP recognition and specificity, allowing for the prediction of novel XIP peptides that induce ComR activity.
In the pathogenic yeast Candida albicans, centromeres are epigenetically inherited and maintained at specific chromosomal sites over generations. Unlike Saccharomyces cerevisiae, where centromeres are defined by a specific DNA sequence, Candida albicans centromeres are maintained by epigenetic mechanisms where DNA has a less definitive role. Genome-wide replication timing analysis revealed that each centromere in Candida albicans is associated with a replication origin that is the first to fire on its respective chromosome. The formation of new ectopic centromeres ( neocentromeres ) was accompanied by shifts in replication timing, with the neocentromere becoming the first to replicate and associating with origin recognition complex ( ORC ) components. Changes in the level of centromere-specific histone H3 isoform led to concomitant changes in ORC association with centromere regions, supporting the idea that centromere proteins determine origin activity. Analysis of centromere-associated DNA revealed a replication-dependent sequence pattern characteristic of constitutively active replication origins. This pattern is conserved among related strains and species, independent of primary DNA sequence, suggesting that inheritance of centromere position is correlated with a constitutively active origin of replication that fires at a distinct early time. The study proposes a model in which the distinct timing of DNA replication serves as an epigenetic mechanism for the inheritance of centromere position.
A genome-wide association study (GWAS) meta-analysis of 158,025 individuals of European ancestry identified three genetic loci associated with chronic back pain (CBP). The study, conducted by the Cohorts for Heart and Aging Research in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) consortium and the UK Biobank, used logistic regression models to adjust for age, sex, study-specific covariates, and population substructure. A genome-wide significant association was found for the intronic variant rs12310519 in SOX5 (OR 1.08, p = 7.2×10−10), which was subsequently replicated in 283,752 UK Biobank participants not included in the discovery sample (OR 1.06, p = 5.3×10−11) and exceeded genome-wide significance in joint meta-analysis (OR 1.07, p = 4.5×10−19). Two other loci, an intergenic variant rs7833174 located between CCDC26 and GSDMC (OR 1.05, p = 4.4×10−13) and an intronic variant rs4384683 in DCC (OR 0.97, p = 2.4×10−10), reached genome-wide significance in a 2-stage joint meta-analysis. The study aimed to elucidate the biological mechanisms underlying CBP and identified novel associations between specific genetic markers and the condition. The results suggest that genetic factors contribute to the development of CBP, and further research is needed to understand the underlying biology.
A study was conducted to estimate the disease burden of Taenia solium cysticercosis in Cameroon. The disease is a zoonosis that affects both humans and pigs in many developing countries, with human neurocysticercosis being a major cause of epilepsy in endemic regions. The study aimed to calculate the impact of this neglected zoonosis using cost and Disability Adjusted Life Year ( DALY ) estimations. Data on human and porcine cysticercosis in West Cameroon were collected and analyzed using R software. The estimated number of people with neurocysticercosis-associated epilepsy was 50, 326 ( 95% CR 37, 299–65, 924 ), representing 1. 0% of the local population. The number of pigs diagnosed with cysticercosis was estimated at 15, 961 ( 95% CR 12, 320–20, 044 ), which corresponds to 5. 6% of the local pig population. The total annual costs due to T. solium cysticercosis in West Cameroon were estimated at 10, 255, 202 Euro ( 95% CR 6, 889, 048–14, 754, 044 ), with 4. 7% attributed to losses in pig husbandry and 95. 3% to direct and indirect losses caused by human cysticercosis. The average number of DALYs lost was 9. 0 per thousand persons per year ( 95% CR 2. 8–20. 4 ). This study provides an estimation of the costs due to T. solium cysticercosis using country-specific parameters and including both the human and animal burden of the zoonotic disease.
In Staphylococcus aureus, a non-coding RNA called RsaA has been identified to play a crucial role in regulating bacterial persistence and virulence. RsaA is a Sigma B-dependent RNA that represses the synthesis of the global transcriptional regulator MgrA by forming an imperfect duplex with the Shine and Dalgarno sequence and a loop-loop interaction within the coding region of the target mRNA. This repression leads to enhanced production of biofilm and decreased synthesis of capsule formation, resulting in a decreased protection against opsonophagocytic killing by polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Mice animal models showed that RsaA attenuates the severity of acute systemic infections and enhances chronic catheter infection. RsaA is part of a regulatory network that contributes to the complex interactions of S. aureus with the host immune system, moderating invasiveness and favoring chronic infections. RsaA is the first example of a conserved small RNA in S. aureus functioning as a virulence suppressor of acute infections. The study suggests that RsaA has been positively selected through evolution to support commensalism and saprophytic interactions with the host. The deletion of rsaA increases the invasiveness of the bacteria in mice sepsis models and resistance to opsonophagocytic killing, while RsaA promotes biofilm formation and catheter colonization in mice, potentially promoting harmful colonization and chronic infections in humans. RsaA functionally links the global regulators σB and mgrA, with potential consequences on the temporal expression of virulence determinants.
A novel strategy has been developed to visualize HIV-1 uncoating in vitro and in living cells using a fluorescently tagged oligomeric form of cyclophilin A (CypA-DsRed). CypA-DsRed is specifically packaged into virions through high-avidity binding to the HIV-1 capsid (CA). Single virus imaging reveals that CypA-DsRed remains associated with cores after viral membrane removal and is lost concomitantly with CA in vitro and in living cells. The rate of loss is modulated by core stability and is accelerated upon initiation of reverse transcription. The majority of single cores lose CypA-DsRed shortly after viral fusion, while a small fraction remains intact for several hours. Single particle tracking at late times post-infection reveals a gradual loss of CypA-DsRed dependent on reverse transcription. Uncoating occurs both in the cytoplasm and at the nuclear membrane. This novel imaging assay enables time-resolved visualization of single HIV-1 uncoating in living cells, revealing spatio-temporal features of this incompletely understood process. The CypA-DsRed probe efficiently and specifically incorporates into HIV-1 particles without compromising viral infectivity, allowing for the visualization of CA on mature native HIV-1 cores without additional manipulations. The correlation between CypA-DsRed retention time and capsid stability supports the notion that CypA-DsRed loss reflects HIV-1 uncoating.
The study investigated the usage of oligonucleotides in prokaryotic genomes and their relationship to various properties such as codon usage, DNA base-stacking energy, and DNA structural conformation. The researchers analyzed the frequencies of oligonucleotides ranging from di- to octanucleotides in coding and non-coding regions of 402 prokaryotic chromosomes. The results showed that prokaryotic chromosomes can be described by hexanucleotide frequencies, indicating that prokaryotic DNA is predominantly short-range correlated, meaning that information in prokaryotic genomes is encoded in short oligonucleotides. Oligonucleotide usage varied more within AT-rich and host-associated genomes than in GC-rich and free-living genomes, and this variation was mainly located in non-coding regions. Bias in tetranucleotide usage correlated with GC content, and coding regions were more biased than non-coding regions. Non-coding regions were found to be approximately 5.5% more AT-rich than coding regions on average. The study also found pronounced DNA compositional differences within and between AT-rich and GC-rich genomes, with GC-rich genomes being more similar and biased in terms of tetranucleotide usage in non-coding regions than AT-rich genomes. The differences between AT-rich and GC-rich genomes may be attributed to lifestyle, as tetranucleotide usage within host-associated bacteria was more dissimilar and less biased than free-living archaea and bacteria. The study suggests that oligonucleotide sizes larger than hexanucleotides possess little additional information potential in prokaryotic DNA.
Biomedical researchers have investigated the factors influencing meiotic recombination, a process that ensures the correct segregation of homologous chromosomes during gamete formation and contributes to DNA diversity. While significant progress has been made in understanding the initiation of recombination at human hotspots, little is known about factors acting downstream. To address this, a study simultaneously analyzed both crossover and noncrossover recombinant molecules in sperm DNA at six highly active hotspots. The analysis revealed a novel form of biased transmission, exclusive to noncrossover recombinants, which arises from differences in heteroduplex formation and biased mismatch repair between crossovers and noncrossovers. This form of biased gene conversion is not predicted to influence hotspot activity but constitutes a previously undetected source of recombination-driven meiotic drive. The study found that this drive favors strong (G/C) over weak (A/T) base pairs, consistent with established correlations between high GC content and recombination activity in mammalian genomes. The findings suggest that this form of biased gene conversion may affect thousands of recombination hotspots throughout the human genome and contribute to the correlation between GC content and recombination, potentially influencing the evolution of genomic base composition.
Biomedical researchers have developed a computational systems biology model to predict the effects of environmental chemicals and drugs on human health. The model integrates toxicogenomics data, chemical structures, protein-protein interaction data, disease information, and functional annotation to associate chemicals with diseases and identify potential molecular targets. This approach differs from existing computational chemical biology networks, which primarily focus on integrating drug information. The researchers used the Comparative Toxicogenomics Database ( CTD ), which contains curated information on drug and environmental chemical associations with proteins. They selected 42,194 associations between 2,490 unique compounds and 6,060 molecular targets known to be involved in human disease. By analyzing these associations, the researchers identified new chemical-disease associations and potential molecular targets for chemicals such as di-ethylhexyl-phthalate, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin, pirinixic acid, and permethrine. The model can also predict which chemicals may be risk factors for human health, including breast cancer, lung cancer, and necrosis. However, it is essential to note that the model does not distinguish between positive and negative associations between chemicals and diseases. The study highlights the importance of integrating toxicogenomics data with other data types to better understand the molecular mechanisms of environmental chemicals and their effects on human health.
The study presents a novel approach to characterizing auditory cortical neurons by fitting nonlinear feedforward network models to their responses to natural sounds. The network receptive field (NRF) model reveals that primary auditory cortical neurons are sensitive to a substantially larger spectrotemporal domain than their standard spectrotemporal receptive fields (STRFs). The NRF model consists of 1-7 sub-receptive fields that interact nonlinearly and consistently outperforms STRFs in predicting neural responses to auditory stimuli. The NRF model also uncovers separate excitatory and inhibitory sub-fields with distinct nonlinear properties, including gain control and conjunctive feature detection. These conjunctive effects enable increased selectivity for complex spectrotemporal structures, which may play a crucial role in sound recognition. The NRF model is a parsimonious network that remains easy to interpret in a physiological context. The study demonstrates that fitting feedforward network models to single neuron activity in primary cortical areas (A1/AAF) allows for better predictions of their responses to natural sounds and reveals some of the nonlinear signal processing strategies used by the auditory brain. The NRF model expands on simple linear receptive field models, yielding substantially improved predictive power and providing insights into the underlying richness and nonlinearity of cortical processing.
The circadian clock in mammals is regulated by a complex transcription-translation feedback loop that drives the rhythmic expression of the transcriptome and allows the organism to anticipate daily events. A novel clock-perturbing peptide was used to investigate the role of casein kinase 2 ( CK2 ) -mediated circadian BMAL1-Ser90 phosphorylation ( BMAL1-P ) in regulating central and peripheral core clocks. The study revealed a pivotal role for CK2 in BMAL1-P and a novel function of cryptochrome ( CRY ) as a repressor of CK2 protein kinase activity toward BMAL1-S90. CRY-mediated periodic binding of CK2β to BMAL1 inhibits BMAL1-Ser90 phosphorylation by CK2α. The FAD binding domain of CRY1, two C-terminal BMAL1 domains, and BMAL1-Lys537 acetylation/deacetylation by CLOCK/SIRT1 are critical for CRY-mediated BMAL1–CK2β binding. Reciprocally, BMAL1-Ser90 phosphorylation is necessary for BMAL1-Lys537 acetylation. A dual negative-feedback model was proposed in which a CRY-dependent CK2-driven posttranslational BMAL1–P-BMAL1 loop is an integral part of the core clock oscillator. This loop forms a distinct interlocked loop in the clock machinery and has integral roles in the core circadian oscillator through periodic CRY-mediated negative feedback suppression. The study established a circadian clock-controlling role of CK2 kinase in BMAL1 phosphorylation and uncovered a novel role of CRY as a regulator of cyclic CK2-mediated BMAL1 phosphorylation. The findings provide new insights into the molecular mechanism of the CK2-mediated posttranslational loop and its role in regulating the intracellular circadian core oscillator.
The bacterium Salmonella enterica has developed mechanisms to survive in the presence of bile, a substance that disrupts membranes, denatures proteins, and damages DNA. Exposure to sublethal concentrations of the bile salt sodium deoxycholate ( DOC ) allows Salmonella to adapt to lethal concentrations of bile. This adaptation is associated with changes in gene expression, including the upregulation of the RpoS-dependent general stress response and other stress responses. The general stress response plays a crucial role in adaptation to bile, as RpoS mutants are sensitive to bile. Furthermore, individual Salmonella cells can become bile-resistant without adaptation, with frequencies ranging from 10−6 to 10−7 per cell and generation. Fluctuation analysis indicates that these resistant cells were present in the previous culture, and full genome sequencing of resistant mutants reveals that alteration of the lipopolysaccharide transport machinery is a common cause of mutational bile resistance. However, selection on lethal concentrations of bile also yields resistant isolates that are not mutants, suggesting that these cells may have been in a physiological state that allowed them to survive upon encountering bile. Single-cell analysis of gene expression using a microscope fluidic system shows that batch cultures of Salmonella contain cells that activate stress response genes in the absence of DOC, highlighting the existence of phenotypic heterogeneity in clonal populations of bacteria. This phenomenon may illustrate the adaptive value of gene expression fluctuations.
The E. coli chromosome is organized into 400-500 supercoiled domains through both active and passive mechanisms, including transcription and DNA-protein association. Prophage Mu is found to be organized as a stable chromosomal domain, bounded by the proximal location of its termini L and R, which are 37 kbp apart on the Mu genome. The formation and maintenance of this domain are dependent on a strong gyrase site (SGS) at the center of Mu, the Mu L end, the MuB protein, and E. coli nucleoid proteins IHF, Fis, and HU. The Mu domain was observed at two different chromosomal locations tested. In contrast, prophage λ does not form an independent domain. The establishment and maintenance of the Mu domain are promoted by low-level transcription from two phage promoters, one of which is domain-dependent. This domain configuration is thought to confer transposition readiness to Mu by fostering topological requirements of the reaction and the proximity of Mu ends. The potential benefits to the host cell from a subset of proteins expressed by the prophage may also contribute to its long-term stability. The Mu domain is characterized by a closed-loop structure, where synapsis of prophage ends is assisted by processive supercoiling by gyrase bound to a centrally located SGS site. This structure is thought to aid the transposition of Mu during its lytic phase of growth, and is also present in the quiescent prophage state.
Primaquine (PQ) is the only licensed antimalarial drug that prevents Plasmodium vivax (Pv) relapses and clears mature Plasmodium falciparum (Pf) gametocytes, thereby reducing post-treatment transmission. A randomized treatment-to-reinfection cohort study in Papua New Guinean children investigated the effects of PQ on Pv and Pf gametocyte carriage after radical cure. Children received radical cure with chloroquine, Artemether-Lumefantrine, and either PQ or placebo. Blood samples were collected at 2- to 4-weekly intervals over 8 months to detect gametocytes using quantitative reverse transcription-PCR targeting pvs25 and pfs25. PQ treatment reduced Pv gametocyte incidence by 73%, comparable to its effect on blood-stage infections. The majority of Pv and Pf gametocyte-positive infections were asymptomatic. Pv and Pf gametocyte positivity and density were associated with high blood-stage parasite densities. Multivariate analysis revealed that mixed-species infections reduced the odds of gametocytes for both species. PQ treatment had no effect on Pv gametocyte density or proportion of Pv infections carrying gametocytes. First infections after blood-stage and placebo treatment were equally likely to carry gametocytes as first infections after PQ treatment. Pv relapses and new infections had similar gametocytaemia levels, highlighting the importance of effective anti-hypnozoite treatment for Pv control. The study suggests that PQ treatment should be used for all Pv infections to prevent relapses and reduce gametocyte carriage.
The Rho family of GTPases plays a crucial role in controlling actin organization during various cellular processes, including migration, cytokinesis, and endocytosis. The primary members of this family, RhoA, Rac, and Cdc42, exhibit distinct downstream effects on actin remodeling despite sharing a common mechanism of targeting to the plasma membrane and activation by GTP binding. A computational analysis was conducted to investigate the details of GTPase cycling between the membrane and cytosol, which is hypothesized to be key to the differential upstream regulation of these biochemical switches. A modeling framework was developed to analyze experimental data for these systems, allowing for the revelation of details of GDI-mediated cycling and the distinction between GDI-dependent and -independent mechanisms, including vesicle trafficking and direct association-dissociation of GTPase with membrane molecules. The analysis of Rac membrane cycling revealed that the lower apparent affinity of GDI for RacGTP compared to RacGDP can be fully explained by the faster dissociation of the latter from the membrane. Non-dimensional steady-state solutions for membrane fraction of GTPase were presented in multidimensional charts, which can be used to illustrate the effects of GEFs/GAPs and regulated affinities between GTPases and membrane and/or GDI on the amount of membrane-bound GTPase. This methodology was applied to analyze glucose-stimulated Rac cycling in pancreatic β-cells and can be used as a guide in assessing how targeted modifications may compensate for altered GTPase-GDI balance in disease scenarios. The results demonstrate that Rho-GTPase cycling can access qualitatively diverse pathways in different cellular systems or through different experimental manipulations.
The World Health Organization (WHO) aims to control and eliminate schistosomiasis as a public health problem. To achieve this goal, monitoring and evaluation (M&E) programmes are used to collect data on the prevalence and intensity of Schistosoma mansoni infection. Traditionally, data are collected from school-aged children (SAC) due to their high likelihood of infection and ease of sampling. However, adults are also likely to be infected, and their infection burden can significantly impact the effectiveness of treatment strategies. This study investigates the importance of collecting adult data to inform treatment strategies for S. mansoni. The authors use three different age-intensity profiles of infection with low, moderate, and high burdens of infection in adults to examine how the age distribution of infection affects mathematical model-generated recommendations for preventive chemotherapy coverage levels. The results show that for moderate prevalence regions, treating SAC only may achieve the WHO goals, but for high prevalence regions with a high burden of infection in adults, adult treatment is required to meet the WHO goals. The study highlights the need for M&E programmes to collect prevalence and intensity of infection data from a broader age-range, including adults, to accurately determine the optimal treatment strategy for a defined region. The authors also emphasize the importance of collecting additional epidemiological data, such as individual longitudinal adherence to treatment, to inform treatment strategies.
Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a prevalent neurological disorder characterized by seizures that can be resistant to medication, prompting resective surgery as a treatment option. However, the success rate of this procedure is unpredictable, with many patients continuing to experience seizures post-surgery. To address this issue, a computational model of epilepsy was applied to patient-specific structural connectivity derived from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) of 22 individuals with left TLE and 39 healthy controls. The model was validated by examining patient-control differences in simulated seizure onset time and network location. The results showed that patients tend to transition from non-epileptic to epileptic states more frequently than controls, and regions in the left hemisphere, particularly within temporal and subcortical regions, are the most common starting points for seizures in patients. The model also implicated regions in the contralateral and frontal locations in seizure spreading or surgery resistance. Furthermore, the model predicted that patient-specific surgery, where resection areas are chosen based on individual model-prompted results, may lead to better outcomes than the standard clinical procedure. This study provides a first step towards developing a patient-specific computational model of epilepsy surgery to inform treatment strategies. The model's predictions are based on a bistable model and DTI data, and the results suggest that subject-specific surgery may result in greater seizure reduction than standard resection procedures.
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) employs various strategies to evade the host's innate antiviral defenses, including the use of viral interferon regulatory factors (vIRFs) to block interferon and apoptotic signaling. The vIRFs function in a dominant negative manner to inhibit cellular IRF activities and target proteins involved in apoptosis, such as p53 and TGFβ receptor-activated Smad transcription factors. This study identifies vIRF-1 as a direct target of the BH3-only pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family member Bim, which is a key negative regulator of HHV-8 replication. vIRF-1 mediates the inactivation of Bim through nuclear translocation, as demonstrated by immunofluorescence assay and western analysis of fractionated cell extracts. Co-localization of vIRF-1 and Bim was observed in the nuclei of lytically infected endothelial cells. In vitro co-precipitation assays revealed a direct interaction between vIRF-1 and Bim, and deletion and point mutagenesis mapped the Bim-binding residues of vIRF-1. Generation of Bim-refractory vIRF-1 variants confirmed the importance of the vIRF-1:Bim interaction in pro-replication and anti-apoptotic activity. Blocking the interaction with a cell-permeable peptide corresponding to the Bim-binding region of vIRF-1 also confirmed the relevance of vIRF-1:Bim association to vIRF-1 pro-replication activity. This study reveals a novel mechanism by which HHV-8 controls replication-induced apoptosis and suggests that inhibitory targeting of vIRF-1:Bim interaction may provide an effective antiviral strategy.
The study investigated the role of the epithelial integrin αVβ6 in regulating the amplitude of protective lung interferon responses against multiple respiratory pathogens. Mice lacking the β6 integrin (β6 KO) were found to be protected from disease caused by influenza infection, characterized by reduced acute lung injury (ALI), edema, inflammatory cytokine expression, and vascular permeability of the lung epithelium. β6 KO mice also exhibited altered baseline homeostasis, with high baseline CD11b+ CD11c+ macrophages. The resistance of β6 KO mice to influenza infection was dependent on the loss of transforming growth factor-β1 (TGF-β1) and elevated type I interferon (IFN) signaling. However, the phenotypic changes in lung macrophages were independent of the type I IFN pathway. Macrophages isolated from TGF-β1-treated β6 KO mice displayed decreased mRNA encoding levels of IFN-associated transcripts, suggesting that the loss of β6-activated TGF-β results in an altered lung macrophage population and increased type I IFN activation. Administration of exogenous TGF-β1 to β6 KO mice led to reduced numbers of CD11b+ macrophages, decreased type I IFN signaling activity, and loss of the protective phenotype during influenza infection. The study demonstrates that the loss of one epithelial protein, αVβ6 integrin, can alter the lung microenvironment during both homeostasis and respiratory infection, leading to reduced lung injury and improved survival against multiple respiratory pathogens, including influenza, Sendai virus, and bacterial pneumonia.
Title: Reappraisal of Leishmanin Skin Test (LST) in the management of American Cutaneous Leishmaniasis: A retrospective analysis from a reference center in Argentina

    A retrospective analysis of 733 cases of American Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (ACL) was conducted at a reference center in Argentina from 2006-2015 to assess the usefulness of the Leishmanin Skin Test (LST) as a diagnostic support tool. The study found that LST was a useful complement to diagnosis, with a high correlation with smear results, particularly for lesions older than 21 days. The analysis included 678 localized cutaneous cases, 50 mucosal cases, and 5 disseminated cases. Diagnostic confirmation was reached in 474 cases through positive smears from skin or mucosal lesions, with only 6 cases having negative LST results among this group. Among smear-negative cases, 190 were also negative by LST, but 69 instances had positive LST results. The study found similar ratios of sensitivity between smear and LST across age groups. The results support the clinical use of LST as a diagnostic complement for ACL across all age groups, even in endemic areas. Standardization of the LST technique and further research into its most adequate preparation and utilization protocols are recommended to aid in the management of suspicious clinical cases. The study highlights the need for expansion of control programs and generation of research-based evidence in all aspects of leishmaniasis, particularly for Leishmania (Viannia) braziliensis, the most frequent cause of American Tegumentary Leishmaniasis.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified over 40 loci associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease (CAD), but the causal mechanisms underlying most of these loci remain unknown. This study aimed to elucidate the role of epigenomic changes in human macrophages in the development of CAD. The researchers used a combination of open chromatin mapping and chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) in primary human macrophages before and after exposure to atherogenic oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL), which leads to foam cell formation. The results showed that oxLDL-induced foam cell formation was associated with changes in a subset of open chromatin and active enhancer sites, which correlated with expression changes of nearby genes. The researchers identified several transcription factors, including C/EBP-beta, which has no previously documented role in foam cell formation, and found that oxLDL exposure up-regulated C/EBP-beta expression and increased its genomic binding events. Variants at CAD-associated loci were significantly enriched in the subset of chromatin sites altered by oxLDL exposure, including rs72664324 in an oxLDL-induced enhancer at the PPAP2B locus. The protective A allele of rs72664324 increased C/EBP-beta binding and enhancer activity, leading to increased expression of the PPAP2B protein product LPP3, which degrades pro-inflammatory mediators. The study provides a genetic mechanism contributing to CAD risk at the PPAP2B locus and highlights the value of studying epigenetic changes in disease processes involving pathogenic environmental stimuli.
The World Health Organization (WHO) previously recommended that districts with trachomatous inflammation–follicular (TF) prevalence in 1–9-year-olds of 5.0–9.9% receive three rounds of azithromycin mass treatment. However, this recommendation may not be practical due to the large number of endemic districts worldwide and the resources required to conduct surveys. In Malawi, eight districts with baseline TF prevalences of 5.0–9.9% received one round of azithromycin mass treatment, achieving a mean coverage of approximately 80%. Population-based trachoma surveys were conducted in 18 evaluation units of the treated districts at least six months after the treatment. The results showed that each of the 18 evaluation units had a TF1-9 prevalence of less than 5.0%. This study demonstrates that one round of azithromycin mass treatment with approximately 80% coverage is associated with a reduction in TF prevalence to less than 5.0% in Malawi districts with TF prevalence of 5.0–9.9%. The study suggests that this approach may be sufficient to eliminate active trachoma in Malawi districts that are hypoendemic at baseline. The findings provide optimism that Malawi may be able to eliminate trachoma as a public health problem by 2020. The study's results are consistent with a previous cohort study in Tanzania, which found that one round of very high coverage azithromycin completely interrupted local transmission of ocular C. trachomatis.
Nucleotide-binding domain leucine-rich repeat (NLR) protein complexes play a crucial role in sensing infections and triggering immune responses in plants and humans. In Arabidopsis thaliana, the activation of NLR resistance (R) proteins by pathogen effectors initiates convergent immune responses, including programmed cell death (PCD), reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and transcriptional reprogramming. Recent studies have identified six closely related Arabidopsis Ca2+-dependent protein kinases (CPKs) that mediate bifurcate immune responses activated by NLR proteins RPS2 and RPM1. The dynamics of differential CPK1/2 activation by pathogen effectors controls the onset of cell death, while sustained CPK4/5/6/11 activation directly phosphorylates a specific subgroup of WRKY transcription factors, WRKY8/28/48, to synergistically regulate transcriptional reprogramming crucial for NLR-dependent restriction of pathogen growth. Additionally, CPK1/2/4/11 phosphorylate plasma membrane-resident NADPH oxidases for ROS production. These findings delineate the bifurcation of complex signaling mechanisms downstream of NLR immune sensors mediated by the myriad action of CPKs with distinct substrate specificity and subcellular dynamics. The results provide genetic evidence that Ca2+ signaling via specific CPKs plays pivotal roles in the diverse downstream signaling and pathogen resistance mediated by distinct intracellular NLR immune sensors.
Schistosoma haematobium, a parasitic disease prevalent in sub-Saharan Africa, poses a significant public health burden due to its high morbidity and mortality rates. The disease is exacerbated by factors such as irrigation and hydro-electric projects, shifts from nomadic to sedentary lifestyles, and ineffective control programs. Despite its impact, less than 0.5% of Schistosoma investigations have attempted to predict its spatial and temporal distributions. To address this knowledge gap, a longitudinal retrospective study was conducted in the district of Niono, Mali, from 1996 to 2004. The study employed general-purpose exponential smoothing methods within a state-space framework to generate contemporaneous on-line forecasts of Schistosoma haematobium time-series. The results showed that the exponential smoothing state-space framework produced reasonably accurate forecasts, with mean absolute percentage error values of approximately 25% for 1- to 5-month horizon forecasts. This approach effectively captured prior non-linear interactions between disease dynamics and exogenous covariates, such as climate, irrigation, and public health interventions. The study suggests that this framework can assist in managing and assessing Schistosoma haematobium transmission and intervention impact in the district of Niono, Mali, and potentially elsewhere in the Sahel region. The findings highlight the potential of parsimonious forecasting and early warning systems to enhance public health programs in developing countries.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) has evolved a self-imposed restriction mechanism mediated by the viral tegument protein pp150, which prevents the onset of viral gene expression in the S/G2 phase of the cell cycle by binding to cyclin A. This restriction ensures that viral replication occurs in the G0/G1 phase, where cyclin A expression is low or absent. However, in S/G2 cells, pp150-mediated repression is relieved once cells lose cyclin A protein after cell division. To investigate the physiological relevance of this restriction, a cyclin A-binding deficient pp150 mutant virus was employed. The results showed that unrestricted viral gene expression in S/G2 led to a G2/M arrest, but G2-arrested cells still supported viral replication. The viral gene product pUL21a was found to destabilize cyclin A, maintaining the virus-permissive G2-arrest. A double-point mutant virus, where both pp150 and pUL21a were disabled in cyclin A interaction, forced mitotic entry of the majority of infected cells, resulting in a severe negative impact on cell viability and virus growth. These findings suggest that pp150 and pUL21a functionally cooperate to build a cell cycle synchronization strategy of cyclin A targeting and avoidance, which is essential for productive HCMV infection. The results indicate that the pp150-dependent restriction to cyclin A-negative cells is a genuine function in the productive replication cycle of HCMV, rather than an inevitable by-product of a silencing mechanism.
Title: Targeted Exon Capture and Sequencing in Sporadic Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis

    Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease characterized by progressive motor neuron degeneration, resulting in paralysis and death. Approximately 90% of ALS cases are sporadic, with the remaining 10% being familial. While genetic studies in familial ALS have identified causative mutations, the cause of ALS in approximately 30% of familial cases and the majority of sporadic cases remains unknown. To address this knowledge gap, researchers undertook a targeted sequencing approach of 169 known and candidate ALS disease genes in 242 sporadic ALS cases and 129 matched controls. The study aimed to identify novel variants linked to ALS.

    The results showed a significant enrichment of novel and rare variants in cases versus controls, indicating the identification of disease-associated mutations. A candidate gene approach was used to discover new mutations in biologically relevant ALS genes, and functional studies were employed to assess the relevance of newly identified variants. Bioinformatics tools were used to evaluate variant pathogenicity, and a rare variant binning approach demonstrated a higher burden of deleterious mutations in cases compared to controls. The study highlights the utility of next-generation sequencing techniques combined with functional studies and rare variant analysis tools to provide insight into the genetic etiology of sporadic ALS. The findings suggest that novel or rare mutations in a set of key genes may contribute to sporadic ALS, underscoring the need for rigorous approaches to distinguish true disease-causing variants from benign ones.
This study investigated the role of interleukin-6 (IL-6) in the development of T cell memory to influenza virus. The results show that IL-6 is crucial for the recall of influenza-specific memory CD4+ T cells, but not CD8+ T cells. IL-6 was found to suppress the activity of virus-specific CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells (Tregs), thereby facilitating the activity of virus-specific memory CD4+ T cells. The study used wild-type and IL-6 deficient mice to compare influenza-specific CD4+ and CD8+ T cell memory responses after infection with influenza virus. The results indicate that IL-6 is a selective regulator of long-term CD4+ T-cell memory responses, limiting the activity of virus-specific Tregs. In IL-6 deficient mice, virus-specific Tregs were more readily detectable and were able to suppress the activity of virus-specific memory T cells. This suggests that IL-6 plays a critical role in ensuring that antigen-specific Tregs do not down-modulate the immune response during an acute infection with a cytopathic virus, thereby favoring pathogen clearance and survival of the host. The study also found that the memory CD8+ T cell response was unimpaired in IL-6 deficient mice, implying that CD4+ and CD8+ T cells differ in their susceptibility to suppression by Tregs. Overall, the findings highlight a novel role for IL-6 in the development of T cell memory to influenza virus.
A new nuclear function of the glycolytic enzyme enolase in the parasite Entamoeba histolytica has been identified. Enolase, which catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, was found to interact with the cytosine-5 methyltransferase 2 ( Dnmt2 ) protein. This interaction was discovered through a yeast two-hybrid screen, and further studies revealed that enolase acts as an inhibitor of Dnmt2 activity. The inhibitory activity of enolase was found to be antagonized by 2-phosphoglycerate, suggesting that glucose metabolism controls the non-glycolytic function of enolase. In response to glucose starvation, enolase accumulates in the nucleus and forms a complex with the E. histolytica Dnmt2 homolog ( Ehmeth ), leading to a reduction in tRNAAsp methylation in the parasite. The role of enolase as a Dnmt2 inhibitor was confirmed in E. histolytica expressing a nuclear localization signal-fused enolase. This study establishes enolase as the first Dnmt2-interacting protein and highlights an unexpected role of a glycolytic enzyme in the modulation of Dnmt2 activity. The results also suggest that glucose metabolism and Dnmt2 activity are linked, and that the interaction between enolase and Dnmt2 may be conserved across different species, including Drosophila and humans.
For the first time, researchers have identified exogenous microRNAs (miRNAs) in the saliva of mosquitoes, specifically Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, which are vectors of Chikungunya virus (CHIKV). MicroRNAs are small, non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression and are typically found inside cells. However, circulating miRNAs have been detected in human serum and saliva. The study used next-generation sequencing to identify 103 exogenous miRNAs in mosquito saliva, of which 31 were previously unknown and designated as novel. Some of these miRNAs were only expressed in CHIKV-infected mosquitoes. The researchers tested five saliva miRNAs for their potential to regulate CHIKV infection and found that inhibiting these miRNAs decreased viral replication. This suggests that the presence and upregulation of these miRNAs in mosquito saliva may enhance CHIKV replication and dissemination in the host. The study provides strong evidence for the presence of mature insect miRNAs in mosquito saliva and highlights the potential role of these miRNAs in the transmission and establishment of CHIKV infection. This is the first report on the identification of exogenous mosquito saliva microRNAs, and the findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of mosquito-borne pathogen transmission.
This study investigated the role of nuclear double-strand break repair (DSBR) proteins Rad51p, Rad52p, and Rad59p in the repair of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. Mitochondrial DNA encodes essential proteins for cellular respiration, and deletions in the mitochondrial genome are associated with various diseases and disorders. The study used a mitochondrially-targeted restriction endonuclease to induce a double-strand break (DSB) in the mitochondrial genome, allowing for direct analysis of DSB repair in vivo. The results showed that loss of Rad51p, Rad52p, and Rad59p significantly decreased the rate of spontaneous deletion events and impaired the repair of induced mtDNA DSBs. Rad51p and Rad59p were found to localize to the matrix of the mitochondria and bind directly to mitochondrial DNA. The study also demonstrated that Rad51p, Rad52p, and Rad59p impact the rate of spontaneous mitochondrial DNA deletions and the repair of induced mitochondrial DSBs in yeast. This is the first study to demonstrate the role of these proteins in the repair of specific mtDNA lesions. The findings provide new insights into the mechanisms of mitochondrial mutagenesis and repair, particularly DSBR, and highlight the importance of these proteins in maintaining the integrity of the mitochondrial genome.
This systematic review aimed to investigate the association between social determinants of health and the risk of Group A Streptococcal (GAS) infection, acute rheumatic fever (ARF), and rheumatic heart disease (RHD). The review included 90 studies that measured the relationship between crowding, dwelling characteristics, education, employment, income, nutrition, or socioeconomic status and the risk of GAS infection, ARF, or RHD. The majority of studies (57.1%) reported a significant association between socioeconomic determinants and the risk of GAS infection, while 50% reported a significant association with ARF/RHD. Crowding was the most frequently assessed factor, with 14 studies examining its association with GAS infection and 36 studies examining its association with ARF/RHD. The majority of studies assessing crowding, dwelling characteristics, education, and employment status of parents or cases, and nutrition reported a positive association with the risk of GAS infection, ARF, or RHD. The Bradford Hill criteria for evidence of causation were met for crowding and socioeconomic status. However, the literature examining the role of social determinants in GAS infection, ARF, and RHD risk lacks quality, with most studies being observational rather than interventional. The findings suggest that crowding is a practical target for prevention actions to reduce the risk of GAS infection and ARF/RHD.
A single point mutation in the PhoQ protein of the PhoQ/PhoP bacterial signaling network results in a phosphatase-deficient mutant that exhibits a bistable response to stimulus, as opposed to the wild-type's graded response. The mutant cells can exist in two distinct states, with different morphologies, and their state is inherited over many generations. Mathematical modeling and experiments suggest that the bistability depends on positive autoregulation of the two key proteins in the circuit, PhoP and PhoQ. The mutant's bistable phenotype comes at a substantial fitness cost, with the on state having a lower fitness than the off state in stationary phase cultures in rich medium. However, due to the high inheritance of the on state, a population of on cells can be epigenetically trapped in a low-fitness state. The study demonstrates the versatility of the prototypical two-component signaling architecture and highlights the tradeoffs in the particular case of the PhoQ/PhoP system. The findings suggest that the architectural features of the network that allow the mutant to exhibit bistability are shared among many two-component systems. The mutation, which produces a T281R substitution in PhoQ, results in bistability with mutants persisting in morphologically distinct OFF and ON states for many generations.
Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis (PAM) is a rare but devastating infection caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri. Current treatment options are limited, and the high mortality rate makes PAM a significant public health concern. To address this issue, researchers have turned to drug repurposing, a cost-effective strategy to apply known drugs for the treatment of rare or neglected diseases. N. fowleri has an essential requirement for ergosterol, a building block of plasma and cell membranes, similar to fungi. Disruption of sterol biosynthesis by small-molecule inhibitors is a validated strategy against fungal pathogens. The N. fowleri genome encodes the sterol 14-demethylase (CYP51) target, which shares 35% sequence identity with fungal orthologues, raising the possibility of repurposing anti-mycotic drugs for PAM treatment. This study systematically assessed the impact of anti-fungal azole drugs on N. fowleri sterol biosynthesis and viability, identified the endogenous CYP51 substrate, and analyzed the interactions between the recombinant CYP51 target and conazoles. The results validated CYP51 as a potentially druggable target in N. fowleri and conazole drugs as candidates for assessment in the animal model of PAM. The findings suggest that CYP51 inhibitors, such as fluconazole and miconazole, may be effective against N. fowleri and warrant further investigation as potential treatments for PAM.
Interleukin-4 receptor alpha (IL-4Rα) plays a crucial role in triggering a host protective type 2 immune response against nematode parasites. However, its function in maintaining type 2 immune responses after polarization is not well understood. To investigate this, researchers used a mouse model where IL-4Rα gene deletion can be temporally controlled. The study found that sustained expression of IL-4Rα is necessary for the maintenance of type 2 immune responses and protective immunity following primary infection with Nippostrongylus brasiliensis. Additionally, the study showed that IL-4Rα mediated signaling is required for the recall of type 2 immune responses and clearance of the parasites during secondary infection. Temporal deletion of IL-4Rα prior to secondary infection resulted in a diminished recall of Th2 responses and reduced ability to clear the infection. These findings suggest that IL-4Rα has a novel function in maintaining anti-nematode type 2 immune responses, distinct from its role in immune polarization. The study highlights the importance of sustained IL-4Rα mediated signaling in the maintenance of protective immunity against nematode parasites. The results provide new insights into the mechanisms of type 2 immune responses and have implications for the development of vaccines against parasitic nematodes.
A global analysis of the distribution of Bartonella bacteria in mammals reveals that humans play a significant role in shaping the patterns of disease risk for themselves, their commensal animals, and wildlife. The study analyzed the largest collection of Bartonella gltA genotypes to date, including 67 new genotypes, and found that the pathogenic genus likely originated as an environmental bacterium and insect commensal before infecting mammals. Rodents and domestic animals serve as reservoirs or key proximate hosts for most Bartonella genotypes in humans. The study also found evidence of exchange of Bartonella between phylogenetically distant domestic animals and wildlife, likely due to increased contact. The findings suggest that humans, domestic animals, and wildlife should be kept separate to protect the health of all. Bartonella is a rich system for examining the impacts of humans on patterns of infectious disease spread within and between species, across landscapes, and across the globe. The study's phylogenetic inferences about the origin of infections should be interpreted with caution, as they are heavily influenced by available data and the taxa that have been sampled. The results highlight the importance of considering a broad range of potential animal hosts and screening for a wide range of Bartonella genotypes when investigating the source of a suspected Bartonella infection. Mammalian species associated with humans, such as dogs, cats, cows, and rats, have managed to bring their strains of Bartonella globally, with rats being particularly common in the largest clade of globally distributed rodent Bartonella.
The study investigated the role of long noncoding RNA MALAT1 in regulating cell cycle progression. MALAT1 levels were found to be upregulated in cancer tissues and associated with hyper-proliferation. Genome-wide transcriptome analyses in normal human diploid fibroblasts revealed that MALAT1 modulates the expression of cell cycle genes and is required for G1/S and mitotic progression. Depletion of MALAT1 led to activation of p53 and its target genes, indicating that p53 is a major downstream mediator of MALAT1 activity. The cell cycle defects observed in MALAT1-depleted cells were sensitive to p53 levels. Furthermore, MALAT1-depleted cells displayed reduced expression of B-MYB, an oncogenic transcription factor involved in G2/M progression, due to altered binding of splicing factors on B-MYB pre-mRNA and aberrant alternative splicing. These findings suggest that MALAT1 promotes cellular proliferation by modulating the expression and/or pre-mRNA processing of cell cycle-regulated transcription factors. The study proposes that abnormal expression of MALAT1 in specific cell types or tissues results in aberrant alternative splicing leading to misexpression of genes involved in cell cycle progression and/or cell death, thereby contributing to tumor progression. Overall, the study provides mechanistic insights into the role of MALAT1 in regulating cellular proliferation.
Juvenile hormone (JH) plays a crucial role in regulating insect development, metamorphosis, and reproduction. While its action in repressing larval metamorphosis is well understood, the molecular basis of its role in promoting adult reproduction is not fully elucidated. Recent studies have shown that the JH receptor, Methoprene-tolerant (Met), mediates JH action during metamorphosis and vitellogenesis. However, the precise mechanism underlying JH's role in vitellogenesis has been lacking. This study aimed to elucidate the molecular basis of JH's action in promoting vitellogenesis in the migratory locust. Using RNA interference (RNAi) to phenocopy a JH-deprived condition, the authors demonstrated that JH stimulates DNA replication and increases ploidy in preparation for vitellogenesis. The study identified Mcm4 and Mcm7, two genes involved in the DNA replication pathway, as key targets of JH action. Depletion of Mcm4 or Mcm7 inhibited de novo DNA synthesis and polyploidization, resulting in reduced vitellogenin mRNA levels and impaired oocyte maturation and ovarian growth. Furthermore, the study showed that the JH-receptor complex directly regulates the transcription of Mcm4 and Mcm7 by binding to upstream consensus sequences. These findings suggest that the JH-receptor complex acts on Mcm4 and Mcm7 to regulate DNA replication and polyploidy for vitellogenesis and oocyte maturation in the migratory locust.
The “Treatment of Early Neuropathy in Leprosy” (TENLEP) trial aimed to determine the optimal duration of prednisolone treatment for patients with recent nerve function impairment (NFI) in leprosy. A total of 868 patients were randomly assigned to receive either a 20-week or 32-week course of prednisolone, with the primary outcome being the proportion of patients with improved or restored nerve function at 78 weeks. The results showed that the proportion of patients with improved or restored nerve function did not differ significantly between the two groups, with 78.1% in the 20-week arm and 77.5% in the 32-week arm. Additionally, there were no significant differences in secondary outcomes, except for a higher proportion of serious adverse events in the 32-week treatment arm. The study found that a 20-week course of prednisolone was as effective as a 32-week course in improving and restoring recent clinical NFI in leprosy patients. The results suggest that a 20-week course of prednisolone is the preferred initial treatment duration for leprosy neuropathy, after which only a minority of patients may require further individualized treatment. This study provides evidence to support the use of a shorter duration of prednisolone treatment for patients with recent NFI in leprosy.
The study presents a computational model of the larynx and vocal tract of male Rocky Mountain elk (Cervus elaphus nelsoni) and European Red Deer (Cervus elaphus scoticus) to investigate the relationship between sound complexity and anatomy/physiology. The model, based on the morphology and biomechanics of the elk, can produce a wide range of fundamental frequencies. The results show that low fundamental frequencies require low vocal fold strain, but high lung pressure and large glottal flow to achieve sound intensity levels above 70 dB at 10 m distance. In contrast, high-frequency bugles require large muscular effort to strain the vocal ligament and high lung pressure to overcome phonation threshold pressure. However, high-frequency bugles can achieve at least 10 dB more intensity level than low-frequency calls. The study found that glottal efficiency, the ratio of radiated sound power to aerodynamic power at the glottis, is higher in elk, suggesting an advantage of high-pitched signaling. This advantage is attributed to lower airflow requirements for aerodynamic power and an acoustic radiation advantage at higher frequencies. The study suggests that the high-frequency bugle may signal muscular strength and endurance, while the low-frequency call relates to overall body size. The findings have implications for understanding the evolution of vocal communication in mammals.
Title: Discovering Transcription Factor Binding Sites in Highly Repetitive Regions of Genomes with Multi-Read Analysis of ChIP-Seq Data

Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-seq) has become a widely used technique for mapping transcription-factor binding sites and chromatin modifications. However, the standard approach of using only uniquely mapping reads (uni-reads) can lead to the omission of up to 30% of alignable reads. To address this limitation, a new method for utilizing reads that map to multiple locations on the reference genome (multi-reads) has been developed. This approach allocates multi-reads as fractional counts using a weighted alignment scheme.

Using human STAT1 and mouse GATA1 ChIP-seq datasets, the authors demonstrate that incorporating multi-reads significantly increases sequencing depths, detects novel peaks not identifiable with uni-reads, and improves peak detection in mappable regions. Computational experiments reveal that peaks from multi-read analysis have similar characteristics to those identified by uni-reads, except that the majority reside in segmental duplications. Independent quantitative real-time ChIP analysis validates a number of GATA1 multi-read only peaks and identifies novel target genes of GATA1. These results establish the importance of multi-reads for studying transcription factor binding in highly repetitive regions of genomes with ChIP-seq experiments. The incorporation of multi-reads can increase sequencing depths by up to 25% and lead to the identification of novel binding sites in highly repetitive and low mappability regions.
The World Health Organization (WHO) has set targets for 2020 to control or eliminate four neglected tropical diseases (NTDs): human African trypanosomiasis, leprosy, visceral leishmaniasis, and Chagas disease. A study estimated the economic benefits to individuals of achieving these targets through innovative and intensified disease management (IDM). The study used a systematic literature review to identify information on productivity loss and out-of-pocket payments (OPPs) related to these NTDs, which were combined with projections of the number of people affected by each disease. The study compared an ideal scenario where the 2020 targets are met with a counterfactual scenario where the situation in 1990 remained unchanged. The economic benefits were calculated as the difference between the two scenarios, discounted at 3% per annum from 2010. The total global productivity gained for the four IDM-NTDs was estimated to be $23.1 billion in 2011-2020 and $35.9 billion in 2021-2030. The reduction in OPPs was estimated to be $14 billion and $18 billion for the same periods. The study found that the economic benefits of achieving the targets far exceed the necessary investments by endemic country governments and their development partners. The benefits are particularly significant for disadvantaged populations in low- and middle-income countries, who often bear the brunt of the health and economic consequences of NTDs.
The prevailing theory in neuroscience suggests that neurons with higher selectivity, which respond to a narrower range of sensory inputs, carry more information about external sensory inputs.
