However, a recent study in the auditory cortex challenges this notion. The study found that the amount of information encoded by the neural population is not dependent on the selectivity of individual neurons, but rather on the total number of population spikes in a given time window. In the auditory cortex, neuronal responses are less selective immediately after sound onset and become highly selective in the sustained response epoch. Contrary to the prevailing theory, the study found that the neural population conveys similar information about sound input across both epochs, despite the differences in neuronal selectivity. The results suggest that inhomogeneous Poisson spiking behavior is sufficient to account for this property. This finding implies a novel principle of sensory encoding that may be shared among multiple sensory systems. The study's results raise questions about the nature of dynamic stimulus encoding in sensory systems and challenge the conventional approach of interpreting informativeness based on neuronal response selectivity. The study's findings have significant implications for our understanding of sensory information processing in the brain.
During chronic viral infections, the immune system must maintain anti-viral T cell responses over an extended period to control viral replication and prevent disease progression. While inhibitory signals, such as PD-1, have been well-characterized, the role of stimulatory signals in sustaining anti-viral T cells is less understood. This study investigated the co-stimulatory molecule OX40 (CD134) in the context of persistent lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) clone 13 infection. The results show that OX40 is critically required for the maintenance of anti-viral T cell responses during chronic LCMV infection. Anti-viral T cells express high levels of OX40 in the presence of their cognate antigen, and mice lacking the OX40 receptor fail to accumulate sufficient anti-viral T cells, leading to impaired germinal center responses and antibody production. Consequently, OX40-deficient mice are unable to control LCMV clone 13 infection over time. The study highlights the importance of OX40 signaling in sustaining anti-viral T cell responses during chronic viral infections. Furthermore, the findings suggest that OX40 plays a key role in driving both CD4 and CD8 T cell responses, as well as T cell-dependent antibody responses, during persistent LCMV infection. Overall, the study establishes OX40 as a critical factor in maintaining cellular and humoral immunity during viral persistence, with implications for the study of T cell dysfunction in persistent viral infections in humans.
Convergent Evolution of Mechanically Optimal Locomotion in Aquatic Invertebrates and Vertebrates
    A study reveals that a mechanically optimal method of swimming with elongated fins has evolved independently at least eight times in both vertebrate and invertebrate swimmers across three different phyla. The optimal specific wavelength ( OSW ), defined as the length of an undulation along an animal’s fin during swimming divided by the mean amplitude of undulations along the fin length, is consistently around twenty. This value maximizes the force generated by the body, which in turn maximizes swimming speed. The OSW is a pattern of movement that occurs across a morphologically diverse set of moving appendages on aquatic animals, including invertebrates such as cuttlefish and vertebrates such as cartilaginous and bony fish. The study suggests that the regulation of OSW, axial elongation, and fin elongation in the phyla in which these traits are observed may reflect the action of common genetic networks. This phenomenon unifies a vast diversity of swimming organisms and raises questions about why slower forms of swimming exhibited by median/paired fin animals would emerge and thrive despite the prevalence of body/caudal fin swimming in ancestral species. The study also highlights the convergent evolution of anatomical specializations for one type of body/caudal fin swimmer that minimizes trunk movement during tail fin movement, resulting in a similarly pure thrust element.
The study investigated the roles of condensins I and II in neural stem cell (NSC) divisions during cerebral cortex development in mice. Condensins are evolutionarily conserved protein complexes essential for chromosome assembly and segregation in eukaryotes. The research found that both condensins I and II are crucial for NSC divisions and survival, with simultaneous depletion of both leading to severe defects in chromosome assembly and segregation, DNA damage, and p53-induced apoptosis. Individual depletions of condensins I and II resulted in slower loss of NSCs compared to simultaneous depletion, but displayed distinct mitotic defects: chromosome missegregation was observed more prominently in NSCs depleted of condensin II, whereas mitotic delays were detectable only in condensin I-depleted NSCs. Notably, NSCs depleted of condensin II displayed hyperclustering of pericentric heterochromatin and nucleoli, indicating that condensin II plays a critical role in establishing interphase nuclear architecture. These defects were also observed in postmitotic neurons. The study demonstrates that condensins I and II have both overlapping and non-overlapping functions in NSCs, providing evolutionary insight into the intricate balancing acts of the two condensin complexes. The findings suggest that condensins I and II are essential for early embryonic development and cortical development in mice, with almost equal contributions to NSC division and subsequent cell survival.
The transcriptome of the human parasite Schistosoma mansoni was investigated in a stage- and sex-comparative manner to study the molecular basis of sex determination and sexual differentiation in this species. RNA-seq analysis was performed on males and females at five developmental stages: cercariae larvae, three in vivo schistosomulum stages, and adults. A total of 7,168 genes were found to be differentially expressed between sexes in at least one developmental stage, with 4,065 of them being functionally annotated. The study also analyzed H3K27me3 histone modification using ChIP-Seq before (in cercariae) and after (in adults) the appearance of phenotypic sexual dimorphism. The results suggest that sexual differentiation in S. mansoni is accompanied by distinct male and female transcriptional landscapes of known players of the host-parasite crosstalk, genetic determinants, and epigenetic regulators. The study identified candidate determinants of sexual differentiation, sex-biased players of the interaction with the vertebrate host, and different dynamics of the H3K27me3 histone mark between sexes as an illustration of sex-biased epigenetic landscapes. The findings provide new insights into the reproductive function of S. mansoni and represent a promising source of therapeutic targets for the treatment of schistosomiasis, a disease caused by this parasite.
The article presents a novel approach for modeling disagreements among experts in large-scale annotation efforts. The proposed method assigns a confidence value to each annotation, representing the posterior probability that it is correct. This is achieved by estimating annotator-specific parameters from data and computing certainty levels for individual annotations. Two probabilistic models are developed and compared using computer simulations and actual performance testing on a large dataset generated by human annotators. The results show that even in the worst-case scenario, where all annotators disagree, the approach significantly increases the probability of choosing the correct annotation. A corpus of 10,000 sentences annotated by eight experts and a 1,000-sentence subset annotated by five new experts is made publicly available. The study aims to provide a holistic approach to quantify certainty in individual annotations for a group of several annotators, allowing for the retention of the complete dataset as a basis for training and testing machine learning methods. The models for annotation reliability are validated through a second cycle of annotation, where five additional annotators annotate a subset of the original 10,000 sentences. The study highlights the importance of careful experimental design and appropriate modeling in improving existing curation approaches. It is suggested that small-scale annotation experiments can be conducted to estimate error rates specific to the task and annotator experts, which can be used to assign confidence to data annotated by a single expert with a known correctness rate.
A DNA vaccine platform using geese has been developed to produce antiviral biologics against Andes virus ( ANDV ), the primary cause of hantavirus pulmonary syndrome ( HPS ) in South America. Geese were vaccinated with an ANDV DNA vaccine encoding the virus envelope glycoproteins, resulting in the production of high-titer neutralizing antibodies. These antibodies, known as IgY and IgYΔFc, were purified from egg yolks and shown to be highly reactive to specific amino acid sequences of ANDV envelope glycoproteins. The protective efficacy of the goose-derived antibodies was tested in a hamster model of lethal HPS. Hamsters were challenged with a lethal dose of ANDV and then passively transferred with α-ANDV immune sera or IgY/IgYΔFc purified from eggs. The results showed that both immune sera and egg-derived purified IgY/IgYΔFc protected 8 of 8 and 7 of 8 hamsters, respectively, from lethal HPS. In contrast, hamsters receiving IgY/IgYΔFc purified from normal geese or no treatment developed lethal HPS. These findings demonstrate the potential of the DNA vaccine/goose platform to produce a candidate antiviral biological product capable of preventing a lethal disease when administered post-exposure. The use of this platform offers an alternative to human convalescent sera or mammalian antibodies, which are in short supply or have risks of reactogenicity in humans.
The Dnmt3a enzyme plays a crucial role in establishing and maintaining normal DNA methylation patterns in the genome. Research has shown that mutations in Dnmt3a are associated with leukemias, and its deletion in a mouse model of lung cancer promotes tumor progression. To investigate the role of Dnmt3a in cancer, scientists used whole-genome bisulfite sequencing to characterize the methylomes of Dnmt3a wildtype and Dnmt3a-deficient mouse lung tumors. The results revealed that Dnmt3a wildtype tumors exhibit large hypomethylated domains corresponding to nuclear lamina-associated domains, whereas Dnmt3a-deficient tumors show a uniformly hypomethylated genome. Further analysis showed that Dnmt3a is essential for maintaining DNA methylation patterns in active chromosome domains and that Dnmt3a-deficient tumors exhibit moderate levels of gene deregulation in these domains. These findings suggest that Dnmt3a acts as a tumor suppressor gene by protecting active chromosome domains against cancer-associated hypomethylation. The study provides new insights into the role of Dnmt3a in maintaining DNA methylation patterns in cancer and highlights the importance of Dnmt3a in preventing tumor development. The results also reveal conserved features of cancer methylomes and provide a better understanding of the epigenetic alterations underlying tumor-promoting effects of Dnmt3a mutations.
The study investigated the neural mechanisms underlying sequence generation in the songbird premotor cortical microcircuit. Using multi-channel electrophysiology and calcium imaging, the researchers found that neural activity in the premotor cortex is correlated with a length scale of 100 µm. Within this length scale, basal-ganglia–projecting excitatory neurons fire at a specific phase of a local 30 Hz network rhythm. This rhythm is coherent over a length scale matching that of projection neuron calcium activity. The activity patterns of excitatory and inhibitory neurons are spatially clustered, with two cell types, HVCX projection neurons and HVC interneurons, firing in alternating phases of the local 30 Hz rhythm. Inhibitory neurons show patterned activity throughout song, while projection neurons fire sparsely, with calcium events correlated in time between neighbors. This suggests a microcircuit in which multiple pools of excitatory neurons drive local interneuron populations. The study suggests that spatial clustering and 30 Hz rhythmic alternation of excitatory and inhibitory cells may be a recurring feature of cortical motor microcircuits and critical for the sequential organization of behavior. The findings have implications for future biophysical models of motor sequence generation in the songbird premotor cortex, which should consider the interplay of spatially correlated patterns of excitation and inhibition.
The regulation of lifespan is a complex process influenced by both genetic and environmental factors in many species. Recent studies have identified specific components from various cellular processes that control lifespan. In Caenorhabditis elegans, loss-of-function mutations in the insulin/insulin-like growth factor-1/daf-2 signaling pathway have been shown to significantly extend lifespan. However, the role of genes essential for growth and development in longevity has not been previously assessed. A screen of 2,700 genes essential for C. elegans development identified 64 genes that extend lifespan when inactivated post-developmentally. These candidate lifespan regulators are highly conserved from yeast to humans and can be classified into functional groups, including insulin and metabolic pathways, translation, RNA, and chromatin factors. Many of these essential gene inactivations extend lifespan as much as the strongest known regulators of aging. Early gene inactivation of these essential genes causes growth arrest at larval stages, and some of these arrested animals live longer than wild-type adults. The daf-16 gene is required for the enhanced survival of arrested larvae, suggesting that the increased longevity is a physiological response to the essential gene inactivation. These findings suggest that insulin-signaling pathways play a role in the regulation of aging at any stage in life.
A forward genetic screen in zebrafish identified a temperature-sensitive allele of the ECM component laminin beta 1a (lamb1a) that impairs fin regeneration. Positional cloning and complementation assays revealed that lamb1a is sharply induced in a subset of epithelial cells after fin amputation, where it is required to establish and maintain a polarized basal epithelial cell layer. This event facilitates the expression of morphogenetic factors shha and lef1, basolateral positioning of phosphorylated Igf1r, patterning of new osteoblasts, and regeneration of bone. In contrast, lamb1a function is dispensable for juvenile body growth, homeostatic adult tissue maintenance, repair of split fins, or renewal of genetically ablated osteoblasts. Fgf20a mutations or transgenic Fgf receptor inhibition disrupt lamb1a expression, linking a central growth factor to epithelial maturation during regeneration. The findings suggest that transient induction of lamb1a in epithelial cells is a key, growth factor-guided step in the formation of a signaling-competent regeneration epidermis. The regeneration epidermis expresses markers of developmental signaling pathways, including Fgfs, Igfs, Wnts, Hhs, Activin-βA/TGFβ, Retinoic acid, Bmps, and Notch. However, the mechanisms by which these pathways define the morphology and signaling activities of the regeneration epidermis have not been addressed.
The article compares the performance of several linear mixed model (LMM) approaches and software implementations in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) with family-based data. The LMM methods, including EMMAX, GenABEL, FaST-LMM, Mendel, GEMMA, and MMM, were applied to a genome-wide association study of visceral leishmaniasis in 348 Brazilian families comprising 3626 individuals. The results show strong concordance between the different LMM approaches, and all are successful in controlling the genome-wide error rate, except for some approaches when applied to longitudinal data with many repeated measures. The LMM results are also highly correlated with alternative approaches, such as MQLS, ROADTRIPS, and MASTOR, except for transmission-based approaches when applied to SNPs with small or non-existent effects. The study concludes that LMM approaches perform well in comparison to competing approaches and are a convenient and robust method for family-based GWAS of quantitative or binary traits. The choice of LMM implementation should be based on considerations such as speed and ease-of-use, rather than power or type I error considerations. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of LMM approaches in controlling the overall genomic inflation factor to an appropriate level and offers higher power than traditional family-based association analysis approaches. The results are based on both real and simulated data derived from a genome-wide association study of visceral leishmaniasis in Brazilian families.
The development of new drugs against Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a priority due to the toxicity and limited efficacy of existing treatments. A high-throughput screening (HTS) assay was optimized to identify compounds that inhibit T. cruzi infection of mammalian cells. A 2000-compound chemical library was screened using a recombinant T. cruzi strain expressing β-galactosidase. Three compounds, PCH1, NT1, and CX1, were identified as hits with high activity against T. cruzi and low toxicity to host cells. These compounds exhibited distinct mechanisms of action against intracellular T. cruzi amastigotes, with CX1 showing trypanocidal activity, NT1 having a trypanostatic effect, and PCH1 affecting parasite division. The compounds also demonstrated high activity against T. cruzi from the Y strain and related kinetoplastid species Leishmania major and L. amazonensis. Further characterization of chemically related molecules led to the selection of two compounds, PCH6 and CX2, with IC50 values of 2 nM, approximately 100 times lower than existing treatments. These results provide new candidate molecules for the development of treatments against Chagas disease and leishmaniasis.
A novel point-of-collection diagnostic platform, termed "Backpack PCR," has been developed for the rapid detection of Brugia parasites in mosquitoes. This platform combines a rapid NaOH-based DNA extraction methodology with a portable, battery-powered PCR platform and a test strip-based DNA detection assay. The system eliminates the need for expensive and bulky instrumentation, making it suitable for use in minimal resource settings. The performance of the platform was evaluated by comparing it to standard silica column-based DNA extraction techniques and real-time PCR. The results showed that the NaOH-based extraction method and test strip-based detection assay provided sensitive and genus-specific detection of parasite DNA from extracted mosquito pools. Additionally, the miniaturized PCR approach was compared to laboratory-based thermal cycling, demonstrating the potential for point-of-collection-based use of the entire diagnostic platform. The Backpack PCR system has the potential to increase the feasibility of molecular xenomonitoring within Brugia malayi-endemic locations and provides a proof-of-concept framework for the development of a parallel assay for the detection of Wuchereria bancrofti, the parasite responsible for approximately 90% of the global lymphatic filariasis burden. This platform could also be extended to the detection of other mosquito-borne pathogens, such as malaria, Zika, dengue fever, and Chikungunya.
The self-assembly of elastomeric proteins into polymeric structures is a complex process that has evolved independently multiple times in nature. These proteins are composed of alternating domains of elastomeric and cross-linking elements, with the former providing elasticity and driving the assembly process, and the latter stabilizing the polymer. The arrangement and number of these domains significantly impact the assembly and mechanical properties of the resulting polymer. To investigate the effects of domain architecture on polymer assembly and integrity, a novel simulation environment was developed using a diffusion-limited aggregation model to simulate the self-assembly of rod-like particles with alternating domain architectures. The model was applied to various domain architectures, and the resulting aggregates were analyzed using graph-theoretic metrics to predict their structural integrity. The results showed that the relative length and number of elastomeric and cross-linking domains can significantly impact the morphology and structural integrity of the resultant polymeric structure. Specifically, the most highly connected polymers were those constructed from asymmetric rods consisting of relatively large cross-linking elements interspersed with smaller elastomeric domains. These findings provide insights into the evolution of elastomeric proteins and may be useful for designing new biomaterials with tunable properties. The study demonstrates the potential of computational modeling in understanding the complex relationships between elastomeric domains and cross-linking domains, and in guiding the rational design of novel elastomeric-peptides.
The study investigated the role of upstream open reading frames (uORFs) in the 5′ untranslated regions (UTRs) of the Zaire ebolavirus (EBOV) genome in regulating viral polymerase translation and replication. The results showed that the EBOV 5′-UTRs do not function as internal ribosomal entry sites (IRESes) but instead regulate cap-dependent translation. The 5′-UTR derived from the viral polymerase (L) mRNA was found to strongly suppress translation of a green fluorescent protein (GFP) reporter gene compared to a β-actin 5′-UTR. The L 5′-UTR contains four upstream AUGs (uAUGs), and ablating each uAUG enhanced translation of the primary open reading frame (pORF). The L uAUG was sufficient to initiate translation and was surrounded by a "weak" Kozak sequence, which suppressed pORF translation in a position-dependent manner. The presence of the uORF maintained translation of the L pORF under conditions where eIF2α was phosphorylated, indicating that the uORF modulates L translation in response to cellular stress. A recombinant EBOV was generated with the L uAUG mutated to UCG, resulting in a 10-100-fold decrease in virus growth in Vero and A549 cells, as well as decreased viral RNA synthesis and enhanced sensitivity to the stress inducer thapsigargin. These findings identify novel mechanisms by which EBOV regulates its polymerase expression and replication, and suggest that the L uAUG is a potential therapeutic target.
Genome-wide mapping of DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) in human chromosomes has revealed non-random fragmentation and DSB hot spots scattered along chromosomes. These hot spots delimit protected 50–250 kb DNA domains, termed forum domains. Approximately 30% of these domains possess coordinately expressed genes, suggesting a novel type of gene regulation. PARP1 and HNRNPA2B1 specifically bind DNA sequences at the forum domain termini, which may influence coordinated transcription or silencing of gene clusters within these domains. The binding of PARP1 and HNRNPA2B1 at these sites may play a crucial role in chromatin organization and transcriptional regulation. The study highlights the relationship between human chromosomal fragile sites, chromosomal organization, and gene regulation, which may be important for cancer genomics and gene therapy. The technique used to map DSBs can also be applied to study fragile chromosomal sites in various human cell types. The findings suggest that the binding of HNRNPA2B1 at forum termini may influence coordinated transcription within these domains, and the interaction between PARP1 and HNRNPA2B1 may be a key mechanism in the functioning of chromosomal domains. This study provides new insights into the regulation of gene expression and chromosomal organization, and highlights the potential importance of PARP1 and HNRNPA2B1 in these processes.
A study was conducted in the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, to investigate the presence of trypanosomatids in bats from two areas with different levels of degradation: Reserva Ecológica de Guapiaçu (REGUA) and Estação Fiocruz Mata Atlântica (EFMA). A total of 181 bat specimens were analyzed, and 24 individuals (13%) were found to be infected with trypanosomatids. The most frequently detected parasite was Trypanosoma dionisii, followed by T. cruzi DTUs TcI and TcIV, and Trypanosoma sp. in Neotropical phyllostomid bats. Mixed infections by T. dionisii/T. cruzi TcIII and T. dionisii/T. cruzi TcI were also observed. The T. cruzi DTUs TcI and TcIV are currently involved in cases of acute Chagas disease in Brazil, and T. dionisii was recently found in the heart tissue of an infected child. Notably, the study also identified Crithidia mellificae, a putative monoxenous parasite from insects, infecting a vertebrate host in the Americas for the first time. The results suggest that bats from the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro state harbor a great diversity of trypanosomatids, maintaining trypanosomatid diversity in this sylvatic environment. The study highlights the importance of including parasites that can potentially infect humans in studies of local biodiversity, particularly in areas with high human population density.
This study investigated the prevalence of 38 pathogens and four symbionts in Ixodes ricinus ticks collected in the French Ardennes. A total of 267 female ticks were analyzed using high-throughput real-time PCR, rRT-PCR, and nested PCR. The results showed that 45% of the ticks were co-infected with up to five different pathogens, and when including symbionts, all ticks were infected with at least one microorganism and up to eight microorganisms were identified in the same tick. The study found a strong association between Borrelia garinii and B. afzelii, but no significant interactions between symbionts and pathogens. The high pathogen co-infection rates in ticks raise questions about possible co-transmission of these agents to humans or animals and their consequences to human and animal health. The study also demonstrated high prevalence rates of symbionts co-existing with pathogens, opening new avenues of enquiry regarding their effects on pathogen transmission and vector competence. Overall, the study provides a comprehensive overview of the epidemiological situation of tick-borne pathogens circulating in ticks from the French Ardennes, highlighting the importance of considering co-infections in the study of tick-borne diseases.
The hematopoietic erythroid-myeloid lineage decision is governed by a genetic switch involving the master genes PU.1 and GATA-1. Prior to lineage commitment, genes are primed at low expression levels, allowing for rapid deployment of transcription factors to implement specific genetic programs. A computational model of the hematopoietic erythroid-myeloid lineage decision reveals that dynamical models based on known interactions between PU.1 and GATA-1, such as mutual antagonism and autoregulation, fail to produce bistability, a necessary feature for robust lineage determination. To achieve bistability, a new mechanism involving a cofactor regulated and recruited by one of the master genes is proposed. This cofactor binds to the antagonistic partner, enabling bistability and switch-like behavior. Suppression of the cofactor leads to a loss of cooperativity and a primed state for PU.1 and GATA-1. The PU.1-GATA-1 switch interacts with another mutually antagonistic pair, FOG-1, which inherits the state of its upstream master genes and reinforces the decision through feedback loops, resulting in irreversible commitment. The genetic switch demonstrates both primed and committed states by regulating cooperativity through cofactor recruitment. Perturbing the feedback between master regulators and downstream targets suggests potential reprogramming strategies. This approach provides a framework for lineage commitment studies and may aid in identifying lineage-determining genes.
The enterococcal polysaccharide antigen (EPA) plays a crucial role in the virulence of Enterococcus faecalis, an opportunistic pathogen with high resistance to lysozyme, a key effector of the innate immune system. A complex network of transcriptional regulators and genes, including oatA, pgdA, dltA, and sigV, synergistically inhibit lysozyme's enzymatic and cationic antimicrobial peptide activities. To identify novel genes modulating E. faecalis resistance to lysozyme, random transposon mutagenesis was performed in a quadruple oatA/pgdA/dltA/sigV mutant. This led to the identification of several independent insertions in a locus referred to as the EPA variable region, located downstream of the conserved epaA-epaR genes. The EPA variable region was previously proposed to be responsible for EPA decorations, but its role remained largely unknown. This study shows that EPA decoration contributes to resistance towards charged antimicrobials and underpins virulence in the zebrafish model of infection by conferring resistance to phagocytosis. The production of the EPA rhamnopolysaccharide backbone is not sufficient to promote E. faecalis infections, and the modification of this surface polymer is essential for enterococcal pathogenesis. The results indicate that several genes contributing to EPA decoration play an essential role in resistance to effectors of the innate immune system and in virulence.
The study presents RACER (Regression Analysis of Combined Expression Regulation), a novel framework for integrating genome-wide data from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) and Encyclopedia of DNA Elements (ENCODE) to predict gene expression in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). RACER infers sample-specific regulatory activities of transcription factors (TFs) and microRNAs (miRNAs), which are then used to infer TF/miRNA-gene interactions. This two-stage regression framework circumvents the difficulty of integrating ENCODE data measured in generic cell lines with sample-specific TCGA measurements. The model was validated through 10-fold cross-validation and demonstrated superior statistical power in detecting known miRNA/TF targets compared to existing methods. A feature selection procedure identified 18 regulators whose activities clustered consistently with cytogenetic risk groups, including miR-548p, which was implicated in AML pathogenesis. Survival analysis using the inferred activities identified C-Fos as a potential AML prognostic marker. RACER successfully integrated TCGA and ENCODE data to reveal an AML-specific regulatory program at a global level. The study demonstrates the potential of RACER to uncover novel regulatory relationships and identify potential biomarkers for AML. The model's ability to integrate multiple data types and infer sample-specific regulatory activities makes it a valuable tool for understanding the complex regulation of gene expression in cancer.
This study investigated the role of RNA silencing in the phytopathogenic fungus Colletotrichum higginsianum. Knock-out mutants were generated to affect genes for three RNA-dependent RNA polymerase ( RDR ), two Dicer-like ( DCL ), and two Argonaute ( AGO ) proteins. The results showed that Δdcl1, Δdcl1Δdcl2 double mutant, and Δago1 strains exhibited severe defects in conidiation and conidia morphology. Total RNA transcripts and small RNA populations were analyzed in parental and mutant strains. The greatest effects on both RNA populations were observed in the Δdcl1, Δdcl1Δdcl2, and Δago1 strains, in which a previously uncharacterized dsRNA mycovirus, Colletotrichum higginsianum non-segmented dsRNA virus 1 ( ChNRV1 ), was derepressed. Phylogenetic analyses revealed a close relationship between ChNRV1 and members of the segmented Partitiviridae family. Immunoprecipitation of small RNAs associated with AGO1 showed abundant loading of 5’U-containing viral siRNA. C. higginsianum parental and Δdcl1 mutant strains cured of ChNRV1 revealed that the conidiation and spore morphology defects were primarily caused by ChNRV1. The study proposes that RNA silencing involving ChDCL1 and ChAGO1 in C. higginsianum functions as an antiviral mechanism. The results suggest that DCL1 and AGO1 are critical for maintaining low levels of accumulation of ChNRV1, a novel dsRNA virus in C. higginsianum.
This study investigated the role of histone acetyltransferase (HAT) MOF in meiotic expansion of H2AX phosphorylation and spermatogenesis in mice. Three waves of H2AX phosphorylation (γH2AX) have been observed in male meiotic prophase I: the first is ATM-dependent and occurs at leptonema, while the second and third are ATR-dependent, occurring at zygonema and pachynema, respectively. The third wave of H2AX phosphorylation marks and silences unsynapsed chromosomes. The study found that MOF is involved in all three waves of H2AX phosphorylation expansion. Germ cell-specific deletion of Mof in spermatocytes by Stra8-Cre (Mof cKO) caused global loss of H4K16ac. In leptotene and zygotene spermatocytes of cKO mice, the γH2AX signals were observed only along the chromosomal axes, and chromatin-wide H2AX phosphorylation was lost. In almost 40% of early-mid pachytene spermatocytes from Mof cKO mice, γH2AX and MDC1 were detected along the unsynapsed axes of the sex chromosomes, but failed to expand, which consequently caused meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI) failure. Furthermore, defects in double-strand break (DSB) repair and crossover formation were observed in Mof cKO spermatocytes, indicating that MOF facilitates meiotic DSB repair after RAD51 recruitment. The study proposes that MOF regulates male meiosis and is involved in the expansion of all three waves of H2AX phosphorylation from the leptotene to pachytene stages, initiated by ATM and ATR, respectively.
The study investigated the effects of human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) infection on human T-cell development in a “Human Immune System” (HIS) Rag2-/-γc-/- mouse model. The mice were infected with HTLV-1 at a time when the three main subpopulations of human thymocytes were detectable. The results showed that the HTLV-1 provirus was integrated in thymocytes in all but two inoculated mice, and the proviral load increased with the length of the infection period. In HTLV-1-infected mice, alterations in human T-cell development were observed, with mature single-positive (SP) CD4+ and CD8+ cells being most numerous at the expense of immature and double-positive (DP) thymocytes. These SP cells also accumulated in the spleen. Human lymphocytes from thymus and spleen were activated, as shown by the expression of CD25, which was correlated with the presence of tax mRNA and increased expression of NF-kB-dependent genes such as bfl-1, an anti-apoptotic gene. The study also found that HTLV-1 infection led to the expansion of mature T-cells in the periphery and the development of pathological features such as hepato-splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, and lymphoma/thymoma. The results demonstrate the potential of the HIS Rag2-/-γc-/- animal model to elucidate the initial steps of the leukemogenic process induced by HTLV-1. The study suggests that Tax activates the transcription of genes involved in cell survival and proliferation in the thymus of HTLV-1-infected HIS Rag2-/-γc-/- mice and favors the expansion of mature activated T cells.
An integrated control project for schistosomiasis was implemented in Al Jabalain locality of White Nile State, Sudan from 2009 to 2011. The project aimed to reduce the prevalence of urogenital schistosomiasis, particularly Schistosoma haematobium infection. The study population consisted of 482,902 individuals, with 78,615 primary school students being the major target group for intervention. A cross-sectional study was conducted to assess the prevalence of S. haematobium and S. mansoni infections. Urine and stool specimens were examined using the urine sedimentation method and the Kato cellophane thick smear method, respectively. At baseline, the overall prevalence of S. haematobium and S. mansoni infections was 28.5% and 0.4%, respectively. After 6-9 months post-treatment, the prevalence of S. haematobium infection was reduced to 13.5% (95% CI = 0.331-0.462). The reduction in prevalence was higher among girls, those with moderately infected status, and residents in rural areas compared to boys, those with high prevalence, and residents in urban areas. Health education and the construction of a drinking water facility at Al Hidaib village also contributed to the reduction in infection rates. However, no significant change was observed in the prevalence of S. mansoni infection between baseline and follow-up surveys. At the end of the project, the prevalence of S. haematobium infection was reduced by more than 50% compared to the baseline rate. Approximately 200,000 subjects received either praziquantel therapy, health education, or supply of clean water.
The matrix protein of Nipah virus (NiV), a highly pathogenic emerging paramyxovirus, plays a crucial role in viral assembly and budding. Contrary to the typical cytoplasmic replication of paramyxoviruses, the NiV matrix protein (NiV-M) is found in the nucleus at early stages of infection before localizing to the cytoplasm and plasma membrane. Mutations in the bipartite nuclear localization signal (NLS) and leucine-rich nuclear export signal (NES) of NiV-M impaired its nuclear-cytoplasmic trafficking and abolished viral budding. A conserved lysine residue in the NLS served dual functions: mediating nuclear import and regulating nuclear export through monoubiquitination. Overexpression of ubiquitin enhanced NiV-M budding, while depletion of free ubiquitin via proteasome inhibitors resulted in nuclear retention of NiV-M and blocked viral budding. Live Nipah virus budding was exquisitely sensitive to proteasome inhibitors, with bortezomib, an FDA-approved proteasome inhibitor, reducing viral titers with an IC50 of 2.7 nM. These findings suggest that the nuclear-cytoplasmic trafficking of NiV-M and associated post-translational modification play a critical role in matrix-mediated viral budding. The study highlights the potential therapeutic application of proteasome inhibitors, such as bortezomib, against acute NiV infection.
The mechanisms by which nonenveloped viruses, such as poliovirus ( PV ), deliver their genomes into host cells are poorly understood due to technical difficulties in direct visualization of viral gene delivery and uncertainties in distinguishing productive and nonproductive pathways. To address this knowledge gap, researchers combined an imaging assay that tracks the viral capsid and genome in live cells with an infectivity-based assay for RNA release to characterize the early events in PV infection. The study found that PV genome release is highly efficient and rapid, and thus does not limit the overall infectivity or infection rate. The results define a pathway in which PV binds to receptors on the cell surface and enters the cell through a clathrin-, caveolin-, flotillin-, and microtubule-independent, but tyrosine kinase- and actin-dependent, endocytic mechanism. Genome release occurs immediately after internalization of the virus particle from vesicles or tightly sealed membrane invaginations located within 100–200 nm of the plasma membrane. This study settles a long-standing debate on whether PV directly breaks the plasma membrane barrier or relies on endocytosis to deliver its genome into the cell. The imaging assay used in this study is expected to be broadly applicable to the investigation of entry mechanisms for nonenveloped viruses.
In rural Cambodia, dengue fever remains a significant public health concern, particularly among children. The National Dengue Control Program (NDCP) relies heavily on health education as a means of prevention and control. However, an ethnographic study conducted in eastern Cambodia in 2003-2004 revealed that community and school-based health education for dengue control is insufficient, under-funded, and irregular. Community health education is delivered through outreach activities and campaigns, but lacks systematic evaluation and follow-up. School-based education is restricted in terms of time and lacks practical activities for prevention and control. As a result, adherence to dengue prevention and control measures is partial. The study highlights the need for sustained routine education and approaches to ensure the translation of knowledge into practice. Local prevention and control activities, involving community members and supported through health education, offer potential to reduce dengue prevalence, but are hindered by poorly resourced and episodic health education. Political commitment and availability of educational resources are also critical factors impacting outreach activities. The study suggests that existing dengue health education messages, materials, and strategies must be redefined to be practical, applicable, and relevant, and that health practitioners require training in health education techniques to effectively deliver health education.
This study investigated the presence of circulating microRNAs (miRNAs) released by filarial nematodes into the host bloodstream. Filarial nematodes cause chronic and debilitating diseases in humans and animals. The researchers used miRNA deep-sequencing and bioinformatics to identify over 200 mature miRNA sequences of potential nematode origin in Dirofilaria immitis-infected dog plasma and 21 in Onchocerca volvulus-infected human serum. Two miRNA candidates, miR-71 and miR-34, were detected in D. immitis-infected dog plasma using stem-loop RT-qPCR assays. These miRNAs were also found in Brugia pahangi-infected dog samples. The presence of miR-71 and miR-34 discriminated infected samples from uninfected samples. However, the absolute miRNA copy numbers were not significantly correlated with microfilaraemia for either parasite. This may be due to the imprecision of mf counts to estimate infection intensity or to miRNA contributions from the unknown number of adult worms present. The study suggests that parasite-derived circulating miRNAs are present in plasma or serum even for species that do not live in the bloodstream. The findings have implications for the development of novel diagnostic tools for filarial infections.
The article presents a computational study on the conformational activation of Src kinases, a family of large allosteric enzymes involved in cellular signaling. A coarse-grained model of the catalytic domain was constructed using experimental structures of the inactive and active states, and molecular dynamics simulations were performed to explore the transition energy landscapes. Two major ensembles of pathways for activation were identified from the structural network constructed from the simulations. The first pathway involves a coordinated switching mechanism among the αC helix, activation-loop, and β strands in the N-lobe of the catalytic domain. In the second pathway, the conformational change is coupled to a partial unfolding of the N-lobe region of the catalytic domain. A detailed analysis of the switching mechanism for the αC helix and activation-loop was also performed. Additionally, a Markov model was tested to account for the structural kinetics in the context of Src conformational changes. The results provide a broad framework for understanding the main features of the conformational transition taking place upon Src activation. The study employed a structure-based coarse-grained model to investigate the Src conformational changes on the free energy landscapes, allowing for the exploration of the detailed conformational landscape by clustering the configurational space and constructing a structural network from simulations. The large-scale motions in the Src conformational activation occur on a relatively slow timescale, which is beyond the reach of brute-force all-atom simulations.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, crosses between diploid and tetraploid individuals of the same genotype can result in F1 lethality due to dosage-sensitive incompatibility, which plays a role in polyploid speciation. Researchers have identified variation in F1 lethality in interploidy crosses and determined the genetic architecture of the maternally expressed variation via QTL mapping. A single large-effect QTL, DR. STRANGELOVE 1 ( DSL1 ), was identified along with two QTL with epistatic relationships to DSL1. DSL1 affects the rate of postzygotic lethality via expression in the maternal sporophyte. Fine mapping placed DSL1 in an interval encoding the maternal effect transcription factor TTG2. Maternal parents carrying loss-of-function mutations in TTG2 suppressed the F1 lethality caused by paternal excess interploidy crosses. The frequency of cellularization in the endosperm was similarly affected by both natural variation and ttg2 loss-of-function mutants. The simple genetic basis of the natural variation and effects of single-gene mutations suggest that F1 lethality in polyploids could evolve rapidly. Furthermore, the role of the sporophytically active TTG2 gene in interploidy crosses indicates that the developmental programming of the mother regulates the viability of interploidy hybrid offspring. Loss-of-function mutations in TTG2 isolated from both the Ler and Col backgrounds improved interploidy crossing success, and the degree of rescue provided by a loss-of-function allele in Col was many-fold greater than in Ler.
The study investigated the coevolutionary patterns of Bartonella and Leptospira bacteria with their mammalian hosts, specifically bats and rodents. Using genetic data from 51 Bartonella genotypes from 24 bat species, 129 Bartonella from 38 rodents, and 26 Leptospira from 20 bats, the researchers generated maximum likelihood and Bayesian phylogenies for hosts and bacteria. The results showed significant coevolutionary congruence between Bartonella and both rodent and bat hosts at a global level. In contrast, the relationship between Leptospira and their bat hosts was non-significant. Event-cost results supported the global-fit findings, with the rodent-Bartonella and bat-Bartonella associations having the least number of host switches per parasite, indicating greater evolutionary congruence over time. The study also found that Bartonella exhibits significant coevolution with minimal host switching in both bat and rodent hosts, while Leptospira in bats lacks evolutionary congruence with its host and has a high number of host switches. These variable coevolutionary patterns are likely due to differences in disease-specific transmission and host ecology. The study suggests that understanding the coevolutionary patterns and frequency of host-switching events between bacterial pathogens and their hosts will allow for better prediction of spillover between mammal reservoirs and ultimately to humans.
A forced damped oscillation framework was applied to a chain-link model of undulatory swimming to investigate the relationship between muscle forcing and deformation kinematics leading to movement. The study aimed to understand whether complex muscle forcing is necessary to produce the observed deformation kinematics in undulatory swimmers. By considering swimming as a forced damped oscillation problem, the researchers found that the forcing triggers the first few deformation modes of the body, which in turn cause translational motion. The study showed that relatively simple forcing patterns can lead to complex deformation kinematics resulting in movement. The forcing frequency relative to the natural frequency of the damped oscillator was found to be crucial in determining the emergent deformation characteristics of the body. A closed-form expression for swimming velocity was derived through a leading-order analysis of the equations of motion. The results suggest that the power generated from muscle work is used to create body deformations, which are then dissipated into the surrounding fluid. The study provides a unified understanding of swimming, encompassing both active and passive swimming, and offers insights into the optimal deformation kinematics for fast swimming. The findings were confirmed by fully resolved computational fluid dynamics simulations and are consistent with prior results on the optimal value of stiffness for maximum speed.
This study investigated the potential for genetic recombination between subspecies of the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma brucei from humans and animals to generate new strains of the human pathogen Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense (Tbr), responsible for sleeping sickness (Human African Trypanosomiasis, HAT) in East Africa. The human infectivity of Tbr is conferred by a single gene, SRA, which can be transferred to the animal pathogen Trypanosoma brucei brucei (Tbb) through sexual reproduction. The study used genetically-engineered fluorescent parental trypanosome lines to track the inheritance of SRA in crosses between Tbr and Tbb transmitted through tsetse flies. The results showed that SRA was readily transferred into new genetic backgrounds, creating new strains of the human pathogen Tbr. There was no evidence of diminished growth or transmissibility of hybrid trypanosomes carrying SRA. The study also found that SRA exists as a single copy in a representative collection of Tbr strains and is located on one homologue of chromosome IV in the majority of Tbr isolates examined. The mobility of SRA by genetic recombination explains the observed genetic variability of Tbr in East Africa. The study concludes that new strains of the human pathogen Tbr are being generated continuously by recombination with the larger pool of animal-infective trypanosomes, posing a risk for future outbreaks of HAT.
The study investigated the role of gap junction coupling in the dysfunction of β-cells in Neonatal Diabetes Mellitus (NDM), a condition characterized by disrupted insulin secretion and glucose homeostasis. Gap junction-mediated electrical coupling between β-cells in the islets of Langerhans plays a crucial role in coordinating a pulsatile secretory response at elevated glucose levels and suppressing insulin secretion at basal glucose levels. The study used a murine model of NDM involving expression of ATP-insensitive KATP channels and a multi-cellular computational model of islet electrical activity to examine the mechanisms by which gap junction coupling contributes to islet dysfunction in NDM. The results showed that reductions in gap junction coupling allow for progressively greater glucose-stimulated calcium ([Ca2+]) and insulin secretion following expression of ATP-insensitive KATP channels. The computational model demonstrated good correspondence between suppression of [Ca2+] and clinical presentation of different NDM mutations. Furthermore, the model predicted significant recoveries in [Ca2+] and insulin secretion for many mutations upon reductions in gap junction coupling, where stochastic noise played a significant role in the recoveries. These findings provide new understanding of how the islet functions as a multicellular system and suggest novel therapeutic options for NDM and other monogenic forms of diabetes. The study highlights the importance of gap junction channels in exacerbating the effects of decreased cellular excitability and suggests that reducing gap junction coupling may recover islet function and blunt diabetes caused by mutations in KCNJ11 and ABCC8.
Predicting the dynamic behavior of large gene transcription networks from the behavior of their composing modules is a significant challenge in systems and synthetic biology. A major obstacle to achieving this predictive ability is the context-dependent behavior of modules, which is influenced by retroactivity. Retroactivity is a phenomenon that affects the dynamic performance of a module when it is connected to other modules. To address this issue, the authors develop an analysis framework for gene transcription networks that explicitly accounts for retroactivity. This framework is based on three retroactivity matrices: internal, scaling, and mixing retroactivity, which can be computed from macroscopic parameters and the modules' topology. The internal retroactivity matrix quantifies the effect of intramodular connections on an isolated module's dynamics, while the scaling and mixing retroactivity matrices describe how intermodular connections change the dynamics of connected modules. Using these matrices and the dynamics of modules in isolation, the authors can accurately predict how loading will affect the behavior of an arbitrary interconnection of modules. The authors also provide a quantitative metric to evaluate the robustness of a module's dynamic behavior to interconnection with other modules. This metric can be used to assess the extent of modularity in natural networks and to design guidelines for minimizing retroactivity in synthetic systems. The authors illustrate the implications of retroactivity on the performance of various network motifs, including negative autoregulation, combinatorial regulation, two-gene clocks, the toggle switch, and the single-input motif.
The human pseudoautosomal region 1 (PAR1) is a short region of homology between the X and Y chromosomes that undergoes rapid evolution. A crossover in PAR1 is essential for proper disjunction of X and Y chromosomes in male meiosis, and its deletion results in male sterility. The PAR1 region has an exceptionally high male crossover rate, 17-fold higher than the genome-wide average. To investigate recombination in this region, researchers constructed a fine-scale genetic map using African-American pedigrees and analyzed recombination rates inferred from linkage disequilibrium in human populations. They also identified direct PRDM9 binding sites using ChIP-seq in human cells. The results show that PRDM9 localizes peaks of recombination in the human PAR1, in contrast to mice. Recombination is a more rapid and intense driver of sequence evolution in PAR1 than on autosomes, and hotspot activities differ significantly among human populations. The study also found evidence that PAR1 hotspot positions have changed between humans and chimpanzees, with no evidence of sharing among the hottest hotspots. The genetic maps built and validated in this work are expected to aid research on this vital and fascinating region of the genome. The findings suggest that PRDM9 remains responsible for positioning recombination events in humans, but other factors may aid this protein in producing a high overall crossover rate.
A new isoform of the histone demethylase JMJD2A/KDM4A, lacking the N-terminal demethylase domain (ΔN-JMJD2A), plays a crucial role in skeletal muscle differentiation. In proliferating myoblasts, muscle-specific genes are silenced by epigenetic modifications, including histone H3K9 methylation, at their promoters. The derepression of the promoter of the myogenic factor myogenin (Myog) is essential for the initiation of muscle differentiation. However, the mechanism of H3K9 demethylation at the Myog promoter was unclear. Genome-wide expression profiling and exon-specific siRNA knockdown revealed that ΔN-JMJD2A is necessary for myotube formation and muscle-specific gene expression. ΔN-JMJD2A promotes MyoD-induced conversion of NIH3T3 cells into muscle cells and binds to genes mainly involved in transcriptional control, leading to gene activation. ChIP-on-chip analysis showed that ΔN-JMJD2A is recruited to the Myog promoter at the onset of differentiation, promoting the demethylation of H3K9me2 and H3K9me3. This study demonstrates that the induction of the ΔN-JMJD2A isoform is crucial for muscle differentiation by directing the removal of repressive chromatin marks at the Myog promoter, thus promoting transcriptional activation of the Myog gene and contributing to the initiation of muscle-specific gene expression. ΔN-JMJD2A acts as a transcriptional co-activator for many genes induced specifically during skeletal muscle differentiation, and its binding to the Myog promoter regulates H3K9 methylation, allowing Myog expression and promoting myotube differentiation.
The Guinea Worm Eradication Programme (GWEP) is in its final stages, with only 25 reported cases in 2016, but global eradication requires certification by the World Health Organization (WHO) of the absence of transmission in all countries. This study evaluates the cost-effectiveness of the GWEP in the end game, when the number of cases is low and the cost per case is high. Using data from the GWEP, the study estimates the cost of implementation, pre-certification, and certification stages from 1986 to 2030. The study compares the GWEP to two alternative scenarios: doing nothing since 1986 and control (surveillance and outbreak response during 2016-2030). The results show that the GWEP costs an estimated $11 (95% uncertainty interval, $4.70-$12.49) per case averted in the period 1986-2030. The cost per Disability-Adjusted Life Year (DALY) averted by the GWEP relative to doing nothing is estimated at $222 (118-372) in 1986-2030. The study finds that the GWEP is probably more cost-effective than control by 2030 and is certainly more cost-effective if the willingness to pay for one year of life lived without the risk of Guinea worm disease exceeds $0.10. Even if economic costs are twice as high as the financial costs estimated for the period to 2020, the GWEP will still be cost-effective relative to doing nothing.
The carboxy-terminal domain of the BBK32 protein from Borrelia burgdorferi sensu stricto, termed BBK32-C, has been shown to bind and inhibit the initiating serine protease of the human classical complement pathway, C1r. This study investigated the function of BBK32 orthologues from the Lyme-associated Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato complex, designated BAD16 from B. afzelii strain PGau and BGD19 from B. garinii strain IP90. The results show that B. afzelii BAD16-C exhibits BBK32-C-like activities in all assays tested, including high-affinity binding to purified C1r protease and C1 complex, and potent inhibition of the classical complement pathway. In contrast, recombinant B. garinii BGD19-C bound C1 and C1r with high-affinity but exhibited significantly reduced in vitro complement inhibitory activities relative to BBK32-C or BAD16-C. The crystal structure of BBK32-C was solved to 1.7Å limiting resolution, revealing an anti-parallel four-helix bundle fold with a fifth alpha-helix protruding from the helical core. Site-directed mutagenesis was performed to convert BBK32-C to resemble BGD19-C at three residue positions, resulting in a chimeric protein that mimicked the properties observed for BGD19-C. The structure-function studies reported here improve our understanding of how BBK32 recognizes and inhibits C1r and provide new insight into complement evasion mechanisms of Lyme-associated spirochetes of the B. burgdorferi sensu lato complex.
The opportunistic fungal pathogen Candida albicans undergoes a morphological and transcriptional adaptation from commensalism to pathogenicity. Previous studies have identified factors involved in this transformation, but the regulatory mechanisms remain unclear. This study investigated the role of post-translational phosphorylation in morphogenetic control, focusing on the cyclin-dependent kinase Cdc28. The Fkh2 transcription factor was identified as a regulatory target of Cdc28 and the cell wall biosynthesis kinase Cbk1, in a role distinct from its conserved function in cell cycle progression. Fkh2 undergoes a radical shift in its phosphorylation profile upon hyphal induction, mediated by Cdc28-Ccn1/Cln3 and Cbk1-Mob2. This shift activates Fkh2 to promote the expression of genes required for pathogenic processes. Mass spectrometry and mutational analyses identified residues phosphorylated by Cdc28 and Cbk1, and substitution of these residues with non-phosphorylatable alanine altered the yeast phosphorylation profile and abrogated the characteristic transformation to the hyphal profile. Transcript profiling of the phosphorylation site mutant revealed that the hyphal phosphorylation profile is required for the expression of genes involved in pathogenesis, host interaction, and biofilm formation. Fkh2 interacts with the chromatin modifier Pob3 in a phosphorylation-dependent manner, providing a possible mechanism by which the phosphorylation of Fkh2 regulates its specificity. This study reveals a novel cell cycle-independent phospho-regulatory event that subverts a key component of the cell cycle machinery to a role in the switch from commensalism to pathogenicity.
Trypanosoma brucei, a human pathogenic parasite, utilizes both de novo and salvage pathways for pyrimidine nucleotide biosynthesis. Thymidine kinase ( TK ) is one of several salvage enzymes thought to be redundant to the de novo pathway. However, analysis of TK conditional null and RNAi cells revealed that TK is essential for growth and infectivity in a mouse model, and that a catalytically active enzyme is required for its function. Unlike humans, T. brucei lacks dCMP deaminase ( DCTD ), which provides an alternative route to dUMP formation. Ectopic expression of human DCTD rescued the RNAi growth phenotype and allowed for selection of viable TK null cells. Metabolite profiling showed a buildup of deoxypyrimidine nucleosides in TK depleted cells. Knockout of cytidine deaminase ( CDA ) led to thymidine/deoxyuridine auxotrophy, suggesting the presence of an unidentified 5'-nucleotidase that converts deoxypyrimidine nucleotides to their corresponding nucleosides. Bioinformatics analysis identified several potential candidate genes that could encode 5’-nucleotidase activity, including an HD-domain protein that catalyzes dephosphorylation of deoxyribonucleotide 5’-monophosphates. These findings suggest that TK is essential for synthesis of thymine nucleotides regardless of whether the nucleoside precursors originate from the de novo pathway or through salvage. The reliance on TK in the absence of DCTD may be a shared vulnerability among trypanosomatids, providing a unique opportunity to selectively target a diverse group of pathogenic single-celled eukaryotes with a single drug.
The initiation of translation in prokaryotic systems typically requires interaction between the ribosome and an mRNA sequence upstream of the initiation codon, known as the ribosome-binding site or Shine-Dalgarno sequence. However, a large number of genes do not possess Shine-Dalgarno sequences, and it is unknown how start codon recognition occurs in these mRNAs. To address this question, the authors performed genome-wide searches in various prokaryotes to identify sequence elements and/or RNA secondary structural motifs that could mediate translation initiation in mRNAs lacking Shine-Dalgarno sequences. The results show that mRNAs without a Shine-Dalgarno sequence are generally less structured in their translation initiation region and exhibit a minimum of mRNA folding at the start codon. Using reporter gene constructs in bacteria, the authors provide experimental support for local RNA unfoldedness determining start codon recognition in Shine-Dalgarno-independent translation. The data suggest that local absence of RNA secondary structure is necessary and sufficient to initiate Shine-Dalgarno-independent translation. Furthermore, the authors found that AUG start codons reside in single-stranded regions, whereas internal AUG codons are usually in structured regions of the mRNA. These findings provide a plausible mechanism for how the correct translation initiation site is recognized in the absence of a ribosome-binding site.
In Bihar, India, a region highly endemic for Leishmania donovani, Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) supported a visceral leishmaniasis (VL) treatment program from July 2007 to August 2012. During this period, 8749 patients received 20 mg/kg intravenous liposomal amphotericin B (Ambisome) as first-line treatment, resulting in a high initial cure rate (99.3%) and low default rate (0.3%). Of the 8311 patients completing treatment for their first episode of VL, 24 (0.3%) returned to the program complaining of symptoms subsequently confirmed as post-Kala-Azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL). The median time to development of PKDL was 1.2 years (interquartile range: 0.8-2.2) following treatment. Comparison of demographic and clinical characteristics of VL patients treated with Ambisome who later developed PKDL with those of the remaining cohort did not identify any significant risk factors for PKDL. However, the time to developing PKDL was significantly shorter with Ambisome than in a subset of patients presenting to the program with PKDL following previous sodium stibogluconate treatment for VL. This study demonstrates that PKDL following treatment for VL with 20 mg/kg liposomal amphotericin B (Ambisome) is a possibility in the Indian context, with no predictive risk factors identified. The shorter median time to developing symptoms of PKDL compared with that after conventional VL treatments should be taken into account when counseling patients treated with regimens including Ambisome.
Title: Spatial Re-Establishment Dynamics of Local Populations of Vectors of Chagas Disease
    Summary:
    Chagas disease prevention relies heavily on controlling the insect vectors that transmit the infection. However, these vectors have been resurgent in some areas, highlighting the need to understand the dynamics of reinfestation. A study analyzed the reinfestation of Triatoma infestans, the main vector of Chagas disease, in three villages in northwest Argentina after community-wide insecticide spraying in 1992. Continuous- and discrete-time models were fitted to patch-level infestation states to elucidate different aspects of re-establishment. The results showed a 6-month time lag between detection of a new infestation and dispersal events, and a seasonal increase in bug establishment from May to November, coinciding with a seasonal increase in dispersal distance. The probability of new bug establishment increased with increasing time since last detected infestation. These findings challenge current understanding of T. infestans ecology and highlight gaps in knowledge. Experiments are necessary to close these gaps. Discrete- and continuous-time Markov models for site-level transitions from uninfested to infested and vice versa were fitted to spatiotemporal population data of T. infestans. The models showed a strong seasonality in bug establishment on new sites by T. infestans, coincident with seasonality in dispersal distance. The study addresses three aspects relevant for population control of T. infestans: the establishment rate of new local populations as a function of distance from existing local populations, possible mechanisms for the observed seasonality in bug establishment, and the effect of insecticide spraying and previous infestation on establishment rates.
This study investigated the effects of polyomavirus SV40 microRNA on the pathogenesis of viral infections in Syrian golden hamsters. The researchers inoculated outbred young adult hamsters with four different variants of SV40 and monitored viral DNA loads in various tissues from 3 to 270 days post-infection. The results showed that SV40 displayed a broad tissue tropism, infecting liver, kidney, spleen, lung, and brain tissues, with liver and kidney containing higher viral DNA loads. Kidneys were identified as the preferred site for long-term persistent infection, although detectable virus was also retained in livers. Expression of SV40 microRNA was demonstrated in wild-type SV40-infected tissues, and microRNA-negative mutant viruses consistently produced higher viral DNA loads than wild-type SV40 in both liver and kidney. The study also found that viruses with complex regulatory regions displayed modestly higher viral DNA loads in the kidney than those with simple regulatory regions. Early viral transcripts were detected at higher levels than late transcripts in liver and kidney, and infectious virus was detected infrequently. The study provides the first evidence of expression and function of SV40 microRNA in vivo and suggests that viral microRNA dampens viral DNA levels in tissues infected by SV40 strains with simple or complex regulatory regions. The results also indicate that SV40 microRNA does not appear to affect SV40 tumorigenicity in hamsters.
This study presents the most comprehensive genome-wide examination of positively selected genes (PSGs) in mammals to date, using six high-coverage genome assemblies of eutherian mammals. The increased phylogenetic depth of this dataset allows for improved statistical power and the application of new lineage- and clade-specific tests. Of approximately 16,500 human genes with high-confidence orthologs in at least two other species, 400 genes showed significant evidence of positive selection (FDR < 0.05) according to a standard likelihood ratio test. An additional 144 genes showed evidence of positive selection on particular lineages or clades. The identified PSGs were enriched for roles in defense/immunity, chemosensory perception, and reproduction, as well as more specific functions such as complement-mediated immunity and taste perception. Several pathways were strongly enriched for PSGs, suggesting possible co-evolution of interacting genes. A Bayesian analysis indicated that most PSGs have switched multiple times between positive selection and non-selection, suggesting that positive selection is often episodic. PSGs were found to be expressed at significantly lower levels and in a more tissue-specific manner than non-PSGs. Genes specifically expressed in the spleen, testes, liver, and breast were significantly enriched for PSGs, but no evidence was found for an enrichment of PSGs among brain-specific genes. This study provides additional evidence for widespread positive selection in mammalian evolution and new genome-wide insights into the functional implications of positive selection.
Staphylococcus aureus is an opportunistic pathogen that forms biofilms on skin and mucosal surfaces. Biofilms are surface-associated communities that contribute to persistent infections. Researchers have discovered a novel extracellular fibril structure composed of phenol soluble modulins ( PSMs ) that promotes S. aureus biofilm integrity. Biochemical and genetic analysis revealed that these fibers have amyloid-like properties and consist of small peptides called PSMs. Mutants unable to produce PSMs were susceptible to biofilm disassembly by matrix degrading enzymes and mechanical stress. In contrast, soluble PSM peptides disperse biofilms while polymerized peptides do not. This suggests that the aggregation of PSMs into amyloid fibers modulates their biological activity and role in biofilms. The fibers share morphological and biophysical characteristics with functional bacterial amyloids such as curli in Escherichia coli biofilms and TasA of Bacillus subtilis. Synthetic S. aureus PSM peptides can self-assemble into amyloid-like fibers in vitro, demonstrating CR and ThT binding capacities similar to known amyloid proteins. These findings implicate fibril formation as a means of altering PSM activity and function in the microenvironment of the biofilm. The discovery of amyloid-like fibers composed of PSMs provides new insights into the mechanisms of S. aureus biofilm formation and stability.
A novel antibody surrogate biomarker, Ab3, has been identified to monitor parasite persistence in Trypanosoma cruzi-infected patients. Chagas disease, caused by T. cruzi, affects approximately six million individuals in over 20 countries. Current methods for monitoring parasite persistence, such as PCR testing, have limitations due to the low and fluctuating parasitic load in circulating blood. A multiplex serology assay was designed to evaluate antibody diversity in 1654 serum samples from chronic Chagas patients. The assay consisted of an array of 15 optimized T. cruzi antigens. One specific antibody response, Ab3, showed a strong correlation with T. cruzi parasite persistence as determined by T. cruzi PCR positive results. High and sustained Ab3 signals were associated with PCR positivity in untreated patients, while significant decline in Ab3 signals was observed in benznidazole-treated patients who cleared parasitemia. Ab3 is a new surrogate biomarker that strongly correlates with parasite persistence in chronic and benznidazole-treated Chagas patients. It is hypothesized that Ab3 is induced and maintained by incessant stimulation of the immune system by tissue-based and shed parasites that are not consistently detectable by blood-based PCR techniques. A simple immunoassay measurement of Ab3 could be beneficial for monitoring the infectious status of seropositive patients.
A recombinant Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) that expresses Cre recombinase (CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre) has been developed to study the pathogenesis of CHIKV infection. CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre replicates in myoblasts and fibroblasts, inducing arthritis during the acute phase in mice. Importantly, it also induces chronic disease, including persistent viral RNA and chronic myositis and synovitis, similar to wild-type virus. Infection of tdTomato reporter mice with CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre results in a population of tdTomato+ cells that persist for at least 112 days. Immunofluorescence and flow cytometric profiling reveal that these cells predominantly consist of myofibers and dermal and muscle fibroblasts. Treatment with an antibody against Mxra8, a host receptor for CHIKV, reduces the number of tdTomato+ cells in the chronic phase and diminishes the levels of chronic viral RNA. Isolation and flow cytometry-based sorting of tdTomato+ fibroblasts from the skin and ankle reveal that these cells harbor most of the persistent CHIKV RNA at chronic time points. The CHIKV-3ʹ-Cre and tdTomato reporter mouse system identifies the cells that survive CHIKV infection in vivo and are enriched for persistent CHIKV RNA. This model represents a useful tool for studying CHIKV pathogenesis in the acute and chronic stages of disease.
Title: Scaling Properties of Dimensionality Reduction for Neural Populations and Network Models
    Abstract: Recent studies have applied dimensionality reduction methods to understand how the multi-dimensional structure of neural population activity gives rise to brain function. It is unclear, however, how the results obtained from dimensionality reduction generalize to recordings with larger numbers of neurons and trials or how these results relate to the underlying network structure. We address these questions by applying factor analysis to recordings in the visual cortex of non-human primates and to spiking network models that self-generate irregular activity through a balance of excitation and inhibition. We compared the scaling trends of two key outputs of dimensionality reduction—shared dimensionality and percent shared variance—with neuron and trial count. We found that the scaling properties of networks with non-clustered and clustered connectivity differed, and that the in vivo recordings were more consistent with the clustered network. Furthermore, recordings from tens of neurons were sufficient to identify the dominant modes of shared variability that generalize to larger portions of the network. These findings can help guide the interpretation of dimensionality reduction outputs in regimes of limited neuron and trial sampling and help relate these outputs to the underlying network structure.

The study reveals that the Pseudomonas aeruginosa quorum sensing-regulated molecule 2-amino acetophenone (2-AA) modulates host immune responses in a manner that increases host ability to cope with this pathogen. Mice treated with 2-AA prior to infection showed a 90% survival rate compared to 10% survival rate in non-pretreated infected mice. 2-AA stimulation activates key innate immune response pathways involving mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs), nuclear factor (NF)-κB, and pro-inflammatory cytokines, but attenuates immune response activation upon pretreatment by upregulating anti-inflammatory cytokines. The study found that 2-AA host pretreatment is characterized by a transcriptionally regulated block of c-JUN N-terminal kinase (JNK) and NF-κB activation, with relatively preserved activation of extracellular regulated kinase (ERK) 1/2. These kinase changes lead to CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein-β (c/EBPβ) activation and formation of the c/EBPβ-p65 complex that prevents NF-κB activation. The results suggest that 2-AA's ability to dampen inflammatory processes while increasing host survival and pathogen persistence concurs with its ability to signal bacteria to switch to a chronic infection mode. The study reveals a quorum sensing immunomodulatory signal that promotes original aspects of interkingdom communication, facilitating pathogen persistence while enabling host tolerance to infection.
The L1TD1 gene, derived from a LINE-1 (L1) retroelement, has been domesticated in mammals for its role in genome defense and pluripotency maintenance. The gene originated in the common ancestor of eutherian mammals, approximately 106 million years ago, and has been conserved in its bipartite double-ORF1p organization since its birth. However, L1TD1 has been lost or pseudogenized multiple times during mammalian evolution, suggesting that it has been recurrently selected for functional novelty. In primates and mice, L1TD1 has evolved under positive selection, and one prosimian L1TD1 has replenished itself with a more recent L1 ORF1 from the prosimian genome. The loss of L1TD1 is associated with L1 extinction in several megabat lineages, but not in sigmodontine rodents. This suggests that L1TD1 may have originally evolved for genome defense against L1 elements, and later became incorporated into pluripotency maintenance in some lineages. The study highlights the role of retroelement gene domestication in fundamental aspects of mammalian biology and demonstrates that domesticated genes can adopt different functions in different lineages. Genome-wide searches revealed that L1TD1 has been lost on at least three separate occasions during the evolution of placental mammals, indicating that its retention is not solely due to its role in pluripotency maintenance. Instead, idiosyncratic L1 insertion patterns in different mammalian genomes may provide an explanation for the retention of L1TD1 in mammals without an active L1.
The highly conserved bacterial protein YbeY has been identified as an essential endoribonuclease in Vibrio cholerae, a human pathogen responsible for cholera. YbeY plays critical roles in virulence, stress regulation, RNA processing, and ribosome quality control. In contrast to Escherichia coli, where YbeY is not essential, its loss in V. cholerae severely impairs the bacterium's ability to colonize mice, form biofilms, produce cholera toxin, and regulate virulence-associated small RNAs. Sucrose gradient analysis of V. cholerae ribosomes revealed that YbeY is the only RNase crucial for 3' processing of 16S rRNA and its assembly into 70S ribosomes.
