Depletion of YbeY in V. cholerae leads to the accumulation of 16S rRNA precursors and free ribosomal subunits, indicating its importance in ribosome quality control. A phylogenetic comparison showed that YbeY is part of a small set of RNases essential in most representative pathogens, highlighting its conserved function across species. Furthermore, the ybeY genes of several distantly related pathogens can complement an E. coli ΔybeY strain under various stress conditions, demonstrating the high conservation of YbeY's activity in stress regulation. Overall, this study provides the first comprehensive exploration of YbeY's physiological role in a human pathogen, underscoring its importance in essential cellular processes.
The study investigated the relationship between the topological properties of human transcription factor networks (TFNs) and the robustness of their gene expression phenotypes to genetic and environmental perturbations. The authors used publicly available DNaseI-seq data to measure the assortativity signatures of genome-wide TFNs in 41 distinct human cell and tissue types. They found that all TFNs share a common assortativity signature, which confers phenotypic robustness to model TFNs. The assortativity signature is a measure of the tendency of nodes with similar numbers of edges to connect, and it comprises four distinct components. The authors determined that each component of the assortativity signature contributes to the phenotypic robustness of TFNs. Theoretical work has shown that TFNs with increased assortativity exhibit increased robustness to mutations in cis-regulatory sites and gene duplication. The study suggests that degree assortativity provides an additional structural source of robustness in biological networks, and that human TFNs share an assortativity signature that confers such robustness. The findings have implications for the theoretical understanding of networked systems and highlight the importance of considering the assortativity signature in the study of biological regulatory networks.
The study investigated how populations of inhibitory (INH) and excitatory (EXC) neocortical neurons collectively encode stimulus-related information in the anesthetized adult rat somatosensory barrel cortex. Using large-scale multi-electrode arrays, the activity of up to 74 neurons in all layers of 3-4 neighboring cortical columns was simultaneously recorded in response to whisker stimuli varying in location and frequency. The results showed that individual INH neurons discriminated better between restricted sets of stimuli than EXC neurons in granular and infra-granular layers. Furthermore, ensembles of INH cells provided as much information about the stimuli as comparable ensembles containing the most informative EXC neurons, but with less information redundancy. This suggests that a consortium of INH neurons dominates the information conveyed to the neocortical network, efficiently processing incoming sensory activity. The study found a higher level of stimulus-related information in both individual and groups of INH neurons compared to their EXC counterparts in granular and infra-granular layers, indicating a sharper tuning of their temporally-precise responses to different stimuli. The results propose that INH cell ensembles have a lower amount of redundancy compared to comparable ensembles containing the best EXC cells, and that L4 INH neurons convey more information about the different stimulus modalities than L4 EXC neurons due to their higher number of spikes per stimulus, higher precision, and lower adaptation at higher frequency stimulation.
The article reports the engineering of a genetic half adder in Escherichia coli based on de novo riboregulation to sum two bits of information encoded in molecular concentrations. The system exploits post-transcriptional control to switch on tightly silenced genes with small RNAs and allosteric transcription factors to sense the molecular signals. The designer circuit robustly performs the intended computation in a living cell, encoding the result as fluorescence amplitudes. This work demonstrates that regulatory RNAs can be key players in synthetic biology and paves the way for engineering more complex RNA-based biocomputers using this designer circuit as a building block. Unlike previous genetic half adders, the reporter gene conveying the sum is not duplicated, making the architecture better organized and more scalable. The genetic footprint of the designer circuit was also greatly reduced due to the use of regulatory RNAs compared to circuits fully implemented with transcription factors. The system is based on riboregulators of translation initiation and exploits the functional versatility and model-based designability of RNA at the nucleotide level. This work highlights the potential of RNA as an ideal substrate for engineering gene expression programs that robustly run in vivo. The designer circuit can be used as a building block for more complex RNA-based biocomputers and demonstrates the importance of regulatory RNAs in synthetic biology.
Cytosolic 5′-nucleotidase II (cN-II) plays a crucial role in regulating intracellular nucleotide pools by catalyzing the dephosphorylation of 6-hydroxypurine nucleoside 5′-monophosphates. However, high levels of cN-II expression have been correlated with poor patient outcomes in cancer therapy. To investigate the role of cN-II in resistance to cytotoxic nucleoside analogues, a class of chemical compounds called ribonucleoside phosphonates was screened as potential inhibitors. These compounds feature a chemically and enzymatically stable phosphorus-carbon linkage instead of the regular phosphoester bond. Six phosphonate analogues were identified as better ligands than the natural substrate, inosine 5′-monophosphate (IMP). The binding strength of these compounds was analyzed in silico and found to be influenced by van der Waals contacts with three cN-II residues: Phe 157, His 209, and Tyr 210. Experimental measurements confirmed that the three best phosphonate analogues induced a total inhibition of cN-II activity at 2 mM. The study highlights the importance of the non-hydrolysable phosphonate bond in the design of new competitive cN-II inhibitors and the crucial role of hydrophobic stacking promoted by the three protein residues. The results suggest that nucleoside phosphonate derivatives represent a class of compounds that efficiently mimic nucleoside 5′-monophosphates and may serve as powerful cN-II inhibitors.
A recent study investigated the presence of prions in milk from ewes incubating natural scrapie, a transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE) affecting ruminants. Contrary to previous findings, the study detected consistent levels of prion infectivity in colostrum and milk from scrapie-affected ewes several months prior to clinical onset. Immunohistochemistry and PET blot analysis revealed abnormal prion protein (PrPSc) accumulation in lacteal ducts and mammary acini, particularly in ewes with mammary ectopic lymphoid follicles resulting from Maedi lentivirus infection. However, prion infectivity was also detected in milk and colostrum from ewes with lesion-free mammary glands. Bioassay revealed that infectivity was present in all tested fractions of milk and colostrum, including cellular, cream, and casein-whey fractions. The highest infectious titre measured in milk and colostrum was equivalent to that contained in 6 µg of a posterior brain stem from a terminally scrapie-affected ewe. These findings suggest that both colostrum and milk from small ruminants incubating TSE could contribute to animal TSE transmission, either directly or through the presence of milk-derived material in animal feedstuffs. The study raises concerns about the risk of TSE exposure associated with milk products from ovine and other TSE-susceptible dairy species.
During the 2014-2015 Ebola virus disease (EVD) outbreak in Liberia, a total of 16,370 laboratory samples were tested between April 4, 2014, and March 29, 2015. Of these, 10,536 individuals were identified, with 3,897 confirmed cases (positive for Ebola virus RNA). The analysis revealed significant differences in sex, age, and place of residence between confirmed and suspected cases that tested negative for Ebola virus RNA. Young children and the elderly, as well as individuals residing in rural areas, were found to be at higher risk of death due to the disease. The case fatality rate of confirmed cases decreased from 80% to 63% during the study period. The data were collected and managed by EVD diagnostic laboratories, which were able to systematically register basic demographic and clinical information of patients. However, surveillance and reporting systems malfunctioned during the outbreak, resulting in inadequate data management, including missing and duplicate data. The findings of this study may contribute to a fuller understanding of the outbreak in Liberia and support future investigations. The data were collected as part of the Ebola public health response in Liberia and were not anonymized, as they were not collected for research purposes.
Tyrosinase (EC 1.14.18.1) is a copper-containing monooxygenase that catalyzes the conversion of phenol to the corresponding ortho-quinone. The enzyme is generated as a complex with a “caddie” protein that facilitates the transport of two copper ions into the active center. In a previous study, the Tyr98 residue in the caddie protein was found to be converted to a reactive quinone through the formation of μ-η2:η2-peroxo-dicopper(II) and Cu(II)-dopasemiquinone intermediates. To elucidate the catalytic mechanism of tyrosinase, cryo-trapped crystal structures were determined at high resolutions (1.16-1.70 Å). The structures revealed an important step in the tyrosinase reaction: the hydroxylation reaction is triggered by the movement of CuA, which induces the syn-to-anti rearrangement of the copper ligands after the formation of μ-η2:η2-peroxo-dicopper(II) core. This rearrangement places the hydroxyl group of the substrate in an equatorial position, allowing electrophilic attack by the Cu2O2 oxidant. UV-vis and resonance Raman spectroscopic analyses confirmed the formation of the μ-η2:η2-peroxo-dicopper(II) and Cu(II)-dopasemiquinone intermediates. The study proposes a catalytic mechanism of tyrosinase toward the caddie Tyr98 residue, in which the coordination preference determined by the oxidation state of copper and the protonation state triggers the generation of reaction intermediates. The binding position of the caddie Tyr98 residue may differ from that of a genuine substrate.
The Npa1p complex plays a crucial role in the assembly of the earliest eukaryotic large ribosomal subunit precursor. The first specific precursor to the yeast large ribosomal subunit, the first pre-60S particle, contains 30 assembly factors ( AFs ), including 8 RNA helicases. One of these helicases, Dbp6p, is essential for the normal accumulation of the first pre-60S pre-ribosomal particle in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The Dbp6p helicase associates with a complex of four AFs, namely Npa1p, Npa2p, Nop8p, and Rsa3p, prior to their incorporation into the 90S pre-ribosomal particles. Npa1p forms the backbone of this complex and is essential for the stable integration of Dbp6p within the initial 90S pre-ribosomal particle. The Npa1p complex is necessary not only for the stable integration of the Dbp6p helicase at the correct site within 90S pre-ribosomal particles but also for the modulation of its enzymatic activities. In vivo cross-linking analysis revealed that Npa1p binds to 25S rRNA adjacent to the root helices of the first and last secondary structure domains of 25S rRNA, suggesting that Npa1p and Dbp6p function in the formation and/or clustering of root helices of large subunit rRNAs. The Npa1p complex also cross-links to snoRNAs involved in decoding center and peptidyl transferase center modifications and in the immediate vicinity of the binding sites of these snoRNAs on 25S rRNA. These findings suggest that the Dbp6p helicase and the Npa1p complex play key roles in the compaction of the central core of 25S rRNA and the control of snoRNA-pre-rRNA interactions.
The present study investigated the role of catecholamines in learning rate regulation in a dynamic environment. Catecholamines, including norepinephrine and dopamine, are neuromodulators that have been implicated in various cognitive processes, but their involvement in learning rate regulation remains poorly understood. The study employed a predictive-inference task to examine the relationship between catecholamine activity and learning rate in 32 participants. The results showed that the P3 component of the EEG, an electrophysiological index of phasic catecholamine release in the cortex, predicted learning rate and formally mediated the effect of prediction-error magnitude on learning rate. Furthermore, P3 amplitude also mediated the effects of unexpectedness of an outcome and uncertainty of a preexisting belief on learning rate. A pharmacological manipulation of catecholamine activity affected learning rate following unanticipated task changes, in a way that depended on participants’ baseline learning rate. These findings provide converging evidence for a causal role of the human catecholamine systems in learning-rate regulation as a function of environmental change. The study suggests that the phasic catecholamine response following surprising outcomes drives subsequent increases in learning rate, and that the catecholamine systems are involved in incorporating new unexpected observations into beliefs about the causal structure of the environment.
A syndromic surveillance system called EPIMIC was implemented in two rural villages in Senegal to monitor infectious diseases using data from Point-Of-Care (POC) laboratories. From 2010 to 2016, two POC laboratories were established in the Saloum region of Senegal, and a homemade syndromic surveillance system, EPIMIC, was implemented to monitor infectious diseases using data from the POC laboratory of the Timone hospital in Marseille, France. The study aimed to describe the implementation of EPIMIC using data from two POC laboratories in rural Senegal. Over five years, 2,577 patients-samples couples from 775 different patients were tested in the Dielmo and Ndiop POC laboratories, with 739 patients-samples couples found to be positive for at least one of the tested pathogens. The retrospective analysis of the data with EPIMIC generated 443 alarms. In the Niakhar POC laboratory, 316 patients-samples couples from 298 different patients were processed, with 56 patients-samples couples found to be positive for at least one of the tested pathogens. The retrospective analysis of the data with EPIMIC generated 14 alarms. EPIMIC was successfully implemented in rural Senegal using data from two POC laboratories, demonstrating its scalability and versatility. The system detected numerous true epidemiological events without requiring heavy human and economic resources. EPIMIC's main asset is its ability to survey 27 POC tests for 15 pathogens in near real-time. Further improvements are needed to enhance the EPIMIC syndromic surveillance network.
The study investigated the role of cellular architecture in collective calcium signaling and cell contractility in endothelial cells. Using a combination of computational modeling and plasma lithography micropatterning, the researchers found that endothelial cells in self-assembled and microengineered networks exhibited calcium oscillations in response to histamine stimulation, whereas individual cells and monolayers did not. The calcium oscillation was found to depend on the number of neighboring cells coupled via gap junctional intercellular communication. This suggests that endothelial cells can sense and respond to chemical stimuli according to the vascular architecture via collective calcium signaling. The study also found that the calcium oscillation attenuated histamine-induced cytoskeletal reorganization and cell contraction, resulting in differential cell responses in an architecture-dependent manner. Computational modeling revealed that the intracellular calcium dynamics driven by calcium-induced calcium release were highly sensitive to the cytosolic calcium concentration, and that the membrane potential and coupling current created oscillations in coupled cells. These findings provide a mechanistic basis for the architecture-dependent calcium signaling in endothelial cells and highlight the importance of cellular architecture in regulating collective calcium signaling and cell contractility. The study's results have implications for understanding the functional implications of diverse vascular structures in response to external stimuli.
Respiratory syncytial virus ( RSV ) is a major cause of lower respiratory tract disease in infants. Previous studies have elucidated the antibody repertoire following primary RSV infection in infants using whole genome-fragment phage display libraries ( GFPDL ). These libraries expressed linear and conformational epitopes from RSV that bound 100-fold more phages within the attachment protein ( G ) following primary RSV infection. The G-reactive epitopes spanned the N- and C-termini of G ectodomain, in addition to the central conserved domain ( CCD ). This study examined the contribution of antigenic regions of G outside of the CCD to RSV-specific immunity. The immunogenicity, neutralization, and protective efficacy of all RSV-G antigenic sites identified following primary RSV infection were evaluated using recombinant E. coli expressed G ectodomain ( REG ), CCD-deleted G ectodomain ( REG ΔCCD ), N- and C-terminal G subdomains, and antigenic site peptides. The results showed that REG ΔCCD, N- and C-terminal subdomains, and peptides generated antibody titers in rabbits and mice that bound fully glycosylated Recombinant Mammalian expressed G ectodomain ( RMG ) and intact RSV virion particles, but minimal in vitro neutralization titers compared with the intact G ectodomain. Vaccinated mice were challenged intranasally with RSV-A2 Line 19F, and viral replication in nasal cavity and lungs was significantly reduced in vaccinated animals compared to unimmunized controls. Control of viral loads post-RSV challenge correlated with serum antibody binding to the virus particles. These data demonstrate the presence of multiple protective sites in RSV G protein outside of the CCD that could contribute to the development of a bacterially produced unglycosylated G protein as a safe and protective vaccine against RSV disease.
This study investigates the role of the splicing component brr2 in the specification of Drosophila neuropeptidergic neurons, specifically the Tv4 neurons of the ventral nerve cord. The Tv4 neurons receive a target-derived BMP signal from their target cells, which acts as the final trigger to activate the FMRFa gene. A genetic screen identified brr2 as one of the genes involved in Tv4 specification, along with Prp8, another component of the U5 subunit of the spliceosome. The study found that brr2 and Prp8 play crucial roles in controlling the expression of the FMRFa neuropeptide specifically in six neurons of the VNC ( Tv4 neurons ). Detailed analysis revealed that brr2 controls the activation of the BMP retrograde signaling pathway in Tv4 neurons through two independent mechanisms: proper axonal pathfinding to receive the BMP ligand and proper RNA splicing of two genes in the BMP pathway, tkv and Medea. The study also found that brr2 is involved in three different steps necessary for Tv4 neuron specification: axon pathfinding, Dimm expression, and activation of the BMP signaling pathway. The results suggest that brr2 plays a cell-specific role in controlling the specification of the neuropeptidergic identity of the Tv4 neuron in the embryonic Drosophila Central Nervous System. This study provides new insights into the molecular genetic aspects of retrograde instructive signals during nervous system development and highlights the importance of RNA processing in diversifying neuronal identity within the central nervous system.
The regulation of substrate receptor subunits of Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligases (CRLs) is crucial for maintaining the full repertoire of CRLs, as unbalanced levels can lead to sequestration of CRL core components by a few overabundant substrate receptors. A novel pathway for regulating F-box protein abundance has been identified, which targets F-box proteins that are dissociated from Skp1. This pathway involves the SCF core components Cdc53 and Rbx1, as well as the cognate SCF ubiquitin conjugating enzyme Cdc34. Notably, this ubiquitylation pathway is independent of Skp1, suggesting a function of Cdc53/Cul1 that is independent from association with Skp1. The ‘Skp1-free’ F-box protein degradation pathway is critical for chromosome stability and effective defense against heavy metal stress. This pathway specifically targets Met30, the substrate adaptor for SCFMet30 ubiquitin ligase, which negatively regulates transcription factor Met4 by proteolysis-independent ubiquitylation. The identification of this novel pathway highlights the complexity of CRL regulation and assigns important biological functions to a sub-complex of cullin-RING ligases that comprises Cdc53/Rbx1/Cdc34, but is independent of Skp1. These findings provide new insights into the regulation of F-box protein abundance and the role of Cdc53/Cul1 in maintaining cellular homeostasis.
Mammalian Kinesin-3 Motors Are Dimeric In Vivo and Move by Processive Motility upon Release of Autoinhibition. Kinesin-3 motors, such as KIF1A, drive the transport of synaptic vesicles and other membrane-bound organelles in neuronal cells. Previous models suggested that KIF1A is monomeric in the inactive state and is activated by concentration-driven dimerization on the cargo membrane. However, this study found that both native and expressed KIF1A proteins are dimeric in the inactive state, contradicting the cargo-induced dimerization model. Instead, KIF1A motors are autoinhibited by two distinct inhibitory mechanisms, which can be released upon cargo binding. Successive truncations of KIF1A resulted in monomeric and dimeric motors that can undergo one-dimensional diffusion along the microtubule lattice, but only dimeric motors undergo ATP-dependent processive motility. The study shows that dimeric KIF1A motors move smoothly and unidirectionally along microtubules with an average velocity comparable to vesicles moving in vivo. The findings suggest that KIF1A may use both diffuse and processive motility to drive long-distance transport in neuronal cells. The results have implications for understanding how kinesin motors are regulated to enable transport of the correct cargo to the proper cellular destination at the relevant time.
Metabolic profiling and network analysis were applied to 76 tomato introgression lines (ILs) grown in two consecutive harvest seasons to investigate the regulation of seed metabolism and estimate the degree of metabolic natural variability. Factorial ANOVA confirmed the presence of 30 metabolite quantitative trait loci (mQTL). Amino acid contents displayed a high degree of variability across the population, with similar patterns across the two seasons, while sugars exhibited significant seasonal fluctuations. Integration of data for tomato pericarp metabolite profiling revealed that the main factor for metabolic polymorphism was the genotypic background rather than the environment or tissue. Analysis of the coefficient of variance indicated greater phenotypic plasticity in the ILs than in the M82 tomato cultivar. Broad-sense estimate of heritability suggested that the mode of inheritance of metabolite traits in the seed differed from that in the fruit. Correlation-based metabolic network analysis comparing metabolite data for the seed with that for the pericarp showed that the seed network displayed tighter interdependence of metabolic processes than the fruit. Amino acids in the seed metabolic network played a central hub-like role, maintaining high interactions with other metabolite categories. Network analysis identified six exceptionally highly co-regulated amino acids: Gly, Ser, Thr, Ile, Val, and Pro. These results reflect the extensive redundancy of the regulation underlying seed metabolism, demonstrate the tight coordination of seed metabolism with respect to fruit metabolism, and emphasize the centrality of the amino acid module in the seed metabolic network. The study highlights the added value of integrating metabolic network analysis with mQTL mapping.
The N-acetylglucosamine binding protein GbpA plays a crucial role in the colonization of Vibrio cholerae to both chitinous exoskeletons of zooplankton and the human gastrointestinal tract. GbpA has been reported to mediate bacterial attachment to marine chitin and mammalian intestinal mucin, but the molecular mechanism behind this interaction was unknown. Structural studies revealed that GbpA possesses an elongated four-domain structure, with domains 1 and 4 showing structural homology to chitin binding domains. A glycan screen demonstrated that GbpA binds to GlcNAc oligosaccharides, and structure-guided GbpA truncation mutants showed that domains 1 and 4 interact with chitin in vitro. In vivo complementation studies revealed that domain 1 is also crucial for mucin binding and intestinal colonization. Bacterial binding studies showed that domains 2 and 3 bind to the V. cholerae surface. Mouse virulence assays demonstrated that only the first three domains of GbpA are required for colonization. These findings explain how GbpA provides structural/functional modular interactions between V. cholerae, intestinal epithelium, and chitinous exoskeletons. The study provides new insights into the molecular properties governing GbpA's ability to mediate interactions between the bacteria and host surfaces in both marine and mammalian environments.
In a study on pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB), researchers investigated the mechanisms underlying chronic T cell activation, a hallmark of the disease. They found that circulating natural regulatory T cells (Treg) in adults with PTB preserve their suppressive potential, but T effector cells (Teff) from these subjects are resistant to Treg-mediated suppression. This resistance was attributed to the expansion of an activated Teff subset identified by Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA)-DR expression. Depletion of this subset restored sensitivity to suppression to control levels. Comparative transcriptome analysis revealed putative resistance mechanisms linked to IFNG, IL17A, IL22, PD-L1, and β-chemokines CCL3L3, CCL4 expression. Antibody blocking experiments confirmed that HLA-DR+ Teff cells, but not the fraction depleted of HLA-DR+ effectors, are resistant to Treg suppression mediated via CCR5 and PD-L1 associated pathways. Furthermore, HLA-DR+ Teff cells expressed significantly higher levels of Th1/Th17 cytokines, which may regulate Treg function through a reciprocal counter-balancing relationship. These findings provide novel insight into how activated HLA-DR+CD4+ T cells may contribute to disease-associated inflammation by compromising Treg-mediated suppression in PTB. The study identifies HLA-DR+ Teff cells resistant to Treg suppression as a potential functional marker of disease, with implications for disease monitoring and response to therapy.
The study investigated the propagation of RML prions in mice expressing PrPC devoid of a GPI anchor (tgGPI- mice). These mice are susceptible to prion infection but accumulate anchorless PrPSc outside the cell, rather than intracellularly. The researchers found that RML and ME7 prions, but not 22L prions, propagated in tgGPI- mice developed novel cell tropisms, as determined by the Cell Panel Assay (CPA). Surprisingly, the levels of proteinase K-resistant PrPSc (PrPres) in RML- or ME7-infected tgGPI- brain were 25-50 times higher than in wild-type brain. When returned to wild-type brain, ME7 prions recovered their original properties, but RML prions gave rise to a novel prion strain, designated SFL, which remained unchanged even after three passages in wild-type mice. This suggests that the two conformations are separated by a high activation energy barrier that is abrogated in tgGPI- mice. The study also found that RML prions from wild-type brain propagated in tgGPI- mice gave rise to a GPI-PrPSc conformer that adapted to the environment and, when transferred to wild-type mice, stably maintained a novel conformation of wild-type PrPSc, distinct from the original RML.
The BMP signaling pathway plays a conserved role in dorsal-ventral axis patterning during embryonic development in Drosophila. Graded BMP signaling is transduced by the Mad transcription factor and opposed by the Brinker repressor. Using a combination of RNA-seq and Mad and Brinker ChIP-seq, the study identifies multiple new BMP target genes, including positive and negative regulators of EGF signaling. EGF signaling is found to negatively regulate embryonic BMP-responsive transcription. The BMP gene network has a self-regulating property, establishing a balance between its activity and that of the antagonistic EGF signaling pathway to facilitate correct patterning. The study also identifies key roles for the Zelda and Zerknüllt transcription factors in establishing the resulting expression domain and widespread binding of insulator proteins to the Mad and Brinker-bound genomic regions. Analysis of embryos lacking the BEAF-32 insulator protein shows reduced transcription of a peak BMP target gene and a reduction in the number of amnioserosa cells, the fate specified by peak BMP signaling. The findings are incorporated into a model for Mad-dependent activation and discussed in relation to BMP signal interpretation in vertebrates. The study provides new insights into the transcriptional responses downstream of the major developmental BMP signaling pathway in the Drosophila embryo, shedding light on the complex interplay between BMP and EGF signaling during dorsal-ventral axis patterning.
In Tunisia, the incidence of zoonotic cutaneous leishmaniasis (ZCL) caused by Leishmania major has been increasing and spreading from the south-west to new areas in the center. To better understand the evolution and population dynamics of L. major, researchers conducted a multi-locus microsatellite typing of human isolates from three endemic governorates (Gafsa, Kairouan, and Sidi Bouzid) collected over two periods: 1991-1992 and 2008-2012. Analysis of the genotyping results showed that L. major populations in Sidi Bouzid evolved over two decades, generating genetically differentiated populations. The genetic patterns of 2008-2012 isolates from the three governorates suggest that L. major populations did not spread gradually from the south to the center of Tunisia, contradicting a geographical gradient. Instead, human activities may be the source of the disease expansion. The study also found previous and current flows of genotypes between governorates and districts, which could be attributed to human activities, reservoir dynamics, and environmental changes. The findings provide new insights into the evolution and spread of L. major in Tunisia, which may improve understanding of parasite flow between geographically and temporally distinct populations.
The study evaluated the effectiveness of anthelmintic chemotherapy and water, sanitation, and hygiene ( WASH ) interventions in reducing helminth infections among HIV-infected adults in Kenya. A cohort study nested within a randomized trial of empiric deworming found that repeated treatment with albendazole and praziquantel significantly reduced the odds of infection with any soil-transmitted helminth ( STH ) species. The odds of infection with any STH species were lower for individuals treated with albendazole ( adjusted odds ratio ( aOR ) : 0. 11, 95% confidence interval ( CI ) : 0. 05, 0. 20, p < 0. 001 ), adjusting for age and sex. While most WASH conditions showed minimal additional benefit in reducing the probability of infection with any STH species, access to safe flooring appeared to offer some additional protection ( aOR : 0. 34, 95% CI : 0. 20, 0. 56, p < 0. 001 ). For schistosomiasis, only treatment with praziquantel was protective ( aOR : 0. 30, 95% CI : 0. 14, 0. 60, p = 0. 001 ). Among individuals not treated with albendazole or praziquantel, the most protective intervention package included safe flooring ( aOR : 0. 34, 95% CI : 0. 20, 0. 59, p < 0. 001 ) and latrine access ( aOR : 0. 59, 95% CI : 0. 35, 0. 99, p = 0. 05 ). There was no evidence of synergy or antagonism between anthelmintic chemotherapy and WASH resources.
The crystal structure of LlpABW, a lectin-like bacteriocin from Pseudomonas putida, has been elucidated, revealing an architecture of two monocot mannose-binding lectin (MMBL) domains and a C-terminal β-hairpin extension. The C-terminal MMBL domain (C-domain) adopts a fold similar to MMBL domains from plant lectins and contains a binding site for mannose and oligomannosides. Mutational analysis indicates that an intact sugar-binding pocket in this domain is crucial for bactericidal activity. In contrast, the N-terminal MMBL domain (N-domain) adopts the same fold but is structurally more divergent and lacks a functional mannose-binding site. Engineered N/C-domain chimeras derived from two LlpA homologues with different killing spectra suggest that the N-domain determines target specificity. The bacteriocin is assembled from two structurally similar domains that evolved separately towards dedicated functions in target recognition and bacteriotoxicity. LlpABW is the first prokaryotic member of the MMBL lectin family, which is typically associated with eukaryotic proteins involved in general defense mechanisms. The N-domain appears to play a major role in target selection, while the C-domain is essential for bactericidal activity. The bacteriocin's activity is not impaired in the presence of excess mannose, suggesting that mannose-containing carbohydrates may not be the natural ligand required for biological activity.
During the sporulation process in Bacillus subtilis, a novel secretion apparatus plays a crucial role in maintaining the integrity and developmental gene expression of the forespore. This apparatus is composed of eight mother-cell proteins encoded in the spoIIIA operon and the forespore protein SpoIIQ, which form a multimeric complex spanning the two membranes surrounding the forespore. The SpoIIIA proteins share similarity with components of specialized secretion systems, including type II and IV secretion systems, and the conserved ATPase motifs in SpoIIIAA are required for σG activity and spore formation. The SpoIIIA-SpoIIQ complex is essential for maintaining forespore integrity, as its absence leads to large invaginations and collapse of the forespore. Notably, the maintenance of forespore integrity does not require σG activity, indicating that forespore collapse is not a result of the failure to activate σG. The findings suggest that the SpoIIIA-SpoIIQ complex forms a novel secretion apparatus that links the mother cell and forespore, allowing the mother cell to nurture the forespore and maintain its physiology during spore maturation. This apparatus appears to have been assembled from components of various specialized secretion systems found in Gram-negative bacteria. The discovery of this novel secretion apparatus provides new insights into the complex process of sporulation in Bacillus subtilis.
A genome-wide association study (GWAS) of 2,191 bipolar disorder (BD) cases and 1,434 controls was conducted to identify genetic variants associated with the disease. The study did not detect genome-wide significant associations for individual loci, but found an association between the power to detect effects calculated from a previous GWAS and evidence for replication (P=1.5×10−7). This suggests that there is likely common genetic variation associated with BD near exons (±10 kb) that could be identified in larger studies. The study also found that SNPs near exons exhibit a greater probability of replication, supporting an enrichment of reproducible associations near functional regions of genes. A meta-analysis of height data showed that, in a large enough study, associations replicate as a function of power, approaching a linear relationship. These results provide a framework for assessing the potential for replication when combining results from multiple studies. Bipolar disorder is a major psychiatric disorder affecting approximately 1% of the population, characterized by extreme mood swings between mania and depression, and has a high heritability but has not easily yielded genetic loci from family and population-based mapping strategies. Multiple GWAS have highlighted compelling candidates for BD without reaching genome-wide significance. The study's findings suggest that larger studies may be able to identify genetic signals in circumscribed regions of the genome that would not be captured by single locus analyses in a single GWAS data set at genome-wide significance levels.
Title: A Genome-Wide Systematic Analysis Reveals Different and Predictive Proliferation Expression Signatures of Cancerous vs. Non-Cancerous Cells

    A genome-wide analysis of 12690 genes across 60 cancer cell lines was conducted to identify genes and cellular processes associated with cancer proliferation. The Cancer Proliferation Index (cPI) was used to quantify the association between gene expression levels and growth rate measurements. Genes found essential in cancer gene knockdown screens exhibited significant positive cPI values, while tumor suppressors showed significant negative cPI values. Cell cycle, DNA replication, splicing, and protein production-related processes were positively associated with cancer proliferation, while cellular migration was negatively associated with it.

    A parallel analysis of non-cancerous proliferation indices (nPI) across 224 lymphoblastoid cell lines revealed marked differences between cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation. Genes in the translation and spliceosome machineries were identified as selective cancer proliferation-associated proteins. A cross-species comparison revealed that cancer proliferation resembles that of microorganisms, while non-cancerous proliferation does not. Combining cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation signatures led to enhanced prediction of patient outcome and gene essentiality in cancer.

    The study identified 200 genes with the highest dPI values, which were enriched in genes belonging to the translation and spliceosome machineries. Cancer-related genes, including tumor suppressors and oncogenes, exhibited higher absolute cPI values. Tumor suppressor genes showed significantly lower and negative cPI values, indicating that their decreased functionality may enhance cellular proliferation. The results provide insights into the inherent differences between cancerous and non-cancerous proliferation determinants, which may contribute to the development of novel cancer-specific anti-proliferative drugs.
A retrospective case series of 11 patients with cardiac and/or endovascular cystic echinococcosis (CE) was conducted over a 15-year period (1995–2009). The main clinical manifestations included thoracic pain or dyspnea, although two patients were asymptomatic. Cysts were primarily located in the right atrium and inferior vena cava. Nine patients had previously been diagnosed with disseminated CE. Echocardiography was the primary diagnostic method, supplemented by serology, electrocardiogram, chest X-ray, computed tomography/magnetic resonance imaging, and histology. Nine patients underwent cardiac surgery, and nine received long-term antiparasitic treatment for a median duration of 25 months. One patient died intra-operatively due to cyst rupture and endovascular dissemination, while two patients died 10 and 14 years after diagnosis due to pulmonary embolism and cardiac failure, respectively. Patients with cardiac involvement exclusively did not experience complications after surgery and were considered cured, whereas those with vena cava involvement developed pulmonary embolisms and presented multiple complications. Cardiovascular CE is associated with a high risk of potentially lethal complications, and clinical manifestations and complications vary according to cyst location. Isolated cardiac CE may be cured after surgery, whereas endovascular extracardiac involvement is associated with severe chronic complications. CE should be included in the differential diagnosis of cardiovascular disease in patients from endemic areas.
The study investigated the role of TirS, a Toll/interleukin-1 receptor (TIR) mimic in Staphylococcus aureus, in modulating virulence and antimicrobial susceptibility. Ectopic expression of TirS in eukaryotic cells inhibited TLR signaling, downregulating the NF-kB pathway through inhibition of TLR2, TLR4, TLR5, and TLR9. In a mouse model of S. aureus skin infection, skin lesions induced by a tirS mutant strain increased compared to wild-type and restored strains, despite similar bacterial loads. TirS was associated with lower neutrophil and macrophage activity, indicating a central role in virulence attenuation through local inflammatory responses. TirS localized within staphylococcal chromosomal cassettes (SCC) containing the fusC gene for fusidic acid resistance but not always carrying the mecA gene. Sub-inhibitory concentrations of fusidic acid increased tirS expression. Epidemiological studies found no link between TirS and clinical presentation but showed a selective advantage with a SCCmec element containing SCC fusC/tirS. The study suggests that TirS modulates an inflammatory response at the site of infection through the MyD88 adaptor protein, and its expression is linked to fusidic acid resistance. The findings indicate that TirS plays a key role in S. aureus virulence and antimicrobial susceptibility, and its interaction with MyD88 may be a potential target for therapeutic intervention.
The study analyzed transcriptional datasets from Drosophila melanogaster (fruit fly) and Anopheles gambiae (malaria mosquito) to identify whole-genome changes in gene expression underlying differences in their embryonic morphologies. The researchers found that many orthologous gene pairs could be clustered based on coincident discordances in their temporal expression profiles. One such cluster contained genes specifically expressed in the mosquito serosa, which is an extra-embryonic tissue. This cluster was also found to be redeployed later in development at the time of cuticle synthesis. Additionally, a striking difference was observed in the temporal expression of a subset of maternal genes. In Drosophila, these genes exhibited a sharp reduction at the maternal-zygotic transition, whereas in Anopheles, they displayed sustained expression. The study proposes that gene clustering by local temporal discordance can be used to identify the gene batteries underlying morphological diversity. The researchers used a computational framework to align and compare transcriptional datasets from the two species, revealing distinctive patterning properties in Dipteran embryos, including the organization of extra-embryonic tissues and the maternal-zygotic transition. The findings suggest that this approach can be used for the de novo identification of functional gene sets from comparative datasets.
A cross-sectional study was conducted in rural villages of Lihir Island, Papua New Guinea, to investigate the presence of Haemophilus ducreyi and Treponema pallidum subsp. pertenue DNA in asymptomatic individuals, flies, and household linens. The study found that 21% of asymptomatic participants had detectable H. ducreyi DNA on their skin, with no significant difference in positivity rates between those exposed or not exposed to a case of H. ducreyi ulcer in the household. Additionally, 90% of flies tested had H. ducreyi DNA, and 50% had T. p. pertenue DNA. Furthermore, 33% of bed sheets sampled had H. ducreyi DNA, and 17% had T. p. pertenue DNA. This study is the first to demonstrate the presence of H. ducreyi DNA and colonization on the skin of asymptomatic children and the presence of H. ducreyi DNA and T. p. pertenue DNA in flies and on fomites. The ubiquity of H. ducreyi in the environment is a contributing factor to the spread of the organism. The study also found that asymptomatic children living in H. ducreyi-endemic communities had detectable H. ducreyi DNA on their skin, with no evidence of cutaneous ulceration or other symptoms. Notably, people from households without an ulcer case had positivity rates similar to those with an H. ducreyi ulcer case in the household.
The International Society of Computational Biology (ISCB) Education Committee’s Curriculum Task Force has developed a set of bioinformatics core competencies to provide a framework for training needs and curricula across various user personas and training programs. These competencies were initially developed through surveys of employers and training programs and have since been refined through a multiyear process of community engagement. The core competencies aim to assist educators in sharing experiences and identifying best practices for bioinformatics education despite divergent needs and expectations. A series of use cases illustrates the application of the competencies in diverse training contexts, demonstrating their value in defining, refining, or assessing bioinformatics training mechanisms. These use cases highlight a range of training needs, user personas, types of training programs, and educational settings. The competencies are not intended to be a prescription for a specific set of curricula or curricular standards, but rather a basis for the community of bioinformatics educators to draw upon their common experiences in designing, refining, and evaluating their own training programs. The core competencies provide a foundation for bioinformatics training and education, enabling educators to tailor their programs to meet the needs of various user groups, including researchers, clinicians, and students. The ISCB Education Committee continues to refine and apply the core competencies to improve bioinformatics training and education globally.
The parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercoralis has a unique life cycle that includes both parasitic and free-living forms, which can be leveraged to investigate the mechanisms of its developmentally arrested third-stage larva ( L3i ). Unlike other parasitic nematodes, S. stercoralis has a similar developmentally arrested larval form, the dauer, whose formation is controlled by four pathways in the free-living nematode Caenorhabditis elegans : cyclic GMP ( cGMP ) signaling, insulin/IGF-1-like signaling ( IIS ), transforming growth factor β ( TGFβ ) signaling, and biosynthesis of dafachronic acid ( DA ) ligands. The authors hypothesized that homologous pathways are present in S. stercoralis, have similar developmental regulation, and are involved in L3i arrest and activation. A deep-sequencing study of the polyadenylated transcriptome generated over 2. 3 billion paired-end reads from seven developmental stages of S. stercoralis. The results showed that genes encoding cGMP pathway components were coordinately up-regulated in L3i, while S. stercoralis has a paucity of genes encoding IIS ligands. Seven S. stercoralis genes encoding homologs of the single C. elegans dauer regulatory TGFβ ligand were identified, three of which are only expressed in L3i. Putative DA biosynthetic genes did not appear to be coordinately regulated in L3i development. The data suggest that while dauer pathway genes are present in S. stercoralis and may play a role in L3i development, there are significant differences between the two species. Understanding the mechanisms governing L3i development may lead to novel treatment and control strategies.
This study investigated the effects of bacterial genotoxins, specifically Cytolethal Distending Toxin (CDT) and colibactin, on nuclear remodeling in the context of cell survival. The researchers used a combination of in vitro and in vivo models, including Helicobacter-infected mice, coculture experiments, and xenograft mouse-derived models. The results showed that CDT and colibactin induced the formation of deep cytoplasmic invaginations in the nucleus of giant cells, which correspond to nucleoplasmic reticulum (NR). The core of the NR was found to concentrate ribosomes, proteins involved in mRNA translation, polyadenylated RNA, and the main components of the mCRD complex involved in mRNA turnover. These structures are active sites of mRNA translation, correlated with a high degree of ploidy, and involve MAPK and calcium signaling. The formation of these structures is dynamic, transient, and protects the cell until the genotoxic stress is relieved. The study suggests that bacterial genotoxins-induced NR may serve as a privileged gateway for selected mRNA to be transported and translated within the nucleus. The findings provide new insights into the context of NR formation, a common feature of many cancers, which can occur in response to genotoxic bacteria and may contribute to the resistance of cancer cells to radiotherapies and some chemotherapies.
This study aimed to evaluate maxillary bone deformation in patients with leprosy using three-dimensional computed tomography (3D-CT). Ten former patients with leprosy and five control subjects underwent 3D-CT scans, and three-dimensional images centered on the maxilla were reconstructed using multiplanar reconstruction methods. The anterior-posterior length of the maxilla (MA-P) was measured, and the difference between the MA-P of patients and controls was evaluated after compensating for individual skull size. The results showed that three former patients with lepromatous leprosy exhibited marked atrophy of the maxilla at the prosthion, which corresponded with the visual appearance of the maxillary deformity. These findings were consistent with paleopathological studies of excavated skeletal remains. Additionally, the precise bone defects of the maxilla could be individually calculated for accurate reconstructive surgery. The study also confirmed the maxillary regression described in paleopathological studies. The use of 3D-CT enabled the evaluation of maxillary bone deformities both qualitatively and quantitatively, providing a promising tool for the quantitative evaluation of maxillary deformities associated with leprosy and other maxillary lesions. This approach may contribute to novel surgical treatments for facial deformity and eliminate social segregation and prejudice attributed to leprosy.
The study investigated how the auditory system constructs noise-invariant representations of sound in the presence of background noise. To address this challenge, the researchers measured neuronal responses to complex sounds embedded in stationary noise in the inferior colliculus and primary fields of the auditory cortex of anaesthetized ferrets. The results show that the strength of adaptation to the mean and contrast of auditory stimulation increases as one ascends the auditory pathway, from the auditory nerve to the midbrain to the cortex. This suggests that adaptation to stimulus statistics is a neural mechanism that drives the construction of noise-tolerant representations of sound. The study used a decoding approach to assess the noise tolerance of the neuronal population code and found that the code for complex sounds in the periphery is affected more by the addition of noise than the cortical code. Furthermore, noise tolerance is correlated with adaptation to stimulus statistics, indicating that populations that show the strongest adaptation to stimulus statistics are also the most noise-tolerant. The findings suggest that the increase in adaptation to sound statistics from the auditory nerve to the midbrain to the cortex is an important stage in the construction of noise-invariant sound representations in the higher auditory brain. Overall, the study provides evidence for the role of adaptation to stimulus statistics in enabling the auditory system to represent sounds in a noise-invariant fashion.
The study investigated the effects of heat shock on the protein-protein interaction network (interactome) of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a well-characterized model organism. The researchers used a systems-level approach to analyze the changes in the interactome topology upon heat shock. They calculated the interaction weights of the yeast interactome from mRNA expression levels and found that heat shock induced a significant decrease in both the overlaps and connections of yeast interactome modules. This resulted in a 4.9-fold increase in the weighted diameter of the yeast interactome. The study identified several key proteins of the heat shock response that became centers of local communities and bridges providing residual connections between modules after heat shock. The changes in the interactome structure were likened to a'stratus-cumulus' transition, with the unstressed interactome having a globally connected organization and the heat-shocked interactome having a multifocal organization. The results suggest that heat shock induces a partial disintegration of the global organization of the yeast interactome, which may be a general adaptation mechanism to environmental changes. The study also found that other complex systems, such as single proteins, social networks, and ecosystems, may exhibit similar changes in response to stress, leading to a partial disintegration of their global structure.
A systematic review and individual patient data meta-analysis was conducted to assess the efficacy and safety of amiodarone in patients with Chagas disease and ventricular arrhythmias. The review included 9 studies ( 3 before-after studies, 5 case series, and 1 randomized controlled trial ), with 2 studies providing individual patient data for analysis. The results showed that amiodarone significantly reduced the number of ventricular tachycardia episodes ( 99.9%, 95% CI 99.8-100% ), ventricular premature beats ( 93.1%, 95% CI 82-97.4% ), and the incidence of ventricular couplets ( 79%, RR 0.21, 95% CI 0.11-0.39 ) in 24-hour Holter recordings. The pooled incidence of adverse side effects associated with amiodarone use included corneal microdeposits ( 61.1%, 95% CI 19.0-91.3 ), gastrointestinal events ( 16.1%, 95% CI 6.6-34.2 ), sinus bradycardia ( 12.7%, 95% CI 3.7-35.5 ), dermatological events ( 10.6%, 95% CI 4.8-21.9 ), and drug discontinuation ( 7.7%, 95% CI 4.2-13.7 ). The quality of evidence ranged from moderate to very low. The findings suggest that amiodarone is effective in reducing ventricular arrhythmias in patients with Chagas disease, but there is no direct evidence for its effect on hard endpoints such as sudden death or hospitalization.
The study examined the seasonal patterns of dengue fever in rural Ecuador from 2009 to 2016 using medical record data from two hospitals. A Poisson generalized linear model was used to determine short- and long-term seasonal patterns, as well as the effect of day of the week and public holidays on dengue fever diagnoses. The results showed that dengue fever cases were more likely to be diagnosed on Tuesdays and Thursdays, and less likely to be diagnosed on Saturdays and Sundays. Public holidays were not significant predictors of dengue fever diagnoses, except for an increase in diagnoses on the day after Christmas. School schedules did not impact dengue diagnoses in school-aged children. A separate model examining the effect of climate on diagnosis patterns found that monthly total precipitation, an interaction between total precipitation and monthly absolute minimum temperature, an interaction between total precipitation and monthly precipitation days, and a three-way interaction between minimum temperature, total precipitation, and precipitation days were significant predictors of dengue fever diagnoses. This study provides the first report of long-term dengue fever seasonality in Ecuador and highlights the importance of considering both climatic and non-climatic factors in understanding dengue fever trends. The results can inform local disease prevention efforts, public health planning, and global and regional models of dengue fever trends.
Transgenic expression of a picornavirus RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) in mice has been shown to profoundly reconfigure mammalian innate antiviral immunity by exposing the normally membrane-sequestered RdRP activity to sustained innate immune detection. This results in a life-long, quantitatively dramatic upregulation of 80 interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) and confers profound resistance to normally lethal viral challenge. The mechanism operates via MDA5 and MAVS and is fully independent of the adaptive immune system. Human cell models recapitulated the key features, with the RdRP inducing an analogous ISG network and a strict block to HIV-1 infection. The RdRP-mediated antiviral mechanism does not depend on secondary structure within the RdRP mRNA but operates at the protein level and requires RdRP catalysis. Importantly, despite lifelong massive ISG elevations, RdRP mice are entirely healthy, with normal longevity. The results demonstrate that a powerfully augmented MDA5-mediated activation state can be a well-tolerated mammalian innate immune system configuration. The study provides a foundation for augmenting innate immunity to achieve broad-spectrum antiviral protection. RdRP mice possess a maximally upregulated innate immune transcriptome, capable of effecting a robust antiviral response, which far exceeds the innate immune gene inductions produced by virus infection itself. The resulting activation of cell-intrinsic innate immunity culminates in production of type I interferons and activation of a large class of potent antiviral factors, collectively termed ISGs.
The effective population size (Ne) of a plant RNA virus determines the strength of genetic drift and the frequency of co-infection by multiple genotypes. However, experimental estimates of Ne for different plant viruses have yielded diverging results. The independent action hypothesis (IAH) proposes that each virion has a probability of infection and acts independently of other virions during the infection process. A corollary of IAH is that Ne must be dose-dependent. This study tested the IAH infection model using Tobacco etch virus (TEV) variants carrying fluorescent markers in Nicotiana tabacum and Capsicum annuum plants. The results showed that the number of primary infection foci increased linearly with dose and followed a Poisson distribution. At high doses, primary infection foci containing both genotypes were found at a low frequency. The probability of a genotype infecting the inoculated leaf and systemically infecting the plant was near 1. The frequency of mixed-genotype infection could be predicted from the mean number of primary infection foci using the independent-action model. The study found that independent action holds for TEV, and Ne is therefore dose-dependent for this plant RNA virus. The mean number of virions causing systemic infection can be very small, approaching 1 at low doses. Dose-dependency in TEV suggests that comparison of Ne estimates for different viruses may not be meaningful unless dose effects are taken into consideration.
The study presents a new approach to understanding the genetic control of gene expression using a Bayesian multi-tissue method. Traditional expression quantitative trait locus ( eQTL ) studies have been conducted in single tissues or cell types, ignoring shared information across tissues. The authors propose a Sparse Bayesian Regression model for mapping eQTLs within individual tissues and simultaneously across tissues. This approach was tested on 2, 000 genes in four tissues and demonstrated increased power in revealing the complexity of the eQTL landscape compared to traditional methods. The study identified a two-eQTL model for the Hopx gene that was experimentally validated and not detected by conventional approaches. Additionally, the authors found common genetic regulation of gene expression across four tissues for approximately 27% of transcripts, resulting in a >5-fold increase in eQTL detection compared to single-tissue analyses at a 5% false discovery rate ( FDR ) level. The proposed method provides a new opportunity to uncover complex genetic regulatory mechanisms controlling global gene expression and has broad application to analysis of multiple intermediate and whole-body phenotypes. The approach is adaptable to other model systems and humans, making it a valuable tool for understanding the genetic control of gene expression. The study also highlights the power of the method in identifying polygenic regulation of gene expression and secondary trans-eQTLs.
A mathematical model of the extrinsic apoptosis pathway has been developed to understand the variable-delay, snap-action switch that controls cell death in response to tumor necrosis factor (TNF) or TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL). The model is based on a mass-action representation of known reaction pathways and was trained against experimental data from live-cell imaging, flow cytometry, and immunoblotting of cells perturbed by protein depletion and overexpression. The model accurately reproduces the behavior of normal and perturbed cells exposed to TRAIL, allowing for the study of switching mechanisms in detail. Analysis of the model shows that the duration of the delay prior to effector caspase activation is determined by initiator caspase-8 activity and the rates of other reactions downstream of the TRAIL receptor. Sudden activation of effector caspases is achieved through reactions involved in mitochondrial membrane permeabilization and relocalization of proteins such as Smac. The pattern of interactions among Bcl-2 family members, the partitioning of Smac from its binding partner XIAP, and the mechanics of pore assembly are critical for snap-action control. The model suggests that the dynamics of initiator caspase and effector caspase substrate cleavage are key to understanding where in the extrinsic apoptosis pathway a steady increase in caspase-8 activity is converted into a snap-action downstream signal.
The Listeria monocytogenes protein Internalin P (InlP) plays a critical role in the bacterium's ability to infect the placenta during pregnancy. InlP is a secreted virulence factor that interacts with the human protein afadin, which is associated with cell-cell junctions. The interaction between InlP and afadin enhances the ability of Listeria monocytogenes to cross the basal face of polarized epithelial monolayers, a process known as transcytosis. This process is necessary for the bacterium to cross the basement membrane and infect the fetus. The crystal structure of InlP reveals an extended leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain with a distinctive Ca2+-binding site, which is essential for its interaction with afadin. Listeria monocytogenes mutants lacking InlP (ΔinlP) or expressing an internal in-frame deletion in InlP (inlP ΔLRR5) that disrupts its interaction with afadin are deficient in their ability to form actin-rich protrusions from the basal face of polarized epithelial monolayers, a necessary step in transcytosis. In contrast, afadin deletion in host cells does not rescue the transcytosis defect. These findings suggest that InlP targets cytosolic afadin to specifically promote Listeria monocytogenes transcytosis across the basal face of epithelial monolayers, which may contribute to the crossing of the basement membrane during placental infection. The interaction between InlP and afadin may play a key role in the pathogenesis of placental infections caused by Listeria monocytogenes.
The study characterizes the proteome of Treponema pallidum ssp. pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis, using complementary mass spectrometry techniques. A total of 6033 peptides were detected, corresponding to 557 unique proteins, representing 54% of the predicted proteome. This is the most comprehensive description of the global T. pallidum proteome to date. The detected proteins were characterized according to their predicted biological function and localization, with half allocated into a wide range of functional categories. A total of 116 potential membrane proteins were identified, of which 16 have evidence supporting outer membrane localization. The study also found 8/12 proteins related to the paralogous tpr gene family. Protein abundance was semi-quantified using label-free spectral counting methods, revealing a low correlation with previous microarray signal data. The study provides valuable insights into in vivo T. pallidum protein expression, paving the way for improved understanding of the pathogenicity of this enigmatic organism. The detected proteins include 106 previously uncharacterized or hypothetical proteins, which is the first account of these proteins at the protein level. The study used multidimensional peptide separation and protein identification via matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time of flight (MALDI-TOF/TOF) and electrospray ionization (ESI-LTQ-Orbitrap) tandem mass spectrometry to analyze T. pallidum ssp. pallidum DAL-1 strain bacteria isolated from rabbits.
The study investigated the conformational dynamics of the tandem cAMP-binding domains (CBD-A and -B) within the regulatory subunit of Protein Kinase A (PKA) RIα. Using Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, the researchers analyzed the two-domain construct RIα (91–379) in its apo, cAMP2, and C-bound forms. The results support a "double conformational selection" model for the cAMP-dependent activation of PKA RIα. In the absence of cAMP, the PKA-RIα region spanning the two CBDs samples four states, populating a nearly degenerate free-energy landscape, where each CBD accesses both C-binding competent and cAMP-binding incompetent conformations with comparable populations. The binding of cAMP eliminates this degeneracy, selectively stabilizing the active conformation within each CBD and inter-CBD contacts, which require both cAMP and W260. The inter-CBD interface is dispensable for intra-CBD conformational selection but is indispensable for full activation of PKA, as it occludes C-subunit recognition sites within CBD-A. The two structurally homologous cAMP-bound CBDs exhibit marked differences in their residual dynamics profiles, suggesting that conservation of structure does not necessarily imply conservation of dynamics. The study highlights the importance of CBD-B dynamics in modulating the control exerted by CBD-A and provides insights into the cAMP-dependent activation mechanism of PKA RIα.
The study investigated the role of interferon-stimulated gene 15 (ISG15) in regulating mitochondrial function in macrophages following vaccinia virus (VACV) infection. ISG15 is a protein induced by interferon and plays a crucial role in antiviral immunity. The researchers compared the proteomes of ISG15-deficient (ISG15-/-) and ISG15-sufficient (ISG15+/+) bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDM) after VACV infection. The results showed that mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) were altered in ISG15-/- BMDM treated with interferon (IFN). Specifically, mitochondrial respiration, adenosine triphosphate (ATP) production, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production were higher in ISG15+/+ BMDM than in ISG15-/- BMDM following IFN treatment. The study also found that ISG15 depletion led to a significant change in macrophage polarization, with ISG15-/- macrophages showing a pro-inflammatory cytokine expression pattern typical of an M1 phenotype, but with a blockade of nitric oxide (NO) production and arginase-1 activation. In contrast, ISG15+/+ macrophages showed higher NO release and a decrease in viral titer following IFN treatment. The results suggest that ISG15 governs the dynamic functionality of mitochondria, specifically OXPHOS and mitophagy, and plays a critical role in antiviral immunity. The study highlights the importance of ISG15 in regulating mitochondrial function and macrophage polarization in response to viral infection.
The HIV-1 viral protein U (Vpu) plays a crucial role in the replication of the virus by degrading its cellular receptor CD4 and enhancing viral particle release. Vpu binds CD4 and recruits the βTrCP subunit of the SCFβTrCP ubiquitin ligase complex through its constitutively phosphorylated DS52GXXS56 motif. However, Vpu escapes degradation while inhibiting the degradation of βTrCP natural targets such as β-catenin and IκBα. A novel phosphorylation site in Vpu, serine 61, was identified as the triggering event for Vpu degradation by a βTrCP-independent process. This phosphorylation event occurs especially in cells arrested in early mitosis. Mutation of Vpu S61 in the HIV-1 provirus extends the half-life of the protein and significantly increases the release of HIV-1 particles from HeLa cells. The S61 determinant of regulated Vpu turnover is highly conserved within HIV-1 isolates, suggesting a role in overall HIV-1 fitness. The results highlight a mechanism where differential phosphorylation of Vpu determines its fate as an adaptor or as a substrate of distinct ubiquitin ligases. The conservation of the Vpu degradation determinant, despite its negative effect on virion release, implies a selective advantage for the virus. The study provides new insights into the regulation of Vpu and its role in HIV-1 replication.
The coordination of tissue patterning with whole-body development is crucial for generating robustness against environmental and physiological perturbations during development. To investigate this coordination, researchers developed a staging scheme for the wing imaginal discs of Drosophila larvae based on the expression of canonical patterning genes. This scheme was linked to three whole-body developmental events: moulting, larval wandering, and pupariation. The study found that the expression pattern in the wing disc always aligned at moulting and pupariation, indicating that these events represent developmental milestones. In contrast, the progression of pattern between these milestones showed greater variability in response to changes in temperature and alterations in physiology. Specifically, discs from wandering larvae exhibited greater variability in patterning stage, suggesting that wandering does not act as a developmental milestone for wing disc patterning. Furthermore, the study revealed that tissue patterning remains robust against environmental and physiological perturbations by aligning at developmental milestones. The findings provide new insights into how the development of individual tissues is coordinated with the body as a whole and highlight the importance of developmental milestones in ensuring the robustness of the adult phenotype. Overall, the study demonstrates that the progression of pattern in the wing disc is more plastic than previously thought, and that developmental milestones play a critical role in coordinating tissue patterning with whole-body development.
The ESCRT regulator Did2 plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance between long-distance endosomal transport and endocytic trafficking in highly polarized cells, such as fungal hyphae. Early endosomes in these cells function in both endocytosis and long-distance transport of various cargo, including mRNA and protein complexes. However, the crosstalk between these trafficking processes is not well understood. This study demonstrates that Did2 coordinates endosomal transport in Ustilago maydis fungal hyphae by regulating endosomal maturation and membrane identity. Loss of Did2 results in defective vacuolar targeting, reduced processive long-distance transport, and abnormal shuttling of early endosomes. The late endosomal protein Rab7 and vacuolar protease Prc1 exhibit increased shuttling on these aberrant endosomes, suggesting defects in endosomal maturation and identity. Molecular motors fail to attach efficiently, explaining the disturbed processive movement. Furthermore, the endosomal mRNP linker protein Upa1 is hardly present on endosomes, resulting in defects in long-distance mRNA transport. The study reveals that Did2 is essential for the precise maturation of endosomes and provides the correct membrane identity for efficient endosomal long-distance transport. The findings highlight the importance of the ESCRT regulator Did2 in maintaining the balance between endocytic trafficking and long-distance transport in highly polarized cells.
A comparative study of adenine riboswitches in Bacillus subtilis and Vibrio vulnificus has revealed distinct differences in their regulatory mechanisms. While both riboswitches bind adenine, they control gene expression at different levels: transcriptionally in B. subtilis and translationally in V. vulnificus. The study found that the B. subtilis pbuE riboswitch requires co-transcriptional binding of adenine to function, whereas the V. vulnificus add riboswitch can bind adenine post-transcriptionally and still regulate translation. The rate of transcription is critical for the B. subtilis pbuE riboswitch to perform efficiently, suggesting a co-transcriptional regulation mechanism. In contrast, the V. vulnificus add riboswitch operates under a thermodynamic model, where ligand binding and regulation can occur post-transcriptionally without the need for transcription-translation coupling. The study also demonstrated that the V. vulnificus add riboswitch can regulate translation even when transcription and translation are uncoupled, and that the riboswitch conformations are responsible for adenine-dependent modulation of translation. Overall, the results suggest that the nature of gene regulation control, whether transcriptional or translational, plays a crucial role in riboswitch regulatory mechanisms.
The study reveals a conserved pattern of primer-dependent transcription initiation (PDI) in Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Vibrio cholerae, a pathogenic bacterium. PDI involves the use of a 2- to 4-nt oligoribonucleotide primer to initiate transcription, which has been shown to be prevalent at promoters of genes expressed during the stationary phase of growth in E. coli. The study establishes a physiological role for PDI in E. coli as a regulatory mechanism that modulates biofilm formation. Using high-throughput sequencing of RNA 5' ends (5' RNA-seq), the study demonstrates that PDI occurs in V. cholerae and reveals a striking similarity in the pattern of PDI between the two organisms. PDI is detected in stationary phase, not in exponential phase, and is preferentially apparent at promoters carrying the sequence T-1A+1 or G-1G+1. The study proposes that PDI in both E. coli and V. cholerae occurs through a growth phase-dependent process that leads to the preferential generation of the linear dinucleotides 5'-UA-3' and 5'-GG-3'. The findings suggest that PDI may be widespread among Gammaproteobacteria and propose a model in which the extent of PDI relative to de novo initiation fluctuates as a function of growth state.
This study investigated the effect of parental genome dosage imbalance on the expression of imprinted genes in Arabidopsis. In mammals and plants, parental genome dosage imbalance has been shown to deregulate embryo growth and may contribute to reproductive isolation between emerging new species. Imprinted genes, which are expressed by a single parental allele, have been proposed to play a key role in this process. The parental conflict theory suggests that parental genome imbalances are directly mirrored by antagonistic regulations of imprinted genes encoding maternal growth inhibitors and paternal growth enhancers. However, this hypothesis has not been directly tested. This study examined the expression of four imprinted genes in Arabidopsis: FERTILIZATION INDEPENDENT SEED2 (FIS2), FLOWERING WAGENINGEN (FWA), MEDEA (MEA), and PHERES1 (PHE1). The results showed that genome dosage imbalance deregulated the expression of FIS2 and PHE1 in an antagonistic manner. Increased dosage of inactive alleles caused a loss of imprinting of FIS2 and MEA. The changes in PHE1 and MEA expression could not be fully accounted for by the corresponding fluctuations of FIS2 expression. These findings suggest that parental genome dosage imbalance deregulates imprinting using mechanisms independent of known regulators of imprinting. The complexity of the network of regulations between expressed and silenced alleles of imprinted genes activated in response to parental dosage imbalance does not support simple models derived from the parental conflict hypothesis.
Biomedical research has made significant progress in understanding the biophysical mechanisms underlying brain rhythms and neuronal synchronization. However, the functional role of these oscillations remains unclear. This study investigates the functional aspects of oscillatory brain dynamics by reverse-engineering network architectures that generate characteristic brain rhythms. The researchers used mathematical techniques to construct abstract networks, or “virtual brains”, whose dynamics are similar to EEG and MEG recordings. These virtual brains display similar topological features and dynamics as actual brains, including spindles and sharp waves. The study also reconstructed putative diseased brains, such as those with epilepsy and schizophrenia, and found consistent alterations in functional connectivity and dynamics. The complexity of the network, as quantified by Tononi, Sporns, and Edelman, was found to be a good indicator of brain fitness, with diseased brains displaying lower complexity than normal brains. The results suggest that the power spectrum of neural recordings conveys significant information about the functional connectivity of the brain. The study provides new insights into the neurobiology of health and disease, and has implications for understanding the functional role of brain rhythms.
The Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) provides a comprehensive analysis of the population structure of Hispanics in the United States. A total of 1,374 unrelated Hispanic individuals from Central America, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and South America were included in the study. Using 60,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) selected for minimal linkage disequilibrium, the researchers performed population structure analysis and identified four distinct subgroups of the MESA Hispanic cohort. These subgroups correspond to primarily Central/South America, the Dominican Republic and Cuba, Mexico, and Puerto Rico, showing close agreement with self-identification. The analysis also revealed that the first two principal components (PCs) of ancestry quantify Caucasian, African, and Native American origins, while the third and fourth PCs bring out an axis that aligns with the known South-to-North geographic location of Human Genome Diversity Panel (HGDP) Native American samples.
