To demonstrate the importance of considering population substructure and genetic heterogeneity in genetic association studies, the researchers performed pooled and stratified association analysis of triglycerides for selected SNPs in the LPL and TRIB1 gene regions, previously reported in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) of Caucasians but unconfirmed in Hispanic populations. The results show statistically significant evidence for genetic association in both genes, highlighting the need for careful consideration of population substructure in genetic analysis of Hispanic cohorts.
The Elongator complex, a six-subunit histone acetyltransferase, interacts with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) and plays a crucial role in transcriptional silencing and genome stability. Deletion of Elp3, the catalytic subunit of the Elongator complex, results in partial loss of silencing of reporter genes at the chromosome VIIL telomere and the HMR locus, and increased sensitivity to DNA replication inhibitor hydroxyurea (HU) and DNA damaging agent methyl methanesulfonate (MMS). Mutations in Elp3 that compromise the formation of the Elongator complex also lead to loss of silencing and increased HU sensitivity. Furthermore, Elp3 is required for S-phase progression in the presence of HU. Epistasis analysis reveals that the elp3Δ mutant exacerbates the MMS sensitivity of cells lacking histone chaperones Asf1, CAF-1, and the H3 lysine 56 acetyltransferase Rtt109. PCNA binds to the Elongator complex both in vivo and in vitro, indicating a novel role for the intact Elongator complex in transcriptional silencing and genome stability linked to the DNA replication and DNA repair protein PCNA. The results suggest that the Elongator complex functions in multiple cellular processes, including DNA replication-coupled nucleosome assembly, and that its interaction with PCNA is essential for maintaining genome stability.
A machine-learning assisted triage method has been proposed to improve the efficiency of biomedical literature curation in genomic variation resources. The method uses deep learning models based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to classify and rank new publications for curation. The models were trained on previously curated publications from UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot and the NHGRI-EBI GWAS Catalog, which served as a gold-standard dataset. The trained models were then applied to the real-world manual curation process of UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot and the GWAS Catalog. The results showed that the machine-assisted triage method outperformed the current query-based triage methods, achieving a precision 1.81 and 2.99 times higher than that obtained by the current query-based triage methods of UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot and the GWAS Catalog, respectively, without compromising recall. The method also retrieved many additional relevant publications that the query-based method of UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot could not find. The study demonstrated that the machine learning-based method can make the triage process more efficient and is being implemented in production, allowing human curators to focus on more challenging tasks to improve the quality of knowledge bases. The method was evaluated on three different datasets, including UniProtKB/Swiss-Prot, the GWAS Catalog, and mycoSet, and achieved high performance on all datasets.
Atrial arrhythmogenicity of KCNJ2 mutations in short QT syndrome was investigated using biophysically-detailed human atria computer models. Gain-of-function mutations in KCNJ2-encoded Kir2. 1 channels underlie variant 3 ( SQT3 ) of the short QT syndrome, which is associated with atrial fibrillation ( AF ). A contemporary model of the human atrial action potential ( AP ) was modified to recapitulate functional changes in IK1 due to heterozygous and homozygous forms of the D172N and E299V Kir2. 1 mutations. The effects of mutations on AP duration ( APD ), conduction velocity ( CV ), effective refractory period ( ERP ), tissue excitation threshold and their rate-dependence, as well as the wavelength of re-entry ( WL ) were quantified. The D172N and E299V Kir2. 1 mutations produced distinct effects on IK1 and APD shortening. Both mutations decreased WL for re-entry through a reduction in ERP and CV. Stability of re-entrant excitation waves in 2D and 3D tissue models was mediated by changes to tissue excitability and dispersion of APD in mutation conditions. Combined block of IK1 and IKr was effective in terminating re-entry associated with heterozygous D172N conditions, whereas IKr block alone may be a safer alternative for the E299V mutation. Combined inhibition of IKr and IKur produced a synergistic anti-arrhythmic effect in both forms of SQT3. This study provides mechanistic insights into atrial proarrhythmia with SQT3 Kir2. 1 mutations and highlights possible pharmacological strategies for management of SQT3-linked AF.
Adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ASC) were investigated for their potential to alter the course of Chagas disease, a complex disease caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, in a mouse model of chagasic cardiomyopathy. ASC were injected intraperitoneally at 3 days post-infection and tracked by bioluminescence, showing that they remained in the abdominal cavity for up to 9 days and migrated to the abdominal or subcutaneous fat, an early parasite reservoir. ASC injection resulted in a significant reduction in blood parasitemia, followed by a decrease in cardiac tissue inflammation, parasitism, and fibrosis at 30 days post-infection. Analyses of cytokine release in cells isolated from the heart and exposed to T. cruzi antigens indicated an anti-inflammatory response in ASC-treated animals. In contrast, splenocytes exposed to the same antigens produced a pro-inflammatory response in both placebo and ASC-treated groups, but splenocytes from the ASC group released higher levels of IL-10. At 60 days post-infection, magnetic resonance imaging revealed that right ventricular dilation was prevented in ASC-treated mice. The results suggest that the injection of ASC early after T. cruzi infection prevents right ventricular remodeling through the modulation of immune responses, promoting the control of parasite burden and protecting the heart from damage.
The study investigated the efficacy of structurally optimized analogs of Retro-2cycl, a retrograde trafficking inhibitor, in limiting Leishmania infections. The analogs, DHQZ 36 and DHQZ 36.1, were previously reported to have superior potency in inhibiting retrograde pathway-dependent phenomena. The results showed that these analogs were more effective than the parent compound, Retro-2cycl, in controlling Leishmania infections in macrophages, with EC50 values of 13.63+/-2.58μM and 10.57+/-2.66μM, respectively, compared to 40.15μM for Retro-2cycl. Additionally, the analogs caused a reversal in Leishmania-induced suppression of IL-6 release by infected cells after LPS activation. Furthermore, unlike Retro-2cycl, which is Leishmania-static, the analogs can kill Leishmania parasites in axenic cultures. This is a desirable attribute for any drug to treat Leishmania infections. The study validates and extends the published structure-activity relationship analyses of Retro-2cycl. The results suggest that the essential retrograde trafficking pathway is more sensitive in Leishmania, and the analogs are more efficacious than Retro-2cycl in suppressing Leishmania infections. These findings have implications for the development of new treatments for Leishmaniasis.
Title: Nucleosome Presence at AML-1 Binding Sites Inversely Correlates with Ly49 Expression: Revelations from an Informatics Analysis of Nucleosomes and Immune Cell Transcription Factors

    A computational method was developed to evaluate the nucleosome sensitivity of transcription factors over a given stretch of the genome. Using this method, the Acute Myeloid Leukemia-1a (AML-1a) transcription factor was identified as potentially sensitive to nucleosomal regulation within the mouse Ly49 gene family. AML-1a is a regulator of immune gene expression, and its binding sites were found to be preferentially depleted of nucleosomes in expressed Ly49 genes compared to silent Ly49 genes. This suggests that nucleosome-based regulation contributes to the expression of Ly49 genes.

    A whole-chromosome analysis of nucleosome-transcription factor interactions revealed that many other transcription factors display nucleosome coverage and lack of 10 bp periodicity, indicating potential nucleosome sensitivity. This was confirmed in a cell line where expressed Ly49 genes showed preferential nucleosome depletion specifically at AML-1a binding sites compared to inactive Ly49 genes. The study also found that AML-1a sites are preferentially depleted of nucleosomes throughout the promoter/enhancer regions of expressed Ly49 genes when compared to unexpressed genes within the same population, implicating nucleosome positioning as a possible mechanism to affect Ly49 expression in vivo. These findings suggest that nucleosome sensitivity is a selected trait for Ly49 regulation and propose that this method of predicting nucleosome sensitivity could aid in dissecting the regulatory role of nucleosomes in general.
The study investigated the role of CDK7 in the activation of CDK4 and CDK2, two key regulators of the cell cycle. CDK7 is a cyclin-dependent kinase-activating kinase (CAK) that phosphorylates the T-loop of CDK2 and CDK1, but its role in CDK4 activation was unclear. The researchers used a chemical-genetics approach to inhibit CDK7 in HCT116 cells and found that CDK7 inhibition prevented the activating phosphorylation of CDK4 and CDK6. However, this effect was partly dependent on the binding of p21cip1 to CDK4. The study also identified a novel CDK7-dependent positive feedback loop mediated by p21 phosphorylation by CDK4 and CDK2, which sustains CDK4 activation, pRb inactivation, and restriction point passage. The results suggest that CDK7 plays a crucial but indirect role in the activation of CDK4 and CDK6, and that there are CDK4-activating kinases other than CDK7. Furthermore, the study found that CDK4 and CDK6 can phosphorylate p21, which is complexed with D-type cyclins and CDK4, and that this phosphorylation is inhibited by CDK7 inhibition. The study provides new insights into the regulation of CDK4 and CDK6 and highlights the importance of CDK7 in cell cycle progression.
The chromatin protein DUET/MMD1 plays a crucial role in regulating the expression of the meiotic gene TDM1 during male meiosis in Arabidopsis. DUET/MMD1 is a PHD finger protein essential for Arabidopsis male meiosis and functions as a transcriptional regulator. The protein binds to H3K4me2 in vitro and this interaction is critical for its function during meiosis. DUET/MMD1 is required for proper microtubule organization during meiosis II, independently of its function in meiosis I. The protein shows stage-specific expression, confined to the diplotene stage of prophase I. Two genes, TDM1 and JAS, which are critical for cell cycle transitions and spindle organization in male meiosis, are identified as targets of DUET/MMD1, with TDM1 being a direct target. Expression profiling revealed reduced expression of a subset of meiosis-preferred genes in the duet mutant. The results suggest that DUET/MMD1 regulates microtubule organization and cell cycle transitions during male meiosis and functions as a direct transcriptional activator of the meiotic gene TDM1. The study reveals the action of DUET/MMD1 as a transcriptional regulator during male meiosis in plants and suggests that transcription of meiotic genes is under stage-wise control in plants, similar to yeast. The findings also suggest a developmental function for H3K4me2 in Arabidopsis male reproduction.
Fragile X–associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by Fragile X premutation rCGG repeats. Previous studies have shown that rCGG repeats can cause neurodegeneration and that proteins such as Pur α and hnRNP A2/B1 can modulate rCGG-mediated neuronal toxicity. To further explore the role of Pur α in rCGG-mediated neurodegeneration, researchers identified over 100 proteins that interact with Pur α, including Rm62, the Drosophila ortholog of p68 RNA helicase. Rm62 physically interacts with Pur α and can modulate rCGG-mediated neurodegeneration. Fragile X premutation rCGG repeats decrease the expression of Rm62 posttranscriptionally, leading to the nuclear accumulation of Hsp70 transcript and other mRNAs involved in stress and immune responses. This accumulation is likely due to impaired nuclear export of these mRNAs. The researchers found that the expression of fragile X premutation rCGG repeats significantly reduced the viability of heterozygous Rm62 mutant flies, indicating a strong genetic interaction between Rm62 and rCGG repeat-mediated neuronal cell death. The study suggests that the nuclear accumulation of select mRNAs caused by fragile X premutation rCGG repeats may contribute to FXTAS pathogenesis, potentially through impaired nuclear export due to decreased levels of Rm62. This could interfere with the neurons' ability to produce sufficient proteins to respond to cellular stress.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a bacterium that forms environmentally and clinically relevant biofilms, has been studied to understand the development of its extracellular matrix. The extracellular polymeric substance (EPS) of P. aeruginosa biofilms is a complex mixture of polysaccharides, nucleic acids, and proteins. The Psl exopolysaccharide, encoded by the polysaccharide synthesis locus (PA2231-2245), is a key component of the EPS and plays a crucial role in biofilm formation. During attachment, Psl is anchored on the cell surface in a helical pattern, promoting cell-cell interactions and the assembly of a matrix that holds bacteria in the biofilm and on the surface. Chemical dissociation of Psl from the bacterial surface disrupts the Psl matrix and the biofilm structure. During biofilm maturation, Psl accumulates on the periphery of 3-D-structured microcolonies, resulting in a Psl matrix-free cavity in the microcolony center. At the dispersion stage, swimming cells appear in this matrix cavity, and dead cells and extracellular DNA (eDNA) are concentrated in the Psl matrix-free area. Deletion of genes that control cell death and autolysis affects the formation of the matrix cavity and microcolony dispersion. These findings provide a mechanism for how P. aeruginosa builds a matrix and a cavity to free a portion of cells for seeding dispersal. The study highlights the importance of Psl as a key scaffolding matrix component and opens up avenues for therapeutics of biofilm-related complications.
This study aimed to investigate the concordance between primary pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) tumours, patient-derived xenografts (PDX), and patient-derived organoids (PDO) at the whole-genome level. The researchers conducted a comprehensive analysis of 16 whole-genome pairs of tumours and matched PDX from primary PDAC and liver metastasis, including a unique cohort of 5 ‘trios’ of matched primary tumour, PDX, and PDO. A pipeline was developed to score concordance between PDAC models and their paired human tumours for genomic events, including mutations, structural variations, and copy number variations. The results showed that tumour-model comparisons of mutations displayed single-gene concordance across major PDAC driver genes, but relatively poor agreement across the greater mutational load. Genome-wide and chromosome-centric analysis of structural variation (SV) events highlighted previously unrecognized concordance across chromosomes that demonstrate clustered SV events. However, polyploidy presented a major challenge when assessing copy number changes, and ploidy-corrected copy number states suggest good agreement between donor-model pairs. The study highlights that while PDXs and PDOs may serve as tractable and transplantable systems for probing the molecular properties of PDAC, these models may best serve selective analyses across different levels of genomic complexity. The findings suggest that PDXs and PDOs can recapitulate primary and metastatic disease at the level of simple somatic mutations mainly in driver genes, but not across the greater expanse of annotated mutations.
A genome-wide association study (GWAS) was conducted in 19,091 breast cancer cases and 20,606 controls of East-Asian descent to identify novel genetic susceptibility loci for breast cancer. The study analyzed 690,947 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 2,918 cases and 2,324 controls, followed by replication in 3,972 cases and 3,852 controls, and further evaluation in 5,203 cases and 5,138 controls. The top 22 SNPs were then investigated in an additional 7,489 cases and 9,934 controls. The study identified a novel breast cancer susceptibility locus represented by SNP rs9485372, located near the TGF-β activated kinase (TAB2) gene on chromosome 6q25.1. This SNP showed a consistent association with breast cancer risk across all four stages, with a P-value of 3.8×10−12 in the combined analysis of all samples. Adjusted odds ratios (95% confidence intervals) were 0.89 (0.85-0.94) and 0.80 (0.75-0.86) for the A/G and A/A genotypes, respectively, compared to the G/G genotype. Two other SNPs, rs9383951 and rs7107217, located in the ESR1 gene and 11q24.3, respectively, also showed a consistent association in each of the four stages. These findings provide strong evidence for a novel breast cancer susceptibility locus and identify two possible susceptibility loci for breast cancer in East-Asian women.
A study of 230 Cryptococcus neoformans (Cn) isolates from HIV-positive South African patients with cryptococcal meningitis revealed high levels of genetic diversity and locus variability compared to globally distributed types. The isolates were grouped into 50 sequence types within the main molecular types VNI, VNII, and VNB, with 72% of isolates typed into one of seven 'high frequency' sequence types. Spatial analysis of patients' cryptococcal genotype did not show geographical clustering, suggesting reactivation of latent infection rather than recent local acquisition. The study found a relationship between genetic lineage and clinical outcome, with patients infected with the VNB lineage having significantly worse survival (HR 3.35, CI 1.51-7.20, p=0.003). This association was maintained even after adjustment for known prognostic indicators and treatment regimen. Comparison of fungal genotype with in vitro phenotype revealed evidence of lineage-associated virulence phenotype, with the VNII lineage displaying increased laccase activity (p=0.001) and ex vivo CSF survival (p=0.0001). The findings suggest that Cryptococcus neoformans is a phenotypically heterogeneous pathogen, and that lineage plays an important role in cryptococcal virulence during human infection. The study highlights the need for a detailed understanding of the genetic diversity in Southern Africa to assess the risks different ecotypes pose to infection.
The evolution of new signal transduction pathways in organisms remains poorly understood due to the scarcity of examples of newly evolved pathways. In Candida albicans, a human fungal pathogen, researchers have identified the transcription factor Tec1 as the last component of the newly evolved signal transduction pathway that regulates the pheromone response of the white cell phenotype. This discovery provides a comprehensive description of the pheromone response pathway in the white cell phenotype of C. albicans, offering insights into the evolution of new signal transduction pathways. The pathway appears to have been derived from three different ancestral programs still functional in C. albicans: the upstream portion from the opaque pheromone response pathway of the mating process, Tec1 from a filamentation pathway, and the white-specific downstream target genes from an ancestral biofilm process. The evolution of this pheromone response pathway in C. albicans may serve as a paradigm for how new signal transduction pathways evolve. The white cell pheromone response pathway is unique in that it has had insufficient time to duplicate, replace, or modify components in response to new selective pressures or changing roles, providing a glimpse into the evolution of a new signal transduction pathway.
The genomic GC-content of bacteria varies significantly across different species, ranging from less than 20% to more than 70%. This variation has been attributed to differences in the pattern of mutation between bacteria. To test this hypothesis, the authors examined patterns of synonymous polymorphism in 149 bacterial species from 8 phyla, 15 classes, and 77 genera. They found a large excess of GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations segregating in all but the most AT-rich bacteria, across a broad range of phylogenetically diverse species. This excess of GC→AT mutations is inconsistent with mutation bias, as it would imply that most GC-rich bacteria are declining in GC-content, which is unsustainable. Additionally, the patterns are unlikely due to translational selection or biased gene conversion, as optimal codons tend to be AT-rich and the excess of GC→AT SNPs is observed in datasets with no evidence of recombination. Therefore, the authors conclude that there is selection to increase synonymous GC-content in many species. Since synonymous GC-content is highly correlated with genomic GC-content, they further conclude that there is selection on genomic base composition in many bacteria. The results suggest that GC-rich bacteria have a genuine excess of GC→AT mutations, while the excess of AT→GC mutations in AT-rich species may be due to a violation of the infinite sites assumption.
The study presents a new approach for mapping the observed prevalence of soil-transmitted helminths (STHs) in Kenya using Bayesian space-time geostatistical models. The models were developed using data from 945 cross-sectional surveys conducted between 1974 and 2009, which included 106,370 individuals. The models were used to interpolate the probability that infection prevalence exceeded the 20% threshold across the country for both 1989 and 2009. The results show that in most areas for 2009, there was high certainty that endemicity was below the 20% threshold, with areas of endemicity ≥20% located around the shores of Lake Victoria and on the coast. Comparison of the predicted distributions for 1989 and 2009 indicates a gradual decrease in observed STH prevalence over time. The model estimated that a total of 2.8 million school-age children live in districts that warrant mass treatment. The study suggests that a quarter of Kenya's school-aged children live in areas of high prevalence and warrant mass treatment. Bayesian space-time geostatistical models can be used to reliably estimate the combined observed prevalence of STH and inform decision-making in helminth control. The results of this study can be used to refine decision-making in helminth control as control efforts are successful in reducing infection levels.
Invariant NKT (iNKT) cells play a crucial role in the innate immune response against Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. Research has shown that iNKT cells can recognize Mtb-infected macrophages, produce interferon-γ (IFN-γ), and suppress bacterial replication. This innate control of bacterial replication is dependent on CD1d-restricted iNKT cells, which require CD1d expression by infected macrophages as well as IL-12 and IL-18 for activation. In vitro studies demonstrated that iNKT cells, even in limiting quantities, are sufficient to restrict Mtb replication. Furthermore, adoptive transfer of primary splenic iNKT cells from uninfected mice significantly reduced the bacterial burden in the lungs of mice infected with virulent Mtb by the aerosol route. This suggests that iNKT cells have a direct bactericidal effect, even in the absence of synthetic ligands such as α-galactosylceramide. The study provides the first evidence that CD1d-restricted NKT cells mediate protection against Mtb in vivo. The results indicate that iNKT cells contribute to host defense against tuberculosis by recognizing Mtb-infected macrophages and producing IFN-γ, which activates macrophages to control bacterial replication. The study highlights the importance of iNKT cells in the innate immune response against Mtb infection.
Transglutaminases (TGases) are enzymes that catalyze the formation of covalent bonds between proteins, stabilizing protein assemblies through intra- or intermolecular ε- (γ-glutamyl) lysil cross-links. In the case of Bacillus subtilis endospores, a transglutaminase called Tgl is responsible for cross-linking proteins in the spore coat. Unlike other TGases, Tgl is produced in an active form, raising questions about how its activity is controlled during spore coat assembly. This study investigated the regulation of Tgl activity and found that substrates assembled onto the spore coat prior to Tgl production govern its localization to the surface of the developing spore. The glutamyl (Q) and lysil (K) substrate docking sites on Tgl are crucial for its localization, with residues on the Q side being more important for assembly than those on the K side. The interaction with Q-substrates and formation of an acyl-enzyme intermediate is the determinant step in Tgl localization. Tgl becomes part of the cross-linked products during the reaction, suggesting that it exerts a "spotwelding" activity, cross-linking pre-formed assemblies. The study suggests that the dependency of Tgl on its substrates is used to accurately control the time, location, and extent of its activity, ensuring the covalent fortification of pre-assembled complexes at the surface of the developing spore. This mechanism may also control the activity of Tgl orthologues in other spore-forming bacteria.
A cross-sectional parasitological and questionnaire survey was conducted in 51 villages in Champasack province, southern Lao PDR, to investigate the spatial distribution of Opisthorchis viverrini infection and identify underlying risk factors. The survey collected data on demography, socioeconomic status, water supply, sanitation, and behavior, which were combined with remotely sensed environmental data and fed into a geographical information system. Bayesian geostatistical models were employed to identify risk factors and investigate the spatial pattern of O. viverrini infection. The prevalence of O. viverrini among 3,371 study participants with complete data records was 61.1%. Geostatistical models identified age, Lao Loum ethnic group, educational attainment, occupation (rice farmer, fisherman, and animal breeder), and unsafe drinking water source as risk factors for infection. History of praziquantel treatment, access to sanitation, and distance to freshwater bodies were found to be protective factors. Spatial patterns of O. viverrini were mainly governed by environmental factors, with predictive modeling identifying two different risk profiles: low risk in the mountains and high risk in the Mekong corridor. The study presents the first risk map of O. viverrini infection in Champasack province, which is essential for spatial targeting of control efforts. The findings suggest that infection with O. viverrini is strongly associated with exposure to the second intermediate host fish, human behavior, and culture, while high transmission is sustained by the lack of sanitation.
In Dar es Salaam, the capital city of the United Republic of Tanzania, the presence of Anopheles and Culex larvae in drains poses a significant risk for the transmission of lymphatic filariasis and malaria. A study analyzed data from the Urban Malaria Control Program (UMCP) and a special drain survey conducted in 2006 to determine the importance of drains as larval habitats. The results show that over 70% of larval habitats in Dar es Salaam are human-made, with drains being the most common type, accounting for 42% of all aquatic habitats. Drains with stagnant water were found to have a significantly higher presence of Anopheles and Culex larvae compared to those with flowing water, with odds ratios of 8.8 and 6.3, respectively. The study also found a positive association between vegetation and the presence of mosquito larvae. Spatial analysis revealed that the proportion of habitats with mosquito larvae was spatially correlated. The findings suggest that restoring and maintaining drains in Dar es Salaam has the potential to eliminate over 40% of all potential mosquito larval habitats that are currently treated with larvicides by the UMCP. The study highlights the importance of human-made larval habitats for both lymphatic filariasis and malaria vectors, underscoring the need for a synergy between ongoing control efforts for these diseases.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection up-regulates the activity of HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR), a key enzyme in cholesterol biosynthesis, through the impairment of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) phosphorylation. In DENV-infected cells, HMGCR activity is significantly higher, leading to increased cholesterol levels in the endoplasmic reticulum, which is necessary for the formation and maintenance of DENV replicative complexes. The inactivation of AMPK by DENV infection is responsible for the enhanced activity of HMGCR, as AMPK activation by metformin reduces HMGCR activity. The co-localization of HMGCR with viral proteins NS3, NS4A, and E suggests a role for HMGCR in the formation of DENV replicative complexes. Metformin and lovastatin, an HMGCR inhibitor, alter this co-localization and replicative complexes formation, indicating that active HMGCR is required for replicative complexes formation. Furthermore, metformin exhibits a dose-dependent antiviral effect in DENV-infected cells, while compound C, an AMPK inhibitor, augments viral genome copies and the percentage of infected cells. The results suggest that DENV infection increases HMGCR activity through AMPK inactivation, leading to higher cholesterol levels in the endoplasmic reticulum necessary for replicative complexes formation. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms involved in host lipid metabolism during DENV replication and identify new potential antiviral targets for DENV replication.
The article explores the connection between the kinetics and energy landscape of tRNA translocation on the ribosome using an all-atom molecular dynamics simulation of the 70S ribosome. The study aims to establish a quantitative bridge between state-like kinetic measurements and the continuous energy landscape of the process. By analyzing the dynamics of an explicit-solvent simulation of an intact ribosome, the authors identified collective reaction coordinates that capture essential motions during substrate translocation, including 30S-body rotation, 30S-head swivel, and tRNA displacements. These motions are critical for protein elongation in the cell. The diffusion coefficients along these collective coordinates were used to interconvert between experimental rates and measures of the energy landscape, providing an upper-bound estimate of the free-energy barriers associated with translocation. The analysis suggests that the process of tRNA translocation can be decomposed into a superposition of slow, large-scale collective movements and rapid local fluctuations, with many residues undergoing coordinated displacements reminiscent of rigid body movement. The study provides a unifying framework for understanding and interpreting all available data for tRNA translocation in the ribosome, establishing a connection between kinetic and energetic descriptions of the process. This framework is general and can be applied to energetic and kinetic descriptions that include any number of intermediates and transition states. The findings contribute to our understanding of the ribosome's function as a "thermal ratchet machine," where random energetic fluctuations lead to large-scale diffusive configurational rearrangements.
The genetic landscape of medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) has been explored through the analysis of 84 sporadic MTC samples and 36 paired normal thyroid tissues using the Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Panel v2. The study identified 101 hotspot mutations in 18 genes, with the most common mutation occurring in the ret proto-oncogene in 47 cases. Other frequently mutated genes included Harvey rat sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, serine/threonine kinase 11, v-kit Hardy-Zuckerman 4 feline sarcoma viral oncogene homolog, and MET proto-oncogene. The study also evaluated anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangement by immunohistochemistry and break-apart fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), identifying two cases positive for ALK FISH. Customized targeted cancer panel sequencing revealed ALK fusions with glutamine:fructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GFPT1) and echinoderm microtubule-associated protein-like 4 (EML4). The EML4-ALK fusion was found in a metastatic MTC case that showed a dramatic response to the ALK inhibitor crizotinib. The study suggests that the EML4-ALK fusion may be a potential driver mutation and a valid target for ALK inhibitors. Additionally, the GFPT1-ALK fusion may be a candidate for molecular target therapy. The findings provide new insights into the genetic landscape of MTC and highlight the potential for targeted therapies in this rare malignancy.
In a study conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India, a high prevalence of asymptomatic leishmaniasis was found in a population of 2,603 individuals, with 3.16% (79/2,497) testing positive for antileishmanial antibodies. The ratio of asymptomatic to symptomatic cases was 7.9:1. Among the asymptomatic cases, 10.39% (8/77) progressed to symptomatic visceral leishmaniasis (VL) or post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) over a three-year follow-up period, while 80.52% (62/77) showed sero-conversion. Seven individuals (9.09%) remained seropositive after three years. The study highlights the importance of asymptomatic cases in driving the epidemic and the need for attention in the VL elimination program initiated by three adjoining endemic countries. The findings suggest that asymptomatic individuals can remain seropositive for up to three years and may progress to symptomatic disease at any time during this period. The study also emphasizes that the absence of VL/PKDL cases for two or more years does not necessarily indicate that an area is free from leishmaniasis, as asymptomatic cases can remain undetected and potentially lead to future outbreaks. The results underscore the need for continued surveillance and monitoring of asymptomatic cases to achieve the goal of VL elimination.
The study describes the use of Multiplex Ligation–dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) to analyze genome rearrangements in Saccharomyces cerevisiae caused by the introduction of the repetitive retrotransposon Ty912. The results show that the distribution of translocations induced by Ty912 is nonrandom and that the majority of these translocations are mediated by only six translocation targets on four different chromosomes. These hotspots are composed of Ty elements and are located on the right arm of chromosome III, the right arm of chromosome V, the left arm of chromosome XIV, and the right arm of chromosome X. The study also found that the majority of Ty912-mediated translocations result from RAD52-dependent recombination, but a number of nonreciprocal translocations mediated by RAD52-independent recombination between Ty1 elements were also observed. Furthermore, the study found that defects in ASF1-RTT109-dependent acetylation of histone H3 lysine residue 56 (H3K56) result in increased accumulation of genome rearrangements and whole-chromosome duplications, leading to aneuploidy. The results suggest that MLPA is a versatile technique for the rapid analysis of genome rearrangements and can facilitate the genetic analysis of the pathways that prevent and promote genome rearrangements and aneuploidy. Overall, the study provides new insights into the mechanisms of genome rearrangements and aneuploidy in S. cerevisiae.
A new docking method called Semi-Definite programming-based Underestimation (SDU) has been developed to predict the association of two proteins by minimizing a free energy funnel in the space of rigid body motions (SE(3)) while accounting for flexibility of the interface side chains. The method employs a general quadratic function to underestimate a set of local energy minima and uses the resulting underestimator to bias further sampling. However, the direct application of SDU in the space SE(3) of rotations and translations fails to yield useful underestimators due to the geometry of that space. To address this issue, a strategy is introduced that uses separate independent variables for side-chain optimization, center-to-center distance of the two proteins, and five angular descriptors of the relative orientations of the molecules. This approach vastly improves the efficiency of the search by transforming the five-dimensional space into a well-behaved energy surface suitable for underestimation. The SDU algorithm explores the free energy surface spanned by encounter complexes that correspond to local free energy minima and shows similarity to the model of macromolecular association that proceeds through a series of collisions. Results for standard protein docking benchmarks demonstrate that the free energy landscape is a funnel in a reasonably broad neighborhood of the native state and that the SDU strategy can generate docking predictions with less than 5 Å ligand interface Cα root-mean-square deviation while achieving an approximately 20-fold efficiency gain compared to Monte Carlo methods. The successful application of SDU to protein-protein docking further validates the assumption that the free energy landscape of the complex is a funnel in some neighborhood of the native state.
